For the Hebrew followers of Jesus who first heard this sermon, factors such as rejection <span id="page-44-13"></span><span id="page-44-12"></span><span id="page-44-11"></span>by family (Heb. 13:12–13), public shame (10:32–33), loss of property and freedom (10:34; 13:3), or the threat of martyrdom (12:3–4) may explain why some neglected meeting together (10:25). Such costs of discipleship still confront the global church today. When faced with such challenges, those who see the supreme glory of Christ find courage to follow the suffering footsteps of OT people of faith, "of whom the world was not worthy," anticipating a better resurrection and a better and abiding possession (11:35–38; 10:34).

<span id="page-44-14"></span><span id="page-44-10"></span><span id="page-44-9"></span>Christians in the West enjoy freedom, safety, and tolerance, yet still some may lose interest in God's last, best word, spoken in his Son. Their drift toward spiritual shipwreck may not start with storms of life-shaking crisis. Instead, subtle rip currents—career advancement and financial security, entertainment and recreation, reputation and social acceptance—loosen the line linking them to a "sure and steadfast anchor of the soul" (6:19). Such drift spells eternal ruin. Our preacher has displayed the majesty of the Son in order to guard our hearts against any distraction that would deflect our gaze from him (3:1; 12:1).

#### <span id="page-44-3"></span>OVERVIEW OF

### <span id="page-44-6"></span>HEBREWS 2:5–18

<span id="page-44-5"></span>The OT texts demonstrating the Son's superiority to angels introduced "those who are to inherit salvation" (Heb. 1:14). This "salvation" reappeared in the first exhortation section (2:1–4). From that exhortation the author now launches a further discussion of the Son's relationship to angels (2:5–18). The focus turns to his mission on behalf of his human siblings, who inherit salvation because he became "for a little while . . . lower than the angels" in order to suffer and thereby achieve their salvation (2:9–10).

<span id="page-44-8"></span><span id="page-44-7"></span><span id="page-44-4"></span><span id="page-44-2"></span><span id="page-44-1"></span><span id="page-44-0"></span>As the OT citations on the Son's superiority (1:5–14) were "bookended" by the rhetorical question "*To which of the angels* did he [God] ever say . . ." (1:5, 13), so is this section enveloped by statements that God has extended his grace "*not [to] angels*" but to humans, whom the Son saves (2:5, 16). Psalm 8:4–6, which anchors this section, is explained in terms of its eschatological, anthropological, and Christological implications. Other OT passages are cited (Ps. 22:22; Isa. 8:17, 18) and alluded to (Isa. 41:8–13) in order to elaborate the Son's bond with the "many sons" whom God brings to glory through him (Heb. 2:10).

### <span id="page-45-3"></span>HEBREWS 2:5–9

**<sup>5</sup>**For it was not to angels that God subjected the world to come, of which we are speaking. **<sup>6</sup>** It has been testified somewhere,

"What is man, that you are mindful of him, or the son of man, that you care for him?

- **<sup>7</sup>** You made him for a little while lower than the angels; you have crowned him with glory and honor,*<sup>1</sup>*
- **<sup>8</sup>** putting everything in subjection under his feet."

Now in putting everything in subjection to him, he left nothing outside his control. At present, we do not yet see everything in subjection to him. **<sup>9</sup>**But we see him who for a little while was made lower than the angels, namely Jesus, crowned with glory and honor because of the suffering of death, so that by the grace of God he might taste death for everyone.

1Some manuscripts insert *and set him over the works of your hands*

#### *Section Overview: The Humbled and Glorified Son of Man*

<span id="page-45-4"></span><span id="page-45-2"></span><span id="page-45-1"></span>The mention of "salvation" (Heb. 1:14; 2:3) calls for elaboration. Salvation includes rescue from the Devil—from his power to inflict death and from the enslaving fear of death (2:14–15). But salvation also encompasses a destiny of glory and dominion for human beings. The eternal divine Son humbled himself to become the incarnate messianic Son in order to redeem his "brothers." Our preacher views Psalm 8:4–6 not as a retrospective on a past paradise lost but as a preview of a paradise to come. The psalm traces the course of human history from the present (in which humans are lower than angels) to the future (in which everything will be subjected to humanity). The present does not yet show all other creatures in submission to humans, who bear the divine image (Gen. 1:26–28). Although humanity's royal destiny is not yet visible, one man has traveled the painful route from lowliness to exalted glory. His name is Jesus, and his coronation is his reward for suffering death on behalf of others.

#### <span id="page-45-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. The world to come will be subjected, not to angels, but to the son of man (2:5)
- II. Scripture announced God's purpose to subject all things to the son of man (2:6–8a)
	- A. The son of man is small but is the object of God's special care (2:6)
- B. The son of man is temporarily subordinated to angels (2:7a)
- C. But the son of man is destined for dominion (2:7b–8a)
- III. The son of man's dominion is not yet visible in our experience (2:8bc)
- IV. Nevertheless God's promise to the son of man is now fulfilled in one whom we do see, Jesus (2:9)
	- A. Jesus was temporarily subordinated to angels (2:9a)
	- B. Jesus has been crowned with glory and honor (2:9b)
	- C. His glorification is his reward for suffering death for others (2:9cd)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-46-8"></span><span id="page-46-7"></span><span id="page-46-2"></span>2:5 The conjunction "for" shows that the forthcoming exposition of Psalm 8 supports the exhortation to stay moored to the word spoken through the Son (Heb. 2:1–4). He has spoken salvation because he has come to share our humanity in order to lead us to glory. Our author has been speaking of the "world to come" since 1:6, where he introduced God's command for angels to worship the Son as having been spoken at the moment when God brought him into that realm of last-days blessedness (through resurrection and ascension). "Not to angels" implies that God subjected the world to come to someone else—but to whom? Psalm 8 gives the answer.

2:6–8a The psalm citation is introduced in vague terms: "It has been testified somewhere" reflects the Greek text's indefinite identification of the quotation's source (lit., "somewhere someone testified"). The author is signaling that this text, unlike those in chapter 1, is addressed by a human speaker to God, but the identity of the human speaker is not significant.

<span id="page-46-4"></span><span id="page-46-3"></span>God put everything "in subjection" under the feet of "the son of man." Scholarly opinion is divided over whether our author treats Psalm 8 as a straightforward messianic prophecy of the *Son's* brief humiliation and subsequent exaltation or as a forecast of *humanity's* destiny, which finds its first fulfillment in Jesus. In favor of seeing the Son as the one to whom the world to come is subject is the motif of subjects being placed "under his feet," which links Psalm 8 with Psalm 110:1, cited in Hebrews 1:13. On the other hand, "those who are to inherit salvation" were introduced in 1:14, and the author will soon describe them as "many sons" whom God brings to glory through Christ's suffering (2:10). Further, when the formula "not [to] angels" concludes this section in 2:16, the preacher places over against angels "the offspring of Abraham," the people of God.

<span id="page-46-10"></span><span id="page-46-9"></span><span id="page-46-6"></span><span id="page-46-5"></span>A third alternative, which builds a bridge between the messianic and anthropological perspectives, is based on the observation that Psalm 8 shares vocabulary appearing in preceding and following psalms (e.g., the Lord's name, the earth, foes, enemies, heavens). These connections embed this psalm in a context that opens the biblical Psalter by identifying the blessed man with the anointed Davidic Messiah, the Lord's Son (Psalms 1–2).5 Psalm 2:7, we recall, was the first OT passage that our

<span id="page-46-1"></span><span id="page-46-0"></span><sup>5</sup> James M. Hamilton, Jr., *Psalms*, Biblical Theology for Christian Proclamation (Nashville: Holman, forthcoming).

<span id="page-47-8"></span><span id="page-47-4"></span><span id="page-47-0"></span>author cited to establish the Son's superiority to the angels (Heb. 1:5). In view of Psalm 8's undeniable allusion to the universal dominion entrusted to Adam and Eve in Genesis 1:28, it is reasonable to believe that David, the royal speaker of Psalm 8, portrayed his reign as a step toward the remedy of Adam's failed kingship in the garden. Our preacher would then be building on David's Adamic-Messianic trajectory, showing its destination in Jesus.

<span id="page-47-2"></span>In this understanding, Psalm 8 is invoked first to describe *humanity's* honored place in the hierarchy and history of God's personal creatures, seen in King Adam at creation and reappearing after the fall in King David, a seed of the woman en route to the ultimate Seed, who would conquer the Foe through his own submission and suffering (Gen. 3:15). Then, after noting that humanity's dominion is not now visible, our author brings Jesus into view as the fulfillment of human destiny, interpreting the psalm as forecasting the phases of Jesus' mission as the last Adam and royal Messiah, first in submissive humility and then in glory.

<span id="page-47-11"></span>Our author's citation follows the LXX except for the deletion of one line, "and you appointed him over the works of your hands," which is essentially synonymous with the next, included by Hebrews and containing the significant term "subjection" (cf. 2:5, 8). The LXX renders the Hebrew term *'elohim* ("heavenly beings" in Ps. 8:5) as "angels," a legitimate interpretation that serves our author's purpose in showing the angels' relationship to humanity and to the incarnate Son.

<span id="page-47-10"></span><span id="page-47-5"></span>In what ways are humans subordinate to angels? Our author implied his answer when he referred to the angels' mediation of the law to Moses at Sinai (Heb. 2:2). That law imposed obligations and stipulated penalties for their violation and delivered an earthly system of worship, including sanctuary and sacrifices (Hebrews 8–10). Christ was "born under the law, to redeem those who were under the law" (Gal. 4:4–5) and to replace the law's shadows (Heb. 9:11–14; 10:19–22).

<span id="page-47-15"></span><span id="page-47-14"></span><span id="page-47-13"></span><span id="page-47-9"></span><span id="page-47-7"></span>2:8bc Our author's commentary first notes that Psalm 8 speaks of earthly creatures' universal subjection to humanity. Then comes the realistic observation that "at present" this human dominion is not visible. Believers' sufferings (2:14–16; 10:32–34; 11:32–38; 12:3–11) and the perishability of the heavens and earth (1:10–12; 12:25–27) display disorder, dysfunctionality, and death, which contradict God's purpose revealed in the psalm. Human sin has infected the created order with rebellion and chaos (Gen. 3:14–19; Rom. 8:18–22). Yet a spark of hope glimmers in the adverb "not yet" (*oupō*). Psalm 8 is not a mournful elegy for an idyllic world long ago deceased. Rather it offers a preview of a peaceable kingdom yet to come, perhaps foreshadowed in the "rest" from enemies that David once enjoyed (2 Sam. 7:1; cf. comment on Heb. 4:8).

<span id="page-47-12"></span><span id="page-47-6"></span><span id="page-47-3"></span><span id="page-47-1"></span>2:9 The spark of hope expands to a ray with the introduction of Jesus, now—for the first time in this sermon-letter—called by the human name given him at birth (Matt. 1:21, 25). The author builds anticipation by first describing an individual using the psalm's terminology: "for a little while . . . made lower than the angels." Then the suspense is broken and he is identified by name, "Jesus." The two lines of

<span id="page-48-2"></span>Psalm 8:5 (Heb. 2:7) forecast two phases of the Son's identification with us in our humanity: (1) first he was lowered for "a little while" beneath the angels (through becoming incarnate and suffering death for others); (2) then he was "crowned with glory and honor" (raised, ascended, and enthroned at God's right hand). The adverbial expression "a little" (Hb. *meʻat*; LXX *brachy ti* ) could indicate a small difference of degree or distance (2 Sam. 16:1) or a brief period of time (Pss. 94:17; 119:87; Luke 22:58; Acts 5:34). Our author understands the expression temporally: "for a little while."

<span id="page-48-4"></span><span id="page-48-3"></span><span id="page-48-0"></span>His appeal to Psalm 8 serves two purposes:

- <span id="page-48-8"></span>(1) It clarifies the relationship between the Son's *eternal divine* superiority to angels and his *mediatorial* superiority to angels. Since the Son is the changeless creator of heaven and earth and all their inhabitants, infinitely greater than angels, how could he "become" superior to angels and "inherit" a name more excellent than theirs (Heb. 1:4)? The exaltation of the Son *after* he made purification for sins (1:3) presupposes his prior condescension to become the incarnate mediatorial Son, sharing for a brief time humanity's position subordinate to the angels.
- <span id="page-48-10"></span><span id="page-48-9"></span><span id="page-48-7"></span>(2) It affirms the solidarity of the Son with human beings through his incarnation and humiliation. Angels are servants not only to the Son but also to the human heirs of the salvation he came to achieve (1:6, 14), whom he calls his "brothers" (2:11–12).

<span id="page-48-12"></span>The prologue mentioned the Son's priestly work of making purification for sins, but here we learn the price he paid to achieve this purifying mission: he suffered death, tasting it "for everyone." Our author will further describe the "everyone" for whom Jesus died as the "many sons" for whom he is the founder of salvation (Heb. 2:10) and as the "offspring of Abraham," whom he helps (v. 16). Jesus' death was the purpose of his incarnation: "He himself likewise partook of [flesh and blood], *that* [Gk. *hina*] through death he might destroy . . . the devil" (2:14–15). His death is also the warrant for his vindication: "crowned with glory and honor *because of* [Gk. *dia*] the suffering of death" (v. 9). His enthronement at God's right hand is his reward for faithful obedience "to the point of death, even death on a cross" (Phil. 2:6–11).

#### <span id="page-48-13"></span><span id="page-48-5"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-48-11"></span><span id="page-48-6"></span><span id="page-48-1"></span>When we step back from everyday activities, diversions, and relationships to consider our place in the grand scheme of things, we are humbled by our insignificance. The psalmist's contemplation of the vastness of the universe rightly evoked the question, "What is man that you are mindful of him?" (Ps. 8:4; cf. Heb. 2:6). Beyond that universe is a Creator who transcends it in majestic infinity. As we reflect on the OT texts cited in Hebrews 1 to show the Son's supremacy, it seems unlikely that we tiny ephemeral creatures might *matter* to him. When we factor in the sobering truth that human sin disrupted the dominion once entrusted to our race by the Creator whom we spurned, our condition seems even more dire and

<span id="page-49-2"></span><span id="page-49-0"></span>despicable. But Psalm 8 lifts our shame-bowed heads. Although the world we see resists us, the Creator has come to us, becoming one of us in humble subjection and emerging from suffering crowned with royal glory and honor. We should marvel and praise the God of grace, who sent his Son to die, bringing us to glory as heirs of "the world to come."

### HEBREWS 2:10–18

**<sup>10</sup>**For it was fitting that he, for whom and by whom all things exist, in bringing many sons to glory, should make the founder of their salvation perfect through suffering. **11**For he who sanctifies and those who are sanctified all have one source.*<sup>1</sup>* That is why he is not ashamed to call them brothers,*<sup>2</sup>* **<sup>12</sup>** saying,

"I will tell of your name to my brothers; in the midst of the congregation I will sing your praise."

**<sup>13</sup>**And again,

"I will put my trust in him."

And again,

"Behold, I and the children God has given me."

**<sup>14</sup>** Since therefore the children share in flesh and blood, he himself likewise partook of the same things, that through death he might destroy the one who has the power of death, that is, the devil, **<sup>15</sup>** and deliver all those who through fear of death were subject to lifelong slavery. **16**For surely it is not angels that he helps, but he helps the offspring of Abraham. **<sup>17</sup>**Therefore he had to be made like his brothers in every respect, so that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in the service of God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people. **18**For because he himself has suffered when tempted, he is able to help those who are being tempted.

1Greek *all are of one* 2Or *brothers and sisters*. In New Testament usage, depending on the context, the plural Greek word *adelphoi* (translated "brothers") may refer either to *brothers* or to *brothers and sisters*; also verse 12

#### *Section Overview: The Champion of Salvation for His Brothers and Sisters*

<span id="page-49-1"></span>The opening conjunction "For" shows that this section argues for the appropriateness ("fitting") of the truth announced in Hebrews 2:9, that God's grace mandated that Jesus suffer death on behalf of others. He could suffer as their substitute because of the family tie that unites him, the unique Son, to them, the "many sons" <span id="page-50-7"></span><span id="page-50-6"></span><span id="page-50-5"></span>whom God is leading to glory (v. 10). He and they share one father (v. 11), so without embarrassment he identifies them as his brothers (vv. 11–12, 17) and God's children (vv. 13–14). It is not angels whom the Son holds and helps but human beings who are Abraham's offspring (v. 16). The plight of his siblings—their enslavement through the fear of death—required that their divine kinsman-redeemer become fully human, like them in every respect, sharing in their flesh and blood. In his incarnation the divine Son became briefly lower than angels because nothing less than his death (vv. 9–10, 14) could set the Devil's guilty captives free and deflect God's just wrath from them (vv. 17–18). Here Hebrews presents Christ's death both as royal combat and as rescue ("destroy . . . the devil, and deliver all those . . . subject to lifelong slavery"; vv. 14–15) and as priestly atonement ("a merciful and faithful high priest . . . to make propitiation for the sins"; v. 17).

#### <span id="page-50-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-50-4"></span>I. The Creator qualified his unique Son through suffering to be rescuer and priest to many sons, leading them to glory (2:10)
- II. The Son and the sons are united by a common father and common faith (2:11–13)
- <span id="page-50-8"></span>III. The Son and the children share a common humanity, subject to harm and death (2:14–18)
	- A. The Son embraced human nature completely, becoming vulnerable to death, so that by his death he might free those enslaved by the Devil's death-inflicting power (2:14–15)
	- B. The slaves whom the Son grasps to help are not angels, but Abraham's offspring (2:16)
	- C. The Son embraced human nature completely, enduring suffering and temptation, in order to become a merciful, faithful High Priest, atoning for our sins and aiding us in our trials (2:17–18)

#### <span id="page-50-11"></span><span id="page-50-9"></span>*Comment*

<span id="page-50-0"></span>2:10 Ancient pagans and Jews found Jesus' suffering on the cross both foolish and offensive, not at all a "fitting" way for the creator and sustainer of "all things" to remedy the plight of humanity (cf. 1 Cor. 1:18–25). But it is the plight of the "many sons" whom God purposes to lead to glory that makes Christ's cross the only fitting and necessary ("had to be"; Heb. 2:17) means of rescue, since their slavery to the fear of death (and the Devil) could be broken only by the propitiating death of their brother, the divine and messianic Son, on their behalf.

<span id="page-50-12"></span><span id="page-50-10"></span><span id="page-50-2"></span><span id="page-50-1"></span>The "many sons" whom God leads to glory define more specifically the "everyone" of verse 9. "Glory" encompasses inheriting salvation (1:14) and dominion in "the world to come," as described in Psalm 8 (cf. Heb. 2:5–8). All those for whom Christ "[tasted] death" (v. 9) are the sons and heirs whom God will lead to glory. They are "the offspring of Abraham" (v. 16) whom the Son laid hold of and helps, for they follow in the footsteps of Abraham's patient faith (6:12–15; cf. Rom. <span id="page-51-9"></span><span id="page-51-7"></span>4:9–12). The Greek term *archēgos*, translated "founder," appears thirty-five times in the LXX, typically with reference to leaders of families and clans. In extrabiblical Greek it designates founders of cities and champions who fight on behalf of a nation. It is applied to Jesus also in Hebrews 12:2 (of faith) and in Acts 3:15 (of life) and Acts 5:31 (with "Savior"). In light of the way Hebrews 2:14–15 will portray Christ as the children's representative combatant (kinsman-redeemer), "champion" is another good English equivalent.6

<span id="page-51-18"></span><span id="page-51-17"></span><span id="page-51-16"></span><span id="page-51-8"></span>God has made the Savior "perfect through suffering." Perfection is a prominent theme in Hebrews (5:9; 7:11, 19, 28; 9:9, 11; 10:1, 14; 11:40; 12:23); the perfecting of Christ himself is mentioned again in 5:9 and 7:28. Jesus was and is undefiled by sin (4:15; 7:26), so with respect to Jesus the concept of progress or moral growth from sinfulness to holiness is unthinkable. Rather, when Hebrews speaks of Jesus' being "made perfect," it is employing the LXX sense of consecration and ordination to priestly office (Ex. 29:9, 29, 33, 35; Lev. 4:5; 8:33; 16:32; 21:10; Num. 3:3; etc.). As Hebrews 2:17–18 and 5:8–10 show, Jesus underwent this induction to his priesthood not through external rituals of washing and anointing but through his lifelong obedience to the will of God amid trial and suffering, climaxing in his death.

<span id="page-51-19"></span><span id="page-51-15"></span><span id="page-51-14"></span><span id="page-51-11"></span><span id="page-51-0"></span>2:11 In Hebrews, to "sanctify" bears priestly overtones of "cleansing" people so that they may enter God's holy presence in worship (9:13–14; 10:14; 13:12). Just as Aaronic priests had family solidarity with their Israelite kinfolk (5:1; 7:5), so Christ shares a family tie with his brothers and sisters. Behind the phrase "all have one source" is the ambiguous Greek "all from one." This probably refers to their sharing one father. But who is this father? He is not Adam (obliquely alluded to in 2:6–8) nor Abraham (2:16). Rather, he is God the Father, for the sanctifier is God's Son, and those whom he sanctifies are God's many sons. Their prior union in the electing purpose of God is the reason for the Son's incarnation on behalf of his brothers' redemption (2:14, 17).

<span id="page-51-22"></span><span id="page-51-21"></span><span id="page-51-13"></span><span id="page-51-12"></span><span id="page-51-10"></span><span id="page-51-4"></span>2:12 We might expect that the brothers' vulnerability to fear of death, arising from sinful guilt, would make the glorious divine Son ashamed to identify them as his siblings, but the opposite is true, as Psalm 22:22 shows. Later we will learn that God is not ashamed to be called the God of ancient people of faith (Heb. 11:16). In response, we must readily bear the reproach of Christ (11:25–26; 13:13) and identify, without shame, with those who suffer for Jesus' sake (13:3; cf. 10:32–34; 2 Tim. 1:8, 12, 16). Here our preacher calls us to marvel that, in the words of Psalm 22, the gloriously divine and messianic Son identifies himself without embarrassment with his sinful, struggling siblings.

<span id="page-51-20"></span><span id="page-51-6"></span><span id="page-51-5"></span><span id="page-51-3"></span><span id="page-51-2"></span><span id="page-51-1"></span>Psalm 22 traces a trajectory of suffering (Ps. 22:1–21), beginning with the forsakenness by God echoed in Jesus' outcry from the cross (Matt. 27:46), to salvation and celebration (Ps. 22:22–31). This is the two-phase path our preacher traced in his Psalm 8 citation: first lower than angels, then crowned with glory. So he cites <span id="page-52-2"></span>Psalm 22:22, the psalm's turning point from suffering to glory, not only because it mentions "my brothers" but also because *as a whole* this psalm projects the pattern of the Christ's redemptive mission (Luke 24:25–27; 1 Pet. 1:11).

<span id="page-52-20"></span><span id="page-52-9"></span><span id="page-52-8"></span><span id="page-52-4"></span><span id="page-52-3"></span><span id="page-52-1"></span>2:13 Isaiah 8:17–18 provides further support for the family ties linking the Son with those he sanctifies. Christ himself speaks through the prophet's confession of trust in God in the midst of his children. (The wording of 2 Sam. 22:3 and Isa. 12:2 parallels Isa. 8:17.) Jesus' faith is not identical to ours; he is the Righteous One whose obedience justifies the ungodly (Isa. 53:11; Rom. 3:21–26; 4:5), so he is the *object* of our faith (Phil. 3:9), the unique mediator through whom we approach God (Heb. 7:25; 10:19–22). Yet Jesus himself trusted the Father's promise to reward his impeccable obedience and sacrificial death, and he is therefore the champion (*archēgos*) of our faith (12:2).

<span id="page-52-27"></span><span id="page-52-25"></span><span id="page-52-21"></span><span id="page-52-19"></span><span id="page-52-17"></span><span id="page-52-15"></span><span id="page-52-14"></span><span id="page-52-13"></span>2:14 Two factors mandated the Son's incarnation. First, he shared one Father with his brothers, who needed salvation (Heb. 2:10–13). Second, his brothers are human beings with "flesh and blood" bodies, vulnerable to corruption, liable to judgment, and threatened by death (cf. Eph. 6:12; 1 Cor. 15:50). His humble condescension to partake of their same flesh and blood, to embrace full (though unfallen) human nature, made it possible for him to die on their behalf (Heb. 2:9) and, in so doing, to disarm the Devil of his power to inflict death. The Greek term *katargeō*, rendered "destroy," can mean eradication (1 Cor. 15:26; 2 Thess. 2:8) but typically refers to nullifying, neutralizing, or depriving of power (e.g., Rom. 3:3, 31; 4:14; Gal. 5:4, 11), which is the immediate effect of Christ's death on the Devil. The Devil wielded deathinflicting power first by luring humans to defy God's prohibition (Gen. 3:4) and then by accusing them before God's just tribunal (Zech. 3:1; John 8:44; Rev. 12:9–11). But the death of Jesus the innocent in the place of his guilty brothers has deprived the Devil of the capital charges he had lodged against them (cf. Col. 2:14–15).

<span id="page-52-22"></span><span id="page-52-16"></span><span id="page-52-11"></span><span id="page-52-10"></span><span id="page-52-7"></span><span id="page-52-6"></span><span id="page-52-0"></span>2:15–16 The Devil's defeat through Jesus' death delivers those enslaved by the fear of death, while the propitiation of God's wrath against their sins (v. 17) removes the verdict of condemnation and the prospect of sin's sentence: eternal death. The author conveys the Son's battling and defeating the Devil through his own substitutionary death with wording echoing Isaiah's portrait of the Lord as his people's kinsman-redeemer. He has come to free captives from the tyrant (Isa. 49:24–26). He "helps"—that is, "takes hold of" (*epilambanomai*; LXX Isa. 41:9, 10, 13; Jer. 31:32, cited in Heb. 8:9)—"the offspring of Abraham" and calms their "fear" through his "help" (*boētheō*). (These terms all appear both in Isa. 41:8–13 LXX and in Heb. 2:16–18). Those whom the Son has redeemed are coming into clearer focus: the "everyone" of Hebrews 2:9 are the "many sons" of verse 10, who are the "offspring of Abraham," imitating Abraham's faith (6:12–13; 11:11, 18; cf. Rom. 4:12).

<span id="page-52-26"></span><span id="page-52-24"></span><span id="page-52-23"></span><span id="page-52-18"></span><span id="page-52-12"></span><span id="page-52-5"></span>2:17 Having portrayed the Son's redemptive death in military (that is, royal) terms as the defeat of the Devil and the emancipation of his slaves, our author now views the Son's sacrifice from a priestly perspective, introducing Jesus' office as <span id="page-53-13"></span><span id="page-53-10"></span><span id="page-53-6"></span>High Priest, a title that hereafter will be applied repeatedly to Christ (3:1; 4:14, 15; 5:1, 5, 10; 6:20; 7:26, 27, 28; 8:1, 3; 9:7, 11, 25; 13:11). This is the main "point" of the sermon that is the book of Hebrews (8:1). Priestly intercession demands identification with those on whose behalf the priest intervenes with God, for their shared nature qualifies the priest to act as their representative, while their shared experience of suffering enriches his sympathy for them in their trials (4:14–5:4).

<span id="page-53-9"></span><span id="page-53-8"></span><span id="page-53-0"></span>Jesus' priestly attributes, his being "merciful and faithful," reflect the Lord's declaration of his name to Moses on Mount Sinai as "merciful and gracious, . . . abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness" (Ex. 34:6; cf. Ps. 40:11). These qualities make Jesus the perfect mediator between weak and sinful humans who need merciful help (Heb. 4:15) and the holy God who demands faithfulness in those who approach him. In the days of Samuel, the priest Eli failed to protect God's sanctuary from defilement by Eli's own corrupt sons, so God declared that he would remove Eli's house from the priesthood, replacing it with a "faithful priest" (1 Sam. 2:35). Jesus is that faithful priest, whose ministry replaces not only Eli but the entire Levitical-Aaronic order (Hebrews 7). In the next paragraph (3:1–6), faithfulness will be the point of comparison between Moses the servant and Jesus the Son (cf. Num. 12:7).

<span id="page-53-7"></span><span id="page-53-2"></span><span id="page-53-1"></span>Scholars debate whether the term translated as "propitiation" (*hilaskomai* ) expresses only the removal of sin's guilt (expiation) or also includes the deflection of God's wrath from the guilty (propitiation). Key OT and NT texts mention divine wrath in contexts implying its removal, along with that of sin's defilement, through sacrifice (e.g., Ps. 78:21, 38; Rom. 1:18; 2:5; 3:23–26). Here, both effects of Christ's sacrifice are in view: guilt is removed and God's just wrath is placated.

<span id="page-53-12"></span><span id="page-53-11"></span><span id="page-53-5"></span><span id="page-53-3"></span>2:18 Having undergone death for others, our High Priest was subsequently raised to "indestructible life" (7:16; cf. 13:20). He "always lives" to "save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him," interceding for them (7:25) and providing timely, empathetic, and strong help to his suffering people in their trials.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-53-4"></span>The incomparable majesty of the Son, announced in the prologue of Hebrews and substantiated in the OT texts that followed, rightly moves us to awe and worship. But his deity also seems to place a vast distance between him and us, stained as we are with sin and struggling in a curse-infected world. But now we marvel at the lengths to which the Creator "for whom and by whom all things exist" (2:10) went in order to save us from sin and the death that is its bitter outcome, leading us to glory instead. The champion of our salvation, Jesus, embraced us as his God-given family and assumed our destructible flesh and blood as his own. Then by his death he put death to death, depriving the Devil of the terror-inducing weapon of his tyranny and setting us captives free.

Since this mighty champion not only called us his brothers and sisters but also gave his life on our behalf, we have the strongest of rationales to fix our attention <span id="page-54-6"></span><span id="page-54-5"></span><span id="page-54-3"></span>and rest our hope on "Jesus, the apostle and high priest of our confession" (3:1). Having died for us, Jesus now lives forever for us, interceding as our Great High Priest. We, in turn, may and must draw near to his Father's throne of grace in prayer and worship, confidently expecting his welcome and his generous provision of the aid we need at the moment we need it (4:14–16).

### OVERVIEW OF

### HEBREWS 3:1–4:13

<span id="page-54-2"></span><span id="page-54-1"></span><span id="page-54-0"></span>Although the motif of Jesus' priestly ministry has now been introduced (Heb. 2:17–18), its elaboration will be deferred to the heart of the sermon (4:14–10:31). In the meantime, the implications of the Son's ministry of revelation will be explored. Moving from the contrast between the angels and the Son (1:4–2:18), we now come to Moses, Israel's preeminent prophet and covenant mediator, and his relationship to Christ. Through Moses the servant and Christ the Son, God's people have heard his voice, as will be shown from Psalm 95's retrospective on Israel's wilderness experience under Moses. The generation that escaped Egypt through Moses' leadership heard but did not believe God's voice, so they died in the desert wasteland, banned from entering the Promised Land. Their history warns those now addressed by God's last-days speech in the Son, lest they too come short of the inheritance God promises to those who persevere in faith.

### <span id="page-54-4"></span>HEBREWS 3:1–6

3 Therefore, holy brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* you who share in a heavenly calling, consider Jesus, the apostle and high priest of our confession, **2**who was faithful to him who appointed him, just as Moses also was faithful in all God's*<sup>2</sup>* house. **3**For Jesus has been counted worthy of more glory than Moses—as much more glory as the builder of a house has more honor than the house itself. **<sup>4</sup>** (For every house is built by someone, but the builder of all things is God.) **5**Now Moses was faithful in all God's house as a servant, to testify to the things that were to be spoken later, **6**but Christ is faithful over God's house as a son. And we are his house, if indeed we hold fast our confidence and our boasting in our hope.*<sup>3</sup>*

1Or *brothers and sisters*; also verse 12 2Greek *his*; also verses 5, 6 3Some manuscripts insert *firm to the end*

<span id="page-55-11"></span><span id="page-55-8"></span><span id="page-55-3"></span><span id="page-55-0"></span>*Section Overview: Jesus the Faithful Son, Greater Than Moses the Faithful Servant* The description of Christ as a "*faithful* high priest" (Heb. 2:17) provides the bridge—via God's commendation of Moses as his "faithful" servant (Num. 12:7; Heb. 3:2, 5)—to a comparison of and contrast between Moses and Jesus. Both Moses and Jesus were faithful to their callings from God, although the honor of their respective roles (servant vs. Son) differed. The themes of revelation and redemptive-historical progress continue from the prologue (1:1–2), for Moses testified to things "to be spoken later" (3:5). The discussion of the superiority of the Son to Moses the servant transitions into an exposition of Psalm 95, which describes the wilderness generation's refusal to heed God's voice through Moses and their consequent failure to enter God's rest (Heb. 3:7–4:11).

#### <span id="page-55-13"></span><span id="page-55-12"></span><span id="page-55-1"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. Focus attention on your "apostle and high priest," Jesus, faithful like Moses for the sake of God's house (3:1–2)
- II. Jesus deserves more glory than Moses (3:3–6a)
	- A. As the builder of God's house is more glorious than the house (3:3–4)
	- B. As a Son over the house has more honor than a servant in the house (3:5–6a)
- III. We are the house that Jesus builds and rules, if we hold to the hope he secures (3:6b)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-55-14"></span><span id="page-55-10"></span><span id="page-55-9"></span><span id="page-55-7"></span><span id="page-55-6"></span>3:1 "Therefore" signals that the obligation to "consider Jesus" follows from the good news that he is a "merciful and faithful high priest" who can help those undergoing temptation (2:17–18). Having affirmed that believers are "brothers" of the Son who sanctifies them (2:10–13), our preacher addresses them as "holy brothers." Christians are addressed as "brothers" often in NT epistles, including later in this sermon-letter (3:12; 10:19; 13:22), but only here, soon after reference to the *sanctification* of God's sons (2:11) through propitiation of their sins (2:17), does the combination "holy brothers" occur. They "share in a heavenly calling" as the heirs of salvation (1:14), destined for dominion in the world to come (2:5–8) and anticipating a heavenly homeland (11:14–16). Their worship on earth already participates in the celebration in the heavenly Jerusalem (12:22–24). They "share" in this glorious calling because the Son came to "share" their fragile flesh and blood (2:14), and thus they are "companions" of the Anointed One (1:8–9; cf. 3:14). The verb "share" (*metechō*) and the noun "companions" (*metochoi* ) are Greek cognates.

<span id="page-55-18"></span><span id="page-55-17"></span><span id="page-55-16"></span><span id="page-55-15"></span><span id="page-55-5"></span><span id="page-55-4"></span><span id="page-55-2"></span>To "consider" (*katanoeō*) Jesus is to focus one's vision and attention on him, since the verb not only refers to mental reflection (Heb. 10:24) but also can have visual overtones (Matt. 7:3; Luke 12:24, 27; Acts 7:31–32; 11:6; 27:39; James 1:23–24). This exhortation reappears in other words in Hebrews 12:2, where believers are to be "looking [*aphoraō*] to Jesus." The point of fixing one's mind's eye (as it were) <span id="page-56-5"></span>on Jesus is not merely to imitate his faithfulness but also to rest one's trust in his ministry as "the apostle and high priest of our confession" (Heb. 3:1). Perseverance in the Christian pilgrimage results from holding fast in confidence to the hope secured for us by Christ. Jesus spoke frequently of the Father's "sending" (both *apostellō* and *pempō*) him on his mission of revelation and redemption (John 3:17, 34; 8:42; etc.), but only here in the NT is Jesus called an "apostle." This term probably highlights his revelatory role, which excels and supersedes that of the OT prophets (Heb. 1:1–2), including Moses.

<span id="page-56-16"></span><span id="page-56-12"></span><span id="page-56-8"></span><span id="page-56-6"></span><span id="page-56-2"></span>3:2 God "appointed" Jesus as "apostle and high priest," just as he appointed Moses to his mediatorial role for Israel and appointed Aaron to his high priesthood (5:4–6). The privilege of intervening between God and mankind is assigned by God, not seized by the human servant. Both Jesus and Moses proved faithful to their respective assignments for "all God's house," that is, God's people. In Numbers 12:6–8 the Lord defended Moses against critiques from his siblings, Miriam and Aaron, who also were prophets. In that passage, listing some of the "many ways" that he spoke through other prophets (cf. Heb. 1:1), the Lord distinguished "my servant Moses," who "is faithful in all my house," as the unique prophet with whom he spoke "mouth to mouth."

<span id="page-56-13"></span><span id="page-56-11"></span><span id="page-56-7"></span>3:3–4 Although Jesus and Moses alike were faithful, they differed in their worthiness to receive glory. God is the implied agent of the passive verb "has been counted worthy," for he is the one who "crowned" Jesus "with glory and honor" (2:9). The Lord honored Moses above other prophets, but he has honored the Son above Moses, the greatest of the OT prophets, as our preacher is about to show explicitly (3:5–6).

<span id="page-56-15"></span><span id="page-56-4"></span><span id="page-56-1"></span><span id="page-56-0"></span>Our author exploits the fact that both Hebrew (*bayit*) and Greek (*oikos*) use "house" to refer both to a habitable structure (e.g., Gen. 12:15) and to the people who inhabit it (Gen. 12:17), even across generations (Gen. 50:22). The superior glory of Jesus to that of Moses is supported by the analogy that a house's builder deserves greater glory than the house he built, since (it is implied) the house owes its existence to its builder's effort. What is true of human builders is all the more true of the Creator, who is the "builder of all things" (cf. Isa. 40:28; 45:7). The Son's role in creation invites readers to perceive the divine glory of Jesus, through whom God "created the world" (Heb. 1:2) and who in the beginning laid earth's foundation and fashioned the heavens (1:10). Moreover, the Son is here honored as the "builder" of the covenant people of God, both the source of their existence and identity as a community and also the sovereign over them.

<span id="page-56-14"></span><span id="page-56-10"></span><span id="page-56-9"></span><span id="page-56-3"></span>3:5–6a The language describing Moses in Numbers 12:7 as the Lord's "*servant* " "*in* all God's house" signals his inferiority to Christ, who "is faithful *over* God's house as a *son*." Both the titles ("servant" vs. "son") and the prepositions ("in" vs. "over") show the superiority of Christ. The Greek term rendered "servant" (*therapōn*; from Num. 12:7 LXX) appears only here in the NT, but the point is the same as that

<span id="page-57-5"></span><span id="page-57-4"></span>made earlier with respect to angels, who are "ministers" (*leitourgous*; Heb. 1:7, 14), in contrast to the Son, who is the enthroned "God" and "Lord" (1:8, 10).

<span id="page-57-3"></span><span id="page-57-2"></span>Moses' mission as servant was to "testify to things that were to be spoken later." Moses had many roles, priestly and royal as well as prophetic, but here the author focuses attention on his prophetic role as one through whom "long ago . . . God spoke" (1:1). The contrast between the earlier prophetic era of revelation and the "last days" era of revelation in the Son (1:1–2) reappears here: Moses' testimony was forward-looking, attesting in advance to what God would speak later in history, the message of salvation to be "declared . . . by the Lord" Jesus and then by those who heard him (2:3). Jesus affirmed that Moses wrote about his sufferings and subsequent glories (John 5:44–47; Luke 24:25–27, 44–49). Hebrews will teach that regulations pertaining to the tabernacle and its sacrifices, received by Moses in the law, foreshadowed a new and better covenant and worship in a "time of reformation" (Heb. 9:6–10; 10:1), which has now come "at the end of the ages" through Christ (9:11–15, 26).

<span id="page-57-12"></span><span id="page-57-11"></span><span id="page-57-8"></span><span id="page-57-6"></span><span id="page-57-1"></span><span id="page-57-0"></span>3:6b Christ's superiority to Moses leads to a conclusion that is both comforting and challenging. It is comforting to learn that now "we are his [Christ's] house" in the sense of being his family, the brothers and sisters for whose liberation he assumed our human nature. His dominion secures the safety of those in his house. The challenge arises from the contingency: "if indeed we hold fast our confidence and our boasting in our hope." As the following analysis of Israel's wilderness experience through the lens of Psalm 95 will show, people can belong to a community that experiences God's acts of power and mercy and yet fail to respond in persevering faith (Heb. 3:7–4:11). The author will later repeat the summons to hold fast our confidence (3:14) and our confession (10:23). Here he stresses that this enduring commitment is not mere dogged, teeth-gritted survival but rather a persistence that radiates bold assurance and hope (cf. 10:19). It is only by focusing attention on Jesus, our faithful apostle and high priest, that we can sustain such lifelong and hopeful tenacity throughout life's journey.

#### <span id="page-57-13"></span><span id="page-57-10"></span><span id="page-57-9"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-57-14"></span><span id="page-57-7"></span>As our revealer of the Father (in his role as apostle) and our reconciler to the Father (in his role as High Priest), Jesus transcends Moses, Israel's covenant mediator and greatest prophet. The response that Christ's superiority should elicit from us is defined at the opening and close of this paragraph (3:1, 6b). On the one hand, Christ's faithfulness in his revelatory and redemptive offices demands that we give him our unwavering and undivided attention, listening eagerly to his voice as he addresses us from heaven through his ministers (cf. 12:25–26; 13:7). On the other hand, this single-minded attention to our faithful Savior must produce in us endurance in our allegiance to him and unashamed confidence in the inheritance he promises.

### <span id="page-58-4"></span>OVERVIEW OF HEBREWS 3:7–4:13

<span id="page-58-6"></span><span id="page-58-5"></span><span id="page-58-2"></span><span id="page-58-1"></span><span id="page-58-0"></span>The author concluded his comparison and contrast between Moses and Christ (3:1–6) by indicating that his hearers' standing as Christ's "house" is contingent on their perseverance in their confidence in Jesus, their apostle and high priest. This motif of persevering faith in response to God's self-revelation is now developed in an exposition and application of Psalm 95:7–11. This portion of Psalm 95 is cited in full in Hebrews 3:7–11 and in part in 3:15; 4:3, 5, 7. Further allusions to Psalm 95 are interspersed throughout the interpretive comments that follow (e.g., "today" in Heb. 3:13; 4:7; "rest" in 3:18; 4:4, 6, 8–11). The psalm draws a sobering warning from the example of Israel's wilderness generation, who experienced liberation from Egyptian slavery through Moses (3:16) but disbelieved God's promise and so died without entering his "rest," the land promised to the patriarchs. The psalm is attributed to David, "so long" after Israel's wilderness generation had died in the desert and after Joshua had led their children into the Promised Land (4:7–8). David's generation, living in the land in their "today," still needed to heed the summons to respond to God's voice in faith and obedience in order to enter God's "rest" (which, it is implied, transcends peaceful life in Canaan). So also do the Hebrew Christians who first received this sermon-letter, whose "today" of wilderness testing, pilgrimage toward God's rest, and obligation to heed God's voice extends until Christ's return (9:28).

### <span id="page-58-8"></span><span id="page-58-7"></span><span id="page-58-3"></span>HEBREWS 3:7–19

**<sup>7</sup>**Therefore, as the Holy Spirit says,

"Today, if you hear his voice,

- **<sup>8</sup>** do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion, on the day of testing in the wilderness,
- **<sup>9</sup>** where your fathers put me to the test and saw my works for forty years.
- **<sup>10</sup>** Therefore I was provoked with that generation, and said, 'They always go astray in their heart; they have not known my ways.'

**<sup>11</sup>** As I swore in my wrath, 'They shall not enter my rest.' "

**<sup>12</sup>**Take care, brothers, lest there be in any of you an evil, unbelieving heart, leading you to fall away from the living God. **13**But exhort one another every day, as long as it is called "today," that none of you may be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin. **14**For we have come to share in Christ, if indeed we hold our original confidence firm to the end. **15**As it is said,

"Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion."

**<sup>16</sup>**For who were those who heard and yet rebelled? Was it not all those who left Egypt led by Moses? **17**And with whom was he provoked for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose bodies fell in the wilderness? **18**And to whom did he swear that they would not enter his rest, but to those who were disobedient? **<sup>19</sup>** So we see that they were unable to enter because of unbelief.

#### *Section Overview: Exhortation: Hear His Voice with Faith*

<span id="page-59-2"></span><span id="page-59-1"></span><span id="page-59-0"></span>Our preacher quotes Psalm 95:7–11 as a divine directive and warning that the Holy Spirit is now speaking to his Hebrew-Christian congregation (Heb. 3:7–11). The directive is to respond to God's voice not with hardened hearts but with faith, which produces obedience. The warning arises from the dire example of the Israelite generation whom Moses led to freedom in the exodus but who fell short of the Promised Land through their unbelief in God's provision and power. The psalm's directive and warning are applied to the Hebrew Christian congregation, which bears corporate responsibility to guard its members from apostasy (3:12–15). Daily mutual exhortation is needed to counteract sin's deceitfulness. Our privilege as Christ's companions must motivate us to keep a firm grip on the reality in which we have placed our confidence. The warning from the wilderness generation's experience is deepened through rhetorical questions that imply that merely belonging to a community favored with God's gifts—delivered from Egypt, hearing God's voice—does not secure eternal salvation (3:16–19). Rebellion, sin, disobedience, and unbelief are complementary descriptions of the hardened hearts that excluded Moses' generation from God's rest.

#### <span id="page-59-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. Warning against unbelief: when you hear God's voice, heed his words, lest you fall short of his rest (3:7–11)
	- A. Do not harden your hearts at the sound of God's voice (3:7–8a)
	- B. In the wilderness, your fathers rebelled and tried God, despite his works (3:8b–10)
	- C. So God excluded those rebels from his rest (3:11)
- II. Call to persevere in confident faith through mutual encouragement (3:12–15)
	- A. Beware lest any of you turn from God through unbelief (3:12)
	- B. Encourage each other daily, to prevent anyone from succumbing to sin's lie (3:13)
	- C. We are Christ's companions, if we maintain our confidence as God speaks to us "today" (3:14–15)
- III. Warning against unbelief: those who rebelled in disobedience and unbelief fell dead in the wilderness (3:16–19)
	- A. The Israelites of Moses' day had experienced God's rescue from Egypt (3:16)
	- B. They provoked their Lord through sinful disobedience (3:17)
	- C. They fell dead, short of God's promised rest, through unbelief (3:18–19)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-60-7"></span><span id="page-60-5"></span><span id="page-60-4"></span><span id="page-60-3"></span>3:7 "Therefore" indicates that the negative example of Israel's wilderness generation supports the obligation of those in God's "house" to hold fast to their confidence in Christ (3:6). Our author introduces his citation of Psalm 95:7d–11 with the formula "as the Holy Spirit says." Other NT authors typically preface OT quotations with "it is written" (e.g., Matt. 2:5; Mark 1:2; Luke 2:23; Rom. 1:17; 1 Cor. 1:31) in order to highlight Scripture's fixed and lasting authority. Hebrews, meanwhile, often introduces OT texts with verbs of *speaking* in the *present* tense in order to emphasize God's immediate address to the congregation (cf. Heb. 3:15; 5:6; 8:8, 13; 9:8; 10:5, 15). Lessons drawn from Israel's ancient history by an ancient psalmist are not relics of a distant past but are the living, present voice of God (4:12), addressing us "today" (12:25–27).

<span id="page-60-11"></span><span id="page-60-10"></span><span id="page-60-9"></span><span id="page-60-6"></span><span id="page-60-2"></span>Psalm 95 opens (Ps. 95:1–7c) as a call to worship the Lord who is the source of salvation, the great God, the creator of everything, the shepherd of his people descriptions that Hebrews applies to Jesus the Son (Heb. 2:10; 1:8, 10; 13:20). Then the psalm shifts suddenly from praise to a sobering warning against hardness of heart, drawn from the travesty of Israelite unbelief in the wilderness after the exodus (Ps. 95:7d–11).

<span id="page-60-8"></span><span id="page-60-1"></span><span id="page-60-0"></span>3:8–9 Psalm 95 draws together two incidents from Israel's post–Red Sea travels in the wilderness in order to illustrate that generation's hard hearts, expressed in open rebellion. The Hebrew text of Psalm 95 contains the meaningful place-names Meribah (strife) and Massah (testing), assigned to a wilderness locale where thirsty Israelites put the Lord to the test, demanding proof of his presence among them (Ex. 17:1–7). The LXX, followed by our author, renders these place-names in Greek terms meaning "rebellion" and "testing," which form a bridge to a later incident at Kadesh (Num. 14:1–38). There the Israelites balked at entering the Promised Land, following the fearful, faithless report of ten spies instead of Joshua and Caleb's <span id="page-61-10"></span><span id="page-61-5"></span>summons not to "rebel" but to trust the Lord (Num. 14:9). Testing the Lord and rebelling against him characterized the wilderness generation (Ps. 78:8, 17, 40, 56).

<span id="page-61-19"></span><span id="page-61-16"></span><span id="page-61-15"></span><span id="page-61-13"></span><span id="page-61-0"></span>The psalmist traced Israel's problem to hearts that were "hardened" (Heb. 3:8) and prone to "always go astray" from the Lord (v. 10). Hebrews likewise warns against "an evil, unbelieving heart," "hardened" by sin's deceitfulness (vv. 12–13). Sin does not advertise its lethal consequences, as Eve sadly discovered (Gen. 3:13; 2 Cor. 11:3). The ten spies' misgivings about the daunting residents of Canaan sounded plausible (Num. 13:27–29, 31–33), so the Israelites trusted in their "bad report" and refused to believe the Lord, openly rebelling against his summons to advance in faith (Num. 14:9, 11).

<span id="page-61-8"></span><span id="page-61-6"></span><span id="page-61-4"></span><span id="page-61-3"></span><span id="page-61-2"></span>"Testing" in the wilderness operated in two directions. At Massah the Israelites wrongly put the Lord to the test, doubting his presence and provision (Ex. 17:7; Deut. 6:16; Matt. 4:7). On the other hand, throughout their wilderness ordeal the Lord was putting his people to the test (Ex. 16:4; 20:20) in order "to know what was in your heart" (Deut. 8:2). Jesus himself underwent testing in his sufferings and is able to help others undergoing such tests (Heb. 2:18; 4:15).

<span id="page-61-20"></span><span id="page-61-17"></span><span id="page-61-14"></span><span id="page-61-9"></span>3:10–11 The Israelites' forty-year trek through the wilderness gave them ample opportunity to see God's works—the ten plagues on Egypt; the crossing of the Red Sea; provision of water from the rock, manna, and quail; healing from venomous snakebites; and more. But those forty years were marred by the people's obstinate, unbelieving response to God's miraculous care, provoking his righteous wrath (Heb. 3:17). The oath that the Lord swore in his anger, "They shall not enter my rest," is expressed grammatically as a conditional clause in Hebrew and Greek, "If they shall enter my rest," with the consequence implied: "may I myself be accursed and destroyed." In other words, the force of oaths sworn by "the living God" (3:12) is to put his own life on the line: if those rebels gained access to his land, the Lord would himself willingly undergo a violent death.

<span id="page-61-18"></span><span id="page-61-7"></span>The source of the psalm's oath language is Numbers 14:28–30: "As I live, declares the Lord, . . . your dead bodies shall fall in this wilderness, and of all your number, . . . from twenty years old and upward, who have grumbled against me, not one shall come into the land where I swore that I would make you dwell, except Caleb . . . and Joshua." Mercifully, Hebrews will also explore God's oath to bless those who believe his promises as Abraham did (Heb. 6:13–18; cf. Gen. 15:7–21; 22:16), and God's sworn oath to bless believers is grounded, in turn, on the oath by which he appointed his Son as the final and eternal High Priest (Heb. 7:20–21; cf. Ps. 110:4).

<span id="page-61-23"></span><span id="page-61-22"></span><span id="page-61-21"></span><span id="page-61-12"></span><span id="page-61-11"></span><span id="page-61-1"></span>Against the background of Israel's rebellion at Kadesh, God's "rest" would be understood as the Promised Land of Canaan, which the next Israelite generation would enter. Yet our preacher will argue from Genesis and from the historical context of Psalm 95 in David's time that "God's rest" must transcend Canaan (Heb. 4:6–11). That land was merely an earthly sign pointing to a better, heavenly country, the object of the patriarchs' hopes (11:13–16).

<span id="page-62-12"></span><span id="page-62-11"></span><span id="page-62-8"></span><span id="page-62-1"></span>3:12 From the sober warning of Psalm 95 our preacher now derives both a negative caution and a positive exhortation for his Jewish-Christian congregation. The combination of "take care" or "see" with "unbelief" in both verse 12 and verse 19 envelopes the exhortation as an inclusio, even though verses 16–19 redirect attention from the current audience back to the wilderness generation. The cause of the wilderness generation's failure to enter God's rest is variously described as having hardened hearts, rebelling, putting God to the test, provoking his anger, going astray, not knowing God's ways, being hardened by sin's deceitfulness, and disobeying. But at the root is an "evil, *unbelieving* heart"—a deep distrust of God and his promises.

<span id="page-62-14"></span><span id="page-62-5"></span>The author addresses the congregation as "brothers," reinforcing the family tie binding them to Jesus the Son and to each other. Thus he also assures them of his concern for their spiritual well-being (2:11–12; 3:1). He will reassure his hearers as a group that he is confident that "things that belong to salvation" characterize them (6:9–10), but his concern extends to the individual who may be tempted to "fall away" from the living God in unbelief (cf. 12:12–17). The Greek verb rendered "fall away" is *aphistēmi*, referring to a more deliberate departure than the verb rendered "drift away" (2:1). To fall away is nothing less than apostasy akin to the Israelites' defiant rebellion in the wilderness.

<span id="page-62-17"></span><span id="page-62-13"></span><span id="page-62-9"></span><span id="page-62-3"></span>3:13 The Christian community can help to safeguard its wavering members by pursuing daily mutual exhortation and encouragement. The psalm's "today" extends from David's day (4:7) to the present, and thus the testing of faith's perseverance in a hostile setting continues, as does believers' responsibility to speak words of faith to each other. This is one purpose of the church's assembling for worship (10:23–25). Encouraging conversation is akin to physically resetting and supporting a dislocated limb or joint (12:12–13). This entire sermon-letter of Hebrews is a "word of exhortation" (13:22).

<span id="page-62-18"></span><span id="page-62-16"></span><span id="page-62-15"></span><span id="page-62-10"></span><span id="page-62-6"></span><span id="page-62-4"></span><span id="page-62-0"></span>3:14 "We have come to share in Christ" could literally be rendered, "We have become Christ's partners [*metochoi* ]." The citation of Psalm 45 in Hebrews 1:8–9 spoke of the Son's anointing and then of his "companions" (*metochoi* ), and in 2:14 the related verb *metechō* spoke of the Son's "partaking" of the human flesh and blood his children share. We and Christ have one father (2:11) and belong to one family, and so through Christ's incarnation, obedience, sacrifice, and resurrection we share the blessedness and benefits that are rightfully his. Such privilege must not tempt us to complacency, however, for the only faith that unites to Christ's grace is a faith that endures. Just as the hearers' identity as the Son's "house" is conditioned on holding fast to their confident hope (3:6), so their status as his coheirs and partners depends on keeping to the end their grip on the substantial reality7 they had grasped at the beginning of their Christian pilgrimage.

<span id="page-62-7"></span><span id="page-62-2"></span><sup>7</sup> The term rendered "original confidence" (*hypostasis*) designates not mere subjective "sureness" but the objective, substantial ground of that assurance, as in the first appearance of *hypostasis* in Hebrews 1:3: "the exact imprint of his *nature*" (1:3).

<span id="page-63-13"></span>3:15 "As it is said" closely connects the "today" of the psalm citation to the preceding exhortations ("take care . . . exhort . . . hold . . . firm") and should be understood as "while it is being said." In other words, we are hearing God's voice *in the present*, so our obligation to heed his voice is valid *now*.

<span id="page-63-14"></span><span id="page-63-6"></span><span id="page-63-0"></span>3:16–18 Our preacher engages his hearers' thought using a series of questions probing the spiritual identity of the wilderness generation. The questions are grouped in three couplets. In the first two couplets, the first question echoes wording in Psalm 95 while the second, rhetorical question draws terminology from the account of Kadesh in Numbers 14, in which the Israelites refused to enter the Promised Land. The third couplet combines features of Psalm 95 and Numbers 14 in a single rhetorical question (terms drawn from the OT passages are italicized):

- <span id="page-63-7"></span>(A) Who, having *heard*, *rebelled*? (Ps. 95:7d–8a = Heb. 3:7b–8a)
- <span id="page-63-2"></span>(A') Was it not all those who *left Egypt* through *Moses*? (Num. 14:13, 19, 22)
- (B) With whom was he *provoked forty years*? (Ps. 95:10a = Heb. 3:9b–10a)
- <span id="page-63-8"></span><span id="page-63-4"></span>(B') Was it not those who *sinned*, whose *bodies fell in the wilderness*? (Num. 14:29, 32, 40)
- <span id="page-63-12"></span><span id="page-63-9"></span>(C) To whom did he *swear* that they *would not enter his rest* (Ps. 95:11 = Heb. 3:11),
- <span id="page-63-5"></span><span id="page-63-3"></span>(C') except to those who *disobeyed*? (Num. 14:21–23, 28–30, 43; cf. Josh. 5:6)

These two OT texts, one narrating the rebellion in Moses' day (Numbers 14) and the other drawing admonition from that incident for later generations (Psalm 95), are interwoven to reinforce the sobering caution that we must take away from that event.

<span id="page-63-11"></span>Mention of the exodus from slavery in Egypt emphasizes two truths. First, the Israelites' unbelieving rebellion against the Lord was utterly without warrant, since they had already experienced his mighty rescue. Second, many who received that initial liberation, who "saw my works for forty years" (Heb. 3:9) and heard his voice, did not respond in faith and so failed to inherit the homeland God had promised to the patriarchs. In 1 Corinthians 10:1–11 Paul draws the same lesson from the wilderness generation's privileges ("baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea," nourished with spiritual food and drink), their rebellion (idolatry, immorality, complaint), and their resultant destruction.

<span id="page-63-15"></span><span id="page-63-10"></span><span id="page-63-1"></span>3:19 The root of Israel's rebellion was "unbelief," a refusal to trust that God would keep his word. The Lord said as much at Kadesh: "How long will this people despise me? And how long will they *not believe in me*, in spite of all the signs that I have done among them?" (Num. 14:11; cf. Deut. 9:23). Their refusal to embrace God's promise provoked his wrath and his solemn oath that they would not experience his rest, but our preacher will now encourage his new covenant listeners to enter a far greater rest than Canaan could ever have provided—through trusting the voice of the God who still speaks "today."

#### *Response*

The life of Christian believers parallels the time of Israel's wilderness generation. On the one hand, those Israelites had experienced God's mighty deliverance, leaving Egypt and its enslavement through Moses. On the other hand, however, they refused to believe that their divine protector could dispossess Canaan's pagan powers and give them the land he had promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Like that ancient people of God, we who have become Christ's companions, children of God being led to glory, have experienced rescue and liberation. But we are not "home" yet.

<span id="page-64-1"></span>Life in this world's wilderness offers many opportunities to see the Lord's works and come to know his ways. But it also tests our trust in him: will we "see through" sin's deceitfulness and listen eagerly to the living God's living word (4:12)? Or will we give credence to voices of doubt and discouragement, allowing a "root of bitterness" to spring up in the midst of our congregations, causing trouble and defiling many (12:15)?

<span id="page-64-5"></span><span id="page-64-4"></span><span id="page-64-3"></span><span id="page-64-2"></span>We have seen God perform greater works than those witnessed by ancient Israel. We have witnessed in the gospel the final sacrifice of Jesus the Son, which cleanses stained consciences "once for all" (9:14; 10:10); his resurrection from the dead (13:20); and his ascent to God's right hand as our ever-living, always interceding High Priest (6:19–20; 7:24–25; 8:1–2). The ground of our confidence is so substantive, so solid, that we have every reason to grip it firmly by faith to the end of our pilgrimage.

### <span id="page-64-0"></span>HEBREWS 4:1–13

4 Therefore, while the promise of entering his rest still stands, let us fear lest any of you should seem to have failed to reach it. **2**For good news came to us just as to them, but the message they heard did not benefit them, because they were not united by faith with those who listened.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>3</sup>**For we who have believed enter that rest, as he has said,

"As I swore in my wrath, 'They shall not enter my rest,' "

although his works were finished from the foundation of the world. **4**For he has somewhere spoken of the seventh day in this way: "And God rested on the seventh day from all his works." **5**And again in this passage he said,

"They shall not enter my rest."

**<sup>6</sup>** Since therefore it remains for some to enter it, and those who formerly received the good news failed to enter because of disobedience, **<sup>7</sup>** again he appoints a certain day, "Today," saying through David so long afterward, in the words already quoted,

"Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts."

**<sup>8</sup>**For if Joshua had given them rest, God*<sup>2</sup>* would not have spoken of another day later on. **<sup>9</sup>** So then, there remains a Sabbath rest for the people of God, **<sup>10</sup>** for whoever has entered God's rest has also rested from his works as God did from his.

**<sup>11</sup>**Let us therefore strive to enter that rest, so that no one may fall by the same sort of disobedience. **12**For the word of God is living and active, sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing to the division of soul and of spirit, of joints and of marrow, and discerning the thoughts and intentions of the heart. **13**And no creature is hidden from his sight, but all are naked and exposed to the eyes of him to whom we must give account.

1Some manuscripts *it did not meet with faith in the hearers* 2Greek *he*

#### *Section Overview: Entering God's Rest*

<span id="page-65-2"></span><span id="page-65-1"></span>The exposition and application of Psalm 95's commentary on Israel's wilderness generation, begun in Hebrews 3:7, continues and concludes in this section. The preacher now focuses on God's "rest," the destination of blessedness that the Promised Land represented for those who left Egypt with Moses. God's oath, which excluded unbelieving rebels, implied his promise that others coming later, whose hearts were not hardened but faith-filled, would enter his rest. Three features of OT Scripture converge to demonstrate that God's "rest" described in Psalm 95 cannot be reduced to the occupation of Canaan through the leadership of Joshua:

- (1) The psalm's opening word, "today," expands the audience to include not only David's generation, long after the conquest of Canaan, but also new covenant believers in Jesus.
- <span id="page-65-0"></span>(2) Genesis 2:2 shows that God's rest transcended the Israelites' possession of the Promised Land, having begun ages earlier when God finished creating the heavens and the earth.
- (3) The fact that Psalm 95 was written "through David so long afterward" (that is, after the death of the wilderness generation and their children's entrance into Canaan) indicates that the rest envisioned in the psalm transcends the rest from enemies in the Promised Land at the conclusion of Joshua's conquest (Heb. 4:6–8).

<span id="page-65-4"></span><span id="page-65-3"></span>The immediacy with which the Holy Spirit is addressing believers "today" gives urgency to the hortatory subjunctives (in which the author includes himself with his readers) bracketing the explanation of God's rest and the way to enter it: "Therefore . . . let us fear" (Heb. 4:1) and "Let us therefore strive" (v. 11). Although the wilderness generation's unbelief and resultant exclusion from God's rest warrant a response of sober fear, the psalm's implied promise that entry into God's rest is still possible gives hearers hope and fortifies their effort to hold fast in faith.

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-66-8"></span>I. We are entering God's rest by believing God's word (4:1–5)
	- A. Therefore let us fear, lest anyone fall short of God's rest (4:1)
	- B. Only those hearers who believe the good news of God's rest will enter it (4:2–3c)
	- C. God's rest began when he completed his work of creation (4:3d–4)
	- D. But those who do not believe God will never enjoy his rest (4:5)
- <span id="page-66-11"></span>II. In a new "today," God reissues the invitation to enter his rest (4:6–13)
	- A. Through David, long after the conquest of Canaan, God still invites hearers to enter his rest through trusting his word (4:6–7)
	- B. God's rest is far more than the rest from enemies achieved by Joshua's conquest (4:8)
	- C. Believers await a Sabbath celebration to come, when wilderness trials will be over (4:9–10)
	- D. Therefore let us strive to enter God's rest, responding in faith to God's living, heart-probing word (4:11–13)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-66-10"></span><span id="page-66-6"></span><span id="page-66-5"></span><span id="page-66-3"></span>4:1 The citation of Psalm 95:7–11 started with the call to hear God's voice with tender hearts (Heb. 3:7–8) and concluded with the divine oath that banned a generation of rebels from God's rest (3:11). These opening and closing statements have led our author to infer that the promise of entering God's rest remained open to subsequent generations, both David's (4:7) and ours (4:1, 3, 11). This inference is elaborated upon and supported in verses 6–7. God's promises concerning future events—things "yet unseen" (11:1, 7)—should elicit a forward-focused faith anchored in hope.

<span id="page-66-14"></span><span id="page-66-7"></span><span id="page-66-4"></span>As in 3:12–13 and again in 12:12–15, the whole congregation must "fear" and soberly embrace its corporate responsibility of mutual encouragement, lest any of its members fall short of (*hystereō*, "fail to reach") the "rest" that God has promised in his presence. Those united to Christ no longer fear death (2:15) or human threats (11:27; 13:6). But to have a reverent fear of the living God (10:31; 12:21), which makes us want to please him, is completely consistent with approaching his throne of grace confidently in Jesus (4:14–16).

<span id="page-66-13"></span><span id="page-66-12"></span><span id="page-66-9"></span><span id="page-66-2"></span><span id="page-66-1"></span><span id="page-66-0"></span>4:2 The hearers of Hebrews and the Israelites in the desert had in common not only that both groups heard God's voice, but also that they both heard "good news." For the Israelites, good news included God's promises to Abraham (Gen. 12:1–3; 15:13–21), his announcement through Moses that he was keeping those promises (Ex. 3:16–17; 4:27–31), and especially the encouragement of Joshua and Caleb at

<span id="page-67-3"></span><span id="page-67-0"></span>Kadesh that the Lord would conquer Canaan's pagan peoples and bring his people into the Promised Land (Num. 14:6–9). New covenant believers have heard even better news: the salvation spoken by the Lord Jesus and then confirmed by his apostles (Heb. 2:3–4; cf. 1:14), access to God's presence, freedom from the fear of death, and the hope of sharing the Messiah's crown of glory and ruling the world to come (2:5–15).

<span id="page-67-4"></span>A textual variant (cf. ESV mg.) offers a slightly different explanation for why the gospel spoken to the wilderness generation did them no good; this variant could be interpreted as stating either that the *message* was not joined with *faith* in those hearers, or, more likely, that *those who died in the desert* were not united with *those who heard the message in faith*, such as Caleb and Joshua. On either reading, the point is the same: hearing God's voice brings wrath, not benefit, to those who refuse to receive his message with submissive trust.

<span id="page-67-5"></span><span id="page-67-1"></span>4:3–4 In contrast to the unbelieving rebels in the desert, "We who have believed enter that rest." Some scholars argue that the present tense (progressive aspect) of "enter" implies that Christian believers have already left the "wilderness" in which faith is tested and have entered the "Promised Land" of God's rest (to use the typology that Hebrews is drawing from Psalm 95).8 Others suggest that the "already–not yet" tension in the Bible explains how Christians already experience God's rest even though they are still summoned to "strive to enter that rest" (Heb. 4:11). Hebrews will later affirm that the church's worship entails *present* participation in heavenly celebration, as we "*have come* . . . to . . . the heavenly Jerusalem" (12:22–24).9 Nevertheless, our author presents the trials of the desert, not rest in the Promised Land, as the ancient counterpart to our present experience. "Today," the redemptive-historical period in which God's voice is heard amid temptations to disbelieve, precedes believers' entrance into God's rest.10

<span id="page-67-8"></span><span id="page-67-7"></span><span id="page-67-6"></span><span id="page-67-2"></span>By characterizing the Promised Land as God's "rest" in reference to God's oath at Kadesh, Psalm 95 invests "rest" with *spatial* associations. Now our author shows that God's rest also has a *temporal* dimension: it began at the birth of the cosmos, when God finished his "works." In providence and in redemptive intervention, of course, God continues to work (Heb. 3:9; cf. John 5:17), but in terms of the original creation, God "rested . . . from all his works" on the seventh day (Heb. 4:4), delighting in what he had made. This means that God's rest itself stretches temporally over the history of the patriarchs, Israel's Egyptian enslavement and exodus, their forty years in the wilderness, their descendants' occupation of the Promised Land, the days of David, and the "today" in which Hebrew Christians (and we) hear God's voice as this sermon-letter is read.

<sup>8</sup> Andrew T. Lincoln, "Sabbath, Rest, and Eschatology in the New Testament, in D. A. Carson, ed., *From Sabbath to Lord's Day* (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 1982), 177–201; and Lane, *Hebrews 1–8*, 99.

<sup>9</sup> Thomas R. Schreiner, *Commentary on Hebrews*, Biblical Theology for Christian Proclamation (Nashville: Holman, 2015), 136–137.

<sup>10</sup> Richard B. Gaffin, Jr., "A Sabbath Rest Still Awaits the People of God," in C. G. Dennison and R. C. Gamble, *Pressing toward the Mark* (Philadelphia: The Orthodox Presbyterian Church, 1986), 33–51; and O'Brien, *Hebrews*, 164–166.

<span id="page-68-4"></span><span id="page-68-3"></span>4:5–7 The author elaborates on the reasoning behind the conclusion stated in verses 1–3, that God's oath at Kadesh, which denied access to disobedient rebels, implies God's promise that later generations could enter his rest if they believed and obeyed his voice "today." Since God had been enjoying his "rest" since creation, while the wilderness generation who "formerly heard good news failed to enter because of disobedience," God appointed another moment of opportunity, a "today," at a much later time, the time of King David, centuries after the conquest of Canaan led by Joshua. The significance of this timing for David's contemporaries and for later generations will be shown in verse 8.

<span id="page-68-6"></span><span id="page-68-5"></span><span id="page-68-2"></span>4:8 This is the first of three instances (cf. also 7:11–19; 8:7–13) in which Hebrews argues that various OT passages (such as Psalm 95) imply the insufficiency or imperfection of tokens of God's grace that were in place when those OT passages were given. The logic of the argument is that God would not have given the OT passages in question at all if those earlier tokens of his kindness had been adequate. Here our preacher reasons that if the "rest" Israel received through Joshua had been full and final, "God would not have spoken of another day later on." That is, he would not have spoken as he did through David in Psalm 95, announcing the prospect of entering his rest to a generation already inhabiting the Promised Land. Our author undoubtedly knows the summation that concludes the conquest of Canaan:

Thus the Lord gave to Israel all the land that he swore to give to their fathers. . . . And the Lord *gave them rest* on every side just as he had sworn to their fathers. Not one of all their enemies had withstood them, for the Lord had given all their enemies into their hands. Not one word of all the good promises that the Lord had made to the house of Israel had failed; all came to pass. (Josh. 21:43–45)
