<span id="page-68-0"></span>Nevertheless, the fact that God spoke Psalm 95 to David's generation, after the rest achieved through Joshua's conquest had given way to the turmoil of the period of the judges and Saul's monarchy, shows that "my rest" cannot be reduced to occupation of the Promised Land, or to a short-lived respite from warfare while residing in Canaan.

<span id="page-68-1"></span>"Rest" returned at one point in David's reign, for the narrator of Samuel echoes Joshua 21: "The king lived in his house and the Lord had *given him rest* from all his surrounding enemies" (2 Sam. 7:1). Nevertheless, for the psalm's first audience in David's generation, "today" and "God's rest" still represented contrasting and successive timeframes. "Today" God's voice was speaking, summoning hearers to embrace his promise with faith-filled hearts. The object of God's promise was his "rest," a future destination of *unthreatened and uninterrupted communion* with God, who is already resting from his creative labors. Canaan was merely a sign pointing upward and forward to the reality of God's rest. The land promised to the patriarchs as they remained "strangers and exiles on earth" was not, after all, <span id="page-69-9"></span>a homeland in this sin-sullied world but rather "a better country, that is, a heavenly one" (Heb. 11:13–16).

<span id="page-69-5"></span><span id="page-69-4"></span><span id="page-69-3"></span><span id="page-69-2"></span>4:9–10 Now for a third time our author assures us of the blessedness that "remains" available to those who, in our "today," hear God's voice and embrace his message with forward-focused faith. The promise of entering God's rest remains, spoken through David not only to his contemporaries but also to new covenant believers (4:1). Their entrance "remains" a real possibility, since the "today" that God appointed for our response continues into the present (4:6). Consequently, a Sabbath rest "remains" for the people of God (4:9). The Greek terms shift from the "rest" (*katapausis*) linking Psalm 95:11 and Genesis 2:2 to a noun (*sabbatismos*) not found elsewhere in biblical Greek (LXX or NT). This term is derived from a verb that means to "keep Sabbath" or "celebrate Sabbath." This new term adds, to the motif of "rest" as *cessation* from labor, the new note of *celebration* of freedom and joyful communion with God in his rest.

<span id="page-69-0"></span>This Sabbath celebration remains *future* for God's people, who trek as pilgrims through the hostile and faith-challenging wilderness of this world. This future character of "rest" is the point of the general maxim of verse 10, although at first glance it seems to speak of past or present experience: "Whoever *has entered* God's rest *has also rested* from his works." In other words, entering God's rest coincides with ceasing one's labors, in imitation of God's cessation of his creative labors on the seventh day of Genesis 2:2. Some theologians have understood "resting from one's works" as no longer relying on one's own obedience, trusting instead in Christ and his all-sufficient righteousness (cf. Rom. 3:20, 28; Gal. 2:16; Phil. 3:3–9). In support, they interpret "repentance from dead works" (Heb. 6:1) as a renunciation of efforts at commandment-keeping pursued in self-reliance and self-righteousness.

<span id="page-69-7"></span><span id="page-69-1"></span>For the recipients of Hebrews, however, the danger posed by Judaism was not a misplaced reliance on their own law-keeping but a misguided inclination to return to the sanctuary and sacrifices of the old covenant, abandoning Jesus and his once-for-all, conscience-purifying sacrifice. Here, the individual who rests from his works is not turning away from "works" assessed negatively. Rather, he is following God's *positive* example in Genesis, which set the precedent for Israel's weekly Sabbath observance. Resting from one's works marks the completion of the labors of this pilgrim life, along the lines of the benediction in Revelation 14:13: "Blessed are the dead who die in the Lord from now on. . . . that they may rest from their labors, for their deeds follow them!"

<span id="page-69-10"></span><span id="page-69-8"></span><span id="page-69-6"></span>4:11 Because entry into God's rest, which brings the cessation of our labors, is yet future, the preacher appeals to that destiny to motivate strenuous exertion: "Let us therefore *strive* to enter that rest." Perhaps the imagery of the Christian life as an athletic race (cf. 6:20; 12:1–3, 12–13) lies in the background of the author's choice of the verb translated "strive" (*spoudazō*), which urges hearers to expend all of their reserves of spiritual energy to persevere in faith and help one another endure. Lest any of their number "fall by the same sort of disobedience" as those who died in

<span id="page-70-7"></span>the wilderness, the whole congregation must support its weak, wounded, and prone-to-wander members (cf. 3:12–13; 4:1; 12:12–15).

<span id="page-70-9"></span><span id="page-70-4"></span><span id="page-70-2"></span>4:12–13 The exposition and application of Psalm 95, which warns against hearing God's voice with hardened hearts, draws to a fitting close in a description of God's word as living and effective, sharp enough to cut to the heart's hidden depths, discerning our secret thoughts and intentions. Scripture elsewhere compares the word to a sharp sword wielded by the Lord's servant, the divine warrior whose very name is "the word of God" (Isa. 49:2; Eph. 6:17; cf. Rev. 1:16; 2:12; 19:13–15). As the speech of the living God (Heb. 3:12; Deut. 5:26), who binds himself by swearing an oath based on his endless life (Heb. 3:11; 6:13–18; Num. 14:21–23; Gen. 22:15–18), the word itself is alive. God knows everyone through and through, and no creature is hidden from his eyes, for all lie exposed and utterly vulnerable. Therefore his word cuts us to the core.

<span id="page-70-6"></span><span id="page-70-5"></span><span id="page-70-3"></span><span id="page-70-1"></span><span id="page-70-0"></span>The mention of "the division of soul and of spirit, of joints and of marrow" is intended not to draw psychological or anatomical distinctions but to dramatize the skill by which God uses his word to penetrate our apparently impenetrable recesses. The God who sees our hidden inner life (Acts 1:24; 15:8; Rom. 8:27; 1 Cor. 4:5) is a judge who will not be deceived by pious appearances (Isa. 11:3–4; John 2:23–25). Mercifully, this all-seeing divine judge has provided for guilty rebels a Great High Priest, Jesus the Son of God, who has experienced their temptations and now represents them before his throne—a throne of *grace*—in heaven (Heb. 4:14–16).

#### <span id="page-70-10"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-70-8"></span>Two exhortations—"let us fear" and "let us . . . strive" (Heb. 4:1, 11)—surround the concluding phase of the discussion of Psalm 95. These admonitions signal the responses that the Holy Spirit, who is speaking Psalm 95 yet "today," seeks as he invites us to enter God's rest through heeding his voice with trusting hearts. The history of the Israelite rebels at Kadesh should move us to sober fear. They refused to believe the good news that they heard, and their bodies fell in the wilderness. We must avoid at all cost their example of doubt and disobedience. Yet the land their children subsequently occupied was a sign pointing upward and forward to a far better "rest"—God's rest, which remains open to those who believe the good news now delivered by God's last, best spokesman, Jesus the Son. We strive in anticipation of the rest that awaits us at the climax of our earthly pilgrimage, for it is faith in Christ's work (not ours) that places us in the lifelong process of entering God's rest.

### <span id="page-71-7"></span>OVERVIEW OF HEBREWS 4:14–7:28

<span id="page-71-12"></span><span id="page-71-1"></span>The central section of this sermon-letter explores its main point (Heb. 8:1), the superior high priestly ministry of Jesus in contrast to the priestly mediation of the Aaronic priests descended from the tribe of Levi. This discussion has two parts: First, our preacher shows that Jesus' *qualifications* for priestly office in the order of Melchizedek, foretold in Psalm 110:4, surpass those of the priests descended from Aaron (Heb. 4:14–7:28). Second, he demonstrates how Jesus' priestly *ministry*  is superior with respect to the heavenly sanctuary in which he serves and the conscience-cleansing sacrifice he has offered (8:1–10:31). At this point in the sermon (4:14), emphasis shifts from Christ's role in *revelation*—his superiority to prophets, angels, and Moses (1:1–4:13)—to Christ's role in *reconciliation*—his superiority to the OT priestly office associated with the tribe of Levi and the family of Aaron and to the animal sacrifices those priests offered in Israel's earthly sanctuary.

<span id="page-71-13"></span><span id="page-71-8"></span><span id="page-71-6"></span><span id="page-71-5"></span><span id="page-71-4"></span><span id="page-71-3"></span><span id="page-71-2"></span>Hebrews 4:14–7:28 directs our attention to the qualifications authorizing Jesus to be our "great high priest" (4:14), "a merciful and faithful high priest in the service of God" on our behalf, as he was previously described (2:17). In order to be the merciful intercessor that weak sinners need, Jesus must be fully human, tempted, and acquainted by personal experience with weakness and suffering (4:14–5:3, 7–8). He must also be appointed by God, not self-nominated, to the privilege of standing on others' behalf in the presence of the Holy One (5:4–6, 9–10). In both of these respects Jesus' priestly qualifications and appointment resemble Aaron's. But Jesus' qualifications are better than Aaron's, for he is the royal priest "after the order of Melchizedek," foretold in Psalm 110:4. This priesthood derives its authority not from a principle of genealogical descent traced back through Aaron to Levi but from an oath sworn by God himself, which secures this priest's office "forever" by "the power of an indestructible life" (Heb. 7:1–28).

<span id="page-71-11"></span><span id="page-71-10"></span><span id="page-71-9"></span><span id="page-71-0"></span>Jesus' superior, eternal priestly office, fulfilling the pattern left by the mysterious Melchizedek of Genesis 14, is a theme on which much needs to be said. But the hearers' dullness of ears will make it "hard to explain" (Heb. 5:11). Therefore, amid his elaboration of Jesus' Melchizedek-like priestly appointment, our preacher again embeds a bracing exhortation. He calls his hearers to grow up by imitating Abraham's faith, for God's oath gives us every reason to trust his promises (5:11–6:20).

### <span id="page-72-0"></span>HEBREWS 4:14–5:10

**<sup>14</sup>** Since then we have a great high priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus, the Son of God, let us hold fast our confession. **15**For we do not have a high priest who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but one who in every respect has been tempted as we are, yet without sin. **<sup>16</sup>**Let us then with confidence draw near to the throne of grace, that we may receive mercy and find grace to help in time of need.

5 For every high priest chosen from among men is appointed to act on behalf of men in relation to God, to offer gifts and sacrifices for sins. **<sup>2</sup>**He can deal gently with the ignorant and wayward, since he himself is beset with weakness. **3**Because of this he is obligated to offer sacrifice for his own sins just as he does for those of the people. **4**And no one takes this honor for himself, but only when called by God, just as Aaron was.

**<sup>5</sup>** So also Christ did not exalt himself to be made a high priest, but was appointed by him who said to him,

"You are my Son, today I have begotten you";

**<sup>6</sup>** as he says also in another place,

"You are a priest forever, after the order of Melchizedek."

**<sup>7</sup>** In the days of his flesh, Jesus*<sup>1</sup>* offered up prayers and supplications, with loud cries and tears, to him who was able to save him from death, and he was heard because of his reverence. **8**Although he was a son, he learned obedience through what he suffered. **9**And being made perfect, he became the source of eternal salvation to all who obey him, **10**being designated by God a high priest after the order of Melchizedek.

1Greek *he*

#### *Section Overview: Our Tested and Sympathetic High Priest*

<span id="page-72-2"></span><span id="page-72-1"></span>Having instilled in his hearers a fear of rebelling against God's voice and thus failing to enter God's rest, our pastor turns to the only theme that can assuage a guilty and terrified conscience: the high priestly ministry of Jesus. The author's pastoral strategy is to motivate his hearers' perseverance by issuing terrifying warnings about the dire consequences of unbelief (Heb. 6:4–8; 10:26–31) and then offering encouragements grounded in God's grace (6:9–12; 10:32–39). With warnings he prods Christians out of complacency. With encouragements he safeguards them

from misgivings about God's gracious disposition toward those who, despite their weakness and sin, nonetheless approach him through Jesus.

Two qualifications for priestly mediation between a holy God and his unholy people are shared by the OT priests (Aaron and his descendants) and the Great High Priest (Jesus Christ): human weakness and divine call. Since both the Aaronic priests and Jesus have experienced weakness and temptation, they can extend sympathy to the tempted, weak, and failing worshipers for whom they offer sacrifice and intercession. And both the OT high priests and Jesus have been authorized by God to enter his Holy Place and approach his throne. God is so majestic a sovereign that no creature may seize for himself the honor of approaching God on behalf of others. That privilege can be granted only by the King himself. These shared qualifications are discussed in chiastic order:

- <span id="page-73-5"></span><span id="page-73-3"></span>(A) Christ's weakness and sympathy (4:14–16)
	- (B) Aaron's weakness and sympathy (5:1–3)
	- (B') Aaron's call from God (5:4)
- <span id="page-73-8"></span><span id="page-73-7"></span>(A') Christ's call from God (5:5–10)

<span id="page-73-6"></span><span id="page-73-4"></span><span id="page-73-0"></span>Although Aaron and Jesus have these priestly credentials in common, the contrasts between them are even more striking. Jesus, though tempted in weakness, withstood every temptation "without sin" (4:15). Aaron, on the other hand, had to "offer sacrifice for his own sins" before he could do so for the people (5:3; cf. 7:27). As Hebrews 7:15–26 will elaborate, Jesus is priest "forever" (5:6, citing Ps. 110:4), whereas God appointed Aaron and his descendants through a principle of genealogy that presupposed their deaths.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. Jesus, like Aaron, is qualified to serve as a merciful priest through his experience of human weakness and testing (4:14–5:3)
	- A. Jesus, the Son of God, is a priest who can sympathize with our weaknesses, so we must hold to our confession and draw near to God's throne of grace (4:14–16)
	- B. Aaron and his sons were priests beset by weakness, so they could deal gently with the wayward (5:1–3)
- II. Like Aaron, Jesus is qualified to serve as a faithful priest through his appointment by God (5:4–10)
	- A. Aaron and his sons were called by God to be priests (5:4)
	- B. Christ the Son was appointed by God as priest, consecrated for his ministry through suffering and resurrection (5:5–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-73-2"></span><span id="page-73-1"></span>4:14 In Hebrews 2:17–18 Jesus was introduced as a "*merciful* and faithful *high priest*," "made *like* his brothers *in every respect*," who "*suffered* when *tempted*" so that he can *help* those who are likewise tempted. The reappearance of these italicized <span id="page-74-17"></span><span id="page-74-7"></span>words links 4:14–16 to 2:17–18. Later, our preacher will signal the conclusion of his discussion of Jesus' priestly office and ministry by repeating terms from 4:14–16 in 10:19–25: "Since *we have a great priest* . . . let us *draw near*. . . . *Let us hold fast the confession*."

<span id="page-74-0"></span>In the Hebrew OT, the expression behind our English "the high priest" is "the great priest" (*hakkohen haggadol*), and the LXX usually reflects this formulation (*ho hiereus ho megas*) (Num. 35:25–32; cf. Heb. 10:21). Here, to emphasize our High Priest's superiority to the order of Aaron, our author adds the adjective "great" to the Greek term "high priest" (*archiereus*), which emerged in later Greek (*Maccabees* and NT). Two features show Jesus' superior priestly status. First, he has "passed through the heavens." This exaltation is implied in his seat at God's right hand (Ps. 110:1, introduced in Heb. 1:3, 13). The heavenly venue Jesus entered as priest is the original sanctuary, of which the earthly tabernacle was a copy (7:26; 8:4–5; 9:11–12, 24). Second, Jesus is "the Son of God," whom God addressed as such in Psalm 2:7 (Heb. 1:5). As Son he is the radiance of God's glory, the agent of creation, the ruler worthy to be addressed as "God," and the ruler over God's house.

<span id="page-74-16"></span><span id="page-74-15"></span><span id="page-74-11"></span><span id="page-74-10"></span><span id="page-74-2"></span><span id="page-74-1"></span>Earlier exhortations to "hold fast our confession" were supported by a negative motive: the spiritual peril of unbelief in the face of wilderness trials (cf. 3:6, 12–14). Now the motive is positive: our Great High Priest suffered with us and can help us. "Confession" (*homologia*) signals believers' corporate responsibility to encourage each other's perseverance, as it refers to what Christians believe and verbally affirm together (3:1; 10:23).

<span id="page-74-12"></span><span id="page-74-9"></span>4:15 The arresting use of a double negative, "*not* . . . a high priest who is *un*able to sympathize with our weaknesses," implies that the Great High Priest's identification with weak and tempted sinners is unexpected in light of his divine dignity. Earlier, the truth that the Son is "not ashamed to call them brothers" took us by surprise (2:11–12). Now his *sympathy* astonishes us.

<span id="page-74-18"></span><span id="page-74-8"></span><span id="page-74-4"></span>The English "sympathize," although derived from the Greek verb used here (*sympatheō*; also in 10:34), may mislead us. When we "sympathize" with sufferers, we attempt to identify emotionally with their distress. Jesus goes deeper, *sharing* his people's experience of suffering, having been tempted when suffering (2:18) and having learned obedience from what he suffered (5:8). Greek speakers would hear the resonance of "sympathize," "deal gently" (*metriopathein*; 5:2), and "suffer" (*epathen*; 5:8) in this section.

<span id="page-74-19"></span><span id="page-74-14"></span><span id="page-74-13"></span><span id="page-74-6"></span><span id="page-74-5"></span><span id="page-74-3"></span>Our preacher previously affirmed the Son's complete participation in human flesh and blood, becoming "like his brothers in every respect" (2:14, 17). Now he introduces the crucial exception to the similarity between Jesus and other human beings: though tempted in every way as they are, Jesus withstood every temptation "without sin." Jesus' complete innocence and freedom from sin is affirmed throughout the NT (Luke 23:41; John 7:18; 8:46; 14:30–31; 2 Cor. 5:21; 1 Pet. 1:19; 2:22; 3:18; 1 John 3:5). Without this difference, he could not be our perfectly "*faithful* high priest in the service of God" (Heb. 2:17). But in fact he is "holy, inno<span id="page-75-12"></span><span id="page-75-8"></span>cent, unstained, separated from sinners" (7:26–27). Jesus' sinless purity sets him apart from every priest in Aaron's line (5:2–3).

<span id="page-75-13"></span><span id="page-75-11"></span><span id="page-75-6"></span>4:16 With such a High Priest, simultaneously compassionate and sinless, we can "with confidence draw near" to God's divine throne. To those who approach through Jesus' mediation, it is a "throne of grace." The imagery evoked by "drawing near" is the approach of worshipers to the sanctuary (7:25; 10:1) and the high priest's entrance into the Most Holy Place on the Day of Atonement (10:19–21). Elsewhere in the NT, "confidence" ( *parrēsia*) characterizes fearless proclamation (Acts 4:13; 9:28; 14:3; Eph. 6:19; Phil. 1:20). In Hebrews, "confidence" entails the worshipers' anticipation of divine favor as they draw near to God (3:6; 10:19, 35), their consciences cleansed of guilt through Jesus' sacrifice so that the "consuming fire" (12:29) of God's holiness no longer threatens them.

<span id="page-75-15"></span><span id="page-75-14"></span><span id="page-75-5"></span><span id="page-75-4"></span>"Mercy" and "grace" are related, but mercy may refer specifically to forgiveness while grace may refer more generally to the unmerited favor by which God strengthens struggling hearts (13:9). God's grace brings timely help—just when temptation and suffering are most intense. The translation "in time of need" represents a single adjective, *eukairos*. Elsewhere in the NT this word group refers to opportune moments (Mark 6:21; 14:11; 2 Tim. 4:2).

<span id="page-75-10"></span><span id="page-75-7"></span><span id="page-75-3"></span>5:1 This verse sums up the high priest's qualifications and tasks, thereby implying how fitting Christ's incarnation, temptation, and suffering are to his ministry as the "great high priest." The following sentences unpack aspects of this description. "Every high priest" is "from among men," sharing human nature and weakness with others so that he can "act on behalf of men in relation to God" (cf. 5:2–3, 9). He is "chosen" (or "taken," *lambanomenos*) through God's initiative and "appointed" (*kathistēmi*, see Num. 3:10 LXX) by God, not self-nominated (Heb. 5:4–5, 10). He is appointed "to offer gifts and sacrifices for sins" (cf. 5:3, 7–8).

<span id="page-75-9"></span><span id="page-75-2"></span><span id="page-75-0"></span>5:2–3 The Aaronic high priest could "deal gently" with people who violated God's commands inadvertently, in ignorance. (The law distinguished sins committed "unintentionally" from defiant rebellion: Num. 15:27–31; Lev. 4:2, 13, 22, 27.) As noted in the comment on Heb. 4:15, the Greek verb (*metriopatheō*) reflected in "deal gently" shares a stem ( *path*-) with "sympathize" (4:15). But the parallel between Jesus and Aaron is not exact. Aaron's gentle treatment of the wayward meant restraining his reaction of righteous indignation or revulsion over others' failures. Such restraint was fitting, since Aaron was not only "beset" by weakness but was also guilty of sins, needing atonement himself. Jesus' compassion is more outgoing and tender, not compelled by a guilty conscience (for he was "without sin"; 4:15) but moved with a pity that can spring only from pure innocence.

<span id="page-75-1"></span>The rituals for the Day of Atonement demonstrated the guilt of every OT high priest. Before he could offer a sacrifice for the people's sins, he had to offer a bull "as a sin offering for himself and . . . make atonement for himself and for his house" (Lev. 16:6–14). Then he could "kill the goat of the sin offering that is for the <span id="page-76-19"></span><span id="page-76-1"></span>people" (Lev. 16:15–19). Our preacher will keep before our minds this crucial difference between Aaron's sin-stained line and our sinless mediator (Heb. 7:27; 9:7).

<span id="page-76-16"></span><span id="page-76-0"></span>5:4 The honor of approaching the sovereign Lord is not ours for the taking but can be bestowed only by God himself. The Lord called Aaron and his sons to serve as Israel's priestly intercessors (Ex. 28:1). The Levite Korah and his Reubenite coconspirators challenged Aaron's unique access to God's presence (Numbers 16), but God destroyed the rebels and reaffirmed his choice of Aaron by causing Aaron's staff alone to sprout buds and blossoms (Num. 17:8–10; Heb. 9:4).

<span id="page-76-17"></span><span id="page-76-12"></span><span id="page-76-11"></span><span id="page-76-10"></span><span id="page-76-6"></span><span id="page-76-3"></span><span id="page-76-2"></span>5:5–6 "So also Christ" did not seize the glory of high priestly office for himself. The ESV "exalt" could be rendered "glorify" (*doxazō*). "Honor" and "glory" have appeared together in Hebrews 2:7, 9; 3:3. Our author has already used the title "Christ" (Anointed One) and spoken of his anointing (3:6, 14; cf. 1:9). Here the title brings us back to Psalm 2:7, the first of the OT series of passages addressing the Son's superiority to angels (Heb. 1:5), in which the Lord declares to his Anointed One, "You are my Son." The syntax of this direct address is parallel to Psalm 110:4: "You are a priest." The grammatical parallel linking these "You are . . ." statements supports the identification drawn in Hebrews 4:14: the "great high priest" is "the Son of God." Other features of Psalm 110:4—this priest's "forever" tenure in office and the template provided by the ancient priest-king Melchizedek—will be unfolded in chapter 7.

<span id="page-76-18"></span><span id="page-76-14"></span>5:7 The procedure by which God installed Christ as priest was neither ritualized (as was Aaron's) nor painless. Thus, in elaborating the truth that Christ received his priestly appointment by God's decree, our author elaborates on the suffering under testing that made Jesus the most merciful of priests. The "days of his flesh" were the period of his humble incarnate life on earth, from the moment he came to share our flesh and blood (2:14), assuming a true human body vulnerable to harm and death (10:5–10), to his resurrection from the dead.

<span id="page-76-20"></span><span id="page-76-15"></span><span id="page-76-13"></span><span id="page-76-8"></span><span id="page-76-4"></span>The same liturgical term ( *prospherō*) that had been used to describe the high priest's "offering" of sacrifices for sins (5:1, 3) now describes how Jesus "offered up prayers and supplications, with loud cries and tears." The desperate pleas that Christ offered corresponded in some way to the animals sacrificed by Aaronic priests. Jesus' prayers, shouts, and tears "to him who was able to save him from death" became intense in the garden of Gethsemane (Luke 22:41–44) and then on the cross. But even before then our Lord had drawn words from Psalm 6:3–4 to lament, "Now is my soul troubled. And what shall I say? 'Father, save me from this hour'? But for this purpose I have come to this hour. Father, glorify your name" (John 12:27–28). His plea, "Abba, Father, all things are possible for you. Remove this cup from me" (Mark 14:36), was a desperate appeal to "him who was able to save him from death."

<span id="page-76-9"></span><span id="page-76-7"></span><span id="page-76-5"></span>The cup of divine wrath was not removed without the sinless Savior's draining it to its dregs. How, then, can our preacher claim (in words drawn from Pss. 22:24; <span id="page-77-2"></span><span id="page-77-1"></span><span id="page-77-0"></span>116:1) that Jesus "was heard" by the God to whom he cried for rescue? In Scripture, for God to "hear" is for him to answer his servants' petition in the affirmative. Some theorize that the request referenced here was not for deliverance from death but was rather "Not what I will, but what you will" (Mark 14:36) or "Glorify your name" (John 12:28). But the description of God as "him who was able to save him from death" gives us the content of Christ's petition. Only through his resurrection was Jesus' plea for rescue from death both heard and answered "because of his reverence." His reverent offering of his body in accord with the Father's will (Heb. 10:5–10) was rewarded when "the God of peace . . . brought again from the dead our Lord Jesus" (13:20; cf. Acts 2:24–28). God's answer came "not by Jesus escaping death, or the fear of death, but by his transcending death through his resurrection and exaltation at God's right hand."11

<span id="page-77-11"></span><span id="page-77-10"></span><span id="page-77-7"></span><span id="page-77-4"></span><span id="page-77-3"></span>5:8 The Son's path to priesthood passed through suffering. From the standpoint of his divine identity, his suffering is incongruous, as the concessive "*although* he was a son" shows. For human sons and daughters—the "many sons" whom God is bringing to glory (2:10)—suffering is to be expected as a sign of our legitimacy in the faith (12:5–8). But it is shocking that the unique Son, who is the radiance of God's glory, would suffer and would "learn obedience" through that suffering. The author skillfully conjoins forms of the Greek verbs "learn" (*manthanō*) and "suffer" ( *paschō*) that rhyme with each other: *emathen . . . epathen* ("he learned . . . he suffered"). A gifted rhetorician, our preacher gives attention to how his language will strike hearers' ears.

<span id="page-77-6"></span>The Son's uniqueness in contrast to humans sets his "learning" apart from theirs. Human children "learn obedience" through correction after they disobey, whereas Jesus never disobeyed (4:15). His "learning obedience," therefore, did not involve the painful correction that sinful children need. Instead it involved his experiential encounter, throughout his life and climaxing in his death, with the overwhelming personal cost of the commitment he embraced as he entered our world at his incarnation: "When Christ came into the world, he said, '. . . Behold, I have come to do your will, O God, as it is written of me in the scroll of the book'" (10:5–7).

<span id="page-77-9"></span><span id="page-77-8"></span><span id="page-77-5"></span>5:9–10 Although suffering is incompatible with the Son's deity, it was both fitting and necessary to his priestly office as our *merciful* High Priest for Christ to experience our weakness and the pangs of our suffering. This mission is what required him to share fully in our embodied, vulnerable humanity (2:14–18). Thus the author concludes this discussion of Jesus' installation into priestly office in two syntactically parallel and semantically complementary ways:

- being made perfect . . .
- being designated by God a high priest . . .

<sup>11</sup> Johnson, *Hebrews*, 146.

<span id="page-78-3"></span><span id="page-78-0"></span>As noted in the comment on 2:10, for Christ to be "made perfect" (*teleioō*) refers not to his transition from a state of moral defect into blamelessness but rather to his induction into priestly office, reflecting LXX usage in passages describing the consecration of OT priests (Ex. 29:9, 29, 33, 35; Lev. 4:5; 8:33; 16:32; 21:10; Num. 3:3; etc.). Here the parallel participle "being designated by God a high priest" (Heb. 5:10) confirms this interpretation of "made perfect."

<span id="page-78-9"></span><span id="page-78-8"></span><span id="page-78-7"></span><span id="page-78-1"></span>Through weakness, temptation, suffering, death, and resurrection, Jesus has been inducted into a uniquely superior high priestly order. This order is "after the order of Melchizedek," heavenly and everlasting, a topic on which our preacher will have "much to say," following an extensive exhortation to his hearers (5:11–6:20). Yet Jesus' ministry is better than that of Aaron not only because of its celestial venue and longevity but also because of its purifying and reconciling effectiveness. Jesus has become "the source of *eternal* salvation to all who obey him" (5:9) because he entered God's sanctuary with his own blood, "securing an *eternal* redemption" (9:11–14). Isaiah praised the Lord for saving Israel with "everlasting salvation" (Isa. 45:17), and the cross demonstrates the price the Son paid to "save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him" (Heb. 7:25).

#### <span id="page-78-11"></span><span id="page-78-10"></span><span id="page-78-2"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-78-5"></span><span id="page-78-4"></span>Two exhortations in Hebrews 4:14–16 show the response that God intends to elicit from us as he reveals the perfect, permanent High Priest, "Jesus, the Son of God." Along the route of our pilgrimage through this life's "wilderness," from the slavery behind us to the eternal safety of the home ahead, we must, first, "hold fast our confession" (4:14). Together, as companions in Christ's community, we must support and reinforce one another's conviction, confidence, and commitment to the living God who speaks in Scripture. Yet, beset with weakness as we are, how can fragile, fickle people like us "hold fast"?

<span id="page-78-6"></span>The second exhortation shows the way: "Let us then with confidence draw near to the throne of grace" (4:16), for there we will receive mercy, grace, and timely help. The resource fortifying our perseverance is the grace that God bestows when we enter his presence. But we dare enter his presence only because he has provided a Great High Priest, perfect in his reverent piety toward God and simultaneously compassionate toward us, having experienced temptation and suffering. Jesus has "passed through the heavens" (4:14) to serve on our behalf in his Father's presence, and so we dare to draw near. There we will find the Father's storehouses of sustaining grace thrown wide open to us in our need.

### <span id="page-79-5"></span>OVERVIEW OF HEBREWS 5:11–6:20

<span id="page-79-2"></span><span id="page-79-0"></span>Our preacher has introduced the sermon's central motif, Jesus' ministry as "high priest after the order of Melchizedek" (Heb. 5:6, 10), a topic about which he has "much to say" (5:11). But before he explains why the priesthood patterned after Melchizedek is better than that of Aaron, the author pauses to issue a blunt rebuke to his hearers for their "dull" ears and immature spiritual appetite, which complicate his teaching task. He urges them to grow up in faith. The boundaries of this exhortation section are signaled by the mention of "a high priest after the order of Melchizedek" at its beginning (5:10) and end (6:20).

<span id="page-79-4"></span><span id="page-79-1"></span>The exhortation comes in two phases. The first phase (5:11–6:12) opens and closes with *nōthros* ("dull" in 5:11; "sluggish" in 6:12). Its tone is primarily negative, rebuking immaturity and warning against apostasy. We will examine this first phase in two installments: a summons to grow up (5:11–6:3) and a terrifying warning against apostasy, accompanied by a word of reassurance (6:4–12).

<span id="page-79-10"></span><span id="page-79-9"></span><span id="page-79-8"></span><span id="page-79-7"></span><span id="page-79-6"></span>The second phase of the exhortation (6:13–20) springs from the mention of exemplars of persevering faith (6:12), among whom Abraham is prominent. Abraham's history motivates hearers by focusing on the oath by which God guaranteed his promises to Abraham and others "who have fled for refuge" to God's care (6:16). The mention of Abraham and the motif of oath converge to bring the discussion back to Melchizedek (6:20), the patriarch's priestly mediator (7:1–10) and the pattern for a superior priestly order, secured by God's oath (7:11–28).

### <span id="page-79-3"></span>HEBREWS 5:11–6:3

**<sup>11</sup>**About this we have much to say, and it is hard to explain, since you have become dull of hearing. **12**For though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you again the basic principles of the oracles of God. You need milk, not solid food, **<sup>13</sup>** for everyone who lives on milk is unskilled in the word of righteousness, since he is a child. **14**But solid food is for the mature, for those who have their powers of discernment trained by constant practice to distinguish good from evil.

6 Therefore let us leave the elementary doctrine of Christ and go on to maturity, not laying again a foundation of repentance from dead works and of faith toward God, **<sup>2</sup>** and of instruction about washings,*<sup>1</sup>* the laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment. **<sup>3</sup>**And this we will do if God permits.

1Or *baptisms* (that is, cleansing rites)

#### *Section Overview: Exhortation: Move On to Maturity*

The metaphor of infants' and adults' intellectual and dietary capacities unifies this section. The hearers have followed Jesus long enough that their grasp of the gospel and response to persecution should be more mature than it is. By now they should understand God's words well enough to teach others, but instead they need someone to teach them the simple alphabet. They should be able to chew solid food but can only ingest milk, lacking the discernment that comes through practice in applying God's word to life. They remain fixated on foundational OT doctrines and practices that belong to (lit.) "the beginning of the word of the Messiah" (*ton tēs archēs tou Christou logon*; Heb. 6:1). These preliminary elements are related to Christ and his mission, but the hearers should have been discerning enough to understand them in the context of God's "last days" speaking in the Son. Our preacher therefore summons his hearers to move forward into maturity, and he intends to lead them there as God enables them.

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-80-0"></span>I. Your dull immaturity impedes your grasp of Christ's superior priesthood (5:11–14)
	- A. Your dull ears impede your understanding of vital truth (5:11)
	- B. Your immaturity is inexcusable in light of your longevity in faith (5:12a)
	- C. Your immaturity restricts your spiritual diet (5:12b–14)
		- 1. You need milky basics, not firm food (5:12bc)
		- 2. Babies cannot ingest the solid word of righteousness (5:13)
		- 3. Adults consume solid food with theological and ethical discernment (5:14)
- II. We must advance toward maturity, rather than remaining in the basics (6:1–3)
	- A. We must move on from OT foundations, the beginning of the Messiah's word (6:1–2)
		- 1. Foundations of covenant commitment: repentance and faith
		- 2. Foundations of cultic cleansing: ritual washings and laying on of hands
		- 3. Foundations of covenant sanctions: resurrection and judgment
	- B. We can move toward maturity only through God's aid (6:3)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-81-7"></span><span id="page-81-2"></span>5:11 Jesus' priesthood in the order of Melchizedek deserves an explanation that will be both lengthy and "hard to explain." The source of the difficulty lies not in the complexity of the subject but in the sluggishness of the students. They have become "dull of hearing," sluggish in their organs of hearing (*akoais*; cf. Mark 7:35; Acts 17:20). Greek had a specific word for "ear" (*ous*;Matt. 11:15), but the term used here fits Psalm 95's warning against *hearing* God's voice in unbelief.

<span id="page-81-12"></span><span id="page-81-3"></span><span id="page-81-1"></span><span id="page-81-0"></span>The preacher is about to embarrass his hearers for their infantile incapacity to "digest" the solid food he intends to serve. But theirs is not a case of arrested development. It is worse: they "have become" sluggish, relapsing from an earlier, healthier spiritual state, of which he will remind them (Heb. 6:9–10; 10:32–34). A confluence of external opposition and internal misgivings about the sufficiency of Christ threatens to pull them back from their prior confidence and courage.

<span id="page-81-8"></span><span id="page-81-6"></span><span id="page-81-4"></span>5:12 The preacher's original hearers have been followers of Jesus long enough that their immaturity is inexcusable. By now they "ought to be teachers." Not every Christian has the spiritual gift and ecclesiastical office of teaching (1 Cor. 12:27–30; James 3:1), but all should be maturing in their grasp of biblical truth and its application, able to "exhort one another every day" against sin's deceitfulness (Heb. 3:12–13; cf. Rom. 15:14; Heb. 10:24–25). Extending the educational imagery, they need to be sent back to the beginning: "basic principles" represents the Greek *stoicheia*, which can refer to a language's alphabet, the starting point of learning to read. They are like "children in the kindergarten who, unable to read or write, have to start at the very beginning by learning their ABCs."12 The "basic principles of the oracles of God" are "the elementary doctrine of Christ" (Heb. 6:1)—a connection visible in Greek through the repetition of key terms (*archē*; *logiōn/logos*). These principles include the six features constituting the "foundation" from which believers in Jesus must advance (cf. comment on 6:1–2).

<span id="page-81-11"></span><span id="page-81-10"></span><span id="page-81-9"></span>5:13–14 At the end of verse 12 the imagery shifts from the school classroom to the family dining room, where infants imbibe milk while solid food is reserved for the mature. The "child" who lives on milk is very young (*nēpios*), an infant not yet able to chew solid food. "Solid food" corresponds to the rich instruction our preacher wishes to impart, if his hearers' spiritual lethargy can be overcome. The "word of righteousness," with which babies are "unskilled" or unacquainted, includes Jesus' high priesthood in the order of Melchizedek. But it also has a strong ethical component, since the mature have moral discernment to distinguish good from evil. The apostle Paul used the same metaphor to rebuke the Christians of Corinth, who displayed their childishness in boastful competition: "I fed you with milk, not solid food, for you were not ready for it. . . . For while there is jealousy and strife among you, are you not of the flesh and behaving only in a human way?" (1 Cor. 3:2–3).

<span id="page-81-5"></span><sup>12</sup> Philip Edgcumbe Hughes, *A Commentary on the Epistle to the Hebrews* (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 1977), 190.

<span id="page-82-11"></span><span id="page-82-3"></span><span id="page-82-2"></span>A third metaphor, athletic training through "constant practice," shows that growth in discernment does not occur through theological instruction alone. Our preacher will invoke athletic imagery also in Hebrews 6:20 ("forerunner") and in 12:1–2, 11–13 (cf. 1 Cor. 9:24–27; Phil. 3:13–14; 1 Tim. 4:7–8; 2 Tim. 2:5; 4:7). As Psalm 95 showed, hearing God's voice must be met by a readiness to trust his words and respond appropriately. Like an athlete's muscles, the believer's skill to make choices pleasing to God grows strong when "trained" (*gegymnasmena*) through repeated exercise in obedient action. "Discernment" (*aisthētēria*; only here in NT) is accurate perception of reality, enabling one to weigh the relative value of alternative courses of action and choose what is superior. Using a cognate term, Paul prayed that Philippian Christians would be given "discernment" (*aisthēsis*) to approve of what is excellent (Phil. 1:9–10).

<span id="page-82-4"></span><span id="page-82-0"></span>The need to "distinguish good from evil" probably alludes to the tree of the knowledge of good and evil and the issue it posed: By what standard—by whose word—would Adam and Eve make ethical decisions (Gen. 2:16–17; 3:1–7)? Sin is deceitful, as Eve sadly acknowledged (Gen. 3:13) and as our author has said (Heb. 3:13). Discernment is needed to expose Satan's plausible-sounding lies.

<span id="page-82-9"></span><span id="page-82-8"></span><span id="page-82-7"></span><span id="page-82-5"></span><span id="page-82-1"></span>6:1–2 A symptom of the hearers' immaturity is their preoccupation with the "elementary doctrine of Christ," that is, aspects of God's revelation belonging to the era "long ago," when "God spoke to our fathers by the prophets" (Heb. 1:1). "The beginning of the word of the Messiah" (woodenly rendering the Greek) is another description of "the basic principles [alphabet] of the oracles of God" (5:12). Christians are to "leave" this earlier revelation, but not by dismissing it as worthless, for it is a "foundation" for faith that has been laid and does not need to be re-laid. Rather, from this foundational revelation we are to be carried forward toward maturity as we learn to interpret God's earlier speech and the institutions it established in light of the Son, God's last and best word (1:2–4).

<span id="page-82-12"></span><span id="page-82-6"></span>The preacher exhorts, "let us . . . go on" (lit., "let us be carried") toward maturity. His choice of verb ( *pherō*), mood (subjunctive, functioning as imperative), and voice (passive) expresses the dynamic of spiritual growth: believers are responsible to "strive for . . . holiness" (Heb. 12:14), as the hortatory subjunctive conveys, but our efforts are utterly dependent upon God's sovereign initiative and strong help, as we are "carried" by his Spirit, as 6:3 will remind us.

<span id="page-82-10"></span>The foundation from which believers must be carried forward as they move toward maturity is summarized in six items, grouped in three pairs:

- (1) Repentance from dead works and faith toward God;
- (2) instruction about washings and the laying on of hands;
- (3) resurrection of the dead and eternal judgment.

Many scholars understand these six foundational features as doctrines and practices identified with individuals' initial conversion to Christ and identification with his church:

- <span id="page-83-2"></span>(1) a spiritual "about-face," turning from sinful practices13 and trusting God (Mark 1:15; Acts 2:38; 20:21);
- <span id="page-83-5"></span>(2) visible rites, namely baptism and the laying on of hands (to convey the Holy Spirit) (Acts 8:17–19; 9:17; 19:6);
- (3) teaching about the alternative outcomes of faith and unbelief: resurrection or judgment.

<span id="page-83-3"></span><span id="page-83-1"></span>But the second couplet does not seem to refer to elements of Christian conversion. The ESV rightly reads "washings," not "baptism," because the Greek term (*baptismois*) is plural (not singular) and masculine in gender (*baptismos*), not neuter (*baptisma*). The neuter noun is the NT term referring to the baptisms by John the Baptizer and later of believers (Mark 1:4; Eph. 4:5), while the masculine noun used here reappears in the NT only in Hebrews 9:10 and Mark 7:4, always referring to *ceremonial washings* related to the OT and Judaism. Moreover, the laying on of hands to impart the Holy Spirit to recent converts is a rare feature in exceptional cases (Acts 8:17; 9:17; 19:6). In the NT (and the OT), the laying on of hands appears in the ordination of leaders (Acts 6:6; 1 Tim. 4:14; 5:22), but that rite is not connected to *entering* into the Christian life.

<span id="page-83-4"></span>A better approach is to see these six phrases as *OT themes* foundational to the revelation of the Messiah and his mission:

- (1) The core of covenant commitment: repentance and trust;
- (2) cultic cleansing for covenant communion: washings (Heb. 9:10) and the laying of hands (on sacrificial animals, symbolizing transfer of worshipers' guilt to substitutes) (9:7, 11–14; Lev. 8:14–22; 16:21–22);
- <span id="page-83-0"></span>(3) covenant sanctions of blessing and cursing: resurrection and eternal judgment.

The contents of the first and third couplets do not differ significantly, whichever view we take of the "beginning of the word of the Christ." But interpreting all six features as aspects of the OT foundation makes better sense of the second couplet and of this list's relation to the redemptive-historical perspective of Hebrews.

<span id="page-83-8"></span>6:3 Our preacher intends to lead his hearers from ancient foundations to their fulfillment in Jesus, from the now-obsolete covenant of Sinai to the new and better covenant promised through Jeremiah and mediated by Jesus (8:5–13). But his hearers will grasp the good news he has to impart only "if God permits." The preacher makes explicit what is implied in the divine passive ("let us be carried") of verse 1: they need to be "carried" forward by the God of grace. In pursuing spiritual growth toward maturity, our effort (which is required) must be humbly dependent on God's enabling power (Phil. 1:6; 2:12–13; 1 Thess. 5:23–24).

<span id="page-83-7"></span><span id="page-83-6"></span><sup>13</sup> In Hebrews "dead works" (here and 9:14) are not "works of the law" (Rom. 3:20, 28; Gal. 2:16) but evil deeds that violate God's commands and deserve death.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-84-2"></span><span id="page-84-1"></span>We have been tantalized by mentions of Jesus' high priestly ministry (2:17–3:1; 4:14–5:10), but our author defers a richer exposition of that theme in order to issue an urgent exhortation. This exhortation opens with a summons to grow up, to rouse ourselves from the spiritual sloth impeding our understanding of the oracles of God and obscuring our perception of how the ABCs of the OT Scriptures find fulfillment in the Christ. But the maturity we need in order to ingest, digest, and profit from "solid food" is not merely theological insight. Like athletes in training, we must exercise our wills by constant practice, again and again choosing good over evil, faith over unbelief. Throughout the discipline that builds discernment, we know we can grow only as "God permits." And so we draw near in humble dependence, relying on his grace to bring us timely help as we strive for holiness.

### <span id="page-84-3"></span>HEBREWS 6:4–12

**<sup>4</sup>**For it is impossible, in the case of those who have once been enlightened, who have tasted the heavenly gift, and have shared in the Holy Spirit, **<sup>5</sup>** and have tasted the goodness of the word of God and the powers of the age to come, **<sup>6</sup>** and then have fallen away, to restore them again to repentance, since they are crucifying once again the Son of God to their own harm and holding him up to contempt. **7**For land that has drunk the rain that often falls on it, and produces a crop useful to those for whose sake it is cultivated, receives a blessing from God. **8**But if it bears thorns and thistles, it is worthless and near to being cursed, and its end is to be burned.

**<sup>9</sup>**Though we speak in this way, yet in your case, beloved, we feel sure of better things—things that belong to salvation. **10**For God is not unjust so as to overlook your work and the love that you have shown for his name in serving the saints, as you still do. **11**And we desire each one of you to show the same earnestness to have the full assurance of hope until the end, **<sup>12</sup>** so that you may not be sluggish, but imitators of those who through faith and patience inherit the promises.

#### *Section Overview: Warning against Apostasy and Comforting Reassurance*

<span id="page-84-5"></span>This daunting warning, with its stark pronouncement that apostasy from a faith in Christ once professed cannot be reversed, is the most troubling passage in this entire sermon-letter. (Its parallel in Hebrews 10:26–31 conveys the same terrifying truth, that apostasy is irreversible: "there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins, but a fearful expectation of judgment"; 10:26–27.)

<span id="page-84-4"></span><span id="page-84-0"></span>Theologically, this text seems to call into question the comforting teaching of other NT passages, that Jesus gives his sheep *eternal* life, and no one can "snatch them out of [his] hand" (John 10:28); that all those whom God justifies he will eventually <span id="page-85-6"></span><span id="page-85-1"></span>glorify (Rom. 8:30); and, within this same sermon-letter, that Jesus is "able to save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him" (Heb. 7:25). Those who believe God's sovereign grace to be more dominant than human freedom of choice find their convictions challenged here. But this passage also challenges those who believe that our choice is the decisive factor in salvation, for this text asserts that a decision to turn one's back on God's Son and his heavenly benefits *can never be reversed*.

<span id="page-85-4"></span><span id="page-85-0"></span>Our preacher, in applying Psalm 95:7–11, presented Israel's wilderness experience as a paradigm for the Christian church's present pilgrimage (Heb. 3:7–4:13). To hear God's voice and see his works were great privileges, yet they brought no eternally saving benefit to those Israelites who failed to respond in faith. Even more so, God has lavished heavenly benefits on the new covenant community as the "house" of his Son (3:6). Yet members of this visible church who, lacking persevering faith, renounce their allegiance to the Son of God, will receive no eternal blessing but only compounded curse.

<span id="page-85-3"></span><span id="page-85-2"></span>Hebrews draws a distinction between the constituency of the church as we view it from our finite perspective and those whom God knows to be joined to Christ by living and lasting faith (cf. 2 Tim. 2:19). Likewise, Hebrews implies a distinction between the *temporal and external* benefits of participation in God's covenant community—whether it be ancient Israel or the new covenant church—and the *eternal and internal* salvation received by living, lasting faith in Christ.

This warning is intended to challenge the presumptuous, but it may also alarm and unsettle the sensitive consciences of sincere believers. Aware of this danger, the author immediately reassures his hearers with reminders of the evidence of good fruit that God's word and Spirit have previously borne in their lives (Heb. 6:9–12).

#### <span id="page-85-5"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. Warning: deliberate apostasy in response to heavenly blessing is irreversible (6:4–6)
	- A. Heavenly blessing (6:4–5)
	- B. Deliberate apostasy (6:6)
- II. Double-edged analogy: farmland's future depends on its response to rainfall (6:7–8)
	- A. Farmland that, receiving rain, yields a useful crop enjoys God's blessing (6:7)
	- B. Farmland that, receiving rain, yields worthless weeds deserves God's curse (6:8)
- III. Reassurance: your response to spiritual privilege has been fruitful, giving hope of salvation—if you persevere in faith (6:9–12)
	- A. Concerning you, we are convinced of better things (than the curse just mentioned) (6:9)
	- B. God remembers your salvation-befitting behavior (6:10)
	- C. But show the same confident hope (as you did at first) to the end (6:11–12)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-86-7"></span><span id="page-86-6"></span><span id="page-86-4"></span>6:4–5 "Impossible" arrests our attention, abruptly opening a Greek sentence that runs for three verses. The author then builds suspense by withholding the detail of what, precisely, is "impossible" until the middle of verse 6: it is impossible, he finally says, "to restore . . . again to repentance" those who "have fallen away." But before pronouncing a sober sentence on the spiritual treason from which there is no return, the author lists a series of God's gracious gifts that compound the gravity of such apostasy. He switches from first- and second-person pronouns of interpersonal conversation ("we" and "you"; 5:11, 12; 6:1, 3) to descriptive thirdperson pronouns ("those who," "they") because he is not accusing his hearers of having passed the spiritual point of no return into curse and condemnation (6:8). Yet the privileges once enjoyed by apostates, the horrific evil of their fall away from trust in the Son of God, and their irremediable ruin are not irrelevant to the original audience in their immaturity, nor to anyone who needs stimulus to persevere to the end.

<span id="page-86-5"></span><span id="page-86-3"></span><span id="page-86-1"></span>Four Greek participles—"having once been enlightened" (*hapax phōtisthentas*), "having tasted" (*geusamenous*), "having become" (*genēthentas*), and again "having tasted" (*geusamenous*)—introduce the spiritual privileges enjoyed by those who are members of the visible church. They were "once . . . enlightened" (6:4) when they heard God's voice speaking good news (3:7; 4:2) of salvation through the apostles (2:3–4). In the work of Justin Martyr and later Fathers, "enlightenment" became a metaphor for baptism; but none of the uses of *phōtizō* in the NT refer explicitly to baptism (Luke 11:36; John 1:9; 1 Cor. 4:5; Eph. 1:18; 3:9; 2 Tim. 1:10; Rev. 18:1; 21:23; 22:5). Rather, those who are "enlightened" seem to be those who are exposed to God's saving light through hearing the gospel proclaimed.

<span id="page-86-9"></span><span id="page-86-0"></span>The other participial constructions focus on the primary means of grace, the apostolic word, and the Holy Spirit's miraculous deeds that confirmed the apostles' testimony. The pairing of the apostolic word and the Spirit's confirmatory testimony is repeated twice, first in generalities and then more specifically:

- (A) *Having tasted* the heavenly gift
	- (B) Having become partners/partakers of the *Holy Spirit*
- (A') *Having tasted* the goodness of the word of God
	- (B') and the *powers/miracles* of the age to come

<span id="page-86-8"></span>Although "the heavenly gift" could refer to the whole salvation that God bestows by grace, the repetition of "tasted" suggests that the gift coming down from heaven is specifically "the goodness of the word of God." In Hebrews 12:25, God's voice speaking to Israel *on earth* (at Sinai) will be contrasted to his addressing the new covenant church now *from heaven*. So the good word of God is a gift that now comes from heaven through Christ's messengers.

<span id="page-86-2"></span>Accompanying the apostles' witness in words was God's confirming testimony "by signs and wonders and various miracles and by gifts of the Holy Spirit" (2:4). The word *dynameis* (plural), translated "miracles" in 2:4, reappears here as "powers," <span id="page-87-3"></span>and in both texts these miracles/powers are connected to the Holy Spirit (cf. Acts 2:17–19; 4:29–31; 10:38). The link of the Spirit to miracles suggests that his public activity in the Christian community, not his secret regenerating work in human hearts, is in view. The Greek construction translated "have shared in the Holy Spirit" is literally "have become *metochoi* [companions] of the Holy Spirit." The apostates had become the Holy Spirit's companions, like the Messiah's "companions" in Hebrews 1:9 and 3:14, as members of the Christian community, in which the Spirit attested the gospel through miracles. Perhaps they themselves performed such deeds of power despite their hearts' alienation from God, as even Judas did (Matt. 10:1–8; cf. 7:21–23).

<span id="page-87-9"></span><span id="page-87-7"></span><span id="page-87-0"></span>6:6 The ESV's "and then have fallen away" rightly renders the final participle in the series of participles we looked at in the comment on 6:4–5. Some English versions read "*if* they fall away," allowing for the interpretation that for people who had experienced the previous blessings, a fall into apostasy might be purely hypothetical, never actual. But the danger of willful apostasy, from which repentance is impossible, is real. It remains true that no one to whom Christ has given eternal life can be snatched out of his hand (John 10:29–30). But one can be a member of a new covenant congregation, hearing God's word and seeing his Spirit's works, yet nevertheless harden one's heart against God's voice, as some Israelites did (Heb. 3:1–4:13; cf. Acts 8:13, 18–24; 2 Pet. 2:1; Jude 4).

<span id="page-87-5"></span><span id="page-87-2"></span>Our author, like pastors today, does not claim to look into others' hearts but rather addresses his hearers in terms of their observable profession and behavior, recognizing that appearances may prove, in the end, to be deceiving. "Although the author addresses the community as a whole as believers, he hints at his own lack of omniscience—some may not be true believers even through by association they appear to be (3:6, 14; 4:1–2; 6:11)."14 The farmland analogy of verses 7–8 illustrates the distinction between externally experienced blessings and internal heart responses.

<span id="page-87-8"></span><span id="page-87-4"></span>The gravity of such resolute rebellion, akin to Judas's treachery, explains why it places the apostate's heart beyond the possibility of repentance. God, who sovereignly grants repentance to rebels (Acts 3:26; 11:18), will not intervene (as he could) to turn around those who have willfully walked away. Such an apostate has identified himself with those who crucified the Son of God and treated him with contempt (Heb. 12:2–3; 13:13; cf. Matt. 27:39–44). Here and in 10:29 our author refers to Jesus as "the Son of God," reminding us of his divine glory announced in the prologue (Heb. 1:1–4). His dignity underscores the horrific evil of renouncing allegiance to him and siding with his enemies.

<span id="page-87-10"></span><span id="page-87-6"></span><span id="page-87-1"></span>6:7–8 This mini-parable of farmland and fields that yield different crops in response to heavenly rainfall draws on imagery from the OT and Jesus' teaching. OT prophets compared God's word and God's Spirit to precipitation falling on parched earth,

<sup>14</sup> George H. Guthrie, *Hebrews*, NIVAC (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 1998), 229.

<span id="page-88-5"></span><span id="page-88-4"></span><span id="page-88-3"></span><span id="page-88-0"></span>making it fruitful (Isa. 44:3–4; 55:10–11). They indicted Israel as a vineyard that bore worthless fruit in response to God's cultivation (Isa. 5:1–10; Jer. 2:21; Ezek. 19:10–14). Israel's treason was "thorns and thistles," like those that sprang from the cursed ground after Adam's original sin (Hos. 10:1–8; cf. Gen. 3:17–18). Jesus' parable of the sower categorized hearers in terms of their response to the word he was broadcasting, whether unresponsive, showing initial interest but fading because of persecution or distraction, or enduring and fruitful (Matt. 13:3–8, 18–23).

<span id="page-88-6"></span><span id="page-88-2"></span><span id="page-88-1"></span>The grim threat of destruction by fire (Heb. 6:8; cf. Deut. 29:22–24) dramatizes the covenant curse awaiting apostates. Yet, just as the Lord set before Israel alternatives of blessings or curses, depending on their response to him (Deut. 11:13–17, 26–29; 28:4, 11–12, 16–18, 23–24), so God promises blessing to those who resemble ground that "produces a crop useful" to its cultivators (Heb. 6:7). Our author is confident his hearers (in general) fit this description.

<span id="page-88-14"></span><span id="page-88-13"></span><span id="page-88-7"></span>6:9–10 With pastoral wisdom our author places alongside his terrifying pronouncement of curse on traitors a word of reassurance for his "beloved" hearers. His purpose is not to blunt the edge of the warning but to capitalize on the evidence of God's prior work in them in order to stimulate their strenuous perseverance in faith. Our preacher is convinced that they are bearing useful fruit, befitting the better outcome of salvation (1:14; 2:10; 5:9). His confidence rests on the faithfulness of God, who will not mistreat his servants by forgetting or ignoring their labor and love for his name. Their love for God's name—that is, for God in his self-revelation (2:12; 13:5)—has been "shown" (*endeiknymi* ) in action, in their past and present service to the saints. Such service included their willing identification with those enduring reproach and affliction for their faith, including prisoners (10:32–34).

<span id="page-88-18"></span><span id="page-88-16"></span><span id="page-88-15"></span><span id="page-88-10"></span><span id="page-88-8"></span>6:11–12 Having reassured the congregation as a whole of God's knowledge of their labor and love, our preacher directs his final challenge to "each" individual member. Within a generally healthy congregation there may be someone harboring "an evil, unbelieving heart" (3:12), at risk of failing to reach God's rest (4:1) and grace (12:12–15). Therefore our pastor expresses his strong desire that "each one of you" would "show" (*endeiknymi* again) in faithful conduct "the same earnestness" (*spoudē*, strenuous action) that had distinguished the beginning of their life in Christ, that each would endure all the way "until the end" (echoing 3:14). Such endurance is sustained not by self-reliant willpower but by the "full assurance of hope" drawn from "considering" and "looking to Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith" (3:1; 12:2).

<span id="page-88-19"></span><span id="page-88-17"></span><span id="page-88-12"></span><span id="page-88-11"></span><span id="page-88-9"></span>The positive alternative to spiritual sloth (*nōthroi*, which opened this section; 5:11) is to become imitators of our forerunners in faith and patience, whose trust in God's promises has been rewarded by the fulfillment of their hopes. Those exemplars of enduring trust include the congregation's original leaders (13:7) and the "cloud of witnesses" throughout OT history, who took action in response to God's word concerning things not yet seen (11:4–40). Our preacher will now direct our attention to Abraham's long-suffering faith and to God's oath-bound promise (6:13–20).

#### *Response*

Our preacher states plainly the response we must make to the terrifying possibility of irreversible apostasy and the comforting evidence of God's heart-transforming, love-producing grace. Before new covenant Christians, no less than before ancient Israel, our covenant Lord has placed alternative outcomes of blessings and curses. These outcomes proceed from alternative responses to God's word and Spirit, which fall like refreshing rain onto our congregations. Both for ourselves and for each other, we must beware of the trajectory that begins with flaccid hearing and an infantile incapacity to "digest" God's word (5:11–6:3), that then proceeds to a deliberate repudiation of God's Son (6:4–6), and ends in a cursed and fiery destruction (6:8).

<span id="page-89-3"></span><span id="page-89-2"></span><span id="page-89-1"></span><span id="page-89-0"></span>On the other hand, we should recall (and God never forgets) how he has turned our hearts toward himself and his saints in practical love demonstrated in service. Such hints of his grace in our past and present experience should steel our confident hope in his sure promises and spur our energies to run the marathon of faith to its completion. This terrifying portrait of irreversible apostasy is given not to tempt us to try to discover whether *someone else* has crossed a spiritual point of no return, nor to discourage our efforts to recover those who have wandered from Christ (Matt. 18:10–14). Rather, its purpose is to caution us to beware, for ourselves and each other, of any movement whatsoever toward that lethal precipice.

### <span id="page-89-4"></span>HEBREWS 6:13–20

**<sup>13</sup>**For when God made a promise to Abraham, since he had no one greater by whom to swear, he swore by himself, **<sup>14</sup>** saying, "Surely I will bless you and multiply you." **15**And thus Abraham,*<sup>1</sup>* having patiently waited, obtained the promise. **16**For people swear by something greater than themselves, and in all their disputes an oath is final for confirmation. **<sup>17</sup>** So when God desired to show more convincingly to the heirs of the promise the unchangeable character of his purpose, he guaranteed it with an oath, **<sup>18</sup>** so that by two unchangeable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled for refuge might have strong encouragement to hold fast to the hope set before us. **19**We have this as a sure and steadfast anchor of the soul, a hope that enters into the inner place behind the curtain, **20**where Jesus has gone as a forerunner on our behalf, having become a high priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.

#### *Section Overview: The Guarantees of God's Sure Promise*

<span id="page-90-13"></span><span id="page-90-12"></span><span id="page-90-5"></span>Having urged his hearers to imitate "those who through faith and patience inherit the promises" (Heb. 6:12), our preacher now cites the experience of one of those imitation-worthy people of faith, Abraham. The preacher's purpose is to persuade us that God can be trusted to keep his promises. In chapter 11 many more "witnesses" (12:1) will be summoned from OT history to testify to God's faithfulness. In response to Abraham's trusting and obedient readiness to sacrifice his son Isaac, God not only promised to bless Abraham but also secured that promise through an oath (Gen. 22:16–17). By that oath, God invoked himself (since no one is greater) to enforce his own commitment, imposing the death penalty (on himself!) in the event of any breach of promise. In this case such a breach was impossible because God cannot lie and cannot die.

<span id="page-90-9"></span><span id="page-90-3"></span><span id="page-90-2"></span><span id="page-90-1"></span><span id="page-90-0"></span>Because believers in Jesus are the "offspring of Abraham" (Heb. 2:16), along with Abraham they are "heirs of the promise." Moreover, now we have witnessed God's fulfillment of a second oath, by which he installed Jesus as priest forever in the order of Melchizedek (5:6; 7:20–22, 28). So we rely on the twofold, unchangeable foundation by which God guaranteed his fidelity to his word (6:17–18). This exhortation section (5:11–6:20) closes with the resumption of a theme introduced in 5:6–10: Jesus' priestly office "in the order of Melchizedek." Elaboration of this priesthood, the central point of the book of Hebrews (cf. 8:1), was deferred at 5:11. But as he completes this exhortation, our preacher prepares to discuss in depth both Jesus' superior qualifications to be priest (7:1–28) and the superior priestly ministry he conducts in "the inner place behind the curtain" (6:19; 8:1–10:31).

#### <span id="page-90-11"></span><span id="page-90-10"></span><span id="page-90-4"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-90-6"></span>I. God's oath-bound promise to bless Abraham (6:13–16)
	- A. God invoked himself as witness and enforcer of his promise (6:13–14)
	- B. Abraham waited patiently and received the fulfillment of God's promise (6:15)
	- C. Oaths invoke a greater power to enforce promises (6:16)
- <span id="page-90-7"></span>II. God's oath-bound promise to us, the heirs of the promise (6:17–20)
	- A. God secured his promise to us by adding his oath, guaranteeing his unchangeable word by his unchangeable life (6:17–18a)
	- B. God gives us strong encouragement to cling to the hope set before us (6:18b–20)
		- 1. This hope is our soul's anchor, firm and reliable (6:18b–19a)
		- 2. This hope enters God's heavenly sanctuary because Jesus our forerunner has entered as the high priest in the order of Melchizedek (6:19b–20)

#### <span id="page-90-8"></span>*Comment*

6:13–14, 16 Repetition of the themes of *patient faith* (v. 15), *inheritance* (v. 17), and *promise* (vv. 13, 15, 17) indicates that this paragraph gives grounds for the exhorta<span id="page-91-12"></span>tion to imitate those who have trusted in God's promises, even when fulfillment was long delayed (v. 12).

<span id="page-91-15"></span><span id="page-91-0"></span>Abraham was the prototypical OT recipient of God's promises (7:6; 11:17). God promised to bless Abraham, to multiply his descendants, to grant him a homeland, and to make him a blessing to other peoples (Gen. 12:1–3; 15:5–7). The oath that God "swore by himself" came after Abraham sustained the testing of his faith, proving himself willing to sacrifice Isaac, the son through whom God had promised to multiply Abraham's descendants (Gen. 22:16–17).

<span id="page-91-9"></span><span id="page-91-7"></span><span id="page-91-4"></span><span id="page-91-2"></span>God's oath, by which he committed himself to bless and multiply Abraham, now emerges as the main topic of this section of Hebrews. The OT describes God's securing his promises by swearing oaths (Ex. 13:5; 32:13; Deut. 1:8; Isa. 45:23; Jer. 22:5; 49:13; cf. Luke 1:73; Acts 2:30). Hebrews elsewhere discusses OT texts referring to two other divine oaths, one negative and the other positive. Negatively, Psalm 95:11 recounted the oath God swore at Kadesh that the unbelieving generation of Israelites would not enter his rest (Heb. 3:11, 18; 4:3; cf. Num. 14:21–23). Positively, the Lord has sworn that the king enthroned at his right hand is priest forever in the order of Melchizedek (Ps. 110:1, 4), an irreversible commitment establishing the permanence of Jesus' tenure as high priest (Heb. 7:20–22, 28).

<span id="page-91-16"></span><span id="page-91-13"></span><span id="page-91-11"></span><span id="page-91-8"></span><span id="page-91-6"></span>In antiquity, an oath was an appeal to "something greater" (6:16)—often a deity—to witness the veracity of a statement or the commitment expressed in a promise, and to impose punishment if the witness perjured himself or if the promise maker failed to follow through. "In the Graeco-Roman world oaths were sworn in the name of God, a king, the genius of the emperor, or the emperor himself. Those who took oaths made themselves liable to the judgment of God or the emperor if they proved false to such a commitment."15 To take an oath was to seal one's word with one's very life. Likewise, in covenant ratification ceremonies, slain animals symbolized the cursed death that would ensue if one party violated the covenant (Gen. 15:9–21; Ex. 24:3–8; Jer. 34:15–20; cf. comments on Heb. 9:15; 9:16–17; 9:18–20).

<span id="page-91-17"></span><span id="page-91-10"></span><span id="page-91-3"></span><span id="page-91-1"></span>Israel was to swear oaths in the Lord's name only, revering his omniscient perception, justice, and power to enforce fidelity to commitments made (Deut. 5:11; 6:13; 10:20; cf. Gen. 31:50; 1 Sam. 20:12). Likewise, Paul invoked God as witness to the truth of his statements (Rom. 1:9; 9:1; Phil. 1:8). An oath invoked the Lord himself to function as a third party—both witness and enforcer—to a legal transaction, certifying the human parties' obligations and therefore ending their dispute with each other.16 Our preacher again builds his argument from lesser to greater: if human oaths, witnessed and enforced by a superior power, are so reliable that they end disputes, how much more can we trust God's oath-bound

<sup>15</sup> O'Brien, *Hebrews*, 237, citing C. R. Koester, *Hebrews* (New York: Doubleday, 2001), 326.

<span id="page-91-14"></span><span id="page-91-5"></span><sup>16</sup> In verse 17 "guaranteed" reflects the Greek verb *mesiteuō*, "mediate," perhaps reflecting Exodus 22:10–12, which states that if one's animal died while in the custody of a neighbor, "*an oath* by the Lord shall be *between them both* [LXX: *ana meson amphoterōn*] to see whether or not he has put his hand to his neighbor's property."

promise, which he swore "by himself"! There is no greater person to witness and enforce his commitment.

<span id="page-92-21"></span><span id="page-92-20"></span><span id="page-92-17"></span><span id="page-92-13"></span><span id="page-92-12"></span>6:15 Because Abraham patiently waited, he "obtained the promise" of God's blessing and multiplied descendants. Abraham did not merely hear God's words of promise but actually obtained the fulfillment of God's promise—"through faith and patience" he was among those who "inherit the promises" (6:12). Likewise, many OT believers "obtained promises" (11:33). Yet Hebrews also states that Abraham and other patriarchs "died in faith, *not having received* the things promised" (11:13) and that OT believers in general "*did not receive* what was promised" (11:39). In what sense did Abraham *obtain*, yet not *receive*, what God was promising? Abraham waited a hundred years for the conception, from parents "as good as dead," of the son through whom his "offspring [shall] be named" (11:18; Gen. 21:12). Years later, when on Mount Moriah the Lord provided a ram to die instead of Isaac (Gen. 22:1–19), Abraham "figuratively speaking" received his only son of promise back from the dead (Heb. 11:19). Isaac's twofold "resurrection," in conception and again on Mount Moriah, began the fulfillment of God's promise to multiply Abraham's descendants to countless numbers.

<span id="page-92-19"></span><span id="page-92-18"></span><span id="page-92-14"></span><span id="page-92-4"></span><span id="page-92-1"></span><span id="page-92-0"></span>6:17–18 God's oath-bound promise to Abraham was not for Abraham alone. It was to reassure all "the heirs of the promise," including first-century Hebrew Christians, so that "*we* who have fled for refuge might have strong encouragement." In fact, the divine oath that secured blessing for Abraham was contingent on the oath God would swear in order to install Christ as the permanent priest in the order of Melchizedek (7:20–22, 28; Ps. 110:4). The concepts of heirship and inheritance, which entail *assured but future ownership*, appear throughout Hebrews. Christ is the heir of all things (1:2). Angels serve those who will inherit salvation (1:14; cf. 9:15). Noah was an heir of righteousness (11:7), and Abraham would be heir of a land through his offspring (11:8–9).

<span id="page-92-16"></span><span id="page-92-15"></span><span id="page-92-11"></span><span id="page-92-10"></span><span id="page-92-9"></span><span id="page-92-8"></span><span id="page-92-7"></span><span id="page-92-6"></span><span id="page-92-5"></span><span id="page-92-3"></span><span id="page-92-2"></span>God intended to "show"—to provide legal evidence demonstrating (*epideiknymi*; cf. Acts 18:28)—that his purpose to bless is unchangeable and irrevocable. Therefore he added his oath to his promise. Thus "two unchangeable things" would banish any doubt as to God's reliability. The first unchangeable thing is the oath God swore to Abraham (Gen. 22:16–17), vowing to impose on himself the penalty of death should he fail to keep his word. But "it is impossible for God to lie"—a theme that pervades the Bible (cf. Num. 23:19; 1 Sam. 15:29; Isa. 46:10–11; Titus 1:2). And it is impossible for God to die, since he is "the living God" (Heb. 3:12; 9:14; 10:31; 12:22). So his oath to Abraham is unchangeable. Yet, just as Hebrews often shows God's new covenant provision improving upon the old (1:1–2; 3:2–6; 4:14–5:10; 7:15–28; 9:13–14; etc.), so here a second, better oath is brought into view, the oath spoken by God in Psalm 110:4 appointing Christ as "priest forever after the order of Melchizedek." The content of that oath was quoted in Hebrews 5:6, and the oath-formula and its implications will appear in 7:20–22. Because Christ lives forever and holds priestly office forever—by inviolable divine oath, <span id="page-93-11"></span>not mere command (7:16, 28)—Abraham and we, his new covenant children of faith, have two oaths on which to rest our confidence.17 These mutually confirming evidences provide "strong encouragement" to us who, though we are "heirs of the promise," are also exiles who have "fled for refuge" to God's protection in a hostile world. "Encouragement" or "exhortation" ( *paraklēsis*) characterizes the entire sermon-letter of Hebrews (13:22; cf. 3:13; 10:25; 12:5; 13:19).
