1Some manuscripts *For finding fault with it he says to them*

#### *Section Overview: The New and Better Covenant*

<span id="page-114-1"></span><span id="page-114-0"></span>In support of the statement that Christ mediates a better covenant (Heb. 8:6), the preacher cites Jeremiah 31:31–34, the Lord's promise to establish a new covenant with his people. This promise implied that the covenant the Lord made with Israel at Sinai suffered from a fatal flaw: Israel's violation of their commitment. By promising a new covenant in "coming" days, God pronounced the first covenant obsolete and close to disappearing. On the other hand, the new covenant is based on better promises: God's law will be written on human hearts, the Lord will be their God and they his people, all his people will know him (having access to his presence), and he will forgive their sins forever.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. Preamble: the Lord's promise of a coming new covenant (Jer. 31:31– 34) implied the faultiness of his first covenant with Israel at Sinai (Heb. 8:7–8a)
- II. Prophecy: the Lord will make a new covenant with his people, unlike the one he made after the exodus (8:8b–12)
	- A. In days to come, the Lord will make a new covenant (8:8b)
	- B. Israel departed from the first covenant, so God rejected them (8:9)
	- C. The new covenant will be based on better promises (8:10–12)
		- 1. The Lord will write his laws into minds and hearts (8:10ab)
		- 2. The Lord will be Israel's God, and they his people (8:10c)
		- 3. Everyone in Israel, from the least to the greatest, will know the Lord (8:11)
		- 4. The Lord will forgive their sins completely, refusing to remember them forever (8:12)

III. Implication: the OT promise of a new covenant rendered the first covenant obsolete, old, and nearly disappearing (8:13)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-115-13"></span><span id="page-115-12"></span><span id="page-115-3"></span>8:7–8 Christ is mediator of a better covenant, "enacted on better promises" than the law and its Levitical priesthood (8:6). For the third time in Hebrews our preacher enlists an OT text to testify to the inadequacy of the OT order (cf. 4:7–8; 7:11). By promising (in Jer. 31:31–34) to establish a "new covenant" with Israel and Judah in the future, God implied that the "first covenant," made at Sinai in the aftermath of the exodus, was not "faultless." If it had been, a second covenant would not have been called for.

<span id="page-115-6"></span><span id="page-115-1"></span>Elsewhere in the LXX and NT, "faultless" (*amemptos*) refers to individuals' moral blamelessness, as in Job 1:1, 8; 2:3; 4:17; 9:20; 11:4 and in such NT texts as Luke 1:6 and 1 Thessalonians 2:10; 3:13; 5:23. Our author also has persons—not the covenant per se—in view. Although he characterizes the covenant enacted at Sinai as "not faultless," he clarifies that the "fault" lay not in the law's requirements but in the Israelites: "find[ing] fault [*memphomenos*] with *them*"—not with the covenant, but with people who "did not continue in my covenant" (Heb. 8:9).

<span id="page-115-15"></span><span id="page-115-9"></span><span id="page-115-8"></span><span id="page-115-7"></span><span id="page-115-2"></span>The promise of a "new covenant" in Jeremiah 31:31–34 is crucial to our understanding of redemptive history. When he instituted the Lord's Supper, Jesus interpreted the cup as a sign and seal of "the new covenant in my blood" (Luke 22:20; 1 Cor. 11:25) and mentioned the new covenant promise of forgiveness of sins (Matt. 26:28; Mark 14:24). Paul draws on the Jeremiah 31 prophecy to contrast the "glory" of Moses' ministry, which brought death and condemnation, with Paul's privilege, as a minister of the new covenant, to proclaim righteousness in the life-imparting power of the Spirit (2 Cor. 3:5–18). Paul applies "old covenant" to the Scriptures given through Moses (2 Cor. 3:14–15), establishing the basis for the familiar titles of the two parts of our Bibles: Old Testament and New Testament. The Lord would establish this new covenant in "days [that] are coming," "after those days" (Heb. 8:8, 10), a new era of redemptive history. Through Jeremiah and other prophets the Lord foretold that in the "last days" (Heb. 1:2; cf. 9:26) he would come to his people in justice and salvation (Num. 24:14; Deut. 4:30; Isa. 2:2; Jer. 30:3–24; Dan. 2:28; Hos. 3:5).

<span id="page-115-14"></span><span id="page-115-11"></span><span id="page-115-10"></span><span id="page-115-5"></span><span id="page-115-0"></span>The permanence of the new covenant may have inclined our author to amend the LXX slightly, replacing "I will decree/confer [*diathēsomai* ]" with, literally, "I will complete [*syntelesō*]" a new covenant, using a term belonging to the "perfection" word group that is so significant for this sermon. Just a few chapters later in Jeremiah, the LXX uses "complete" (*synteleō*) to describe the covenant inauguration rite in which Israelites passed between animal carcasses, enacting a self-maledictory oath (Jer. 34:15 = 41:15 LXX).

<span id="page-115-4"></span>8:9 The new covenant is "not like the covenant that I made with their fathers" because the Israelites "did not continue" in that first covenant. With a strong arm <span id="page-116-10"></span><span id="page-116-1"></span>the Lord "took them by the hand" to lead them out of slavery. This tactile imagery of God's personal and powerful engagement to free his captive people, anticipated in Hebrews 2:16 (cf. comment on 2:15–16), compounds the guilt of their infidelity. They professed allegiance when the covenant was read and ratified at Sinai (Ex. 24:3–8), but when Moses went back up the mountain for further directions, they turned to worshiping a golden calf (Exodus 32). Then, as Psalm 95 testified, that generation disbelieved God's voice and failed to enter his rest (Heb. 3:7–11). Finally, by the time of Jeremiah, faithless Israel and Judah had been banished from the Promised Land (Deut. 28:15–68; Jer. 2:1–32).

<span id="page-116-13"></span><span id="page-116-11"></span><span id="page-116-5"></span><span id="page-116-3"></span>8:10 Our preacher has piqued our curiosity about the "better promises" on which the new covenant would be established (8:6). Jeremiah's prophecy mentions four ways in which the new covenant would surpass its predecessor. The Hebrews author does not immediately elaborate on these promises, instead moving to conclude that the announcement of a new covenant implies the obsolescence of the old. But Hebrews 9:1–10:17 will show implicitly how the new covenant's promises are fulfilled.

<span id="page-116-16"></span><span id="page-116-14"></span><span id="page-116-8"></span><span id="page-116-2"></span>First, whereas at Sinai God inscribed his commandments on stone tablets (Ex. 24:12; 31:18; 34:1), in the new covenant "I will put my laws into their minds, and . . . on their hearts" (Heb. 8:10). The apostle Paul interprets this promise in light of the Holy Spirit's work of sanctifying our affections and desires (2 Cor. 3:3). In Hebrews, the contrast between external and internal is expressed in the contrast between OT rites that could only "sanctify for the purification of the flesh" and the blood of Christ, which can "purify our conscience . . . to serve the living God" (Heb. 9:13–14; cf. 9:9–10).

<span id="page-116-18"></span><span id="page-116-9"></span><span id="page-116-0"></span>The second promise, "I will be their God, and they shall be my people," appears often in Scripture to summarize the mutual commitment between the Lord and his human subjects (Ex. 6:7; Lev. 26:12; Jer. 24:7; 32:38; Ezek. 11:20; 34:30; 37:27; Zech. 8:8; 2 Cor. 6:16; Rev. 21:3; etc.). The new covenant is secured by God's oath-bound promise to Abraham and his oath-bound appointment of Christ as Abraham's and our priestly intercessor (Heb. 6:13–20; 7:1–28). In this better covenant, therefore, the bond between the Lord and his people is unbreakable.

<span id="page-116-15"></span><span id="page-116-12"></span><span id="page-116-7"></span><span id="page-116-4"></span>8:11 The third promise, that all God's people, "from the least of them to the greatest," will know him, can be understood against the backdrop of the mediatorial role of the OT Levitical priests. Priests were to teach God's law to Israel (Deut. 33:8–10; Mal. 2:4–7). Parents were to teach the Torah to their children (Deut. 6:6–9), but their knowledge of God's word was dependent on priests who preserved it, read it aloud, and explained it (Deut. 31:9–13; Ezra 7:1–10; Neh. 8:1–8). Moreover, access to the Lord's presence was limited: only priests could minister in the tabernacle's Holy Place, and only the high priest could enter the Most Holy Place.

<span id="page-116-17"></span><span id="page-116-6"></span>These restrictions showed that "the way into the holy places" for all God's people was "not yet opened" (Heb. 9:6–9). Hebrews does not infer from the promise that "they shall not teach, each one his neighbor . . . , saying, 'Know the Lord'" <span id="page-117-11"></span><span id="page-117-10"></span>that the new covenant community needs no recognized leaders or teachers (Heb. 13:7, 17). The preacher himself is teaching them in this "word of exhortation" (13:22). Nevertheless, Christ's coming has effected a wider access to God's word and to his Holy Spirit's instruction from that word (1 John 2:26–27), as well as a more intimate access to God's presence for all believers.

<span id="page-117-13"></span><span id="page-117-5"></span>8:12 The previous three promises flow from the fourth, which these two lines express in complementary ways:

I will be merciful [will forgive, turning away my wrath] toward their iniquities.

<span id="page-117-4"></span>I will remember their sins no more.

<span id="page-117-12"></span><span id="page-117-2"></span><span id="page-117-1"></span><span id="page-117-0"></span>"Merciful" reflects a Greek word (*hileōs*) that differs from the "mercy" (*eleos*) of 4:16 (cf. 2:17). The term here belongs to the cognate group that expresses the turning aside of God's wrath from the guilty through the forgiveness of their sins (Ex. 32:12–14; Num. 14:19–20). This family of related words includes *hilaskomai* ("make propitiation"; Heb. 2:17; Luke 18:13; Ps. 78:9 LXX); *hilastērion* ("mercy seat"; Heb. 9:5; Ex. 25:17–21; or "propitiation"; Rom. 3:25); and *hilasmos* ("propitiation"; 1 John 2:2; 4:10). The animal sacrifices of the OT provided a "reminder of sins every year," an incessant witness to the inability of bulls' and goats' blood to remove sin's guilt and defilement (Heb. 10:3–4). Our preacher will explore the sufficiency of Jesus' sacrifice to achieve complete forgiveness of sins and deep cleansing of conscience (9:11–15, 23–28; 10:5–14), concluding: "Where there is forgiveness of these [sins]"—where God *refuses to remember* our offenses—"there is no longer any offering for sin" (10:17–18).

<span id="page-117-9"></span><span id="page-117-8"></span><span id="page-117-7"></span><span id="page-117-6"></span><span id="page-117-3"></span>8:13 Our author concludes from Jeremiah 31:31–34 that, when God promised a "new" covenant, he relegated the first covenant to the category of what was aging and obsolete, near the point of disappearing altogether. Thus the OT announced that the Sinai covenant, as the framework for God's relationship to his people, was destined to be discarded.

#### *Response*

Through the prophet Jeremiah, weeping amid the wreckage Israel and Judah had made of the covenant enacted through Moses, God revived hope by his promise of a better covenant in days to come. That covenant's "better promises"—transformation of heart, belonging to the Lord our God, open access to his presence and word, complete forgiveness of sins—have been fulfilled through the sacrifice of Jesus, the mediator and guarantor of this new covenant.

Are we, new covenant believers, inclined to take those stunning promises for granted? Do we assume that forgiveness and cleansing are trivial matters, granted cheaply? That access to the Holy One is our right rather than a privilege bestowed in his mercy on us who deserve wrath, banishment, and destruction? Rivers of blood from countless animal victims and daunting restrictions circumscribing approach to God were designed to impress on Israel both the gravity of their sinful pollution and the magnificence of God's reconciling mercy. Pause to savor those promises—deep cleansing, open access, complete forgiveness—and give thanks to the Lord who made them and who kept them through Jesus, his Son and our priest forever.

### <span id="page-118-1"></span>HEBREWS 9:1–10

9 Now even the first covenant had regulations for worship and an earthly place of holiness. **2**For a tent*<sup>1</sup>* was prepared, the first section, in which were the lampstand and the table and the bread of the Presence.*<sup>2</sup>* It is called the Holy Place. **3**Behind the second curtain was a second section*<sup>3</sup>* called the Most Holy Place, **4**having the golden altar of incense and the ark of the covenant covered on all sides with gold, in which was a golden urn holding the manna, and Aaron's staff that budded, and the tablets of the covenant. **5**Above it were the cherubim of glory overshadowing the mercy seat. Of these things we cannot now speak in detail.

**<sup>6</sup>**These preparations having thus been made, the priests go regularly into the first section, performing their ritual duties, **7**but into the second only the high priest goes, and he but once a year, and not without taking blood, which he offers for himself and for the unintentional sins of the people. **8**By this the Holy Spirit indicates that the way into the holy places is not yet opened as long as the first section is still standing **<sup>9</sup>** (which is symbolic for the present age).*<sup>4</sup>* According to this arrangement, gifts and sacrifices are offered that cannot perfect the conscience of the worshiper, **<sup>10</sup>**but deal only with food and drink and various washings, regulations for the body imposed until the time of reformation.

1Or *tabernacle*; also verses 11, 21 2Greek *the presentation of the loaves* 3Greek *tent*; also verses 6, 8 4Or *which is symbolic for the age then present*

#### *Section Overview: The Old Covenant's Earthly Tent*

<span id="page-118-3"></span><span id="page-118-2"></span><span id="page-118-0"></span>Having introduced the Sinai covenant, Israel's breach of it, and its divinely promised replacement by a new and better covenant (Heb. 8:7–13), our author discusses that first covenant's provisions for worshipers' approach to God. That aging, obsolescent covenant included regulations governing who could approach God, how near they could come, and what service they were to offer him. It also had an earthly sanctuary, with a floor plan and furniture shown to Moses when he met God on the mountain (8:5). After a brief survey of the tabernacle's design and contents (9:2–5), the discussion proceeds to the priests' and the high priest's respective ministries in the tabernacle's two chambers (9:6–7). The restrictions

limiting access to God's Most Holy Place were the Holy Spirit's demonstration, via symbolism, that the new covenant promise of access to God for all his people would not arrive as long as the earthly sanctuary functioned as the focal point of worship. Levitical priests executed physical rites that could not cleanse worshipers' consciences, and the regulations directing those rites were designed to be temporary, lasting only "until the time of reformation" promised by God would arrive (9:10).

#### <span id="page-119-12"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-119-4"></span>I. Introduction: the first covenant's ministry restrictions and its tent (9:1)
- <span id="page-119-6"></span><span id="page-119-5"></span>II. The tent: its floor plan and furniture (9:2–5)
	- A. The first chamber, the Holy Place (9:2)
	- B. The second chamber, the Most Holy Place (9:3–5)
- <span id="page-119-11"></span><span id="page-119-10"></span><span id="page-119-9"></span><span id="page-119-8"></span>III. The ministry restrictions and their meaning (9:6–10)
	- A. Priests' daily ministries in the first chamber (9:6)
	- B. The high priest's yearly ministry in the second chamber (9:7)
	- C. The meaning of the restrictions (9:8–10)
		- 1. The way into the holy places was not yet open (9:8–9a)
		- 2. The sacrifices could not cleanse the conscience, but only the flesh (9:b–10ab)
		- 3. A time of reformation would come (9:10c)

#### *Comment*

9:1 Our preacher begins his exploration of the contrast between the old and new covenants by discussing the sanctuary and the service of worship offered there. God's purpose for his covenants is for people to draw near to him in worshipful engagement, offering their adoration and receiving his timely aid. Therefore the author introduces two themes: (1) "regulations for worship" and (2) "an earthly place of holiness." He will discuss them in reverse order, first the earthly Holy Place (vv. 2–5) and then the regulations for the worship conducted there (vv. 6–10).

<span id="page-119-3"></span><span id="page-119-2"></span>The Holy Place belonging to the first covenant was "earthly." That is, it was on earth, in contrast to the "true tent that the Lord set up" in heaven (8:2), in which Christ ministers as our High Priest (8:1–4). The first covenant's sanctuary was "made with hands" and was "of this creation" (9:11), and therefore subject to change and decomposition (1:10–12).

<span id="page-119-13"></span><span id="page-119-7"></span><span id="page-119-1"></span><span id="page-119-0"></span>9:2 Our author uses "tent" (*skēnē*; also in vv. 3, 6, 8) to refer to both of the chambers or "sections" (ESV) of the tabernacle, an enclosed tent that stood within a fenced, open-air courtyard. The "first" or outer section was called the Holy Place, while behind a second veil was a second section, called the Most Holy Place (vv. 3–5, 7). (The first veil, not mentioned in Hebrews but implied by "second veil," was in the outer doorway that led from the courtyard into the tent itself; cf. Ex. 36:37.) A brief inventory of the furniture associated with each chamber sets the scene for the priestly ministries associated with these holy spaces.

<span id="page-120-3"></span><span id="page-120-2"></span>Two items are mentioned in connection with the first section: a six-branched lampstand (cf. Ex. 25:31–40) and the table on which the "bread of the Presence" was set (cf. Ex. 25:23–30). Although Exodus states that the lampstand was made of gold and the table was overlaid with gold, our preacher bypasses this feature, instead mentioning gold three times when describing the contents of the Most Holy Place (Heb. 9:3–5). This gold reflects and radiates the greater glory of the inner, second section, in contrast to the first.

<span id="page-120-13"></span>9:3–5 Behind the second curtain was a "section" (*skēnē*) called the Most Holy Place. Two items are associated with the Most Holy Place: the golden altar of incense and the ark of the covenant, also gold-covered. According to the OT, the altar of incense was actually in the Holy Place, immediately in front of the second curtain that led into the inner chamber (Ex. 30:6; 40:26–27). The altar's placement outside the Most Holy Place enabled priests to burn incense on it every morning and evening throughout the year (Ex. 30:7–8).

<span id="page-120-15"></span><span id="page-120-5"></span><span id="page-120-4"></span>Wishing to focus on the close association of the incense altar with the Most Holy Place and the Day of Atonement (cf. comment on Heb. 9:7), our preacher here modifies his language for accuracy. Instead of stating that this altar was "in" the Most Holy Place (as the lampstand and table were "in" the Holy Place), he says that the Most Holy Place was "having" (*echousa*) the altar and the ark of the covenant, not that it contained them both. The incense altar was closely tied to the Most Holy Place because from it on the Day of Atonement the high priest carried burning incense, "that the cloud of the incense may cover the mercy seat that is over the testimony, so that he does not die" (Lev. 16:13). Our author may also have in mind the description of Solomon's temple, which identified this altar with the Most Holy Place (1 Kings 6:16–22).

<span id="page-120-14"></span><span id="page-120-12"></span><span id="page-120-11"></span><span id="page-120-10"></span><span id="page-120-9"></span><span id="page-120-8"></span><span id="page-120-7"></span><span id="page-120-6"></span><span id="page-120-1"></span><span id="page-120-0"></span>The ark of the covenant was the focal point of the Most Holy Place, and our author gives it the most attention. The ark contained three items (Heb. 9:4), memorializing events of Israel's years in the wilderness. (1) A golden urn contained manna, the "bread" the Lord provided to sustain his people in the wasteland. God directed that manna be placed in a jar before the "testimony," that is, the two tablets of God's covenant, which were placed inside the ark of the covenant—which is also called the "ark of the testimony" (Ex. 25:22; cf. 16:32–34; 25:16, 21). This manna was a token of the Lord's "works," which the Israelites saw over those forty years (Heb. 3:9). (2) Aaron's staff, which had budded miraculously in the aftermath of Korah's rebellion and destruction (Numbers 16–17), signified that priestly privilege can be granted only by God (Heb. 5:4). Again, the staff was preserved "before the testimony" (Num. 17:10–11). (3) As mentioned, inside the ark were also the "tablets of the covenant" (Ex. 25:21; 40:20; Deut. 10:1–5), which contained the text of the covenant delivered on Mount Sinai—the "first" covenant, which Israel had broken so grievously (Heb. 8:6–13).

<span id="page-121-1"></span>On the cover of the ark were two cherubim of glory—superhuman defenders of the Lord's holy majesty—who faced one another. Between them was the "mercy seat," the place of propitiation22 for sin (Ex. 25:17–22; Lev. 16:14–16). This cover was the Lord's royal throne and the place where he spoke to his servants (Ex. 25:22; Num. 7:89; 1 Sam. 4:4; 2 Sam. 6:2).

<span id="page-121-16"></span><span id="page-121-9"></span><span id="page-121-2"></span>Although one could explore the symbolic significance of the furniture in both chambers,23 our author dismisses this opportunity as beside the point he is making. In Hebrews 11:32 he will again abridge what could have been a longer discussion, there mentioning time considerations. His purpose is to focus rather on the worship activities conducted by priests in the tabernacle's two chambers.

<span id="page-121-14"></span><span id="page-121-13"></span>9:6 Verse 1 mentioned the first covenant's "regulations for worship" (*dikaiōmata latreias*). As the discussion turns from the tabernacle's structure and furnishings to the ministry conducted in it, these terms mark the boundaries of the paragraph: the priests' "ritual duties" (*tas latreias*) open the paragraph, which concludes with "regulations [*dikaiōmata*] for the body" (v. 10). The Greek syntax of verses 6–7 emphasizes the contrast between the ministry activities befitting each of the tent's sections (table 1.4).

<span id="page-121-4"></span>In the "first" (outer) section, priests "regularly" (*dia pantos* = always) performed several worship tasks. The lampstand burned continuously, so priests replenished its oil regularly (Ex. 27:20–21). The bread of the Presence was replaced each Sabbath (Ex. 25:30; Lev. 24:5–9). Incense was burned twice a day on the altar in front of the curtain leading to the Most Holy Place (Ex. 30:6–8; cf. Luke 1:8–9).

<span id="page-121-8"></span><span id="page-121-6"></span><span id="page-121-3"></span>9:7 The plurality of the priests and the regularity of their activities in the outer section were in stark contrast to the high priest's solitary and infrequent entrance into the tabernacle's second chamber, the Most Holy Place. Three differences set apart worship performed in the first section from that in the second: (a) Into the former *many* priests entered, whereas the high priest *alone* entered the latter (Lev. 16:17). (b) In the former, priests fulfilled their tasks "regularly" (daily and weekly), whereas the high priest entered the latter "but once a year," on the Day of Atonement (Ex. 30:10; Lev. 16:34). (c) Those familiar with the regulations would know that the regular tasks in the former (attending the lampstand, the table, and the incense altar) involved no shedding of blood,24 whereas the high priest entered

See the cognate verb "make propitiation" (*hilaskomai* ) (Heb. 2:17) and the other NT appearance of *hilastērion* (Rom. 3:25), and *hilasmos* (1 John 2:2; 4:10). 23 See Vern S. Poythress, *The Shadow of Christ in the Law of Moses* (Phillipsburg, NJ: P&R, 1995); Tremper Longman III, *Immanuel in Our Place: Seeing Christ in Israel's Worship* (Phillipsburg, NJ: P&R, 2001).

<span id="page-122-0"></span>the latter "not without blood" (AT) for the atonement of his own and Israel's sins (Lev. 16:11, 14–15). This offering of blood foreshadows Christ's offering of "his own blood" when he entered the "greater and more perfect tent," the heavenly Most Holy Place (Heb. 9:11–14).

<span id="page-122-7"></span>9:8–10 The significance of the contrast between the tabernacle's two chambers is now interpreted, but in a way that is difficult both linguistically and conceptually. The linguistic difficulties focus on the meaning of the Greek represented in the ESV by "not yet opened" (*mēpō pephanerōsthai* ), "the first section" (*tēs prōtēs skēnēs*), "still standing" (*echousēs stasin*), and "for the present age" (*eis ton kairon ton enestēkota*).

With respect to "not yet opened," since the subject is a "way," we might expect a verb meaning "open," such as *anoigō*. Instead we have a verb ( *phaneroō*) meaning "manifest" or "reveal." The regulations restricting who could enter the OT tabernacle's two chambers were the Holy Spirit's way of *revealing* that the route by which all God's people could draw near to God had not yet appeared in redemptive history. That "new and living way" of access would arrive only through the priestly ministry of Christ (Heb. 10:19–22).

<span id="page-122-10"></span><span id="page-122-6"></span><span id="page-122-5"></span><span id="page-122-4"></span>With respect to "the first section," the ESV rightly indicates that in verses 2, 3, 6, and 7 the first and second tents (*skēnē*) are the outer and inner "sections" or chambers of the tabernacle—the Holy Place and the Most Holy Place. Scholars debate whether the reference in verse 8 is to the Holy Place only (so ESV) or to the entire earthly sanctuary associated with the first covenant. The most likely solution to the text's conceptual challenges (as we will see) supports the ESV's consistency in interpretation: the disclosure of the way into the Most Holy Place depends on the removal of the "first section"—that is, of the Holy Place populated by many priests in ceaseless activity—as the locus of worship.

With respect to "is still standing," an unusual Greek word (*stasin*) suggests that the issue is probably not whether the first "section" still *exists* but whether it still *functions* as the divinely appointed site of worship. As long as that first section still "has standing" as the divinely authorized venue for worship, the restrictions remain, barring any but the high priest from God's presence.

<span id="page-122-8"></span>With respect to "for the present age," the question is whether the author has in view the age that *was* present when the first covenant's sanctuary served as Israel's worship venue or the age that *is now* present by virtue of Christ's priestly mediation. Put another way, is "the present age" *prior to* or *identified with* "the time of reformation," which Christ has inaugurated (v. 10)? Our author's frame of thought, as well as the sense of similar expressions elsewhere in the NT (Matt. 12:32; Gal. 1:4; Eph. 1:21), favor the conclusion that "the present age," symbolized by the first section and its regulations, was *brought to an end* by the arrival of "the time of reformation."

<span id="page-122-9"></span><span id="page-122-3"></span><span id="page-122-2"></span><span id="page-122-1"></span>Drawing together our linguistic conclusions, we can trace the author's reasoning: The Holy Spirit (who speaks in Scripture [10:15] and acts in the apostolic church [2:4; 6:4]) has now shown that the tabernacle's two sections symbolize ( *parabolē*) two ways of worship, befitting two successive covenants and ages in God's redemptive

plan. Our discussion has referred to the Holy Place and Most Holy Place, respectively, as the tabernacle's "outer" and "inner" sections, but Hebrews calls them "first" and "second." Their spatial relationship—the high priest must move through "the first" to enter "the second"—also symbolizes chronological succession.

The first section (outer chamber), in which many priests repeatedly performed actions that could not cleanse consciences, illustrates the insufficiency of the old covenant's *entire* earthly sanctuary with its sacrifices—a system beset with the imperfections of "the present age." The "gifts and sacrifices" offered by the many priests "cannot perfect the conscience of the worshiper." The ceremonial regulations concerning food and drink and washings, like goats' and bulls' blood, touch only "the body" (*sarx*, rendered "flesh" in v. 13) and cannot remove sin's defilement from the conscience. As long as that system functions, the way into God's Most Holy Place remains hidden.

<span id="page-123-4"></span><span id="page-123-3"></span><span id="page-123-2"></span>On the other hand, the second section, entered by a solitary high priest once a year with atoning blood, provides a *preview* of Christ's entrance into heaven, "the greater and more perfect tent," bringing his own blood, shed once for all to cleanse the consciences of believers (9:11–14). His appearance in history "at the end of the ages" (v. 26) has inaugurated "the time of reformation," for his sacrifice and exaltation have opened unrestricted communion between the Lord and his people. The route of access for all into God's presence is "set right" (*diorthōsis =* "reformation"; ESV) and displayed at last. This term represents the rectifying of something damaged or defective. A related term refers to political or social reforms in Acts 24:2, and the cognate verb appears in Jeremiah 7:3–5 LXX with the sense of "to correct." The restrictions surrounding access to the first covenant's sanctuary were the Holy Spirit's signal that radical repair was needed if God's people were ever to make their way into his presence.

#### <span id="page-123-1"></span><span id="page-123-0"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-123-5"></span>Knowing how scenes of splendor strike our own senses and grip our own hearts with wonder and awe, we can appreciate why the OT sanctuaries—the tabernacle and later the temple—were designed by God in stunning beauty in order to overwhelm the Israelites with holy reverence for his majesty. Gold gleamed from the furnishings, reflecting his glory. Priests constantly attended to the signs of his light-giving presence, his food-furnishing faithfulness, his ever-listening ear. Once a year, for the whole community, innocent blood was shed to avert sin's just retribution by covering sin's defilement. Surely faith should be fortified by all that the eyes could see! Yet Hebrews informs us that the visible splendor and the multiple actions of multiple intermediaries were symptomatic of a system of covenant communion in dire need of repair. Our hope of welcome into our Creator's presence lies not in gorgeously appointed facilities or elaborate rituals but in the solitary sacrifice of Jesus the Son of God and his never-failing intercession at God's right hand. To focus our faith on him is to "offer to God acceptable worship, with reverence and awe" (12:28).

### <span id="page-124-3"></span>OVERVIEW OF HEBREWS 9:11–28

<span id="page-124-5"></span><span id="page-124-4"></span><span id="page-124-1"></span><span id="page-124-0"></span>Having sketched the inadequacy of the first (Sinai) covenant (8:7–13), its sanctuary, and its worship (9:1–10), our author explores the superiority of Christ's high priestly ministry, with reference to the themes of sanctuary, sacrifice, and covenant. The sanctuary in which he serves is heaven itself, and the sacrifice he offers is his own blood (9:11–14, 21–28). Through his death he redeemed people who, by transgressing the old covenant, had forfeited their lives; thus he mediates a new covenant that secures their eternal blessedness (9:15–20).

### <span id="page-124-2"></span>HEBREWS 9:11–14

**<sup>11</sup>**But when Christ appeared as a high priest of the good things that have come,*<sup>1</sup>* then through the greater and more perfect tent (not made with hands, that is, not of this creation) **12**he entered once for all into the holy places, not by means of the blood of goats and calves but by means of his own blood, thus securing an eternal redemption. **13**For if the blood of goats and bulls, and the sprinkling of defiled persons with the ashes of a heifer, sanctify*<sup>2</sup>* for the purification of the flesh, **14**how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without blemish to God, purify our*<sup>3</sup>* conscience from dead works to serve the living God.

1Some manuscripts *good things to come* 2Or *For if the sprinkling of defiled persons with the blood of goats and bulls and with the ashes of a heifer sanctifies* 3Some manuscripts *your*

#### *Section Overview: Christ's Conscience-Cleansing Blood*

The reality foreshadowed by the OT high priest's once-a-year entrance into the Most Holy Place has now appeared in the person and ministry of Christ, the High Priest who delivers the good things God promised in the new covenant. Both the sanctuary Christ entered and the sacrificial blood he presented to God surpass the first covenant's earthly Holy Place and its rituals. As a result, Christ has secured for those who trust him not a temporary reprieve from exclusion from a handmade tent but eternal redemption and endless access to God's heavenly sanctuary. Now that Christ has purified our consciences from evil deeds that breed death, we may and must serve the living God.

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-125-5"></span><span id="page-125-4"></span>I. Christ has appeared as the High Priest who grants the good blessings of the new covenant (9:11–12)
	- A. He entered a better sanctuary, not made by human hands (9:11)
	- B. He brought better blood, not that of animals but his own (9:12a)
	- C. He secured eternal redemption (9:12b)
- <span id="page-125-6"></span>II. The flesh-purifying blood of animals foreshadowed the consciencepurifying blood of Christ (9:13–14)
	- A. The blood and ashes of slain animals produce ceremonial purification (9:13)
	- B. The blood of Christ produces conscience purification (9:14)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-125-8"></span><span id="page-125-3"></span>9:11–12 The conjunction "But" signals the contrast between the old covenant era, with its restrictive regulations and superficial cleansing rituals, and the "time of reformation" (v. 10) that has arrived with the coming of Christ. The old covenant's earthly sanctuary was "but a shadow of the good things to come" (10:1), and with Christ's appearance "the good things"—the new covenant's better promises (8:6)—"have come" (9:11). Here a number of Greek manuscripts read "good things to come" (*mellontōn*), as in 10:1. Fewer but more reliable manuscripts read "good things that *have* come" (*genomenōn*; so ESV). This reading better fits the transition from the "not yet" OT situation (9:8–10) to the new era inaugurated by Christ's appearance.

<span id="page-125-9"></span><span id="page-125-7"></span><span id="page-125-2"></span><span id="page-125-1"></span>Christ's ministry as High Priest is similar to but better than that of the OT high priest on the Day of Atonement (v. 9). As the high priest entered the Most Holy Place "once a year" (v. 7), so Christ entered the heavenly holy places "once for all" (v. 12). Of course, "once a year" imperfectly previewed "once for all," since the OT high priest did so "repeatedly . . . every year" (9:25), and the sacrifices he offered were "a reminder of sins every year" (10:3). The ancient high priest passed through the first section of the tabernacle/temple (Holy Place) in order to enter the second (Most Holy Place). So also Christ "through the greater and more perfect tent ["section," consistent with the sense of *skēnē* in 9:2, 3, 6, 7, 8] . . . entered . . . into the holy places." As the high priest brought blood for his own and others' sins, so Christ brought blood—not that of goats and calves but his own—to secure for others "eternal redemption."

<span id="page-125-0"></span>Our author uses a chiasm25 to stress the contrasts:

Christ

- (A) through the greater and more perfect tent
	- (B) *not* made with hands, that is, *not* of this creation
	- (B') *not* by means of the blood of goats and calves

(A') but by means of his own blood

entered once for all into the holy places, thus securing an eternal redemption

<span id="page-126-10"></span><span id="page-126-9"></span><span id="page-126-0"></span>God's heavenly sanctuary is envisioned as consisting of two chambers, like its earthly copy (8:5). Christ passed through the "greater and more perfect tent" through the heavens (4:14)—to enter "the holy places," the heavenly Most Holy Place. Since the entryway into Christ's heavenly sanctuary was not made by human hands (unlike the tabernacle; Ex. 31:1–11), it is exempt from the mutability that besets the created universe (Heb. 1:10–12; 12:26–28; cf. Mark 14:58; Acts 7:48). By contrast, Judaism's second temple would lie in ruins, dismantled by Roman soldiers, only a few years after this sermon-letter of Hebrews was penned.

<span id="page-126-16"></span><span id="page-126-2"></span>The superiority of Christ's sacrificial offering fits the sanctuary he has entered. "His own blood" surpasses the blood of goats and calves not only because animal deaths cannot atone for human sin (Heb. 10:4) but also because Christ's blood represents the suffering he personally endured as God incarnate in order to lead to glory God's many sons (2:10–12). Ancient Israel's high priest entered the Most Holy Place annually "with blood not his own" (9:25). Jesus suffered "to sanctify the people through his own blood" (13:12; cf. Acts 20:28).

<span id="page-126-17"></span><span id="page-126-15"></span><span id="page-126-14"></span><span id="page-126-7"></span><span id="page-126-4"></span>Christ's ministry surpasses that of OT high priests with respect to its result as well: it secured "eternal redemption." Both "eternal" and "redemption" set Christ's ministry apart from that of previous high priests. Since his "once-for-all" sacrifice completely cleanses consciences, its purifying effectiveness is "eternal" (Heb. 10:3, 10–12). The Greek word behind "eternal" (*aiōnios*) refers not only to endless duration but also to participation in the "age to come," which will be better than the present age not merely quantitatively but also qualitatively (Heb. 6:5; cf. 2:5; 13:14; Matt. 12:32; Mark 10:30; Rom. 8:18; Eph. 1:21).

<span id="page-126-13"></span><span id="page-126-6"></span><span id="page-126-1"></span>"Redemption" (*lytrōsis*) includes both forgiveness of sins and deliverance from sin's penalty, death, as shown in the appearance of a cognate term (*apolytrōsis*) in verse 15: "a death has occurred that redeems them from the transgressions committed." Sin not only disqualifies people from approaching God but also places them under his wrath. Redemption further includes liberation from enslavement (Luke 1:68–71; 2:38; 24:21; Titus 2:14; 1 Pet. 1:18). Christ achieved "age to come" redemption by dying to defeat the death-inflicting Devil and free the Devil's slaves (Heb. 2:14–15).

<span id="page-126-12"></span><span id="page-126-11"></span><span id="page-126-8"></span><span id="page-126-5"></span><span id="page-126-3"></span>9:13–14 The superior achievement of Christ's sacrifice is now supported by another "lesser-to-greater" argument (cf. comment on 2:2–4): If slain animals' blood and ashes effected ceremonial purification of the *flesh* (9:9–10), how much more effective is Christ's blood for purifying worshipers' *consciences*, qualifying them to serve in God's presence! In addition to the shedding of goats' and bulls' blood for regular <span id="page-127-0"></span>sin offerings (Leviticus 4) and the Day of Atonement (Leviticus 16), our preacher mentions a purification ceremony involving "sprinkling . . . with the ashes of a heifer," a rite to cleanse those ceremonially defiled by contact with a human corpse (Numbers 19). All these sacrificial animals were to be physically "without blemish" (*amōmon*) (Lev. 4:3, 23, 28, 32; Num. 19:2).

<span id="page-127-11"></span><span id="page-127-10"></span><span id="page-127-9"></span><span id="page-127-5"></span><span id="page-127-2"></span><span id="page-127-1"></span>Christ "offered himself" as one not merely physically but also spiritually and morally "without blemish" (*amōmon*). Because he was "without sin" (Heb. 4:15), "holy, innocent, unstained" (7:26), he needed no sacrifice for his own sins (unlike the Levitical high priest; 5:2–3; 7:27) and could serve as the flawless substitute for others. He offered himself in death "through the eternal Spirit," as God had anointed him with the Holy Spirit (1:8–9; Acts 10:38) for his redeeming task as royal Messiah and suffering servant (Luke 3:21, alluding to Ps. 2:7 and Isa. 42:1). The Spirit is "eternal" (*aiōnios*) not only because he is divine but also because his presence characterizes the age (*aiōn*) to come, manifested already in displays of new creation power (Heb. 2:4; 6:4–5).

<span id="page-127-13"></span><span id="page-127-8"></span><span id="page-127-7"></span><span id="page-127-4"></span><span id="page-127-3"></span>Christ's greater sacrifice accomplishes deeper purification—not merely of the flesh but also of the conscience. "Purify" (*katharizō*) appears in another expression of Jeremiah's new covenant prophecy: "I will *cleanse* them from all the guilt of their sin against me, and I will forgive all the guilt of their sin and rebellion against me" (Jer. 33:8 = LXX 40:8). For our preacher, "dead works" are violations of God's law, which deserve death (Heb. 6:1; cf. 2:14–15; 10:26–31). Cleansing from sin's pollution and penalty opens access to God's presence, so that those who trust Christ may draw near to God with confidence (10:2, 9–14, 22). That we can now "serve the living God" in his Most Holy Place is implied by our author's use of the worship-related verb "serve" (*latreuō*), related to the noun (*latreia*) used to describe the priests' activities in the tabernacle (9:1, 6). He will apply the same term to our thankful worship (12:28). This is the second of four texts in which our preacher points out that we worship "the living God" (3:12; 10:31; 12:22; cf. 1 Thess. 1:9).

#### <span id="page-127-14"></span><span id="page-127-12"></span><span id="page-127-6"></span>*Response*

The self-offering of Christ bestows on believers benefits beyond our capacity to fathom. His blood silences the charges of our own accusing, shame-shrouded conscience. He defeats and disarms Satan, who can no longer prosecute or enslave us by the fear of death. Yet Christ's death does more than meet our need for "eternal redemption" through cleansing, forgiveness, and liberation. The goal of the redemption he secured is to bring us into God's presence as priests consecrated "to serve the living God." What more fitting response could there be than for those who are receiving an unshakable kingdom to "offer to God acceptable worship, with reverence and awe" (12:28)?

### <span id="page-128-0"></span>HEBREWS 9:15–22

**<sup>15</sup>**Therefore he is the mediator of a new covenant, so that those who are called may receive the promised eternal inheritance, since a death has occurred that redeems them from the transgressions committed under the first covenant.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>16</sup>**For where a will is involved, the death of the one who made it must be established. **17**For a will takes effect only at death, since it is not in force as long as the one who made it is alive. **18**Therefore not even the first covenant was inaugurated without blood. **19**For when every commandment of the law had been declared by Moses to all the people, he took the blood of calves and goats, with water and scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the book itself and all the people, **<sup>20</sup>** saying, "This is the blood of the covenant that God commanded for you." **21**And in the same way he sprinkled with the blood both the tent and all the vessels used in worship. **<sup>22</sup>** Indeed, under the law almost everything is purified with blood, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness of sins.

1The Greek word means both *covenant* and *will*; also verses 16, 17

#### *Section Overview: Covenant-Inaugurating Blood*

The sacrificial bloodshed on the Day of Atonement showed that only a substitute's death could sustain the covenant between the Lord and his sinning people. This covenant was a solemn commitment of all-encompassing, exclusive loyalty. To violate it meant incurring the curse of a violent, shameful death. This sanction was portrayed graphically when ancient covenants were ratified using slain animals' carcasses and blood, illustrating the destruction that would befall covenant breakers. Moses used blood to inaugurate the first covenant at Sinai, but slain animals could not undergo God's curse in the place of guilty humans. Only Christ's death was able to avert the punishment our treason deserves and to secure for us the eternal inheritance we had forfeited.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. Christ's death, redeeming the first covenant's violators from death, secures their inheritance under the new covenant (9:15)
- II. Covenants are inaugurated through bloodshed to signify the lethal consequence of covenant violation (9:16–17)
	- A. Covenants are established when dead animals, symbolizing the covenant maker's death, are brought forward (9:16–17a)
	- B. Covenants do not go into force until the covenant maker has bound himself to a commitment of loyalty or death (9:17b)
- <span id="page-129-8"></span>III. Moses used bloodshed to inaugurate the first covenant, binding the Lord and Israel in a mutual commitment demanding loyalty or death (9:18–22)
	- A. He sprinkled the blood of the covenant on the Lord's book and on the people (9:18–20)
	- B. He sprinkled blood on the tent and the worship vessels (9:21–22)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-129-5"></span><span id="page-129-3"></span><span id="page-129-1"></span>9:15 Our author has spoken of Christ as the guarantor and mediator of a new covenant (7:22; 8:6–7). Then he discussed the old covenant's sanctuary and sacrifices and how Christ's entering the heavenly sanctuary with his own blood achieved our eternal redemption (9:1–14). But why are rituals involving death and bloodshed at the core of Israel's worship and of God's covenant (*diathēkē*)? The answer lies in the exclusive, comprehensive commitment the Lord imposed on his people by inaugurating a covenant relationship with them. Only two outcomes were possible. If covenant servants were faithful, they would be blessed ("eternal inheritance"). If not, they would endure curse ("death").

<span id="page-129-2"></span><span id="page-129-0"></span>Moses elaborated these opposite alternatives in graphic detail in his farewell addresses to the Israelites (Deuteronomy 28). The gravity of the covenant mandated that a death had to occur in order for those who had transgressed its commandments to escape its curse. Yet the Israelites "did not continue in my covenant" (Heb. 8:9). They brought upon themselves the covenant's dire curses, including famine, violence, exile, disease, and death. They needed to be redeemed, which could occur only through the death of an innocent substitute, Christ, whose blood purified covenant breakers from their treasonous acts, which deserve death (9:14).

<span id="page-129-6"></span><span id="page-129-4"></span>9:16–17 The ESV, like most versions and interpreters, gives the impression that the discussion shifts here suddenly, surprisingly, and briefly from biblical covenants (v. 15) to the administration of a last will and testament in the Greco-Roman legal system (vv. 16–17) and then back again to biblical covenants (vv. 18–20). (Although the NASB uses "covenant" to represent *diathēkē* in 9:16–17, its wording in verses 16–17 also describes the administration of a will after a testator's death.) This widespread interpretive tradition suggests that the mention of "inheritance" led the author to switch legal contexts, from covenants between living parties to a will involving stipulations to be implemented after the testator's death.26 However, the term translated "covenant" in verses 15, 18 (*diathēkē*) is the same word translated "will" in verses 16–17. This Greek term did often mean "last will and testament" in Hellenistic extrabiblical literature, but *diathēkē* was also the term that the LXX typically used to represent the Hebrew word *berit* (covenant). Did our author, even though he was deeply influenced by the LXX and biblical categories, suddenly

<span id="page-129-7"></span><sup>26</sup> E.g., Geerhardus Vos, *The Teaching of the Epistle to the Hebrews* (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 1956), 28–29, 39–40; Bruce, *Hebrews*, 221–224; Johnson, *Hebrews*, 240.

"switch gears" to introduce a secular Hellenistic concept into his discussion of the relation of Jesus' death to the transgressions of the first *diathēkē*?

<span id="page-130-2"></span>Recent research into ancient Near Eastern treaties and biblical covenants suggests that our author has the ratification rites of biblical covenants in view in verses 16–17. This interpretation certainly makes better sense (than the "will" view) of the *inferential links* between these verses and their context, and it also explains certain *peculiarities in the Greek wording*. 27 Consider first the *inferences* linking verses 16–17 to the preceding and following contexts. The conjunction "For" (*gar*) shows that verse 16, which binds *diathēkē* to death, supports the previous claim (v. 15) that a death has occurred to effect redemption from transgressions of the first *diathēkē*—the *covenant* established at Sinai. In verse 18 the opening "therefore" (*hothen*) indicates that the death-*diathēkē* connection described in general terms in verses 16–17 can be seen in the specific event of Moses' sprinkling of "the blood of the covenant" to inaugurate the covenant at Sinai.

The *peculiar Greek wording* is smoothed out by the ESV: "The death of the one who made it *must be established*. For a will *takes effect* only *at death*." That is a responsible interpretation. But a more literalistic rendering of the Greek would be, "The death of the one who made it *must be brought* [*pheresthai* ]. For a *diathēkē* is *confirmed*  [*bebaia*] *over dead things* [*epi nekrois*]." If a will is in view, the "bringing" of the testator's death would presumably require evidence of his death (the ancient equivalent of modern death certificates), which would set in motion the settling of the estate. But this fails to explain the plural "dead things" (*nekrois*, which the ESV makes singular and abstract: "death"). If, however, verses 16–17 refer to covenant inauguration, the covenant maker's "death" is brought in the animal carcasses symbolizing his selfmaledictory oath and the curse to befall him if he breaks the covenant. Covenant ratification rituals involving slain, split carcasses are described in Genesis 15:8–21 (where the Lord invoked covenant curse on himself) and Jeremiah 34:8–20 (where Jews who broke their covenant commitment brought upon themselves the cursed death symbolized by animal carcasses through which they had passed).

<span id="page-130-1"></span><span id="page-130-0"></span>The final clause of verse 17, "It is not in force as long as the one who made it is alive," is difficult for both the "will" interpretation and the "covenant" interpretation of *diathēkē*. In the ancient world, as in our day, a will was "in force" as a legal document as soon as it was certified by a testator. Only the execution of its stipulations regarding the distribution of the estate awaited the testator's death. If, however, *diathēkē* means "covenant" in verses 16–17 (as well as in the surrounding verses), this clause of verse 17 would mean that the covenant is not ratified until the covenant maker has taken the self-maledictory oath, committing himself to maintain loyalty—or face violent death. One scholar writes, "The formulation accurately reflects the legal situation that a covenant is never secured until the ratifier has bound himself to his oath by means of a representative death."28

<sup>27</sup> O. Palmer Robertson, *The Christ of the Covenants* (Phillipsburg, NJ: P&R, 1980), 138–144; John J. Hughes, "Hebrews IX 15ff. and Galatians III 15ff.: A Study in Covenant Practice and Procedure," *NovT* 21 (1979): 27–96; Lane, *Hebrews 9–13*, 242–243. Cf. O'Brien, *Hebrews*, 328–332. 28 Lane, *Hebrews 9–13*, 243.

<span id="page-131-6"></span><span id="page-131-5"></span>9:18–20 The ratification of the Sinai covenant illustrates the principle of verses 16–17: entering into covenant with the living God is deadly, dangerous business! A chiastic structure binds the description of Sinai's covenant inauguration (vv. 18–20) and the consecration of its sanctuary (vv. 21–22)—both by blood:

- (A) Not . . . without blood
	- (B) according to the law
		- (C) he sprinkled
			- (D) this is the blood of the covenant
		- (C') he sprinkled
	- (B') according to the law
- (A') without the shedding of blood29

Although the ritual of passing between animal carcasses is not mentioned in connection with the inauguration of the covenant at Sinai, the sprinkling of sacrificial blood at that ceremony served to symbolize the lethal consequences that would ensue in the event of a breach of commitment. Unlike the covenant with Abraham, in which the Lord alone bore the obligation to secure his servant's blessedness, at Sinai blood was sprinkled both on the people and on objects representing the Lord (Ex. 24:3–8). The Exodus account states that Moses threw half of the blood of slain animals on the Lord's altar, read from the book of the law, and then sprinkled the rest of the blood on the people who had vowed to observe "all that the Lord has spoken." Hebrews says that the blood was sprinkled on the book itself and on the people. Both texts speak of the blood being applied to the people, which is our preacher's point: at Sinai, Israel bound themselves to keep the Lord's covenant or else face a violent death under his curse.

<span id="page-131-3"></span><span id="page-131-2"></span><span id="page-131-0"></span>Hebrews mentions other features (goats as well as calves, water, scarlet wool, hyssop) that do not appear in Exodus 24. The author and his readers may have known of oral traditions not preserved in Scripture. The blood of both calves and goats was integral to the Day of Atonement ritual (Heb. 9:12; cf. Leviticus 16). The mention of features involved in other cleansing rituals (Leviticus 14; Numbers 19) may underscore the pervasiveness of the people's defilement. Moses' announcement, "This is the blood of the covenant that God commanded for you" (cf. Ex. 24:8), was appropriated by Jesus when he instituted the Lord's Supper: "This is *my* blood of the covenant" (Matt. 26:28).

<span id="page-131-7"></span><span id="page-131-4"></span><span id="page-131-1"></span>9:21–22 The tent (tabernacle) was to be the dwelling place of the holy covenant Lord. Yet the tent and its furnishings had been crafted by the hands of those same covenant-breaking, defiled, death-deserving servants. Therefore the sanctuary itself and its equipment needed ceremonial purification, as did the people. Our author stresses the use of blood in the consecration of the tent and its contents, although Exodus also prescribed the use of a specially formulated sacred anointing oil

<sup>29</sup> So O'Brien, *Hebrews*, 327, citing K. Backhaus, *Der Neue Bund und das Werden der Kirche* (Münster: Aschendorff, 1996), 185.

<span id="page-132-1"></span><span id="page-132-0"></span>(Ex. 30:22–33; 40:9–10). Blood was used to "atone for" the incense altar in the Most Holy Place (Ex. 30:1–10) and, with the holy oil, to consecrate the altar for burnt offerings in the courtyard (Lev. 8:15).

<span id="page-132-5"></span><span id="page-132-2"></span>The widespread use of blood (and a heifer's ashes, also from a victim's violent death) in the procedures of the old covenant's sanctuary served only for the purification of the flesh and could not reach the conscience (Heb. 9:9–10). Yet those rites announced a truth transcending their own effects: in order for sinful people to be redeemed from covenant curses, they need a full and free forgiveness that wipes their sullied record clean. They need the God of justice, who does not merely excuse breaches of his covenant, to fulfill his promise that he "will remember their sins no more" (8:12). Such forgiveness cannot occur "without the shedding of blood," and the only blood that can wash clean our stained consciences is "the precious blood of Christ, like that of a lamb without blemish or spot" (1 Pet. 1:19).

#### <span id="page-132-6"></span><span id="page-132-4"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-132-3"></span>Contemporary Christians may be inclined toward a casual, consumerist approach to religious "commitments." To those with this mind-set, faith in Christ may seem to be one of several potential solutions to personal problems that are worth "giving a try." If it does not "work" or it stops "working," or if something more interesting comes along, one may move on with little sense of loss. The world of biblical covenants that Hebrews summarizes takes our relationship with God far more seriously. We have heard a terrifying warning about the danger of irreversible apostasy (Heb. 6:4–8). Now we confront the life-or-death consequences of entering into covenant with the living God, who is not to be trifled with or just "given a try." At Sinai the Israelites were shown a bloody preview of the death they would die if they spurned their divine husband. Yet their loyalty lasted no longer than ours often does. Our Hebrews preacher calls us to deep seriousness and to high joy: *seriousness* because transgressors of God's holy commands deserve utter ruin at his hands, but *joy* because God sent his Son as High Priest and blameless sacrifice in order to redeem us from ruin by bearing wrath in our place and to bestow upon us an eternal inheritance.

### <span id="page-133-6"></span>HEBREWS 9:23–28

**<sup>23</sup>**Thus it was necessary for the copies of the heavenly things to be purified with these rites, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these. **24**For Christ has entered, not into holy places made with hands, which are copies of the true things, but into heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God on our behalf. **25**Nor was it to offer himself repeatedly, as the high priest enters the holy places every year with blood not his own, **<sup>26</sup>** for then he would have had to suffer repeatedly since the foundation of the world. But as it is, he has appeared once for all at the end of the ages to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself. **<sup>27</sup>**And just as it is appointed for man to die once, and after that comes judgment, **<sup>28</sup>** so Christ, having been offered once to bear the sins of many, will appear a second time, not to deal with sin but to save those who are eagerly waiting for him.

#### *Section Overview: Christ's Heavenly Sanctuary and Final Sacrifice*

<span id="page-133-2"></span>In the theology of Hebrews, covenant, sacrifice, and sanctuary are interrelated in both the old covenant and the new. The blood of sacrifices was integral to the inauguration of the old covenant, for that blood illustrated the life-or-death sanctions that reward loyalty and punish infidelity (9:15–20). Sacrificial blood was used to consecrate the OT sanctuary and its equipment, purging the pollution they absorbed from sinful human artisans (9:21–22). Thenceforth the sanctuary was the Holy Place where priests offered sacrifices to atone for worshipers' sins, maintaining their communion with the Lord by averting his covenant curse.

<span id="page-133-5"></span><span id="page-133-4"></span><span id="page-133-3"></span><span id="page-133-1"></span>Having surveyed this relationship with respect to the first covenant's earthly sanctuary and sacrifices (9:16–22), our author now turns to the new covenant's heavenly sanctuary and Christ's role as mediator of this new covenant (cf. 9:15). Christ's single self-sacrifice sustains our covenant communion with God. Two marks of its superiority are highlighted: (a) Christ's blood consecrates heaven itself (not a handmade copy thereof) as the sanctuary where we approach God (9:23–24); (b) Christ entered this sanctuary once (not repeatedly) to atone for the sins of many (9:25–28). This section elaborates the themes of 9:11–12: Christ entered a sanctuary not belonging to the created universe, he did so once for all, he brought his own blood (not that of goats and calves), and thus he secured eternal redemption.

#### <span id="page-133-0"></span>*Section Outline*

I. Christ's blood has purified the heavenly sanctuary, the venue of our worship (9:23–24)

- A. The handmade tent, a copy of the heavenly sanctuary, was purified by animals' blood; so the heavenly sanctuary had to be purified by a better sacrifice: Christ's blood (9:23)
- <span id="page-134-8"></span>B. Christ, our Great High Priest, represents us in God's presence (9:24)
- II. Christ accomplished his priestly mission once for all (9:25–28)
	- A. Unlike the Levitical high priest, Christ did not enter the Most Holy Place repeatedly, but once at the climax of the ages to remove sin by sacrificing himself (9:25–26)
	- B. As every human faces two milestones, so does Christ (9:27–28)
		- 1. Every human dies once, and afterward faces judgment (9:27)
		- 2. Christ has died once for others' sins, and afterward will return to save them (9:28)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-134-7"></span>9:23–24 Verse 22 connected the purification (*katharizō*) of handmade instruments of worship and the forgiveness of human sins. This link makes sense of the consecration of the *earthly* tabernacle and its furnishings through blood. The products of defiled human hands had to be purged in order to serve as God's holy residence. Such cleansing required bloodshed, the prerequisite for the forgiveness of sins. Now our preacher's "how much more" argument takes a surprising turn: If animal sacrifices were needed to purify the handmade earthly tent, how much greater are the sacrifices needed to purify "the heavenly things themselves," the Most Holy Place "not . . . made with hands" (v. 24, echoing v. 11)! This reasoning is consistent with the sermon's pervasive theme: Christ and the new covenant surpass in every way God's prior provision for his people (1:1–4; 2:1–4; 3:5–6; 4:14–5:10; 7:1–28; 8:6–13; 9:11–14; etc.). The "better sacrifices" refer to the one, unrepeatable self-offering of Christ himself, the innocent High Priest and sacrificial victim "without blemish."

<span id="page-134-5"></span><span id="page-134-4"></span><span id="page-134-3"></span><span id="page-134-1"></span>But why would "heaven itself," untouched by human hands and undefiled by human sin, need "to be purified" (*katharizō*)? Perhaps the reference to "the heavenly things themselves" points not only to God's heavenly sanctuary but also to the people destined to worship there. To be sure, since the tabernacle and its contents were "copies [*hypodeigmata*] of the heavenly things," those "heavenly things" must refer to the transcendent Most Holy Place, which Moses beheld on the mountain (8:5). Yet the tabernacle's consecration by blood was bound up with the forgiveness of worshipers who meet God there (9:22). This suggests that the "heavenly things" purified by Christ's sacrifice may be the people of God, pictured as his living sanctuary.30 The imagery of God's people as his dwelling place appears elsewhere in the NT (1 Cor. 3:16–17; Eph. 2:20–22; 1 Pet. 2:4–8). In Hebrews such imagery appeared when Jesus' greater glory was compared to that of "the builder of a house," followed by the statement, "We are his house" (Heb. 3:3, 6).

<span id="page-134-6"></span><span id="page-134-2"></span><span id="page-134-0"></span><sup>30</sup> Bruce, *Hebrews*, 228–229; O'Brien, *Hebrews*, 336–338.

<span id="page-135-8"></span><span id="page-135-7"></span><span id="page-135-6"></span>However we construe the purification of "the heavenly things," the preacher's point is to reassert that Christ's high priestly ministry occurs not in an earthly replica of God's true sanctuary (8:5) but in "heaven itself." Every high priest offers sacrifices for sins (5:1), so Christ needed "something to offer" (8:3). He offered himself to purify others of their sins (7:27; 9:11–14). These statements have prepared us for this decisive moment in redemptive history, the fulfillment of the Day of Atonement as the Great High Priest enters into the heavenly Most Holy Place.

<span id="page-135-12"></span><span id="page-135-11"></span>9:25–26 The author explores the contrast between the repeated ( *pollakis* in both verses) sacrifices offered by Levitical high priests and Christ's once-for-all (*hapax*; v. 27) sacrifice of himself. The mention of the high priest's entering the holy places "with blood not his own" shows that the Day of Atonement is in view. Previously, the infrequency of the high priest's access to the Most Holy Place ("but once a year") was cited to show that the way into God's true sanctuary was not revealed under the old covenant (vv. 7–8). The once-a-year ministry of the Levitical high priest did, however, prefigure the once-for-all (*ephapax*) entrance of Christ into the heavenly Most Holy Place (v. 12).

<span id="page-135-14"></span><span id="page-135-9"></span>From a different perspective, the fact that the Day of Atonement ritual took place over and over, year after year, showed that Levitical rites could never remove defilement from human consciences. If "the blood of bulls and goats" could take away sins, they would not have been "offered every year" (10:1–4). Christ brought infinitely more costly blood when he entered once for all into the heavenly Most Holy Place. Whereas the Levitical high priest presented "blood not his own," that of slain goats and calves (9:12), Christ put "away sin by the sacrifice of *himself* " (v. 26) when he was "offered once to bear the sins of many" (v. 28).

<span id="page-135-15"></span><span id="page-135-10"></span>Because Christ's offering was his own death, it is unthinkable that he would undergo this suffering "repeatedly [*pollakis*] since the foundation of the world." Rather, he appeared "at the end of the ages [*epi synteleia tōn aiōnōn*]," the climactic moment in redemptive history. Christ's incarnation, ministry, death, and exaltation form the complex of events marking the arrival of "the last days" (1:1–2; Acts 2:17) and "the end of the ages [*ta telē tōn aiōnōn*]" (1 Cor. 10:11; cf. Matt. 13:39–40).

<span id="page-135-13"></span><span id="page-135-5"></span><span id="page-135-4"></span><span id="page-135-3"></span><span id="page-135-2"></span><span id="page-135-1"></span><span id="page-135-0"></span>9:27–28 General human experience further demonstrates that Christ's sacrificial death could occur only once. The observation that "it is appointed for man to die once, and after that comes judgment" refutes Eastern religions' belief in reincarnation and Western materialism's belief that physical death annihilates human beings' personal existence. But our preacher's real purpose is to draw a parallel to Christ's experience. Others' deaths will be followed by the last judgment (Rom. 14:10; 2 Cor. 5:10; Rev. 20:11–15). Christ, who died "to bear the sins of many" as the suffering servant (Isa. 53:4–5, 11–12), "will appear a second time," just as on the Day of Atonement the Levitical high priest emerged from the Most Holy Place after sprinkling blood on the mercy seat (Lev. 16:12–19;

<span id="page-136-4"></span><span id="page-136-2"></span><span id="page-136-1"></span><span id="page-136-0"></span>Heb. 9:4–5). When Christ emerges from the heavenly sanctuary, he will appear a second time not for judgment, as in the case of fellow humans, but to bring the fullness of "salvation" to those who eagerly await him (cf. Rom. 8:19–25; 1 Cor. 1:7; Gal. 5:5; Phil. 3:20). The "salvation" that the Lord first announced to his apostles (Heb. 2:3) included not only the forgiveness of sins but also dominion in the world to come (2:5). Christ's return in glory will complete his people's salvation.

#### <span id="page-136-3"></span>*Response*

This text reveals truths about Christ that elicit confident assurance and eager expectation. First, Christ now appears "in the presence of God on our behalf." He has carried the sacrificial blood he himself shed on the cross, when he died the death we deserve for breaking God's covenant. Because his blood "puts away sin," purifying our conscience, we "have confidence to enter the holy places by the blood of Jesus" (10:19). Our privileged place in the history of redemption, the era in which Jesus has opened the way into God's sanctuary, should move us to "draw near . . . in full assurance of faith" through prayer and worship (10:22).

<span id="page-136-8"></span><span id="page-136-7"></span><span id="page-136-6"></span><span id="page-136-5"></span>Second, Christ "will appear a second time." The certainty of his second coming must move us to "eagerly [wait] for him." Although daily duties and creature comforts often focus our attention on the present, knowing that our High Priest will return, bringing complete salvation, lifts our sights and stirs our longings: "Come, Lord Jesus!" (Rev. 22:20).

### HEBREWS 10:1–10

10 For since the law has but a shadow of the good things to come instead of the true form of these realities, it can never, by the same sacrifices that are continually offered every year, make perfect those who draw near. **2**Otherwise, would they not have ceased to be offered, since the worshipers, having once been cleansed, would no longer have any consciousness of sins? **3**But in these sacrifices there is a reminder of sins every year. **4**For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.

**<sup>5</sup>**Consequently, when Christ*<sup>1</sup>* came into the world, he said,

"Sacrifices and offerings you have not desired, but a body have you prepared for me;

- **<sup>6</sup>** in burnt offerings and sin offerings you have taken no pleasure.
- **<sup>7</sup>** Then I said, 'Behold, I have come to do your will, O God, as it is written of me in the scroll of the book.' "

**<sup>8</sup>**When he said above, "You have neither desired nor taken pleasure in sacrifices and offerings and burnt offerings and sin offerings" (these are offered according to the law), **<sup>9</sup>** then he added, "Behold, I have come to do your will." He does away with the first in order to establish the second. **<sup>10</sup>**And by that will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.

1Greek *he*

### *Section Overview: Repeated Animal Sacrifices Replaced by Christ's Once-for-All Offering*

<span id="page-137-0"></span>The superiority of Christ's sacrifice to the atonement provisions of the old covenant is shown in three ways: (1) The law's sacrifices were a shadow, not the substance, of the real means of cleansing from sin. (2) The annual repetition of the Day of Atonement sacrifices implied that the blood of bulls and goats could not take away sins. (3) Christ's words in Psalm 40:6–8 identify two ways to receive forgiveness, the first (the deaths of animals) ineffective and destined to be replaced by the second, Christ's offering his human body to fulfill God's will. Christ's self-offering has sanctified our consciences once for all.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. The annual repetition of the law's sacrifices shows that they cannot purify consciences (10:1–4)
	- A. The law presented a shadow, not the substance, of the good things that were to come in the new covenant (10:1a)
	- B. The law's Day of Atonement sacrifices could not cleanse worshipers' consciences (10:1b–4)
		- 1. If those sacrifices had cleansed consciences, they would not have needed to be repeated (10:1b–2)
		- 2. Those sacrifices were annual reminders, not removers, of sin's defilement (10:3)
		- 3. The deaths of bulls and goats cannot atone for humans' sins (10:4)
- II. As he entered the world, Christ announced that he was replacing OT sacrifices by his own obedience to God's will through offering his body (10:5–10)
	- A. The words of Psalm 40 are the words of the incarnate Christ (10:5a)
	- B. Psalm 40:6–8 contrasts sacrificed animals that do not please God to Christ's performance of God's will (10:5b–7)
	- C. Psalm 40:6–8 announced that Christ' obedience would replace the law's sacrificial system (10:8–10)
		- 1. Although God's law commanded animal sacrifices, their deaths did not win his pleasure toward worshipers (10:8)
- 2. Christ's coming to do God's will replaced the law's sacrifices (10:9)
- <span id="page-138-4"></span>3. Christ did God's will by offering his body once for all, sanctifying us (10:10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-138-12"></span><span id="page-138-0"></span>10:1–4 On Mount Sinai God showed Moses his heavenly sanctuary and directed him to construct the tabernacle after that pattern; thus it was "a copy and shadow [*skia*] of the heavenly things" (Heb. 8:5, citing Ex. 25:40). Likewise, the sacrifices ordered by the law were "but a shadow [*skia*] of the good things to come" and not "the true form [*eikōn*]" of those realities (10:1). In Colossians 2:16–17 Paul makes a similar point: the law's regulations were a "shadow of the things to come [*skia tōn mellontōn*]," whereas "the substance belongs to Christ." The contrast between shadow and substantial reality is not ontological (immaterial vs. physical), as in Platonic dualism. Rather, the contrast is historical and eschatological. Because the law and its rituals belonged to an earlier era, they traced the silhouette of a better mode of atonement that was, at that time, still "to come."

<span id="page-138-10"></span><span id="page-138-9"></span>The annual Day of Atonement ritual has already been contrasted to Christ's once-for-all sacrifice and entrance into the heavenly sanctuary (Heb. 9:25–28). Now our author argues that this year-by-year repetition demonstrates that the blood of bulls and goats cannot "perfect" worshipers (10:1) by removing sin's guilt (10:4). Again the plurality characterizing old covenant institutions shows their imperfection (cf. 1:1–2; 7:23–25). Now the repetition of animal sacrifices year by year on the Day of Atonement testifies to their inability to cleanse worshipers' consciences of sin's stain.

<span id="page-138-11"></span><span id="page-138-8"></span><span id="page-138-6"></span><span id="page-138-5"></span>The terms "make perfect" (*teleioō*), "cleansed" (*katharizō*, sometimes "purify" in ESV), and "sanctified" (*hagiazō*) (10:1–2, 10) are complementary ways of describing the results of forgiveness, namely, the purification of conscience that qualifies worshipers to "draw near" to God. This "perfection" could never be achieved by the Levitical priesthood, for the law "made nothing perfect" and thus could not enable sin-stained people to "draw near to God" (7:19; cf. 7:11; 9:9). Whereas slain animals' blood could "sanctify" and "purify" the flesh, only Christ's blood could purify the human conscience (9:13–14). Rather than removing sin's defilement from the conscience, the slain bulls constituted a "reminder of sins every year" (10:3). Numbers 5:15 spoke of an "offering of remembrance, bringing iniquity to remembrance" in connection with a rite to address suspicions of adultery. Our preacher's point is broader: again and again the Day of Atonement sacrifices brought Israelites' sins to their minds and "reminded" the Lord of their guilt. Only with the new covenant's arrival would the Lord "remember their sins no more" (Heb. 8:12; 10:17, citing Jer. 31:34).

<span id="page-138-13"></span><span id="page-138-7"></span><span id="page-138-3"></span><span id="page-138-2"></span><span id="page-138-1"></span>The "blood of bulls and goats" (Heb. 10:4) was central to the Day of Atonement liturgy (9:12–13). The high priest first entered the Most Holy Place with the blood of a bull to atone for his own sin and that of his family (Lev. 16:6–14). Then he emerged to slay a goat and return to God's presence with its blood to atone for the <span id="page-139-0"></span>people (Lev. 16:5–9). The mention of bulls' blood thus first reinforces the point that Levitical high priests were sinners needing atonement before they could intercede for others (Heb. 5:2–3; 7:26–27; 9:7).

<span id="page-139-11"></span>Second, the shedding of animals' blood on the Day of Atonement demonstrated that "the blood of bulls and goats" could not remove sins, for otherwise it would have been performed only once, not yearly. The question remains of why animal victims cannot die to atone for human sinners. Our preacher has already answered: those enslaved by the Devil could be saved only by a Rescuer who shared their flesh and blood, so that through his own death he might destroy the Devil's power to inflict death (2:14–15).

<span id="page-139-12"></span><span id="page-139-10"></span><span id="page-139-7"></span><span id="page-139-4"></span>10:5–7 The citation of Psalm 40:6–8 (LXX 39:7–9) is introduced as the words Christ spoke to God the Father as he "came into the world" at the incarnation. In John 11:27 Martha confessed that Jesus was "the Christ, the Son of God, who is coming into the world." At his incarnation, the Son received the "body . . . prepared" for him (Heb. 10:5), henceforth partaking of the flesh and blood his brothers and children share (Heb. 2:10–14). Here in Hebrews 10:5, "world" represents a different Greek word (*kosmos*) from that used in 1:6 and 2:5 to refer to the glorious realm of the age to come (*oikoumenē*). Here the "world" is our sin-cursed world (cf. 11:7, 38), in which Christ would fulfill God's will by sacrificing the body prepared for him.

<span id="page-139-16"></span><span id="page-139-9"></span><span id="page-139-8"></span><span id="page-139-6"></span><span id="page-139-2"></span><span id="page-139-1"></span>Psalm 40 is one of several OT texts affirming that what God seeks from his people is not the sacrificial slaughter of animals but loyalty, integrity, mercy, and obedience (1 Sam. 15:22; Pss. 50:12–16; 51:16–17; Isa. 1:11–17; Jer. 7:22–23; Hos. 6:6; Mic. 6:6–8).
