These warnings against formalism refute the assumption that sacrificial rituals will placate God's righteous wrath regardless of the state of worshipers' hearts. But our preacher views Psalm 40 in a wider perspective, as a timeline of redemptive history that has progressed chronologically from a defective sacrificial system to the final sacrifice offered by Christ. Our author's interpretation of Psalm 40, in Hebrews 10:8–10, will therefore unpack his redemptive-historical reading of the psalm.

<span id="page-139-15"></span><span id="page-139-14"></span><span id="page-139-13"></span><span id="page-139-5"></span><span id="page-139-3"></span>The citation in Hebrews of Psalm 40:6–8 follows the wording of the main LXX manuscripts with minor variations. English readers who compare Psalm 40:6–8 to its citation in Hebrews 10:5–7 will note two differences: First, English versions translate the Hebrew original of Psalm 40:6 along the lines of "You have given me an open ear" (ESV). The author of Hebrews, following the textual tradition reflected in the major LXX manuscripts, reads, "A body have you prepared for me." The origin of the LXX's departure from the Hebrew original is uncertain. Perhaps the Greek translators understood "open ears" as representative of the whole body, offered in obedience to God's voice. The reading "body" (*sōma*) serves our author's point, as we see in his explanation of the psalm, which addresses "the offering of the body [*soma*] of Jesus Christ once for all" (10:10). Second, the ESV rearranges the word order of verse 7 from that of both the OT Hebrew and the LXX of Psalm 40:7–8 (39:8–9), as well as the Greek of Hebrews 10:7:

<span id="page-140-0"></span>Hebrew and LXX of Psalm 40:7–8 (39:8–9); Greek of Hebrews 10:7:

 Then I said, "Behold I have come, in the scroll of the book it is written of me: . . . to do your will, O God."

ESV of Hebrews 10:7:

 Then I said, "Behold, I have come to do your will, O God, as it is written of me in the scroll of the book."

The rearrangement makes the ESV flow smoothly, without the interruption of the parenthetical comment "in the scroll of the book it is written of me." But this change perhaps minimizes the striking declaration, "Then I said, 'Behold, *I have come!*'" That announcement was foreshadowed in the introduction to this citation: "When Christ *came* into the world, he said . . ." (Heb. 10:5). The "then" opening verse 7 signals the temporal transition from the era of the law to the era of the new covenant that dawned when Christ entered the world to do God's will.

<span id="page-140-5"></span>The citation is structured in two couplets of lines in antithetical parallelism. The first line of each couplet expresses God's disfavor toward animal sacrifices (vv. 5b, 6). In the second line of each couplet, the speaker presents himself as a positive alternative to the (rejected) sacrifices: God has prepared a body for him, and with that body he will do God's will (vv. 5c, 7):

<span id="page-140-6"></span> Sacrifices and offerings you have not desired, (v. 5b) . . . in burnt offerings and sin offerings you have taken no pleasure. (v. 6)

<span id="page-140-8"></span><span id="page-140-7"></span> but a body have you prepared for me; (v. 5c) . . . Then I said, "Behold, I have come to do your will, O God, as it is written of me in the scroll of the book." (v. 7)

<span id="page-140-9"></span>10:8–10 In his interpretation our preacher sorts the features of the psalm citation, connecting like with like. From the first lines of the couplets he draws together four terms describing animal sacrifices: "sacrifices and offerings and burnt offerings and sin offerings." Their concentration emphasizes how *numerous* those old covenant offerings were. Then the verbs expressing God's displeasure are united ("You have neither desired nor taken pleasure"). This pairing makes the point that, in God's estimation, the blood of bulls and goats was never sufficient to take away sins.

<span id="page-140-4"></span><span id="page-140-3"></span><span id="page-140-2"></span><span id="page-140-1"></span>Although our preacher is citing Holy Scripture, some might misconstrue his strong assertion that God *disapproves* of animal sacrifices. He therefore acknowledges that "these [animal sacrifices] are offered according to the law"—the message God spoke to Moses (2:2; 3:3–5; 8:5; 12:18–21). God himself instituted that first covenant at Sinai, yet that covenant was not faultless (8:7–13) since "the law made nothing perfect" (7:19). The first covenant, with its sanctuary and sacrifices, was destined to be replaced by a new and better covenant (8:6). The psalm's "then" <span id="page-141-14"></span><span id="page-141-11"></span>reappears (10:9) to signal that the new covenant, with its better means of removing sin's defilement, has appeared in history in the Son who announced, "Behold, I have come to do your will." By his coming, Christ "does away with the first"—the first covenant, with its earthly sanctuary and slain animals (9:1)—"in order to establish the second" means of atonement and access, which is God's "will" (*thelēma*) for the complete, conscience-deep cleansing of his people—in contrast to the ineffective animal sacrifices that "you have not desired [*thelō*]" (10:5).

<span id="page-141-13"></span><span id="page-141-6"></span><span id="page-141-5"></span><span id="page-141-0"></span>The key terms "will" and "body" from Psalm 40 reappear as the author concludes his interpretation. The will of God that Jesus Christ came into the world to accomplish was his offering of the body prepared for him—the flesh and blood he now shared with his children (Heb. 2:14)—as the sacrifice that could remove our sinful pollution once for all. Christ was "without sin" throughout his life (4:15); but here our preacher focuses on God's specific redemptive purpose leading Jesus to the cross, the will to which he submitted in Gethsemane when he "offered up prayers and supplications, with loud cries and tears, to him who was able to save him from death" (5:7; cf. Mark 14:34–36). Every high priest approaches God with gifts and sacrifices (Heb. 8:3), but only Jesus offered himself, the body he shares with his human brothers, to atone for their sin.

<span id="page-141-12"></span><span id="page-141-8"></span><span id="page-141-7"></span><span id="page-141-3"></span><span id="page-141-2"></span>Christ's self-offering in death "sanctified" his people "once for all" (cf. also 7:27; 9:12, 26, 28). Unlike later theologians, the author to the Hebrews typically uses the verb "sanctify" (*hagiazō*) to refer not to the lifelong process of the Holy Spirit's subjective transformation of believers' character to conform us to Christ's holiness (e.g., 1 Thess. 5:23; cf. Heb. 12:14) but rather to a *status* of blameless purity. This status is conferred immediately on believers through forgiveness of sins, qualifying them to enter God's holy presence with confidence (2:11; 9:13; 10:14, 29; 13:12).

#### <span id="page-141-4"></span>*Response*

The first response this passage should elicit is a firm confidence that Christ's selfsacrifice has perfected, purified, and sanctified us once for all, removing sin's stain from our consciences and enabling us to draw near to God in worship. What the blood of bulls and goats, offered repeatedly according to God's law, could never do, Jesus has done fully and finally by offering his body for us on the cross. God ordained those animal victims to be a "shadow," prefiguring the true atonement accomplished by Christ. Our preacher urged his original audience not to turn away from Jesus to a system God himself had instituted, preliminarily and temporarily. All the more, then, we must not seek cleansing of conscience anywhere other than in Christ alone.

<span id="page-141-10"></span><span id="page-141-9"></span><span id="page-141-1"></span>A second response flows from our trust in Jesus. He came into the world to do God's will—the unique redemptive mission the Father had assigned him—obeying from a heart captivated by God's word (Ps. 40:8). So for us the new covenant blessing that God "will remember their sins no more" (Heb. 8:12) carries with it another blessing, reshaping our hearts in the image of our Savior: "I will put my laws into their minds, and write them on their hearts" (8:10). Full forgiveness granted freely draws us close to God and moves us to eager obedience.

<span id="page-142-6"></span>**<sup>11</sup>**And every priest stands daily at his service, offering repeatedly the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins. **12**But when Christ*<sup>1</sup>* had offered for all time a single sacrifice for sins, he sat down at the right hand of God, **13**waiting from that time until his enemies should be made a footstool for his feet. **14**For by a single offering he has perfected for all time those who are being sanctified.

**<sup>15</sup>**And the Holy Spirit also bears witness to us; for after saying,

**<sup>16</sup>** "This is the covenant that I will make with them after those days, declares the Lord: I will put my laws on their hearts, and write them on their minds,"

**<sup>17</sup>** then he adds,

"I will remember their sins and their lawless deeds no more."

**<sup>18</sup>**Where there is forgiveness of these, there is no longer any offering for sin.

<span id="page-142-3"></span>1Greek *this one*

#### *Section Overview: Christ's Atoning Mission Completed*

<span id="page-142-7"></span><span id="page-142-2"></span><span id="page-142-1"></span>The central section of Hebrews (4:14–10:31) demonstrates first why Christ's priestly *office* is better than that of Aaron and the Levitical priests (4:14–7:28), and then why Christ's priestly *ministry* surpasses theirs (8:1–10:31). Our preacher now draws his instruction on these themes to a close (10:11–18) before issuing an exhortation summoning his hearers to respond appropriately to their Great High Priest's ministry (10:19–31). One more contrast sets Jesus' atoning sacrifice above the ministry of the Levitical priests: the priests stand daily to make offerings repeatedly, whereas Jesus has been seated at God's right hand, his atoning work finished forever. Through his superior priesthood Christ mediates a new and better covenant (8:6), so the preacher's exploration of the motifs of covenant, sanctuary, and sacrifice concludes (10:15–18) where it began (8:7–13): with the new covenant promises of Jeremiah 31:31–34.

#### <span id="page-142-5"></span><span id="page-142-4"></span><span id="page-142-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. Christ's seated posture at God's right hand confirms that he has completed his sacrificial mission for all time (10:11–14)
	- A. Levitical priests stand every day, repeatedly offering sacrifices that cannot remove sin (10:11)
- B. Christ offered a single sacrifice that removes sins for all time (10:12a)
- <span id="page-143-4"></span>C. Now Christ is the king addressed in Psalm 110:1 (10:12b–13)
	- 1. He sits at God's right hand (10:12b)
	- 2. He is waiting for the subjugation of his enemies (10:13)
- D. Christ made a single offering that perfects his people for all time (10:14)
- II. The Holy Spirit testifies that Christ has enacted the new covenant's promises (10:15–18)
	- A. God is putting his word into his people's hearts (10:15–16)
	- B. God has forgiven his people's sins forever, making further sacrifice for sin unnecessary (10:17–18)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-143-9"></span><span id="page-143-6"></span>10:11 When surveying the features of the law's earthly sanctuary above (9:1–10), our author mentioned the *daily* ministries of many priests in its first section (the Holy Place) and the high priest's *yearly* ministry (Day of Atonement) in the inner section (the Most Holy Place). He then discussed why the sacrificial blood presented by high priests "repeatedly" ( *pollakis*; 9:25) on the Day of Atonement could not cleanse worshipers' consciences, as Christ's sacrifice has done once for all (9:11–10:10). Now the discussion returns to the *daily* ministry conducted by the ordinary priests.

<span id="page-143-8"></span><span id="page-143-7"></span><span id="page-143-2"></span><span id="page-143-1"></span><span id="page-143-0"></span>Inside the Holy Place, the priests attended to the lampstand and offered incense on a daily basis, and weekly they replaced the bread of the Presence (Ex. 25:30; 27:20–21; 30:6–8). On the altar of burnt offering in the courtyard, priests sacrificed two year-old lambs each day (one in the morning and another in the evening; Ex. 29:38–46; Num. 28:1–8). These animal sacrifices, offered "frequently" ( *pollakis*), are in view here. They were frequent, many, and redundant ("*the same* sacrifices") because they could never take away sins. Their inability to atone for sins or cleanse consciences was demonstrated by the priests' posture as they performed their acts of worship: those Levitical priests always *stood* (Deut. 18:5) because their work was never finished; the sacrifices they offered could never remove the guilt of sin.

<span id="page-143-10"></span><span id="page-143-5"></span><span id="page-143-3"></span>10:12–14 In contrast to the Levitical priests, who perpetually stood to perform repetitive and ultimately ineffective service, Jesus "sat down at the right hand of God." His enthronement is the result of his having offered "for all time" (*eis to diēnekes*; also in 7:3) a "single sacrifice." The terms "for all time" and "single" will reappear in verse 14, so they function as bookends (an inclusio) surrounding and unifying this further argument for the superiority of Jesus' sacrifice. At its center (vv. 12b–13) this argument revisits Psalm 110:1, enlisting its testimony to clinch the case that Christ has completed forever the removal of sin's stain from our consciences.

<span id="page-143-11"></span>Psalm 110:1 reads, "The Lord says to my Lord: 'Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies your footstool.'" Jesus appealed to this passage to challenge <span id="page-144-4"></span><span id="page-144-2"></span><span id="page-144-1"></span>his critics' assumption that the Messiah, whom David calls "my Lord," would be merely human (Matt. 22:41–45). This text is the source of NT passages teaching that Christ is now "at the right hand" of God in heaven (Matt. 26:64; Acts 2:33–36; 5:31; 7:55–56; Rom. 8:34; Eph. 1:20). Paul alludes to this verse in 1 Corinthians 15:25–26, declaring that the risen Christ must reign until all his enemies—the last of which is death (cf. Rev. 20:7–14)—are subjected under his feet.

<span id="page-144-21"></span><span id="page-144-13"></span><span id="page-144-8"></span><span id="page-144-5"></span><span id="page-144-0"></span>In Hebrews, Psalm 110:1 has been alluded to in the prologue (Heb. 1:3) and in the series of OT passages demonstrating the Son's superiority to angels (1:13). The Son's enthronement "at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven" shows that his priestly ministry is conducted not in an earthly sanctuary but in "the true tent that the Lord set up" (8:1–2). Here in 10:12 our attention is drawn to Jesus' posture: having offered the single sacrifice that finally removes sins, "he *sat down*" at God's right hand. The prologue had profiled the two phases of the Son's redemptive mission: "After making purification for sins, he sat down" (1:3). Later our author will encourage us to stay steadfast under suffering by directing our sight to Jesus and his two phases of ministry as mediator: he "*endured* the cross, despising the shame, and *is seated* at the right hand of the throne of God" (12:2; cf. Luke 24:26; 1 Pet. 1:11).

<span id="page-144-20"></span><span id="page-144-18"></span><span id="page-144-14"></span><span id="page-144-10"></span><span id="page-144-3"></span>Just as believers are awaiting Christ's reappearance from heaven (Heb. 9:28), so he himself is waiting "until his enemies should be made a footstool for his feet." His death has already neutralized the Devil, "who has the power of death," and has freed us from slavery to the fear of death (2:14–15). The blood of the Lamb has deprived that accuser of his right to press charges against us (Rev. 12:10–11). But both NT Scripture and Christian experience show that Christ's archenemy and many lesser enemies still resist his rule and assault his people (Eph. 4:27; 6:11; 1 Pet. 5:8). Only in "the world to come" will everything be subjected under Christ's feet. Even though he is already "crowned with glory and honor," we "do not yet see everything in subjection to him" (Heb. 2:5–9; cf. 1 Cor. 15:25–28).

<span id="page-144-19"></span><span id="page-144-17"></span><span id="page-144-16"></span><span id="page-144-9"></span><span id="page-144-7"></span><span id="page-144-6"></span>Because Christ's "single sacrifice for sins" achieved the forgiveness that animal deaths could never provide (Heb. 10:12), his "single offering" results in the "perfecting" and "sanctifying" of those who draw near to God through him (10:14). Throughout Hebrews, "perfect" (*teleioō*) carries the sense it acquired in the LXX, expressing the consecration qualifying priests (and other worshipers) to approach God's presence in worship (cf. comment on 2:10). Although he was sinless, Christ was "perfected"—that is, "designated by God a high priest"—through his suffering (5:8–10; 2:10; 7:28). All others, stained by sin, can only be "perfected"—purified of defilement to draw near in worship—when their sins are atoned for and their consciences purified from pollution (7:19; 9:11; 10:1).

<span id="page-144-15"></span><span id="page-144-12"></span><span id="page-144-11"></span>Although "are being sanctified" gives the impression of referring to the Holy Spirit's progressive transformation of Christians' character, the phrase is better understood as describing the holy standing conferred immediately on believers when their consciences are cleansed, once for all, by Christ's atoning blood (cf. comment on 10:8–10). Under the OT law, animals' blood "sanctified" for the puri<span id="page-145-15"></span>fication of the flesh so that those previously defiled could thereafter rejoin Israel's worshiping community (9:13). So also Christ's single sacrifice for sins has cleansed our consciences and consecrated us as holy priests, once for all and for all time.

<span id="page-145-17"></span><span id="page-145-12"></span><span id="page-145-8"></span><span id="page-145-7"></span><span id="page-145-4"></span><span id="page-145-2"></span>10:15 God's word itself supports this conclusion, since the Holy Spirit "bears witness [*martyreō*] to us" in the new covenant prophecy of Jeremiah 31:31–34, previously cited in Hebrews 8:7–12. The Holy Spirit speaks in Scripture not only in the remote past, when the word came through prophets (Heb. 1:1), but also in the present, as he still speaks through those ancient texts to new covenant believers. For instance, Psalm 95, penned by David, is what the Holy Spirit is saying to us in our "today" (Heb. 3:7). The old covenant's regulations restricting access to the tabernacle were the Holy Spirit's way of demonstrating that the way into God's presence had not yet arrived (9:8). Through the OT, God bears witness (*martyreō*) on behalf of Jesus (Heb. 7:8, 17) and on behalf of ancient saints who responded to God's promises in active faith (11:2, 4–5, 39). Now the Spirit speaks his testimony in the new covenant promises delivered through Jeremiah.

<span id="page-145-19"></span><span id="page-145-18"></span><span id="page-145-13"></span><span id="page-145-10"></span>10:16–17 Having cited Jeremiah's prophecy more fully in 8:7–12, our author selects two of the new covenant's "better promises" to conclude his case for the superiority of this covenant, of which Christ is mediator (8:6).

<span id="page-145-11"></span><span id="page-145-6"></span>First, God will put his laws into his people's hearts. The contrast with the covenant at Sinai, which the Israelites broke, is made explicit by Paul when he describes the Spirit of the living God writing his message "not on tablets of stone but on tablets of human hearts" (2 Cor. 3:3). The author of Hebrews has contrasted cleansing rituals that touch only the flesh with the conscience-purifying effectiveness of Christ's blood (Heb. 9:9–10, 13–14). It is not that believers merely imagine that they are presently sinless; rather, their sin's defilement has been removed and no longer obstructs their communion with God.

<span id="page-145-14"></span><span id="page-145-9"></span>Yet the writing of God's laws into our hearts also includes the Holy Spirit's transformation of our motivations, affections, and desires so that "the thoughts and intentions of the heart," always visible to God (4:12), begin to conform to the heart of Jesus, who said, "Behold, I have come; in the scroll of the book it is written of me: I delight to do your will, O my God; your law is within my heart" (Ps. 40:6–8, cited partially in Heb. 10:7). When our author quotes Psalm 110:1 and 4 (as he repeatedly does), he may intend to evoke also the intervening verses, which state this promise in other words: "Your people will offer themselves freely on the day of your power, in holy garments." (Ps. 110:3).

<span id="page-145-16"></span><span id="page-145-5"></span><span id="page-145-3"></span><span id="page-145-1"></span><span id="page-145-0"></span>Second, God "will remember their sins and their lawless deeds no more." Whereas the Day of Atonement sacrifices were a "reminder of sins every year" (Heb. 10:3), under the new covenant God will no longer keep sinners' offenses in mind; he will no longer relate to them in terms of their sin and guilt but rather will welcome them as holy through the purification they have received from Christ. Jeremiah 31:34 is one of several OT texts that portray God's forgiveness as his refusal to "remember sins" (Pss. 25:7; 79:8; Isa. 43:25; 64:9; Ezek. 18:22; contrast <span id="page-146-1"></span><span id="page-146-0"></span>Jer. 14:10). Instead of our sins, God "remembers" his mercy and his steadfast love (Ps. 25:6) through Christ, the mediator of the new covenant.

<span id="page-146-3"></span>10:18 The closing comment underscores the importance of God's commitment to "remember their sins . . . no more" because of Jesus' once-for-all sacrifice. His full and free forgiveness means that no further offering for sin is needed. Christ's single sacrifice ended all the animal bloodshed God's law had mandated for the era of anticipation (10:8–9).

#### <span id="page-146-2"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-146-8"></span><span id="page-146-7"></span>Christ's seated posture at God's right hand confirms that his one sacrifice forgives sin, cleanses the conscience, and grants access to the presence of God. From now on no sacrifice for sin, other than Christ's completed death on the cross, has any standing in God's eyes. The following exhortation will show that this truth has both encouraging and sobering implications. We will be encouraged to enter God's heavenly sanctuary by the blood of Jesus, since our hearts are "sprinkled clean from an evil conscience" (10:19, 22). On the other hand, we dare not turn away from Jesus, for apart from him "there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins" (10:26). The covenant he mediates imparts the inseparable twin blessings of once-for-all forgiveness and powerful transformation of heart, making us willing and able to obey God's law. As we rest in the sufficiency of Christ's blood to remove our guilt, we will submit gladly to his heavenly reign. We trust and obey.

#### OVERVIEW OF

### <span id="page-146-6"></span>HEBREWS 10:19–35

<span id="page-146-10"></span><span id="page-146-9"></span><span id="page-146-5"></span><span id="page-146-4"></span>The exhortation that flows from the superiority of Jesus' priestly ministry comes first in a positive note of encouragement, then in a negative note of warning, and finally in a positive reassurance based on the hearers' past record of faith. The term "confidence" opens and closes the exhortation (vv. 19, 35), marking its boundaries (serving as an inclusio) and reinforcing its theme. Because Jesus' blood has cleansed our consciences, we may enter God's heavenly sanctuary with confidence, hold fast to our Christian confession, and support each other in persevering hope (vv. 19–25). On the other hand, to abandon fellowship with Christ, seeking assurance in obsolete old covenant institutions, is to incur severe judgment, from which the law's sacrifices offer no escape (vv. 26–31). Yet, though sobered by this warning, hearers should nevertheless recall their past record of steadfast faith amid severe sufferings, for this evidence of God's grace will fortify their confidence (vv. 32–35).

### HEBREWS 10:19–25

**<sup>19</sup>**Therefore, brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* since we have confidence to enter the holy places by the blood of Jesus, **20**by the new and living way that he opened for us through the curtain, that is, through his flesh, **<sup>21</sup>** and since we have a great priest over the house of God, **<sup>22</sup>** let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith, with our hearts sprinkled clean from an evil conscience and our bodies washed with pure water. **23**Let us hold fast the confession of our hope without wavering, for he who promised is faithful. **24**And let us consider how to stir up one another to love and good works, **25**not neglecting to meet together, as is the habit of some, but encouraging one another, and all the more as you see the Day drawing near.

1Or *brothers and sisters*

#### *Section Overview: Draw Near to God and Encourage Each Other*

<span id="page-147-6"></span><span id="page-147-5"></span><span id="page-147-3"></span>Three hortatory subjunctives—in which the speaker exhorts himself along with his hearers—articulate the responses Jesus' superior priesthood should evoke from us: "let us draw near" (Heb. 10:22), "let us hold fast" (v. 23), and "let us consider" (v. 24). To motivate his hearers, our preacher first summarizes the result of Christ's ministry as our Great High Priest: his blood and flesh, offered in death, have opened for us a "new and living way" into the Most Holy Place in heaven, so that we can approach God with confidence (vv. 19–22). God's faithfulness gives us reason to hold fast to our hope in his promises (v. 23). Perseverance is not a solitary achievement but a corporate calling, so we must "consider" each other, seeking to stimulate loving actions as we meet together (vv. 24–25). A final reason for these positive exhortations is that "the Day," when Christ's enemies are made his footstool at his return (v. 13), is drawing near (v. 25).

<span id="page-147-7"></span><span id="page-147-2"></span>This exhortation revisits themes in the exhortation that introduced the discourse on Christ's priestly office and ministry (4:14–16). See table 1.5.

<span id="page-147-4"></span><span id="page-147-1"></span>

| Hebrews 4:14–16                  | Hebrews 10:19–25                       |  |
|----------------------------------|----------------------------------------|--|
| Having                           | Having confidence                      |  |
| a Great High Priest              | (the blood of) Jesus                   |  |
| Jesus (the Son of God)           | a Great High Priest                    |  |
| Let us hold fast our confession  | Let us draw near (with full assurance) |  |
| Let us draw near with confidence | Let us hold fast our confession        |  |

<span id="page-147-0"></span>TABLE 1.5: Common Themes in Hebrews 4:14–16 and 10:19–25

<span id="page-148-4"></span><span id="page-148-3"></span><span id="page-148-2"></span>In order to intercede for human beings with their God, a high priest must, on the one hand, *identify with* them in their weakness (5:1–3) and, on the other, have *access to God* in his holiness (5:8–10; 7:26; 9:11–12). So the exhortation that opened the sermon's central discourse on Christ's priestly mediation (4:14–10:35) highlighted *Jesus' sympathy with fragile sinners* (4:14–16), while the closing exhortation focuses on *the access into the heavenly Most Holy Place* that Jesus' sacrifice has provided.

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-148-9"></span><span id="page-148-1"></span>I. We have strong reasons to approach God with confidence (10:19–21)
	- A. Jesus' sacrificial suffering opens access for us into heaven's Most Holy Place (10:19–20)
		- 1. His blood cleanses from sin (10:19)
		- 2. His body opens a new, living route into God's presence (10:20)
	- B. Jesus' perpetual priestly service assures us of God's welcome (10:21)
- <span id="page-148-11"></span><span id="page-148-10"></span>II. So let us draw near to receive grace, hold fast our confession, and encourage each other (10:22–25)
	- A. Draw near to God because Christ has cleansed your consciences (10:22)
	- B. Hold fast your confession of hope because God is faithful to his promises (10:23)
	- C. Encourage each other in fellowship because the day of Christ approaches (10:24–25)

#### *Comment*

10:19–20 Two gifts from God under the new covenant motivate believers to "draw near" in worship (v. 22). Believers have (a) "confidence to enter the holy places" (vv. 19–20) and (b) "a great priest over the house of God" (v. 21). As the preceding discourse demonstrated, the first gift (confidence) is based on the second (Jesus' priestly ministry), which removed the sinful defilement that would otherwise have excluded sinners from God's presence. The preacher has already urged his readers to hold fast to their confidence (3:6, 14), and at the conclusion of this exhortation he will insist that they not throw it away (10:35).

<span id="page-148-8"></span><span id="page-148-7"></span><span id="page-148-6"></span><span id="page-148-5"></span><span id="page-148-0"></span>The "holy places" are the Most Holy Place in God's heavenly sanctuary, the original from which the earthly tabernacle was copied (8:2, 5). Jesus has entered the heavenly sanctuary on our behalf, bringing not the blood of slain animals but his own blood, the evidence of his sacrificial death on our behalf (9:24–25). As he entered, therefore, he "opened" or "inaugurated" (*enkainizō*; also in 9:18) for us a route into heaven's inmost sanctuary "through the curtain." The repetition of "curtain" reminds us that Jesus has gone "behind the curtain" as the high priest in the order of Melchizedek, and his presence there anchors our souls in solid hope (6:19–20). The Greek terms rendered "to enter" (*eisodos*) and "way" (*hodos*) emphasize <span id="page-149-13"></span>the change that has occurred since the OT era, when "the way [*hodos*] into the holy places" was not yet displayed (9:8–10).

<span id="page-149-2"></span><span id="page-149-1"></span>Now, not only has Jesus entered God's glorious presence, but we also may draw near to God's throne of grace through him (4:16; 10:22). The Gospels record that, when Jesus died on the cross, the temple's curtain, separating the Most Holy Place from the Holy Place, was torn from top to bottom (Matt. 27:51; Mark 15:38; Luke 23:45). Hebrews provides the Holy Spirit's interpretation of that event. This way of access is both "new" and "living." It is "new" because Jesus has opened it recently. It is "living," even though inaugurated through his death, because this High Priest, who died once for all, has been raised and "lives forever to make intercession" for those who draw near to God through him (Heb. 7:24–25).

<span id="page-149-15"></span><span id="page-149-11"></span>The parenthetical comment "that is, through his flesh," though it could be understood as saying that the curtain itself symbolized Jesus' flesh, is probably parallel to "by the blood of Jesus" in verse 19. Thus it refers not so much to the veil itself but rather to the entire sacrificial event that grants access to God. The divine Son assumed our "blood and flesh" so that he could die for us (2:14–18) and thus qualify us to "enter the holy places . . . by the new and living way."

<span id="page-149-16"></span><span id="page-149-6"></span><span id="page-149-4"></span><span id="page-149-0"></span>10:21 The second rationale for our drawing near is that we have a "great priest over the house of God." In the OT "the great priest" (Hb. *hakkohen haggadol*; LXX *ho hiereus ho megas*) was the high priest (Num. 35:25–32). In the exhortation that opened this sermon's discourse on priesthood, Jesus was called a "great high priest" (Heb. 4:14). Both his death and his never-ending life contribute to the perfection of his priestly mediation. Moreover, an echo of the contrast between Moses and the Son reminds us of his authority "over the house of God" and of our identity as "his house," the people he rules and among whom he dwells (3:6).

<span id="page-149-17"></span><span id="page-149-5"></span><span id="page-149-3"></span>10:22 Having recapped the indicative foundation of Christians' confidence, our preacher now expresses the imperative implications in three hortatory subjunctives, which include the three lasting virtues of faith, hope, and love (1 Cor. 13:13; Col. 1:3–5; 1 Thess. 1:3; 5:8). These three appeared in another order (love, hope, faith) in the book's earlier reminder of the hearers' past faithfulness (Heb. 6:10–12).

<span id="page-149-18"></span><span id="page-149-14"></span><span id="page-149-12"></span><span id="page-149-10"></span><span id="page-149-9"></span><span id="page-149-8"></span><span id="page-149-7"></span>First, we must "draw near" to God's throne of grace (cf. 4:16), exercising the priestly privilege that under the old covenant had been restricted to a few (7:19, 25; 10:1; cf. 11:6). We can approach God "in full assurance of faith," just as we must persevere in "full assurance of hope until the end" (6:11). Our confident assurance comes from the fact that our hearts have been "sprinkled clean from an evil conscience." Under the old covenant, ceremonially defiled persons were sprinkled with water containing the ashes of a heifer for ritual cleansing (9:13). Now our consciousness of defilement from sins has been removed through the "sprinkling" of Christ's blood (12:23–24; cf. 1 Pet. 1:2). This cleansing of conscience is received through faith and is visibly signified and sealed in baptism: "our bodies washed with pure water."

<span id="page-150-14"></span><span id="page-150-11"></span><span id="page-150-10"></span><span id="page-150-8"></span><span id="page-150-7"></span>10:23 Second, we must "hold fast the confession of our hope." Hebrews has called its hearers to "hold fast" to our confidence and to our boasting in hope (3:6; cf. 6:18), to the reality that we grasped in the beginning (3:14), and to our confession of faith (4:14). Perseverance is essential because the present situation of Christians is like Israel's in the wilderness, undergoing testing en route to God's promised rest (3:7–4:13). The complete salvation for which we wait will arrive when Jesus reappears from heaven (9:28). In the meantime our hope is sustained by the assurance that God, who promised us rescue and rest, "is faithful." He has sealed his promises by two unchangeable things in which he cannot lie: his promise to Abraham and his oath sworn to Christ as a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek (6:12–18). Therefore we, like ancient believers such as Sarah (11:11), can rely on his faithfulness.

<span id="page-150-15"></span><span id="page-150-13"></span><span id="page-150-6"></span><span id="page-150-3"></span><span id="page-150-2"></span>10:24–25 Finally, believers must "consider" one another for the purpose of stirring up, or "provoking," each other to love and good works. The noun rendered "stir up" ( *paroxysmos*) also appears with reference to Paul and Barnabas's "sharp disagreement" over John Mark (Acts 15:39). The cognate verb describes Paul's outrage over idolatry (Acts 17:16). Our preacher's choice of this term, expressing stimulus to the point of discomfort, is itself provocative! As in its other appearance in Hebrews (3:1), "consider" (*katanoeō*) has a personal object: we must direct our attention to fellow believers, who need encouragement in showing love through good deeds. Previously the hearers had demonstrated love in serving others' needs (6:10). Such compassionate care in action is the sort of sacrificial offering that all believers, as priests consecrated by Christ's blood, must offer for the pleasure of God (13:16).

<span id="page-150-20"></span><span id="page-150-18"></span><span id="page-150-12"></span>The urgency of their responsibility toward one another is heightened by the pressures threatening to draw believers away from Christ and his gathered church. Some had already fallen into the habit of "neglecting to meet together," perhaps because being known as Jesus' followers entailed "reproach and affliction" from their own family and the wider Jewish community (10:33; 11:26; 13:11–13). Our preacher urges his hearers to "exhort [*parakaleō*] one another every day," strengthening the weak and the wavering (3:12–13; 12:12–15). This is the purpose of his "word of exhortation" (13:22).

<span id="page-150-21"></span><span id="page-150-19"></span><span id="page-150-17"></span><span id="page-150-16"></span><span id="page-150-9"></span><span id="page-150-5"></span><span id="page-150-4"></span><span id="page-150-1"></span><span id="page-150-0"></span>A final motivation supports the call to mutual accountability: "the Day" is drawing near (10:25). The OT prophets announced that "the day of the Lord is near," often portraying this day as one of judgment to be dreaded (Isa. 13:6–9; cf. Jer. 46:10; Joel 1:15; 2:1; Zeph. 1:14–15). NT authors also predict the coming of "the Day" of the Lord, now identified as the "day of Jesus Christ," when he will reappear from heaven (Phil. 1:6; cf. 1 Cor. 1:8; Phil. 1:10; 2:16; Heb. 9:28). This day will bring both judgment and salvation (1 Cor. 3:13; 5:5; 2 Tim. 1:12; 4:8). Therefore, its approach simultaneously sustains hope in suffering believers (Heb. 10:34; 11:35–38) and issues a terrifying warning to those tempted to abandon Christ and his congregation (10:26–31).

#### *Response*

The author has told us how to respond to Christ's work. Through his atoning sacrifice and living intercession, we must "draw near" to God in worship, confident of his welcome. Because God is the faithful fulfiller of promises, we must keep a firm grip on the hope we confess. The approach of the Day on which that hope will arrive in full must move us to care for each other's needs and to cultivate each other's faith, lest any lose their moorings and drift into ruin.

### <span id="page-151-2"></span>HEBREWS 10:26–35

**<sup>26</sup>**For if we go on sinning deliberately after receiving the knowledge of the truth, there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins, **27**but a fearful expectation of judgment, and a fury of fire that will consume the adversaries. **28**Anyone who has set aside the law of Moses dies without mercy on the evidence of two or three witnesses. **29**How much worse punishment, do you think, will be deserved by the one who has trampled underfoot the Son of God, and has profaned the blood of the covenant by which he was sanctified, and has outraged the Spirit of grace? **30**For we know him who said, "Vengeance is mine; I will repay." And again, "The Lord will judge his people." **<sup>31</sup>** It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.

**<sup>32</sup>**But recall the former days when, after you were enlightened, you endured a hard struggle with sufferings, **<sup>33</sup>** sometimes being publicly exposed to reproach and affliction, and sometimes being partners with those so treated. **34**For you had compassion on those in prison, and you joyfully accepted the plundering of your property, since you knew that you yourselves had a better possession and an abiding one. **35**Therefore do not throw away your confidence, which has a great reward.

#### *Section Overview: A Terrifying Warning and Reassuring Memories*

<span id="page-151-1"></span><span id="page-151-0"></span>For the third time our preacher reasons that those who ignore or repudiate the Son of God incur the severest of punishments. The law "declared by angels" was so holy that its violation "received a just retribution." How much less will those escape who ignore the message of salvation spoken by the Son, who excels the angels (Heb. 2:1–4)! In 6:4–8, the author listed privileges of participating in the new covenant community. Then he warned that anyone who abandoned such gracious gifts by committing apostasy could not be restored because such a person had allied himself with those who crucified the Son of God. Now the author repeats his argument that disregarding the word of salvation spoken by Christ deserves even greater punishment than did a breach of the law God spoke through angels (2:1–4). He combines this reasoning with the charge of assaulting the Son of God (6:6) to

<span id="page-152-7"></span>reinforce his sober warning that "sinning deliberately"—repudiating Christ by seeking atonement elsewhere—deserves God's fiery judgment (10:26–31).

<span id="page-152-8"></span><span id="page-152-4"></span>Our author is too wise and pastoral, however, to motivate his hearers only by fear. As he did in 6:9–12, here he balances his terrifying announcement of apostasy's dire consequences with a heartening reminder of his hearers' previous record of courageous faith at the outset of their Christian pilgrimage (10:32–35). They endured ridicule and the loss of property for Jesus' sake, and they did not withdraw from identifying with other Christian sufferers, including those in chains. Those evidences of God's gracious work in their hearts should fortify their confidence that he is faithful to keep his promises.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. A terrifying warning: repudiating God's Son after learning the truth will incur worse punishment than the law's severest penalties (10:26–31)
	- A. No sacrifice for sins, but only fiery judgment, awaits those who turn from the truth they once received (10:26–27)
	- B. Merciless death was imposed on violators of the law of Moses; and those who repudiate God's Son, his blood, and his Spirit will receive worse punishment (10:28–29)
	- C. Scripture shows that the living God judges his people in justice (10:30–31)
- II. Reassuring memories: remember the sufferings you endured together when the light of Christ first shone on you (10:32–35)
	- A. Remember your initial endurance amid sufferings (10:32–34)
	- B. Do not cast away your confidence, for God will reward your faithfulness (10:35)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-152-9"></span><span id="page-152-6"></span><span id="page-152-5"></span><span id="page-152-0"></span>10:26 Because "the Day" of Christ's return to subdue his enemies is "drawing near" (10:13, 25), to "go on sinning deliberately" after "receiving the knowledge of the truth" is to bring upon oneself the severest form of divine wrath. "Deliberately" (*hekousiōs*) and its cognates describe actions performed voluntarily, not under coercion (Lev. 7:16; Num. 15:3; Ezra 1:4–6; 3:5; Ps. 54:6 [53:8 LXX]; Philem. 14; 1 Pet. 5:2). The law of Moses distinguished between sins committed inadvertently out of ignorance and those committed "with a high hand," reviling the Lord and despising his word (Num. 15:22–31; cf. Deut. 17:12). Atonement through sacrifice was possible for inadvertent violations of commandments ("unintentional sins"; Heb. 5:2; 9:7), but not for transgressions committed deliberately and defiantly.

<span id="page-152-3"></span><span id="page-152-2"></span><span id="page-152-1"></span>In a move that would have sounded shocking to Jewish ears, our author identifies the high-handed, unforgiveable sin not as a willful breach of the Ten Commandments but as abandoning trust in the Son of God and the blood he shed to sanctify sinners (6:6; 10:29) *by returning to the OT sanctuary and its sacrifices*. This

<span id="page-153-7"></span>repudiation of Christ is not a sin committed in ignorance, for it is committed by those who have received "the knowledge of the truth" (10:26), who were "enlightened" (6:4–5; 10:32) when they heard the good news of cleansing through Jesus' blood (4:2; 10:19–22).

<span id="page-153-9"></span><span id="page-153-6"></span>The discussion of the contrast between the old covenant and its animal sacrifices, on the one hand, and the once-for-all sacrifice offered by Jesus to inaugurate the new covenant, on the other (8:1–10:18) has shown why "there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins" if we turn away from Christ to seek cleansing elsewhere. The blood of bulls and goats could never take away sins, but *now* even their foreshadowing function has been rendered obsolete by the once-for-all, consciencecleansing offering of Christ's body. As we learned from Psalm 40, "He *does away* with the first in order to establish the second" (Heb. 10:5–10). This development in redemptive history means that, now that Jesus has inaugurated the new covenant (10:18), "there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins" in *any* sense under the old covenant system.

<span id="page-153-11"></span><span id="page-153-10"></span><span id="page-153-3"></span>10:27 All that remains for those who abandon God's provision in Christ is a "fearful expectation of judgment" and a "fury of fire that will consume the adversaries" of God. The author blends wording from Isaiah 26:11 and Zephaniah 1:18. "Fury" translates the Greek *zēlos*, which refers to God's zeal for his own glory and his jealousy for his people's absolute loyalty.

<span id="page-153-12"></span><span id="page-153-4"></span>10:28–29 Our preacher again reasons from lesser to greater: violations of God's lesser-to-greater revelations deserve lesser-to-greater punishments. God entrusted the law to Moses, so the violation of its commands warranted capital punishment (in many cases). To "set aside" (*atheteō*) the law of Moses may sound like a mild offense, but it is actually to reject the authority of God, who spoke the law's commandments (cf. Mark 7:9; Luke 7:30). In Ezekiel 22:26 God accuses Judah's priests of having "done violence" (LXX *atheteō*) to his law and having defiled his sanctuary. Because the punishment was so severe, Israel's judges were obligated to establish an offender's guilt through the "evidence of two or three witnesses" (cf. Num. 35:30; Deut. 17:1–7; 19:15; cf. also Matt. 18:16; 2 Cor. 13:1; 1 Tim. 5:19). Mercy could not be shown to those committing capital violations, such as murder or advocating idolatrous worship (Deut. 13:6–11; 19:11–13).

<span id="page-153-1"></span><span id="page-153-0"></span>Mere physical execution, however, cannot compare with the "worse punishment" awaiting those who have contemptuously repudiated the Son of God, the mediator of the new and better covenant. Previously the preacher characterized the sin of apostasy as "crucifying once again" and "holding . . . up to contempt" the divine and messianic Son (Heb. 6:6). Now the defiant scorn is portrayed as "[trampling] underfoot," treating him as utterly worthless (cf. Isa. 10:6; 25:10; Matt. 5:13; 7:6; Luke 8:5).

<span id="page-153-8"></span><span id="page-153-5"></span><span id="page-153-2"></span>To turn from Christ back to the ineffective animal offerings of the OT is to pour scorn not only on Christ's person but also on his infinitely costly sacrifice, "profaning" (regarding as unholy) the "blood of the covenant" he shed to atone <span id="page-154-14"></span><span id="page-154-12"></span><span id="page-154-9"></span>for others' transgressions (Heb. 9:14–15). To look elsewhere for atonement is tantamount to claiming that Jesus shed his blood not as a sinless substitute for sinful people (7:26; 9:14) but merely as one more defiled sinner receiving his just deserts, along with the rest of humanity (9:27; Rom. 5:12; 6:23). It is all too possible to be part of the covenant community, even to be "sanctified" (set apart from the unbelieving world) visibly and externally by the "blood of the covenant" (cf. Heb. 9:18–20), but then, through unbelief, to throw away the benefits offered in the gospel (10:35–39). Because the Holy Spirit is bearing witness to us that Christ's death secures forgiveness of sins (10:15–18), to repudiate Christ and his blood is to "outrage" the Spirit as the messenger of this grace.

<span id="page-154-20"></span><span id="page-154-18"></span><span id="page-154-16"></span><span id="page-154-15"></span><span id="page-154-10"></span><span id="page-154-3"></span>10:30–31 The reasoning that leads from the capital punishment of those who disregarded the Mosaic law to a more terrifying penalty for those who spurn Christ is confirmed by God's announcement that he will repay vengeance to his enemies and will judge his people. Two OT citations are drawn from the Song of Moses (Deut. 32:35, 36; cf. Ps. 135:14). As in the earlier citation of Isaiah 8:17–18 (Heb. 2:13), "and again" is inserted to show that, though they are adjoining, each quotation makes a distinctive statement, the second complementing the first. Moses' song previewed the future history of the Lord's faithful grace toward Israel (Deut. 32:1–14), Israel's unfaithfulness (vv. 15–18), the Lord's judgment on his unfaithful people (vv. 19–38), and the Lord's eventual compassion on his humbled people and vengeance on their enemies (vv. 39–43).

<span id="page-154-5"></span><span id="page-154-4"></span><span id="page-154-2"></span><span id="page-154-1"></span><span id="page-154-0"></span>The words cited by our preacher appear in the section in Deuteronomy 32 announcing Israel's punishment under the just hand of God. In the second statement the verb "judge" (*krinō*) can include both vindicating and condemning verdicts; thus in Deuteronomy 32:36 the ESV and other versions opt for "vindicate," since the next line says that the Lord will have compassion on his people. Here in Hebrews, however, our author uses "judge" in a negative sense, parallel to exacting "vengeance." His point is that God exacts vengeance not only on Israel's enemies (Deut. 32:41) but also on those among *his own people* who spurn his grace in unbelief. Being a member of the covenant community does not, in itself, guarantee immunity from divine displeasure, either for OT Israel or for the NT church.

<span id="page-154-17"></span><span id="page-154-8"></span><span id="page-154-7"></span><span id="page-154-6"></span>Again our author states that it is "fearful" ( *phoberos*; cf. Heb. 10:27) to be confronted by God in his wrath apart from the cleansing of Christ's blood. Similarly, the psalmist extols God as the one "to be feared" (Ps. 76:7–12 [LXX 75:8–13]), and Jesus himself advised his hearers to fear God "who can destroy both soul and body in hell" (Matt. 10:28). Moses, the faithful servant in God's house (Heb. 3:5) who met God on the mountain (8:5), found the display of divine glory "terrifying" ( *phoberos*) and trembled with fear (12:21). To fall into the hands of the living God when his jealous anger is kindled is to face anguish and destruction.

<span id="page-154-21"></span><span id="page-154-19"></span><span id="page-154-13"></span><span id="page-154-11"></span>10:32 Although some in the original congregation were at risk of "[falling] away from the living God" (3:12), our preacher hastens to reassure his hearers that the evidence of God's grace in their response to suffering in "the former days" gives <span id="page-155-3"></span>them grounds to expect that their faith will stand the test of mounting opposition in the present. Fear has its place in dispelling the "deceitfulness of sin" and alerting us to its danger (3:13), but it is God's kindness that leads to repentance and his initiating love that evokes our love in return (Rom. 2:4; 1 John 4:10–12, 19).

<span id="page-155-10"></span><span id="page-155-5"></span><span id="page-155-0"></span>Recalling how Christ's light-giving word produced life-changing fruit when it first burst into our hearts gives stronger grounds for persistent trust in the face of opposition. The hearers were "enlightened" when the gospel of Christ was first preached to them and they "tasted the goodness of the word of God" (Heb. 6:4–5). At that point they "endured a hard struggle with sufferings." Endurance under persecution will be a major emphasis in the next section of the sermon (10:36; 12:1–3, 7), as it has been implicit in the exhortations to "hold fast" our confession (3:6, 14; 4:14; 6:18; 10:23). "Struggle" (Gk. *athlesis*) has overtones of both military combat and sports, since these activities were closely connected in the Hellenistic world (Phil. 1:27; 4:3; 2 Tim. 2:5). Our author uses athletic imagery elsewhere in 6:20 ("forerunner") and in 12:1–2, 11–13.

<span id="page-155-13"></span><span id="page-155-9"></span><span id="page-155-6"></span><span id="page-155-2"></span><span id="page-155-1"></span>10:33–34 Earlier in their history, the recipients of Hebrews had suffered both individually and corporately. Their past readiness to identify with persecuted fellow believers set a standard that they need to recapture in the present. Since the same sorts of afflictions are threatening their personal safety, freedom, and financial security, they must recall how God's grace had strengthened them to suffer alongside each other. The author itemizes their experiences in four categories, starting and ending with personal distresses. Between these, he commends their readiness to identify themselves with other sufferers for the faith:

Personal: publicly exposed to reproach and affliction Corporate identification: partners with those so treated Corporate identification: you suffered with31 those in prison [AT] Personal: joyfully accepted the plundering of your property

<span id="page-155-7"></span>Fear of persecution may be motivating "some" to neglect gathering with other followers of Jesus (10:25), so the preacher commends his hearers' previous courage in staying close to those who were paying the price of faithfulness, enduring both public reproach and imprisonment. Among the forefathers in faith soon to be empaneled as witnesses to attest to God's reliability (11:1–40) is Moses, who "considered the reproach of Christ greater wealth than the treasures of Egypt" and therefore chose "to be mistreated with the people of God" (11:25–26).

<span id="page-155-16"></span><span id="page-155-12"></span><span id="page-155-11"></span>Like Moses (and like themselves, at the outset) the hearers of this letter must also "bear the reproach" Jesus endured by sharing the repudiation he suffered "outside the camp"—excluded from the established Jewish community (13:12–13; cf. comments on 13:11–12; 13:13–14). Their proactive ministry to prisoners in the past must continue in the present, despite the risk of guilt by association (13:3).

<span id="page-155-15"></span><span id="page-155-14"></span><span id="page-155-8"></span><span id="page-155-4"></span><sup>31</sup> The ESV renders *sympatheō* as "had compassion on" here, and the same verb as "sympathize" in 4:15. Since the verb's stem echoes "sufferings" ( *pathēmatōn*) in 10:32, it would seem that our author refers to active "co-suffering," not just emotional empathy.

<span id="page-156-7"></span>They had joyfully acquiesced when their property was seized by others, confident that they had a better, abiding possession, just as the patriarchs fixed their spiritual sights on a city with foundations, "whose designer and builder is God"—a better, heavenly country (11:10, 16). The hope of a "kingdom that cannot be shaken" (12:28) and a "lasting city" to come (13:14) will sustain Jesus' followers today, just as it strengthened OT people of faith to endure mocking, flogging, chains, homelessness, destitution, and death (11:36–38).

<span id="page-156-11"></span><span id="page-156-9"></span><span id="page-156-6"></span><span id="page-156-5"></span><span id="page-156-4"></span>10:35 With the reappearance of "confidence" ( *parrēsia*), the exhortation arising from Jesus' superior priesthood draws to a close. Those who approach God through Jesus' sacrifice have confident access in the present to enter the heavenly Most Holy Place in worship (10:19–21), and likewise they have confident hope for the future, knowing that in his overflowing generosity God has promised a great reward. The exhortation not to "throw away your confidence" also builds a bridge to a new section (10:36–12:17), in which the enduring faith that pleases God, described in Habakkuk 2:3–4, will be illustrated in a series of OT "witnesses" (Heb. 11:1–40) and in Jesus, the "founder and perfecter" of faith (Heb. 12:1–2). As God promised Abraham a great reward (Gen. 15:1), so now those who hold fast their confidence in Jesus can expect a great reward bestowed by grace, the better, abiding possession of a heavenly homeland (Heb. 11:16).

### <span id="page-156-10"></span><span id="page-156-8"></span><span id="page-156-1"></span><span id="page-156-0"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-156-3"></span><span id="page-156-2"></span>This third terrifying warning against turning away from Jesus—by turning *back* to the OT institutions God had instituted as shadows of good things to come soberly summons us to hold fast our confession of faith in Jesus, "the apostle and high priest of our confession" (3:1). The new covenant's inauguration has made obsolete the law with its sanctuary and sacrifices, and the only sacrifice that removes sins has been offered once for all by Christ himself. To spurn him is to incur God's wrath, so Christians have reason to "fear lest any of you should seem to have failed" to enter God's rest through enduring faith (4:1). But fear is not our only motive for enduring to the end. Our grateful recollection of God's sustaining grace in the past and our hopeful expectation of the lasting inheritance awaiting us in the future strengthen us to move forward in confidence.

#### OVERVIEW OF

### <span id="page-157-2"></span>HEBREWS 10:36–12:17

<span id="page-157-1"></span>The exhortation not to "throw away your confidence, which has a great reward," naturally leads to a discourse addressing the vital importance of enduring faith in God's promises for the future. "Faith" ( *pistis*) and its cognate verb "believe" ( *pisteuō*) appear no less than twenty-eight times in Hebrews 10:36–12:17. Along with faith is its vital attribute "endurance" (*hypomonē*; cognate verb "endure," *hypomenō*). Although the terms "endure/endurance" are less frequent (10:32, 36; 12:1–3, 7), our author's conception of faith entails long-lasting stamina. The faith that pleases God does not shrink back in the face of opposition and suffering (10:38–39). It does not "grow weary or fainthearted" (12:3) but looks forward in hope and clings to God's promises, even when the fulfillment of those promises lies far away in an unseen future (11:1, 7, 9–10, 13, 35, 39–40).

<span id="page-157-8"></span><span id="page-157-7"></span><span id="page-157-6"></span><span id="page-157-5"></span><span id="page-157-4"></span><span id="page-157-3"></span><span id="page-157-0"></span>This fifth movement in the sermon opens with its underlying OT text, Habakkuk 2:3–4 (Heb. 10:36–39). Then an extended survey of the "people of old" who received God's commendation (11:1–40) illustrates the characteristics of faith mentioned in the Habakkuk citation. The "great cloud of witnesses" who attest to God's faithfulness from the pages of Scripture draws our attention to Jesus, "the founder and perfecter of faith" (AT), whose endurance of sinners' hostility must fortify the hearers to endure suffering as confirmation of the Father's good purpose for his true sons (12:1–11). Finally, believers must embrace their corporate responsibility for each other, supporting the spiritually weak and resisting the influence of those whose idolatry and sensuality would spread infection to others (12:12–17).

### <span id="page-158-2"></span>HEBREWS 10:36–39

**<sup>36</sup>**For you have need of endurance, so that when you have done the will of God you may receive what is promised. **37**For,

|    | "Yet a little while,                             |
|----|--------------------------------------------------|
|    | and the coming one will come and will not delay; |
| 38 | but my righteous one shall live by faith,        |
|    | and if he shrinks back,                          |
|    | my soul has no pleasure in him."                 |

**<sup>39</sup>**But we are not of those who shrink back and are destroyed, but of those who have faith and preserve their souls.

#### *Section Overview: Exhortation to Enduring Faith*

The preacher now restates positively the point he just made negatively (table 1.6).

<span id="page-158-0"></span>TABLE 1.6: Hebrews 10:36 as a Positive Restatement of 10:35

| 10:35                             | 10:36                                    |
|-----------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| do not throw away your confidence | you have need of endurance               |
| [because it] has a great reward   | so that you may receive what is promised |

<span id="page-158-1"></span>The need for endurance is demonstrated by Habakkuk 2:3–4, which is first quoted and then followed by a comment assuring hearers that their faith is the kind that lasts and leads to life. Four aspects of faith appear in the words of Habakkuk: Faith (a) acts in light of God's promises for the future, (b) characterizes those whom God declares "righteous," (c) does not shrink back, and (d) pleases God. These will be illustrated in the vignettes of OT believers that follow (Heb. 11:1–40).

#### <span id="page-158-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. By faith that endures, you will receive God's promised blessing (10:36)
- II. God will come promptly to take pleasure in believers who endure (10:37–38)
	- A. The Coming One will come soon (10:37)
	- B. God takes pleasure in his righteous one, who lives by faith (10:38a)
	- C. God takes no pleasure in anyone who shrinks back in unbelief (10:38b)
- III. We have enduring faith and can expect salvation (10:39)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-159-18"></span><span id="page-159-15"></span><span id="page-159-14"></span>10:36 The prohibition of verse 35 ("do not throw away your confidence") is restated in positive terms ("you have need of endurance"), transitioning to the theme of faith's endurance. Faith must endure because God's promises concern things not yet seen (11:1, 7). Those who trust God's promises take appropriate action in the present in light of his announcements concerning the future. Faith is not mere intellectual assent to God's declarations; rather, it moves the believer to do "the will of God." Christ came "to do your will, O God" (10:7), and the fruit of his costly commitment to do God's will (Mark 14:36) is the new covenant in which God writes his laws on believers' hearts (Heb. 8:10) so that they may willingly do his will.

<span id="page-159-13"></span><span id="page-159-11"></span><span id="page-159-10"></span><span id="page-159-9"></span><span id="page-159-8"></span><span id="page-159-5"></span>Faith's forward focus is implied in the prospect of receiving "what is promised" by God. OT believers, "who through faith and patience inherit the promises" (6:12), have set the example, with Abraham in the lead (6:13–17; 7:6; 11:9–19). Although they received God's promises in words and preliminary fulfillments (6:15; 11:33), in another sense they "did not receive what was promised" but awaited God's better provision in the new covenant instituted by Christ (11:39; cf. 11:13). We too eagerly await Christ's return and the full salvation he will bring (9:28).

<span id="page-159-21"></span><span id="page-159-16"></span><span id="page-159-12"></span><span id="page-159-3"></span><span id="page-159-1"></span>10:37–38 Most of this OT quotation is from Habakkuk 2:3–4, but "a little while" comes from Isaiah 26:20–21, intensifying the promise that the Coming One "will not delay" his arrival. Both prophetic texts advise sufferers to await patiently the coming of their God to deliver them and judge their enemies. The context of the words drawn from Habakkuk expresses the tension between eager expectancy and patient endurance demanded by the mysterious timing of God's promise keeping: "The vision awaits its appointed time; it hastens to the end. . . . If it seems slow, wait [LXX *hypomenō*, "endure"] for it; it will surely come; it will not delay" (Hab. 2:3). Jesus prepared his followers for the unpredictability of his return, which may seem either unduly delayed or unexpectedly sudden (Luke 12:35–46; 18:7–8; cf. 1 Thess. 5:1–4; 2 Pet. 3:4–10).

<span id="page-159-7"></span><span id="page-159-6"></span><span id="page-159-4"></span><span id="page-159-2"></span>The Hebrew of Habakkuk 2:4 is difficult. The LXX seems to capture its sense by contrasting the individual who displeases God through shrinking back to "my righteous one" who "shall live by faith." Our author inverts the descriptions, introducing the faithful righteous one before the apostate who "shrinks back" in cowardice32 and receives God's displeasure. Key terms from this text (righteous, faith, pleasure) will reappear in the following survey of OT saints: "faith" distinguishes the person whom God commends as "my righteous one," such as Abel or Noah (cf. Heb. 11:4, 7), while Scripture's statement that Enoch "walked with God" means that he "was commended as having pleased God" (11:5–6).

<span id="page-159-20"></span><span id="page-159-19"></span><span id="page-159-17"></span>10:39 Our author follows the negative conclusion of the OT citation ("my soul has no pleasure in" the one who shrinks back) with the reassurance that his hearers are

<span id="page-159-0"></span><sup>32</sup> "Shrinks back" represents a verb (*hypostellō*) and cognate noun (*hypostolē*) that refer to avoiding right action through undue fear (Acts 20:20, 27; Gal. 2:12; cf. Deut. 1:17 LXX).

<span id="page-160-2"></span>not among the cowering apostates who are destined for destruction but instead have the lasting faith that secures their souls for eternal life (1 Thess. 5:9).

#### *Response*

<span id="page-160-1"></span>Faith in Jesus meets stiff opposition in every age. The parable of the sower shows that various forces work against our endurance all the way until the time of harvest (Mark 4:3–20). In cultures enamored with fluidity and flexibility in relationships, personal identity, and religious allegiance, the stamina of faith in Jesus faces even greater challenges. But the Lord assures us that he "will come and will not delay," and he takes pleasure in people who trust him persistently. His promises supply and sustain the endurance we need.

### <span id="page-160-7"></span><span id="page-160-5"></span><span id="page-160-4"></span>OVERVIEW OF HEBREWS 11:1–40

<span id="page-160-10"></span><span id="page-160-9"></span><span id="page-160-8"></span><span id="page-160-6"></span><span id="page-160-3"></span><span id="page-160-0"></span>Hebrews 11:1–40 surveys OT history from the perspective of faith, showing how the biblical account of early people of faith illustrates the themes of Habakkuk 2:3–4 (cf. Heb. 10:37–38): faith focuses on God's promise for the future, perseveres, gives God pleasure, and wins his verdict that the one who lives by faith is "righteous." By faith believers gain access to realities that cannot be seen. Faith moves people to take appropriate action in response to God's word—offering an acceptable sacrifice, building an ark, setting out for a promised but heretofore unseen homeland, and so on. The survey opens and closes with the comment that God has "commended" (*martyreō*) the ancients for their faith (11:2, 39). After an introduction defining faith and the approving testimony it receives from God (vv. 1–2), each installment in the survey opens with "by faith" ( *pistei* ) (vv. 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 17, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31). The repetition of "by faith" and its prime location in each statement underscore faith's significance. At 11:32 the author shifts from specific instances to summaries of the ancients' actions "through faith" (v. 33). The concluding comment that OT saints were "commended [*martyreō*] through their faith" forms a bridge to their role as "witnesses" (*martyrōn*) on behalf of God and his faithfulness (12:1).

### <span id="page-161-3"></span>HEBREWS 11:1–7

11 Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen. **2**For by it the people of old received their commendation. **3**By faith we understand that the universe was created by the word of God, so that what is seen was not made out of things that are visible.

**<sup>4</sup>**By faith Abel offered to God a more acceptable sacrifice than Cain, through which he was commended as righteous, God commending him by accepting his gifts. And through his faith, though he died, he still speaks. **5**By faith Enoch was taken up so that he should not see death, and he was not found, because God had taken him. Now before he was taken he was commended as having pleased God. **6**And without faith it is impossible to please him, for whoever would draw near to God must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who seek him. **7**By faith Noah, being warned by God concerning events as yet unseen, in reverent fear constructed an ark for the saving of his household. By this he condemned the world and became an heir of the righteousness that comes by faith.

#### *Section Overview: Faith Pleasing to God in Early Redemptive History*

<span id="page-161-4"></span><span id="page-161-2"></span><span id="page-161-1"></span>To appreciate how OT individuals and events illustrate the faith that God approves (Heb. 10:37–39), one must understand what faith truly is. Our author offers a concise definition of faith (11:1) and a comment on God's commendation of the "people of old" who acted in such faith (11:2). Then he begins to work through the OT, beginning "in the beginning." Faith in God's written record in Genesis gives insight into the creation of the visible universe through the invisible word of God (11:3). In the pre-patriarchal history, three individuals receive God's commendation for their faith: Abel, Enoch, and Noah (11:4–7). Each is described as "righteous" and "pleasing God," terms drawn from Habakkuk 2:3–4.

#### <span id="page-161-6"></span><span id="page-161-5"></span><span id="page-161-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. Introduction: faith described and commended (11:1–2)
	- A. Faith described: the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things unseen (11:1)
	- B. Faith commended: by faith the ancients received God's commendation (11:2)
- II. By faith we understand that the visible universe was created by God's invisible word (11:3)
- III. By faith the ancients before Abraham received God's approval (11:4–7)
- A. Abel's sacrifice received God's approval before he died (11:4)
- B. Enoch walked with (that is, pleased) God and did not die (11:5–6)
- <span id="page-162-9"></span>C. Noah, warned of a flood not yet seen, built an ark and so inherited the righteousness of faith (11:7)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-162-10"></span><span id="page-162-7"></span>11:1 Most translations present this verse as describing the subjective experience of faith as "assurance" and "conviction." The Greek terms chosen by our author focus instead on the objective realities of faith and could perhaps be translated, "Faith is the *reality* [*substance*] of things hoped for, the *evidence that proves* things unseen" (cf. KJV, NKJV). The Greek noun (*hypostasis*) represented by "assurance" (ESV, RSV, NRSV, NIV, NASB) earlier described the Son as the "exact imprint of [God's] *nature*" (1:3). In 3:14 it may include a subjective sense (ESV "our original *confidence*"), though even there "the beginning of *the substantial reality* in which our faith rests" (AT) is preferable. Elsewhere our author uses "confidence" ( *parrēsia*; 10:19, 35) and "full assurance" ( *plērophoria*; 10:22) to express subjective assurance. Here he has chosen "reality/substance" and paired it with a term that refers to a legal argument substantiated by evidence (*elenchos*; Job 13:6; 16:21; 23:7 LXX). Faith goes beyond our internal attitudes to put us in touch with realities that are "not seen" (because they transcend the material universe; Heb. 11:3) but are "hoped for" (because they are still future; 11:7; cf. Rom. 8:24). One commentator translates this verse, "Now faith celebrates the objective reality [of the blessings] for which we hope, the demonstration of events as yet unseen."33

<span id="page-162-12"></span><span id="page-162-11"></span><span id="page-162-8"></span><span id="page-162-6"></span><span id="page-162-3"></span><span id="page-162-2"></span>11:2 By means of faith, OT figures "received their commendation" from God. Here the ESV uses "commendation" and "commend" to represent the Greek verb *martyreō* (11:2, 4, 5, 39). Hebrews has introduced biblical quotations and allusions as "testimony" or "witness" (*martyreō*) borne by God (7:8, 17; 10:5; cf. 2:5). God has taken the witness stand to testify on behalf of OT believers, that they were righteous and pleasing to him, and his testimony is recorded in the OT narrative. Though repudiated and oppressed by human opponents (11:24–26, 36–38), "all these" were nevertheless "commended through their faith" by God's testimony in the OT (v. 39). As God bears witness on their behalf in Scripture, so they constitute a "great cloud of witnesses" on his behalf, testifying to his faithfulness (12:1; cf. 11:4, 13–14, 35).

<span id="page-162-14"></span><span id="page-162-13"></span><span id="page-162-5"></span><span id="page-162-4"></span><span id="page-162-1"></span><span id="page-162-0"></span>11:3 Although our preacher will emphasize faith's forward-looking focus, he begins his biblical history of faith in the remote past, with the creation of the universe, which no human eye saw. By faith we understand from Genesis that "the ages" (the temporally tinged term *tous aiōnas*, from 1:2) were created by the word of God. In Genesis 1 the repeated refrain "And God said" brings creatures into existence and arranges them in order (vv. 3, 6, 9, 11, 14, 20, 24, 26). This spoken word of God is not visible, yet its product—the material universe—can be seen. So God's <span id="page-163-11"></span><span id="page-163-8"></span>unseen reality and power transcend all that our eyes behold (cf. Heb. 8:5). Faith, as the evidence that demonstrates the existence of "things not seen" (11:1), puts us in touch with eternal reality that precedes, gives rise to, sustains, and will outlast the heavens and earth that present themselves to our eyes (1:10–12; 12:26–28).

<span id="page-163-12"></span><span id="page-163-7"></span><span id="page-163-4"></span><span id="page-163-0"></span>11:4 Abel's sacrifice "of the firstborn of his flock and of their fat portions" was better than the offering presented by Cain, his brother (Gen. 4:1–16). Genesis 4:4–5 states that the Lord "had regard for" Abel and his gifts but not for Cain's. Our author restates the meaning of Moses' narrative in terms of Habakkuk 2:3–4: by accepting Abel's offering, God "bore witness" (*martyreō*) on behalf of Abel, affirming that he was "righteous" (cf. also Matt. 23:35; 1 John 3:12). This shows that Abel was acting in "faith," since "my righteous one shall live by faith" (Heb. 10:38).

<span id="page-163-10"></span><span id="page-163-6"></span><span id="page-163-1"></span>Yet Abel's story illustrates not only God-pleasing faith but also untimely, violent death. Our author's brief "though he died" invites recollection of the circumstances of Abel's death: he was murdered by his envious brother. Cain could not hide his crime from the divine judge: "The voice of your brother's blood is crying to me from the ground" (Gen. 4:10). At that moment Abel, though dead, nonetheless spoke, crying out for just retribution (cf. Rev. 6:9–10). Our preacher will later contrast the justice-demanding outcry of Abel's blood with the compassionate appeal for forgiveness uttered by Jesus' blood on our behalf (Heb. 12:24). But Abel, though dead, also affirms God's faithfulness.

<span id="page-163-21"></span><span id="page-163-20"></span><span id="page-163-19"></span><span id="page-163-16"></span><span id="page-163-15"></span><span id="page-163-14"></span>As the first of many who "died in faith, not having received the things promised" (11:13), Abel heads the chorus of witnesses who speak from Scripture's pages, testifying that the God who promises is faithful (v. 11), even as their blood is shed (vv. 35–37). Abel is among the "spirits of the righteous made perfect," assembled to worship in the heavenly Jerusalem (12:23). These faithful sufferers of old set the pace for those who hear this sermon-letter now, whose struggle against sin has not yet reached the point of bloodshed (12:4). The ancients were privileged to serve as "previews" of faith's founder and perfecter, Jesus, who endured execution on the cross for his people (12:2).

<span id="page-163-18"></span><span id="page-163-17"></span><span id="page-163-13"></span><span id="page-163-9"></span><span id="page-163-5"></span><span id="page-163-2"></span>11:5–6 Enoch's experience was the counterpoint to Abel's: he did "not see death, and he was not found, because God had taken him." Our author follows the lead of the LXX, which interpreted the Hebrew metaphor "walked with God" (twice in Gen. 5:21–24) as "was well-pleasing to God." This description shows that Enoch fit Habakkuk's description of the righteous one who lives by faith (Hab. 2:4; cf. Heb. 10:37–38). Since God's soul "has no pleasure" in anyone who pulls back in unbelief (10:38), the opposite is true of one with persevering faith: God "has pleasure" in such a believer. Even though the Genesis accounts of Abel and Enoch do not contain the word "faith," reading their stories through the lens of Habakkuk 2:3–4 makes their faith visible. By faith Enoch pleased God during his earthly life, and so "he was not found, because God had taken him" (paraphrasing Gen. 5:24 LXX).

<span id="page-163-3"></span>The inference that Enoch lived by faith comes not only from the link between human faith and God's pleasure in the Habakkuk citation but also from a further <span id="page-164-8"></span>consideration: the only way to draw near to God to receive his blessing is to approach him in faith, believing (a) that he exists and (b) that, to those who seek him, he becomes a rewarder (Heb. 11:6). "Reward" (10:35; 11:26) is one of several ways that Hebrews describes the object of believers' hope—their inheritance (1:14; 6:12, 17; 9:15; 11:8–9) in the heavenly homeland and city of God (11:10, 16; 13:14).

<span id="page-164-12"></span><span id="page-164-7"></span><span id="page-164-6"></span>These first two "heroes" of faith stand at the extremes that their successors would experience: violent death (martyrdom), on the one hand, and a rare anticipation of resurrection life, on the other. This OT history of faith will close with a catalogue that transitions from a series of visible *victories* in life (11:33–35a) to a litany of *hardships and death*, endured in anticipation of a better resurrection to come (11:35b–38).
