<span id="page-164-13"></span>11:7 The last account of faith in pre-patriarchal history is that of Noah (Genesis 6–9). Moses' narrative facilitates the link between Noah and faith, testifying that "Noah was a *righteous* man, blameless in his generation. Noah walked with God" (Gen. 6:9). The LXX paraphrases this last Hebrew phrase as "Noah was pleasing [*euaresteō*] to God." Noah was, therefore, a righteous man who lived by faith. His *living* by faith is what we must see: when "warned by God concerning events as yet unseen" namely, an impending life-destroying flood (Gen. 6:13–21)—Noah's faith and "reverent fear" (Heb. 11:7) were exercised in action. He built an ark just as God commanded (Gen. 6:22). Faith's forward focus is seen here as the coming flood is characterized as "*not yet* seen" (AT).

<span id="page-164-15"></span><span id="page-164-14"></span><span id="page-164-11"></span><span id="page-164-10"></span><span id="page-164-3"></span><span id="page-164-2"></span><span id="page-164-0"></span>The outcomes of Noah's proactive faith were the salvation of his household and the condemnation of the rebellious world (Gen. 6:5–8; 7:7, 23; 1 Pet. 3:20; 2 Pet. 2:5). Our preacher will comment that the "world was not worthy" of the persecuted people of faith (Heb. 11:38), urging his hearers to welcome the exclusion they themselves may suffer in union with Christ (11:24–26; 13:12–13). Noah had already received God's favor before he built the ark (Gen. 6:8). When his faith was tested and shown to be genuine, Noah "became an heir of the righteousness that comes by faith."

#### <span id="page-164-1"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-164-9"></span><span id="page-164-5"></span><span id="page-164-4"></span>"We walk by faith, not by sight," wrote the apostle Paul (2 Cor. 5:7). This dichotomy between faith and sight captures the description of faith that opens Hebrews 11. However, deeply ingrained instincts often attune our expectations and emotions, our attitudes and actions, more to the circumstances we see than to the voice of God who speaks in Scripture. To please God by taking him at his word for things we cannot see, we must resist the attention-hoarding demands of the visible. At creation, God's unseen word brought about all that our senses now perceive, and the Son's powerful word still sustains his universe (Heb. 1:3). The primacy of God's speech over our sight still stands. Trust that truth, and act in its light. God will be pleased.

### <span id="page-165-1"></span>HEBREWS 11:8–22

**<sup>8</sup>**By faith Abraham obeyed when he was called to go out to a place that he was to receive as an inheritance. And he went out, not knowing where he was going. **9**By faith he went to live in the land of promise, as in a foreign land, living in tents with Isaac and Jacob, heirs with him of the same promise. **10**For he was looking forward to the city that has foundations, whose designer and builder is God. **11**By faith Sarah herself received power to conceive, even when she was past the age, since she considered him faithful who had promised. **12**Therefore from one man, and him as good as dead, were born descendants as many as the stars of heaven and as many as the innumerable grains of sand by the seashore.

**<sup>13</sup>**These all died in faith, not having received the things promised, but having seen them and greeted them from afar, and having acknowledged that they were strangers and exiles on the earth. **14**For people who speak thus make it clear that they are seeking a homeland. **<sup>15</sup>** If they had been thinking of that land from which they had gone out, they would have had opportunity to return. **16**But as it is, they desire a better country, that is, a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed to be called their God, for he has prepared for them a city.

**<sup>17</sup>**By faith Abraham, when he was tested, offered up Isaac, and he who had received the promises was in the act of offering up his only son, **<sup>18</sup>** of whom it was said, "Through Isaac shall your offspring be named." **<sup>19</sup>**He considered that God was able even to raise him from the dead, from which, figuratively speaking, he did receive him back. **20**By faith Isaac invoked future blessings on Jacob and Esau. **21**By faith Jacob, when dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph, bowing in worship over the head of his staff. **22**By faith Joseph, at the end of his life, made mention of the exodus of the Israelites and gave directions concerning his bones.

#### *Section Overview: The Patriarchs' Faith in God's Promise of a Heavenly Homeland*

<span id="page-165-2"></span><span id="page-165-0"></span>The largest section of the Hebrews history of OT faith is devoted to Abraham. Five events of Abraham's life are described as occurring "by faith": (a) Abraham's departure from his original homeland for an unseen inheritance (Heb. 11:8); (b) his (and Isaac's and Jacob's) sojourn as strangers in the Promised Land (11:9–10); (c) Sarah's conception of Isaac (11:11–12); (d) the patriarchs' deaths in hopeful expectation of a distant, heavenly country and city (11:13–16); and (e) Abraham's readiness to sacrifice Isaac in faith that God could raise him from the dead (11:17–19).

<span id="page-165-5"></span><span id="page-165-4"></span><span id="page-165-3"></span>Faith likewise sustained the next three patriarchal generations. The blessings conferred by Isaac and Jacob on their heirs and Joseph's end-of-life direction <span id="page-166-4"></span><span id="page-166-0"></span>concerning his bones anticipated God's future fulfillment of his promises in Israel's exodus from Egypt and entrance into the Promised Land (11:20–22). Two themes are emphasized through repetition. First, the homeland sought by the patriarchs was not a geographical territory on the present earth. Rather, the patriarchs looked and longed for— and even glimpsed from afar— an indestructible city built by God himself (11:10) and belonging to a "better country, that is, a heavenly one" (11:15–16). Second, the patriarchs believed in a God who could keep his word even when it required his bringing life into the realm of death (11:11–12, 19).

### <span id="page-166-2"></span><span id="page-166-1"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. By faith Abraham heeded God's call to seek the place of his promised inheritance (11:8)
- II. By faith Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob sojourned in the land God had promised them (11:9–10)
	- A. Abraham and his heirs lived in the land as aliens (11:9)
	- B. Abraham anticipated the eternal city that God had designed and built (11:10)
- III. By faith Sarah conceived the son of promise through whom Abraham's offspring would multiply (11:11–12)
	- A. God empowered Sarah to conceive, though she was too old and Abraham was (reproductively) "dead" (11:11–12a)
	- B. From these infertile parents God produced countless descendants (11:12b)
- IV. In faith the patriarchs died before receiving what God promised, confessing that their hoped-for home was heavenly (11:13–16)
	- A. Before they died, the patriarchs glimpsed from afar what God had promised (11:13a)
	- B. They confessed that they were strangers on earth, seeking a homeland that is beyond this present world (11:13b–16a)
	- C. So God committed himself to them as "their God," and prepared the city for which they longed (11:16b)
- V. By faith Abraham offered Isaac, trusting that God could restore life to the son in whom God's promises centered (11:17–19)
	- A. Abraham offered the "only son" in whom God's promises were concentrated (11:17–18)
	- B. Abraham believed that God could raise Isaac from the dead, and—symbolically—God did (11:19)
- <span id="page-166-3"></span>VI. By faith patriarchs announced future blessings (11:20–22)
	- A. Isaac pronounced different blessings on his younger (Jacob) and older (Esau) sons (11:20)
	- B. Jacob pronounced different blessings on the (younger and older) sons of Joseph (11:21)

C. Joseph predicted the exodus and directed that his bones be brought back to the Promised Land (11:22)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-167-14"></span><span id="page-167-13"></span><span id="page-167-11"></span><span id="page-167-10"></span><span id="page-167-1"></span><span id="page-167-0"></span>11:8 Just as Noah took action "by faith" when warned of the coming flood (v. 7; cf. Gen. 6:22), so Abraham, when "called" by God, "obeyed" by "go[ing] out" of his homeland in Mesopotamia (Gen. 12:1, 4; cf. Acts 7:2–4). Faith is awakened as God's voice speaks to his people, and faith responds readily to what God says (Heb. 3:14–4:3). Just as unbelief and disobedience were correlated in the wilderness generation's hardened response to God's voice (3:18–19; 4:2, 6), so Abraham's belief in God's promise prompted his obedience to God's command to set out for a place that God would cause him to inherit. Faith's trust in God's word about "things not seen" is illustrated in Abraham's departure, "not knowing where he was going." The Lord had called it simply the "land that I will show you" (Gen. 12:1).

<span id="page-167-15"></span><span id="page-167-2"></span>11:9 Abraham's second expression of faith, in which his son Isaac and grandson Jacob also participated, was his sojourning in tents—in temporary dwellings and transient circumstances—in the very land the Lord had promised to give his offspring as their inheritance. The patriarchs' movement and pitching of tents at various sites in the "land of promise" is a repeated feature of the Genesis narrative (Gen. 12:8; 13:3, 12, 18; 18:1; 26:25; 33:18–19; 35:16–21, 27). Abraham's offspring would eventually receive the entire land as an inheritance, but for Abraham himself his residence there was "as in a foreign land." Even when Abraham beheld the land with his own eyes (Gen. 13:14–17), his actual possession of it remained a reality "not yet seen," perceived only by faith. His alien status was most evident when his wife, Sarah, died and he needed to negotiate with Hittites to obtain a burial place for her. In making his request, Abraham acknowledged, "I am a sojourner and foreigner among you" (Gen. 23:3–20), a confession to which our preacher will later allude (Heb. 11:13).

<span id="page-167-17"></span><span id="page-167-16"></span><span id="page-167-8"></span><span id="page-167-4"></span><span id="page-167-3"></span>11:10 Our preacher draws a striking conclusion from the fact that Abraham lived out his days as a stranger in the very land God had promised as his inheritance. Abraham was waiting for the "city that has foundations, whose designer and builder is God." In general, tent-dwelling is temporary, whereas residence in cities with foundations is stable and secure (Pss. 105:12–17; 107:4–7). Our author takes that contrast to a higher level when he speaks of "*the* city" and describes it as designed and constructed by God himself. One psalmist celebrated Mount Zion in Jerusalem, citing the security of its foundations (Ps. 87:1); but another lamented the razing of the city to its (manmade) foundations (Ps. 137:7; cf. Lam. 4:11; Ezra 4:12).

<span id="page-167-18"></span><span id="page-167-12"></span><span id="page-167-9"></span><span id="page-167-7"></span><span id="page-167-6"></span><span id="page-167-5"></span>Abraham's hope focused on a city that would be unassailable because the living God both designed and built it (cf. Rev. 21:9–26). Earlier in this sermon, a citation from Psalm 102 described the eventual dissolution of the present heavens and earth (Heb. 1:10–12; cf. 12:26–28). The heavenly sanctuary in which Jesus now ministers was "not made with hands" (9:11, 24), so it cannot be touched by <span id="page-168-17"></span>the ravages of decay or destruction. Abraham's hope looked beyond Canaan and Jerusalem, which his offspring would eventually occupy, to the ultimate city of refuge—a "lasting city," still to come even for believers today (13:14)—in a better, heavenly country (11:16).

<span id="page-168-16"></span><span id="page-168-14"></span><span id="page-168-11"></span><span id="page-168-10"></span><span id="page-168-6"></span><span id="page-168-5"></span>11:11–12 Sarah (v. 11) and Rahab (v. 31) are the only two women mentioned by name in the Hebrews registry of faith. Additionally, the statement "Women received back their dead by resurrection" (v. 35) refers to the mothers in Zarephath and Shunem, whose young sons were raised by Elijah and Elisha (1 Kings 17:17–24; 2 Kings 4:18–37). Most versions, including the ESV, present Sarah as the one exercising faith, but commentators are divided over whether Abraham or Sarah is the subject of verse 11. Those who favor Abraham argue that the Greek construction rendered "conceive" describes a *father's* contribution in (lit.) "depositing seed" (*katabolēn spermatos*). And in verse 12, which describes the result of verse 11, Abraham is the "one man" from whom countless descendants came. Some also note that Genesis presents Sarah as far from exemplary in respect to her faith (Gen. 18:11–15).

<span id="page-168-15"></span><span id="page-168-8"></span><span id="page-168-3"></span>On the other hand, throughout Hebrews 11 the name of the individual(s) exercising faith closely follows the opening "by faith" (vv. 4, 5, 7, 8, 11, 17, 20, 21, 22, 24, 29, 31). (The only exceptions are vv. 23 and 30.) "Sarah" is almost certainly in the Greek nominative case, and is thus the subject who "received power." And it is Sarah's incapacity to conceive ("past the age") that is highlighted in verse 11.34 Abraham's reproductive incapacity ("as good as dead") is not introduced until verse 12. Moreover, the Genesis record is no more complimentary of Abraham's faith than of Sarah's. Both dismissed God's promise of a son through Sarah as laughable (Gen. 17:15–18). The fact that both Abraham and Sarah, whose faltering faith is evident in the OT text, appear in the catalogue of ancient believers whom God "commended" should encourage us all.

<span id="page-168-7"></span><span id="page-168-2"></span>The faith that pleases God and receives his promises may struggle, but it does not let go (Rom. 4:16–22). We noted earlier (comment on Heb. 6:15) that in Isaac's birth Abraham received, in a preliminary form, the fulfillment of God's promise of innumerable offspring. Here our author scans across the generations to make us marvel that God's power could bring "from one man," who was "as good as dead" (lit., "had been put to death"; *nenekrōmenou*, 11:12) in terms of reproduction, descendants as countless as the stars in the sky and the sand on the seashore, the very imagery in which the Lord painted his astonishing promise (Gen. 15:5; 22:17; cf. 32:12; Isa. 51:2).

<span id="page-168-13"></span><span id="page-168-12"></span><span id="page-168-4"></span><span id="page-168-1"></span>11:13 The patriarchal generations together are the subject of the fourth event associated with faith: "these all died." Their deaths occurred before God's promises to them—inheritance of the land (vv. 8–9) and countless offspring (v. 12)—reached

<span id="page-168-9"></span><span id="page-168-0"></span><sup>34</sup> The ESV follows manuscripts that read, "Sarah herself received power to conceive . . . past the age." Another textual tradition, appearing as early as a papyrus dated around AD 200 and preferred in the standard edition of the Greek New Testament (NA28), contains not just one but *two* references to the impossibility of Sarah's conceiving: "Sarah herself, *barren*, received power to conceive . . . *past the age*." Both of Sarah's disabling conditions appear in Genesis (Gen. 11:30; 16:2; 17:17).

<span id="page-169-12"></span>fulfillment. Thus Abraham and Sarah, Isaac and Rebekah, and Jacob and his wives (and sons) represent the entire "cloud of witnesses" who populate the pages of the OT, who "though commended through their faith, did not receive what was promised" (v. 39). By faith Abraham and the others perceived the objects of their hope across the centuries and greeted them from a distance, as Jesus himself said: "Your father Abraham rejoiced that he would see my day. He saw it and was glad" (John 8:56).

<span id="page-169-13"></span><span id="page-169-8"></span><span id="page-169-7"></span><span id="page-169-6"></span>Those who lived by faith (Heb. 10:38) and died in faith realized that no earthly regions or cities, vulnerable as they are to invasion and desolation, could provide the security for which they longed. Thus the patriarchs "acknowledged"—or "confessed" (*homologeō*, referring to corporate confession of faith (3:1; 4:14; 10:23; 13:15)—that they were strangers and exiles while they sojourned in the *land* (of promise). They were actually confessing that they were exiles anywhere on *earth* (the Greek noun *gē* includes both "land" and "earth"). The patriarchs made this confession not only in Abraham's negotiations with the Hittites (Gen. 23:4) but also in Jacob's retrospective summary of his whole life, both inside and outside the Promised Land: "The days of the years of my sojourning are 130 years. Few and evil have been the days of the years of my life, and they have not attained to the days of the years of the life of my fathers in the days of their sojourning" (Gen. 47:9).

<span id="page-169-11"></span><span id="page-169-10"></span><span id="page-169-9"></span><span id="page-169-5"></span><span id="page-169-4"></span><span id="page-169-1"></span>11:14–16 Our preacher reasons that the patriarchs' confession that they were "strangers and exiles" implied not only that they were "seeking a homeland" but also that the homeland they sought was, ultimately, a "better country, that is, a heavenly one." To acknowledge one's status as a temporary resident, living in tents and lacking property rights "in a foreign land" (v. 9), is to imply that there is another "homeland" or "hometown" ( *patris*) where one truly belongs (cf. Matt. 13:53–57). Lest we assume that the homeland for which the patriarchs longed was merely the land of Canaan, which their descendants would eventually receive as their inheritance in coming generations (Heb. 11:8), the author raises and then dismisses the patriarchs' opportunity to occupy a geographical locale in which they could have been at home. They might have returned to Mesopotamia, the country, kindred, and father's house that God had called Abraham to leave behind (Gen. 12:1). In fact, twenty of Jacob's 130 years were spent outside Canaan in Mesopotamia, "that land from which" his grandfather Abraham "had gone out" (Heb. 11:15; cf. Gen. 31:38–42). Yet Jacob considered those two decades as included in his lifetime of "sojourning," not as a period of respite in which he enjoyed the security of home (Gen. 32:4).

<span id="page-169-3"></span><span id="page-169-2"></span><span id="page-169-0"></span>Whether living in the land his offspring would eventually occupy or in the land his ancestors once called "home," Jacob described his entire 130 years on earth as a brief and stressful sojourning. Our author has strong warrant to conclude that those ancient fathers and mothers of faith desired a better, heavenly homeland and city, where they could dwell forever with the God who had drawn them into covenant.

That God is "not ashamed to be called their God" recalls the earlier, surprising announcement that the divine Son is "not ashamed" to name as "brothers" the <span id="page-170-8"></span><span id="page-170-0"></span>struggling sinful human beings whose salvation he achieves through his incarnation and suffering (Heb. 2:10–11). Genesis shows Abraham, Sarah, Isaac, and Jacob to be seriously flawed. Yet, despite their sin and sometimes shaky faith, the Lord engaged them in covenant love, identifying himself as their sovereign protector: "I will establish my covenant between me and you and your offspring after you throughout their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be God to you and to your offspring after you" (Gen. 17:7–8; cf. Gen. 15:1). The Lord identified himself as "the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob" (Ex. 3:6; cf. Gen. 28:13; 1 Kings 18:36). The city he had prepared for them and for all who follow in their footsteps of faith is that city whose foundations stand forever because God laid them (Heb. 11:10), the heavenly Jerusalem filled with joyful worship (12:22), which will outlast the coming cosmic cataclysm (12:27–28; 13:14).

<span id="page-170-13"></span><span id="page-170-12"></span><span id="page-170-11"></span><span id="page-170-9"></span><span id="page-170-6"></span><span id="page-170-5"></span><span id="page-170-2"></span>11:17–19 The final event of Abraham's life of faith was his readiness to sacrifice his "only son" Isaac, whom God had designated as the offspring through whom all of his promises would be fulfilled (Gen. 22:1–19). In several ways our author underscores the gravity of this "test" ( *peirazō*) of Abraham's faith in God, which would be shown in his readiness to act in keeping with God's command. First, the term "offered" ( *prospherō*), already associated with sacrificial bloodshed (Heb. 5:1, 3; 8:3–4; 9:7, 14), appears not once but twice. Second, our author describes Isaac as Abraham's "only" (*monogenēs*) son, at this point following the Hebrew text of Genesis 22:2 instead of the LXX (which replaced "only" with "beloved"). Although Ishmael had been born to Abraham and the slave Hagar, Isaac was Abraham's "only" son from the standpoint of God's covenant promises. Third, Isaac's indispensability to God's good purpose is reinforced by the description of his father as "he who had received the promises" (cf. Heb. 6:12–15; 7:6) and by the quotation of God's designation of Isaac, not Ishmael, as the son through whom Abraham's offspring would be named (Gen. 21:12; cf. Gen. 17:18–21).

<span id="page-170-10"></span><span id="page-170-3"></span><span id="page-170-1"></span>To obey God's command that Isaac be slain so young, before marrying or fathering children, would put all God's promises (offspring, land, blessing to all nations) in jeopardy. How could Abraham's faithful God issue such a death sentence after issuing such promises? Our author unfolds the patriarch's line of reasoning: "He considered that God was able even to raise [Isaac] from the dead." This conviction underlay Abraham's words to the servants whom he and Isaac had left at the foot of the mountain: "I *and the boy* will go over there and worship *and come again to you*" (Gen. 22:5). The verbs "will go," "worship," and "come again" are plural: Abraham and his son will ascend the mountain, worship, and return together.

<span id="page-170-7"></span><span id="page-170-4"></span>The apostle Paul observed that Abraham had already experienced God's imparting life to the dead in the conception of Isaac from Abraham's own "dead" body and the morbidity of Sarah's womb (Rom. 4:19). At Mount Moriah, Abraham reasoned that nothing less than God's power to raise the dead could reconcile Isaac's early death and the promises God had vested in that only son. Abraham was spared fatherly anguish, and his son the blade of death, through the Lord's provision of a <span id="page-171-13"></span><span id="page-171-10"></span><span id="page-171-1"></span>substitute (Gen. 22:11–14). So it was that Abraham "figuratively" (lit., "in a parable [*en parabolē*]"; cf. "symbolic [*parabolē*]," Heb. 9:9) did receive his son back from death, foreshadowing not only physical revivifications later in the OT (11:35) but also, supremely, the resurrection of God's Son, "brought again from the dead" (13:20) to be our Great High Priest forever.

<span id="page-171-15"></span><span id="page-171-14"></span><span id="page-171-11"></span>11:20–21 The blessings pronounced by the next generations of patriarchs, Isaac and his son Jacob, are mentioned briefly to illustrate faith's confidence in God to bring about an as-yet-unseen future. Our author passes over in silence the ruse by which Jacob, having already purchased Esau's inheritance right as firstborn, duped their father and stole the preeminent blessing as well (cf. Heb. 12:16–17). The story is well known, and the inversion of birth order in naming the brothers is sufficient allusion to it. Our preacher's point is that their respective blessings from their aged and unseeing father spoke of things future and so demonstrated Isaac's faith in things not seen (Gen. 27:27–29, 39–40).

<span id="page-171-5"></span><span id="page-171-4"></span><span id="page-171-3"></span><span id="page-171-2"></span>Jacob's deathbed blessing of Joseph's two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, also involved a blind patriarch, the firstborn's inheritance rights, and an inversion in which a younger was honored over an older brother (Genesis 48). Jacob's firstborn, Reuben, had disqualified himself from the privileges of primogeniture—leadership and inheritance (Gen. 35:22; 49:3–4). When Joseph approached his dying father with his two sons, Jacob adopted both as his immediate heirs: "Ephraim and Manasseh shall be mine, as Reuben and Simeon are" (Gen. 48:5). As a later Israelite historian observed, Reuben's birthright was given to the sons of Joseph, as they would receive two tribal allotments in the Promised Land, while leadership in Israel would pass to Judah, the tribe of King David (1 Chron. 5:1–2). Again an aging and sightless patriarch preferred a younger son (Ephraim) over his older brother (Manasseh), but in this case it was deliberate (Gen. 48:13–20). By faith Jacob, despite failing physical sight, foresaw the multiplication of tribes that would descend from Ephraim (more dominant) and Manasseh (less influential) in coming generations, and he worshiped his faithful promise-keeping Lord.

<span id="page-171-12"></span><span id="page-171-9"></span><span id="page-171-7"></span><span id="page-171-6"></span>11:22 Finally, the faith of the patriarchs was exhibited in the prediction and direction of the dying Joseph (Gen. 50:24–25). Although Joseph and his brothers would die in Egypt, the Lord would cause a future generation to exit Egypt and return to the land he had promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Joseph "made mention of"—spoke a reminder of (*mnēmoneuō*)—the exodus, which God had predicted to Abraham (Gen. 15:13–16). Joseph's expectant faith was confident, and his directions solemn: "Joseph made the sons of Israel swear, saying, 'God will surely visit you, and you shall carry up my bones from here'" (Gen. 50:25).

#### <span id="page-171-8"></span><span id="page-171-0"></span>*Response*

Four generations of Israel's forebears illustrate the forward-looking hope that characterizes faith in the living God, who drew them into his gracious covenant. Our faith often fluctuates and falters. The brutally honest record of Genesis shows that theirs fluctuated and faltered also. Yet their experiences of God's faithfulness and power bear witness to us from the pages of Scripture, and their testimony must fortify our fragile faith. They trusted and followed a Lord who could begin with an elderly, childless couple and create a countless multitude of descendants; who could confer on the offspring of a tent-dwelling nomad the possession of a bountiful homeland; who could raise the dead; and who could lift their hearts' line of sight beyond the span of their earthly "sojourn" to greet "from afar" blessings to come in a distant future and a "better country" than anything we have yet encountered.

<span id="page-172-2"></span><span id="page-172-1"></span>We who live since Jesus inaugurated the new covenant have seen God keep his greatest promises at the greatest cost to himself. Trusting God's life-restoring power, Abraham was prepared to perform a heart-wrenching act and received God's commendation: "You . . . have not withheld your son, your only son" (Gen. 22:16). His son was spared, replaced by a substitute that foreshadowed God's ultimate gift of faithful love: "He who did not spare his own Son but gave him up for us all, how will he not also with him graciously give us all things?" (Rom. 8:32). When humanly impossible circumstances confront us as they did Abraham, our trembling hearts and fretful minds must be stilled to hear and heed our God's probing question: "Is anything too hard for the Lord?" (Gen. 18:14).

### <span id="page-172-4"></span><span id="page-172-0"></span>HEBREWS 11:23–31

**<sup>23</sup>**By faith Moses, when he was born, was hidden for three months by his parents, because they saw that the child was beautiful, and they were not afraid of the king's edict. **24**By faith Moses, when he was grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter, **<sup>25</sup>** choosing rather to be mistreated with the people of God than to enjoy the fleeting pleasures of sin. **<sup>26</sup>**He considered the reproach of Christ greater wealth than the treasures of Egypt, for he was looking to the reward. **27**By faith he left Egypt, not being afraid of the anger of the king, for he endured as seeing him who is invisible. **28**By faith he kept the Passover and sprinkled the blood, so that the Destroyer of the firstborn might not touch them.

**<sup>29</sup>**By faith the people crossed the Red Sea as on dry land, but the Egyptians, when they attempted to do the same, were drowned. **30**By faith the walls of Jericho fell down after they had been encircled for seven days. **31**By faith Rahab the prostitute did not perish with those who were disobedient, because she had given a friendly welcome to the spies.

#### *Section Overview: Deliverance by Faith in the Exodus and Conquest*

<span id="page-172-3"></span>The life of Moses, the faithful servant in God's house and mediator of God's covenant at Sinai (Heb. 3:2–5; 9:18–22), exemplifies the *courage* and *costliness* of faith <span id="page-173-4"></span>(11:23–29). By faith his parents fearlessly protected their newborn son from the Egyptian king's death warrant. By faith Moses himself, having reached adulthood, chose costly identification with God's oppressed people over the privileges of Egypt's royal court. Moses' departure from Egypt was motivated not by fear of the king's retribution but by a vision of the invisible God. Faith in the mercy and might of God was instrumental in the two great events of the exodus: the Passover protection of Israel's firstborn and the parting of the Red Sea, opening Israel's path to freedom.

The survey of specific OT instances of faith concludes with events that began the conquest of the Promised Land: the destruction of Jericho and the rescue of Rahab (vv. 30–31). After this, time constraints will necessitate consolidating and abbreviating the survey of faith and its fruit in the eras of Israel's judges, kings, and exile (vv. 32–38).

#### <span id="page-173-7"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-173-3"></span>I. By faith Moses' life displays courage and costliness (11:23–29)
	- A. As an infant, Moses was hidden by parents who did not fear the king (11:23)
	- B. As an adult, Moses chose the cost of sharing the reproach of Christ with God's abused people (11:24–26)
	- C. Though he fled Egypt, Moses' motive was not fear of the king but perception of the Lord (11:27)
	- D. Moses observed Passover, trusting God to spare Israel's firstborn through the shedding of blood (11:28)
	- E. The Israelites crossed the Red Sea on dry land, and then their enemies were drowned (11:29)
- <span id="page-173-6"></span><span id="page-173-5"></span>II. By faith Jericho fell and Rahab was rescued (11:30–31)
	- A. God used an unlikely strategy to cause Jericho's walls to fall (11:30)
	- B. God rescued an unlikely believer, Rahab the prostitute (11:31)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-173-0"></span>11:23 Although Moses is the grammatical subject of the passive verb "was hidden," it was his parents' courageous faith that set him apart in infancy. Recounting the narrative of Exodus 2:1–2, our author states that Moses' parents hid him for three months because they saw that he was "beautiful" (Gk. *asteios*). Our author follows the LXX, in which *asteios* represents the Hebrew adjective *tov* (often glossed as "good," but having a broad semantic range). In Acts 7:20 Stephen's comment on Moses' infancy likewise reflects the influence of the LXX, but he describes Moses as "beautiful [*asteios*] *in God's sight*."

<span id="page-173-2"></span><span id="page-173-1"></span>In view of our author's description of faith as focused on "things not seen" (Heb. 11:1), which reappears explicitly in the Moses section (v. 27), the reference to the infant Moses' "beauty" refers to more than physical appearance. His parents "saw" <span id="page-174-0"></span>that there was something special about this child. The king's edict mandated that male infants of Hebrew mothers be killed at birth (Ex. 1:15–22). Presumably those who defied Pharaoh's semi-genocidal policy would themselves be punished, probably by death. Yet Moses' parents did not fear to protect this special child whom God had entrusted to them. Their fearlessness foreshadowed their son's fearlessness when facing the king's anger (Heb. 11:27) and illustrated how a living faith in God can set people free from the fear of death (2:15; cf. 13:6).

<span id="page-174-8"></span><span id="page-174-7"></span><span id="page-174-6"></span><span id="page-174-3"></span><span id="page-174-2"></span>11:24–26 Our preacher is most interested in the life-changing decision that Moses reached when he had become an adult (Ex. 2:11–15; Acts 7:23). He had gone out to his brothers in order to see their burdensome toil. Suddenly he saw an Egyptian taskmaster cruelly beating a Hebrew slave—"one of his brothers" (ESV mg.; Moses' recognition of Hebrew slaves as his "brothers" is mentioned twice in Exodus 2:11, an emphasis that seems relevant to our author's interest in this incident.) In Exodus Moses himself records his action of killing the Egyptian abuser, thereby defending his Hebrew brother, without revealing his motivation.

<span id="page-174-5"></span><span id="page-174-1"></span>Our author, however, insists that we contemplate the alternatives Moses confronted at that moment. Moses had been adopted by a daughter of Pharaoh, Egypt's quasi-divine monarch (Ex. 2:10). As a member of the royal court, Moses had access to the "treasures of Egypt" and could "enjoy the fleeting pleasures [*apolausis*] of sin." The term *apolausis* is not intrinsically negative (cf. 1 Tim. 6:17), but here it refers to pleasures that are both sinful and short-lived. Such ephemeral enjoyment would have included not only violations of God's moral law but also, especially relevant here, a culpable refusal to be identified with his suffering Hebrew kinfolk. On the other hand, although the children of Israel had been welcomed to Egypt with honor in Joseph's day, they had long been an enslaved, despised, and abused minority. To identify with them would be to suffer mistreatment with them (cf. Heb. 11:37; 13:3).

<span id="page-174-9"></span>The alternatives are described first in terms of physical and social experience: either mistreatment or enjoyment. They are then restated in financial metaphors: either Egypt's "treasures," or the "greater wealth" and "reward" on which Moses' sights were set. In a doubly arresting move, our author identifies the "greater wealth" that Moses chose as "the reproach of Christ." It is a shocking paradox to equate *reproach* to *wealth*—and wealth exceeding that of Pharaoh's court. Moreover, the author seamlessly links afflictions endured by ancient Hebrew slaves to the suffering of "reproach" endured by the Messiah himself. The psalmists lamented the reproaches suffered by the Lord's Anointed (Pss. 69:7–9, 19–20; 89:50–51), and Hebrews will speak of the shame endured by Jesus on the cross (Heb. 12:2). His execution "outside the gate" and "outside the camp," in territory reserved for death and defilement, symbolized the reproach he endured, which his followers must share (13:11–13).

<span id="page-174-11"></span><span id="page-174-10"></span><span id="page-174-4"></span>The sermon-letter's original Jewish-Christian hearers had already suffered reproach for their faith and had identified with others who had likewise suffered <span id="page-175-9"></span>(10:32–34). They will be called to do so again (13:3). For them, the choice was not between the luxuries of Egypt's royal court and the helplessness and exhausting toil of a nation of slaves. Rather, it was between status and welcome in the Jewish community, synagogue, and near and extended family circles, on the one hand, and shunning by synagogue and family, with related social and economic ramifications, on the other. For every generation, bearing the reproach of Christ in solidarity with his faithful followers has its price, and the cost of enduring faith is not negligible. But Moses' reckoning was right: Christ's reproach is wealth that sin's pleasures and society's acceptance cannot rival. The reward is nothing less than drawing near and dwelling with God in the heavenly country and city to come (10:34–35; 11:6, 10, 16; 12:22–24, 28; 13:14).

<span id="page-175-13"></span><span id="page-175-12"></span><span id="page-175-11"></span><span id="page-175-10"></span><span id="page-175-2"></span><span id="page-175-1"></span>11:27 A third display of faith in Moses' life was his departure from Egypt, "not being afraid of the anger of the king." Since this precedes the mention of the Passover (v. 28), it probably refers to Moses' flight from Egypt to Midian soon after he killed an abusive Egyptian taskmaster and his act became public knowledge and reached the king's ears (Ex. 2:14–15; cf. comment on 11:24–26). The OT text, however, states that, when the news got out, "Moses was afraid" and fled (Ex. 2:14).35 How can our author so flatly contradict the OT? To attribute Moses' flight from Egypt to his faith instead of to his fear of the king conveniently parallels our author's treatment of Moses' parents' protection of him in infancy as being motivated by their faith in God, not their fear of the king. But surely a desire to highlight this parallel cannot justify our author's deliberately suppressing the truth about his fear that Moses frankly confessed when he wrote Exodus. Our preacher's point seems to be that, although Moses was afraid of the king's wrath (as anyone familiar with the OT knows), his faith, not his fear, was the *dominant motive* driving him out of Egypt.

<span id="page-175-8"></span><span id="page-175-6"></span><span id="page-175-5"></span><span id="page-175-3"></span>Our author assumes that his hearers have seen Moses' struggle with fear in Exodus, just as we observed Abraham's and Sarah's fluctuating faith in Genesis. Over against that fear, however, was his faith, by which he "endured as seeing him who is invisible." The invisible one is God the creator (Rom. 1:20; Col. 1:15; 1 Tim. 1:17; 6:15–16). Forty years after Moses fled Egypt, he saw the angel of the Lord in the burning bush (Exodus 3–4) and the "form of the Lord" on Mount Sinai (Num. 12:8). But long before those *visible* displays of divine glory, Moses had already glimpsed God's glory, by faith (not physical sight) perceiving "things not seen." Our preacher assures us that Moses' faith overshadowed his (very obvious) fear. By that same faith, all believers now "behold" the Lord's glory and are being transformed into his image (2 Cor. 3:18).

<span id="page-175-7"></span>11:28 Like Noah previously, Moses and Israel believed God's announcement about a traumatic judgment to come in an unseen but fast approaching future: a final plague would inflict death on the firstborn throughout Egypt (Ex. 11:4–7). Like

<span id="page-175-4"></span><span id="page-175-0"></span><sup>35</sup> Moses narrated embarrassing details that reveal his timidity even when he defended his suffering Hebrew brother. Before resisting the abusive Egyptian, Moses "looked this way and that, and seeing no one, he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand" (Ex. 2:12).

<span id="page-176-0"></span>Noah, in their faith they obeyed God's instruction for their protection, smearing the blood of a lamb "without blemish" on their doorframes and eating the Passover meal in their homes (Ex. 12:3–13). Acting in faith preserved their lives (Heb. 10:39), as God had promised: "The blood shall be a sign for you, on the houses where you are. And when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and no plague will befall you to destroy you" (Ex. 12:13). As the blood of bulls and goats on the Day of Atonement foreshadowed Christ's conscience-cleansing sacrifice, so the Passover lamb's blood symbolized Jesus' death as the means of rescue from the enslaving fear of death (Heb. 2:14–15; 9:13–14; cf. John 1:29; 1 Cor. 5:7).

<span id="page-176-15"></span><span id="page-176-12"></span><span id="page-176-3"></span><span id="page-176-2"></span><span id="page-176-1"></span>11:29 Another rescue immediately followed the first Passover. The final plague forced Egypt's Pharaoh to release his Hebrew slaves, but immediately he regretted that decision and sent forces to recapture the Israelites, who had reached the Red Sea and were trapped between impassable waters and implacable foes (Exodus 14). Fear, not faith, fueled their words of complaint against Moses (Ex. 14:11–12), ominously foreshadowing the next forty years. Nevertheless, "by faith" they crossed the sea as on dry ground (Ex. 14:21–22, 29), and, when the waters returned, their oppressors were drowned (Ex. 14:26–28). This visible display of power evoked from the Israelites a confession of faith, short-lived though it would be: "Israel saw the great power that the Lord used against the Egyptians, so the people feared the Lord, and they *believed* in the Lord and in his servant Moses" (Ex. 14:31).

<span id="page-176-16"></span><span id="page-176-14"></span><span id="page-176-13"></span><span id="page-176-6"></span><span id="page-176-5"></span><span id="page-176-4"></span>11:30–31 Our author bypasses major events he discusses elsewhere: the inauguration of the Sinai covenant (Heb. 9:15–22; 12:18–21) and the Israelites' four decades of doubt in the desert (chs. 3–4). He concludes this section with two simultaneous displays of God's power and mercy when a new generation of Israelites finally entered the Promised Land. The sudden fall of Jericho's walls illustrates our preacher's point that the faith that pleases God takes action in response to God's word, even when visible circumstances make his commands seem foolish and his promises impossible. The Lord directed Israel's priests—sounding trumpets and bearing the ark of the covenant—and its armed forces to march around Jericho once a day for six days, and seven times on the seventh day, before shouting and again blasting trumpets (Josh. 6:1–21). But Jericho was a formidable fortress, securely sealed against siege (Josh. 6:1). Such a bizarre military strategy—no battering ram to shatter gates, no ladders to scale walls—must have seemed unlikely to breach Jericho's stout battlements. But Joshua had just led Israel through the Jordan River on dry land in flood season (Joshua 3–4), so Israel again proceeded in obedience, trusting God's word about things not yet seen, and they watched their divine champion throw down Jericho's walls.

<span id="page-176-11"></span><span id="page-176-10"></span><span id="page-176-9"></span><span id="page-176-8"></span><span id="page-176-7"></span>While Jericho was overthrown, Rahab the prostitute (with her family; Josh. 6:22–25) was spared "by faith." Despite her background in Canaan's pagan religions, this Gentile woman's faith in the living God of Israel was robust in content, informed by reports of the Lord's prior victories (Josh. 2:8–13). Her trust was both active and risky. Jeopardizing her own and her family's safety from harm by human <span id="page-177-1"></span>powers, she secured their deliverance from destruction by the Lord, expecting that he would fulfill his promise to give his land to his people. If she had been caught giving "a friendly welcome" (lit., "welcome with peace") to the Israelite spies, no doubt Jericho's authorities would have executed her (Josh. 2:2–7). Her hope lay not in her own virtue but in the trustworthy word of God. Thus the Bible identifies Rahab as "the prostitute" while nevertheless commending her exemplary faith (Josh. 2:1; 6:17, 22, 25; James 2:25). She is one of four women with Gentile associations enfolded into the genealogy of Jesus the Messiah, along with Tamar, Ruth, and Uriah's wife (Matt. 1:1–16).

#### <span id="page-177-3"></span><span id="page-177-0"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-177-2"></span>The OT portraits of Moses and Rahab differ widely, yet their stories converge to show us that the faith that delights God is both costly and courageous. Honored by God above all other prophets, Moses had privileged access to God's glorious presence. Yet the self-portrait Moses offers in the Pentateuch exposes the fear mingled with his faith. Rahab, a pagan prostitute, exercised fearless faith and received the Lord's rescue. Her confidence that God would give his people the Promised Land set her apart from "those who were disobedient," not only in idolatrous Jericho but also in Israel (cf. Heb. 3:18; 4:6; Josh. 7:1). We too must look beyond the fleeting pleasures of sin and the threats of rejection and persecution, setting our sights on the living God, too glorious to be seen by human eyes, and the reward he will bestow (Heb. 11:24–27).

### <span id="page-177-5"></span><span id="page-177-4"></span>HEBREWS 11:32–40

**<sup>32</sup>**And what more shall I say? For time would fail me to tell of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, of David and Samuel and the prophets— **33**who through faith conquered kingdoms, enforced justice, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions, **34**quenched the power of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, were made strong out of weakness, became mighty in war, put foreign armies to flight. **35**Women received back their dead by resurrection. Some were tortured, refusing to accept release, so that they might rise again to a better life. **36**Others suffered mocking and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment. **37**They were stoned, they were sawn in two,*<sup>1</sup>* they were killed with the sword. They went about in skins of sheep and goats, destitute, afflicted, mistreated— **<sup>38</sup>** of whom the world was not worthy—wandering about in deserts and mountains, and in dens and caves of the earth.

**<sup>39</sup>**And all these, though commended through their faith, did not receive what was promised, **<sup>40</sup>** since God had provided something better for us, that apart from us they should not be made perfect.

#### *Section Overview: Victory, Suffering, and Future Hope by Faith*

<span id="page-178-2"></span>As he concludes his survey of faith in the lives of OT saints, our preacher, mindful of time constraints and his hearers' mental stamina, changes his approach. Instead of recounting events one by one, he abbreviates by mentioning some judges, a king, and a prophet by name and then briefly sketching both their achievements, enabled by faith, and their afflictions, endured by faith. Verse 35 is the pivot point in this overview. The resurrection of the dead, restored to the women who mourned them, is the climax of the achievements over enemies that God granted to those who trusted him (vv. 33–35a). The courage of those tortured to their deaths for their faith then opens a series of afflictions endured by the faithful, without relief or release (vv. 35b–38). Finally, a summary of all of the ancients commended for their faith in the OT makes the point that, whether the Lord granted them visible rescue in their lifetimes or called them to enduring hope amid affliction, they did not receive the fullness of God's promises. That fullness awaited the arrival of Christ, who has brought OT and NT believers together to "perfection," the cleansing of conscience that opens access to God (vv. 39–40).

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-178-1"></span>I. Through faith some—too many to recount—won victories over God's enemies (11:32–35a)
	- A. Their company included judges, kings, and prophets (11:32)
	- B. They conquered human enemies (11:33–34)
	- C. They saw God conquer death, the last enemy (11:35a)
- <span id="page-178-4"></span><span id="page-178-3"></span>II. Through faith others persevered under sufferings, without relief (11:35b–38)
	- A. They endured torture and death, anticipating a better resurrection (11:35b–37a)
	- B. They endured homelessness and destitution, anticipating a better homeland (11:37b–38)
- <span id="page-178-5"></span>III. Whether victorious or suffering, all these died in faith, awaiting the perfection that we now share with them through Jesus (11:39–40)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-178-0"></span>11:32 Our preacher is mindful of the length of time that would be involved in listening to his sermon-letter being read aloud. He has already abbreviated what could have been a longer discussion of the tabernacle's furniture (9:5). Now he condenses the rest of OT history's profiles of faith, since "time would fail me" to discuss in detail the stories of Israel's judges, kings, and prophets after the conquest of the Promised Land. He will draw attention to his restraint in his final greetings as a reason for his hearers to "bear with my word of exhortation, for I have written to you briefly" (13:22).

<span id="page-178-6"></span>The names of judges (Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah), a king (David), and a prophet (Samuel) would bring their stories to the minds of Jewish listeners. <span id="page-179-7"></span><span id="page-179-5"></span><span id="page-179-3"></span>The names are not in strict chronological order. In the OT, Barak (Judges 4–5) appears before Gideon (Judges 6–8), and Jephthah (Judges 11–12) before Samson (Judges 13–16). Then Samuel, Israel's last judge as well as a prophet (1 Samuel 1– 25), appears before David (1 Samuel 16–2 Samuel 24). Perhaps in each pair the more prominent individual is mentioned first. It is also fitting to list "Samuel and the prophets" last, since Samuel is viewed as the head of those prophets following Moses, who pressed the Lord's lawsuit against Israel for their breach of covenant while promising God's continuing faithfulness to his unfaithful people (Acts 3:24). Each of the six "through faith conquered kingdoms," "enforced justice" (in varying degrees), "became mighty in war," and "put foreign armies to flight" (Heb. 11:33–34), defending Israel against surrounding enemies such as the Canaanites, Midianites, Ammonites, and Philistines.

<span id="page-179-16"></span><span id="page-179-14"></span><span id="page-179-9"></span><span id="page-179-8"></span><span id="page-179-6"></span><span id="page-179-4"></span><span id="page-179-0"></span>Nevertheless, although our author highlights the faith of these men, the OT accounts present blemished portraits of the judges and of King David. Like Moses, Gideon strove to evade God's call to courageous leadership (Judg. 6:11–40; cf. Exodus 3–4). Barak timidly refused to take up arms without the support of the judge-prophet Deborah (Judg. 4:6–8). Samson scorned his holy status as a Nazirite, wielding his extraordinary strength more often in service to his own sensual lust and rage than in submission to his God (Judg. 14:1–4, 8–9, 19–20; 15:1–8; 16:1–17). Jephthah rashly vowed away his daughter's life in exchange for victory in battle, and then even more wickedly kept his vow, contrary to God's law (Judg. 11:29–40; cf. Ex. 13:15; Deut. 12:29–31; 18:10). David waged war in the name of the Lord (1 Sam. 17:45) but later shamed the Lord's name through adultery and murder, bringing rape and bloodshed into his own family and civil war to Israel (2 Samuel 11–18). Even Samuel apparently replicated the paternal negligence of the priest who had raised him, so that his sons turned out as badly as Eli's (1 Sam. 2:12–17, 22–36; 8:1–4).

<span id="page-179-13"></span><span id="page-179-12"></span><span id="page-179-11"></span><span id="page-179-10"></span><span id="page-179-2"></span><span id="page-179-1"></span>If the author had intended to convey the impression that God commended OT figures who were stalwart in trust and spotless in character, he might have selected judges described so briefly that their flaws remained unmentioned (such as Othniel, Ehud, and Shamgar; Judges 3) or a king such as Josiah, distinguished for his righteous reforms (2 Kings 22–23; but see 2 Chron. 35:20–22). Instead our preacher calls us to listen to God as he testifies on behalf of patriarchs, politicians, prophets, and prostitutes who had fluctuating faith and questionable morality but who continued to trust God to be faithful to his promises. If they could act in faith and see God work, so could the sermon-letter's first hearers, some of whom had "drooping hands" and "weak knees" (Heb. 12:12–13)—and so can we in our trials and frailty.

<span id="page-179-17"></span><span id="page-179-15"></span>11:33–34 The overview of faith's victories after the conquest of Canaan includes military victories against Israel's hostile neighbors: these heroes "conquered kingdoms, . . . were made strong out of weakness, became mighty in war, put foreign armies to flight." In addition to the leaders named in verse 32, God granted <span id="page-180-5"></span><span id="page-180-0"></span>triumph in battle to other judges, to Jonathan son of Saul, and to Judah's later kings. Justice was administered by judges such as Deborah and Samuel (Judg. 4:4–5; 1 Sam. 8:1–7; 12:1–5) and by kings such as David and Solomon (2 Sam. 8:15; 1 Kings 3). Although we cannot overlook the defects of those named in verse 32, we must not underestimate the faith involved in Gideon's waging war against Midian with a brigade reduced from thousands to three hundred, or in Samson's single-handed slaughter of Philistines, or in young David's confrontation with the well-armed Philistine champion Goliath.

<span id="page-180-12"></span><span id="page-180-3"></span>Those who "obtained promises" would include David, to whom the Lord promised an ongoing dynasty (cf. 2 Sam. 7:11–13). Like Abraham, who received an initial fulfillment of God's promise of offspring in the birth of Isaac (cf. comment on Heb. 6:15), so other OT believers who awaited the *fulfillment* of promises Christ would bring (8:6; 11:39–40) received preliminary installments of the redemption for which they hoped (e.g., David's son Solomon would build God's house; 2 Sam. 7:12–13; 1 Kings 6).

<span id="page-180-13"></span><span id="page-180-10"></span><span id="page-180-4"></span><span id="page-180-1"></span>Various OT believers were delivered from violent death. Samson and David "stopped the mouths of lions" by killing them (cf. Judg. 14:5–6; 1 Sam. 17:34–37), but the wording here echoes Daniel: "My God sent his angel and shut the lions' mouths." Daniel emerged unharmed "because he had trusted in his God" (Dan. 6:22–23). Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego "quenched the power of fire" (cf. Daniel 3). David "escaped the edge of the sword" (cf. 1 Sam. 17:45–51), as did prophets such as Elijah, Elisha, and Jeremiah, who had no weapons in hand to defend themselves but relied on their faith in God (1 Kings 19:1–3; 2 Kings 6:30–7:20; Jer. 26:7–24).

<span id="page-180-15"></span><span id="page-180-11"></span><span id="page-180-9"></span><span id="page-180-7"></span><span id="page-180-2"></span>11:35 The capstone of the rescues received by OT people of faith was deliverance from death itself, the "last enemy" (1 Cor. 15:26). During a famine, the prophet Elijah sojourned with a Gentile widow and her son in Zarephath, and the Lord sustained her meager store of food through the prophet's presence. When her son fell ill and died, God granted Elijah's plea to restore the child to life (1 Kings 17:8–24). His successor, Elisha, received hospitality from a Shunammite couple, and God granted them a son in answer to the prophet's prayer. When the boy suddenly fell ill and died, the Lord returned him to life and to his mother through the prophet's intercession (2 Kings 4:8–37).

<span id="page-180-14"></span><span id="page-180-8"></span><span id="page-180-6"></span>Suddenly, in the middle of verse 35, the Greek syntax signals a thematic shift: "But others [*alloi de*] were tortured [*tympanizō*], not accepting release, in order that they might obtain a *better resurrection*." Abraham had received Isaac back in a metaphorical [*en parabolē*] resurrection (Heb. 11:19), and the mothers of Zarephath and Shunem received sons back in physical revivification. But by faith others endured torture that ended in death, anticipating a new life in the age to come, from which suffering, sorrow, and death will be banished altogether. Those who refused the offer of release because they hoped for a better resurrection may allude specifically to the account of the torture and martyrdom of the aged scribe Eleazar and a family of seven brothers at the hands of the Syrian tyrant Antiochus IV Epiphanes, reported in the apocryphal book of *2 Maccabees*. This account mentions the rack (*tympanon*) as an instrument of torture, and the brothers' mother encourages them to endure suffering faithfully, expressing to the youngest her hope that "in God's mercy I may get you back again along with your brothers" (*2 Macc.* 7:29).36

<span id="page-181-19"></span><span id="page-181-18"></span><span id="page-181-17"></span><span id="page-181-11"></span><span id="page-181-8"></span><span id="page-181-6"></span><span id="page-181-3"></span>11:36–38 Persecutions less extreme than martyrdom—"mocking and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment" (v. 36)—were endured by the prophets as a group (2 Chron. 36:15–16; cf. Mark 12:2–5), including by some to extreme lengths (1 Kings 22:24–27; Jer. 20:2; 37:15–16). These afflictions, the price of bearing the "reproach of Christ" (Heb. 11:26; cf. 13:13), were akin to those that the original audience of Hebrews had borne in the past and were confronting in the present (10:32–34; 13:3). In the first Christian generation, Jesus' apostles and followers endured such hardships, regarding themselves honored when suffering contempt for the sake of his name (Acts 5:40–41; 8:3; 9:1–2; 16:22–24; 2 Cor. 11:23–27). OT martyrs were slain by stones, saws, and swords. Judah's king Joash had learned God's law from the faithful priest Jehoiada, but after his mentor's death, Joash forsook the Lord. When confronted by Jehoiada's son Zechariah, the king ordered his death by stoning (2 Chron. 24:17–22). Jewish tradition reported that the prophet Isaiah was put to death by being sawn in half on the orders of King Manasseh. Rulers of both Israel in the north (1 Kings 19:10) and Judah in the south (Jer. 26:20–23) cut faithful prophets down with the sword for speaking the Lord's troublesome words of judgment.

<span id="page-181-10"></span><span id="page-181-7"></span><span id="page-181-5"></span><span id="page-181-2"></span><span id="page-181-1"></span>Even those not called to pay the ultimate price of martyrdom endured a lifestyle of deprivation and marginalization, alienation and exclusion befitting their identity as "strangers and exiles on the earth" (Heb. 11:13). Their destitution, clothing ("skins of sheep and goats"), and homeless "wandering about in deserts and mountains" showed they had no status or security in society (cf. 1 Kings 17:3–7; 2 Kings 1:8; Matt. 3:1–4). They were expelled "outside the camp" (Heb. 13:11–13; cf. comments on 13:11–12; 13:13–14). Their shelter, such as it was, in "dens and caves" (cf. Judg. 6:2; 1 Sam. 13:6; 1 Kings 18:4), foreshadowed the plight of the original audience of Hebrews, whose property had been seized (Heb. 10:34).

<span id="page-181-20"></span><span id="page-181-13"></span><span id="page-181-12"></span><span id="page-181-9"></span><span id="page-181-4"></span><span id="page-181-0"></span>Our author would concur with the apostle Paul's assessment that Christ's apostles—and, in fact, all of Jesus' followers—are regarded by those outside the church as "scum of the world, the refuse of all things" (1 Cor. 4:13). The faith that pleases God, however, since it is the demonstrable evidence of things not seen (Heb. 11:1), provides a radically different perspective. It enabled Moses to assess the reproach of Christ, endured in solidarity with God's mistreated people, as greater wealth than Egypt's treasures (vv. 25–26). Such faith reveals that these outcasts, whom the world despised, were actually the people "of whom the world was not worthy" (v. 38). They were heirs destined for a far better homeland than this world has to offer: a heavenly country (v. 16).

<span id="page-181-16"></span><span id="page-181-15"></span><span id="page-181-14"></span><sup>36</sup> *The English Standard Version Bible with Apocrypha* (New York: Oxford University Press, 2009).

<span id="page-182-5"></span><span id="page-182-4"></span><span id="page-182-3"></span>11:39–40 The discourse on God-pleasing faith began with the announcement that those ancient believers whose lives we read of in the OT were "commended" by God (11:2), and it closes as it opened. By inscribing their stories into his Scriptures, God still bears testimony that these saints were righteous, for they lived by persevering faith (10:36–39). God "commended" Abel and Enoch (11:4, 5) and all those who lived by faith, hoping for the arrival of Christ in redemptive history. Some tasted partial and provisional fulfillments of God's promise, but on the whole they "did not receive what was promised," for the "something better" that God provided for us is the new and better covenant, inaugurated on better promises by the blood of Jesus (8:6–12; 9:13–15). By his blood both they who pre-hoped in the Messiah (Eph. 1:12) and we who hear him speaking salvation "in these last days" (Heb. 1:1–2; 2:3–4) are together perfected, cleansed, and qualified to draw near to God.

#### <span id="page-182-2"></span><span id="page-182-1"></span><span id="page-182-0"></span>*Response*

Our preacher concludes his survey of OT history with an avalanche of vignettes graphically portraying the *costs* of living by faith in God: mockery and mistreatment, destitution and alienation, homelessness, abuse, torture, and death. Our cultural contexts, as well as our own hearts, often incline us to weigh the "pros" and "cons" of entrusting ourselves wholly to Jesus in terms of the tangible outcomes that may appear in the short run. When the reward is distant and the price to be paid is very present and painfully high, we feel pressured to conform and blend in. But Jesus called his followers to swim upstream against the downward current of the culture around them. The ancient exemplars of faith, for all their flaws, held fast to a hope in things not yet seen, considering the God who promised to be faithful and the reward worth receiving, whatever the cost. Both their testimony to God's faithfulness and his testimony to their faith challenge our self-centered and frivolous conceptions of faith, calling us instead to lifelong endurance, with our eyes fixed steadfastly on Jesus and our hearts resolved to follow him to the end, by the grace he supplies.

### <span id="page-182-6"></span>HEBREWS 12:1–11

12 Therefore, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us also lay aside every weight, and sin which clings so closely, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us, **<sup>2</sup>** looking to Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith, who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is seated at the right hand of the throne of God.

**<sup>3</sup>**Consider him who endured from sinners such hostility against himself, so that you may not grow weary or fainthearted. **<sup>4</sup>** In your struggle against

sin you have not yet resisted to the point of shedding your blood. **5**And have you forgotten the exhortation that addresses you as sons?

"My son, do not regard lightly the discipline of the Lord, nor be weary when reproved by him.

**<sup>6</sup>** For the Lord disciplines the one he loves, and chastises every son whom he receives."

**<sup>7</sup>** It is for discipline that you have to endure. God is treating you as sons. For what son is there whom his father does not discipline? **<sup>8</sup>** If you are left without discipline, in which all have participated, then you are illegitimate children and not sons. **9**Besides this, we have had earthly fathers who disciplined us and we respected them. Shall we not much more be subject to the Father of spirits and live? **10**For they disciplined us for a short time as it seemed best to them, but he disciplines us for our good, that we may share his holiness. **11**For the moment all discipline seems painful rather than pleasant, but later it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness to those who have been trained by it.

#### *Section Overview: Look to Jesus, and Endure God's Fatherly Discipline*

<span id="page-183-4"></span><span id="page-183-2"></span><span id="page-183-1"></span><span id="page-183-0"></span>The exhortation to enduring faith, grounded in Habakkuk 2:3–4 (Heb. 10:35–39) and illustrated in the lives of OT saints (11:1–40), is now repeated and elaborated. *Endurance* is a theme pervading this section, both explicitly (12:1, 2, 3, 7) and implicitly, in the warnings against weariness and faintheartedness (vv. 3, 5, and cf. vv. 12–13). The summons to "run with endurance" is supported by the testimony of a "cloud of witnesses" who attest to God's faithfulness, and it is grounded in the vision of "Jesus, the founder and perfecter of faith" (AT), who endured the cross and now sits at God's right hand. Suffering for their faith apparently daunted the original hearers. The remedy is to appreciate more fully the shame and pain Jesus endured and to remember the encouraging perspective on sufferings provided in Proverbs: our sufferings are signs that God acknowledges us as sons and cares enough to discipline us. *Discipline* is thus the other theme interwoven throughout this exhortation (vv. 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11). God's goal for such painful discipline is our benefit: to conform us to his character in holiness, peace, and righteousness. So we must endure in hope.

#### <span id="page-183-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- I. Consider Jesus' sufferings and endurance, which provide perspective on your adversity (12:1–4)
	- A. Run with endurance, because a cloud of OT witnesses attests God's faithfulness (12:1)
	- B. Fix your attention on Jesus, who endured the severest suffering on the cross (12:2–4)
- II. God's painful discipline confirms that you are beloved sons and serves his good purposes for you (12:5–11)
	- A. God exhorts you as sons to recognize his painful discipline as proof of his love (12:5–8)
	- B. If we respected finite human fathers for disciplining us, we should much more submit to the Father who disciplines us for a greater goal (12:9–10)
	- C. Though painful in the present, discipline yields peaceful fruit in the end (12:11)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-184-8"></span><span id="page-184-6"></span><span id="page-184-5"></span>12:1 An emphatic "Therefore" shows that the survey of OT people of faith is the basis for the exhortation "Let us run with endurance." They are "so great a cloud of witnesses [*martyrōn*]" because they testify from the pages of Scripture that God is faithful (11:11). Abel, Enoch, and others were those on whose behalf God was testifying (*martyreō*; ESV "commended") in his Word (11:2, 4, 5, 39). Now our author turns things around: those ancient believers bear witness on God's behalf, affirming that he can be trusted. Their testimony should give us stamina to endure in our race. They may also be spectators who are observing the hearers' performance, but the writer's use of "witness" terminology favors the sense that they are actively testifying: Abel, "though he died, . . . still speaks," as do others (11:4; cf. 11:13–14).

<span id="page-184-12"></span><span id="page-184-7"></span><span id="page-184-0"></span>Our preacher evokes athletic imagery drawn from the ancient Panhellenic games, precursors of our modern Olympics. He previously described Jesus as our "forerunner" (6:20). Now he calls his hearers to strip off every encumbering "weight" and run the "race" on the course set out before them. He will refer to being "trained" by discipline (12:11) and will apply the metaphor of runners' injuries to spiritual disabilities (vv. 12–13). In this imagery the "weight" to be stripped away could be training weights or encumbering clothing. Perhaps clothing is in view, since "lay aside" (*apotithēmi* ) elsewhere refers to disrobing (Rom. 13:12; Eph. 4:22; Col. 3:8), and "trained" (*gymnazō*) in Hebrews 12:11 alludes to the Greek athletic practice of competing unclothed (*gymnos*). The weight to be discarded symbolizes "sin which clings so closely." The sin to which the original hearers were especially tempted was not only violation of God's moral commands (12:16; 13:4) but also apostatizing from their allegiance to Christ under the threat of persecution (10:26–39). Their "struggle against sin," which had not yet escalated to bloodshed, was a struggle to hold fast their faith (12:4).

<span id="page-184-13"></span><span id="page-184-11"></span><span id="page-184-10"></span><span id="page-184-9"></span><span id="page-184-4"></span><span id="page-184-3"></span><span id="page-184-2"></span><span id="page-184-1"></span>12:2 Although the voices of OT witnesses should encourage us, the key to endurance in the race is looking to the "founder and perfecter" of faith, Jesus. (The Greek word order here, as in 2:9; 3:1; 4:14; 6:20; and 7:22, builds hearers' anticipation by first *describing* the Savior before finally *naming* him.) "Founder" (*archēgos*) has a range of meanings (cf. comment on 2:10). Often in the LXX it refers to Israel's

<span id="page-185-12"></span>tribal heads and military commanders. Here, as the "founder" of faith as well as its "perfecter (*teleiōtēs*)," Jesus is not only faith's preeminent exemplar, overshadowing the OT people of faith, but also the originator and object of our faith. He initiates our faith, runs faith's race ahead of us, and brings our faith to its goal. In the OT era believers were not yet "made perfect [*teleioō*]" (11:40), because the system of sacrifices administered by Aaronic priests "made nothing perfect" (7:11, 19). But now Jesus' sacrifice has "perfected for all time" those who trust him (10:14), opening access into God's holy presence.

<span id="page-185-9"></span><span id="page-185-8"></span><span id="page-185-7"></span><span id="page-185-1"></span>Jesus set the pace of enduring faith. His faith is expressed in his words cited from Isaiah 8:17 in Hebrews 2:13: "I will put my trust in him." For sinful people, saving faith involves reliance on Jesus' blood and righteousness as we recognize our own unworthiness. But for Jesus, the sinless priest and unblemished sacrifice, faith was his trust in his Father's assurance that, after he fulfilled God's will through death on the cross, his cries for deliverance from death would be "heard" and answered in his resurrection (5:7–10; 7:26–28; 10:10; 13:20). Jesus' trust in the Father's promise was thus expressed in his readiness to endure the cross, "despising the shame." He made that costly choice "for the joy that was set before him." The Greek preposition rendered "for" (*anti* ) frequently means "instead of" (e.g., Matt. 2:22; 5:38; 20:28), and the verb "set before" ( *prokeimai* ) was just used to describe the racetrack *immediately* ahead of us (cf. 2 Cor. 8:12). So it has been argued that the author means that, instead of a joyful rescue that Jesus could have experienced immediately (Matt. 26:53), he chose instead the reproach of crucifixion. Moses' reckoning the reproach of Christ as greater wealth than Egypt's treasures foreshadowed Christ's own valuation of even more extreme alternatives (Heb. 11:26).

<span id="page-185-11"></span><span id="page-185-5"></span><span id="page-185-3"></span><span id="page-185-2"></span>On the other hand, according to the ESV, other versions, and most commentators, Jesus endured the cross and its shame *for the sake of* the joy awaiting him *beyond his suffering*—the joy of being "seated at the right hand of the throne of God." This interpretation fits the only other use in Hebrews of the preposition *anti*, a few verses later: Esau "sold his birthright for [*anti* = not "instead of" but "for the sake of obtaining"] a single meal" (12:16). Thus Moses resembled Jesus in a different sense: he was "looking to the reward" (11:26). Our author is about to urge his hearers to endure painful suffering in anticipation of its future fruit (12:11). Jesus shows them how and why.

<span id="page-185-14"></span><span id="page-185-13"></span><span id="page-185-10"></span><span id="page-185-6"></span><span id="page-185-4"></span><span id="page-185-0"></span>The shame of execution on a cross was well known across the Greco-Roman world among both pagans and Jews, for whom it bore the added stigma of God's curse (Deut. 21:22–23; 1 Cor. 1:18–25; Gal. 3:13; cf. Acts 5:30; 10:39; 13:29). Jesus' suffering on the cross, however, transformed its shame and reproach (Heb. 13:12–13) into an occasion for Christian boasting (Gal. 6:14). Believers can rejoice in their own mistreatment and "dishonor for the name," realizing that God has counted them "worthy" to be identified with their Lord (Acts 5:41). As increasing intimidation and opposition loomed on their horizon, the hearers of this letter, who had already endured public reproach (Heb. 10:32–33), needed to recall that Jesus had borne shame as he suffered for them.

H ebr ews 12:1–11 186

<span id="page-186-17"></span><span id="page-186-13"></span><span id="page-186-6"></span>12:3–4 To look to Jesus is to consider him with focused, thoughtful reflection. The author directs our attention not to the cross's physical torments but to the "hostility" of "sinners" that assaulted Jesus as he died (Mark 15:18–20, 29–32). His endurance in the face of such spiteful repudiation should hearten believers who are tempted to "grow weary or fainthearted" when ostracized by their families or the wider community. "Grow weary" reflects a Greek term (*kamnō*) that expresses weakness or sickness (cf. James 5:15). To be "fainthearted" (*eklyomai* ) is to suffer exhaustion. Those who are "fainthearted" physically may fail to reach their destination (Mark 8:3), and those who suffer spiritual exhaustion are prone to discouragement (Gal. 6:9). The term "fainthearted" is the bridge into the encouragement offered in Proverbs 3, which our preacher is about to cite in verses 5b–6 (there translated "be weary").

<span id="page-186-12"></span><span id="page-186-11"></span><span id="page-186-8"></span><span id="page-186-7"></span><span id="page-186-5"></span><span id="page-186-0"></span>The hearers' necessary "struggle against sin" is specifically their need to resist the sin of apostasy (cf. Heb. 10:26–39). This is why the preacher notes that their struggle has not yet escalated to the "point of shedding your blood." Our preacher has pointed out that Jesus has rescued us from the fear of death (2:14–15), and he has catalogued the losses endured by OT believers (11:35–38). His hearers were probably being pressured by intimidation, ostracism, and physical threats to renounce their confession of faith in Jesus. So far the persecution had not reached the extreme of martyrdom (though cf. comment on 13:7). In this respect, their sufferings cannot be compared with the ultimate price paid by Jesus, who shed his blood to purify their consciences and draw them near to God (9:14; 10:19, 29). Meditating on *his* sacrifice would put their own trials into perspective, fortifying their hearts against self-pity and hopelessness.

<span id="page-186-15"></span><span id="page-186-14"></span><span id="page-186-10"></span><span id="page-186-9"></span><span id="page-186-2"></span>12:5–6 Contributing to the hearers' dismay over the opposition they were receiving was their forgetfulness of the "exhortation," or "encouragement" ( *paraklēsis*), that God spoke to them as sons. Again our preacher assumes that the OT (here, Prov. 3:11–12) is not merely a text inscribed in a bygone generation but also is the Holy Spirit's speech to us in our "today" (Heb. 3:7, 13; 10:15–17). The *paraklēsis/parakaleō* word group, prominent throughout Hebrews (cf. 13:22), has a semantic range that includes stern exhortation (admonition) but also warm encouragement (comfort). Here the tone of the Proverbs citation and the author's application favor the sense of heartening "encouragement."

<span id="page-186-16"></span><span id="page-186-1"></span>Proverbs 3:11 seems to describe different reactions to the Lord's discipline, on the one hand "regard[ing it] lightly" and on the other "be[ing] weary." The first response is that of an arrogant son who ignores his father's discipline; the second is that of an insecure son who construes his father's reproof as personal rejection. In fact, both reactions demonstrate forgetfulness of the truth of Proverbs 3:12: "The Lord disciplines the one he loves, and chastises37 every son whom he receives." Those who respond to adversities either by challenging God's authority

<span id="page-186-4"></span><span id="page-186-3"></span><sup>37</sup> Hebrews follows the LXX, which inserts the verb *mastigoō* ("chastises," often "beats" or "flogs"), which has no counterpart in the Hebrew text of Proverbs 3:11–12.

<span id="page-187-2"></span>or by doubting his good purpose have forgotten that such sufferings are tokens of his love and of their legitimacy as his sons. The situation envisioned in Proverbs is fatherly correction when a son misbehaves (cf. Prov. 13:24; 19:18; 22:15; 23:13–14). Our author of Hebrews widens the perspective to include afflictions suffered as the consequence of faithfulness in resisting sin. Those who suffer for righteousness' sake, no less than those disciplined to wean them from sin, can be assured that their pains serve their Father's loving purpose for them (Matt. 5:10–12).

<span id="page-187-7"></span><span id="page-187-3"></span>12:7–8 Both the noun "discipline" ( *paideia*) and the cognate verb appear in the Proverbs citation, and now "discipline" sums up God's paternal purpose that makes endurance both possible and obligatory. The form of the Greek verb "endure" (*hypomenete*) could be in either the indicative mood ("you are enduring") or the imperative ("you must endure"). The ESV's "you have to endure" nicely conveys this ambiguity, leaning toward the imperative: hearers must endure because "God is treating you as sons." In the Greco-Roman world it was not unusual for a nobleman to subject his legitimate son and heir to a rigorous upbringing under the severe tutelage of a guardian, since the future of the father's name and estate would rest with the son (Gal. 4:1–2). Meanwhile, illegitimate children, since they did not bear their father's name nor stand to inherit his property, might be left without moral discipline. To be spared God's painful discipline is indicative not of his favor but of his indifference and rejection.
