<span id="page-187-8"></span><span id="page-187-6"></span><span id="page-187-5"></span>12:9–10 When we recognize how God's painful discipline reveals his loving acceptance and our legitimacy as his children and heirs, this perspective will affect our attitude toward him amid our afflictions. The preacher draws an analogy to human family dynamics in another *a fortiori* (*qal v'homer*, "light and heavy") argument (cf. comment on 2:2–4). The point of comparison is clear: when a son recognizes that his father's discipline, however difficult to bear at the moment, springs from a desire for the son's well-being, the son respects (that is, humbles himself before; *entrepō*) such a father. The verb *entrepō* in the passive voice means to "be humbled" and in the middle voice means to "humble oneself" before another person (Ex. 10:3 LXX; Titus 2:8)—that is, to acknowledge that person's greater honor (Luke 18:2, 4). That principle is all the more applicable in our response to the discipline God imposes on us, since it is better than that of human fathers in three ways:

- <span id="page-187-4"></span><span id="page-187-1"></span><span id="page-187-0"></span>(1) Human fathers were "fathers of our *flesh*" (ESV = "earthly fathers"), whereas God is the "Father of *spirits*" (echoing Num. 16:22; 27:16).
- (2) Human fathers "disciplined us for a short time," whereas God works throughout our lives to remold our characters through painful discipline.
- (3) Human fathers exercised discipline "as it seemed best to them" in their finite and fallen perspective, whereas in his infinite wisdom God infallibly knows what is for our benefit (*to sympheron*), namely, "that we may share his holiness."

The more we remember that our painful circumstances are orchestrated by God in his infinite wisdom, sovereign control, and fatherly love, the better we will bear his discipline in hopeful endurance.

<span id="page-188-8"></span><span id="page-188-3"></span>12:11 The encouraging assurance God speaks to his sons does not anesthetize us against the pain of present afflictions. Our preacher frankly admits that, when it is happening, discipline "seems painful rather than pleasant"—or, to reflect the strength of the contrast: "not joyful [*chara*] but grief-filled [*lypē*]." Paul uses the same contrast to express the hope that, on an impending visit to Corinth, he will not "suffer pain [*lypē*] from those who should have made me rejoice [*chairō*]" (2 Cor. 2:3). Enduring faith must look beyond the painful present to the fruitful future, grasping the reality of things hoped for, the evidence of things not yet seen (Heb. 11:1). Our preacher joins his voice to the chorus of NT authors who, inspired by God's Spirit, assure us that our "light momentary affliction is preparing for us an eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison" (2 Cor. 4:17; cf. John 16:33; Rom. 8:17–18; 1 Pet. 1:6–7).

<span id="page-188-7"></span><span id="page-188-6"></span><span id="page-188-2"></span><span id="page-188-1"></span><span id="page-188-0"></span>To strengthen hope in the face of present pain, the preacher mixes agricultural and athletic metaphors (cf. 2 Tim. 2:3–6). As farmers till soil and sow seed in anticipation of a future crop, so those undergoing God's wise and loving discipline should patiently expect a later harvest of the "peaceful fruit of righteousness." The author of Hebrews, along with James and Paul, all seem to have drawn this farming metaphor from Isaiah 32:16–18 and other OT texts (James 3:18; 5:7–8; Phil. 1:11; cf. Prov. 11:18; Hos. 10:12). Then, shifting back to the athletic imagery with which he opened this exhortation, our preacher speaks of those who "have been trained" (*gymnazō*) by the Lord's discipline. Alongside the apparent passivity of farmland he reintroduces the picture of strenuous human exercise in training and then running the race set before us (cf. 1 Tim. 4:7–8). Enduring faith is strenuous effort springing from assurance of God's fatherly love, and therefore it sprints with the strength he supplies "toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus" (Phil. 3:14). Moreover, this is not a solo race but a team sport, in which every member must attend to others' weak knees and disabled joints (as our preacher will carry the athletic metaphor forward in Heb. 12:12–13).

#### <span id="page-188-9"></span><span id="page-188-5"></span><span id="page-188-4"></span>*Response*

In every generation Christians face opposition that works against lifelong perseverance in following Jesus. Sometimes the "hostility of sinners" is expressed verbally and socially. Sometimes matters escalate to financial hardship, physical harm, imprisonment, and even death. But God gives us strong reasons to run with endurance the race of faith laid out in front of us: the abundant testimony of those who ran ahead of us; the courageous example and loving self-sacrifice of faith's founder and perfecter, Jesus; and the Father's encouragement that our present pains as we struggle to hold fast to faith signal his loving acceptance and fit his flawless plan for our eternal well-being. Looking to Jesus and recalling our Father's encouragement supply the stamina to run the race to the finish line.

### <span id="page-189-8"></span>HEBREWS 12:12–17

**<sup>12</sup>**Therefore lift your drooping hands and strengthen your weak knees, **<sup>13</sup>** and make straight paths for your feet, so that what is lame may not be put out of joint but rather be healed. **<sup>14</sup>** Strive for peace with everyone, and for the holiness without which no one will see the Lord. **<sup>15</sup>** See to it that no one fails to obtain the grace of God; that no "root of bitterness" springs up and causes trouble, and by it many become defiled; **<sup>16</sup>** that no one is sexually immoral or unholy like Esau, who sold his birthright for a single meal. **17**For you know that afterward, when he desired to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no chance to repent, though he sought it with tears.

### *Section Overview: Exhortation: Cultivate Endurance through Christian Community*

<span id="page-189-7"></span><span id="page-189-6"></span><span id="page-189-5"></span>The author continues his exhortation to endurance, extending his athletic metaphor of training (12:11) and running a race (v. 1) with instructions to fortify weakened and wounded limbs and joints (vv. 12–13). These verses form a bridge between the preceding paragraph and what follows, transitioning to a focus on believers' *corporate* responsibility to support one another in the lifelong marathon of faith, an obligation that has already been discussed (3:12–14; 4:1; 10:24–25). This exhortation is reinforced by OT allusions. The imagery of physical therapy for injured limbs and joints, echoing Isaiah 35:3–4, illustrates the congregation's obligation to care for its weak and wounded members and to follow "straight paths" toward the goal (cf. Prov. 4:26).

<span id="page-189-4"></span><span id="page-189-3"></span><span id="page-189-2"></span>Because the church is to be characterized by unity and purity, its members must pursue peace and holiness (Ps. 34:14). The community's members and leaders must be on the lookout for three types of individuals who would inject toxins into the body of Christ, putting others' health at risk: (1) the *doubter*, who "fails to obtain the grace of God" by hardening his heart rather than heeding God's voice; (2) the *defiant* "root of bitterness" (cf. Deut. 29:18–19), who imagines that God will not detect his secret stubbornness; and (3) the *devotee* of immediate gratification, who, like Esau, prefers sating his physical appetites above waiting for God's future blessing (Genesis 25–27).

#### <span id="page-189-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-189-1"></span>I. Support weak and wounded runners in the race (12:12–13)
	- A. Strengthen feeble members (12:12)
	- B. Stabilize disabled members (12:13)
- II. Strive for peace and holiness (12:14)
- III. See to it that your communion is free of the doubter, the defiant, and the devotee of immediate gratification (12:15–17)
	- A. The doubter, who falls short of God's grace (12:15a)
	- B. The defiant, who defiles many (12:15b)
	- C. The devotee of immediate gratification, who prefers his present cravings to God's future blessing (12:16–17)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-190-12"></span><span id="page-190-11"></span><span id="page-190-10"></span><span id="page-190-4"></span>12:12–13 "Trained" (*gymnazō*) in verse 11 recalled the athletic imagery of verse 1: hearers must discard everything that would hinder their running the lifelong race of faith on the course set out before them. Their endurance is threatened by "sin" (vv. 1, 4) and by their "weariness" in the face of opposition (cf. v. 3). Now our preacher extends the sport symbolism, exhorting the whole congregation to strengthen its weakened members, drawing imagery from Isaiah. The symbolism of "weak hands" and "feeble knees" was interpreted in the prophecy itself: "Say to those who have *an anxious heart*: 'Be strong; fear not! Behold, your God will come with vengeance . . . and save you'" (Isa. 35:3–5; cf. Heb. 12:3). When God comes, blessings will abound, including the healing of the lame so that they will leap like the deer (Isa. 35:6; cf. also Hab. 3:19; Zeph. 3:16–19). The promise of God's *coming* with *vengeance* and in saving grace connects this passage with OT texts quoted earlier (Heb. 10:30–31, 37–38, citing Deut. 32:35–36; Hab. 2:3–4). The context of Isaiah's summons to strengthen limp hands and quivering knees shows that these are not bare commands but are encouragements grounded in the promise that our divine defender is coming.

<span id="page-190-7"></span><span id="page-190-5"></span><span id="page-190-2"></span><span id="page-190-1"></span><span id="page-190-0"></span>The ESV uses two verbs, "lift" and "strengthen," to represent a single Greek verb (*anorthoō*), which has two objects, "drooping hands" and "weak knees." The Greek verb conveys not only strengthening but also straightening (Ps. 145:14; Luke 13:13), and so it serves as a bridge to another pertinent OT text, Proverbs 4:26 LXX, which our preacher introduces in Hebrews 12:13: "Make straight [*orthas*] paths for your feet." Paths that further healing, rather than dislocation, must be "straight" in two senses. First, they must be *level*, free of stumbling stones or pitfalls that would compound injury to a twisted ankle or wrenched knee (Isa. 40:4). But they also must *run straight* toward the finish line, not leading runners astray (Prov. 4:27 LXX).

<span id="page-190-9"></span><span id="page-190-8"></span><span id="page-190-6"></span><span id="page-190-3"></span>Such paths will keep what is lame from being twisted—in two ways. First, on such paths the lame will not be "put out of joint," twisted to the point of dislocation, but rather will be "healed." The verb rendered "put out of joint" (*ektrepō*) often describes straying "off course" from the way that leads to life (1 Tim. 1:6; 5:15; 2 Tim. 4:4). Hebrews adjusts the wording of Proverbs 4:26 LXX, changing the number of the verb "make straight" and of the possessive pronoun "your" from singular to plural, transforming a father's advice to an individual son into an exhortation to an entire congregation. When Christians are spiritually weak

(drooping hands, feeble knees) or disabled (lame), fellow believers must gather around them, clearing away obstacles and pointing them straight ahead to the finish line.

<span id="page-191-18"></span><span id="page-191-17"></span>12:14 Verses 14–16 form one sentence in Greek. Its main clause is "Strive for peace . . . and . . . holiness." Then a subordinate clause introduced by the participle "seeing to it" (*episkopountes*) at the beginning of verse 15 shows how these virtues are preserved and promoted, namely, by watching out for three threats to the church's peace and purity (vv. 15–16).

<span id="page-191-21"></span><span id="page-191-20"></span><span id="page-191-4"></span><span id="page-191-3"></span><span id="page-191-1"></span>The straight path is marked by two virtues to be pursued (*diōkō*; ESV "strive for"): peace and holiness. "Strive for peace" echoes Psalm 34:14 (33:15 LXX; cf. 1 Pet. 3:10–12). NT authors instruct believers to live peacefully with each other (Mark 9:50; Rom. 14:19; 2 Cor. 13:11; 2 Tim. 2:22). Here, however, the command is to "strive for peace with *everyone*." This broader peacemaking obligation also has parallels elsewhere in the NT (Matt. 5:9–11; Rom. 12:14–21; 1 Cor. 7:15). The gospel shows that our peacemaking and peacekeeping, both with each other and with outside opponents, flow from the peacemaking sacrifice of Jesus (Rom. 5:1; Eph. 2:14–18) and the heart-changing power of his Spirit (Eph. 4:3–6). God's fatherly discipline will yield in his children's relationships a *peaceful* harvest of righteousness (Heb. 12:11). Included in the fruit the Spirit is producing in believers is peace (Gal. 5:22).

<span id="page-191-16"></span><span id="page-191-13"></span><span id="page-191-12"></span><span id="page-191-8"></span><span id="page-191-7"></span><span id="page-191-6"></span><span id="page-191-2"></span>Along with peace, we must also pursue "the holiness without which no one will see the Lord." Jesus pronounced blessing on the "pure in heart," who "shall see God" (Matt. 5:8). The OT law revealed that *lack* of holiness prevents worshipers from drawing near to God, but through Christ's blood we "have been sanctified" once for all in our standing before God, so we can draw near to him (Heb. 10:10, 14, 19–22). Yet the new covenant delivers not only forgiveness but also transformation of hearts (10:15–16). Tasting God's grace in the cleansing of our stained consciences will whet Christians' longing to reflect the beauty of his holiness in our character, affections, desires, and conduct (1 Thess. 4:3–7; 5:23; 2 Thess. 2:13). Our Father's loving purpose in disciplining us is "that we may share his holiness" (Heb. 12:10).

<span id="page-191-19"></span><span id="page-191-15"></span><span id="page-191-14"></span><span id="page-191-11"></span><span id="page-191-10"></span><span id="page-191-9"></span><span id="page-191-5"></span><span id="page-191-0"></span>12:15 "See to it" reflects a Greek verb (*episkopeō*) that in other contexts refers to oversight of others (2 Chron. 34:12; 1 Pet. 5:2). The cognate noun "overseer" (*episkopos*) expresses church elders' responsibility for the spiritual care and protection of their flock (Acts 20:28–31; 1 Tim. 3:2–7; Titus 1:5–9). Our author will mention this role in his discussion of the church's leaders (Heb. 13:7, 17), but here, as in 3:13, the entire congregation is called to be vigilant. We must be on the lookout for three types of people whose sinful example and influence threaten the unity and purity of the Christian community. The repeated Greek formula *mē tis* ("lest any[one]," reflected in the ESV's repeated "that no one") identifies these three dangers: (1) one who falls short of God's grace; (2) a "root of bitterness," who defiles others; and (3) one who is immoral and profane, like Esau. The author has drawn from

<span id="page-192-7"></span>Deuteronomy 29:18–21 LXX not only the "root of bitterness" expression but also the "lest anyone" (*mē tis*) formula: "Beware lest [*mē tis*] there be among you a man or woman . . . whose heart is turning away today from the Lord our God. . . . Beware lest [*mē tis*] there be among you a root bearing poisonous and bitter fruit." These covenant breakers are not just weakened limbs needing healing (Heb. 12:12–13); they are malignancies endangering the body's very survival.

<span id="page-192-13"></span><span id="page-192-11"></span><span id="page-192-9"></span>The one who "fails to obtain" (*hystereō*) God's grace is like those in Israel's wilderness generation, who fell short (*hystereō*) of God's rest through unbelief (4:1). All humanity has sinned and fallen short of God's glory (Rom. 3:23). Some who have failed to obtain God's grace are identified visibly with the people of God— OT Israel and the NT church—but their professed faith will not prove genuine. Since our preacher is adapting Deuteronomy 29:18, to fall short of God's grace is nothing short of apostasy, "turning away . . . from the Lord our God."

<span id="page-192-8"></span><span id="page-192-6"></span>Moses used the image of a "root bearing poisonous and bitter fruit" to characterize the one who "blesses himself in his heart, saying, 'I shall be safe, though I walk in the stubbornness of my heart'" (Deut. 29:19), imagining that belonging to Israel's covenant community would insulate him from judgment despite his defiance of the Lord's demands. Our preacher warns that such smug rebellion can infect and "defile many" others. The OT laws of ceremonial purity defined conditions and contacts that would "defile," rendering people unfit for worship (Leviticus 11; 13; 18; 21; 22; etc.). Physical defilement temporarily excluded worshipers from an earthly sanctuary, but spiritual defilement is eternally lethal.

<span id="page-192-14"></span><span id="page-192-5"></span><span id="page-192-4"></span><span id="page-192-3"></span><span id="page-192-1"></span>12:16–17 The third threat is the individual who imitates Esau's secular mind-set and immoral lifestyle. Esau exemplifies the opposite of the OT faithful witnesses. They trusted God's word about things not yet seen, while Esau looked no further than his bodily appetites. He was "sexually immoral," taking two Hittite wives, who grieved his covenant-revering parents (Gen. 26:34–35). His mind-set was "unholy" (*bebēlos*): "common" in contrast to holy, irreverent in contrast to Godfearing, secular in contrast to glimpsing eternal things (Lev. 10:10; Ezek. 22:26; 1 Tim. 1:9; 4:7; 6:20). Esau's this-worldly frame of reference explains his readiness, as firstborn, to sell his right to a double inheritance in exchange for a single meal. Scripture comments, "Thus Esau despised his birthright" (Gen. 25:29–34). Disbelieving God's promises, Esau prioritized the immediate gratification of his appetites over inheritance in a land in which his family only sojourned as aliens (Heb. 11:9, 13).

<span id="page-192-12"></span><span id="page-192-10"></span><span id="page-192-2"></span><span id="page-192-0"></span>Later, Jacob (through deceit, unmentioned by our author) secured the firstborn's blessing as well as the birthright Esau had so easily bartered away (Gen. 27:30–38). Esau's outcry and weeping (Gen. 27:34, 38) could not reverse his rejection by God nor undo the blessing Isaac had already pronounced on Jacob. Esau sought "the blessing," but he (lit.) "found no *place* of *repentance* [*metanoias . . . topon*]." Even though he desired the dominance his father had conferred on Jacob, Esau never experienced a deep change of heart. He became the archetype of a

<span id="page-193-1"></span>person so hardened, despite covenantal privileges, that he could not be restored to repentance (Heb. 6:6).

#### *Response*

<span id="page-193-0"></span>Christians' responsibility to protect the vulnerable and support the weak and wounded entails our calling to pursue peace and holiness together. We do not nervously attempt a superficial peace at any price, indifferent to God's truth or holiness. Nor do we magnify prohibitions beyond God's Word, defining holiness in negative terms ("Do not handle . . . taste . . . touch"; Col. 2:21) and thereby fragmenting the church's peace and crushing its walking wounded. As God disciplines us in fatherly love, so we must express his caring correction to each other, especially to those with drooping hands or feeble knees, our teammates who, though injured, are still in the race. Moreover, pursuing peace and holiness together demands that we all be vigilant to identify and resist those who would lure others toward apostasy, complacency in sin, and short-sighted fixation on immediate gratification. Running with endurance is a team sport.

### <span id="page-193-2"></span>HEBREWS 12:18–29

**<sup>18</sup>**For you have not come to what may be touched, a blazing fire and darkness and gloom and a tempest **<sup>19</sup>** and the sound of a trumpet and a voice whose words made the hearers beg that no further messages be spoken to them. **20**For they could not endure the order that was given, "If even a beast touches the mountain, it shall be stoned." **<sup>21</sup>** Indeed, so terrifying was the sight that Moses said, "I tremble with fear." **22**But you have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to innumerable angels in festal gathering, **<sup>23</sup>** and to the assembly*<sup>1</sup>* of the firstborn who are enrolled in heaven, and to God, the judge of all, and to the spirits of the righteous made perfect, **<sup>24</sup>** and to Jesus, the mediator of a new covenant, and to the sprinkled blood that speaks a better word than the blood of Abel.

**<sup>25</sup>** See that you do not refuse him who is speaking. For if they did not escape when they refused him who warned them on earth, much less will we escape if we reject him who warns from heaven. **26**At that time his voice shook the earth, but now he has promised, "Yet once more I will shake not only the earth but also the heavens." **27**This phrase, "Yet once more," indicates the removal of things that are shaken—that is, things that have been made—in order that the things that cannot be shaken may remain. **28**Therefore let us be grateful for receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, and thus let us offer to God acceptable worship, with reverence and awe, **<sup>29</sup>** for our God is a consuming fire.

#### *Section Overview: The Earthly Mount Sinai and the Heavenly Mount Zion*

<span id="page-194-0"></span>In the previous section, the place where believers enjoyed "rest" with God was the heavenly *homeland* symbolized by Canaan, the earthly Promised Land, though a promised *city* was also mentioned (Heb. 11:8–10, 13–16). Now our attention is focused on that *city and sanctuary*, in which we draw near to worship God. In contrast to the terrors of the earthly Mount Sinai, where God delivered the first covenant to Israel, we have come now by faith to Mount Zion in the heavenly Jerusalem, entering a worshiping assembly filled with joy and thanksgiving through the presence of Jesus, the mediator of the new covenant. Since God now addresses us from heaven, we must attend even more carefully to his word, both because spurning him brings judgment and because God bestows an eternal kingdom on those who worship through Jesus, in reverence and awe.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. You have not come to the terrifying Mount Sinai on earth, but to the celebrating Mount Zion in heaven (12:18–24)
	- A. The terrors of Mount Sinai in sight and sound struck Israel and Moses with trembling fear (12:18–21)
	- B. The celebrating sanctuary of Mount Zion is populated by angels, perfected saints and heirs, God the judge, and Jesus, whose blood secured our forgiveness (12:22–24)
- II. Heed God's voice as he warns from heaven, and worship him with grateful faith (12:25–29)
	- A. As we hear God's voice speaking from heaven, we must heed his warning (12:25)
	- B. God's voice shook the earth at Sinai; but at history's end his voice will "shake" the present heaven and earth, dismantling all but his unshakable kingdom (12:26–27)
	- C. We are receiving this unshakable kingdom, so let us offer thankful and reverent worship, pleasing to our God, the "consuming fire" (12:28–29)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-194-1"></span>12:18 The sermon moves to a new theme: the better mountain, city, and sanctuary that constitute the locale of worship under the new covenant. Yet the opening "For" shows that this discussion supports the preceding call to encourage those who are discouraged, to pursue peace and holiness, and to rebuff infecting influences that would lure us away from allegiance to Jesus. Our corporate care for each other is motivated by the privilege we now share as those who worship in the heavenly Jerusalem.

Our preacher graphically portrays the terrifying phenomena that accompanied the Lord's descent to Mount Sinai to meet with Moses and deliver his covenant to Israel. His point, however, is that those who approach God through Jesus'

<span id="page-195-19"></span>mediation "have *not* come" to such a daunting encounter with God. Rather, our worship centers on a mountain sanctuary far better than Sinai in both mood and transcendent reality. On the other hand, this section opens with "blazing fire" and closes with a reminder that Israel's God is our God, a "consuming fire" (v. 29). He is gracious toward us through Jesus, but his holiness is still lethal to those who harbor their sin.

<span id="page-195-20"></span><span id="page-195-10"></span>Sinai was both *touchable* and *terrifying*. The verb translated "may be touched" refers elsewhere to the tangibility of Jesus' resurrection body (Luke 24:39; 1 John 1:1), which is vital to our eternal hope. But here Sinai's physical "touchability" shows that it belongs to the present created order, which will pass away (Heb. 1:10–12). That touchable mountain was associated with the sanctuary made by human hands (9:11, 24) and with the animal sacrifices offered there, which could cleanse only the flesh, not the conscience (9:10, 13).

<span id="page-195-14"></span><span id="page-195-13"></span><span id="page-195-11"></span><span id="page-195-3"></span>The display of God's glory at Sinai was also *terrifying*, visibly and audibly. Reminding the Israelites of what they saw at that mountain, Moses mentioned blazing fire, darkness, gloom, and tempest (Deut. 4:11 LXX; cf. Ex. 19:16–18; 20:18). The mountain also "trembled greatly" (Ex. 19:18), but our author is reserving that detail for later (Heb. 12:25–27).

<span id="page-195-18"></span><span id="page-195-15"></span><span id="page-195-7"></span><span id="page-195-4"></span><span id="page-195-2"></span>12:19–20 Audibly, Sinai stunned the people of Israel with the sound of a trumpet, which grew louder and louder (Ex. 19:16, 19), and the very voice of God (Heb. 12:19; Deut. 4:12). The Lord's voice thundered so mightily that the Israelites pleaded for God not to address them directly but instead to convey his word through the mediation of Moses: "You [Moses] speak to us, and we will listen; but do not let God speak to us, lest we die" (Ex. 20:18–21). The glory of the Lord consecrated the entire mountain with his dangerous holiness. No human or animal was permitted to touch the mountain, and violators would be executed by stoning (Ex. 19:12).

<span id="page-195-16"></span><span id="page-195-6"></span><span id="page-195-5"></span><span id="page-195-1"></span>12:21 The entire scene was so "terrifying," so fear-instilling ( *phoberon*), that Moses himself, with whom God spoke "face to face, as a man speaks to his friend" (Ex. 33:11), trembled in fright. Looking back on Israel's spiritual adultery with the golden calf as he received the law on the mountain peak, Moses said, "Then I lay prostrate before the Lord . . . forty days and forty nights. . . . For I was afraid of the anger and hot displeasure that the Lord bore against you" (Deut. 9:18–19).

<span id="page-195-17"></span><span id="page-195-12"></span><span id="page-195-9"></span><span id="page-195-8"></span><span id="page-195-0"></span>12:22 "But you have come to" a mountain with more majesty and a mood of joy, not dread. Earlier in Hebrews, "you have come to" ( *proserchomai* ) described the priestly privilege of "drawing near" to God in worship and prayer (4:16; 7:25; 10:1, 22). The first, fear-filled mountain has not been named, though Sinai's identity is obvious from the allusions to Exodus 19 and Deuteronomy 4 and 9. Now, however, the mountain to which new covenant believers have come is named: "Mount Zion, . . . the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem." The first two titles call to mind the stronghold David captured and made his capital (2 Sam. 5:6–10), which became the site of the temple built by Solomon. One psalmist sang,

| Great is the Lord and greatly to be praised |
|---------------------------------------------|
| in the city of our God!                     |
| His holy mountain, beautiful in elevation,  |
| is the joy of all the earth,                |
| Mount Zion, in the far north,               |
| the city of the great King. (Ps. 48:1–2)    |

<span id="page-196-1"></span>The third title, "*heavenly* Jerusalem," however, casts a new light on the others. The location of Christians' worship is not on a mountain that "may be touched" anywhere on earth—neither in the Sinai Peninsula nor in Judah/Judea. The apostle Paul identified Mount Sinai and the law delivered there with the "present Jerusalem," the center of the Judaism of his day, which rejected Jesus' gospel of grace. By contrast, believers in Jesus, whatever their racial background, can look to the "Jerusalem above" as their mother (Gal. 4:21–31). Likewise, one of John's visions on Patmos identified the earthly Jerusalem with the "great city" that rejected God's witnesses, in which "their Lord was crucified" (Rev. 11:8). Another vision portrayed the "holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God" (Rev. 21:2).

<span id="page-196-15"></span><span id="page-196-14"></span><span id="page-196-12"></span><span id="page-196-5"></span><span id="page-196-4"></span>Jews who came to believe in Jesus sometimes faced expulsion from the Jewish community (John 9:22, 34; 16:2; Acts 18:4–7; Rev. 2:9; 3:8–9). The original hearers of Hebrews may have been facing such exclusion (Heb. 13:12–13). But in Jesus they and we have access to the better sanctuary in the heavenly city of God. This city is the home for which the patriarchs hoped (11:10, 16) and the "lasting city" for which new covenant believers still long (13:14). Yet even now, as we gather in worship, we "have come" to it already.

<span id="page-196-13"></span><span id="page-196-10"></span><span id="page-196-3"></span><span id="page-196-2"></span>Those assembled for worship in this heavenly sanctuary show the celebratory and reverent tone of the event. First are "innumerable angels in festal gathering [*panēgyris*]." In the LXX this term refers to Israel's appointed feasts (Ezek. 46:11; Hos. 2:13; 9:5; Amos 5:21). The ESV correctly connects "festal gathering" with the myriads of angels rather than with the "assembly of the firstborn" (contra KJV, NASB). In this list, "and" marks off discrete groups, so *panēgyris* (followed by "and") belongs to what precedes it. Angels are mentioned first since they appear early in the sermon (Heb. 1:4–2:18). God directed them to worship the Son when he entered the world to come at his ascension (cf. comment on 1:6), and they are sent by God to serve humans who are to inherit salvation through the Son (1:14; 2:5–10). They celebrate as observers of that salvation (1 Pet. 1:10–12; Rev. 5:11–12).

<span id="page-196-11"></span><span id="page-196-9"></span><span id="page-196-8"></span><span id="page-196-7"></span><span id="page-196-6"></span><span id="page-196-0"></span>12:23 The human worshipers are introduced under two titles: "the assembly of the firstborn who are enrolled in heaven" and "the spirits of the righteous made perfect." That "the firstborn" is a plural noun is obvious in Greek ( *prōtotokōn*) and visible in English, since they "*are* enrolled" and constitute an assembly. The term translated "assembly" (*ekklēsia*) typically refers to the "church" in the NT. In the LXX it is the term for the congregation of Israel assembled to worship in God's presence (Deut. 9:10; 31:30; Pss. 26:12; 35:18; etc.). The plural form of "firstborn" seems surprising, since we have heard God direct angels to worship his (singular) <span id="page-197-16"></span><span id="page-197-7"></span>firstborn Son (Heb. 1:6), the unique "heir of all things" (1:2). Esau's shortsighted sale of his birthright ( *prōtotokia*) has just reminded us that only one son in a family may enjoy the unique privileges of the firstborn (12:16–17). Yet *many* firstborn children of God make up this heavenly "assembly." This is because all whom the unique divine and messianic Son calls his "brothers" share by grace in the Son's inheritance (2:12; Rom. 8:17). Their names are "enrolled in heaven," inscribed for eternal life in God's book. This image runs throughout the Bible (Ex. 32:32–33; Pss. 87:6; 139:16; Dan. 12:1; Luke 10:20; Phil. 4:3; Rev. 20:12–15) and symbolizes God's sovereign, specific, and irreversible electing love toward individuals.

<span id="page-197-13"></span><span id="page-197-6"></span><span id="page-197-3"></span><span id="page-197-1"></span>From another perspective, the human worshipers in heaven are the "spirits of the righteous made perfect." These are the OT people of faith on whose behalf God testified that they were righteous as they lived by faith (Heb. 10:37–38; 11:2, 39). That they are "spirits" indicates they have not yet participated in the final resurrection of the dead (Rev. 6:9–11; 20:4). Yet, in contrast to their condition prior to Christ's coming (Heb. 11:40), now they have been "made perfect"—along with us—through the sacrifice of Jesus (10:14).

<span id="page-197-18"></span><span id="page-197-15"></span><span id="page-197-10"></span><span id="page-197-5"></span><span id="page-197-4"></span><span id="page-197-0"></span>Between the two descriptions of this privileged ("firstborn") and consecrated ("made perfect") people stands the divine object of their adoration: "God, the judge of all." Abraham appealed to God's supreme authority as "Judge of all the earth" as he bargained for the survival of anyone living in Sodom who might have been righteous (Gen. 18:25). Jesus announced that his Father had delegated to him the role of judge, and various NT texts repeat this point (John 5:22–23, 27; Acts 10:42; 17:31; 2 Tim. 4:8; James 5:9). Here God the Father is in view. As the earlier citation of Deuteronomy 32:36 showed, the Lord's authority to judge his people is a "fearful thing" to the guilty (Heb. 10:30–31). How, then, can our author assure us that the mountain we have approached does *not* hold Sinai's terrors? The answer lies in the last two features of the heavenly festival, described in the following verse (cf. comment).

<span id="page-197-17"></span><span id="page-197-12"></span><span id="page-197-8"></span><span id="page-197-2"></span>12:24 Finally our author brings into view "Jesus, the mediator of a new covenant," and his "sprinkled blood that speaks a better word than the blood of Abel." Jesus has inaugurated this new and better covenant and secured its better promises: forgiveness of sins, transformation of hearts, and access to God (7:22; 8:6–12; 10:15–18). The "sprinkled blood" represents the infinitely costly sacrifice he offered to secure these blessings for those who approach God through him. As the law provided cleansing from ceremonial defilement through the blood of bulls and goats and through the sprinkling of water containing a heifer's ashes, "how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without blemish to God, purify our conscience from dead works to serve the living God" (9:13–14). Our hearts have been "sprinkled clean from an evil conscience" (10:22; cf. 1 Pet. 1:2).

<span id="page-197-14"></span><span id="page-197-11"></span><span id="page-197-9"></span>The OT roster of faith opened with Abel's acceptable sacrifice and death (Heb. 11:4), but the cause of his death—his brother's violence—was not mentioned. Now we hear an echo of God's accusation against Cain: "The voice of your brother's <span id="page-198-13"></span><span id="page-198-0"></span>blood is crying to me from the ground" (Gen. 4:10). Its cry was for avenging justice, but Jesus' blood intercedes for mercy and forgiveness. God the "judge of all," who sent his Son into the world to accomplish his will, offering his body as a sacrifice for others' sins (Heb. 10:5–10), is pleased to grant the petition of that precious blood on our behalf. Thus we may draw near with confidence and enter this heavenly assembly with joyful gratitude (12:28).

<span id="page-198-16"></span><span id="page-198-14"></span><span id="page-198-10"></span>12:25 In view of our privilege to worship in the heavenly Jerusalem, our author issues two exhortations, one a warning ("See that you do not refuse him who is speaking") and the other a positive admonition ("let us be thankful and worship"; cf. v. 28). The warning repeats the *a fortiori*, "how much more" (rabbinic *qal v'homer*, "light and heavy") argument that appeared in different terms in 2:1–4 (cf. comment on 2:2–4): Since God's word spoken through angels was so binding that its violation brought severe punishment, God's word spoken by Jesus must receive even more allegiance.

<span id="page-198-19"></span><span id="page-198-11"></span><span id="page-198-9"></span><span id="page-198-7"></span>In chapter 2 the contrast between the ancient law and the "last days" word of salvation focused on the respective dignities of God's *messengers*, as the angels were contrasted to the Son. Now the contrast is between the *earthly* venue of God's speech at Sinai and the *heavenly* source from which the Lord now addresses his new covenant people. Since the Son through whom God speaks "in these last days" (1:2) is enthroned above (8:1–2), he "warns from heaven." Christ speaks in this inspired "word of exhortation" (13:22), since through this Scripture the Holy Spirit is testifying and God's voice is heard "today" (3:7, 13, 15; 4:7; 10:15). The exalted Christ's voice is also heard as he addresses his church through human leaders who teach God's Word (13:7, 17). Such servants of the Word may seem less splendid than angels, but they are heirs of salvation whom angels are sent to serve (1:14), and through them Jesus Christ, who remains "the same yesterday and today and forever," teaches and leads his people (13:8).

<span id="page-198-18"></span><span id="page-198-17"></span><span id="page-198-15"></span><span id="page-198-12"></span><span id="page-198-8"></span><span id="page-198-2"></span><span id="page-198-1"></span>12:26–27 Our preacher draws one more contrast between God's ancient speech at Sinai and his speech in times to come. At Sinai, God's voice "shook the earth." "The whole mountain trembled greatly" at the arrival of its Creator (Ex. 19:18; cf. Judg. 5:4–5; Ps. 68:7–8). That trauma to the earth foreshadowed a coming day when God would speak "once more" and his voice would "shake not only the earth but also the heavens." The words of this promise come from Haggai 2:6 (also Hag. 2:21). Jews who had returned from the exile needed encouragement to rebuild God's temple, so the Lord promised to shake "the heavens and the earth and the sea and the dry land."

<span id="page-198-6"></span><span id="page-198-5"></span><span id="page-198-4"></span><span id="page-198-3"></span>In its immediate context this promise meant that he would compel the nations to contribute their wealth to his sanctuary (Hag. 2:7–9). Yet Haggai's imagery transcended its immediate application, as he was evoking imagery used previously by Isaiah to portray the coming day when the Lord's vengeance would bring destruction not only to the earth's inhabitants but also to the heaven and its starry host (Isa. 13:13; 34:1–5). Isaiah also prophesied that the present cosmos would be replaced by a new heavens and earth (Isa. 65:17; 66:22). NT authors develop this

<span id="page-199-13"></span><span id="page-199-2"></span>motif (2 Pet. 3:10–13; Rev. 21:1–4). Psalm 102:25–27, cited in Hebrews 1:10–12, predicted that the earth and heavens would wear out and perish, whereas the divine Son who created them remains eternally, unchangeably "the same" (cf. Heb. 13:8). Since the eschatological cosmic "shaking" will remove "things that have been made," we might have thought that only the Creator himself would remain in its aftermath. Yet our preacher hastens to assure us that God has a kingdom that cannot be shaken, and this unshakable kingdom is his gift to those who believe.

<span id="page-199-11"></span><span id="page-199-3"></span><span id="page-199-1"></span>12:28–29 The kingdom of God was the dominant theme of Jesus' preaching, yet so far Hebrews has mentioned it just once (1:8–9, citing Ps. 45:6–7). Our attention has been so focused on Jesus' priesthood that our preacher's conclusion may now take us by surprise: God has a kingdom that is so unshakable that it will survive when all else dissolves. In King Nebuchadnezzar's troubling dream, a great stone shattered a statue representing human empires. That stone symbolized a kingdom that the God of heaven would erect, one that "shall never be destroyed, nor shall the kingdom be left to another people. It shall . . . stand forever" (Dan. 2:44; cf. 7:13–14, 18). Even more surprisingly, God bestows this kingdom as a gift we are "receiving." Believers in Jesus are the heirs of salvation (Heb. 1:14) to whom God will subject the world to come (2:5); they are the "many sons" whom he is bringing to glory (2:10), whom the Son calls his brothers (2:11–12). Jesus assured his followers, weak though they were, that his Father was pleased to give them the kingdom (Matt. 25:34; Luke 12:32; 22:28–30).

<span id="page-199-10"></span><span id="page-199-8"></span><span id="page-199-7"></span><span id="page-199-6"></span><span id="page-199-5"></span><span id="page-199-4"></span>Our response to so gracious a gift must be worship offered in gratitude, reverence, and awe (Heb. 12:28). God the judge of all, for the sake of Jesus the new covenant mediator, has welcomed believers to draw near and worship in his Most Holy Place. Thanksgiving for such privilege must motivate worship that God finds "acceptable," or pleasing (*euarestōs*). What pleases God in worship is *faith*: "Whoever would draw near to God must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who seek him" (Heb. 11:4–6; cf. 10:37–38; 13:15–16). Our grateful joy must be blended with reverence and awe because "our God is a consuming fire" (12:29; cf. Deut. 4:24). He is "our God," committed to us in covenant, and for that reason he jealously demands our complete trust and allegiance.

#### <span id="page-199-12"></span><span id="page-199-9"></span><span id="page-199-0"></span>*Response*

This section teaches us much about the worship our churches offer to God each Lord's Day. It calls us to look through what is "touchable," accessible to our five senses, and to stand amazed that—through faith—in our songs, prayers, sermons, and sacraments we are participants in the liturgy of heaven itself, joining our hearts with those of countless angels and the cloud of witnesses who have run faith's race before us. This text assures us that Jesus' sprinkled blood has silenced Sinai's terrors and ushered us into his Father's favor. Because the ascended Christ addresses us from heaven as his Word is read and preached, our ears must be attuned to his voice and our hearts responsive to his warning, correction, and <span id="page-200-5"></span>exhortation. Our secret motives and spoken words must blend gratitude (which keeps seriousness from drifting into dry duty) with reverent awe (which keeps joy from degenerating into flippancy).

### OVERVIEW OF HEBREWS 13:1–25

<span id="page-200-6"></span><span id="page-200-0"></span>The genre of Hebrews now shifts from homiletical to epistolary. Up to this point the "word of exhortation" (13:22) has been structured as a sermon expounding a series of OT passages in order to show Jesus as superior to the offices and institutions of the old covenant. The biblical expositions have led to exhortations that show hearers how they should respond to God's grace in Christ. Now Hebrews concludes with features typical of Hellenistic epistles: brief ethical directives, instructions about relationships, a request for prayer, benedictions, travel plans, and personal greetings. These epistolary components, though conventional, are not merely perfunctory. Rather, the preacher incorporates major themes from the sermonic material of chapters 1–12. Specifically, Hebrews 13:9–16 revisits and applies the contrast between OT worship and Jesus' priestly ministry (8:1–10:35), the reproach of Christ (10:32–33; 11:13, 35–38), the heavenly city (11:10, 16; 12:22–24), and "acceptable worship" (12:28).

## <span id="page-200-4"></span><span id="page-200-3"></span><span id="page-200-2"></span><span id="page-200-1"></span>HEBREWS 13:1–8

13 Let brotherly love continue. **2**Do not neglect to show hospitality to strangers, for thereby some have entertained angels unawares. **<sup>3</sup>**Remember those who are in prison, as though in prison with them, and those who are mistreated, since you also are in the body. **4**Let marriage be held in honor among all, and let the marriage bed be undefiled, for God will judge the sexually immoral and adulterous. **5**Keep your life free from love of money, and be content with what you have, for he has said, "I will never leave you nor forsake you." **<sup>6</sup>** So we can confidently say,

"The Lord is my helper; I will not fear; what can man do to me?"

**<sup>7</sup>**Remember your leaders, those who spoke to you the word of God. Consider the outcome of their way of life, and imitate their faith. **<sup>8</sup>** Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever.

#### *Section Overview: Love, Purity, and Trust in Jesus Christ's Constant Presence*

<span id="page-201-3"></span>The epistolary closing begins with a series of terse ethical directives. These commands address three spheres: relationships with other believers, especially sufferers (Heb. 13:1–3); the meeting of physical needs (sexual and financial) in submission to and trust in God (vv. 4–6); and leadership transitions in the congregation (vv. 7–8). The brevity of the commands is more evident in Greek (many are only three or four words) than in English: "Let brotherly love continue" translates a Greek noun (with article) and a verb; "Do not neglect to show hospitality to strangers" reflects a noun (with article), a negative particle, and a verb; and "Let marriage be held in honor" reflects an adjective and noun (with article). Most of these commands are supported by rationales for obeying. For example, hospitality should be extended to strangers because "thereby some have entertained angels unawares" (v. 2); marriage should be honored because God will punish adulterers (v. 4); we should not crave money because God will never forsake us (vv. 5–6).

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-201-2"></span>I. Show love to brothers and sisters, hospitality to strangers, and compassion to prisoners (13:1–3)
	- A. Let brother-love continue (13:1)
	- B. Do not neglect stranger-love (13:2)
	- C. Remember those imprisoned and publicly abused (13:3)
- <span id="page-201-7"></span><span id="page-201-6"></span><span id="page-201-5"></span><span id="page-201-4"></span>II. Seek satisfaction of physical needs in submission to God the everpresent judge and helper (13:4–6)
	- A. Honor marriage and shun immorality (13:4)
	- B. Find security not in money but in God's promised presence (13:5–6)
- <span id="page-201-9"></span><span id="page-201-8"></span>III. Learn from the example of your past leaders, but rest in the unchanging Christ (13:7–8)
	- A. Remember and imitate human leaders' faith (13:7)
	- B. But rest your hope in Jesus Christ, who is ever "the same" (13:8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-201-1"></span><span id="page-201-0"></span>13:1–3 The first three imperatives summon hearers to costly care for fellow Christians, particularly those in special need: strangers who need lodging, and believers enduring chains or mistreatment for Christ. The first command insists that the practice of brotherly love ( *philadelphia*) must "continue" across the whole congregation (cf. Rom. 12:10; 1 Thess. 4:9; 1 Pet. 1:22; 2 Pet. 1:7). In the past, the hearers have shown love for God's name by serving the saints (Heb. 6:9–10; <span id="page-202-6"></span>cf. 10:32–34). Now they must not let increasing persecution discourage them from continuing to care for one another. Their family solidarity is grounded in their identity as sons of God and brothers and sisters of Christ (2:10–12, 17; 12:5–11), and thus as each other's brothers and sisters as well (3:1, 12; 10:19; 13:22).

<span id="page-202-12"></span><span id="page-202-7"></span>The general command (13:1) is linked to the second (v. 2) by vocabulary and syntax visible in the Greek original. In both, nouns containing the stem *phil*- ("love") open the clause and are followed by verbs:

Brother-love ( *philadelphia*) let continue Stranger-love ( *philoxenia*) do not neglect

<span id="page-202-13"></span>The second command is then linked to the third (v. 3) through synonymous verbs: "do not neglect" (or lit., "do not forget") states negatively what "remember" (*mimnēskesthe*) states positively. Hearers must not merely mentally recall but also tangibly practice hospitality to strangers. Brotherly love must especially continue to brothers and sisters in need: strangers, prisoners, and victims of public mistreatment. These groups must be the recipients of concrete acts of brotherly love because of their obvious lack (of shelter or of human contact or consolation).

<span id="page-202-11"></span><span id="page-202-9"></span>In a situation of looming persecution, the publicly reviled are those from whom others might be tempted to withdraw. The first audience of Hebrews knew from experience what it meant to have one's property plundered (10:34), so they might empathize with the OT faithful who went homeless, seeking shelter in caves (11:38). But with opposition on the rise, to open one's home to strangers posed a risk. Even if they bore letters of introduction, such as that which Demetrius carried to Gaius (3 John 1–3, 12), such letters could be forged (2 Thess. 2:2; 3:17). So some might fear that, by welcoming strangers, they would take in *spies or informants* "unawares." When Saul the persecutor returned from Damascus, claiming to have become a disciple, many in the church at Jerusalem understandably viewed him with suspicion (Acts 9:26).

<span id="page-202-4"></span><span id="page-202-3"></span><span id="page-202-1"></span><span id="page-202-0"></span>Our author counterbalances that fear with another possibility: some believers who extended hospitality to strangers subsequently discovered they had been entertaining the Lord's angels without recognizing who they were (Gen. 18:1–8; 19:1–3). Jesus said that those who extended hospitality to his homeless brothers or visited even the least of his imprisoned siblings were, unbeknownst to them, caring for the King himself (Matt. 25:34–40).

<span id="page-202-10"></span><span id="page-202-8"></span><span id="page-202-5"></span><span id="page-202-2"></span>The command to "remember" not only prisoners as though chained alongside them but also those publicly abused for Jesus' sake is an encouragement to continue what the hearers had done during an earlier wave of persecution (Heb. 10:32–34). After all, "you also are in the body," equally vulnerable to captivity and mistreatment. By going to and being with such victims, despite the stigma, the hearers bear the reproach of Christ (11:24–26) and encourage their suffering siblings. In chains and nearing martyrdom, Paul was similarly refreshed by Onesiphorus, who sought him out and "was not ashamed of my chains" (2 Tim. 1:16–18).

<span id="page-203-7"></span>13:4–6 The next two directives—to honor marriage (v. 4) and eschew the love of money (vv. 5–6)—are linked by parallels in Greek syntax. In each command a predicate adjective opens the clause, followed by the subject (with its article), with the connecting verb (a form of "to be") unstated but implied (see the three-part table 1.7).

<span id="page-203-6"></span>

| TABLE 1.7: Greek Syntactical Parallels Linking Hebrews 13:4 and 13:5–6 |  |
|------------------------------------------------------------------------|--|
|------------------------------------------------------------------------|--|

|        | Predicate Adjective              | Implied Verb | Subject                   |
|--------|----------------------------------|--------------|---------------------------|
| 13:4   | valuable/precious (timios)       | [let-it-be]  | the marriage (ho gamos)   |
| 13:5–6 | not silver-loving (aphilargyros) | [let-it-be]  | the lifestyle (ho tropos) |

In each directive the first clause is amplified by a second that restates the first in other words:

| 13:4   | valuable/precious                  | [let-it-be] | the marriage                            |
|--------|------------------------------------|-------------|-----------------------------------------|
|        | and the bed                        | [let-it-be] | undefiled                               |
| 13:5–6 | not silver-loving<br>being content | [let-it-be] | the lifestyle<br>[with] the possessions |

Finally, each directive is supported by a rationale introduced by "for" (*gar*):

| 13:4   | for (gar) immoral and adulterous people God will judge.                  |  |
|--------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------|--|
| 13:5–6 | for (gar) he has said, "Never you will I leave, nor you will I forsake." |  |

These directives summon Christians to seek satisfaction of their physical needs and desires through submitting to God's will and trusting in God's presence. Sex and money are perennial human issues, and with both the author orients our hearts toward God, who designed our sexual drives to be fulfilled in marriage and who jealously woos our anxious hearts away from an adulterous affair with silver. In doing so, God makes good his promise never to leave us (a promise that silver cannot keep: Prov. 23:4–5; Luke 12:16–21).

<span id="page-203-5"></span><span id="page-203-4"></span><span id="page-203-3"></span><span id="page-203-2"></span><span id="page-203-1"></span><span id="page-203-0"></span>"Held in honor" reflects the adjective *timios* (Acts 5:34), which can often mean "precious" in the sense of having great value, such as "precious stones" (1 Kings 10:2, 10–11; 1 Cor. 3:12). Our author focuses on the priceless gem of sexual intimacy, to be protected by the covenant of exclusive fidelity between a man and a woman. That sexual purity within marriage is his concern is shown in the amplification "Let the marriage bed be undefiled [*amiantos*]" and in the rationale he offers: "God will judge the sexually immoral and adulterous." Because God designed human marriage and its sexual intimacy to illustrate his exclusive covenant love for his people, he will jealously defend its precious purity (Ezekiel 16; Eph. 5:22–33). Sexual union (lit., "the bed") within the covenant of marriage is "undefiled." Jesus likewise is intrinsically "unstained" (*amiantos*; Heb. 7:26), and he has cleansed our consciences.

Having experienced such cleansing at such great cost to our High Priest, we must not cheapen the treasures of sexuality and marriage that he counts so precious. Our author has warned against the bitter root that could "defile" many and against the influence of the "sexually immoral" person like Esau (12:15–16).

<span id="page-204-13"></span><span id="page-204-6"></span><span id="page-204-4"></span><span id="page-204-3"></span>Esau's preference of one meal over God's promised inheritance also exemplifies the person whose life is characterized by "love of money." An insatiable appetite to acquire possessions is a form of idolatry (Eph. 5:5; Col. 3:5), since it relies on created things to provide the satisfaction and security found only in the Creator (Rom. 1:25; cf. Jer. 2:11–13). The Lord Jesus warned against covetousness: "One's life does not consist in the abundance of his possessions" (Luke 12:15). Christian contentment (Phil. 4:11–13; 1 Tim. 6:6–10) springs from confidence that our divine provider and protector will keep his promise to "never leave you nor forsake you." In this statement our preacher blends the wording of God's promises to Jacob (Gen. 28:15) and Joshua (Josh. 1:5; cf. Deut. 31:6–8), as each faced a daunting and uncertain future.

<span id="page-204-7"></span><span id="page-204-2"></span><span id="page-204-1"></span><span id="page-204-0"></span>Since God kept his word to Jacob, Joshua, and a great cloud of OT witnesses, we too can echo the bold announcement the author quotes from Psalm 118:6 (LXX 117:6): "The Lord is my helper [*boēthos*]; I will not fear; what can man do to me?" The ancient psalmist, surrounded by enemies, confidently defeated them "in the name of the Lord" (Ps. 118:10–13). Hebrews has shown the length to which the Lord went to be our "helper," undergoing suffering and temptation in order to "help" (*boētheō*) us in temptation (2:14–18) and to grant us access to the throne of grace, where we find "grace to help [*boētheia*] in time of need" (4:16).

<span id="page-204-16"></span><span id="page-204-14"></span><span id="page-204-10"></span><span id="page-204-9"></span><span id="page-204-8"></span>13:7–8 The Lord will never leave his people, but the same cannot be said of human leaders. Like Levitical priests, they are "prevented by death from continuing in office" (7:23). Therefore, in addition to "remembering" those presently suffering imprisonment and abuse (13:3), the hearers must also "remember" their congregation's original leaders, who no longer serve among them. In the past they "*spoke* to you the word of God," and hearers must now recollect the "outcome of their way of life." That "outcome" (*ekbasis*) was their exit from life on this earth, the completion of their pilgrimage. Whether their deaths were due to natural or accidental causes or to martyrdom, our author does not say. Although the hearers of Hebrews themselves had not yet shed blood (12:4), some of their leaders may have done so. Elsewhere in the NT, congregational leaders are called "elders" or "overseers" (Acts 20:17–35; Phil. 1:1; 1 Tim. 3:1–7; Titus 1:5–9; 1 Pet. 5:1–3). Teaching and spiritual shepherding are the ministries of such elders/overseers. The original leaders of the people reading this letter "spoke . . . the word of God," and their successors were "keeping watch over your souls" (Heb. 13:7, 17). The first generation's integrity and conduct were no doubt exemplary, but our author spotlights their *faith* as that which must be imitated (reinforcing the point of 10:26–12:3).

<span id="page-204-17"></span><span id="page-204-15"></span><span id="page-204-12"></span><span id="page-204-11"></span><span id="page-204-5"></span>The later admonition to "obey your leaders and submit to them" (13:17) may imply that some in the congregation have not transitioned well from the first generation to the present leadership. If any were troubled over the loss of those who once shepherded them, they must realize that their great shepherd is and always will be with them: "Jesus Christ is the same [*ho autos*] yesterday and today and forever." The OT citations showing the Son's divine superiority to angels at the start of this sermon included Psalm 102:25–27, in which the Son is contrasted with the created heavens and earth: "They will perish, but you remain. . . . You are the same [*ho autos*], and your years will have no end" (Heb. 1:10–12).

<span id="page-205-6"></span><span id="page-205-5"></span><span id="page-205-4"></span><span id="page-205-0"></span>The created order's mutability has touched his hearers' experience in the death of their shepherds, but the divine Son, Jesus Christ, remains "the same," unchangeable and eternal. That divine Son has become the incarnate Son, has undergone temptation and suffering and death, and has emerged triumphant "by the power of an indestructible life" (7:16) to become and remain a "priest *forever*, after the order of Melchizedek" (7:17). If the death of trusted human shepherds has contributed to the hearers' weariness and faintheartedness, they must realize that they have a "great shepherd" whom God "brought again from the dead" (13:20). He "always lives to make intercession for them" (7:25) and keeps his word, promising, "I will never leave you nor forsake you," which he expressed in other words to his awestruck disciples after his resurrection: "I am with you always, to the end of the age" (Matt. 28:20).

#### <span id="page-205-7"></span><span id="page-205-1"></span>*Response*

Christian faith has doctrinal content, but it is much more than intellectual agreement with propositions. To live by faith is to allow God's Word about "things not seen" to control our perception of situations, our desires and affections and priorities, and our actions and relationships. The ethical directives concluding this sermon-letter of Hebrews illustrate this. Faith opens our eyes to see homeless strangers bearing Jesus' name not as threats or inconveniences but as opportunities to serve our Lord or his angels; thus faith opens our hearts and homes. Faith shows us the priceless treasure of the marriage covenant as God defines and jealously defends it. Faith enables us to "see through" silver's fleeting glitter, calming our frenetic quest for security in anything other than the helper who will never leave us.

<span id="page-205-3"></span><span id="page-205-2"></span>In the lives and words of frail human leaders, faith catches glimpses and hears echoes of Jesus Christ, the ever-living, never-leaving great shepherd of the sheep. In everyday relationships, decisions, stresses, and trials, "we walk by faith, not by sight" (2 Cor. 5:7). How is this possible? As Paul summarizes, "We look not to the things that are seen but to the things that are unseen. For the things that are seen are transient, but the things that are unseen are eternal" (2 Cor. 4:18).

### <span id="page-206-1"></span>HEBREWS 13:9–16

**<sup>9</sup>**Do not be led away by diverse and strange teachings, for it is good for the heart to be strengthened by grace, not by foods, which have not benefited those devoted to them. **10**We have an altar from which those who serve the tent*<sup>1</sup>* have no right to eat. **11**For the bodies of those animals whose blood is brought into the holy places by the high priest as a sacrifice for sin are burned outside the camp. **<sup>12</sup>** So Jesus also suffered outside the gate in order to sanctify the people through his own blood. **<sup>13</sup>**Therefore let us go to him outside the camp and bear the reproach he endured. **14**For here we have no lasting city, but we seek the city that is to come. **15**Through him then let us continually offer up a sacrifice of praise to God, that is, the fruit of lips that acknowledge his name. **16**Do not neglect to do good and to share what you have, for such sacrifices are pleasing to God.

1Or *tabernacle*

#### *Section Overview: Priestly Privilege for Those Who Share Christ's Reproach*

<span id="page-206-0"></span>By reminding the hearers of their past leaders who taught them God's Word (13:7), our preacher has set the context for a sharp warning against succumbing to "diverse and strange teachings" that depart from the apostolic norm. This warning draws together themes already addressed in the sermon, such as the superiority of Jesus' blood to the sacrifices offered on the Day of Atonement, the contempt Jesus endured and believers must share, the abiding heavenly city, and worship pleasing to God. Striking turns of phrase alert hearers to the radical reversals of expectations that Christ's ministry has produced: Teachings that would lure Hebrew Christians back to the OT sanctuary and sacrifices are now "strange," since they contradict God's preparatory purposes for those institutions. Jesus' suffering "outside the camp," where things rendered unclean by sin were destroyed, has now cleansed his people. To share his reproach "outside" is to gain access to the benefits of a better altar and lasting city. The region of rejection has become the realm where, through Jesus, we offer sacrifices pleasing to God.

#### *Section Outline*

- I. Do not be drawn away from the true means of grace (13:9–10)
	- A. The OT tent and its foods cannot strengthen your hearts (13:9)
	- B. We have access to heart-establishing grace through Jesus' sacrifice (13:10)
- II. Jesus cleansed us by dying as one excluded and unclean, so we must share his reproach (13:11–14)
	- A. As Day of Atonement sacrifices, defiled by Israel's sins, were burned outside the camp, so Jesus died outside the gate to remove our defilement (13:11–12)
	- B. Let us share Jesus' rejection outside the camp, since we seek a lasting city to come (13:13–14)
- III. Through Jesus let us offer worship pleasing to God (13:15–16)
	- A. Let us offer a sacrifice of praise with our lips (13:15)
	- B. Let us offer sacrifices of generous compassion in our actions (13:16)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-207-10"></span><span id="page-207-8"></span><span id="page-207-3"></span><span id="page-207-2"></span>13:9–10 The church is always at risk of being "led away" (or "washed away," as in a river current; cf. Eph. 4:14) by "diverse and strange teachings." During the apostolic age, some denied Christ's incarnation (1 John 4:1–3), while others emphasized ascetic self-denial and mystical visions (Col. 2:8, 16–23). For the Jewish Christians who first received this sermon-letter, such strange teachings concerned "foods" (*brōmasin*) associated with the earthly sanctuary ("tent") and its altar. Some commentators believe that the "foods" in question are those defined as "clean" by the OT kosher dietary laws (Leviticus 11), while others cite sources that link all meals consumed in observant Jewish homes with rites at the sanctuary.

<span id="page-207-9"></span><span id="page-207-6"></span><span id="page-207-1"></span>Both of these associations are possible, but the preacher's argument in verses 10–12 directs our attention specifically to the sacrificial rituals performed at the sanctuary itself. "Foods" have been linked to "gifts and sacrifices" offered in the first tent that "cannot perfect the conscience of the worshiper" (Heb. 9:9–10). Now our author repeats that they "have not benefited those devoted to them." He seems to have in mind the peace offerings that symbolized communion between the Lord and his people, since the meat of the sacrificed animal was shared by the Lord (blood sprinkled, fat and entrails burned), the priests, and the Israelite worshipers themselves (Lev. 3:1–17; 7:11–16). Such a fellowship meal in the OT sanctuary was rich in symbolism, but, since it conformed to "regulations for the body" (Heb. 9:10) that were temporary and external, it is no longer appropriate for new covenant believers.

<span id="page-207-7"></span><span id="page-207-5"></span><span id="page-207-4"></span><span id="page-207-0"></span>The original hearers, Jewish Christians long immersed in the practices of the OT sanctuary, may have been shocked to hear those familiar rites called "diverse and strange." Our preacher calls them "strange" because they treat regulations that God ordained only "until the time of reformation" (9:10) as though they were intended to continue into "the last days." Now that Christ has inaugurated the new covenant and has rendered the first covenant "obsolete" (8:13), to return to old covenant institutions is to contradict God's agenda for redemptive history. Our author used similar shocking language when he implied that losing faith in Jesus and returning to the comforting familiarity of Judaism would be nothing less than "[falling] away from the living God" (3:12).

<span id="page-208-12"></span><span id="page-208-9"></span><span id="page-208-7"></span><span id="page-208-6"></span>What *does* now "strengthen" (or "establish": *bebaioō*; cf. 2:3; 6:19) the heart is God's grace, received through faith in Jesus. By God's grace Jesus tasted death on behalf of every believer (2:9), so that through him we can draw near to God's throne of grace to find grace (4:16). We can anticipate receiving God's grace through Jesus because "we have an altar" to nourish us that is forbidden to the Levitical priests who serve "the tent," the earthly sanctuary (cf. 8:4–5). Our "altar" symbolizes Jesus' sacrifice on the cross "outside the gate" of Jerusalem (13:12). To "eat" from this altar is to benefit from his sacrifice offered once for all "to sanctify the people." We do this not physically but by "[drawing] near with a true heart in full assurance of faith," since Jesus' blood has sprinkled our hearts clean from an evil conscience (10:22).

<span id="page-208-21"></span><span id="page-208-19"></span>Those who do not trust in Christ's atoning sacrifice, whether priests or lay folk, have no right to eat from this altar, no permission to draw spiritual benefit from his death. If the original hearers were to maintain their affiliation with Jesus and his people, they would risk reproach and exclusion from the Jewish community in which they were once welcome (13:13). But that loss is more than counterbalanced by the benefits flowing from Jesus' shed blood on the cross: atonement, forgiveness, cleansing, confident access, and fellowship with the living God.

<span id="page-208-22"></span><span id="page-208-20"></span><span id="page-208-18"></span><span id="page-208-17"></span><span id="page-208-13"></span>13:11–12 The imagery shifts from the perennial peace offerings to the annual Day of Atonement sacrifices, when the high priest entered the Most Holy Place, carrying blood to atone first for his own sins and then for the sins of the people (9:7, 25). This annual rite has been contrasted with the self-sacrifice of Christ, who brought his own blood into the heavenly sanctuary, atoning for sins once for all (9:24–28; 10:10–14). Now our attention is directed to what happened to the carcasses of the animals after their blood was brought into God's presence. Whereas the meat of peace offerings could be consumed by priests and worshipers after the Lord's best portions were consumed on the altar, on the Day of Atonement the whole bull and goat from which atoning blood had been taken were carried outside Israel's camp and completely incinerated. They were destroyed "outside the camp," the realm of what was unclean, unfit to be seen by the Lord, who "walks in the midst of your camp" (Deut. 23:14; cf. also Lev. 13:45–46; Num. 5:1–4). Flagrant violators of God's covenant were also taken outside the camp, to be executed (Lev. 24:10–23; Num. 15:32–36).

<span id="page-208-16"></span><span id="page-208-15"></span><span id="page-208-14"></span><span id="page-208-11"></span><span id="page-208-10"></span><span id="page-208-8"></span><span id="page-208-5"></span><span id="page-208-4"></span><span id="page-208-3"></span><span id="page-208-2"></span><span id="page-208-1"></span><span id="page-208-0"></span>The association of territory "outside the camp" with defilement and banishment from God's holy presence explains the theological significance of the fact that Jesus was crucified "outside the gate" of Jerusalem (cf. John 19:16–17). He endured God's wrath as he bore others' sin in his body on the tree (Matt. 27:46; Rom. 3:24–25; 1 Pet. 2:24). By bearing their guilt and absorbing its penalty, this "holy, innocent, unstained" High Priest (Heb. 7:26) endured sin's curse (2 Cor. 5:21; Gal. 3:13) and thereby "sanctified" his people by his blood. Throughout this sermon, "sanctify" (*hagiazō*; Heb. 2:11; 10:10, 14), "cleanse" (*katharizō*; 9:14, 23), and "perfect" (*teleioō*; 7:19; 9:9; 10:1, 14) have designated the purging from defilement that qualifies worshipers to approach God's holy presence. Jesus' sacrifice sanctifies <span id="page-209-17"></span><span id="page-209-15"></span>his people so that they may respond to divine grace with thankful and reverent worship (12:28), standing in God's presence as priests and offering sacrifices pleasing to him (13:15–16).

<span id="page-209-16"></span><span id="page-209-12"></span><span id="page-209-11"></span><span id="page-209-10"></span><span id="page-209-9"></span>13:13–14 Jesus' crucifixion outside Jerusalem represented not only his forsakenness by God but also his repudiation by the Jewish community, "his own" people (Mark 15:9–15, 29–32; John 1:11; Acts 3:13–15). He prepared his disciples to endure the same rejection he had endured (Luke 6:22; John 16:2), and indeed they were rejected (John 9:22, 33; 12:42; Acts 18:5–7). To follow Jesus is to carry one's cross toward shameful death (Mark 8:34; Heb. 12:2). Now the recipients of this letter must be prepared to share the reproach that Jesus endured, just as Moses did long ago (Heb. 11:24–26). To join Jesus "outside the camp" may demand that one forgo access to the Jerusalem temple, acceptance in local synagogues, and acknowledgment by one's own family (Matt. 10:35–38).

<span id="page-209-14"></span><span id="page-209-8"></span><span id="page-209-0"></span>Yet one OT passage foreshadows the *privilege* now enjoyed by those who go "outside the camp" for Jesus' sake. After Israel's adultery with the golden calf, the Israelites' defilement was so pervasive that Moses had to pitch the tent of meeting "outside the camp" (Ex. 33:7–11). That became the place where people went to meet with God. Because of institutional Judaism's repudiation of the Messiah, the spheres of the holy community and the polluted wasteland have been reversed. Those unwelcome in earthly Jerusalem's temple and expelled from synagogues have become heirs of God's unshakable kingdom and citizens of "the city that is to come." Admittedly, "*here* we [followers of Jesus] have no lasting city." But within a few years, in AD 70, Roman troops would destroy Jerusalem and its temple on Mount Zion. That city, which the psalmists had extolled for its security (Psalms 48; 87), would lie in ruins. When compared to the promise of being welcomed into the coming city that *abides* forever, to be expelled from a community that has turned its back on God's grace in Christ is no great loss.

<span id="page-209-13"></span><span id="page-209-6"></span><span id="page-209-2"></span><span id="page-209-1"></span>13:15–16 As the promise of an unshakable kingdom led to a call to worship acceptably (12:28), so the prospect of life in God's everlasting city calls us to offer sacrifices that please him. Jesus offered himself as the final, complete sacrifice to atone for sins, so no further sin offering is needed (10:14, 18, 26). But believers cleansed by his death now enjoy the priestly privilege of bringing offerings that express their thanksgiving and consecration. The original "sacrifice of praise" was a slain animal (Lev. 7:12–15), but even in the OT the term underwent redefinition in the direction of oral expressions of adoration toward God. Our author alludes to Psalm 50, which states that the Lord seeks loyal hearts, not slain animals (Ps. 50:7–13) and commands us to, "Offer to God a sacrifice of thanksgiving, and perform your vows to the Most High. . . . The one who offers thanksgiving as his sacrifice glorifies me" (Ps. 50:14, 23).

<span id="page-209-7"></span><span id="page-209-5"></span><span id="page-209-4"></span><span id="page-209-3"></span>To make clear that new covenant worship involves no animal bloodshed for any purpose, the author clarifies: "that is, the fruit of lips that acknowledge his name." "Fruit of lips" is another OT echo, this one from Hosea 14:2 LXX, where <span id="page-210-4"></span>the phrase refers to words expressing repentant contrition. Our author adapts the wording to express a confession of allegiance to God. The term represented by "acknowledge" (*homologeō*) is a cognate of "confession" (*homologia*). Our author has identified Jesus as the "apostle and high priest of our confession" (Heb. 3:1) and has called us to hold fast our confession (4:14; 10:23). God is pleased by his people's worship when they keep confessing their faith together.

<span id="page-210-8"></span><span id="page-210-7"></span><span id="page-210-6"></span><span id="page-210-5"></span><span id="page-210-1"></span><span id="page-210-0"></span>The epistolary conclusion opened with an exhortation not to "neglect" ("forget," *epilanthanomai* ) hospitality for strangers (13:2). Now the verb reappears in order to urge hearers not to forget doing good or sharing financially. Their earlier service to the saints (6:10) and compassion for the persecuted (10:33–34) must continue in the present, not merely in hospitality and care for prisoners and other sufferers (13:1–3) but in all types of good deeds and generosity. "Share what you have" captures the financial connotation the term *koinōnia* (sometimes rendered "fellowship") often has in the NT (Acts 2:42–45; Rom. 12:13; 15:26; 2 Cor. 8:4; Gal. 6:6; Phil. 4:15). Such "horizontal," human-to-human forms of service have a "vertical" dimension as well, for God counts them as sacrifices offered to him and pleasing to him. Paul compares a church's contribution toward his own financial support to an offering with a fragrant aroma, a "sacrifice acceptable and pleasing to God" (Phil. 4:18). Our author expands the horizon further, showing that deeds of kindness and sharing offered to any of God's people are offerings in which God himself delights.

#### <span id="page-210-2"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-210-3"></span>In the twenty-first century, no less than in the first, the church is exposed to "diverse and strange teachings" that threaten to loosen our moorings and set us adrift, sweeping us away from the word of God taught by the Lord and those who first heard him (Heb. 2:1–4). Sometimes, as they did for the first hearers of Hebrews, such rip currents take the form of a siren song, luring us to return to some earlier epoch in God's redemptive agenda. Sometimes those who propose "improvements" to the apostolic gospel present themselves as progressives helping the church to keep in step with an ever-moving cultural context. Alternatives to living by faith in Jesus' sacrifice and looking forward to his return may offer the comfort of familiarity or the reassurance of tangible rituals. But in whichever direction the ideological currents around us flow, however fierce the surrounding opposition, we must savor the priestly privilege Jesus won for us at the cost of his own lifeblood, hold fast our confession, and through him offer sacrifices of praise to God—while also caring for others.

### <span id="page-211-1"></span>HEBREWS 13:17–25

**<sup>17</sup>**Obey your leaders and submit to them, for they are keeping watch over your souls, as those who will have to give an account. Let them do this with joy and not with groaning, for that would be of no advantage to you.

**<sup>18</sup>**Pray for us, for we are sure that we have a clear conscience, desiring to act honorably in all things. **<sup>19</sup>** I urge you the more earnestly to do this in order that I may be restored to you the sooner.

**<sup>20</sup>**Now may the God of peace who brought again from the dead our Lord Jesus, the great shepherd of the sheep, by the blood of the eternal covenant, **<sup>21</sup>** equip you with everything good that you may do his will, working in us*<sup>1</sup>* that which is pleasing in his sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.
