#### *Section Overview*

The first four verses have introduced John's authority concerning Jesus. This section moves more specifically into what Jesus has taught and required of his followers. After the opening statement concerning God's holiness, the remainder of this section is shaped by three "If we say" statements, each with a follow-up statement. "If we say" introduces a false claim, and the following verse provides the contrasting truth:

```
 If we say . . . (1:6)
But if we walk . . . (1:7)
If we say . . . (1:8)
If we confess . . . (1:9)
If we say . . . (1:10)
But if anyone does sin . . . (2:1–2)
```
#### <span id="page-423-10"></span><span id="page-423-9"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-423-1"></span>II. The Necessity of Holiness (1:5–2:2)
	- A. God's Utter Holiness (1:5)
	- B. God's People Must Be Holy (1:6–7)
	- C. Holiness Involves Confessing Our Sins (1:8–9)
	- D. We Can Confess because We Have an Advocate (1:10–2:2)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-423-4"></span>1:5 The message John and others heard from Jesus centered on holiness. There is a note of authority here once again. This message came from Jesus himself ("we have heard from him") and is now proclaimed by John to his readers. To disregard John's message, then, is to disregard Christ.

<span id="page-423-2"></span><span id="page-423-0"></span>"Light" and "darkness," as used here, are moral categories. This usage is found elsewhere in Scripture (Job 18:5–6, 18; 30:26; Isa. 5:20; Luke 11:33–36; Acts 26:18), including in John's Gospel (1:5; 3:19; 12:46). To say that "God is light, and in him is no darkness at all" is to say that God is utterly holy.

<span id="page-423-5"></span><span id="page-423-3"></span>1:6 This verse draws an inference from the preceding verse. Since God is utterly holy, one cannot be in fellowship with him and also walk in sin ("darkness"). To claim to do so is to lie. The verb "walk" ( *peripateō*) is commonly used to refer to one's lifestyle (e.g., Rom. 14:15; Eph. 5:2). Thus John is not saying that any individual act of sin puts the lie to a claim to know God, but that a lifestyle characterized by ongoing, unrepented sin proves one is not converted.

This understanding is further affirmed by the opposite of walking in sin: practicing the truth. What is expected of believers is the ongoing practice, the living out, of the truth. The use of "practice" here is similar to our use when we say a doctor "practices medicine"—it is his manner of life.

<span id="page-424-4"></span><span id="page-424-3"></span>1:7 In contrast to the warning of verse 6, walking in holiness ("the light") confirms a profession of knowing God. In this case we have fellowship with believers ("one another") and thus, it is implied, with God (as John said in 1 John 1:3). John once again explicitly roots the call to holiness in the character of God. We should walk in the light because God is in the light (similarly 1 Pet. 1:15–16).

<span id="page-424-2"></span>Walking in the light has two consequences. First, as mentioned, we have fellowship with "one another," i.e., other believers and the apostolic witness. We must not miss how John says that holiness produces fellowship. Legalism and casual acceptance of sin will kill fellowship, but true holiness unites us with fellow believers. The second consequence is that "the blood of Jesus . . . cleanses us from all sin." This does not mean our holy behavior earns us such cleansing. Rather, walking in the light shows that we are among those who have been cleansed.

The "blood of Jesus" refers to his sacrificial death, using terms in keeping with the OT sacrificial system, which underlies the consistent biblical discussion of Jesus' work. John stresses the comprehensiveness of this cleansing, noting that believers are cleansed from "all sin."

<span id="page-424-5"></span>1:8 The previous "If we say" comment (v. 6) was an attempt to claim fellowship with God while remaining in sin. Now, in verse 8, we encountered the claim to have no sin to begin with. But, John says, a claim to sinlessness is simply self-deception. Such self-deceived people do not have the truth in them, which means they are not converted. The possibility of self-deception concerning one's spiritual state is sobering, and the comfort is that the truth, if received, will set us free from such deception.

<span id="page-424-6"></span><span id="page-424-1"></span>1:9 The structure noted above ("If we say," followed by a response) shows that this verse stands in contrast to the preceding one. If, rather than trying to hide or deny our sin, we confess it, we can know cleansing. This is a truth clearly taught in the OT (e.g., Ps. 32:5; Prov. 28:13). The temptation to hide our sins rather than confess them arises from the fear of how the offended person will respond. John assures his readers that God, the one whom ultimately all sin offends, is "faithful and just" (the faithfulness of God is the consistent appeal of Psalm 32).

<span id="page-424-0"></span>We might wonder why the faithfulness and justice of God would lead him to forgive our sins, for justice seems to require his punishing our sins. No doubt the broader truth of God's new covenant with his people established by the work of Christ is in view. Those who repent and believe have been united with God in Christ and have been promised forgiveness of sins and cleansing. Because Christ has taken their punishment and has promised them his righteousness, this forgiveness and cleansing is the just and faithful thing for God to do. We then rest in the covenant promises of God.

<span id="page-425-4"></span><span id="page-425-2"></span>1:10 This verse is in many respects a restatement of verse 8. Various suggestions have been made for postulating a difference between the statements in verse 8 and verse 10. It seems best to take this as a summarizing, general statement. The use of the perfect tense could broaden the statement from verse 8, not merely prohibiting the denial of currently having any particular sin but also rebuking the idea of being in a general state of sinlessness. Regardless, the overall point is clear: no Christian should expect sinless perfection in this life.

If we claim sinless perfection, we make God to be a liar, denying his clear statements of humanity's sinfulness and need of redemption. A claim of sinlessness also reveals that God's word is not in us, because the claim is a denial of God's word ("truth" [v. 8] and "his word" [v. 10] are parallel with one another). This is a striking contrast to verse 9, where, by confessing sin, we found God to be faithful and just. By denying our sin we instead make out God to be a liar, untrue to his word.

<span id="page-425-5"></span><span id="page-425-3"></span>2:1 This verse begins as a parenthetical statement, as John pauses before responding to the "if" clause (v. 10) as he has done each time previously. This shift is marked by his use of a direct personal address, "my little children." This form of address produces an affectionate earnestness. Having just urged his readers to recognize the reality of their sin, John pauses to make clear that confessing our sin is not the same as condoning it. While hiding the reality of our sin is unwise, he is not calling us to the opposite evil of becoming complacent about it. Instead he pauses to state that his very purpose in writing is to help his readers not to sin. This is the third purpose for writing that John has mentioned (cf. 1:3 and 1:4), and these purposes are directly related. John wants his readers to demonstrate the reality of their conversion, demonstrating that they are in fellowship with God and his apostle, which will involve fighting sin. This will then lead to their collective joy.

<span id="page-425-1"></span>Thus John calls for his readers to avoid sin, while also recognizing the reality of sin. The conditional "if anyone does sin" does not suggest it is possible to attain a state of sinlessness this side of heaven. Rather, the Greek construction suggests that the action discussed ("sin") is probable.17 John writes to help his hearers fight sin, but when they do sin, they must turn to Jesus, their advocate with the Father. This develops what John said in verse 9. The new information concerns the specific role of Jesus in obtaining our forgiveness. In 1:9 the covenant faithfulness of the Father was the basis of our confidence in turning to God in confession; here it is the intercessory work of Christ. He is our "advocate."

<span id="page-425-0"></span>The Greek word used here ( *paraklētos*) is the same one John uses for the Holy Spirit in his Gospel (John 14:16; 15:26; 16:7). In John 14:16 Jesus calls the Holy Spirit "another Helper," implying that he, Jesus, is one as well. This word refers to one who is an "intercessor" or "mediator," one who might help with a legal issue or gain access for another to a prominent person. John reminds his readers that Jesus is this "advocate" for us to the Father when we sin. If this letter is any indication, John's preaching had already made clear to his readers that sin separates us from

<sup>17</sup> Cf. Daniel B. Wallace, *Greek Grammar beyond the Basics* (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 1997), 696–698.

<span id="page-426-1"></span>God and incurs his holy wrath. Thus, when we sin, we might be driven to despair. But, John says, while sin is heinous, we have an intercessor to help us deal with this fact and to keep us close to God. This intercessor is further described as "righteous," as the Father was described in 1:9. Because he is righteous, he can be trusted and can stand before the Father even though we, in our lack of righteousness, cannot. How this advocate deals with our sin is treated in the next verse.

<span id="page-426-2"></span>2:2 Jesus can help us with our sin because he is "the propitiation for our sins." The word "propitiation" (*hilasmos*) refers to a sacrifice that turns away wrath.18 The reason Jesus can be our advocate despite our sin is that he has borne, on the cross, the punishment required for the sins of all who believe. Since he took that punishment, meaning that our sins have been judged, he has turned away the wrath we deserve so that we can now be reconciled to God (cf. Romans 3). This "sin-bearer" now stands as our advocate, and so we can turn to him.

<span id="page-426-0"></span>John goes on to say that Jesus dealt with not only "our sins" but also the sins of "the whole world." Some have suggested this means that all people will be saved whether or not they repent of their sins and trust Jesus. However, the burden of this letter is to discern true believers from false ones. John's letter would be pointless if all are redeemed anyway. John has declared various groups of people to be out of fellowship with God, not recipients of the propitiating work of Christ. He is, then, not contradicting himself here. The point, rather, is that Jesus is the one sacrifice available for the world. The message of this salvation is not to be restricted to one group but is to be proclaimed boldly to all people everywhere.

#### *Response*

This is a powerful and important text as we deal with the reality of sin in the life of a Christian. Any discussion of this topic must begin, as John does, with the bedrock truth of God's utter holiness. Without this we will tend to downplay or excuse our sinfulness for various reasons. I have had countless pastoral discussions that ended up with the person saying, in essence, "If you just knew how difficult this is, you would understand that my sin must be excused. God wants me to be happy, and this difficult marriage makes me unhappy, so I must be allowed to walk away." Or, "I am attracted to people of the same sex, and since I am lonely I must be allowed to marry someone of the same sex." The examples abound. We must begin with the absolute holiness of God so that we are reminded that the standards of holiness do not depend on our whims.

John, then, is an example of a wise pastor guiding us through the possible dangers of responding to our sin. We tend, on the one hand, to excuse or hide our sin or, on the other, to be crushed by despair over the reality of our sin—and the enemy of our souls does not care which snare catches us. He deploys both stratagems readily and cunningly. John refutes all claims to sinless perfection this side

<sup>18</sup> For the debate over whether this word should be translated "propitiation" or "expiation," cf. Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 77–79.

of heaven. He pokes a hole in all of our puffed up pretension. For all of us, sin is not merely a past memory but also a present reality. We must face it. But when we face it, we can be overwhelmed. We must face it and then run to Jesus. We must take sin seriously, and we must also take God's forgiveness seriously.

The best way to fight sin is to confess it. It often feels like admitting our sin would lead to taking it lightly ("Oh, it's okay. We all do it") and that it would be better to conceal our sin ("I would never do that"). But this is not the way. We find cleansing by confessing. This faithful cleansing produces gratitude in the forgiven. Since, as Jesus taught, he who is forgiven much loves much (Luke 7:41–47), this confession leads us to greater love for Jesus, and such love is a greater deterrent to sin than fear of exposure is.

<span id="page-427-3"></span><span id="page-427-1"></span><span id="page-427-0"></span>It is also interesting to note how John contrasts things we might say ("If we say . . ." 1 John 1:6, 8, 10) with God's truth. People make all sorts of claims and sometimes will allow no disagreement. But God's Word determines truth despite our claims.

### 1 JOHN 2:3–6

**<sup>3</sup>**And by this we know that we have come to know him, if we keep his commandments. **4**Whoever says "I know him" but does not keep his commandments is a liar, and the truth is not in him, **5**but whoever keeps his word, in him truly the love of God is perfected. By this we may know that we are in him: **6**whoever says he abides in him ought to walk in the same way in which he walked.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-427-4"></span>John continues to discuss the holiness of true believers, now in terms of obedience to Christ's "commands" (using for the first time a key term in this letter). Obedience to God's commands is a clear evidence of conversion. John continues to refute false claims, though the language shifts from "if we say" to "whoever says" (1 John 2:4, 6). The flow of thought is a simple back-and-forth between positive and negative assessments of persons' spiritual condition based on their obedience (vv. 3, 5–6) or disobedience (v. 4). Verses 5b–6 restate a positive assessment as a summary of the section.

#### <span id="page-427-6"></span><span id="page-427-5"></span>*Section Outline*

III. The Necessity of Obedience (2:3–6)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-427-2"></span>2:3 With slightly different language John continues to discuss evidence of true conversion. In the previous section, believers were designated as those in whom <span id="page-428-5"></span>resides "the truth" (1:8) or God's "word" (1:10). Now true believers are described as those who "have come to know him" (the first occurrence of "knowing God" language, which continues throughout the letter). To "know" God is a fairly common biblical term for being in covenant relationship with him (e.g., Jer. 9:24; John 17:3; Titus 1:16).

<span id="page-428-2"></span><span id="page-428-0"></span>In this and subsequent verses John refers to "keeping" God's commands. This Greek verb (*tēreō*) refers to maintaining or guarding and thus, in this context, obeying. Obedience to God's commands is the indicator that those in question have entered a relationship with God. This is a variation on the basic point made in 1:7: knowing God results in obedience to God. It may be a halting, stumbling obedience, but such a relationship always results in a move toward obedience to God's commands.

<span id="page-428-6"></span><span id="page-428-4"></span><span id="page-428-3"></span>2:4 In light of the statement in verse 3, any claim to know God that is not followed by obedience to him is a lie. This is a variation of the truth expressed in 1:6. In 1:10 the person who claimed to have no sin made God a liar, but here the person who claims to know God, but does not in fact obey him, is himself a liar; that is, "the truth is not in him." True faith always produces obedience.

<span id="page-428-8"></span><span id="page-428-7"></span>2:5a The first part of verse 5 continues the sentence from verse 4, stating the inverse truth. As disobedience disproves a claim to know God, so obedience substantiates such a claim. Here God's "word" replaces his "command" as a synonym, and the reality of knowing God is stated as the love of God being perfected in that person. This is the first reference to the love of God, which will later become a key theme.

The "love of God" could be understood in various ways. It seems most likely in this context that John is referring to the love believers have for God. Our love for God comes to its proper completion as it results in obedience to God (which will also result in love for others, as John will say in the following verses). This connection between love for God and obedience is a common theme throughout John's writing (John 14:15, 21, 23; 2 John 6).

<span id="page-428-9"></span><span id="page-428-1"></span>2:5b–6 "By this we may know" restates the phrase that opened this section in verse 3, indicating that John is concluding this subsection and summarizing the emphasis on obedience as proof of conversion. If anyone truly abides in Christ, he will live as Christ lived. This is a descriptive way of saying that true believers will obey Christ, for this is what it means to be a disciple: to follow the ways, imitate the behavior, and adhere to the teachings of a specific master. Thus a claim to be a disciple of Christ while not seeking to follow his ways is patently false.

#### *Response*

Obedience is nonnegotiable in the Christian life. The reality of salvation by grace alone does not negate the necessity of obedience, as John (and Paul) makes abundantly clear. The order is what is crucial. John does not say, "Obey in order to be forgiven." Rather, he says repeatedly that anyone who is truly in Christ will obey <span id="page-429-2"></span>him. John's concern is for his readers to recognize the telltale signs of one who knows God. If someone shows no concern to submit to God's commands, even indeed especially—when these commands cut across our cultural ideas or our comfort, we must question the spiritual state of that person.

### 1 JOHN 2:7–11

**7**Beloved, I am writing you no new commandment, but an old commandment that you had from the beginning. The old commandment is the word that you have heard. **8**At the same time, it is a new commandment that I am writing to you, which is true in him and in you, because*<sup>1</sup>* the darkness is passing away and the true light is already shining. **<sup>9</sup>**Whoever says he is in the light and hates his brother is still in darkness. **<sup>10</sup>**Whoever loves his brother abides in the light, and in him*<sup>2</sup>* there is no cause for stumbling. **11**But whoever hates his brother is in the darkness and walks in the darkness, and does not know where he is going, because the darkness has blinded his eyes.

1Or *that* 2Or *it*

#### *Section Overview*

John continues the theme of obedience, shifting to the command to love one another. One key way Christians obey God is by loving one another. A lack of love for fellow believers is evidence that one does not know God.

#### *Section Outline*

- IV. The Necessity of Loving Fellow Christians (2:7–11)
	- A. The Old Yet New Command (2:7–8)
	- B. Love and Light, Hate and Darkness (2:9–11)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-429-1"></span><span id="page-429-0"></span>2:7 John addresses his readers as "beloved" for the first time, and will do so regularly throughout the rest of the letter. This is no mere convention. Having just mentioned the love of God being perfected in them (2:5), and preparing to call them to love one another, John uses a term of endearment for them that refers to the fact that they are loved by John and by God.

The "commandment" discussed here and in the following verses is the command to love one another. John says this is nothing new to them but is something they "had from the beginning" and "have heard." Undoubtedly this refers to the fact that from the beginning of their Christian life, from the earliest times they

<span id="page-430-2"></span>heard the gospel proclaimed, they had been taught that Christians are to love one another—quite possibly as they heard John relate the words of Jesus that the apostle recorded in John 13:34–35. "Beginning" could also refer to the beginning of Scripture, as this command is also recorded in the earliest revelation, the Pentateuch (e.g., Lev. 19:18).

<span id="page-430-5"></span><span id="page-430-0"></span>2:8 In another sense, this "commandment" is now "new" in light of Christ's resurrection and ascension. The "darkness . . . passing away" and the "true light . . . already shining" refers to the breaking in of the kingdom of God. The darkness is not completely gone, but now because of Christ's decisive victory the new era has begun. Thus this commandment is more than what could have been stated by Moses or even understood by the hearers of Jesus previously. In light of Christ's ultimate fulfillment of this command with his self-sacrifice at the cross and his resulting powerful presence before the Father (John 16:10, 28) and his mediatorial role (1 John 2:1), this command has new power and possibility of fulfillment among his people.

<span id="page-430-6"></span><span id="page-430-4"></span><span id="page-430-3"></span>2:9 John continues with the light/darkness theme reintroduced in the previous verse, noting ethical implications in another "whoever says" statement. Anyone who claims to partake in this in-breaking kingdom of God ("the light") but "hates his brother" does not know what he is talking about. Hatred of a fellow believer ("brother") has no place in this kingdom of light, so such hatred is another refutation of a claim to know God.

<span id="page-430-7"></span>2:10 The one who obeys this renewed love command is "in the light," participating in the in-breaking kingdom of God. He partakes of the benefits of Christ's victory. As a result, there is in such a one "no cause for stumbling" (Gk. *skandalon*, which in the NT almost always refers to that which causes another person to stumble). Thus, when we love other believers, we "promote rather than deter the kingdom progress of others."19

<span id="page-430-8"></span>2:11 John returns to the condition of the one who hates another believer, repeating that such a person is in darkness (outside of God's kingdom; cf. v. 9). John adds that such a hater "walks in the darkness," stressing his ongoing life outside of God's ways, with the result that such a person is lost and aimless ("does not know where he is going"). Furthermore, the one who hates his brother is "blinded." Sin blinds us to theological and ethical truth, putting us in a condition where we cannot see the truth even when it stands before our very eyes. Jesus rebuked such blindness among religious leaders (John 9:35–41), and Paul describes it as well (2 Cor. 4:4).

### <span id="page-430-1"></span>*Response*

Love for fellow believers is a nonnegotiable part of the Christian faith. If someone professes faith but does not love his fellow believers, such a person has not been truly converted. Love may be stronger or weaker, more or less consistent, but if conversion has occurred, it will be present. At this point in redemptive history, as Christ has accomplished his work on the cross, has poured his Spirit upon us, and continues to make intercession for us, a lack of love among believers is particularly inexcusable. If anyone seeks to justify hatred toward other believers, it is clear that such a one is blinded, unable to see the clear truth of this text.

Since darkness does indeed blind people, we must remember that mere rational explanation will not be adequate to bring others to Christ; the work of the Holy Spirit is necessary. Our duty is to speak the gospel, but only God can open blind eyes.

<span id="page-431-0"></span>John's use of "beloved" is instructive. Although "dearly beloved" has for many become an overused, archaic-sounding convention, we must not lose the pastoral import of addressing the people of God in ways that regularly affirm our love and God's love for them. Pastors, particularly, can learn from John's example by addressing their people in ways that make clear their affection for them, even when challenging or rebuking them.

### 1 JOHN 2:12–14

- **<sup>12</sup>** I am writing to you, little children, because your sins are forgiven for his name's sake.
- **<sup>13</sup>** I am writing to you, fathers, because you know him who is from the beginning. I am writing to you, young men, because you have overcome the evil one. I write to you, children,
- because you know the Father.
- **<sup>14</sup>** I write to you, fathers, because you know him who is from the beginning.
- I write to you, young men, because you are strong, and the word of God abides in you, and you have overcome the evil one.

#### *Section Overview*

This passage presents a tangled web of difficulties for explaining exactly who and what is in view. What is the difference between "I am writing" (present tense verb, three times) and "I write" (aorist tense verb, three times)? Who are the "children," "fathers," and "young men"—are these three separate groups, or do they overlap

in some way? And what is the point of the message to each group? It may help to place the parallel portions side-by-side, as in table 5.1. Identical language is in bold.

<span id="page-432-5"></span>

| (12) I am writing to you, little children<br>[Gk. teknia],<br>because your sins are forgiven for his<br>name's sake. | (13, continued) I write to you, children [Gk. paidia],<br>because you know the Father.                                             |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| (13) I am writing to you, fathers,<br>because you know him who is from the<br>beginning                              | (14) I write to you, fathers,<br>because you know him who is from the<br>beginning.                                                |
| I am writing to you, young men,<br>because you have overcome the evil one.                                           | I write to you, young men,<br>because you are strong, and the word of God<br>abides in you, and you have overcome the evil<br>one. |

TABLE 5.1: The Parallel Portions of 1 John 2:12–14

<span id="page-432-2"></span><span id="page-432-1"></span>The comments to each group concern gospel benefits mentioned elsewhere in the letter: forgiveness of sins (1:9), knowing God (2:3), overcoming the Evil One (4:4 [addressed specifically to *teknia*]; 5:4–5), the word of God abiding (1:8, 10; 2:24). The only one missing from the rest of the letter in explicit terms is the comment to the young men about being strong.

<span id="page-432-0"></span>The repetition of "I am writing" and "I write" is rhetorical, functioning as a call to renewed focus. John has already mentioned reasons for his writing (1:4; 2:1), but having gotten well into his message addressing holiness and love for fellow believers, John pauses to ensure that he has their attention. It is as if John, as a good preacher, pauses at a key moment and says, "Listen to me!"

<span id="page-432-4"></span><span id="page-432-3"></span>Given the parallelism, it is unlikely that any distinction is intended between "little children" (v. 12, *teknia*) and "children" (v. 13, *paidia*). *Teknia* occurs only in John's writings in the NT and always seems to serve as a term of endearment it is an emotionally evocative term, demonstrating love and fatherly concern.20 Furthermore, since throughout this letter John refers to his audience as a whole with both of these terms (*teknia*, 2:12, 28; 3:18; 4:4; 5:21; *paidia*, 2:18; 3:7), it is unlikely that in these verses he uses the terms to refer to simply one part of his audience. Therefore, by "children" or "little children" John refers to the whole church.

<span id="page-432-7"></span><span id="page-432-6"></span>John then refers to the believers in two categories using encouraging terms. "Father" was a term of respect in the ancient world that evoked the responsibility to care for, lead, and be an example for others. Thus John is appealing here to those with some level of maturity within the church. Those who do not yet have the maturity (younger in age or in the faith) are addressed as "young men" (*neaniskoi* ), a term often connected with a stage of particular strength, vitality, and potential. In the LXX this word is used for the men who went into Jericho

<sup>20</sup> Cf. ibid., 116, for further evidence for this point.

<span id="page-433-1"></span><span id="page-433-0"></span>as spies (Josh. 6:23) and for Daniel and his three friends, who remained faithful to God in exile (Dan. 1:17). Thus John refers to this group in terms of their potential and promise.

<span id="page-433-9"></span>As mentioned above, each of the "because" clauses refers to gospel benefits mentioned elsewhere in the letter. John is saying, in essence, "I am writing to you because you believe the gospel and have held fast to it in spite of the false teachers who have left the church" (cf. 2:19). At this point in the letter he pauses to remind them of powerful gospel benefits in order to encourage them in their continued perseverance.

#### *Section Outline*

V. Gospel Encouragements (2:12–14)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-433-6"></span><span id="page-433-5"></span><span id="page-433-4"></span>2:12 John opens this rhetorical section by reminding his hearers that their sins have been forgiven. Effectively restating the point of 1:9 and 2:1 shows the importance of this point to the argument of the letter. John seeks the joy of his hearers (1:4) by giving them a solid basis for recognizing true faith (in distinction from the false teachers) and by reminding them that because they hold fast to the gospel, they can be assured that their sins are forgiven. "For his name's sake" makes explicit that forgiveness comes because of Christ and his work.

<span id="page-433-7"></span><span id="page-433-2"></span>2:13 The more mature among the congregation are reminded that they know God, the one "who is from the beginning," the same one John has seen with his own eyes (1:1). By holding fast to the message John preached, they have continued in knowledge of the true God whom John preached.

The younger in the faith are reminded that they have conquered the Devil, a truth John will further expound later in the letter. Presumably one key way they have overcome this enemy is by withstanding the wooing of the false teachers.

<span id="page-433-10"></span><span id="page-433-3"></span>The entire congregation is reminded that they all "know the Father," that is, they have fellowship with him (1:3). As John will say later, they have remained in the Father by resisting the teaching of those who denied the Father (2:22–24).

<span id="page-433-11"></span><span id="page-433-8"></span>2:14 The statement to the more mature is repeated from 2:13, providing emphasis. John adds two points to his comments to the younger ones among the congregation. Because the Word of God abides in them (cf. 2:24), they are strong and have thus overcome the Evil One. This group may not have the maturity of the "fathers," but because the Word of God abides in them they can be confident that the strength of God is at work in them.

#### *Response*

John provides a valuable pastoral example in this section. He has not dodged the challenging truths that needed to be stated in the previous sections. He has been <span id="page-434-3"></span>bold and direct. But he is not shrill, and he does not stay in confrontation mode. Here he pauses to encourage his people with the reality of gospel promises. These truths—and not browbeating—are what will inspire them to persevere and to pursue holiness.

### 1 JOHN 2:15–17

**<sup>15</sup>**Do not love the world or the things in the world. If anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him. **16**For all that is in the world the desires of the flesh and the desires of the eyes and pride of life*<sup>1</sup>*—is not from the Father but is from the world. **17**And the world is passing away along with its desires, but whoever does the will of God abides forever.

1Or *pride in possessions*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-434-1"></span>Verses 7–11 of 1 John 2 discussed who must be loved: fellow believers. After the dramatic pause and refocusing of attention (2:12–14), John now highlights what must *not* be loved: the world. If anyone does not love believers, he is in darkness and is blinded. If anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him.

#### *Section Outline*

- VI. The Snare of Loving the World (2:15–17)
	- A. Do Not Love the World (2:15)
	- B. Reasons Not to Love the World (2:16–17)
		- 1. The World Is Not of God (2:16)
		- 2. The World Is Passing Away (2:17)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-434-6"></span><span id="page-434-5"></span><span id="page-434-4"></span><span id="page-434-2"></span><span id="page-434-0"></span>2:15 This first imperative of the letter can be misunderstood if we fail to identify the "world" properly. "Things in the world" does not refer to creation; this is not a dualist call to be concerned only with spiritual rather than physical things. John can use "world" (*kosmos*) more positively, such as in God's love for the world (John 3:16), Jesus as the propitiation for the sins of the world (1 John 2:2), or Jesus as the Savior of the world (1 John 4:14). In these instances mankind, the inhabitants of the world, is in view. They are opposed to God, but God still loves humanity and comes to redeem it. Quite often, however, the "world" is the realm, even the system, of rebellion against God (4:4–5). It does not know God or believers (3:1) and indeed hates believers (3:13). It is the realm of false prophets and the antichrist (4:1, 3),

<span id="page-435-7"></span><span id="page-435-5"></span>for "the whole world lies in the power of the evil one" (5:19). Into this realm of hostility Jesus came (4:17) in order to be the Savior, to redeem people out of this realm, allowing us to overcome the world (5:4–5).21

<span id="page-435-6"></span>Thus John is not forbidding appreciation of creation or love for people. Rather he is warning against setting one's affections on sin or behaviors inimical to God and his character. John "counsels strategic disavowals of loyalties to features of the world that would surely compromise the total devotion that is appropriate to God alone."22

This point is made even clearer in the second half of the verse, which contrasts love of the world with love of the Father. John directs his readers toward the proper object of their affections by holding up contrasting objects. One cannot love the world and love the Father at the same time, for the world is at odds with the Father. One must choose. One must take a side. And because of who God is, proper love for him can brook no rivals. True love for God must place him supreme in one's affections.

<span id="page-435-4"></span><span id="page-435-3"></span>2:16 The problem with "the things in the world" mentioned in 2:15 is, first of all, that they are not "from the Father," that is, they are not rooted in him. They arise instead from that which is in opposition to God. "John is thinking of things that can be regarded as detrimental because they lack sanctifying ties with the Father."23 Obviously, people who love God ought not be attracted to things that arise from opposition to God and thus to them. John is saying, in part, "Do not love the sin that seeks to destroy you."

The rivals in view here are heart dispositions. "Desire" (*epithymia*) is not always negative, but here it clearly is.24 "Desires of the flesh" refers to those desires that arise from fallen humanity apart from the influence of God's sanctifying work, including a broad range of sinful desires such as lust, gluttony, and the pursuit of various other addictions.

<span id="page-435-1"></span>The second element of things of the world, "the desires of the eyes," is not an entirely separate category but can be seen as another aspect of the desires of the flesh. Our eyes are, of course, wonderful gifts, but once again John has in view the sinful use of these gifts. Jesus spoke of the eyes as the "lamp of the body," with potential either for good or for causing the "whole body" to be "full of darkness" (Matt. 6:22–23). In the first sin, Eve was taken in as she noticed that the forbidden fruit was a "delight to the eyes" (Gen. 3:6). Thus "desires of the eyes" refers to being captivated via sight by desire for forbidden things. C. H. Dodd suggests this refers to "the tendency to be captivated by the outward show of things, without enquiring into their real values."25 This would then refer to the tendency to chase what "looks good" without concern for whether or not it is pleasing to God.

<span id="page-435-0"></span><sup>21</sup> Cf. further the chapter on "The World," in Paul Rainbow, *Johannine Theology* (Downers Grove, IL: IVP Academic, 2014), 115–145.

<sup>22</sup> Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 128.

<sup>23</sup> Ibid., 131.

<span id="page-435-2"></span><sup>24</sup> Peter also contrasts wrong human desires (*epithymia*) with God's will, that which God desires (*thelēma*) (1 Pet. 4:2).

<sup>25</sup> Dodd, *Johannine Epistles*, 41. Cf. also Daniel Akin *1, 2, 3 John*, NAC (Nashville: Broadman & Holman, 2001), 110.

<span id="page-436-0"></span>The last item in the list is the "pride of life." This phrase is vaguer than the others. The word for "pride" (*alazoneia*) typically refers to arrogant boasting, while the word for "life" (*bios*) often refers to material goods, or that which one has to live on (e.g., Luke 15:12, 30; 21:4), which is precisely the meaning of the word when it occurs later in this letter, in 1 John 3:17. Thus what is in view here is not pride generally but the vaunted sense of self-importance derived from one's possessions, position, or prestige.

<span id="page-436-3"></span>These three things "in the world" characterize what is at work in the world system in opposition to God. They are not passive, but aggressively seek to allure the affections of everyone including Christians. Thus, John warns his hearers not to love these things.

<span id="page-436-2"></span>2:17 Not only are the "world" and its "things" opposed to God, but they are also "passing away." They will not endure and thus are not suitable objects for our affections. Nor do they provide a stable basis for life. In contrast, those who do the will of God "[abide] forever." John's point is exhortatory: we ought not set our hearts on these sinful desires that will fade and fall away, for they will finally disappoint. Obedience to God, however, will lead to lasting joy. If, then, we love life and long for fulfillment, we must resist the allure of sinful desires and obey God instead.

#### *Response*

Contrary to much of popular culture, John realizes that love, in and of itself, is not the answer. It matters what we love. Some love is sinful. We must love God, his Word, and his people, but we must not love selfishness and sin.

<span id="page-436-1"></span>Some have wreaked havoc with 2:15, seeing there a pleasure-hating asceticism or a curmudgeonly skepticism toward beauty, enjoyment, or people. None of this is called for here. It is clear that there is a common way of life that is opposed to the things of God, a way that seems to help one get ahead but is actually opposed to God. This is what John is telling us not to love. He is not telling us to hate God's creation or the good gifts he has given to us as part of that creation.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer ministered in the shadow of the Nazi machine, where friendship with the world captivated many believers, as it seemed to promise safety. He captured the essence of our text when he wrote,

In obedience and faith alone the church took up the struggle ordained for her. From the Word alone she may be led. For her Lord she gladly gave up all cares, all security, all friendship with the world. Yes, our way leads also through distress, but the Lord bound us not to yield. Do we want to yield today for the sake of friendship with the world, do we want to sell our calling for the mess of pottage of a safe future? Through our own behavior we are making the Gospel of our church unworthy of belief!26

<sup>26</sup> Bonhoeffer, quoted in Rudolf Wentorf, *Paul Schneider: The Witness of Buchenwald*, trans. Franklin Sanders (Las Vegas: Geodesics, 1986), 68.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-437-2"></span><span id="page-437-0"></span>The vocative ("Children") signals the opening of a new section. This new section addresses "antichrist" (2:18 [2x], 22), those who are "trying to deceive" John's audience (2:26). We now discover the cause for this letter—a group has left the church and instead has followed a new, distorted teaching concerning the identity of Jesus. This schism has raised questions concerning how we may know if someone is truly a believer. Having addressed some of the attendant issues (holiness, and love of fellow believers), John now focuses on the doctrinal issue at the center of the trouble.

#### *Section Outline*

- VII. The Necessity of Discernment (2:18–27)
	- A. The Reality of Antichrist (2:18)
	- B. Apostasy (2:19)
	- C. Affirmation of the Faithful (2:20–21)
	- D. Antichrist Denies the Son (2:22–23)
	- E. Call to Abide (2:24–27)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-438-4"></span><span id="page-438-2"></span>2:18 The use of "children" once again highlights the familial setting and paternal affection of John, as he turns to address more directly the painful circumstance that has occasioned this letter. With his typical manner of interweaving repetition, John states that the appearance of "many antichrists" proves that the "last hour" has come. John's reference to "antichrist" is the earliest preserved use of this term in Christian writing. Paul refers to a later-day figure who opposes God and his people ("the man of lawlessness"; 2 Thess. 2:3), and John may refer to the same figure here. John's audience has already been taught that such a one will appear. The concern at the moment, however, is that many opponents of Christ—those who by teaching wrongly about the person of Christ are therefore anti-Christ—are currently on the scene. John's concern is pastoral and present, not merely predictive.

<span id="page-438-3"></span><span id="page-438-1"></span>Warnings that false teachers would come is standard apostolic teaching (Paul: Acts 20:29–30; Peter: 2 Pet. 2:1–3), especially with regard to these teachers' arrival in the "last days" (2 Tim. 3:1; 2 Pet. 3:3). However, readers often misunderstand these references to the "last days" or "last hour." In NT terms the world entered the "last days" or "last hour" after the resurrection and ascension of Christ (Acts 2:17; Heb. 1:2; cf. also 1 Cor. 10:11; Heb. 9:26; 1 Pet. 4:7). John's point is that his readers knew these false teachers were coming. This is nothing surprising, even if the impact (some of their number turning away) has shaken them.

<span id="page-438-5"></span><span id="page-438-0"></span>2:19 Some who were members of this fellowship (whether false teachers or those influenced by them) "went out from us." In order to follow the new, aberrant teaching, these people abandoned the Christian community, which held fast to the apostolic teaching. In a theologically loaded and pastorally crucial comment, John says that the abandoning of the church by these individuals proves that they were never truly a part of it. That is, while they had joined the congregation and engaged with it, they were never truly converted. In traditional theological terms, they joined the "visible church" but were never part of the "invisible church."

How does John know this? Because if they had truly been "of us," truly converted, they would have "continued with us." True converts persevere in the faith and remain in vital connection with the faithful church. The departure of these people, John says, makes clear that they were never truly converted.

<span id="page-438-6"></span>2:20 Having stated the awful truth that these individuals—known and no doubt loved by those hearing this letter—are outside the faith and thus under the wrath of God, John then reassures the faithful. He encourages them by stating that they "have been anointed" and have "knowledge." Anointing in the OT was a mark of being chosen by God and set apart for a task. Here John means ultimately that they have been converted, that God has marked them off for himself. More directly, it may refer to the apostolic teaching they have received or to the Holy Spirit's regenerating them prior to conversion. Such apostolic teaching has been in view throughout this letter, and it is this teaching that gives them "knowledge." While

<span id="page-439-3"></span><span id="page-439-0"></span>the Holy Spirit has not been explicitly mentioned, he is often associated with anointing (1 Sam. 16:13; Isa. 61:1; Acts 10:38)27 and in John's Gospel is specifically the one who will lead believers into all truth (John 16:13). As Calvin said, "Men are not rightly made wise by the acumen of their own minds, but by the illumination of the Spirit."28 In any case, Spirit and truth are joined closely throughout Scripture.

This anointing comes from "the Holy One," meaning God (whether specifically Father or Son is not made explicit). The use of this phrase connects to John's earlier teaching regarding holiness. In contrast to those who have turned away and abandoned holiness, the faithful are marked by the Holy One "in such a way that the departure of some need not demoralize those who are still standing fast."29

Because of this anointing, believers "all"—every one of us—"have knowledge." In contrast to those who have turned away, true believers know the truth, the apostolic teaching, the gospel.

<span id="page-439-5"></span>2:21 John is encouraging his hearers who have been shaken by the apostasy of those they had considered brothers. So he tells them he is not writing because they failed to know or remember the truth. Rather, he is writing because they *have* faithfully maintained the truth amid difficulty. This truth, which they know and have held to, has no place for lies.

<span id="page-439-6"></span>2:22 John expounds the "lie" he had in mind in verse 21: it is the claim that Jesus is not the Christ. John goes on to describe this denial as a denial of the Son, and thus of the Father. John thus connects the messiahship of Jesus with his status as divine Son of God. The true identity of Jesus is a central part of the truth believers know, and to deny this truth is to lie. To assert this lie is to be "antichrist," since to do so is a denial of Christ. As Yarbrough aptly states, this is the anticonfession of the antichrist.30 Contrary to postmodern sensibilities, John asserts that this religious idea is no mere personal opinion. It is true for all people at all times.

<span id="page-439-7"></span>2:23 If one does not accept the Son, then, despite claims otherwise, he does not know the Father, since the Father and the Son are one. Positively, then, if one confesses the Son, he will have the Father also. There is no way to know Yahweh apart from Jesus.

<span id="page-439-8"></span><span id="page-439-4"></span>2:24 In light of the seriousness of what is at stake, John urges his readers to remain in the apostolic teaching they have heard rather than moving on to something new, like the apostates have done (cf. similar language in 2:14). Abiding or remaining in this truth ensures that they will remain in God, Father and Son. The key to perseverance here is holding fast to proper doctrine.

<span id="page-439-9"></span>2:25 Though not explicitly stated, the point of this verse is that God has promised eternal life to those who abide in the Son and in the Father (cf. v. 24). As John has

<span id="page-439-2"></span><span id="page-439-1"></span><sup>27</sup> This seems to be what is pictured at the baptism of Jesus (Matt. 3:16–17; Mark 1:10–11; Luke 3:21–22; John 1:32–34).

<sup>28</sup> John Calvin, *Commentaries on the Catholic Epistles*, trans. John Owen (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker, 1999), 194. 29 Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 151.

<sup>30</sup> Ibid., 157.

made clear previously, what is at stake is the eternal destiny of those who have turned away.31

<span id="page-440-3"></span>2:26 John restates that his warnings and instructions are given because of those who are seeking to lead his readers away to error. As a good pastor, John exposes error and urges perseverance in order to defend his flock from deception.

<span id="page-440-4"></span><span id="page-440-1"></span>2:27 John returns to the "anointing" he first mentioned in 2:20. As noted in the comment on that verse, this could refer to the apostolic teaching or to the indwelling Holy Spirit, and the two are closely related (the apostolic teaching is inspired by and confirmed in our hearts by the Holy Spirit). This anointing abides in John's readers and teaches them, just as John has been urging them to let what they have heard abide in them (v. 24). This gospel truth will continue to instruct and guide them, calling them to abide in God and not to chase after error.

<span id="page-440-2"></span>Much mischief has been made with John's statement that his readers "have no need" for anyone to teach them. He is not rejecting any place for human teachers; to do so would be to undercut the very letter he is writing! Furthermore, this would fly in the face of consistent biblical witness concerning the need for teachers. Rather, he is saying that they do not need anyone to lay again the basic foundation of their faith. They have that foundation in the teaching with which John instructed them, and that truth will guide them. In a direct pastoral appeal, John assures them that they are not without knowledge (cf. 2:20), so they need not let someone come in and tell them to "start all over again." Rather, they certainly have enough truth to discern the error of these false teachers and to recognize their need to abide in God—Father and Son.

#### *Response*

Often too much energy is given to speculation about a future "antichrist" rather than dealing with current antichrists afflicting the church and turning people away to their damnation. We need, like John here, to be more concerned with protecting the flock than with predicting the future.

<span id="page-440-0"></span>First John 2:19 is an important text when dealing with those who have professed faith but later turn away and deny it. Christians debate exactly how to understand this theologically, but John seems to make clear that such people, although they appeared to us to have been converted, never were truly believers ("if they had been of us, they would have continued with us"). This is a key verse for understanding the importance of church membership, by which we help one another persevere; abandoning the church demonstrates a lack of true spiritual life.

Once again, John is a model for pastors. While exposing error, he is careful to encourage those who have held on. It is too easy for our zeal for truth to crush tender souls without our intending to do so. "Dominical and apostolic authority

<sup>31</sup> The textual variant here, "us" versus "you" (ESV mg.), matters little for the meaning of this verse. The promise is made to all Christians ("us"), though John could directly focus on his hearers ("you") without excluding himself.

are effective when administered with a shepherd's care rather than a tyrant's force," as Yarbrough points out.32

<span id="page-441-0"></span>Verses 22–23 hold important and grave implications for interaction with other world religions. No one truly knows or worships Yahweh if he denies the Son. That is, if one does not accept Jesus as Messiah and divine Son, such a person does not worship Yahweh. Thus Jews and Muslims do not worship the same God as Christians. Of course Jews use the same name for God as believers do, but they use the proper name for a wrong conception of him.
