#### *Section Overview*

The direct address ("little children") again signals a new section. John continues the theme of abiding, addressing the idea of being God's children and the holiness required as such. Having directly addressed false teaching in the previous section, John returns to the need for holiness, now connected to the reality of Christ's return and the effect of being made children of God.

<span id="page-442-2"></span>This unit includes two subsections, 1 John 2:28–3:3 and 3:4–10. The first subsection addresses our status as God's children as the center of our hope on the day of Christ's coming, while the second turns more directly to the theme of righteous living in light of that status as God's children, eagerly anticipating Christ's return (3:3). The two subsections are held together by the theme of being born of God, which occurs in 2:29; 3:1; 3:9; and 3:10.

#### <span id="page-442-3"></span>*Section Outline*

VIII. Confidence as God's Children at Christ's Return (2:28–3:10)

- A. Abiding and Righteous Living as Preparation for Christ's Return (2:28–3:3)
- B. Righteous Living as a Consequence of Being God's Children (3:4–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-442-1"></span>2:28 John again uses the term of endearment "little children" (*teknia*). Having just stated that their anointing teaches his readers to abide in God, he now directly urges them to do just this. The new idea here is "his coming." Because living in light of Christ's return was basic Christian teaching that his readers had already received, John does not pause to explain it. Instead he focuses on two starkly different responses to Christ's return. Those who are faithful and remain in God will have "confidence," while those who do not remain but move on to other (false) teaching will "shrink from him in shame." John is continuing to call his readers to perseverance, now in light of Christ's return: "His return is sure. You will stand before him. The only question is, what will that be like for you?"

2:29 John now states how one can have confidence at Christ's return: by demonstrating one's spiritual birth through righteous living. Those who will be confident will be those who know they are God's children, marked by the family trait of righteousness. Once again John roots holy living in the character of God (cf. 1:5–6; 2:5–6).

<span id="page-442-0"></span>3:1 Reference to being born of God spurs John to marvel at the privilege of being God's children. "See" ("Behold!") is an exclamation of wonder and amazement. John is enraptured with the reality of being adopted by God. For God to stay his hand of judgment, to forgive and redeem rebellious sinners like us, would have been, in and of itself, a remarkable display of divine love, but our Lord went even further and made us his children! We dare not pass quickly over this point; we must ponder it until we share the awe and wonder of the apostle at this truth. J. I. Packer is right in saying that knowing God as one's holy Father sums up "New Testament religion" and that one can tell how well he understands Christianity by seeing how much he makes of being a child of God. "If this is not the thought

that prompts and controls his worship and prayers and his whole outlook on life, it means that he does not understand Christianity very well at all."33

<span id="page-443-1"></span>John's amazement also serves to urge perseverance. The truth in which his hearers abide provides for them the unimaginable privilege of being God's children. Who would turn their back on this for some other message? (The book of Hebrews makes a similar argument.) In fact, being God's children is not only an immense privilege; it also explains our conflict with the world. The world does not know us, it does not recognize or appreciate us, because "it did not know him." It should be no surprise that a world that rejected Christ should reject his followers. This is a far cry from prosperity theology. The "world" here no doubt includes particularly the false teachers.

<span id="page-443-3"></span>3:2 By referring to his hearers as "beloved," John not only uses another term of endearment but also recaps the previous verse. They are beloved as objects of John's love, but even more so as objects of God's amazing love, which has just been described and is now described again as John says again that they are "God's children now." John also returns to the idea of Christ's coming. We do not know, John says, exactly what we will be like at his return, but we do know that "we shall be like him"—that is, like him in holiness. We are to live righteously now (2:29), even though we will not attain complete righteousness until Jesus comes. At that point we will be purified, "because we shall see him as he is." This is what theologians have called the "beatific vision" or the "blessed vision": seeing Christ in his fullness and being purified as a result.

<span id="page-443-4"></span><span id="page-443-2"></span>3:3 Anyone who sets his heart on future purification will pursue present purification. It is interesting to note John's language concerning the believer's hope. True believers set their hope in Christ for future vindication and sanctification. The Christian life cannot be lived with eyes set only on the current situation. Thus the NT consistently grounds present perseverance in eschatological hope (e.g., Titus 2:12–13). Faith in the future grounds perseverance in the present.

<span id="page-443-0"></span>This returns to John's continuing concern for holiness. Those who do not pursue holiness show that they do not know God, for they neither reflect his character nor live in light of his return.

<span id="page-443-5"></span>3:4 Now John moves directly to the problem of continuing in sin. Having substantiated the need for holiness, he turns to the lack of it. The ESV appropriately translates the underlying Greek as "makes a practice of sinning" and "practices lawlessness." The Greek phrase combines a verb meaning "do" or "practice" ( *poieō*) with the nouns for sin and lawlessness. This wording emphasizes the ongoing practice (as Daniel Akin says, "willful, habitual action"34) that is in view. John is referring not to occasional acts but to a lifestyle, as he continues to do throughout this section.

<sup>33</sup> J. I. Packer, *Knowing God* (Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity Press, 1973), 182.

<sup>34</sup> Akin, *1, 2, 3 John*, 140.

John connects "sin" and "lawlessness." "Lawlessness" is commonly used in the Bible for particularly heinous sin.35 It suggests a disregard for God's ways. To make a habit of sinning is to live in complete rebellion against God. Such sin cannot be treated lightly.

<span id="page-444-1"></span>3:5 John appeals again to the truth his readers already know. They know that one purpose of the incarnation was for Jesus to remove ("take away") sins. If Jesus came to get rid of sin, how can his people live in it? It is impossible to walk with Jesus while supporting what he came to destroy. Furthermore, there is no sin in Jesus, so his people should give no place to it either.

<span id="page-444-2"></span>3:6 Abiding in or knowing God is contradictory to sinning. This is central to John's message concerning holiness. The holy God is opposed to sin, so his people cannot cozy up to it. The ESV appropriately translates "keeps on sinning" because the present tense verb here, along with the context, makes clear that John is not saying that once a person is converted he no longer commits any sin. Such an idea would contradict 1:8–10. Rather, John is saying that while a believer will continue to struggle with sin, he has made a decisive break with it. Specific sins will still show up in the snapshots of his life, but the video of his life can no longer be titled "Sin."

<span id="page-444-3"></span><span id="page-444-0"></span>3:7–8a A strong warning is introduced by John's most tender term of endearment. It is his affection for his "little children" that drives his urging. His warning against deception (setting up vv. 7–8a) suggests that he seeks to counter the false teachers. We must not allow any amount of clever talk to distract us from the plain truth: righteousness arises from connection to God, while sin arises from connection to the Devil. Thus a life marked by righteous behavior is evidence of knowing God, while a life characterized by sin is evidence of not knowing God and of being in the clutches of the Devil (note that John, like the rest of the Bible, sees only two possible categories here). In fact, sin is not merely connected with the Devil but originates *from* him, for he was sinning from the "beginning," from the earliest records we have of the Devil. Sin itself began with his rebellion.

<span id="page-444-4"></span>3:8b One key purpose of Christ's coming was to destroy the Devil's works, his sin and rebellion into which he seduces people. On the one hand, this verse functions as another statement as to why God's people are not to take part in sin. Additionally, it is an encouraging statement. Although sin and deception have brought heartache and trouble on the church and thus may seem quite strong, John reminds his readers that Jesus has come to destroy all of Satan's works. He may yet cause further destruction, but, in Luther's words, "lo, his doom is sure."

<span id="page-444-6"></span><span id="page-444-5"></span>3:9 The two halves of this verse state the same point in slightly different ways. One who is born of God does not make a practice of sinning (v. 9a) and indeed cannot (v. 9b). The reason in both cases is related to being born of God. Verse 9a states this

<span id="page-444-7"></span><sup>35</sup> Cf. Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 181–182, for examples and further evidence.

<span id="page-445-0"></span>in terms of God's "seed" (*sperma*), while the second half states it more literally. The term "seed" (or "offspring") was used to refer to descendants (note how Paul uses "offspring" and "children" almost interchangeably in Rom. 9:6–8), because children came from the "seed" of man. Likewise here the paternity of God is stressed. Those who are birthed from God's seed will share in his characteristics, just as natural children share the characteristics of their biological parents.

3:10 This concluding statement summarizes John's point in the preceding verses. The behavior of individuals should make clear their spiritual state. We will resemble our father, whether it be God or the Devil. One's lack of righteousness and lack of love for fellow believers lead to a lack of any assurance that such a person is a Christian.

#### *Response*

John lifts his readers' eyes beyond the current distress to their blessed hope in order to bolster them for day-to day faithfulness. Calvin aptly said,

Our present condition is very short of the glow of God's children; . . . death is always before our eyes; we are also subject to [a] thousand miseries, and the soul is exposed to innumerable evils. . . . The more necessary it is that all our thoughts should be withdrawn from the present view of things, lest the miseries by which we are on every side surrounded and almost overwhelmed, should shake our faith in that felicity which as yet lies hid. For the Apostle's meaning is this, that we act very foolishly when we estimate what God has bestowed on us according to the present state of things, but that we ought with undoubting faith to hold to that which does not yet appear.36

<span id="page-445-2"></span><span id="page-445-1"></span>Scripture makes clear that we do not attain sinless perfection in this life. We anticipate such perfection at Christ's coming (1 John 3:2). However, conversion produces a real change in our lives. On the one hand, we must not allow this to be brushed off so that people who claim faith can continue floating along despite their lack of concern for holiness. On the other hand, we must help sensitive souls who never find assurance because they never see enough holiness in their own lives. We must indeed heed the call to examine ourselves (2 Cor. 13:5), but we must recognize that this is not merely an individualistic effort. We need the community of faith to help us in this examination lest we be either too lax or too harsh in our assessment.

<span id="page-445-3"></span><sup>36</sup> Calvin, *Commentaries on the Catholic Epistles*, 204.

### <span id="page-446-2"></span>1 JOHN 3:11–24

**<sup>11</sup>**For this is the message that you have heard from the beginning, that we should love one another. **12**We should not be like Cain, who was of the evil one and murdered his brother. And why did he murder him? Because his own deeds were evil and his brother's righteous. **13**Do not be surprised, brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* that the world hates you. **14**We know that we have passed out of death into life, because we love the brothers. Whoever does not love abides in death. **15**Everyone who hates his brother is a murderer, and you know that no murderer has eternal life abiding in him.

**<sup>16</sup>**By this we know love, that he laid down his life for us, and we ought to lay down our lives for the brothers. **17**But if anyone has the world's goods and sees his brother in need, yet closes his heart against him, how does God's love abide in him? **18**Little children, let us not love in word or talk but in deed and in truth.

**<sup>19</sup>**By this we shall know that we are of the truth and reassure our heart before him; **<sup>20</sup>** for whenever our heart condemns us, God is greater than our heart, and he knows everything. **21**Beloved, if our heart does not condemn us, we have confidence before God; **<sup>22</sup>** and whatever we ask we receive from him, because we keep his commandments and do what pleases him. **23**And this is his commandment, that we believe in the name of his Son Jesus Christ and love one another, just as he has commanded us. **24**Whoever keeps his commandments abides in God,*<sup>2</sup>* and God*<sup>3</sup>* in him. And by this we know that he abides in us, by the Spirit whom he has given us.

1Or *brothers and sisters*. In New Testament usage, depending on the context, the plural Greek word *adelphoi* (translated "brothers") may refer either to *brothers* or to *brothers and sisters*; also verses 14, 16 2Greek *him* 3Greek *he*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-446-4"></span><span id="page-446-3"></span><span id="page-446-1"></span><span id="page-446-0"></span>The theme of love returned somewhat abruptly at the end of 1 John 3:10, forming a hook for a return to the topic in 3:11–24. Verse 11 serves as the thesis statement for this unit—John's audience knows they have been commanded to love one another. Verses 12–15 explain this in terms of a contrast between hate and murder. Verses 16–18 provide the positive example of love (the cross) and an explanation of what such love looks like in everyday terms. In light of this challenging call, verses 19–24 discuss how we may have confidence despite our failures.

#### <span id="page-446-5"></span>*Section Outline*

- IX. The Necessity of Love and Gospel Comfort (3:11–24)
	- A. Renewed Call to Love (3:11)
- B. Love versus Hate and Murder (3:12–15)
- C. The Cross as the Ultimate Example of Love (3:16–18)
- D. Assurance despite Our Failures (3:19–24)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-447-6"></span><span id="page-447-5"></span>3:11 John likes to remind his audience that what he is urging corresponds to the truth they have heard "from the beginning" (2:7, 24). John is not peddling in novelty, which may suggest that the false teachers are.

<span id="page-447-0"></span>3:12 For a counterexample John reaches back to Cain in Genesis 4, perhaps reinforcing the fact that this love command goes back to the "beginning." The opposite of love is hatred (mentioned explicitly in the next verse), which leads to murder. And what leads to such hatred-inspired murder? The evildoer hates the one who does righteousness. This connects John's points concerning the practice of righteousness and the love we ought to have for one another.

<span id="page-447-8"></span>3:13 Here John makes his application. The first murder (by Cain) was caused by hatred of righteousness by the wicked. Therefore, we should not be surprised when the world, which is opposed to God, hates us, who do righteous deeds because we are God's children. The Bible states clearly that we should expect such opposition, and if we are shocked by it, our ignorance of the Bible is exposed (John 16:33; 2 Tim. 3:12; cf. Psalm 2).

<span id="page-447-9"></span><span id="page-447-4"></span><span id="page-447-1"></span>3:14 Love for fellow believers is evidence of conversion, that one has been transformed from the realm of death to the realm of life. This is one way we can know the reality of our conversion. This also shows that such love is supernatural: it does not arise naturally in fallen hearts but requires the supernatural work of God. On the other hand, anyone who does not have such love remains in the realm of death.

<span id="page-447-10"></span><span id="page-447-2"></span>3:15 Now John makes explicit the connection between hatred and murder. Echoing Jesus' words (Matt. 5:21–22), John says that to hate a brother is to violate the command against murder. Hatred makes one a murderer, and it is well known, John says, that no murderer has eternal life.

<span id="page-447-7"></span><span id="page-447-3"></span>The Evil One inspires hatred of God's people, ranging from lack of care to actually destroying them (murder). This is because the Evil One was a murderer from the beginning (John 8:44). Thus Cain, the first murderer, is "of the evil one" (1 John 3:12), meaning he belonged to and was from the realm of the Devil. All of those who live in the realm of the Evil One, who abide in death, will hate God's people.

John is not claiming that no murderer can be converted (indeed, the apostle Paul would be a counterexample!). Nor is he speaking of self-defense or accidental slaying.37 Rather, he is declaring that no one who is converted can wantonly destroy innocent human life. It is striking that the word used here for "murderer"

<sup>37</sup> The OT makes these distinctions (Ex. 21:12–14; Deut. 4:41–43; 19:1–13).

<span id="page-448-1"></span>(*anthrōpoktonos*) occurs elsewhere in the NT only in John 8:44, where it refers to the Devil.

Regarding the connection between hatred and murder, I. Howard Marshall aptly states, "We may not like to put the point so frankly, but it is good that the real character of hatred should be so unambiguously displayed, so as to warn us against it. . . . Hatred is incompatible with spiritual life. Put otherwise, the person who hates another wants to deprive him of life; such a person clearly does not belong to the realm of life."38

<span id="page-448-4"></span>3:16 After offering this negative example, John returns to the exhortation to love. Jesus' giving of himself, culminating at the cross, teaches us what love is and calls us to follow his example. Whereas hate leads to taking another's life, love leads to laying down one's own.

<span id="page-448-5"></span><span id="page-448-3"></span>3:17 Laying down one's life involves meeting the basic needs of others. The phrase "the world's goods" uses the same word discussed in 2:16 (*bios*). The situation in view is clear—one believer has financial means and sees another believer in need. If a believer knows of such a fellow brother in need but closes his heart against him, such behavior calls into question this believer's faith.

There is a deliberate switch here from plural (general) in verse 16 to singular (specific) in verse 17. As G. P. Lewis points out, "It is easier to be enthusiastic about Humanity with a capital 'H' than it is to love individual men and women, especially those who are uninteresting, exasperating, depraved, or otherwise unattractive. Loving everybody in general may be an excuse for loving nobody in particular."39

3:18 John's term of endearment ("little children") draws specific attention to his concluding point, summarizing the last two verses. Real love, the love of God that John has been addressing, is not simply "word or talk." It always results in deeds. God so loved the world that he *gave* (John 3:16).

<span id="page-448-0"></span>Of course, this does not mean that loving words or talk are useless! John himself demonstrates loving talk in this letter. His point is that true love is not *merely* talk or sentiment. Love is not content only to speak but must act for the good of the one loved. That which only feels and speaks but does not act is not true love. Love without works is dead.

<span id="page-448-6"></span><span id="page-448-2"></span>3:19–20 "By this" refers back to the previous verses. Thus, as we love "in truth" (genuinely) we will have assurance ("we shall know") that we are "of the truth," which is another of John's phrases referring to knowing God or being converted (like practicing or being in the truth; 1:6–8). Obedience leads to assurance. John is writing to a flock rocked by the departure of a number who claimed to have the truth, and he is repeatedly showing them how they can see that they are right for continuing in the apostolic pattern. "This" love, which he has been describing, is the right way.

<sup>38</sup> Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 191–192.

<sup>39</sup> G. P. Lewis, cited in Stott, *Letters of John*, 147.

However, there will also be times in which we will need to "reassure our heart" before God,40 presumably because we are painfully aware of the deficiency of even our best love. Thus, when our hearts condemn us, John tells us to look to God. We do examine our lives to see the obedience that results from faith, but in the end we look to God and not to ourselves. We repent of sin, seek to obey, and look to God, knowing that he is greater than our hearts and knows everything. He knows all our sin, and he knows his atoning work. In other words, despite a smiting conscience, we can remind ourselves that what God has forgiven stands forgiven forever. As Paul said, "If God is for us, who can be against us? . . . Who shall bring any charge against God's elect? It is God who justifies. Who is to condemn? Christ Jesus is the one who died—more than that, who was raised—who is at the right hand of God, who indeed is interceding for us" (Rom. 8:31–34).

<span id="page-449-4"></span><span id="page-449-1"></span>3:21 Having addressed the remedy for a condemning heart, John now addresses his readers with another of his terms of endearment as he moves to the blessing of a cleared conscience. We can almost feel a sense of excitement as he makes this transition, reminding them that they are indeed "beloved." When our hearts no longer condemn us because we rest in the work of Christ, we can approach God with confidence (similarly in Heb. 10:19–20, with the same word for "confidence"). This is precisely what Charles Wesley described when he wrote, in his hymn "Amazing Love,"

<span id="page-449-2"></span> No condemnation now I dread; Jesus, and all in Him, is mine; Alive in Him, my living Head, And clothed in righteousness divine, Bold I approach the eternal throne, And claim the crown, through Christ my own.

<span id="page-449-5"></span>3:22 Along with the previous verse, this verse makes clear that the context of prayer is in view. The confidence of a conscience cleared by grace leads to effective prayer. We must be careful neither to abuse nor to minimize what John says. On the one hand, the promise of "whatever we ask" must not be construed as the basis for a prosperity theology, which tells us simply to "name it and claim it." Despite the worldwide popularity of this idea, such beliefs miss the entire thrust of Scripture as well as the qualification here that we must obey God and do what pleases him. Prayers for mere self-gratification or self-exaltation do not please God.

<span id="page-449-0"></span>Because of this abuse, however, some Christians fail to take seriously the promise that is indeed given (also in Matt. 7:7; Mark 11:24). As we obey and please God, asking for things that please him because they are in line with his commands, God will answer our prayers and do great things. This should encourage us to obey and pray.

<span id="page-449-3"></span><sup>40</sup> Some suggest "before him" in verse 19 refers to the final judgment. However, the "whenever" of verse 20 argues against such a reading. John has in view any time we feel guilty before God and thus unable to come before him.

<span id="page-450-9"></span><span id="page-450-5"></span><span id="page-450-0"></span>3:23 Having mentioned obedience to commands, John specifies two such key commands. The first is to "believe in the name of his Son Jesus Christ." This is quite similar to Jesus' statement in John 6:29. The title "his Son Jesus Christ" connotes the full confession of the person of Christ, which the false teachers deny (cf. 1 John 2:22–23). The second command is to "love one another," as the sent Son commanded. Thus John repeats two key themes of the letter to this point: Effective prayer, then, is contingent on right belief in the person of Christ and genuine love for believers.41

<span id="page-450-4"></span><span id="page-450-3"></span>3:24 Continuing the theme of keeping God's commandments, John writes that such obedience shows that a person abides in God and that God abides in him. Abiding in God is another of John's phrases denoting true Christianity. Earlier John connected abiding in God with obedience (2:6; 3:6) and with being confident at the return of Christ (2:28). God's Word (2:14), anointing (2:27), seed (3:9), and love (3:17) are all said to "abide" in believers. This is the truth of which Jesus spoke in John 15 and refers to the interrelatedness of life between God and his children, with God as their source of life. "In John's theology, abiding is the epitome of trust in Christ, like being 'in Christ' in Paul," explains Yarbrough.42

<span id="page-450-10"></span><span id="page-450-7"></span>"By this" refers back to keeping God's commandments (1 John 3:24a). Obedience is how we know God abides in us. This is in keeping with what John has written elsewhere in this letter, as well as with the consistent NT witness that faith produces works. This assurance of God's abiding in us comes also through the work of the Spirit. Paul also speaks of confidence that comes "through the Holy Spirit who has been given to us" (Rom. 5:5). Mention of the Spirit here sets up the new focus on his work in the next section.

#### <span id="page-450-1"></span>*Response*

We should not be surprised by the hatred of the world but rather should be surprised by any lack of love within the church. Sadly, too often today this is reversed. Church members expect conflict within the church but are taken aback by opposition from the world. We desperately need John's challenge in order to reclaim the deep loving community that can be built on the gospel and then face confidently the opposition of the world.

<span id="page-450-6"></span>The love John calls for is quite demanding. John challenges us to be willing to make the supreme sacrifice (3:16) and then keeps us from thinking merely of grand sacrifices by pointing to daily needs (3:17). Care and awareness of such needs will not arise simply from weekly attendance at the same meeting as others in need. The church envisioned here is not merely a place to go but a family to which to belong.

<span id="page-450-8"></span>John's clear words concerning the necessity of obedience combined with his careful handling of troubled consciences (3:19–24) is rich in pastoral lessons. Too

<span id="page-450-2"></span><sup>41</sup> Interestingly, a failure of love by Christian husbands toward their wives may also hinder their prayers (1 Pet. 3:7).

<sup>42</sup> Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 216.

<span id="page-451-2"></span>often believers choose either a firm stand for truth or a gentleness with troubled souls, as if the two were mutually exclusive. John shows us another way: the gospel makes clear, nonnegotiable claims upon us and then reminds us of the hope and power found in Christ.

### 1 JOHN 4:1–6

4 Beloved, do not believe every spirit, but test the spirits to see whether they are from God, for many false prophets have gone out into the world. **2**By this you know the Spirit of God: every spirit that confesses that Jesus Christ has come in the flesh is from God, **<sup>3</sup>** and every spirit that does not confess Jesus is not from God. This is the spirit of the antichrist, which you heard was coming and now is in the world already. **4**Little children, you are from God and have overcome them, for he who is in you is greater than he who is in the world. **5**They are from the world; therefore they speak from the world, and the world listens to them. **6**We are from God. Whoever knows God listens to us; whoever is not from God does not listen to us. By this we know the Spirit of truth and the spirit of error.

#### *Section Overview*

The Spirit was mentioned at the end of the previous section, setting up the focus on him in the section at hand. Having just discussed the difficult issue of discerning our own hearts, John moves to the discernment of "spirits," those claiming to speak as inspired by the Spirit. In many ways, this section of 1 John parallels 1 John 2:18–27.

#### <span id="page-451-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-451-1"></span>X. The Necessity of Discernment and the Spirit of Antichrist (4:1–6)
	- A. Call to Discernment (4:1)
	- B. The Test: Confession of Jesus (4:2–3)
	- C. Comfort to a Rattled Church (4:4–5)
	- D. Confirmation: Listening to God and His Apostles (4:6)

#### *Comment*

4:1 Once more the vocative term of endearment "Beloved" marks the shift to a new section. This direct address calls for refocused attention as John again warns his readers about false teachers. The "spirits" in view here are men who claim to speak under the prompting of the Spirit. John stresses that discernment is necessary, for numerous false teachers will claim the inspiration of the Spirit. We do not have to believe people just because they claim that God told them what to say. Such people could be sincerely misled or even intentionally deceitful. These ideas or teachings ("spirits") must always be tested rather than simply taken at face value. The manner of testing is what John addresses next.

<span id="page-452-4"></span><span id="page-452-3"></span>4:2 John's characteristic "by this you know" introduces the test he prescribes for questionable teachings (cf. 4:1 and comment). Our aim is to "know the Spirit of God," that is, to recognize whether or not the Holy Spirit is behind any questionable teaching. To be considered as being from God, every idea or teacher must affirm that Jesus is the incarnate Messiah. This concern about proper understanding of the person and work of Christ was mentioned previously, in 2:18–23, which has many similarities to this section.

<span id="page-452-5"></span><span id="page-452-2"></span>4:3 To "confess Jesus" is a shorthand way of referring to the full affirmation of 4:2. Any teacher or doctrine that fails to affirm, or that perhaps undermines, the messiahship and incarnation of Jesus cannot be from God. Instead, such teaching is the "spirit of the antichrist." As in 2:18, John reminds his readers that they knew such a spirit was coming and that it is now currently active.

<span id="page-452-1"></span>This flies in the face of much of modern Western Christianity, which seems to think that sincerity is all that matters and that doctrinal distinctives are insignificant if one means well. Of course doctrinal precision is not all that matters, but certain doctrines must be clearly held in order for a person to be part of God's people. No matter how well-intentioned one is, if he denies the incarnation of Jesus, he is not a true member of Christ's church.

<span id="page-452-6"></span>4:4 The reality of a sinister spirit at work that is opposed to Christ should be disconcerting, and no doubt was to John's audience, since they had just witnessed the effect of this spirit in their own church. So, having mentioned this reality, John turns to comforting his beloved "little children." His comfort is threefold. First, he reminds them that they are "from God," like the spirit that confesses Jesus (4:2) and unlike the false spirit (4:3).43 The distinction of being "from God" or "from the world" will be a major theme in the rest of this section. Despite whatever the false teachers may say, these believers who are holding fast can be encouraged by the apostolic witness that they are rooted in God.

Secondly, these faithful believers have "overcome" the false teachers and those who follow them (the spirit of antichrist). We do not know what percentage of this church left and what percentage stayed, but it may have felt like evil was winning. John encourages them that they have in fact overcome, no matter what they were feeling (cf. more on this in the comment on 5:4).

<span id="page-452-7"></span>Third, the basis for the certainty of victory is that the one who is in them, empowering them—God—is greater than the one who is in and empowering the world. The one in the world is not explicitly identified but is ultimately the Devil, who has been in view at various times (2:14; 3:10, 12).

<span id="page-452-0"></span><sup>43</sup> The same Greek phrase, *ek tou theou*, is used in each instance of the phrase "from God" in verses 2–4.

Thus believers should recognize the serious reality of spiritual danger, but they should not be paralyzed by fear, because they know God—that he has made them his own (they are "from" him, and he is in them) and that he is more powerful than all the forces arrayed against them. This fundamental truth can be found throughout Scripture and is the basis for Christian courage and composure in a fallen world.

<span id="page-453-3"></span><span id="page-453-2"></span>4:5 In contrast, those who follow the false teachers are "from the world" (the realm of hostility to God, which believers are not to love; cf. 2:15). John has just explained that the false teachers' connection to the world is why faithful believers have overcome them (4:4). Here he explains why such conquered people seem to have such success: the world is attracted their message because they are "on the same page." False teachers will commonly gain a great following because they tell the world what the world wants to hear. A message tailored to the desires of the world will always find a following, but it will not lead to life. This is a resounding warning against assessing any ministry by the number of its followers.

<span id="page-453-4"></span><span id="page-453-1"></span>4:6 "We," as in chapter 1, refers to John and the broader apostolic witness (cf. comment on 1:1). In 4:4 he said that "you," his hearers, were from God. Here he includes himself—"we"—because now he is speaking of the message proclaimed. John is from God (he meets the test of v. 2), and therefore those who know God listen to his message, while those who are not from God do not listen to him.

This is no license for any given preacher to say, "I am from God, and thus whoever listens to me is from God, and whoever does not like me does not know God." Instead we must recognize this to be the inspired apostolic witness speaking. The status of message/messenger from God is not a subjective thing to be appropriated by whoever might do so. Rather, it is clearly delineated in this letter that to be "from God" is to be those who affirm Jesus as incarnate Messiah and Son of God, who pursue holiness and love fellow believers. The point is that those who truly know God listen to this sort of message. Those who do not like such a message prove that they do not know God. This is the point of the last sentence of verse 6: believers can tell the difference between the "Spirit of truth" and the "spirit of error" by whether or not any given teacher heeds the apostolic witness.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-453-0"></span>In a particularly gullible age, the church desperately needs the discernment this text describes. Far too often Christians fall for false teachers and charlatans simply because they claim to speak for God and tack on a few Bible verses. Some authoritarian leaders suggest that to doubt them is to doubt God. But this text calls for us to examine every teacher in light of revealed Scripture. Indeed, the Bible commends as "noble" those who double-checked the apostle Paul by searching the Scriptures (Acts 17:11). Any true gospel minister will welcome such testing. Such vigilance indicates not a thoroughgoing skepticism but an allegiance to Scripture and a healthy awareness of the reality of false teachers.

<span id="page-454-3"></span>**<sup>7</sup>**Beloved, let us love one another, for love is from God, and whoever loves has been born of God and knows God. **8**Anyone who does not love does not know God, because God is love. **<sup>9</sup>** In this the love of God was made manifest among us, that God sent his only Son into the world, so that we might live through him. **<sup>10</sup>** In this is love, not that we have loved God but that he loved us and sent his Son to be the propitiation for our sins. **11**Beloved, if God so loved us, we also ought to love one another. **<sup>12</sup>**No one has ever seen God; if we love one another, God abides in us and his love is perfected in us.

#### *Section Overview*

Having discussed the sharp divide between believers and the world, and the need for vigilance regarding false teaching, John now turns to the need for love within the church. Too easily, defense against error can lead us to forget the need for building a community of intentional love toward one another. John never allows his hearers to forget that the "Spirit of truth" (1 John 4:6) is always connected to love.

<span id="page-454-2"></span><span id="page-454-0"></span>In this paragraph John asserts once again the necessity of loving other Christians (vv. 7–8) and explains what love is by pointing to the cross (vv. 9–10). Then he applies this truth to his hearers, calling on them to emulate this exemplary love (vv. 11–12).

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-454-1"></span>4:7 Once again, direct address using a term of endearment marks the transition to a new section. Here the term, "beloved," also introduces the theme. John returns to the recurring theme of love, now *giving* a command rather than discussing one.44 This first-person-plural command to love is particularly Johannine language.45

Christians must love one another for two reasons. First, love originates from God, and so his people should be marked by it. Second, love is evidence of being

<sup>44</sup> John uses a hortatory subjunctive, a grammatical form for giving a command in the first person.

<sup>45</sup> Cf. Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 233, for its uniqueness to John.

"born of God" and "know[ing] God." Love is fundamental to God's character; thus his children must bear the family resemblance. This does not mean that anyone who does something loving or kind is by that fact alone a believer in Christ. There is no basis here for universalism or an inclusivism that teaches that people who deny Christ will be saved apart from faith. Such an idea would flatly contradict what John says elsewhere in this letter. Unbelievers can be loving and kind, but John is describing a deep, self-sacrificial sort of love that is directed specifically by Christians toward other Christians.

<span id="page-455-4"></span><span id="page-455-3"></span>4:8 If one does not love in this way, he must not know God, for this love is central to who God is. The statement "God is love" (repeated at 4:16) is a momentous theological point, one that J. I. Packer calls "one of the most tremendous utterances in the Bible."46 It is also true that much misunderstanding has arisen here.

<span id="page-455-2"></span>What does it mean to say that "God is love"? It is helpful to consider this statement alongside the other statement of God's basic character in 1:5: "God is light." Neither statement intends to reduce God to an abstract idea or emotion. Rather, these statements refer to God's action, the essential elements of his character that shape all that he does, and thus how we experience him. Thus, God is loving in all he does: "The love which he shows to men, and which Christians know and rejoice in, is a revelation of His own inner being."47 This is amazing news for sinful beings like us. It brings us to the glory and beauty of the gospel that an all holy God (1:5) would choose to love sinners and accomplish their salvation and sanctification. Surely Packer is right that in this doctrine we stand on holy ground.48

4:9 Since this love is so crucial, John turns now to make clear what it looks like in concrete terms by pointing to the supreme example of love, the work of Christ. This love was "made manifest" or "revealed" among us. The verb used here ( *phaneroō*) typically refers to the revelation of something that was previously hidden. God's love for humanity stretches back to before the dawn of time, and although it was revealed in part throughout the OT, it was fully revealed only in the sending of the Son to redeem us. In language strikingly similar to John 3:16,49 John shows that this event dwarfs all others in terms of its demonstration of God's love (cf. also Rom. 5:8). This statement and others like it point to the fact that this work of Christ is the center-point of all of Scripture.

<span id="page-455-1"></span><span id="page-455-0"></span>The "sending" of the Son envisions the full work of Christ—incarnation, life, death, burial, resurrection and ascension. The one sent is God's "only" Son. The adjective used (*monogenēs*) stresses the uniqueness of Jesus as God's son;50 as Calvin wrote, "He who is his only Son by nature, makes many sons by grace and adoption."51 Whereas false teachers went out "into the world" to deceive (1 John

<sup>47</sup> Ibid., 108.

<sup>48</sup> Ibid.

<sup>49</sup> Marshall says that "there can be no doubt that he is deliberately reminding his readers of that tremendous declaration" (*Epistles of John*, 213).

<sup>50</sup> Cf. ibid., 214n8 for detailed discussion of the meaning of *monogenēs*.

<sup>51</sup> Calvin, *Commentaries on the Catholic Epistles*, 239.

<span id="page-456-3"></span><span id="page-456-2"></span>4:1), the Son was sent "into the world" (same Greek phrase) "so that we might live through him" (v. 9). This is why his work is a demonstration of love—at great cost to himself, Jesus rescued us. Thus two things are involved in this love: self-sacrifice, and action done for the benefit of others.52

<span id="page-456-4"></span>4:10 John further clarifies love, stating very clearly where love began: it began with God, not with us. Our love is weak, fragile, inconstant. We could not be the measure of true love. Rather, God is the standard and the initiator of love. Before we did anything, he "sent his Son to be the propitiation for our sins." As Paul says, "God shows his love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us" (Rom. 5:8).

<span id="page-456-1"></span><span id="page-456-0"></span>As in 4:9, God's love is demonstrated by his sending of the Son. Here the work of the Son is more specifically delineated. "Propitiation" describes Jesus' work at the cross as a sacrifice that turns away God's holy wrath because of our sins (cf. comment on 2:2). As he often does, John refers to large theological realities without elaboration. By referring to propitiation, John says that God's love is seen in the fact that he sent his Son to die a cruel death, bearing the full fury of the Father's wrath for our sins so that we might be forgiven and redeemed. He came to die that we might live. This is no mere sentimental indulgence. This is love. William Rees (1802–1883) captured this truth well in his classic hymn, "Here Is Love":

 Here is love, vast as the ocean, Lovingkindness as the flood, When the Prince of life, our ransom, Shed for us His precious blood. . . .

 On the mount of crucifixion Fountains opened deep and wide; Through the floodgates of God's mercy Flowed a vast and gracious tide. Grace and love, like mighty rivers, Poured incessant from above, And heaven's peace and perfect justice Kissed a guilty world in love.

<span id="page-456-5"></span>4:11 "Beloved" marks John's return to his exhortation. Having paused to define love by pointing to the work of Christ, John now comes back to his hortatory purpose, saying in essence, "Beloved, in view of this amazing love, as recipients of such a persevering, sacrificial, effective love, how can we not love one another as well?" This is the root of all of John's statements declaring that one who does not love his brother cannot know God. If one knows this love that has just been described, he will love in return. As a skilled preacher, John has moved from the pinnacle of marvelous theological truth to pointed moral exhortation. Adoration must lead to action.

52 Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 214.

<span id="page-457-0"></span>4:12 The connection of this verse to the preceding material is not immediately clear. That no one can see God because he is spirit is a basic truth of the Bible (Ex. 33:20; 1 Tim. 1:17), but one might wonder what the point is of the assertion here. There does not seem to have been any questioning of this truth among John's hearers. Rather, John is arguing from a theological given to an ethical necessity. Since God cannot be seen, Christians can "show" him to a watching world only by loving one another.

When Christians love one another, God abides in them; he dwells in their midst. And his love, which has just been so powerfully described, is brought to completion in them. To say God's love is "perfected" is not to suggest a deficiency in God's love. Rather, the word (*teleioō*) means "to complete," to bring to its intended outcome: "God's already pristine love find[s] its fullest possible earthly expression as people respond to the message of Christ and reach out to one another as a result."53 Thus the way for God to be "seen," recognized—for people to see that he is real—is for Christians actively and aggressively to care for one another.

#### *Response*

This is a rich text in terms of doctrine, delight, and duty. We need to think long, deep, and often on the reality of God's love. Knowledge of such love is the crying need of the soul. Broken, needy souls trample and devour one another looking for this balm, though they do not know that this is what they seek. J. I. Packer is right to note that "to know God's love is indeed heaven on earth."54 We should revel in this reality and allow it to lead us to worship. Then we must take this glorious news to those who do not yet know it.

Since John calls us to love as we have been loved, we would do well to contemplate how it is that God has loved us:

- He loved first. He did not wait for us to make the first move. Ours must also be an initiating love.
- He loved those who hated him. We cannot excuse ourselves from love because people are difficult. If the *sinless* God can love *sinful* people, then *sinful* people can surely love other *sinful* people.
- He loved those who were different than he. No human will ever be more different from us than we are from God. Our love must not be limited to those who are like us.
- His love accomplished what was best for us even though it was not what we wanted at the time.
- His love continued when it was not convenient.
- His love perseveres even though we wrong and offend him.
- He loved at extreme cost.

<sup>53</sup> Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 245.

<sup>54</sup> Packer, *Knowing God*, 106.

• His love found concrete expression—not merely vague feelings but real action.

Furthermore, churches must be communities marked by this intentional care and love. All the outreach programs in the world cannot approach the power of seeing this love lived out in tangible ways on a consistent basis. John has told us that this is the way God will be seen. But, too often, it is easier to plan another program than to engage in messy, vulnerable love for one another. This commentator has seen this lived out as fellow believers went out of their way to minister to my family in times of grief and suffering, and onlookers were bewildered by what they saw: "Who are these people? Why would they go to such trouble for you?" When I told them they were members of our church, they responded, "What kind of church do you go to?" Even in my Bible Belt community, the door was now open to explain the love of God.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-459-11"></span><span id="page-459-5"></span><span id="page-459-1"></span>4:13 "By this" points forward, as John lists three evidences of true conversion.55 The first evidence is that God has given us his Spirit. Exactly how this functions as proof is not stated here. It could be a point similar to Paul's in Romans 8:16: "The Spirit himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of God." John's wording is very similar to that of 1 John 3:24, where we argued that the Spirit assures us of God's presence in us as we obey. Here the mutual indwelling of God and believers is evidenced by the Spirit's work, which seems to be to inspire and elicit the love that has been discussed: "To abide in one another reciprocally is to know and love one another, and this love is fostered by the Holy Spirit."56 John is not claiming that we know we are Christians because of some feeling that we have his Spirit; rather, he is pointing out that the fact that we love fellow believers is evidence of the Spirit's work in us, which is then confirmation of our conversion.

<span id="page-459-12"></span><span id="page-459-9"></span><span id="page-459-7"></span><span id="page-459-2"></span>4:14 Before moving on to the second evidence of conversion, John pauses to accentuate apostolic authority for this evidence. John stresses that, while no one has seen the Father (4:12), John and the other apostolic witnesses have seen that Jesus was in fact sent, that he is the Son, and that he is the Savior.57 The sending of Jesus by the Father refers to his incarnation as well as to his divine source and mission, which was denied by some (4:2; 5:6; 2 John 7). Jesus' sonship establishes his deity and oneness with the Father, which was also being denied (1 John 2:23–24). "Savior of the world" refers to Jesus' mission, which was possible only if he indeed was the sent Son (a mission just described in 4:9–10; cf. similar language in John 4:42).58 The veracity of these truths leads to the next evidence of conversion.

The language mirrors John 6:69, where Peter makes the confession called for in 1 John 4:15.

<span id="page-460-4"></span><span id="page-460-0"></span>Further buttressing the astonishing reality of God's love for his people, John reiterates his point from 4:8: "God is love." Therefore, in light of God's astounding love for us, we ought to "[abide] in love." In one sense this means to "remain in love," that is, to continue believing the truth that God loves us and not to be dissuaded by the Devil's lies. On the other hand, this also means to "live in love," exhibiting this love to others. This is a continuation of the point made in 4:11. The one who thus "abides in love" shows that he is truly a believer, that he "abides in God, and God abides in him."

<span id="page-460-11"></span><span id="page-460-7"></span><span id="page-460-6"></span><span id="page-460-3"></span><span id="page-460-1"></span>4:17 Having listed his three evidences of conversion, John now elaborates on the third evidence (loving fellow believers), reiterating the idea of 4:7–12. "By this" refers to loving one another (cf. v. 16). Thus, just as in 4:12, God's love comes to its fruition among us as we love one another. John now adds that this completion of God's love will give us "confidence for the day of judgment." As in 2:28, abiding in God is the basis of such confidence, though there the abiding was linked to doctrinal fidelity and here it is linked to loving fellow believers. John thus continues to show that these issues are inextricably linked.

The "day of judgment" is referred to without elaboration, showing that John expected his readers to be well acquainted with the central NT truth that we will give account of ourselves before God. This is rightly a sobering reality. John's point is that knowing that the Judge loves us deeply provides confidence (despite our fallenness) for that day. The love of God is our only hope.

This confidence is rooted in the love described in the previous verse ("by this") and in the fact that "as he is so also are we in this world." In 3:2, following a statement concerning confidence at his coming, John stated that we will be like Jesus when we see him at that coming. In this verse, however, we are like him *now*. In 3:2 John was addressing how we will share in the glory and holiness of Jesus, while here in 4:17 John is addressing our participation with Jesus in the same relationship of love with the Father. This draws from the truth regarding Jesus' sonship

<span id="page-461-4"></span><span id="page-461-2"></span>that has just been asserted (4:15–16): just as he is the beloved Son, so now we also, while still in this world, are beloved children due to our adoption (3:1). Though it will still be sobering, we can stand before such a judge with assurance. As Luther said, "If consciousness of a great sin weighs you down, comfort yourself with this blood of love. . . . No human religion can hold its own in the face of the judgment, but it is solely in the blood of Christ that we can have confidence in the Day of Judgment."60

<span id="page-461-6"></span>4:18 This verse is often thought to be confusing because it is taken out of context, suggesting that fear and love can never go together. But we know that the Bible commends both fear and love of God. Notice both of these points, for instance, in Deuteronomy 6:1–5, a central OT text:

<span id="page-461-0"></span>This is the commandment—the statutes and the rules—that the Lord your God commanded me to teach you . . . that you may *fear* the Lord your God, you and your son and your son's son. . . . Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one. You shall *love* the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your might.61

Following his previous statement, John is affirming that love casts out fear of rejection or condemnation in judgment. We cannot know that someone completely loves us while also fearing that he will reject us. When we fear that another will reject us, we fear that his love is not complete. Having just affirmed God's perfected love for us, John tells us that such love drives out this fear of condemnation—this is why it is such an assurance. Therefore, whoever fears such punishment or condemnation has not yet been brought to the fullness of knowing and believing the love of God (1 John 4:16).

<span id="page-461-7"></span><span id="page-461-5"></span><span id="page-461-3"></span>4:19 John pauses to make clear where such love begins: it begins with God, not with us. John has been arguing all along that because God has loved us, we should love as well. His mode of argumentation has thus assumed the priority of God's love for us. Now he makes this explicit, even more so than he did in 4:10. God, in love, first thought of us before the dawn of time, then at the cross he bought us, and then he sought us until he caught us and brought us into his kingdom. Our love for God, then, is in no way meritorious but rather is our grateful response to the demonstration of his love. The more we are aware of God's love, the more we love in return. "It is, therefore, good for us constantly to renew our knowledge of God's love as we read of it in the Bible, as we hear it proclaimed in the worship of the church, and as we consider the ways in which our whole life has been molded by experiences of God's love and care for us."62

<span id="page-462-3"></span>4:20 This love for God *must* result in love for other believers, as John has been urging. If one does not love God's people, he does not love God; thus to claim to love God while refusing to love his people makes one a "liar."

<span id="page-462-1"></span>Now John expounds on why a claim to love God while hating God's people makes no sense. He has just affirmed in 4:12 the basic biblical truth that no one can see God (since he is spirit). How, then, can one love someone he *cannot* see if he does not love the one he *can* see? Throughout this letter, "love" for John has meant not nice feelings but direct action. How could anyone act lovingly toward someone he cannot see? One way to act lovingly toward the unseen God is to love his people.

This is a strong point against mysticism. We cannot demonstrate love toward God while being hidden away by ourselves, concerned only with ourselves and God. To love God we must care for his people. Thus it is ludicrous to claim we love God while failing to assemble with his people. The Bible knows nothing of a "just me and God" religion.

<span id="page-462-4"></span>4:21 John develops a specific command from the Scriptures that we must love fellow believers. As Jesus summarized the OT law as requiring love for God and for neighbors, so now John declares that the command is to love God *by* loving one's brothers. Such love is the way to demonstrate love for a God we cannot see. Thus there is simply no way around the requirement to love one another. If we do not love other believers in concrete terms, there is simply no way we could truly know God.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-462-2"></span><span id="page-462-0"></span>It is not a small thing to believe that God truly does love his people deeply and faithfully. Typical human experience tells us that love is fickle, and surely none of us would tolerate the unfaithfulness we know we have exhibited toward God. Additionally, we have an enemy who whispers in our ear, "It is too good to be true. He cannot really love *you*. Not anymore. Not after what you have done." This is why we need the affirmation of 4:9–10: so that we might make the confession of 4:16. Knowing and believing the love of God for us empowers us to love others in the way John teaches.

### 1 JOHN 5:1–5

<span id="page-463-2"></span>5 Everyone who believes that Jesus is the Christ has been born of God, and everyone who loves the Father loves whoever has been born of him. **2**By this we know that we love the children of God, when we love God and obey his commandments. **3**For this is the love of God, that we keep his commandments. And his commandments are not burdensome. **<sup>4</sup>**For everyone who has been born of God overcomes the world. And this is the victory that has overcome the world—our faith. **5**Who is it that overcomes the world except the one who believes that Jesus is the Son of God?

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-463-3"></span><span id="page-463-1"></span>This section continues to address love for other believers, bringing obedience and faith back into the discussion. The unit opens and closes with mentions of faith (1 John 5:1, 4–5) and of being born of God. In Johannine fashion, faith, love, and obedience are shown to be deeply intertwined. Faith in Jesus is evidence of new birth, and those who love God must love those born of God. Thus those "born of God" share a common faith ("our faith"; v. 4). Loving God's children entails loving God and obeying God, and love for God itself entails obedience to God. Despite the onslaught of the world, this requirement of loving obedience is not overwhelming, because faith in Jesus as the Son of God empowers us.

XIII. Faith in Jesus Overcomes the World (5:1–5)

- A. Interconnectedness of Faith, Love, and Obedience (5:1–3)
