#### *Comment*

5:1 John continues to insist that one who loves God must love other Christians as well. Here he does so by identifying those who have been born of God. Everyone who trusts in Jesus as the Messiah (implying the full confession just discussed in 4:14–15) has been born of God.63 Thus, anyone who loves God will love those who are born of him. If we love him, we will love his children.

<span id="page-463-0"></span>John's point will continue with love, but it is worthwhile to pause to note that John has identified faith as another mark of conversion. Faith is central to Christian living, as John will make clear in 5:4–5. This does not mean, however, that all who

<sup>63</sup> For further discussion about all that is implied by affirming Jesus as Messiah, cf. Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 209.

simply profess faith have been converted. John makes clear that saving faith has a transformative effect. Such life-transforming faith is a mark of the children of God.

<span id="page-464-3"></span>5:2 Having written earlier that love for believers proves one's love for God, John now states that love for God proves one's love for believers. This is not double-talk, however. John is implying that this divinely implanted love moves in both directions, necessarily producing love toward people and toward God. Furthermore, the love of others that John is commending is not merely human. We love others properly when we are also loving God. A "love" that places any human, rather than God, as primary in our affections is not proper love. As Calvin comments, "Men are rightly and duly loved, when God holds the primacy. . . . For it often happens, that we love men apart from God, as unholy and carnal friendships regard only private advantages or some other vanishing objects."64

True love for fellow children of God is seen also in obedience to God's commands, one of which is the requirement to love fellow believers. The first point showed that love for believers includes loving them under God, for God's sake. This point shows that love for fellow believers is a holy, obedient love. We are not loving others well when we disobey God for them or encourage them to be disobedient in any way to God's commands. This cuts right across our culture's idea that loving someone requires one to affirm whatever that person does.

<span id="page-464-4"></span>5:3 Having just mentioned love for God and obedience to his commands as elements of loving others, John now makes clear that these two elements are actually one. To love God is to obey God. John is not denying that affection is a part of love, but here he continues to speak of the active side of love. Proper affection for God will lead to obedience. Where there is no obedience there is no affection for God, despite claims to the contrary. This is what Jesus himself said (John 14:15, 23–24).

<span id="page-464-1"></span>The statement that God's "commandments are not burdensome" does not mean that obedience is easy. Indeed, the Bible is replete with explicit teaching and examples of the difficulty of obedience and the suffering it often entails. Rather, as the next verse will state, divine power is available to enable obedience. Furthermore, the commands of God are all for our good. They are not weights bearing us down and preventing us from attaining true life. They are just the opposite (John 6:63; Psalm 119).

<span id="page-464-5"></span><span id="page-464-0"></span>5:4 Even though God's commands cut across the desires of fallen humanity, they are not burdensome because "personal faith enables believers to break free from the world's downward pull."65 "Our faith," the faith of those who have been "born of God," provides victory over this world system, which fights against the things of God (cf. comment on 2:15).

<span id="page-464-2"></span>The believer's "victory," in this context, would seem to be a "love for God through faith which joyfully embraces God's commands."66 This is not a triumpha-

<sup>64</sup> Calvin, *Commentaries on the Catholic Epistles*, 252.

<sup>65</sup> Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 275.

<sup>66</sup> Ibid., 276.

<span id="page-465-0"></span>lism that suggests we always succeed in the world's eyes. Rather, it is an overcoming of the temptations and seductions of the world by trusting that God's commands are good and right (Ps. 119:137) and therefore joyfully obeying them despite our fallen flesh. Such victory over the world entails trusting God even when it hurts, even when it seems to cost us. This is true victory, and it comes by faith: trusting God in order to obey him.

<span id="page-465-2"></span>5:5 John personalizes the point of verse 4 and specifies the faith mentioned there. This victory comes not merely by believing *some*thing. Our culture suggests we should "only believe," regardless of what we believe in. As long as we have faith in something, the world claims, that is all that matters. John does not agree. Rather, what matters is faith in Jesus as the Son of God. The object of our faith is key. This is the confession that began this section and was explained in the preceding one (4:14–15). Belief in Jesus shows that one has been born of God and enables one to overcome the world.

#### <span id="page-465-1"></span>*Response*

John makes clear that faith in Jesus is at the center of Christian existence. While John has stressed the necessity of obedience, it is clear that this obedience arises from faith in and love for God, all of which are the result of the new birth.

In our fight with sin, we often need this reminder that we are to overcome the world. It can be tempting to give in to resignation to sin—"What did I expect anyway?" Of course we struggle, but God has not left us defenseless, and we dare not downplay the transformative work God has begun by giving us new birth. We must trust God, believe his word, and obey.

Such victory also requires faith to withstand the apparent irresistibility of sin. In the face of temptation and our own weakness, we need a firm belief that Jesus has indeed overcome in order to empower us to hold on. Such faith "rests foursquare on the fact that Jesus Christ has defeated death, and anybody who can defeat death can defeat anything."67

<sup>67</sup> Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 229.

### 1 JOHN 5:6–12

<span id="page-466-3"></span>**<sup>6</sup>**This is he who came by water and blood—Jesus Christ; not by the water only but by the water and the blood. And the Spirit is the one who testifies, because the Spirit is the truth. **7**For there are three that testify: **<sup>8</sup>** the Spirit and the water and the blood; and these three agree. **<sup>9</sup>** If we receive the testimony of men, the testimony of God is greater, for this is the testimony of God that he has borne concerning his Son. **10**Whoever believes in the Son of God has the testimony in himself. Whoever does not believe God has made him a liar, because he has not believed in the testimony that God has borne concerning his Son. **11**And this is the testimony, that God gave us eternal life, and this life is in his Son. **<sup>12</sup>**Whoever has the Son has life; whoever does not have the Son of God does not have life.

#### *Section Overview*

Building from the emphasis in the last section on proper belief in Jesus, this section emphasizes the strong witnesses, or testimonies, that support such belief (the Greek words for "testify" and "testimony," sharing the same root, occur ten times in this section). These varied but unified witnesses establish the veracity of Jesus' identity and work and are from God himself. Thus to fail to accept this testimony is to call God a liar. To believe the truth about Jesus, on the other hand, is to "have the Son" and thus have eternal life. Since John has made clear throughout the letter that all of life depends on God's Son, this section serves as an anchor to the letter. The letter opened with an affirmation of who Jesus is, and here it begins to conclude with the same theme.

#### *Section Outline*

XIV. Testimony to the Person of Christ (5:6–12)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-466-2"></span><span id="page-466-1"></span>5:6 As John turns to witnesses to bolster the confession called for in 5:5, he identifies Jesus as the one "who came by water and blood." Although this phrase is not immediately clear to modern readers, and there has been some debate about its meaning, it almost certainly refers to Jesus' baptism and death.68 Since false teachers were disputing Jesus' incarnation (4:2–3), this verse identifies Jesus in

<span id="page-466-0"></span><sup>68</sup> Cf. Akin, *1, 2, 3 John*, 195–197, for a good discussion of different interpretations. Akin, like most commentators, takes the view argued here.

terms of his earthly ministry, which began publicly with water at his baptism and concluded in blood at his death.

By saying "not by the water only but by the water and the blood," John stresses Jesus' death, perhaps suggesting that the false teachers granted the baptism but disputed the death. We cannot be certain as to the exact teachings of these specific false teachers, but we do know that a false teaching did arise in the early church that claimed the divine Christ came upon a merely human Jesus at his baptism and then left him before his death.69 In any case, John stresses the importance of belief in the historical death of the God-man, Jesus. The term "blood" also evokes the atoning nature of his death, a point testified to across the NT (e.g., Matt. 26:28; Acts 20:28; Rom. 3:25; 5:9; Eph. 1:7; Heb. 13:12).

<span id="page-467-8"></span><span id="page-467-5"></span><span id="page-467-3"></span><span id="page-467-2"></span>The lynchpin for John, though, is that the Spirit testifies to these truths. John's witness, as eyewitness and member of the apostolic band, is significant (1:1–4), but these truths do not rest on his witness alone. Rather, the Spirit of God himself bears witness. Since the Spirit is truth, his testimony settles the question. One might ask, though, how, when, and where the Spirit testifies. First, the Spirit testified to these truths in the ministry of Jesus (e.g., at his baptism; John 1:32–34), in the inspiration of OT authors who foretold him, and in bringing to remembrance for the NT authors all that Jesus said (John 14:26). Secondly, the Spirit testifies to the truth of Jesus as the Word is proclaimed (1 Cor. 2:9–16). Third, the Spirit confirms the veracity of gospel truths internally to believers (Rom. 8:16).

<span id="page-467-9"></span><span id="page-467-7"></span><span id="page-467-6"></span><span id="page-467-4"></span><span id="page-467-1"></span><span id="page-467-0"></span>5:7 OT law required that the truth of a matter be established by two or three witnesses (Deut. 19:15). John seems to appeal to this requirement, as did Jesus (Matt. 18:16) and Paul (2 Cor. 13:1). The witnesses that John presents, even though two of them reference past events (Jesus' baptism and death), presently testify to Jesus as the Son of God. In the work of the Spirit, the historical becomes homiletical as the import of that which truly occurred in the past is pressed into our hearts.70

<span id="page-467-10"></span>5:8 The three witnesses are the Spirit, the water, and the blood, all of which have just been discussed. These represent the earthly ministry of Jesus (its beginning and conclusion) and the present work of God through his Spirit. These three witnesses agree in their testimony.71 The water and blood testify that he came *to* us; the Spirit testifies that he came *for* us.72 One provides historical attestation, the other personal appropriation.

<span id="page-467-11"></span>5:9 John drives home the necessity of believing this orthodox view of Jesus with an argument from the lesser to the greater. We accept the testimony of mere humans

<sup>69</sup> A man named Cerinthus espoused these views, whether or not he or his followers are in view here. Cf. Gareth Lee Cockerill, "Cerinthus," in *The Anchor Bible Dictionary*, ed. David Noel Freedman, vol. 1 (Doubleday, 1992), 885. 70 The KJV includes further text in this verse that is not included in the ESV or most other translations. The textual evidence shows that these extra statements are a later addition to the text. For further discussion, cf. Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 236–237; Akin, *1, 2, 3 John*, 198–200.

<sup>71</sup> For discussion of the complicated Greek phrase used here (*eis to hen eisin*; lit., "are into one," translated "agree"), cf. Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 285; Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 237n21.

<sup>72</sup> Here I am borrowing language from Adolf Schlatter (cited in Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 284), though using it in a different way than he did.

when confirmed by two or more witnesses. How much more, then, should we accept the testimony of God himself, since it is the Spirit of God who bears this witness. Rhetorically, this is similar to the repeated OT phrase "Thus says the Lord." John makes it clear that God has spoken on this issue: Jesus is the divine Son of God who came in the flesh and died, and to refuse to believe this truth is to refuse to believe God.

<span id="page-468-2"></span>5:10 There are only two possible responses to this testimony—belief or unbelief and they have very different results. Belief in this message leads to the indwelling of the Spirit, so that this testimony is now within the believer as the Spirit bears witness. Unbelief is rejection of God. The one who "does not believe God has made him a liar." These are stark words, but they fit John's language throughout the letter. John is not being dramatic or ungracious. Rather, he is earnest about the eternal fate of men's souls. In light of the clear testimony of God, substantiated by the historical ministry of Jesus, the apostolic witness, and the testimony of the Spirit, John wants us to know there is no way to be neutral. God has spoken. We either trust him and believe or else we refuse to believe, which is tantamount to claiming that his testimony is untrue. We cannot, like these false teachers, claim to believe God while rejecting his testimony about his Son. Rudolf Schnackenburg puts it well: "To reject [the testimony of God] is therefore a serious evil, and to oppose it a futile project."73

<span id="page-468-3"></span><span id="page-468-1"></span>5:11 "And" here does not add a new or different idea but rather draws out an implication of the previous verse. Verses 9–10 stated that God has borne witness to the person and work of Jesus. This witness points to God's gift of eternal life in his Son. Again, John's point has not been merely abstract theology; rather, as a godly pastor he has been contending for the life of his people, reminding them that eternal life is available only through the Son.

<span id="page-468-4"></span>5:12 This verse concludes and draws together what has been said in this section. Since eternal life is found only in the Son, whoever has him has life, while whoever does not have him does not have life. To "have" the Son means to believe in him. Since such faith results in abiding in him and his abiding in the believer, it makes sense to refer to this as "having" the Son.74

#### *Response*

This section is a bold affirmation of doctrinal truth, with a resounding call to believe that truth. The absolute certainty with which John writes may sound odd or harsh to modern ears that have been trained to think such certainty unbecoming. But if God has spoken, then to be hesitant with his message is inappropriate and suggests an unwillingness to believe him. Furthermore, if his message involves the only way for people to escape eternal doom and instead find life, then clarity

<sup>73</sup> Rudolf Schnackenburg, *The Johannine Epistles,* trans. R. Fuller and I. Fuller (New York: Crossroad, 1992), 239.

<span id="page-468-0"></span><sup>74</sup> John elsewhere refers to "having" the Father (2:23) or God (2 John 9).

and boldness with this message is not callous or harsh but is the most loving thing anyone could do.

John makes clear that there is but one way to eternal life: faith in the crucified Son of God. There is no excuse for dismissing doctrine in favor of good intentions or amorphous faith. God has called us to believe certain things about his Son. Saving faith has doctrinal content. This text also strongly teaches exclusivity, the truth that salvation is found only in Christ. John's writing makes no sense if, in the end, salvation can come by sincere belief in other religions. This truth undergirds the importance and urgency of evangelism and missions.

### <span id="page-469-1"></span>1 JOHN 5:13–21

**<sup>13</sup>** I write these things to you who believe in the name of the Son of God, that you may know that you have eternal life. **14**And this is the confidence that we have toward him, that if we ask anything according to his will he hears us. **15**And if we know that he hears us in whatever we ask, we know that we have the requests that we have asked of him.

**<sup>16</sup>** If anyone sees his brother committing a sin not leading to death, he shall ask, and God*<sup>1</sup>* will give him life—to those who commit sins that do not lead to death. There is sin that leads to death; I do not say that one should pray for that. **17**All wrongdoing is sin, but there is sin that does not lead to death.

**<sup>18</sup>**We know that everyone who has been born of God does not keep on sinning, but he who was born of God protects him, and the evil one does not touch him.

**<sup>19</sup>**We know that we are from God, and the whole world lies in the power of the evil one.

**20**And we know that the Son of God has come and has given us understanding, so that we may know him who is true; and we are in him who is true, in his Son Jesus Christ. He is the true God and eternal life. **21**Little children, keep yourselves from idols.

1Greek *he*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-469-2"></span><span id="page-469-0"></span>This section summarizes the key points of the letter. The opening verse (1 John 5:13) connects the belief discussed in the last section to assurance, the theme of the rest of the section, as seen in the repeated use of "we know" (vv. 15, 18, 19, 20). As those who believe in the Son of God, we are assured of the truths highlighted in this passage. John closes with points of assurance for his dear audience in order to help them persevere. This is an important pastoral point. We need our sins to be rebuked, and we also need to be called to obedience. But the pastor must not leave us there. Rather, he must point us to the promises of the gospel, which give us a firm place to stand as we seek to persevere.

### *Section Outline*

- XV. Summary and Conclusion: Assurance (5:13–21)
	- A. Assurance of Eternal Life (5:13)
	- B. Assurance of Answered Prayer (5:14–17)
		- 1. Statement of Assurance in Prayer (5:14–15)
		- 2. Specific Example: Prayer for an Erring Brother (5:16–17)
	- C. Assurance of Spiritual Protection (5:18)
	- D. Assurance of Belonging to God (5:19)
	- E. Assurance of the Truth of Jesus (5:20)
	- F. Closing Charge (5:21)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-470-2"></span>5:13 Using another purpose statement, John summarizes his aim in writing: he writes to provide assurance of eternal life to those who hold fast to faith "in the name of the Son of God." Throughout this letter, John has been concerned with "eternal life," and in the previous section he demonstrated how possession of such life depends on believing the full truth about who Jesus is. The whole letter has been concerned to help this congregation hold on to such truth and thus to know that they have eternal life.

The Greek word order puts emphasis on their belief. John is saying, in essence, "I am writing in order to provide you assurance, that is, assurance to those who hold fast to orthodox faith in Jesus." Any pastor knows the challenge of providing assurance without providing *false* assurance. John makes clear here that the assurance on offer is available only through faith in Jesus.

<span id="page-470-3"></span><span id="page-470-1"></span>5:14 Knowing that one has eternal life leads to "confidence" in prayer. John repeats the same basic point from 3:21–22. To say that God "hears" our prayers means he hears favorably, he pays attention with the intent to answer. The prayer he hears in this way is one that is "according to his will." (Jesus makes similar remarks about prayer in John's Gospel; cf. John 14:13–14; 15:7, 16; 16:23–27). This qualification keeps us from thinking of God as our cosmic servant, here to perform whatever task we desire.

<span id="page-470-4"></span><span id="page-470-0"></span>5:15 John goes on to say that if God "hears" us in this way, he will answer us. Again, the hearing and granting are conditioned upon the request being "according to his will." The prosperity teachers who suggest we can have all the health and wealth we want, if we would just believe enough, grossly distort this text and others. In the context of this letter, John is seeking to help his readers see God not as a vending machine but as a loving Father to whom they can bring all their concerns and requests. As such a Father, he is attentive to our needs and delights to answer us,

although because he loves us he screens our requests through the filter of his wise awareness of what is best for us.

So, while we must rebuff any abuse of this text, we must also embrace what it does teach. Building on all he has taught concerning mutual abiding in God, and God's deep, adopting love for us, John calls on us to pray and make our requests known to the Father. We ought to pray in boldness, knowing that God will respond to our prayers. Marshall calls such confidence in prayer "one of the most important fruits of Christian assurance."75

<span id="page-471-3"></span>5:16 John restates another key emphasis of the letter—love for fellow believers—in light of what he has just said about prayer. Thus love for the brothers is expressed in terms of praying for the perseverance of one another. If a believer sees "his brother," a fellow believer, fall into sin, he should pray for him with the aim that God might grant him life, that is, that God might preserve this brother in the faith. The deep value and importance of life together with other believers is implied and assumed here.

However, two key questions remain: (1) What is the "sin that leads to death"? (2) Why does John "not say" we should pray for people committing such sin?

While there has been much discussion about the identity of this "sin that leads to death," we should look for clues within the context of this letter.76 John has been particularly concerned throughout the letter with sins that show that one does not have eternal life abiding in him, that is, with sins that do, in fact, lead to death. John has particularly identified such sin as rejection of belief in Jesus as Messiah and Son of God, unwillingness to obey God and pursue holiness, and failure to love fellow believers. Thus, "Sin that leads to death is deliberate refusal to believe in Jesus Christ, to follow God's commands, and to love one's brothers."77 This was the behavior of those who were seeking to deceive John's hearers (2:26). This interpretation makes the most sense within the context of the letter.

<span id="page-471-2"></span><span id="page-471-0"></span>Therefore, John is not describing a sin that can be committed accidentally or even in a moment. Yet all sin is gradual. No one reaches full degradation overnight. Rather, every sin paves the way for deeper and greater sin. Thus, John calls for believers to pray for one another lest anyone be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin (similar to Heb. 3:13) so that he eventually turns away from Christ and goes out from the company of the redeemed, proving that he was never truly saved (1 John 2:19). Marshall's challenging words are apt: "It is not characteristic of the modern church prayer meeting (if we hold one at all) that we pray for specific members who have fallen into sin by name. . . . John's words are a challenge to the quality of our intercession for others."78

<span id="page-471-1"></span>John tells us to expect such prayer for other believers to be answered: "God will give him life." This is not presumption, but we can pray boldly for one another,

<sup>75</sup> Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 245.

<sup>76</sup> For an overview of the main interpretations, cf. Akin, *1, 2, 3 John*, 208–211.

<sup>77</sup> Marshall, *Epistles of John*, 248.

<sup>78</sup> Ibid., 250–251.

1 Joh n 5:13–21 472

<span id="page-472-7"></span>knowing that as we pray for the perseverance of the saints, we pray according to God's will (5:15).

Lastly, how should we understand John's counsel regarding those who do commit a sin "leading to death"? In a letter where John has been quite blunt, his words here are very careful, almost hesitant. Notice that he *does not forbid* prayer for those who have committed such sin. He simply notes that he has "not" told us that we "should pray for that" ("I do not say . . ."). His words *leave the door open for us to pray*, and then perhaps at some point to stop praying, without feeling guilty about it.

<span id="page-472-3"></span><span id="page-472-2"></span>There came a time when God told Jeremiah to quit praying for his people (Jer. 7:16; 11:14; 14:11). Jesus told his disciples there would be a time to shake from their feet the dust of a city that would not listen (Matt. 10:14). It seems John is acknowledging that people may come to the point beyond which prayer would do no good. However, it is not always clear when this point is reached, so John does not prohibit praying for such individuals. Rather, he gives permission for such praying to cease when the time comes.

<span id="page-472-9"></span><span id="page-472-6"></span>5:17 Lest the differentiation between sins seem to downplay the gravity of sins that do not lead to death, John quickly affirms that "all wrongdoing is sin." No sin is acceptable. All sin is rebellion against God (3:4) and qualifies as "unrighteousness" or "wrongdoing." But there is a wide range of sin short of deliberate refusal to believe or obey. Thus, while we maintain the heinousness of sin, we must also maintain the greatness of God's grace and his willingness to forgive. This truth about God is what should animate our prayers for one another.

<span id="page-472-10"></span>5:18 Following the discussion of apostasy, this verse not only restates John's teaching on holiness but also offers assurance. Those who have truly been born of God do not continue in sin leading to spiritual death. When we are born of God, we are changed in such a way that we begin to fight sin, as John has already argued.

<span id="page-472-8"></span>Those born of God are protected by "he who was born of God." This could possibly refer to a fellow believer, whose prayer protects his fellow brother (cf. v. 16). However, it is perhaps more likely that this refers to Jesus, highlighting the connection between Jesus as the "only Son" and believers as adopted children. Jesus protects the children of God so that the Evil One does not "touch" them. Jesus prayed for and thus protected Peter in a similar way (Luke 22:32).

<span id="page-472-5"></span><span id="page-472-4"></span><span id="page-472-1"></span><span id="page-472-0"></span>But what does it mean that Satan cannot "touch" the protected brother? It would seem that Satan "touched" Job in one sense (Job 2:4–8, note the verb "touch" in v. 5). Jesus prayed not for his followers to be taken out of the world but for the Father to "keep" them (John 17:15). What this protection looks like can be deduced by the experience of the one "born of God." Jesus suffered and died but was ultimately resurrected. So also we may suffer and even be killed, but our spiritual life cannot be touched.

<span id="page-472-11"></span>5:19 John has been providing his readers with proofs that they are "from God." As he summarizes his message, John tells them directly, in effect, "We have been through the evidence. We are weak and fail and do stumble. But we believe, obey, and love, and so we are from God." This affirmation from the apostle must have meant much to this beleaguered congregation.

<span id="page-473-1"></span>John reminds his readers that there are two clearly distinct spheres at work in the universe. In contrast to John and his hearers, the world "lies in the power of the evil one." This is the "world" we are not to love (2:15). In contrast to the life given to believers, these people are under the domination of the Evil One. This should make John's hearers grateful while protecting them from thinking that in any way those who have departed from the church might be better off.

This also fills out the promise of protection in the previous verse. We know we are protected and that we belong to God, but we also know we currently live in enemy-occupied territory. John wants his audience to be under no illusion about the difficulty of their setting. The ultimate victory is assured, but there will be battles and casualties along the way.

<span id="page-473-2"></span>5:20 If people in the world are under the sway of the Devil, how do people move from the "world" to God? Such a transition is possible only because of the coming of Jesus. The incarnation was the divine invasion of the world in order to overthrow the usurper and rescue the people of God.

In his coming, Jesus gave us "understanding" so that we might recognize the reality of who he is. This is the language of grace. We did not in our own wisdom discern the truth of God and thus pursue him. Rather, we too were under the power of the Evil One, but by the work of Christ our eyes were opened, that we might know him (2 Tim. 2:25–26; 2 Cor. 4:3–6). Thus, John's hearers are reminded that the ultimate reason they "understand" the truth about Jesus, while others have rejected that understanding, is grace.

<span id="page-473-0"></span>In this one verse John three times describes Jesus as "true." The word used here (*alēthinos*) occurs more often in John's writings than anywhere else in the NT and refers to that which is the ultimate reality. It is most often used of God or Christ, taking on the sense of "divine."79 We have come to know the only one who can be properly called "God." As Yarbrough points out, "There is perhaps no loftier modifier for John to use as a substantive for the Son."80 Thus, after all the ways in which John has argued for a proper understanding of who Jesus is, he closes with this crescendo: "Jesus, is the true, genuine, real God." John's hearers are encouraged to hold fast to this confession despite those who teach otherwise.

<span id="page-473-3"></span>5:21 Instead of including a typical letter closing, John provides a final charge. The pastoral tone pervading the letter is sounded once more with the final use of the term of endearment "Little children." Modern readers may wonder what "idols" are in view.81 The letter has dealt not with paganism (where images were

<sup>79</sup> Ceslas Spicq, *Theological Lexicon of the New Testament*, trans. and ed. James Ernest, vol. 1 (Peabody, MA: Hendrickson, 1994), 84–85. 80 Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, 319.

<sup>81</sup> For a thorough listing of proposed identities of the "idols," cf. Raymond Brown, *The Epistles of John*, AB (New York: Doubleday, 1982), 627–628.

worshiped) but with an aberrant version of Christianity. Most likely, what John has in mind are the false views of God proclaimed by the false teachers who deny Jesus' incarnation, his messiahship, or his status as Son of God. If we worship as god any being that is not the triune God of Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, we are guilty of idolatry. John closes by urging his beloved hearers to hold fast to the one true God and to worship him only.

#### *Response*

As I write this, my wife and two of my sons are in Africa sharing the gospel in an impoverished area. At one house my wife asked a man if they could pray for him. He said, "Pray for God to give me a job, and, if he does, I will believe in him." While happy to pray for a job for this man, my wife pointed out that he was in no position to barter with God over his soul. Indeed, God may intend to use his joblessness to bring him to faith. This account illustrates a very common misconception of God and prayer. John is not saying that prayer (or even faith) is a tool we can use to get things from God. Instead, if we remember the flow of the letter, with its discussion of love of God and abiding in him, we can see that John is referring to confidence that, because of Jesus, we can be God's children. Our heavenly Father wants to bless and care for his children. But because he loves us, he will not give us things that will harm us. Thus we are encouraged to come and ask, trusting that every good thing we ask for he will grant.

# 2 JOHN

*Ray Van Neste*

INTRODUCTION TO

# <span id="page-477-0"></span>2 JOHN

*(See 1 John: Introduction to 1–3 John)*

#### *Overview*

<span id="page-477-3"></span><span id="page-477-2"></span><span id="page-477-1"></span>Second John largely addresses the interconnectedness of truth and love. The introduction (vv. 1–3) previews these two themes, which then run throughout the brief letter. In verses 4–6, John stresses that those who walk in the truth obey the command to love one another. In verses 7–11 he discusses the danger of those who distort the truth, before concluding the short epistle in verses 12–13.

#### <span id="page-477-4"></span>*Outline*

- I. Greeting (vv. 1–3)
- II. Message (vv. 4–11)
	- A. Walking in Truth and Love (vv. 4–6)
	- B. Those Who Oppose the Truth (vv. 7–11)
- III. Closing (vv. 12–13)

<span id="page-478-5"></span><span id="page-478-3"></span>**<sup>1</sup>**The elder to the elect lady and her children, whom I love in truth, and not only I, but also all who know the truth, **2**because of the truth that abides in us and will be with us forever:

**<sup>3</sup>**Grace, mercy, and peace will be with us, from God the Father and from Jesus Christ the Father's Son, in truth and love.

#### *Section Overview*

Using the standard form for beginning a letter in the Hellenistic world, John greets the church to which he writes, establishing the twin themes of the letter: truth and love. Gospel truth grounds and promotes mutual love between John, this church, and other believers.

#### *Section Outline*

I. Greeting (vv. 1–3)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-478-6"></span><span id="page-478-4"></span><span id="page-478-1"></span>1 John refers to himself simply as "the elder." As noted in the Introduction to 1–3 John, some argue that this suggests the author is someone other than the apostle John. However, elsewhere in the NT, Peter also refers to himself as an "elder" (1 Pet. 5:1), and thus such usage by an apostle is not unknown. "Elder" is the most common NT term for the pastoral office, and thus John is identifying himself particularly by this pastoral role.

The "elect lady" to whom John writes could be either a literal woman or a church referred to figuratively. Most commentators believe that John refers here to a church and its members ("her children"), using imagery common to the Bible. Through both Testaments the people of God are often referred to as a woman or bride (Isa. 54:6; 62:5; Jer. 2:2; 3:1; Ezekiel 23; Hosea 2; Eph. 5:22–31; Rev. 22:17). In 1 John, John regularly referred to believers as "children," as he does now in 2 John. Thus John uses common biblical imagery to address a local church.

<span id="page-478-2"></span><span id="page-478-0"></span>2 The emphasis in this greeting is on love and truth. John loves this church "in truth," and all who "know the truth" love this church as well (v. 1). Furthermore, the reason for this love is "the truth that abides" in believers (v. 2). Even the "grace, mercy, and peace" that come to believers from God are "in truth and love" (v. 3). This repetition can seem dizzying to modern readers, but the emphasis on and interconnectedness of love and truth is clear. John's statement that he loves this

church "in truth" could simply mean "truly" or "sincerely." However, considering the other uses of "truth" here, it seems likely that more is intended. John's love is "in the truth," that is, rooted in the gospel truth they hold in common. This is why all who know the truth also love this church.

Shared commitment to the gospel produces love. This is what verse 2 makes clear, stating that the basis of such love is "the truth." Thus, truth (the gospel) is the basis for Christian unity and love. We cannot increase our love for one another by downplaying truth. Rather, holding to core gospel truths and our shared allegiance to them is what will increase our love for fellow believers. Since this truth abides and will be with us forever, our love also will abide and persevere. Christian love is based not on our performance or ability but on the truth of the gospel.

3 Hellenistic letters typically included a health wish in their greetings. John does something similar here, pronouncing a gospel blessing that "will be with us." While "grace, mercy, and peace" is a fairly conventional triad in Christian writing, the terms are not as common in John. He is pronouncing God's covenant blessings on his people, reminding them of God's willingness to pardon their sin and of their favorable relationship with God.1

#### *Response*

This text strongly emphasizes Christian love and fellowship. Since "all who know the truth" are said to love the specific church in view here, we should understand that all Christians should love every church that knows and upholds the truth of the gospel. Failure to love others who hold fast to the gospel exposes a failure to truly grasp that gospel.

<span id="page-479-0"></span>Too easily, people separate love and truth. Some say they love people too much to be too concerned with doctrinal error. They see it as unloving to discriminate between true and false teaching. Others affirm the importance of doctrinal precision but fail to express the love for other believers this doctrine should produce. Either end of this spectrum is a grave error. There is no "either/or" in this arena, no room for considering it safer to err in one direction or the other. The interconnectedness of love and truth shown here is crucial for Christian living and witness.

<sup>1</sup> Robert Yarbrough, *1–3 John*, BECNT (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker Academic, 2008), 336.

<span id="page-480-3"></span>**<sup>4</sup>** I rejoiced greatly to find some of your children walking in the truth, just as we were commanded by the Father. **5**And now I ask you, dear lady—not as though I were writing you a new commandment, but the one we have had from the beginning—that we love one another. **6**And this is love, that we walk according to his commandments; this is the commandment, just as you have heard from the beginning, so that you should walk in it.

#### *Section Overview*

John commends the love demonstrated by this church and urges them to continue in it. He continues to show how love and truth are intertwined by defining love as obedience to God's commands, which are truth.

#### *Section Outline*

- II. Message (vv. 4–11)
	- A. Walking in Truth and Love (vv. 4–6)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-480-2"></span>4 As noted above, "your children" refers to members of the church to which John writes. He has received word that members of this church were faithfully living in obedience to the commands of God, and he rejoiced greatly in this news. Not only does sharing in the truth cause Christians to love one another; it also grants them deep joy in one another's obedience. In the previous section, John said that if we love the truth, we love people who believe that truth. Now John states that if we love truth, we love to see people live in accordance with that truth.

<span id="page-480-4"></span><span id="page-480-1"></span>5 To walk in truth, i.e., in accordance with God's commands, requires loving fellow believers. Almost certainly John refers here to the teaching of Jesus recorded in John's Gospel (John 13:34–35). This is "not . . . a new commandment" for the recipients but is one they have heard from the earliest days of their Christian experience. This command is even rooted in the old covenant (e.g., Lev. 19:18). Thus this command to love fellow believers goes back to the beginning of their Christian experience and, in fact, back even further to the beginning of Scripture.

<span id="page-480-0"></span>6 As is common for John, he does not leave love undefined. A misunderstanding of love is not unique to today; it has been common throughout human history. Proper love is shaped and informed by the commands of God. To love another person is to do what God commands us to do (or not do) in regard to them and is to help them obey God's commands. Any action toward the other person that violates God's commands—no matter how well intended or how romantically inclined—is not love. Any action that encourages or helps that person to avoid obedience to God's commands—no matter how nice the motivation—is not love.

<span id="page-481-1"></span><span id="page-481-0"></span>Some understand "the commandment" in the latter half of verse 6 to refer back to the love command (v. 5). However, it seems best to understand this as referring more generally to the fact that Christianity has a basic, nonnegotiable command structure (referred to in v. 4). From the beginning of their Christian experience, John's readers have known that God commands and expects obedience. This reminder of the necessity of obedience sets up the discussion of false teachers, which follows in the next section.

#### *Response*

Loving fellow believers is central to the gospel. Real love for truth always leads to love for others who likewise love the truth. Furthermore, this love among believers should lead us to rejoice greatly in the obedience of other believers. Does the faithfulness of other believers move you to deep joy? If not, your loves are out of order. This deep affection for one another, and the resulting pleasure in one another's obedience, is what creates a thriving church community where people care for, help, and encourage one another, seeking our joy in obedience to God.

Additionally, John's pastoral joy comes not from some sort of recognition from others but from the faithful obedience of his people. If pastors find their satisfaction in recognition by the broader world (culturally or denominationally), they will focus on what outsiders see or hear. If we derive our satisfaction from the faithful obedience of our people, however, our gaze will be settled more upon them, producing interest in and concern for their daily lives. Thus counseling, caring, discipling, and spending time with them will no longer be a hindrance from "more important work" but will be a pathway to joy.

This text is vital in a day in which many declare it to be unloving to name sin as sin, a day in which many define love as indulgence, simply letting people do as they please. It is loving to affirm people in obedience, to call people to obedience, and to rebuke disobedience. As Matthew Henry stated, "It is a sign that our friends are faithful indeed if, in love to our souls, they will not suffer sin upon us, nor let us alone in it."2 Of course, this rebuke should be given graciously, but if we fail to give it, we fail to love.

The reality of grace does not negate the necessity of obedience. Some wellmeaning people claim that "Christianity is not about rules but about relationship." This phrase, however, is misguided. One cannot read the NT long without realizing that commands and rules occur frequently. God is King and therefore has every

<sup>2</sup> Matthew Henry, *Matthew Henry's Commentary on the Whole Bible*, new modern ed., 6 vols. (Peabody, MA: Hendrickson, 1991), 3:779.

<span id="page-482-1"></span>right to tell his creatures how to live. We err seriously when suggesting that rules and relationships do not go together. In fact, any healthy relationship includes rules. Of course, Christianity is not merely a list of rules; it is a relationship a relationship with God the Father Almighty, whose commands must be obeyed.

### 2 JOHN 7–11

**<sup>7</sup>**For many deceivers have gone out into the world, those who do not confess the coming of Jesus Christ in the flesh. Such a one is the deceiver and the antichrist. **8**Watch yourselves, so that you may not lose what we*<sup>1</sup>* have worked for, but may win a full reward. **9**Everyone who goes on ahead and does not abide in the teaching of Christ, does not have God. Whoever abides in the teaching has both the Father and the Son. **<sup>10</sup>** If anyone comes to you and does not bring this teaching, do not receive him into your house or give him any greeting, **<sup>11</sup>** for whoever greets him takes part in his wicked works.

1Some manuscripts *you*

#### *Section Overview*

This section contains the central concern of the letter: avoiding the lure of false teachers. John desires his hearers to know that such deceivers always exist, and so we must be on guard. The remedy to false teaching is to hold fast to faithful doctrine ("the teaching of Christ") and to have no part in supporting such false teachers.

#### *Section Outline*

- II. Message (vv. 4–11) . . .
	- B. Those Who Oppose Truth (vv. 7–11)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-482-0"></span>7 The reason John's readers must continue in obedience and love for one another is the presence of "many deceivers" in the world, who will try to beguile them. Believers need to persevere in love for one another so that they may help protect one another from these evil influences.

John notes that there are "many" such false teachers, and, indeed, false teaching features prominently throughout the NT. The specific false teachers in view here deny the incarnation. They are Grinches seeking to steal Christmas. Some have suggested that these were early Gnostics, but we do not know the full content of their teaching. A denial of the incarnation would seem to downplay the full humanity

of Christ. We should see that any deviation from full biblical Christology leads to false teaching. This is not merely an academic issue. The salvation promised in Christ, the loving fellowship he creates, and the future hope we await all depend on Jesus' being who the Scriptures claim him to be. Anyone who distorts the biblical portrait of the person of Christ is a "deceiver" and is literally anti-Christ.

<span id="page-483-5"></span>8 "Watch yourselves," a plural imperative, is a call for the church community as a whole to watch out for each of its members. Guarding against deception is not only a pastoral duty but also the duty of each member of the flock. While pastors lead the work of overseeing souls (Heb. 13:17), all members play a part. Perseverance is a community project.

<span id="page-483-3"></span><span id="page-483-2"></span>The key concern in this verse is the potential result of failing to be vigilant. John is clearly concerned that his readers persevere in the faith and thus show themselves to be true believers (1 John 2:18–20). He has worked so that they might understand the gospel, repent and believe, and persevere in the faith. If they turn away from the gospel to false teaching, they will show themselves to be unbelievers and thus squander what John and others within the church have worked for. John desires them to persevere and thus win the full reward of their faith on the final day. The use of "reward" (*misthos*) ought not concern us. Jesus and the apostles commonly used this language to refer to the eternal benefits of trusting Christ and persevering in that faith and in the good deeds it produces (e.g., Luke 6:23; John 4:36; 1 Cor. 3:8, 14; Rev. 22:12).

<span id="page-483-6"></span><span id="page-483-1"></span><span id="page-483-0"></span>9 This verse clarifies further that John is concerned for the eternal salvation of his readers. Those who embrace the teaching of the deceivers and thus fail to "abide in the teaching of Christ" do not have God. They are not believers. Abiding, or "remaining," points to persevering in proper doctrine. Abandoning this doctrine is here described as "[going] on ahead." These false teachers are overly progressive. Not content with orthodox teaching, they "advance" into heresy.

John makes clear that one cannot have the Father without the Son. If one abandons the proper teaching concerning the Son, he cannot have the Father, but if he holds fast to the right understanding of the Son, he has both Father and Son (on "having" God, cf. comment on 1 John 5:12).

<span id="page-483-8"></span><span id="page-483-7"></span><span id="page-483-4"></span>10–11 Because false teaching is so serious—with the potential to damn souls we must not support it in any way. Traveling teachers in the ancient world were able to do their work only as people took them into their homes, providing food and shelter. In 3 John, John encourages the church to provide this support for orthodox teachers, but here he tells Christians they must *not* support *heretical* teachers. The greeting prohibited here is not a casual "hello" but a Christian greeting that would denote acceptance and prayer for God's blessing. This is not a call to be uncivil or rude; rather, it is a call for clarity as to who is, and who is not, recognized as a fellow Christian. To encourage or support false teachers is to participate in their "wicked works" of deceiving people, leading to their damnation.

#### *Response*

The NT is clear concerning the necessity of perseverance. True faith, though it may waver, continues. Believers must, then, be wary of false teaching while holding fast to faithful doctrine and to one another. Grasping the reality of this call to perseverance will help Christians understand why the Bible places such importance on our need of the church and of faithful soul-care within it. These are God's ordained means for enabling us to persevere. No one ought to expect to persevere in the faith while neglecting these resources.

We must, like John, be willing to identify false teaching that compromises the gospel. We must not regard everyone who disagrees with us as false teachers, but we must resist any who distort the biblical understanding of the person of Christ. No true shepherd will ignore the presence of wolves near his flock, nor be content with general warnings. Care for the flock requires direct, explicit warning as well as instruction.

<span id="page-484-1"></span><span id="page-484-0"></span>Verses 10–11 do not imply that believers cannot reach out to people of other faiths or have them into their homes. Believers can and should reach out to unbelievers in this way. What they must not do is give aid, encouragement, or monetary support to any who teach an aberrant view of the gospel. Believers must be diligent and careful when supporting any ministry. They should investigate what such ministries teach and seek guidance from a faithful pastor.

## 2 JOHN 12–13

**<sup>12</sup>**Though I have much to write to you, I would rather not use paper and ink. Instead I hope to come to you and talk face to face, so that our joy may be complete.

**<sup>13</sup>**The children of your elect sister greet you.

#### *Section Overview*

In a simple conclusion to the letter, John again expresses his affection for this congregation and his hope to follow this letter with a personal visit.

#### *Section Outline*

III. Closing (vv. 12–13)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-484-2"></span>12 John uses the technology available to him to communicate with the people under his care, but nothing compares with personal, face-to-face interaction. This is what he longs for. The purpose of John's communication by letter and in person is the joy that he and his people will share. This is a pastor's heart—longing for the joy of his people, sharing that joy, and knowing that such joy will be found in conformity with the truths of Christ.

<span id="page-485-3"></span><span id="page-485-0"></span>13 "Elect sister" refers to another church, one at which John is stationed at the time of writing, just as "elect lady" in verse 1 refers to the church to which he is writing. As in 3 John, John is concerned with sharing greetings, thus fostering relationships between churches.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-485-1"></span>The goal of a pastor's labor with his people and of interaction between church members is shared joy in Christ (v. 4). Knowing that obedience to the Word of God is the path to joy, Christians must encourage one another in this obedience, so that they might know the joy of Christ. Like John, we must make use of whatever means available to interact with and help other believers, knowing all the while that nothing compares with real physical presence. The completion of our joy, that is, our perseverance in the faith, will be best served by regular face-to-face interactions with a faithful church community.

# 3 JOHN

*Ray Van Neste*

#### INTRODUCTION TO

# <span id="page-489-1"></span>3 JOHN

*(See 1 John: Introduction to 1–3 John)*

#### *Overview*

Third John is the shortest book of the NT.1 This brief letter is built around John's description of three men: Gaius, Diotrephes, and Demetrius. Gaius, the recipient of the letter, is commended and serves as a positive example of faithfulness, particularly in his support of faithful traveling preachers. Diotrephes is a negative counterexample, being arrogant, rebellious, and divisive. Most likely, the behavior of Diotrephes is the primary occasion of the letter. With the mention of Demetrius, John returns briefly to a positive example before closing the letter. These are real people, but they serve as examples as well, supporting John's call not to imitate evil but to imitate good (v. 11).

#### <span id="page-489-2"></span>*Outline*

- I. Greeting (vv. 1–4)
- II. Body (vv. 5–12)
	- A. Commendation for Support of Missionaries (vv. 5–8)
	- B. Critique of Diotrephes (vv. 9–10)
	- C. Demetrius and Imitation (vv. 11–12)
- III. Letter Closing (vv. 13–15)

<span id="page-489-0"></span><sup>1</sup> Although 3 John has more verses than 2 John, it has fewer words.

## 3 JOHN 1–4

<span id="page-490-4"></span>**<sup>1</sup>**The elder to the beloved Gaius, whom I love in truth.

**<sup>2</sup>**Beloved, I pray that all may go well with you and that you may be in good health, as it goes well with your soul. **3**For I rejoiced greatly when the brothers*<sup>1</sup>* came and testified to your truth, as indeed you are walking in the truth. **<sup>4</sup>** I have no greater joy than to hear that my children are walking in the truth.

1Or *brothers and sisters*. In New Testament usage, depending on the context, the plural Greek word *adelphoi* (translated "brothers") may refer either to *brothers* or to *brothers and sisters*; also verses 5, 10

#### *Overview*

In keeping with the standard letter greeting of the time, John greets Gaius. John's concern with the interconnectedness of love and truth is stated clearly. John identifies himself as a pastor ("elder"), and his pastoral heart is evident.

#### *Section Outline*

I. Greeting (vv. 1–4)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-490-3"></span><span id="page-490-2"></span><span id="page-490-1"></span>1 John identifies himself simply as "the elder," as he did in 2 John, highlighting his pastoral role. More striking is his repetition of terms for love in regard to Gaius. He is "beloved" and one "whom I love in truth." Then, three more times in the letter Gaius is addressed as "Beloved" (vv. 2, 5, 11). Some translations render this Greek word (*agapētos*) as "dear friend," but this is too weak, even if "beloved" is less commonly used today. There is no need to see these terms as mere formality, particularly in these letters that stress so often the importance of Christian love. John not only urges deep love for fellow believers—he also exemplifies it.

<span id="page-490-0"></span>We do not know anything about Gaius beyond what is mentioned in this letter. This was a common name, and it is unlikely that this is the same Gaius mentioned by Paul in 1 Corinthians 1:14 and Romans 16:23. John says he loves Gaius "in truth." As noted in 2 John, "in truth" conveys the sincerity of John's love, but even more it shows that the love shared between these friends is rooted in the truth revealed in Jesus Christ. Real friendship is always rooted in a common bond, whether fleeting or significant. This friendship is rooted in ultimate truth.

<span id="page-490-5"></span>2 A health wish or prayer was common in the opening of Greco-Roman letters, as it still is in letters today. John prays for good health and overall well-being for Gaius

in keeping with the health of Gaius's soul. The word translated "soul" here ( *psychē*) refers not to the immaterial in contrast to the material but to the whole of life. In Christian usage this would include one's relationship with God. Thus, John prays for Gaius's health and well-being in all aspects of life. This comprehensiveness in prayer is helpful in light of imbalances that are all too common. Some prosperity teachers have seized on this verse as supporting the idea that faithful Christians should expect good health at all times. Such is a terrible misreading of this verse, as well as the rest of Scripture, particularly since we rest our faith on the suffering of an innocent Messiah.

<span id="page-491-0"></span>3 Some fellow believers ("brothers") have told John about Gaius's faithful living. As elsewhere in John's letters, "truth" is not merely an *idea* but is something to be *lived*. Gaius's "truth" mentioned here refers to his behavior, as is clarified by the following phrase, "walking in the truth." Gaius is living in accord with the truths proclaimed in Christianity. This causes John to "rejoice greatly." All who truly love God's truth find great joy in seeing others live out this truth.

<span id="page-491-2"></span>4 John says it is his greatest joy to hear that his "children" (believers he has pastored and instructed) are living faithfully. This is the heart of a pastor, and it should be the heart of every believer. If we love people and love God's truth, we will rejoice greatly when people live out this truth.

#### *Response*

Some Christians today think it is somehow "less spiritual" to pray for physical health as compared to "more spiritual" matters. In response to those who seem to pray for nothing other than the latest surgery, some believers long to pray for deeper things. John gives us a good example of praying for health and well-being. We need not try to be "more spiritual" than the Bible. On the other hand, John's example pushes us to include all of life in our prayers, praying for ourselves and others, that our souls may prosper as well.

<span id="page-491-1"></span>Verses 3–4 are a beautiful portrait of a pastor. Just as parents take great pride and joy in the maturing of their children, so pastors take great joy in the faithful living of those they serve. They cannot be content with simply the production of sermons or the building of "ministries" or fame; instead they find deepest joy in the spiritual well-being of individuals to whom they minister.

### <span id="page-492-0"></span>3 JOHN 5–8

<span id="page-492-2"></span>**5**Beloved, it is a faithful thing you do in all your efforts for these brothers, strangers as they are, **6**who testified to your love before the church. You will do well to send them on their journey in a manner worthy of God. **7**For they have gone out for the sake of the name, accepting nothing from the Gentiles. **8**Therefore we ought to support people like these, that we may be fellow workers for the truth.

#### *Section Overview*

One of the evidences that Gaius is "walking in the truth" (v. 3) is that he supports those who are sent out by the churches to preach the gospel in other regions. In affirming Gaius's practice, John demonstrates the propriety and importance of supporting faithful missionaries.

#### *Section Outline*

- II. Body (vv. 5–12)
	- A. Commendation for Support of Missionaries (vv. 5–8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-492-5"></span><span id="page-492-3"></span>5 This section now elaborates on the specific behavior of Gaius that has led to his commendation by John. Gaius has been supporting fellow believers ("brothers") who "have gone out for the sake of the name" (v. 7), that is, they have served as traveling preachers or missionaries. Although these men were believers, they were not personally known to Gaius ("strangers as they are"). But this did not prevent Gaius from supporting them, demonstrating that his efforts were rooted not in familiarity but in commitment to the spread of the gospel.

<span id="page-492-4"></span><span id="page-492-1"></span>6 In the first century, traveling teachers were dependent on the hospitality of churches to provide housing and food in order to complete their task. This was seen in the warning in 2 John 10 against supporting unorthodox teachers. The *Didache* (a late-first- or early-second-century document) seeks to aid Christians in differentiating between faithful teachers who ought to be supported and false teachers or opportunists who seek to take advantage of such hospitality. Gaius has rightly discerned that the brothers in view here are faithful teachers, and he has demonstrated Christian love by supporting them.

This is one of the most significant passages in the NT concerning missionary support. The "brothers" in view here have been sent to preach the gospel ("for the sake of the name"). John affirms the work of supporting such servants of the gospel. Care and support given to them is referred to as "love," because love, for John (and for the rest of the NT authors), is affection that leads to the meeting of needs. These traveling preachers had reported back to the church about the support and care given by Gaius.

John commends the support of such workers, telling Gaius he will do well to support them "in a manner worthy of God." This is a striking standard for missionary support! It was common in the ancient world (as in many places today) to expect a messenger to be treated as if he were the one who sent him. Thus, those who go out for the sake of preaching the message of Jesus should be supported in a manner worthy of Jesus himself. This obviously rules out any halfhearted, ham-fisted approach to support and instead calls for glad, gracious generosity of the sort the Macedonian churches had demonstrated and Paul had praised (2 Cor. 8:1–5).

<span id="page-493-2"></span><span id="page-493-0"></span>7 The reason these people should be given such strong support is that they "have gone out for the sake of the name." One's "name" refers to one's reputation and character. These brothers have left behind familiar settings of home in order to spread the fame of the name of Jesus. Their labors are not for their own glorification (their names are not even mentioned) but for the exalting of Jesus. The body of Christ should support efforts exalting Christ. Efforts to exalt man, however, have no right to the support of God's people.

John states that these preachers accepted "nothing from the Gentiles." The term here translated "Gentiles" is not the typical word translated "Gentiles" elsewhere in the NT (*ethnos*). It is instead a word (*ethnikos*) that, while still referring to an outsider status, emphasizes that which is "*unbelieving*, *worldly*, *polytheistic*."2 These gospel servants did not look to unbelievers to support their ministries. The children of God ought not look to the Devil's house for support of their work—it is the church's job to support gospel ministries.

<span id="page-493-3"></span><span id="page-493-1"></span>8 This verse draws together the point of the paragraph. Gaius has been commended for supporting faithful traveling preachers, and John makes clear his application that "we" all "ought to support" such people. John also adds a final motivation for this support: by supporting them we become "fellow workers for the truth." Supporters share in the work of those whom they support (just as in 2 John 11, where those who support heretical teachers share in their sin). Those who love the truth seek to work for it, and can do so by taking that truth to new areas or by supporting those who do.

#### *Response*

John sets a high standard indeed, and one that bears some pondering when churches consider their participation with missionaries in terms of money, engagement, encouragement, and prayer. The church is to support this mission work and not to expect the world to do so. John's teaching is not intended to prevent an *unbeliever* from supporting a well-digging or other humanitarian project led by Christians, but it is telling *the church* to shoulder the responsibility of taking the gospel to the nations. As we support those who go out to proclaim the gospel, we have a hand in the work that is done. This is an appeal to gospel-rooted selfinterest, the desire to be a part of as much kingdom work as we can in the short lives that we have. We can multiply our impact by supporting others.

### 3 JOHN 9–10

<span id="page-494-3"></span>**<sup>9</sup>** I have written something to the church, but Diotrephes, who likes to put himself first, does not acknowledge our authority. **<sup>10</sup>** So if I come, I will bring up what he is doing, talking wicked nonsense against us. And not content with that, he refuses to welcome the brothers, and also stops those who want to and puts them out of the church.

#### *Section Overview*

In contrast to the positive example of Gaius, John describes the wickedness of Diotrephes, who is opposing John's authority and disrupting the faithful work of the church.

#### *Section Outline*

- II. Body (vv. 5–12) . . .
	- B. Critique of Diotrephes (vv. 9–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-494-2"></span>9 Diotrephes does not demonstrate love but rather "refuses to welcome the brothers" (v. 10). John has written to the church where Gaius and Diotrephes are both members, but it seems that Diotrephes has prevented the letter from being read. In Diotrephes, the infection of personal ambition has swollen into rebellion.

<span id="page-494-1"></span><span id="page-494-0"></span>The first thing said about Diotrephes is that he "likes to put himself first" (v. 9). This is a striking description of arrogance. We do not know the substance of the disagreement between John and Diotrephes, but such selfish ambition is enough to cause trouble. Scripture is clear about God's distaste for human pride. In the list in Proverbs 6:16–17 of things the Lord hates, "haughty eyes" heads the list, and wisdom later declares, "Pride and arrogance . . . I hate" (Prov. 8:13). Furthermore, "Everyone who is arrogant in heart is an abomination to the Lord; be assured, he <span id="page-495-1"></span>will not go unpunished" (Prov. 16:5). Diotrephes's self-absorption has made him a hindrance to the church and an opponent of the apostle John.

Diotrephes's arrogance has led to rebellion, as John reports that he "does not acknowledge our authority." Diotrephes is now willing to disregard the authority of John—an apostle, one of the Twelve (and among the inner circle of three), one who was at the crucifixion, who visited the empty tomb, and who talked with the risen Christ.

10 Diotrephes's arrogance and rebellion also led to slander, as he was "talking wicked nonsense against" John ("us" could be an "editorial plural" for John or might include Gaius and others who were in agreement with John). To resist proper authority almost always requires speaking evil against that authority, heedless of the warning of Proverbs 10:18: "Whoever utters slander is a fool."

<span id="page-495-4"></span><span id="page-495-2"></span><span id="page-495-0"></span>Lastly, Diotrephes foments division in the church not only by refusing hospitality to faithful teachers but also by preventing others from providing such hospitality and by driving out those who, like Gaius, seek to engage in this "faithful" work (cf. 3 John 5). While the NT affirms the importance of proper church discipline even to the point of excommunication (1 Corinthians 5), Diotrephes is abusing this practice by putting out people who are seeking to be faithful. Diotrephes is the forebear of those who act as if they "own" the church and can operate it according to their own ideas or desires. Such leaders will not fare well when eventually confronted by the true Lord of the church.

<span id="page-495-6"></span>As the representative of the Lord of the church, John is prepared to confront Diotrephes upon his visit (cf. also 3 John 14). He is prepared to deal directly and firmly with one who is harming the church by his opposition to the truth. When John comes, he will not ignore Diotrephes in hopes that he will do better; rather, he will "bring up what he is doing." John will call attention to the wicked actions of Diotrephes and call him to repentance. True love does not indulge wrongdoing but is always in accord with truth, desiring what is best for others and calling them to align with that same truth.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-495-5"></span><span id="page-495-3"></span>One of the insidious things about pride is how it blinds us to its power. As wrong as Diotrephes's actions clearly are to us, we nevertheless emulate him whenever we disregard the plain teaching of the NT, for the NT is the apostolic teaching handed down to us. Refusing to acknowledge proper authority is a common issue in the Western church today, to the extent that many do not even recognize the church as having any authority. Yet, Hebrews 13:17 clearly commands, "Obey your leaders and submit to them, for they are keeping watch over your souls, as those who will have to give an account." We would do well to examine ourselves honestly to see if we are submitting willingly to proper authority.

### 3 JOHN 11–12

<span id="page-496-0"></span>**<sup>11</sup>**Beloved, do not imitate evil but imitate good. Whoever does good is from God; whoever does evil has not seen God. **12**Demetrius has received a good testimony from everyone, and from the truth itself. We also add our testimony, and you know that our testimony is true.

#### *Section Overview*

In contrast to wicked Diotrephes, John commends the example of Demetrius. John stresses the importance of finding good examples to emulate.

#### *Section Outline*

- II. Body (vv. 5–12) . . .
	- C. Demetrius and Imitation (vv. 11–12)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-496-1"></span>11 John returns his attention to Gaius, again addressing him as "beloved." The call not to imitate evil is an encouragement to avoid responding with evil to the evil of Diotrephes. Gaius must not stoop to his level. "Doing good" refers here to faithful living, which is one's proper response to the gospel. The NT is clear that while salvation is not earned by works, it always *results in* good works. Therefore, those who, rather than doing good, live lives marked by evil "[have] not seen God"—they have not come to saving knowledge of him.

12 Immediately after commending "good" and those who do good, John introduces another faithful brother, Demetrius. It seems likely that Demetrius was tasked by God with delivering this letter to Gaius. It was common, in the body of ancient letters, to commend the letter-bearer to the letter's recipient, because the one bringing the letter often played a key role in interpreting the letter as well.3 With testimony from three sources, John assures Gaius that Demetrius can be trusted. First, "everyone" (believers in the location from which John writes) commends him. Demetrius has the full commendation of the local church. Second, the "truth itself," that is, the gospel, commends Demetrius. For the gospel to commend someone means that person's life conforms to the truths of the gospel. This is similar to John's statement earlier that Gaius is "walking in the truth" (v. 3). This also means that Demetrius passes the test of verse 11—his life is marked by obedi-

<sup>3</sup> Cf. E. R. Richards, *Paul and First-Century Letter Writing* (Downers Grove, IL: IVP Academic, 2004), 207–209.

ence ("good"), and thus he is "from God." Lastly, John himself ("we"), the apostolic witness, commends Demetrius.

#### *Response*

The temptation to respond to evil with evil is terribly common, and, far too often, seductively compelling. It is easy to convince ourselves that we must resort to evil in order to combat evil, but this line of reasoning fails to trust that God will eventually judge all evil. The Bible regularly commands us to leave such judgment to God and to carry on with doing what is right. As people who are "from God," we must be faithful in doing good, despite what is done to us—lest we become evildoers ourselves.

<span id="page-497-1"></span>This text also touches on the importance of good models for imitation. We do not learn merely in the abstract; as a matter of course, humans cannot help but imitate that which is around them. We must offer good models to ourselves, our children, and our church. We do so, of course, by engaging in life with godly saints. We can also do so by reading biographies and writings of faithful men and women who have gone before us.

### 3 JOHN 13–15

**<sup>13</sup>** I had much to write to you, but I would rather not write with pen and ink. **<sup>14</sup>** I hope to see you soon, and we will talk face to face. **<sup>15</sup>**Peace be to you. The friends greet you. Greet the friends, each by name.

#### *Section Overview*

John closes his letter with standard greetings infused with Christian elements, stating his desire to see Gaius.

#### *Section Outline*

III. Letter Closing (vv. 13–15)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-497-0"></span>13–14 John's high regard for direct personal interaction is striking. That is not to say that written communication should be avoided; after all, it is only because the Spirit prompted John to write that this letter has become part of the NT canon. The key point in this verse is John's pastoral concern and love for those to whom he writes.

3 Joh n 13–15 498

15 "Peace" here refers not only to the absence of conflict (though no doubt it contains hope for resolution with Diotrephes) but also includes "God's covenant blessing, protection, and provision in all its fullness."4

John gives and extends greetings, fostering connections between believers in different churches. The use of "friends" as a designation for other believers is uncommon in the NT; here it highlights the love John encourages among believers. Continuing the theme of personal care, John calls for the friends to be greeted "each by name" (*kat' onoma*.).

#### *Response*

John is no aloof pastor checking items off a list so he can get on with more important or interesting matters. Here is a busy pastor dealing with controversy in a way that clearly demonstrates his love and care for individuals in the church. He can communicate from a distance and does so, but he longs to see them, to be in their presence. Then he can really discern how they are faring and ensure that he is doing everything possible for their well-being. Furthermore, the church is not merely a collective group to him. He asks for them to be greeted "by name." It is doubtful whether people can be pastored merely as a group, as if a pastor could oversee souls if he does not even know their names.

A solid and helpful commentary. Akin is conversant with linguistic and structural issues and often provides the best concise listing of different interpretations of a passage.

Though older, the solid exegesis naturally interwoven with insightful reflection and application makes this a must-read. Marshall is very pastoral and is the easiest to read straight through.

- Rainbow, Paul A. *Johannine Theology*. Downers Grove, IL: IVP Academic, 2014. The most helpful survey of the theology of all the books attributed to John (including Revelation). Arranged by topic, it is helpful particularly for understanding how John deals with key concepts such as the "world."
- Schuchard, Bruce. *1–3 John*. Concordia Commentary. St. Louis: Concordia, 2012. Schuchard is quite thorough, with a detailed discussion of the Greek text and significant theological reflection. He also gives attention to linguistic and structural issues.
