#### *Comment*

<span id="page-614-10"></span><span id="page-614-8"></span><span id="page-614-7"></span><span id="page-614-4"></span><span id="page-614-3"></span><span id="page-614-0"></span>6:1–2 The Lamb begins to break the seven seals on the scroll. When the first seal is broken, one of the four living creatures summons the first rider to come. The first four seals are correlated with four horses, echoing Zechariah 1:8–11 and 6:1–8, where four differently colored horses and four chariots with various kinds of horses patrol the earth. The first horse in Revelation 6 is a white horse, whose rider has a bow and a crown. This rider conquers as he roams the earth. Interpreters have radically different views as to what is symbolized here. Some have argued the first rider is the beast of Revelation 13, riding a white horse as a parody of Christ's riding a white horse (Rev. 19:11). The beast conquers the saints, as we see elsewhere in Revelation (11:7; 13:7). Such a reading is possible, but it is not clear that this conquering refers to persecution of the saints or that the rider is a parody. Others argue, more plausibly, that the seal represents continued wars plaguing the human race. Such an interpretation may be correct, but it seems significant that the only other rider of a white horse in Revelation is Jesus (19:11), and the next seal has to do with war. In Revelation 19 Jesus comes on the white horse to judge the wicked, but here he conquers through the spread of the gospel to the ends of the earth. Such a reading fits with Jesus' prediction that the gospel would spread throughout the world before the end arrives (Matt. 24:14; 28:19; Mark 13:10). One characteristic of the present age is the proclamation of the gospel to all peoples in all places. Amid the woes and sufferings of the present age, the gospel continues to be proclaimed and to triumph throughout the world.

<span id="page-614-9"></span><span id="page-614-5"></span><span id="page-614-1"></span>6:3–4 When the Lamb breaks the second seal, one of the four living creatures summons a red horse. The rider has a sword and takes peace from the earth. Armies fight and kill one another because of disagreements over land, material goods, or other matters that incite hatred. Jesus predicted there would be "wars and rumors <span id="page-615-6"></span><span id="page-615-5"></span>of wars" in this age (Matt. 24:6). He declared, "Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom" (Matt. 24:7). The coming of the Christ did not put an immediate end to war. Indeed, war and strife will persist until he comes again; no matter how many peace treaties are signed, war breaks out again.

<span id="page-615-10"></span><span id="page-615-3"></span>6:5–6 The Lamb breaks the third seal, and a living creature again issues a summons to come. This time a black horse comes forth with scales in the hand of the rider. Food is being measured out for man, but it is woefully lacking (cf. Ezek. 4:10–11). A denarius is a day's wages, but there is scarcely enough food if one can buy only a quart of wheat with a day's wage or three quarts of barley for the same. The sparing of the olive oil and wine may mean that the rich continue to consume luxury items or that the famine doesn't touch all the necessities of life. It is difficult to decide between these two, but the latter is slightly more probable, for oil and wine weren't just luxuries. Jesus predicted that "famines" would take place before his coming (Matt. 24:7), and John reinforces that message here.

<span id="page-615-11"></span>6:7–8 The Lamb breaks the fourth seal, and a living creature calls the next horse to come forth. John sees a pale green horse. The rider on this horse is Death, and Hades, standing for the realm of death, follows close behind. Death and Hades are personified as the great enemies of human existence, and hence they are virtually demonic forces. Life on earth is full of sorrow and desolation as a significant portion of the world experiences war, famine, disease, and death inflicted by wild animals (cf. Jer. 14:12; Ezek. 5:17; 29:5; 33:27). The judgment echoes Ezekiel 14:21, "How much more when I send upon Jerusalem my four disastrous acts of judgment, sword, famine, wild beasts, and pestilence, to cut off from it man and beast!" Life is marked by sorrow, death, and grief.

<span id="page-615-14"></span><span id="page-615-13"></span><span id="page-615-12"></span><span id="page-615-9"></span><span id="page-615-8"></span><span id="page-615-7"></span><span id="page-615-4"></span><span id="page-615-2"></span><span id="page-615-1"></span><span id="page-615-0"></span>6:9 The opening of the fifth seal is different, for on this occasion no horse is summoned. Instead John sees the souls of those who had been martyred because of their testimony and their allegiance to the word of God. The use of the term "souls" indicates the day of resurrection hasn't come yet. Why are the souls under the altar, and which altar is in view? The reference could be to the altar of incense (8:3, 5; 9:13; 11:1; 14:18; 16:7; cf. Ex. 30:3) or the altar of burnt offering, where burnt offerings were sacrificed twice a day (Num. 28:1–6). The blood under the altar suggests the latter is in view (though a decision on this matter isn't crucial), and that the death of Christians was a pleasing sacrifice to the Lord. We see a similar reality in Revelation 20:4: "I saw the souls of those who had been beheaded for the testimony of Jesus and for the word of God." John himself was imprisoned on Patmos "on account of the word of God and the testimony of Jesus" (Rev. 1:9), and the contents of Revelation are summed up in terms of John's witnessing the "word of God and the testimony of Jesus Christ" (1:2). Christians were being slain because of their commitment to the gospel of Christ, and Jesus predicted believers would be persecuted and slain before the end came (Matt. 24:9). It is also possible the language used here describes all believers. In other words, John portrays the

<span id="page-616-3"></span>church as a martyr church. This is not to say all Christians are actually slain for their witness, but John portrays the church as a martyr church to emphasize the contrast between the church and the world. All believers are persecuted (2 Tim. 3:12), and some suffer to the extent of giving up their lives for Christ. John focuses on the death believers experience on account of their devotion to Jesus Christ, and the words of those under the altar reflect the longing in the hearts of all Christians.

<span id="page-616-8"></span><span id="page-616-5"></span><span id="page-616-2"></span>6:10 The souls of those slain for Christ's sake have not been vindicated publicly, and the wicked have not been punished for slaughtering the righteous. Thus the martyrs under the altar call out for justice. They voice their prayer to the sovereign one, the one powerful enough to enforce justice. They voice their prayer to the one who is holy and true. Since he is holy, he cannot ultimately tolerate evil; since he is true, he is faithful to his own. The souls ask "how long" God will wait before judging and avenging the blood shed by "those who dwell on earth." In the comment on 3:10, it was noted that, in Revelation, "those who dwell on earth" always refers to unbelievers. The question of "how long?" was also raised by OT saints. "O Lord, how long shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked exult?" (Ps. 94:3). And, "How long, O God, is the foe to scoff? Is the enemy to revile your name forever?" (Ps. 74:10; cf. also Pss. 13:1–2; 35:17; 62:3; Hab. 1:2; Zech. 1:12; Luke 18:7). The issue isn't vindictiveness or raging vengeance, but justice. The prayer of the saints here is not sinful (they are dead, after all, and free from sin!) but righteous. Such a reading accords with the rest of Revelation, for John affirms the rightness of God's judgment on the wicked (Rev. 16:7; 19:2). The blood of those who love Jesus Christ has been shed. Such evil must be addressed; justice must be done (cf. Deut. 32:43; Pss. 79:10; 119:84; Luke 18:7). Otherwise, evil would reign unchecked in the universe, and God's holiness would be called into question.

<span id="page-616-12"></span><span id="page-616-11"></span><span id="page-616-9"></span><span id="page-616-6"></span><span id="page-616-4"></span><span id="page-616-1"></span><span id="page-616-0"></span>6:11 God hears and answers the prayers of his people, another indication that the prayers of the martyrs are righteous. The slain martyrs are given a white robe. Those in white robes belong to God (7:9), for they have washed their robes in the Lamb's blood (7:13–14). Also, those with white garments have lived righteously (3:4–5, 18), and thus the white robe reveals that the martyrs truly belong to God. God acknowledges them as his own. The martyrs are personally assured by God that they are his, but they are also told to wait. Vindication is coming in its fullness, but not yet. There are "fellow servants," brothers and sisters who must face the same fate as those who have already lost their lives. God has appointed others to suffer for the sake of his name, and as the ruler over history he determines how many will be put to death and how long the interval shall be before judgment strikes (cf. *1 En.* 47:4; *4 Ezra* 4:35–37). The saints' cry for justice is right and good, but they must also trust God as to when the judgment of the wicked and their own vindication will occur.

<span id="page-616-10"></span><span id="page-616-7"></span>6:12 The opening of the sixth seal by the Lamb is the answer to the prayer of the martyrs in 6:9–11. As the sixth seal is opened, John sees the judgment to be poured out on the wicked. He uses apocalyptic language from the OT to describe the impending judgment, and it is clear in the context that the final judgment is described.

<span id="page-617-12"></span><span id="page-617-7"></span><span id="page-617-4"></span>In the judgment scene portrayed here, the created order reels and falls apart. The end is signaled with an earthquake, a regular feature of the final judgment in Revelation (8:5; 11:13, 19; 16:18) that often signifies God's judgment in the OT as well (Jer. 10:22 LXX; Ezek. 38:19–21; Joel 3:16; Nah. 1:5). At the same time, the sun turns black and the moon turns to blood. The language isn't literal but is stock apocalyptic imagery for judgment. John picks up words from Joel: "The sun shall be turned to darkness, and the moon to blood, before the great and awesome day of the Lord comes" (Joel 2:31). Isaiah says about Babylon's dissolution, "The sun will be dark at its rising, and the moon will not shed its light" (Isa. 13:10). In the judgment of Egypt prophesied by Ezekiel, God "will cover the sun with a cloud, and the moon shall not give its light" (Ezek. 32:7). Jesus uses the same language of the darkening of sun and moon in association with his coming (Matt. 24:29; cf. also Isa. 24:23; Joel 2:10; 3:15; Amos 8:9; Zeph. 1:15). Images used of God's judgment in history are now applied to the final judgment, so that the judgments in history function as a precursor to God's final judgment of the wicked.

<span id="page-617-10"></span><span id="page-617-8"></span><span id="page-617-6"></span><span id="page-617-2"></span><span id="page-617-1"></span><span id="page-617-0"></span>6:13 The apocalyptic language describing the end of history and the world as we know it continues. John portrays the stars falling to the earth, just as figs fall from a tree when a powerful wind sweeps through. As is common for John, the image is picked up from Isaiah and slightly altered. Isaiah 34:4 says, "All the stars of the heaven will fall like leaves from a vine and as leaves fall from a fig tree."22 Even though the imagery is not literal, John communicates that the world is ending, for the natural order is falling apart.

<span id="page-617-11"></span><span id="page-617-9"></span><span id="page-617-5"></span>6:14 The world is dissolving and breaking up before John's eyes. A massive earthquake sunders the world, the sun is black, the moon has turned to blood, and stars are flying out of the sky. And the sky itself is vanishing, being rolled up like a scroll and vanishing. Again, John draws on Isaiah 34:4, which says, "All the host of heaven shall rot away, and the skies roll up like a scroll." We find similar language in Hebrews 1:10–12. The language is apocalyptic and symbolic, but what do the symbols mean? If the sky is withdrawn, the world as we know it is over. The same point is made in saying the islands and mountains are moved from their locations (cf. Ezek. 26:15). The stability of the world is undermined, and the natural order necessary for life to continue is unraveling. This is further evidence that the breaking of the sixth seal represents the end of history. Just as the earthquake symbolizes the end, so too do the moving islands and mountains, as seen later in Revelation. Thus, the seventh bowl indicates the end has come, as is testified in the words "It is done!" (Rev. 16:17). When the seventh bowl is poured out, "every island fled away, and no mountains were to be found" (16:20). The fleeing islands and absent mountains testify that history is concluding. Similarly, the great white throne judgment takes

<span id="page-617-14"></span><span id="page-617-13"></span><span id="page-617-3"></span><sup>22</sup> My translation of the LXX of Isaiah 34:4.

<span id="page-618-10"></span><span id="page-618-9"></span>place at the end of history, after the beast, false prophet, and Devil are cast into the lake of fire (20:10). The final judgment begins with the words, "Then I saw a great white throne and him who was seated on it. From his presence earth and sky fled away, and no place was found for them" (20:11). Here it isn't islands and mountains that flee, but the thought is similar, for now earth and sky are gone. Life on earth has dramatically changed, for the final judgment has arrived. John testifies to the same reality in declaring that "the first heaven and the first earth had passed away" (21:1).

<span id="page-618-11"></span><span id="page-618-7"></span><span id="page-618-5"></span><span id="page-618-3"></span><span id="page-618-2"></span><span id="page-618-0"></span>6:15 The collapse of the created order means judgment is at hand, and John draws on the "day of the Lord" theme from the prophets (e.g., Isa. 13:6, 9; Ezek. 13:5; Joel 1:15; 2:1; Amos 5:18, 20; Obad. 15; Zeph. 1:7, 14; Zech. 14:1) to describe the final judgment. He emphasizes that the judgment is universal: no one is spared, from kings to slaves. The emphasis is particularly on those who have power and influence—kings, generals, and the rich are included among those who will be judged (cf. Rev. 19:18; Isa. 34:12 LXX). When the judgment comes, their power, riches, or stature will be of no use. Instead, they will flee to caves and rocks in the mountains to hide. John picks up the majestic language from Isaiah 2, where Isaiah says that on the day of the Lord, "People shall enter the caves of the rocks and the holes of the ground, from before the terror of the Lord, and from the splendor of his majesty, when he rises to terrify the earth" (Isa. 2:19; cf. Isa. 2:10, 21). The day of the Lord in history forecasts the final day of the Lord, which John describes here; the historical days of the Lord anticipate the great and climactic day of the Lord. On that day the creation will disintegrate and creatures will be in panic and dread when the judgment arrives.

<span id="page-618-8"></span><span id="page-618-4"></span><span id="page-618-1"></span>6:16 All the joys and advantages of life are worthless when the world reels and collapses. Human beings who have fled to the mountains and rocks for safety realize they won't escape, so they ask the mountains and rocks to fall on them and crush them. The language of judgment alludes to the judgment predicted for Israel in Hosea 10:8: "They shall say to the mountains, 'Cover us,' and to the hills, 'Fall on us.'" Jesus also picks up the language of Hosea when predicting the final judgment (Luke 23:30), another example of Hosea's prediction of judgment in history functioning as prelude and anticipation of the final judgment. People long for death in mountains and rocks because they fear facing God, who reigns on the throne, and the wrath of the Lamb. The prospect of standing before God and the Lamb is so dreadful that death is preferable.

<span id="page-618-6"></span>Three other elements of the verse stand out. First, God and the Lamb are placed on the same level; they play an equal role in the final judgment—another indication the Lamb has the same identity and nature as God. Second, John speaks in a most striking way of the wrath of the Lamb. We don't think of lambs as full of wrath, but this Lamb is a different kind of lamb! Third, it is common to hear people say that the God of the NT is different from the God of the OT, but such an assertion is false. In both Testaments God is angry at sin and judges those who despise his name and indulge in evil. Grace and judgment are present in both the OT and the NT.

<span id="page-619-10"></span><span id="page-619-9"></span><span id="page-619-5"></span><span id="page-619-2"></span><span id="page-619-1"></span>6:17 Now the reason for the terror of human beings is explained further. As the present creation falls apart, people implore rocks and mountains to destroy them, that they might avoid God on the throne and the wrath of the Lamb, because the "great day of their wrath has come." It is interesting to note that verse 16 spoke of the Lamb's wrath, but now we are told that God on the throne and the Lamb are both wrathful. Indeed, it is the "great day" of their wrath. The OT prophets often spoke of the day of the Lord, emphasizing it was a day of judgment (Isa. 2:12; 22:12; Ezek. 30:3; Joel 2:1, 31; 3:14; Zeph. 1:7, 14; Mal. 4:5), though it was also the day the Lord would deliver his people (e.g., Isa. 4:2; 11:11; 19:16, 18, 19; 27:12–13; Joel 3:18; Zech. 13:2). The focus here is on judgment, and the OT prophets say it is a day of "destruction" (Isa. 13:6; Joel 1:15), "darkness" and "gloom" (Amos 5:18, 20), and "wrath and fierce anger" (Isa. 13:9; cf. Zeph. 1:18; 2:2, 3), when the kings on earth will be punished (Isa. 24:21). The day of the Lord in the OT often refers to days in history when God judged his people or their enemies, but these days of the Lord point to and culminate in the final day of the Lord—what John calls the "great day" of the Lord.

<span id="page-619-8"></span><span id="page-619-7"></span><span id="page-619-6"></span><span id="page-619-4"></span><span id="page-619-3"></span><span id="page-619-0"></span>OT writers reflected on the day of God's anger, asking who could "endure" the day of his "great" and "awesome" anger (Joel 2:31). "Who can endure the day of his coming, and who can stand when he appears?" (Mal. 3:2; cf. Ps. 76:7; Luke 21:36). John asks a similar question here. When the end arrives and the wrath of God and the Lamb are about to be unleashed, who can withstand their wrath? John will answer that question in the next chapter.

#### *Response*

Jesus has come and brought salvation, so what should we as Christians expect in our life on earth? Will life be radically different now that the Messiah has come to defeat the Devil and forgive our sins? John disabuses us of any notion of heaven on earth. Yes, the gospel will be proclaimed to the ends of the earth, Christ will triumph throughout the world, and every tribe and tongue will be reached with the message that liberates and frees from sin. Still, the gospel will spread amid fierce opposition, and believers will be slain for their allegiance to Jesus. Our vindication won't come during this present evil age. War and strife, famine and hunger, disease and pestilence will characterize life on earth. Life on earth is significant, and what we do matters (the gospel reaches the ends of the earth through us!). We won't create heaven on earth, yet we should still work for justice and peace during the present evil age. There is no room, however, for utopian visions, as anyone who studies the last two thousand years of history surely knows. Believers are not promised health and wealth in the present age but suffering, persecution, and even martyrdom. Soon, however, the day of judgment will come and God and the Lamb will pour out their wrath on the wicked. The question of "how long?" won't persist forever. A day of reckoning is coming, a day when the wicked will be punished and the righteous will be vindicated forever.

## <span id="page-620-3"></span>REVELATION 7:1–8

7 After this I saw four angels standing at the four corners of the earth, holding back the four winds of the earth, that no wind might blow on earth or sea or against any tree. **2**Then I saw another angel ascending from the rising of the sun, with the seal of the living God, and he called with a loud voice to the four angels who had been given power to harm earth and sea, **<sup>3</sup>** saying, "Do not harm the earth or the sea or the trees, until we have sealed the servants of our God on their foreheads." **4**And I heard the number of the sealed, 144,000, sealed from every tribe of the sons of Israel:

- **<sup>5</sup>** 12,000 from the tribe of Judah were sealed, 12,000 from the tribe of Reuben, 12,000 from the tribe of Gad,
- **<sup>6</sup>** 12,000 from the tribe of Asher, 12,000 from the tribe of Naphtali, 12,000 from the tribe of Manasseh,
- **<sup>7</sup>** 12,000 from the tribe of Simeon, 12,000 from the tribe of Levi, 12,000 from the tribe of Issachar,
- <span id="page-620-2"></span>**<sup>8</sup>** 12,000 from the tribe of Zebulun, 12,000 from the tribe of Joseph, 12,000 from the tribe of Benjamin were sealed.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-620-6"></span><span id="page-620-5"></span><span id="page-620-4"></span><span id="page-620-1"></span><span id="page-620-0"></span>Chapter 6 concluded with the final judgment, asking who can withstand God's wrath on the final day. Chapter 7 functions as an interlude and answers the question posed in chapter 6: those sealed by God will be spared from wrath. They are the ones, as 7:9 says, who *stand* before God's throne. The four angels hold back, for now, the four winds of judgment that will bring about the dissolution of this present world (Rev. 7:1; cf. 6:12–14). Another angel arises with the seal of God, saying that the earth, sea, and trees must not be harmed until God's servants are sealed (7:2–3). The seal will protect God's servants from wrath at the final judgment, and God's servants will be authenticated as his own. Verses 4–8 record the number of those sealed: the total is 144,000, with 12,000 sealed from each of the twelve tribes of Israel. The identity of the 144,000 is contested, but I will argue that they represent the church of Jesus Christ, the people of God. We can summarize the passage this way: Who will be protected from the wrath of God and the wrath of the Lamb? Those who are sealed and protected by God, i.e., the 144,000, the true Israel, the church of Jesus Christ.

#### *Section Outline*

- IV. The Seven Seals (6:1–8:5) . . .
	- B. Interlude (7:1–17)
		- 1. Sealing of the 144,000 (7:1–8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-621-12"></span><span id="page-621-11"></span><span id="page-621-5"></span><span id="page-621-2"></span><span id="page-621-0"></span>7:1 The previous text (6:12–17) concludes with a query: Who can withstand the wrath of God and the wrath of the Lamb? John answers that question in these verses. The "four corners" of the earth aren't intended to teach that the world is flat. Instead, the four corners stand for the entire world (cf. Isa. 11:12; Rev. 20:8), just as "four corners" of a house stand for the entire house (Job 1:19), and "four corners of the land" stand for the entire land of Israel (Ezek. 7:2). The four angels, then, superintend the world for God's sake. The "four winds" stand for the judgment to come, the final judgment, which will engulf the entire world. We see precedent for this in the OT (cf. also Ezek. 5:10, 12) where "four winds from the four quarters of heaven" will be inflicted on the entire land of Elam (Jer. 49:36; cf. Ezek. 37:9; Dan. 7:2; 8:8; 11:4; Zech. 2:6; 6:5; Matt. 24:31; Mark 13:27), but here the four winds encompass the whole world. Elsewhere in Scripture, a close relationship is forged between angels and winds that strike the world (Ps. 104:4). Here the angels are restraining the winds so that they are not unleashed on land, sea, or trees. John takes us back to the period before the final judgment commences.

<span id="page-621-15"></span><span id="page-621-13"></span><span id="page-621-9"></span><span id="page-621-6"></span><span id="page-621-4"></span><span id="page-621-3"></span><span id="page-621-1"></span>7:2–3 Another angel appears with the seal of the living God, commanding the four angels about to harm the earth and sea—i.e., the angels about to bring final judgment on the world—to refrain from doing any harm until God's servants are sealed on their foreheads. The sealing on the forehead isn't literal but symbolizes protection granted to those who belong to God (cf. 9:4). So now we know who can endure the wrath of God—those with God's seal upon them. John again draws upon the OT. In Ezekiel 9, Jerusalem is about to be judged by executioners because of its evil. Those who are wicked will be annihilated, but a "mark" is put "on the foreheads of the men who sigh and groan over all the abominations that are committed in it" (Ezek. 9:4). The judgment will not spare the young or old, but those with the mark will remain untouched (Ezek. 9:6). Those who are sealed by God on the forehead in Revelation stand in contrast to those who accept the mark of the beast on their foreheads (Rev. 13:6; 14:9; 20:4). In both instances the mark is symbolic. What separates believers from unbelievers is that the former have God's seal and the "Father's name written on their foreheads" (14:1; cf. 22:4). They are protected by God and marked out as his own people, his genuine servants.

<span id="page-621-17"></span><span id="page-621-16"></span><span id="page-621-14"></span><span id="page-621-10"></span><span id="page-621-8"></span><span id="page-621-7"></span>7:4–8 Those who are sealed are now identified. John *hears* the number. They are 144,000 from every tribe of Israel. John then lists 12,000 from each tribe. God numbers, knows, and cares for his own; he knows each of his sheep by name (John 10:3). The list of tribes doesn't match any rendition of the tribes in the OT. Judah

<span id="page-622-1"></span>may be first since Jesus the Messiah, head of the people of God, comes from Judah. What is also striking is that Dan is omitted, perhaps because of the evil associated with that tribe (Judges 18). Instead we have Joseph and Manasseh. This is curious, as Manasseh descended from Joseph, and thus we would expect Ephraim and Manasseh. These peculiarities in the listing suggest a symbolic reading.

Scholars differ on identifying the 144,000. Some say the number is literal and records Jews from each tribe who become believers in Jesus Christ. Dispensational interpreters think the number refers to Jews who are saved during the final sevenyear tribulation period.

<span id="page-622-8"></span>It is more convincing to say the 144,000 symbolically represent all Christians throughout history, both Jews and Gentiles. They are God's army who wage war by being faithful to the Lamb and enduring persecution. The reasons for thinking John refers to all Christians are numerous, and some stem from Revelation 14, where the 144,000 appear again. First, numbers in apocalyptic literature are regularly symbolic. Here we have the number twelve representing the people of God from the twelve tribes in the OT, and the number is squared and then multiplied by 1,000. Hence the number should be understood as a symbolic way of designating the entire people of God.

<span id="page-622-7"></span><span id="page-622-6"></span><span id="page-622-5"></span><span id="page-622-4"></span><span id="page-622-3"></span>Second, John follows a pattern we saw in chapter 5. He is *told* about a Lion (5:5), but he *sees* a Lamb (5:6), and the Lion and the Lamb are the same entity. So too here, John *hears* the number 144,000 (7:4), but he *sees* an uncountable multitude (7:9). Again we have two different ways of describing the same entity, and the uncountable multitude buttresses the point that the 144,000 represent all believers.

<span id="page-622-2"></span>Third, specifying 144,000 from Israel doesn't necessarily mean they are Jews. John has already said twice that the Jews are a synagogue of Satan (2:9; 3:9), and the roles between unbelieving Jews and Christians have been reversed, so that now unbelieving Jews play the role of Gentiles in the OT; they will bow before Christians to acknowledge them as the loved ones, the elect ones of the Lord (3:9; cf. Deut. 7:7–8; Isa. 41:8).

<span id="page-622-0"></span>Fourth, a practical problem arises if the reference is to 12,000 from each tribe of Israel. Virtually no Jews today know from what tribe they descend, nor is it clear that most knew their genealogical ancestry in John's day. If someone were to say that God knows the tribes and apportions exactly 12,000 from each tribe, it is difficult to see how such a statement would be meaningful, for no one on earth could know that the 12,000 are from each of the twelve tribes specified.

<span id="page-622-10"></span><span id="page-622-9"></span>Fifth, in 14:3 the 144,000 are described as those "redeemed from the earth" and in 14:4 as having been "redeemed from mankind as firstfruits for God and the Lamb." The redeemed are most naturally interpreted to refer to *all* the redeemed, both Jews and Gentiles.

Sixth, John says they are "virgins" who have "not defiled themselves with women" (14:4). But surely this language is symbolic, for being a virgin is not more pleasing to God than marriage, and it is false teachers who say sexual rela<span id="page-623-1"></span><span id="page-623-0"></span>tions within marriage are defiling (1 Tim. 4:1–3). John (cf. comment on Rev. 14:4) reaches back to the OT, which often warns Israel against spiritual prostitution. To be devoted to God is to be a "pure virgin" devoted "to Christ" (2 Cor. 11:2). For all these reasons, then, we have good grounds for thinking the number 144,000 is laden with imagery and symbolism, referring to the entire people of God.

#### *Response*

Who will escape the wrath of God at the final judgment? Only those who belong to God, those who are sealed by him, who are numbered by him. If we are sealed by God, we are protected and authenticated by him. At the same time, those of us who are sealed by God are the true and new Israel, the chosen and loved people of the Lord. We too deserve the wrath of God but have been spared by his grace and mercy, which should lead to thankfulness and heartfelt praise. How wonderful it is to be counted among his flock, to be the army of the Lord—an army that preaches peace and love through the slain and risen Lamb!

Blessing and glory and wisdom and thanksgiving and honor and power and might be to our God forever and ever! Amen."

And he said to me, "These are the ones coming out of the great tribulation. They have washed their robes and made them white in the blood of the Lamb.

**<sup>15</sup>** "Therefore they are before the throne of God, and serve him day and night in his temple; and he who sits on the throne will shelter them with his presence. **<sup>16</sup>** They shall hunger no more, neither thirst anymore; the sun shall not strike them,

nor any scorching heat.

**<sup>17</sup>** For the Lamb in the midst of the throne will be their shepherd, and he will guide them to springs of living water, and God will wipe away every tear from their eyes."

#### <span id="page-624-2"></span>*Section Overview*

<span id="page-624-8"></span><span id="page-624-6"></span><span id="page-624-5"></span><span id="page-624-4"></span><span id="page-624-3"></span>John now turns to *see* what he has just *heard* (Rev. 7:4)—not 144,000, but an uncountable multitude of believers, showing that the 144,000 symbolizes the entire people of God. This uncountable multitude is before God's throne and the Lamb, wearing white robes and carrying palm branches (v. 9). In other words, they are in heaven with God, showing that those sealed by God are rewarded with eternal life. These believers give praise to God and the Lamb for their salvation (v. 10), and the angelic multitudes also give praise and honor to God for his goodness and glory (vv. 11–12). The narrative then steps back to clarify for readers exactly what is occurring. An angel asks John the identity of those in white robes and where they have come from (v. 13). John acknowledges he doesn't know, and that the angel must inform him (v. 14). The angel reveals to John that they have come "out of the great tribulation," and that their robes have been whitened by the blood of the Lamb. Thus, the reason they are before God's throne, the reason they are in the heavenly temple, is that they have been redeemed by the Lamb's blood (v. 15). Their earthly lives are completed, for in verses 15–17 John previews the new creation elaborated in 21:1–22:5. There is no more hunger, thirst, or pain for this uncountable multitude, those sealed by God (7:16). The Lamb is their shepherd and has guided them to springs of living water and wiped every tear from their eyes (v. 17). Chapter 7 tells us who will survive the wrath of God and the Lamb (6:17): it is those who are sealed by God, those whose robes have been made white by the blood of the Lamb—and they will enjoy God's presence in the new creation forever.

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-624-7"></span><span id="page-624-0"></span>7:9 "After this" refers to John's next vision and does not designate an event subsequent to the sealing of the 144,000. John *heard* the number 144,000 but *sees* an innumerable multitude, showing that the 144,000 from the twelve tribes of Israel symbolize the people of God from every tribe, tongue, people, and nation. This is the same pattern as in chapter 5, where John is *told* about a Lion but *sees* a Lamb—the Lion and Lamb having the same referent. So too here, the 144,000 and the uncountable multitude are the same entity, portrayed from two different perspectives. Here we see fulfilled the promise given to Abraham that all nations would be blessed (e.g., Gen. 12:3; 18:18; 22:18; 26:4; 28:14; Acts 3:25; Gal. 3:8, 16). Those from every people group and tribe stand before God's throne and before the Lamb. They can stand in God's presence because of their white robes, showing they are righteous and clean before God and have won the victory (cf. comment on Rev. 7:13–14). John has answered, then, the question posed in 6:17 of who can "stand" in the light of God's coming wrath: the 144,000 sealed by God. That is, the innumerable multi<span id="page-625-6"></span>tude with palm branches in their hands, signifying joy and praise in triumph, as when many took palm branches to celebrate Jesus' entry into Jerusalem and greeted him with cries of "Hosanna" (cf. John 12:13). We see the same theme in *2 Maccabees* 10:7—"Bearing ivy-wreathed wands and beautiful branches and also fronds of palm, they offered hymns of thanksgiving to him who had given success to the purifying of his own Holy Place"23 (cf. *1 Macc.* 13:51; *Jub.* 16:31). The multitude isn't standing before God and the Lamb with fear of judgment (cf. Rev. 6:16–17) but with great joy.

<span id="page-625-10"></span><span id="page-625-9"></span>7:10 The multitude cries out with praise, ascribing their salvation, their deliverance from God's wrath, to God and the Lamb. The multitude doesn't deserve praise and honor for escaping God's wrath. All praise goes to God and the Lamb for their salvation. The Scriptures teach repeatedly that salvation is God's work, that he is the one who delivers his people (e.g., Pss. 3:8; 37:39; 62:7; Isa. 43:11; Jer. 3:23; Hos. 13:4; Jonah 2:9; Rev. 19:1). In addition, we see once again the Lamb and God sharing the same stature, for salvation is ascribed both to God and to the Lamb.

<span id="page-625-11"></span><span id="page-625-8"></span><span id="page-625-4"></span><span id="page-625-1"></span>7:11–12 The salvation of some from every people group fills the angels around the throne with praise. The angels, elders, and four living creatures are placed together here, further evidence that the elders are angelic, distinguished from human beings and performing the same function as other angelic beings. The greatness of what God has done fills the angels with awe, and they fall on their faces to worship God (cf. 4:10; 5:8, 14; 11:16; 19:4). Their worship is expressed in words of delight, saying "Amen" to the salvation of the innumerable multitude. Blessing, glory, wisdom, thanksgiving, honor, and power are ascribed to God forever and punctuated with an "Amen." God, of course, is already blessed, glorious, wise, powerful, and worthy of all thanksgiving and honor (cf. 4:9, 11; 5:13; 19:1). Thus, the angels don't give God anything he doesn't already possess intrinsically. Still, they ascribe to God all these qualities, recognizing they belong properly to him (cf. 1 Chron. 29:10–11).

<span id="page-625-12"></span><span id="page-625-7"></span><span id="page-625-3"></span><span id="page-625-0"></span>7:13–14 The narrative moves in a new direction, and the elder's (i.e., the angel's) question provokes the reader to take notice of the answer's significance. The questionanswer format calls attention to the situation in a fresh way (cf. Ezek. 37:3) and functions as an effective literary device. The angel/elder asks John to identify those in white robes and explain where they came from. John's answer ("Sir, you know.") reveals implicitly John's ignorance and highlights the wisdom of the angel, who is able to disclose the true state of affairs. The elder explains that John is seeing those who have come "out of the great tribulation." The phrase "great tribulation" isn't a technical term with a single meaning. In Matthew it denotes the days when Jerusalem and its temple were destroyed by the Romans (Matt. 24:21). But the phrase also designates the entire period between the first and second coming of Christ. Daniel describes this period as a "time of trouble" from which God's people will be delivered (Dan. 12:1; cf. Jer. 30:7). It is probable that John sees the entire

<span id="page-625-5"></span><span id="page-625-2"></span><sup>23</sup> *The English Standard Version Bible with Apocrypha* (New York: Oxford University Press, 2009).

R evelation 7:9–17 626

<span id="page-626-3"></span>period before Christ's return as a time of trouble and great tribulation. In other words, the term isn't limited to a seven-year period at the end of history, for we have no clear teaching anywhere of such a distinct period before the conclusion of history. John, like Daniel, teaches that those who belong to God are rescued. They are rescued and delivered because they have washed their robes white in the Lamb's blood, picturing the cleansing work of Christ on the cross (cf. Rev. 1:5; 12:11). The robes of the redeemed are white, not on account of their inherent righteousness but because of the cleansing atonement of the Lamb who gave himself for their sins (cf. comment on 5:6). Often in Revelation white robes and garments designate the righteousness of the saints, the godly lives they have lived (3:4, 5; 6:11; 7:9). John gives us here the ultimate reason why believers have white robes and explains why they have endured the great tribulation. Their salvation is due to the blood of the Lamb, the sacrifice of Jesus Christ, the cleansing coming only from him.

<span id="page-626-11"></span><span id="page-626-6"></span><span id="page-626-5"></span><span id="page-626-4"></span>7:15 "Therefore" ties the text to what precedes: those who have endured the great tribulation and have had their robes whitened by the Lamb's blood are now before God's throne (cf. 7:9). To be before God's throne means being in heaven, or, perhaps better, in the new creation. The language here is symbolic of eternal life in the new creation. This innumerable crowd is akin to priests serving God constantly, day and night, in his temple. Worshiping God at his throne characterizes the new creation (22:3). The reference to the temple is clearly symbolic, for in the new creation there is no temple, but the temple is God and the Lamb (21:22). God personally dwells with his people, as the entire world is his temple (21:3). The tabernacle/ temple imagery continues, for God who sits on the throne will shelter (*skēnōsei*; lit., "tabernacle over") his people, protecting them from harm. In the new creation, nothing can touch them (cf. Isa. 4:5); the days of suffering are over.

<span id="page-626-10"></span><span id="page-626-9"></span><span id="page-626-7"></span><span id="page-626-2"></span><span id="page-626-1"></span><span id="page-626-0"></span>7:16 The nature of God's protection and dwelling with his people is expanded upon, and it is even more evident that life in the new creation, life after the resurrection, is pictured here. The days of hunger and thirst have ended. No longer will believers face the intense heat of the sun, where no relief can be found, for the time of bodily suffering and privation has ended. Now they are under God's protection, and everything is provided for them in his temple, the new creation he indwells (cf. Lev. 26:11; Ezek. 37:27). The second exodus from Babylon is described in similar terms in Isaiah 49:10: "They shall not hunger or thirst, neither scorching wind nor sun shall strike them, for he who has pity on them will lead them, and by springs of water will guide them." What God promised in the second exodus is fulfilled in a final and ultimate manner in the new creation for the true Israel—the church of Jesus Christ. In Isaiah, God promises Israel he will satisfy their needs as they travel through the desert; but in Revelation, what God did in the wilderness is magnified. He will protect his people from harm forever and ever.

<span id="page-626-8"></span>7:17 Every need of those before God's throne is met by the Lamb, their shepherd. Revelation is full of striking images, but this is surely one of the most striking. <span id="page-627-11"></span><span id="page-627-9"></span><span id="page-627-8"></span><span id="page-627-7"></span><span id="page-627-6"></span><span id="page-627-1"></span><span id="page-627-0"></span>Lambs aren't shepherds; they are sheep. Still, this Lamb is also the shepherd of his people. The psalmist says the Lord is his shepherd (Ps. 23:1), and identifying the Lamb as a shepherd constitutes further evidence of the divinity of Jesus, as he is the shepherd of God's people just as the Father is the shepherd of Israel. The picture of Jesus as the shepherd of the sheep also finds its roots in John's Gospel, where Jesus identifies himself as the good shepherd (John 10:2, 11, 14, 16; cf. also Matt. 2:6; Heb. 13:20; 1 Pet. 5:4). Jesus' role as a shepherd also fulfills OT expectations, for the Davidic king was shepherd and ruler of his people (2 Sam. 5:2). John especially draws here on Ezekiel 34:23. There God promises to establish a "shepherd, my servant David" to "feed" and "shepherd" his people (cf. also Zech. 11:4, 7, 9, 15; 13:7). The Lamb as the shepherd of his people will lead them to refreshing water, just as the Lord leads his people "beside still waters" (Ps. 23:2). With living water Jesus slakes the thirst of those who belong to him (John 4:14; 7:37–38; cf. Jer. 17:13)—those who belong to Jesus "drink from the river of your delights" (Ps. 36:8; cf. Rev. 22:1). Finally, God will wipe all tears from their eyes. It is quite clear the new creation is in view here, for we find the same promise in Revelation 21:4 (cf. Isa. 25:8). Those whom God seals and protects will delight in the Lamb and in God forever. Every joy will be theirs, and the sorrow of the present evil age will be only a memory.

#### <span id="page-627-12"></span><span id="page-627-10"></span><span id="page-627-5"></span><span id="page-627-4"></span><span id="page-627-3"></span><span id="page-627-2"></span>*Response*

Praise God there will be a countless multitude in the new creation; salvation isn't limited to a few but includes more than can be calculated, enjoying the lavish greatness of God's grace. The fulcrum of history, the key to history, is the cross of Christ. Believers enter the new creation because the blood of the Lamb was shed for our sake. The stain of guilt is removed by his atoning sacrifice. Seeing the grace and beauty of this great salvation causes both saints and angels to swell with praise and joy. The sorrows and troubles of this present world won't last forever. The day is coming when the entire universe will be God's temple, and he will wipe away our tears. The Lamb will be our shepherd, satisfying every need and filling us with unspeakable joy.

## <span id="page-628-4"></span>REVELATION 8:1–5

8 When the Lamb opened the seventh seal, there was silence in heaven for about half an hour. **2**Then I saw the seven angels who stand before God, and seven trumpets were given to them. **3**And another angel came and stood at the altar with a golden censer, and he was given much incense to offer with the prayers of all the saints on the golden altar before the throne, **<sup>4</sup>** and the smoke of the incense, with the prayers of the saints, rose before God from the hand of the angel. **5**Then the angel took the censer and filled it with fire from the altar and threw it on the earth, and there were peals of thunder, rumblings,*<sup>1</sup>* flashes of lightning, and an earthquake.

<span id="page-628-6"></span>1Or *voices*, or *sounds*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-628-5"></span><span id="page-628-3"></span><span id="page-628-1"></span>The opening of the seventh seal seems superfluous, since final judgment came with the sixth seal (Rev. 6:12–17), but this seal, a literary device leading to the seven trumpets, recapitulates, rehearses, and expands upon the coming judgments. The silence in heaven for about thirty minutes suggests that judgment is about to fall (8:1), and the short time period indicates judgment will be sudden. Seven angels are given seven trumpets (v. 2), and another angel stands at the golden altar of incense to offer incense along with the prayers of the saints before the throne (v. 3). The prayers and incense rise before God (v. 4), and the angel takes fire from the altar of incense and casts it to the earth (v. 5). The result is thunder, lightning, and an earthquake. The passage clearly teaches that the judgment of the seven trumpets is an answer to the prayers of the saints (cf. 6:9–11). God judges those who stubbornly resist his will, and their failure to repent demonstrates that they deserve judgment.

#### <span id="page-628-8"></span><span id="page-628-0"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-628-7"></span>IV. The Seven Seals (6:1–8:5) . . .
	- C. The Seventh Seal and the Seven Trumpets (8:1–5)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-628-2"></span>8:1 John has explained in 7:1–17 that those who are sealed by God will escape his wrath. Now he returns to the opening of the seals, and the Lamb opens the seventh seal. A seventh seal seems unnecessary, since the sixth seal led to final judgment and the end of history. The breaking of the seventh seal, however, leads to the blowing of seven trumpets. The trumpets don't describe a new series of events but revisit, from a different perspective, the same period of time found in the first six

<span id="page-629-8"></span>seals. Revelation, like many texts in the OT, is recursive, revisiting the same period of time from a complementary perspective. When the Lamb opens the seventh seal, there is silence in heaven for about half an hour. What is the significance of the silence? In the OT we see silence before God acts in judgment (Hab. 2:20; Zeph. 1:7; cf. *Wisd. Sol.* 18:14–15). It is the kind of eerie silence we feel in the natural world before a tornado suddenly strikes.

<span id="page-629-16"></span><span id="page-629-15"></span><span id="page-629-14"></span><span id="page-629-11"></span><span id="page-629-5"></span><span id="page-629-2"></span>8:2 John sees seven angels standing in God's presence (cf. *Tob.* 12:15; *1 En.* 90:21; *3 En.* 17:1). Seven angels are mentioned quite often in Revelation (Rev. 8:6; 15:1, 6, 7, 8; 16:1; 17:1; 21:9), and as God's servants they execute his will. The angels are given seven trumpets; when these trumpets are blown, the trumpet judgments will be inflicted on the earth (8:6–9:21; 11:15–19). The blowing of trumpets is often a call to war and judgment in the OT (Num. 10:9; Josh. 6:4–6, 20; Judg. 7:22; Jer. 4:19; 6:1; Ezek. 33:3–6; Hos. 5:8; Joel 2:1; Amos 3:6; Zeph. 1:16; cf. Matt. 24:31), and here the trumpets signify God's judgment, just as the trumpets blown at Jericho heralded the fall of that city (Joshua 6). The opening of the seventh seal before the trumpet judgments doesn't prove that the trumpets are subsequent to the seals, for we saw that the sixth seal was the final judgment. More likely, this is a literary device to continue the narrative.

<span id="page-629-12"></span><span id="page-629-10"></span><span id="page-629-7"></span><span id="page-629-3"></span><span id="page-629-1"></span><span id="page-629-0"></span>8:3–4 Another angel appears with a golden censer and stands at the altar of incense (cf. Rev. 14:18; Amos 9:1). The angel plays a role in bringing the prayers of the saints before God (cf. *1 En.* 9:3; 15:2; 99:3). The altar of incense was in the Holy Place in the OT tabernacle/temple (Ex. 30:1–10; 37:25–29; 40:5). On the Day of Atonement a censer of incense was brought inside the veil, and the incense cloud covered the mercy seat to avoid judgment (Lev. 16:12–13). John informs us that the incense here is offered with the prayers of the saints on the altar before God's throne. Some understand this to say that the prayers of the saints are defiled without incense being added to them. It seems more plausible to say that the incense *is* the prayers—they are acceptable to God, just as incense was pleasing to him. The OT usage supports this notion, for Psalm 141:2 says, "Let my prayer be counted as incense before you, and the lifting up of my hands as the evening sacrifice!" The prayers of the saints and incense are put in a censer and offered to God.

<span id="page-629-13"></span><span id="page-629-9"></span><span id="page-629-6"></span><span id="page-629-4"></span>8:5 In response to the prayers of believers, the angel takes the censer from the altar of incense, fills it with fire from the altar, and throws it on the earth. The imagery is apocalyptic, of course, as there is no literal altar of incense involved. The fire the angel flings represents God's judgment of the wicked. We see a similar judgment scene in Ezekiel, where the man in linen is instructed, "Go in among the whirling wheels underneath the cherubim. Fill your hands with burning coals from between the cherubim, and scatter them over the city" (Ezek. 10:2). Here too in Revelation, the judgments poured out in the trumpets represent answers to the prayers of the saints. Their prayers for God's kingdom to come and his will to be done are being answered (Matt. 6:10). The coming judgments, as a result of the

<span id="page-630-3"></span><span id="page-630-0"></span>prayers of the saints, are previewed with a massive thunderstorm and earthquake (cf. Isa. 29:6). In Revelation, a thunderstorm and earthquake regularly signal that the final judgment is coming (cf. 6:12; 11:13, 19; 16:18), and show that the judgment comes from God's throne (4:5). (Cf. comment on 6:12.)

#### <span id="page-630-1"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-630-2"></span>It may often seem that our prayers are not being answered—that they are offered in vain. But Revelation assures us that God hears the prayers of the saints. All through history, God's people have prayed for his kingdom to come and his will to be done. Every prayer for the coming kingdom will certainly be answered. The prayers for justice voiced by martyrs are not ignored (cf. 6:9–11). Justice will be realized, the new creation will arrive, and the wicked will be judged. Our prayers make a difference; they are one of the means God has ordained to accomplish his purposes. We must not lose heart or ever think our prayers for goodness to prevail are ignored. Instead, we must continue to pray to our wise and sovereign God. Our prayers will be answered—at just the right time.

### <span id="page-630-4"></span>REVELATION 8:6–13

**<sup>6</sup>**Now the seven angels who had the seven trumpets prepared to blow them.

**<sup>7</sup>**The first angel blew his trumpet, and there followed hail and fire, mixed with blood, and these were thrown upon the earth. And a third of the earth was burned up, and a third of the trees were burned up, and all green grass was burned up.

**8**The second angel blew his trumpet, and something like a great mountain, burning with fire, was thrown into the sea, and a third of the sea became blood. **9**A third of the living creatures in the sea died, and a third of the ships were destroyed.

**<sup>10</sup>**The third angel blew his trumpet, and a great star fell from heaven, blazing like a torch, and it fell on a third of the rivers and on the springs of water. **11**The name of the star is Wormwood.*<sup>1</sup>* A third of the waters became wormwood, and many people died from the water, because it had been made bitter.

**<sup>12</sup>**The fourth angel blew his trumpet, and a third of the sun was struck, and a third of the moon, and a third of the stars, so that a third of their light might be darkened, and a third of the day might be kept from shining, and likewise a third of the night.

**<sup>13</sup>**Then I looked, and I heard an eagle crying with a loud voice as it flew directly overhead, "Woe, woe, woe to those who dwell on the earth, at the blasts of the other trumpets that the three angels are about to blow!"

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-631-3"></span><span id="page-631-2"></span>The seven angels begin to blow the seven trumpets (Rev. 8:6), and the text is nicely structured by the sequence of the trumpets, as seen in table 9.8.

<span id="page-631-8"></span><span id="page-631-7"></span>

| Trumpet 1 | Earth              | 8:7        | Hail, fire, and blood on land            |
|-----------|--------------------|------------|------------------------------------------|
| Trumpet 2 | Sea                | 8:8–9      | Burning mountain thrown into the sea     |
| Trumpet 3 | Rivers and springs | 8:10–11    | Burning star falls on rivers and springs |
| Trumpet 4 | Sky                | 8:12       | Sun, moon, and stars darkened            |
| Interlude |                    | 8:13       |                                          |
| Trumpet 5 | First woe          | 9:1–12     | Demons from the abyss                    |
| Trumpet 6 | Second woe         | 9:13–21    | Demons from the east                     |

<span id="page-631-6"></span><span id="page-631-5"></span><span id="page-631-0"></span>TABLE 9.8: The Seven Trumpets

<span id="page-631-14"></span><span id="page-631-13"></span><span id="page-631-11"></span><span id="page-631-10"></span><span id="page-631-9"></span>There is an interlude between the first four trumpets and the last three; the last three trumpets are introduced with a threefold woe warning unbelievers of the horror of the last three trumpets (8:13). John prepares us, then, for the terrors eventuating with the last three trumpets. When do the trumpet judgments occur? Some restrict them to a seven-year tribulation in the end times, but there is no clear evidence in Scripture for such a seven-year period before the end arrives. It is preferable to locate the trumpets in the period between Christ's resurrection and return. The trumpets and seals overlap, so that the trumpet judgments represent a recursive retelling, from a different perspective, of the time period of the seals. In chapter 8, the first four trumpets communicate God's judgment on land, sea, rivers, and the skies; every realm of life is touched by human sin. Thus the descriptions should not be interpreted literally; instead we have a vivid and exaggerated picture of devastating judgments encompassing the entire world. The judgments striking earth during this present evil age are designed to bring people to repentance, and the failure to repent (9:20–21) demonstrates that the judgments are just.

#### <span id="page-631-12"></span>*Section Outline*

- V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19)
	- A. The First Four Trumpets: Cosmic Destruction (8:6–13)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-631-4"></span><span id="page-631-1"></span>8:6–7 As a result of the prayers of the saints, the seven angels begin to blow their trumpets, signaling that God is about to judge his enemies. Some of the trumpet judgments echo the plagues poured out on Egypt. The first trumpet reminds us of the plague of hail (cf. Ex. 9:23–24). The fire accompanying it probably refers to lightning strikes, so that the picture is of a massive storm with hail and lightning <span id="page-632-7"></span><span id="page-632-6"></span><span id="page-632-2"></span>(Ps. 18:13; Ezek. 38:22; *Sir.* 39:29). John signals that the language is symbolic and apocalyptic, for the lightning is mixed with blood (cf. Joel 2:30). This is not an ordinary lightning storm! In its wake, one-third of the earth and its trees are burned up (cf. Ezek. 5:2, 12) and green grass vanishes. If the language is literal, what is described must be future, for such a devastating judgment has not yet taken place. It is more plausible, however, to posit that John is describing with apocalyptic language the devastation marking life on earth during this present evil age. The desolations impacting the earth represent God's judgment. The apocalyptic and exaggerated nature of the imagery is confirmed by Revelation 9:4, for the locusts are told not to harm the grass on earth, but this makes little sense if all the grass is already burned up! The message communicated is that living in this world has many benefits (two-thirds of the world is unaffected), but God's judgments strike the world on account of sin.

<span id="page-632-11"></span><span id="page-632-8"></span><span id="page-632-5"></span>8:8–9 The trumpet of the second angel sounds, and a great mountain burning like fire is thrown into the sea (cf. *1 En.* 18:13; 21:3), picturing a volcanic eruption. We are reminded of how Babylon will be reduced by God to a "burnt mountain" (Jer. 51:25). Once again, the judgment is scarcely literal. The first trumpet describes the effect of God's judgment on the earth, and here we see its effect on the seas and oceans. One-third of the sea turns to blood, just as the Nile turned to blood during the days of Moses (Ex. 7:20). The Nile turned to blood literally, but John takes this image and uses it apocalyptically to describe the effect on the seas and oceans. He says one-third of the creatures in the sea died and one-third of the boats were destroyed. The number one-third isn't exact; the point is that God's judgment is poured out on a world resisting him.

<span id="page-632-9"></span><span id="page-632-4"></span><span id="page-632-3"></span><span id="page-632-0"></span>8:10–11 With the third trumpet sounded by the third angel, a star falls from heaven, burning with fire (cf. 9:1; Isa. 14:12; *1 En.* 86:1). The burning star falls on rivers and springs and embitters them. One-third of the water is polluted, and many die upon drinking it. We see a similar judgment in Jeremiah: "I will feed this people with bitter food, and give them poisonous water to drink" (Jer. 9:15). Again, we should not interpret this literally; the poisoning of the waters signals the devastation poured out on the earth. The waters of the earth should be refreshing and invigorating, but life on earth is polluted because of human sin. God's judgments affect life on land, oceans, and seas, and they also strike the water human beings need to live.

<span id="page-632-10"></span><span id="page-632-1"></span>8:12 When the fourth angel blows his trumpet, the sun is darkened for one-third of the day and the moon and stars for one-third of the night. It is hard to imagine what these words could mean if they were interpreted literally, for life on earth wouldn't continue if the sun didn't shine for one-third of every day. We are reminded of the plague of darkness that engulfed Egypt (Ex. 10:21–23). Similarly, Isaiah describes the "day of the Lord" as a time when the stars do not shine and the sun and moon yield no light: "The stars of the heavens and their constellations will not give their light; the sun will be dark at its rising, and the moon will not

<span id="page-633-3"></span><span id="page-633-1"></span>shed its light" (Isa. 13:10; cf. Ezek. 32:7; Joel 2:31; 3:15). The celestial phenomena predicted at the coming of the day of Lord in the prophets did not take place literally. The language is used to depict God's judgment on nations in history. Jesus also says that the same kinds of things will accompany his future coming (Matt. 24:29; Mark 13:24; Luke 21:25). The four trumpets speak of God's judgment on land, sea, rivers, and the skies. All of life in this present age is affected by human sin, and the temporal judgments of God in history point to and anticipate the final judgment.

<span id="page-633-7"></span><span id="page-633-5"></span><span id="page-633-4"></span><span id="page-633-2"></span>8:13 Verse 13 functions as a literary device to highlight that the judgments of the last three trumpets will be worse than the first four. A flying eagle anticipates and heralds the three trumpets to come with a threefold woe (cf. Jer. 4:13; Hos. 8:1), warning of impending desolation and devastation. The desolation and devastation is limited, however, to those who dwell on earth. As we saw in Revelation 3:10, "earth dwellers" in Revelation always represent unbelievers. Those who believe in Jesus Christ have no reason to fear the last three trumpet judgments, but unbelievers should be filled with dread.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-633-6"></span><span id="page-633-0"></span>God rules over the world, despite resistance to his reign and rule (cf. Ps. 103:19). His rule manifests itself in judgment and salvation—here we see his judgments over a world in rebellion against him. God's judgments touch every sphere of the world, including land, sea, rivers, and skies. The world is disfigured and distorted, showing that it is neither what it should be nor what it will be. God's judgment isn't irrational, for we saw previously that it falls in answer to the prayers of the saints (Rev. 8:1–5) in response to the rebellion of human beings against God. So, God's judgments are one way he restores order and justice and harmony to a world gone wrong—it is one stage along the pathway by which shalom will be reestablished in the world.

### <span id="page-633-8"></span>REVELATION 9:1–12

9 And the fifth angel blew his trumpet, and I saw a star fallen from heaven to earth, and he was given the key to the shaft of the bottomless pit.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>2</sup>**He opened the shaft of the bottomless pit, and from the shaft rose smoke like the smoke of a great furnace, and the sun and the air were darkened with the smoke from the shaft. **3**Then from the smoke came locusts on the earth, and they were given power like the power of scorpions of the earth. **4**They were told not to harm the grass of the earth or any green plant or any tree, but only those people who do not have the seal of God on their foreheads. **5**They were allowed to torment them for five months,

but not to kill them, and their torment was like the torment of a scorpion when it stings someone. **6**And in those days people will seek death and will not find it. They will long to die, but death will flee from them.

**<sup>7</sup>** In appearance the locusts were like horses prepared for battle: on their heads were what looked like crowns of gold; their faces were like human faces, **<sup>8</sup>** their hair like women's hair, and their teeth like lions' teeth; **<sup>9</sup>** they had breastplates like breastplates of iron, and the noise of their wings was like the noise of many chariots with horses rushing into battle. **10**They have tails and stings like scorpions, and their power to hurt people for five months is in their tails. **11**They have as king over them the angel of the bottomless pit. His name in Hebrew is Abaddon, and in Greek he is called Apollyon.*<sup>2</sup>*

**<sup>12</sup>**The first woe has passed; behold, two woes are still to come.

1Greek *the abyss*; also verses 2, 11 2*Abaddon* means *destruction*; *Apollyon* means *destroyer*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-634-4"></span><span id="page-634-3"></span><span id="page-634-2"></span><span id="page-634-1"></span>The blowing of the fifth trumpet introduces us to more strange and apocalyptic imagery, difficult to interpret. The passage describes the unleashing of a demonic horde upon the earth to torment and afflict human beings. The star that fell from heaven to earth is probably a good angel, granted authority over the abyss (Rev. 9:1). The angel opens the abyss, and the world is darkened by the smoke rising from it (v. 2). Locusts, which are probably demons, appear on earth out of the smoke and have power like scorpions (v. 3). We see from verse 4 that these are not ordinary locusts, for they have no interest in grass, green plants, or trees. Instead, they seek those who do not have God's seal on their foreheads (v. 4). These locustlike creatures torment those who do not have God's seal, stinging them with the sting of a scorpion (v. 5). The torment will be so great that people will long to die yet will continue living (v. 6). The appearance of the locusts is then described: they are like horses prepared for battle, but with human faces (v. 7). Their hair is like women's, and their teeth like lions' (v. 8). They have iron breastplates, and the sound of their wings is like chariots preparing for war (v. 9). Most of the language here is taken from Joel's description of the day of the Lord, showing that these "locusts" are agents of judgment. Their tails sting like scorpions, and they inflict misery on unbelievers for five months (v. 10). Their king is the "angel of the abyss." He is identified as "Apollyon," which means "destroyer," and he is probably Satan (v. 11). John then informs the reader that two woes remain (v. 12).

#### <span id="page-634-10"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-634-11"></span><span id="page-634-9"></span><span id="page-634-8"></span><span id="page-634-7"></span><span id="page-634-6"></span><span id="page-634-5"></span>V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19) . . .
	- B. Fifth Trumpet: Demonic Locust Plague (9:1–12)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-634-0"></span>9:1 When the fifth angel blew his trumpet, John saw a star fall from heaven to earth. The star probably represents an angel (cf. Judg. 5:20; Job 38:7), and some <span id="page-635-10"></span>identify it as Satan or another evil angel. Such an interpretation is attractive, but elsewhere in Revelation it is always good angels who do God's bidding, and hence the evidence for it being a satanic or evil angel is not convincing. It seems a bit more likely that a good angel is in view here, but certainty is impossible. The angel was granted the key to open the "bottomless pit." We recognize again that the language is symbolic, for demons aren't literally confined in a pit under the earth. The same language is used of the place of origin for the beast (Rev. 11:7; 17:8), and Satan is thrown into the abyss for a thousand years (20:3). The "key" grants the angel authority and rule over those in the pit (cf. 20:1), implying that the angel's authority is granted him by God. This reading is confirmed by the words "he was given" (*edothē*). Whenever the clause "it was given" or "he was given" (or an equivalent phrase) appears in Revelation, God is the implied subject of the passive verb (6:2, 4, 8, 11; 7:2; 8:3; 9:3, 5; 11:1, 2; 13:5, 7, 14, 15; 16:8; 19:8; 20:4).

<span id="page-635-12"></span><span id="page-635-11"></span><span id="page-635-7"></span><span id="page-635-6"></span><span id="page-635-0"></span>9:2 When the angel opens the shaft of the abyss, smoke billows forth as from a gigantic furnace. The sun and air are both darkened by the smoke spreading over the world, representing judgment (cf. Gen. 19:28; Isa. 34:10). In Joel, the sky is darkened by a locust horde (Joel 2:10), and here we find God's judgment diffused throughout the world.

<span id="page-635-5"></span><span id="page-635-1"></span>9:3 As John peers through the smoke, locusts emerge on the earth. Locusts represent judgment and were one of the plagues the Lord poured out on Egypt (Ex. 10:4). We actually have the singular "it was given" (*edothē*) to denote again that the authority granted to the locusts is finally from God, even if Satan is an intermediary agent. The biblical portrait of evil is complex, for God rules over evil without being morally blameworthy, while Satan is counted guilty for his motives and actions. The authority of the locusts is compared to the authority of scorpions. We have an important hint here that these locusts aren't ordinary locusts, for scorpions are associated with the demonic elsewhere in Scripture and Jewish writings (Luke 10:19; cf. Deut. 8:15; *Sir.* 26:7). Furthermore, since their leader is Apollyon (Rev. 9:11), these are clearly not ordinary locusts.

<span id="page-635-9"></span><span id="page-635-8"></span><span id="page-635-4"></span><span id="page-635-3"></span><span id="page-635-2"></span>9:4 The locusts are instructed, presumably by God (showing again that they are the agents of his judgment), to spare the green grass, new green growth, and trees. Instead, they are to concentrate their destruction on those who lack God's seal on their foreheads. The 144,000, representing the people of God, have been sealed by him and protected from his wrath (cf. 7:1–17; cf. Ezek. 9:4, 6). Therefore the locusts attack unbelievers, those who will face the full brunt of God's wrath. We have further and decisive evidence that the locusts aren't literal, for these locusts have no interest in eating green grass or plants. No one has ever heard of locusts that don't eat green plants! The locusts ate every plant when Egypt was devastated (Ex. 10:12; cf. *Wisd. Sol.* 16:9). But these locusts are interested only in attacking human beings, demonstrating that these are bizarre locusts. In fact, they are not locusts at all but demons from the abyss.

<span id="page-636-8"></span><span id="page-636-0"></span>9:5 God did not permit ("it was not given [*edothē*]") the locusts to kill unbelievers not sealed by God. Instead, they torment them for "five months." Five is a symbolic number here, signifying a limited period of time. The torment is compared to the sting of a scorpion. We are reminded, although the context is different, of God allowing Satan to afflict righteous Job but not to kill him (Job 2:4–7). Here too, God determines the extent of the torment to be inflicted. Since the text is laden with symbolic language about locusts as demons, the stings should not be construed as literal stings. Indeed, John says the torture was *like* (*hōs*) the torment inflicted by scorpions. It is difficult to be certain what John has in mind. The first four trumpet judgments covered the created world from skies to oceans, and here John refers to human beings. The reference is probably to the psychological misery and unhappiness marking human existence. Perhaps the reference to five months indicates such torment isn't constant or all-encompassing.

<span id="page-636-9"></span><span id="page-636-1"></span>9:6 The life of human beings is beset by wretchedness, ultimately because we have rebelled against God. Hence, there is a desire for death (cf. Job 3:21; Jer. 8:3), but also a desire for life, and the two war in the human breast, tormenting human existence. Unbelievers want to die, but at the same time they fear to die. John is not saying every fallen human is suicidal or deeply unhappy. His point is that torment and a desire to die characterize human existence, particularly the lives of unbelievers. The experience is complex and difficult to describe, but in any case life on earth can be a kind of living death. The desire to die wells up in us, and yet death flees from those who have turned against God, since there is both a longing for death and a great fear of dying.

<span id="page-636-10"></span><span id="page-636-6"></span><span id="page-636-2"></span>9:7 In the next several verses John describes the locusts. It is clear from the outset that the description isn't literal, for the word "like" is used three times to indicate similes instead of literal descriptions. The locusts are compared to horses prepared for battle (cf. Job 39:20); they have something like golden crowns on their heads, symbolizing victory. Their faces are like human beings, perhaps suggesting they combine animal and human characteristics and have power over all creation. John alludes to Joel 2:4, where we find an actual locust invasion, with locusts compared to war horses.24 Joel describes the judgment of the day of the Lord (cf. Joel 1:15; 2:1, 11), and John uses the imagery of locusts to describe God's judgment on unbelievers. They are, so to speak, under siege, as demons are unleashed upon them. It is as if a human army with horses and authority were on the attack, but their foes are worse than any human army.

<span id="page-636-11"></span><span id="page-636-7"></span><span id="page-636-4"></span>9:8 The description of the locusts continues, for their hair is like women's and their teeth like lions'. The prophet Joel is again alluded to, for Joel declares, "A nation has come up against my land, powerful and beyond number; its teeth are lions' teeth, and it has the fangs of a lioness" (Joel 1:6). Joel uses the image of

<span id="page-636-5"></span><span id="page-636-3"></span><sup>24</sup> Scholars dispute whether locusts or a human army is in view in Joel 2. I incline to the view that actual locusts are described.

lions' teeth to describe locusts, and John, as noted above, takes up Joel's imagery into his apocalyptic symbolism. He states that the locusts have hair like women's. Long hair on locusts is ghoulish, ghastly, and eerie, which is John's point. These are otherworldly creatures—what terrifies us in nightmares punishes the ungodly. We are reminded of Joseph Stalin, who heard wolves howling as he lay dying, as if they were descending upon him to tear him apart.

<span id="page-637-6"></span>9:9 These terrible locusts have breastplates of iron (showing that they cannot be killed), and the sound of their wings is likened to the clattering of attacking chariots. The imagery is again derived in part from the locust invasion described in Joel. "As with the rumbling of chariots, they leap on the tops of the mountains, like the crackling of a flame of fire devouring the stubble, like a powerful army drawn up for battle" (Joel 2:5). This locust army, John teaches, is on the attack; they are an invincible army. Humans not sealed by God are helpless to withstand the ferocity of the attack.

<span id="page-637-7"></span><span id="page-637-5"></span><span id="page-637-3"></span>9:10 The torment inflicted by the stings of these scorpion-like creatures, adumbrated in verse 5, is picked up again here. We see repeatedly that these are not ordinary locusts, for locusts do not have "tails like scorpions." Nor does the literal sting of a scorpion persist for five months. As noted in verse 5, the reference to scorpions shows the demonic character of these locusts, as they inflict agony, anguish, and distress on those not sealed by God.

<span id="page-637-8"></span><span id="page-637-4"></span><span id="page-637-2"></span>9:11 The demonic character of the locusts is confirmed here, for the ruler and king of the locusts is the angel with authority over the bottomless pit. Actual locusts do not have a king (cf. Prov. 30:27), but these locusts do! Some think this angel is the one who fell to earth and released these demons from the pit (Rev. 9:1), i.e., Satan himself. But I have suggested that the angel in verse 1 is a good angel and shouldn't be identified with Apollyon. Still, Apollyon in this verse is Satan himself. "Apollyon" means "destroyer"—one who destroys and ruins human beings, and the locusts become the agent of this destruction. The Hebrew "Abaddon" has the same meaning in this context, describing Satan's destructive power. In the OT, Abaddon is often parallel with Sheol and designates the place of the dead and the power of death (Job 26:6; 28:22; 31:12; Ps. 88:11; Prov. 15:11; 27:20). John extends the meaning: the place of death is now personified, for there is a king over the dead, Satan himself (cf. Heb. 2:14–15). Job calls death the "king of terrors" (Job 18:14), and those in Satan's realm will not be spared from such terror.

<span id="page-637-10"></span><span id="page-637-9"></span><span id="page-637-1"></span><span id="page-637-0"></span>9:12 The first woe, bringing much anguish and terror, has now been explicated, but there are two more to come (9:13–19; 11:15–19).

#### *Response*

In this text we see a fascinating confluence of divine sovereignty, demonic agency, and human misery. Ultimately, God is sovereign, even over the actions of the Devil and demons. We see the malevolence of the Devil and demons in the anguish they <span id="page-638-0"></span>bring into the lives of human beings. At the same time, God is sovereign over the torment human beings feel; it is his punishment on the ungodly. Yet, he uses the Devil and demons as his agents in inflicting misery. Still, God's role in what happens to humans is dramatically different from that of the Devil and demons, for God always does what is holy and just, while the Devil and demons are filled with hate and spite. We also learn from this text that sin brings anguish and torment. Initially, it may be pleasurable (Heb. 11:25), but there is a sting in the tail (pun intended!), and the end result is grief. When we see human beings controlled by self-pity, anger, lust, and jealousy, full of unhappiness and rage against life, it is part of the judgment of God. They are under Satan's dominion. Their lives are slowly unraveling, and pretty soon the thread is gone and only insanity remains. Everyone in hell is insane, for there is nothing more insane than the worship of self and the hatred of God. This too is part of God's judgment on the human race.

### <span id="page-638-2"></span>REVELATION 9:13–21
