**<sup>13</sup>**Then the sixth angel blew his trumpet, and I heard a voice from the four horns of the golden altar before God, **<sup>14</sup>** saying to the sixth angel who had the trumpet, "Release the four angels who are bound at the great river Euphrates." **<sup>15</sup>** So the four angels, who had been prepared for the hour, the day, the month, and the year, were released to kill a third of mankind. **16**The number of mounted troops was twice ten thousand times ten thousand; I heard their number. **17**And this is how I saw the horses in my vision and those who rode them: they wore breastplates the color of fire and of sapphire*<sup>1</sup>* and of sulfur, and the heads of the horses were like lions' heads, and fire and smoke and sulfur came out of their mouths. **18**By these three plagues a third of mankind was killed, by the fire and smoke and sulfur coming out of their mouths. **19**For the power of the horses is in their mouths and in their tails, for their tails are like serpents with heads, and by means of them they wound.

**<sup>20</sup>**The rest of mankind, who were not killed by these plagues, did not repent of the works of their hands nor give up worshiping demons and idols of gold and silver and bronze and stone and wood, which cannot see or hear or walk, **21**nor did they repent of their murders or their sorceries or their sexual immorality or their thefts.

<span id="page-638-3"></span>1Greek *hyacinth*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-638-1"></span>The second woe is rehearsed in Revelation 9:13–19, while verses 20–21 are the response to God's judgments. People should repent upon seeing and experiencing the judgment of God, but instead they further harden their hearts. The second woe <span id="page-639-14"></span><span id="page-639-13"></span><span id="page-639-12"></span><span id="page-639-9"></span><span id="page-639-5"></span>occurs at the blast of the sixth trumpet. A voice from the golden altar tells the angel with the trumpet to release the four angels bound at the Euphrates (vv. 13–14). The angels are released and kill one-third of the human race, as they were destined to do (v. 15). John *hears* the number of 200 million mounted troops (v. 16), and he *sees*  horses and horsemen in his vision (v. 17; cf. 5:5–6; 7:4, 9). The horsemen had breastplates of red, blue, and sulfur yellow. These horses are unlike any other, for their heads are like the heads of lions, with fire, smoke, and sulfur coming from their mouths. Hence John probably describes demons here. This demonic horde slays a third of the human race with fire, smoke, and sulfur (9:18). The unearthly character and demonic nature of these horses is apparent again in verse 19. The power of the horses is located in their mouths and tails. The focus is on their tails, which are like snakes and inflict injury, presumably death, on others. The death of a third of the human race (almost certainly not a literal number) functions to warn those who so far have escaped death (v. 20). On seeing God's just judgment, they should repent of their idolatry. But the hardness of their hearts is evident, for they continue in their evil despite seeing the consequences of the evil they embraced (v. 21).

#### <span id="page-639-17"></span><span id="page-639-16"></span><span id="page-639-15"></span>*Section Outline*

- V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19) . . .
	- C. Sixth Trumpet: Demonic Cavalry (9:13–21)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-639-10"></span><span id="page-639-7"></span><span id="page-639-2"></span>9:13 The sixth angel sounds his trumpet, and the contents of this judgment represent the second woe (cf. 8:13; 9:12). The trumpet judgments are from a censer of incense hurled from the altar of incense onto the earth (8:1–5), and John hears a voice from the four horns on the altar of incense (Ex. 27:2; 30:2–3). Horns on altars don't typically speak, but this is apocalyptic literature! Perhaps the voice represents an angel speaking. The connection with the altar reminds us that the judgments are an answer to the prayers of the saints (Rev. 8:3–4).

<span id="page-639-18"></span><span id="page-639-11"></span><span id="page-639-8"></span><span id="page-639-6"></span><span id="page-639-4"></span><span id="page-639-3"></span><span id="page-639-1"></span><span id="page-639-0"></span>9:14 The voice from the altar instructs the (good) angel with the sixth trumpet to release the four angels being detained at the Euphrates River. Earlier, four angels were restraining the winds of judgment from being unleashed on the earth (7:1). Here the bound angels are probably demons, since the language of binding is used elsewhere of Satan (Matt. 12:29; Mark 3:27; Rev. 20:2); they cannot be the same angels described in 7:1, as the location is different. The Euphrates River comes into the picture again with this judgment (Rev. 16:12). In the OT, the Euphrates' headwaters were in the land of Eden (Gen. 2:14), and the river was the border of the land promised to Abraham (Gen. 15:18; cf. Deut. 1:7; Josh. 1:4) and possessed finally by Solomon (1 Kings 4:21, 24). The enemies of God and his people, however, were on the far side of the Euphrates. John is also perhaps alluding to the Parthians, enemies of Rome who invaded from the east in 53 BC and AD 62. So here, too, wicked forces are unleashed from the Euphrates.

<span id="page-640-11"></span><span id="page-640-8"></span><span id="page-640-4"></span>9:15 The four angels bound at the Euphrates are released to kill a third of humanity. The Euphrates was the boundary between the Roman and Parthian Empires, and thus the Parthian enemies would have come over the Euphrates (cf. *1 En.* 56:6–57:3). "Released" (*elythēsan*) suggests they are demons, as Satan is also "released" (*lyō*; Rev. 20:3, 7) by God. Good angels aren't "released" but are commissioned or sent, whereas demons are restrained by God but sometimes released and permitted by him to undertake specific activities. The reference to the hour, day, month, and year probably does not mean the punishment took place on a specific day. It refers to the era in which this punishment took place, and John probably has in mind the entire period between Christ's resurrection and second coming. Others place this punishment in a final seven-year tribulation period, but, as we have seen, there is no warrant in Scripture for a sevenyear period of tribulation (cf. comment on 7:13–14). The slaying of a third of human beings does not represent a literal number but means the attacks led to the death of a great number of people. We see the same emphasis on one-third in previous trumpet judgments (8:7–12). The death inflicted by demons uses ordinary means, such as disease and pestilence (cf. 6:3–8), and so what John records here fits with the seal judgments, overlapping them temporally. At the same time, it seems the trumpets represent an intensification of what we see in the seal judgments. In the fifth trumpet (9:1–12), we see unbelievers longing to die because of their misery. The sixth trumpet and the second woe (9:13–21) show people dying because of demonic activity. This demonic activity is not visible to us, of course, since demons use ordinary means to accomplish their purposes. In particular, demons use false teaching to deceive and advance their purposes (cf. 1 Tim. 4:1–5), and hence it is possible the death described here refers to both spiritual and physical death. Ultimately, the spiritually dead also die physically and eternally. They experience what Revelation calls the "second death" (Rev. 2:11; 20:6, 14; 21:8).

<span id="page-640-9"></span><span id="page-640-6"></span><span id="page-640-5"></span><span id="page-640-3"></span><span id="page-640-2"></span><span id="page-640-1"></span><span id="page-640-0"></span>9:16 John *hears* the number of the demonic army, a staggering 200 million. Earlier we noted that John heard the number of the 144,000 (7:4). The number isn't literal, of course, but designates an incalculable army. In any case, John isn't talking about a human army, for the release of the four demonic angels (cf. 9:14–15) unleashes an incomprehensibly evil demonic horde.

<span id="page-640-10"></span><span id="page-640-7"></span>9:17 The horses and their riders constitute a massive army. The riders have breastplates of fire, sapphire, and sulfur, but the horses are truly "out of this world," for their heads are like lions, and fire, smoke, and sulfur belch from their mouths. John is not describing modern weaponry, nor does he depict literal horses. His point is that this army is no ordinary army; it isn't a human army at all. He uses symbolic language to describe a demonic horde inflicting death on human beings, and the death in view is fundamentally spiritual death—separation from God, leading to physical and eternal death.

<span id="page-641-9"></span>9:18 The fire, smoke, and sulfur coming from the horses' mouths represent three plagues. The number three is symbolic, and thus the plagues refer to every kind of disease, virus, and pestilence that kills human beings. Satanic teachings are probably also in view. The plagues poured out on unbelieving Egypt foreshadow the judgments recorded here.

<span id="page-641-10"></span>9:19 These horses are nothing like horses in this world, for the power to injure people is in their mouths and tails. Their tails are like serpents, signaling demonic power at work. The language is apocalyptic and symbolic. John is not anticipating modern weaponry. Instead, he teaches that the plagues come from demonic powers. Demons destroy human beings, especially through false teaching that separates unbelievers from God.

<span id="page-641-13"></span><span id="page-641-11"></span>9:20 The judgments meted out on human beings are intended to provoke other unbelievers ("the rest" are non-Christians) to repent (cf. 16:9, 11). In this sense, the judgments have a redemptive purpose. Unfortunately, those who were not killed by these plagues do not repent. John is not intending to make a universal statement here, as if no unbeliever ever repents upon seeing God's judgment on others. The hyperbolic nature of the statement is typical of apocalyptic literature. Another way of stating John's point here is that, in general, those who remain unbelievers are stubborn and do not turn to God even when they see depictions of the coming judgment.

The reason for the failure to repent is elaborated further. People do not want to turn from "the works of their hands." Repentance means to confess that what one has done is evil. But humans do not repent because they are too proud to admit that what they have done is wrong.

<span id="page-641-7"></span><span id="page-641-3"></span><span id="page-641-1"></span>The reason men do not repent is pursued further. It is a matter of worship and affections. Humans grow attached to demons (Deut. 32:17; Ps. 96:5; 1 Cor. 10:20) and idols (cf. Jer. 1:16; Dan. 5:4, 23). The attachment to idols is foolish and futile, showing how disordered our affections are, for idols cannot see, hear, or walk (cf. Pss. 115:4–7; 135:15–17). What John writes here is deeply informed by the OT. Isaiah says concerning Israel, "Their land is filled with idols; they bow down to the work of their hands, to what their own fingers have made" (Isa. 2:8). In other words, idols can't deliver what we long for them to provide, and yet unbelievers, because of spiritual blindness, fail to see this (cf. Isa. 2:20), whereas those who do repent perceive that idols cannot deliver what they promise (Isa. 17:8).

<span id="page-641-12"></span><span id="page-641-8"></span><span id="page-641-6"></span><span id="page-641-5"></span><span id="page-641-4"></span><span id="page-641-2"></span><span id="page-641-0"></span>9:21 Verse 21 zeros in on various sins requiring repentance, specifically murder, sorcery, sexual immorality, and theft (cf. Gal. 5:20; Rev. 21:8; 22:15). It is striking that all of these sins are forbidden in the Ten Commandments. Sorcery relies on another god besides the Lord (cf. 2 Kings 9:22; Nah. 3:4), thereby taking his name in vain (cf. Ex. 20:3, 7). Murder and stealing reveal how human beings secure their well-being through their own machinations, while sexual immorality pursues pleasure on our terms instead of through adherence to God's standards.

#### *Response*

God displays his sovereignty and justice in punishing those who pursue evil. Still, there is a redemptive motive in such punishments, for it displays the ultimate consequences of rebellion against God to those who have not repented. Still, many humans refuse to turn from their sin and repudiate their idols. They are blinded by their idols, thinking they can bring joy and fulfillment, and yet their idols lead to futility, to profound emptiness and disillusionment. Other gods can never substitute for the one true and living God. Our only joy and satisfaction come through him.

### REVELATION 10:1–11

10 Then I saw another mighty angel coming down from heaven, wrapped in a cloud, with a rainbow over his head, and his face was like the sun, and his legs like pillars of fire. **2**He had a little scroll open in his hand. And he set his right foot on the sea, and his left foot on the land, **<sup>3</sup>** and called out with a loud voice, like a lion roaring. When he called out, the seven thunders sounded. **4**And when the seven thunders had sounded, I was about to write, but I heard a voice from heaven saying, "Seal up what the seven thunders have said, and do not write it down." **5**And the angel whom I saw standing on the sea and on the land raised his right hand to heaven **<sup>6</sup>** and swore by him who lives forever and ever, who created heaven and what is in it, the earth and what is in it, and the sea and what is in it, that there would be no more delay, **7**but that in the days of the trumpet call to be sounded by the seventh angel, the mystery of God would be fulfilled, just as he announced to his servants the prophets.

**<sup>8</sup>**Then the voice that I had heard from heaven spoke to me again, saying, "Go, take the scroll that is open in the hand of the angel who is standing on the sea and on the land." **<sup>9</sup>** So I went to the angel and told him to give me the little scroll. And he said to me, "Take and eat it; it will make your stomach bitter, but in your mouth it will be sweet as honey." **10**And I took the little scroll from the hand of the angel and ate it. It was sweet as honey in my mouth, but when I had eaten it my stomach was made bitter. **11**And I was told, "You must again prophesy about many peoples and nations and languages and kings."

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-642-1"></span><span id="page-642-0"></span>We expect the seventh trumpet to follow the sixth trumpet, but Revelation 10:1–11:14 is an interlude prior to the final trumpet. In this interlude, John prepares readers for the seventh trumpet by emphasizing the prophetic ministry of the church—the proclamation of God's Word. Chapter 10 begins with a mighty <span id="page-643-13"></span><span id="page-643-12"></span><span id="page-643-11"></span><span id="page-643-8"></span>angel coming down from heaven, glorious in his appearance (v. 1). The angel has a small scroll in his hand, probably different from the one with seven seals (cf. 5:1–6:17). The angel's message is universal, for he plants his feet on the sea and the land (10:2). His voice roars like a lion, and the seven thunders also speak (v. 3), but John isn't permitted to write down what they say (v. 4), indicating that part of what is to come is hidden. The angel then swears by the God who created all things that the time of the end has come and God will conclude and fulfill what is prophesied by the seventh trumpet (vv. 5–7). The old creation is coming to an end, as John prophesied, but the seven thunders inform us that not everything to come is revealed to us. Nevertheless, God's mystery will be revealed, and what was prophesied will be fulfilled. John is then told to take and eat the angel's scroll (vv. 8–9). It is like honey in his mouth but bitter in his stomach (v. 10). God's Word is sweet like honey, but it prophesies destruction against those who turn from him. John is given the scroll to eat because he must prophesy further against people, nations, languages, and kings (v. 11). History will end with the seventh trumpet, but John has more to say about the course of history, and he will pull back the curtain on Satan and the beast (12:1–14:20) and the great harlot Babylon (17:1–19:10) in succeeding chapters.

#### <span id="page-643-17"></span><span id="page-643-16"></span><span id="page-643-15"></span><span id="page-643-14"></span>*Section Outline*

- V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19) . . .
	- D. Interlude (10:1–11:14)
		- 1. Renewed Call to Prophesy (10:1–11)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-643-10"></span><span id="page-643-9"></span><span id="page-643-3"></span><span id="page-643-1"></span><span id="page-643-0"></span>10:1 John sees another mighty angel, just as he earlier saw a mighty angel asking who was worthy to open the scroll with seven seals (5:2). The angel here descends from heaven (cf. Dan. 12:5), just as others do later in the book (Rev. 18:1; 20:1). The angel is described in glorious terms: he is "wrapped in a cloud," which often denotes God's presence (cf. Ex. 13:21; 14:19; 16:10; 24:15; Lev. 16:2; Num. 9:15; Deut. 31:15; 1 Kings 8:10; Neh. 9:12, 19; Ps. 99:7; Isa. 19:1; Ezek. 1:28), and thus is an emissary of the Lord. The "rainbow over his head" also signifies God's presence and authority (cf. Ezek. 1:28; Rev. 4:3). The angel's face shines with the sun, just as Jesus' face shone with the glory of God (Matt. 17:2; Rev. 1:16). His feet are "pillars of fire," while Jesus' were burnished bronze (1:15).

<span id="page-643-19"></span><span id="page-643-18"></span><span id="page-643-7"></span><span id="page-643-6"></span><span id="page-643-5"></span><span id="page-643-4"></span><span id="page-643-2"></span>Since the angel is described in such glorious terms, we might think he is Jesus himself, for the word "angel" means messenger, and Jesus could be God's messenger. Despite the attractiveness of this view, it should be rejected for the following reasons. First, Jesus is never called an angel in Revelation, and, in fact, the worship of God and Jesus is clearly distinguished from worship of an angel (19:10; 22:8–9). Second, an angel may be described in glorious terms, some of which are true also of God, and yet be distinct from him (cf. Dan. 10:5–6 and comments on Rev. 1:13–16). Third, the angel swears by God, suggesting that he himself is not <span id="page-644-18"></span><span id="page-644-13"></span>divine (10:6). Fourth, the reference to "another mighty angel" points back to the same expression in 5:2, where an angel is clearly in view (cf. also 18:21).

<span id="page-644-19"></span><span id="page-644-14"></span><span id="page-644-12"></span>10:2 The angel holds in his hand a little scroll, which should be distinguished, contrary to some commentators, from the seven-sealed scroll, for several reasons (5:1–6:17). First, the scroll is given to John instead of to the Lion of the tribe of Judah (10:9). Second, John does not open the scroll but eats it (10:9–10). Third, in Ezekiel, which John draws on here, the scroll is open, but the scroll in chapters 5–6 is sealed until opened by the Lamb. Fourth, God holds the scroll in chapter 5, but here the angel holds it.

<span id="page-644-11"></span><span id="page-644-6"></span>The angel puts one foot on land and one on the sea, implying he is larger than life (cf. Dan. 12:5), and John communicates that the angel's message is for the entire world, for those who live on land and those who sail the seas.

<span id="page-644-15"></span><span id="page-644-8"></span><span id="page-644-4"></span>10:3 The angel roars like a lion, and when the Lord roars he judges those he roars against (Joel 3:16; Amos 1:2; 3:8). We see again that the angel is God's agent, roaring on his behalf. The shouting of the angel resounds, and the "seven thunders" also peal forth. The seven thunders remind us of Psalm 29, where a thunderous storm sweeps the land. When the Lord thunders, he judges those opposed to him (cf. Ex. 9:23, 28; 1 Sam. 2:10; 7:10; Isa. 29:6) or shows his awesome holiness (Ex. 19:16, 19; 20:18). In Revelation the final judgment is accompanied by thunder (Rev. 8:5; 11:19; 16:18; 19:6). As the number seven is symbolic, the seven thunders probably depict a full revelation of God's majesty and wrath.

<span id="page-644-20"></span><span id="page-644-16"></span><span id="page-644-10"></span><span id="page-644-2"></span><span id="page-644-1"></span>10:4 The seven thunders resound, and John is about to write the message communicated. Suddenly, John is interrupted by a heavenly voice instructing him not to reveal the content of the seven thunders. He is to "seal up" their message instead of writing it down. This stands in contrast to the remainder of the book, for John is told at the conclusion of the book *not* to seal up the message, for the end is imminent (22:10). In this respect, the sealing of the seven thunders echoes the command to Daniel to seal up what he had written, since it related to the end of time (Dan. 8:26; 12:9). Revelation, as a whole, must be distinguished from Daniel, since "the time is near" (Rev. 1:3), and thus the message is revealed to John's generation. Nevertheless, the message of the seven thunders is similar to the message given to Daniel, for the readers are left in the dark as to its contents. In other words, the fullness of what is to come at the end is still concealed and hidden from believers. Not everything is disclosed; surprises still await us as history draws to a close.

<span id="page-644-17"></span><span id="page-644-9"></span><span id="page-644-7"></span><span id="page-644-5"></span><span id="page-644-3"></span><span id="page-644-0"></span>10:5–7 John sees the angel lift his hand to heaven and swear by the God who made all things—heaven, earth, and sea. As the creator of all things, God rules and reigns over all (cf. Gen. 14:19, 22; Neh. 9:6; Ps. 146:6). The angel declares that the time of delay is over. The angel in Daniel's day lifted up his hand to heaven and swore that there was still a significant delay before the end (Dan. 12:6–7; cf. Deut. 32:40), but here the angel declares that the end has arrived. The angel is not saying that temporal existence will cease, that eternity will consist of an eternal <span id="page-645-17"></span><span id="page-645-16"></span><span id="page-645-13"></span><span id="page-645-11"></span><span id="page-645-10"></span>now. That question is fascinating, but John is not considering such a philosophical matter here. He means, as verse 7 makes plain, that the time of the old creation has ended and the new creation prophesied in Revelation 21:1–22:5 is at hand. The sounding of the seventh trumpet by the seventh angel will wrap up history as we know it (11:15). God's "mystery" will be fulfilled. Mystery in the Scriptures typically refers to something previously hidden that is now revealed (e.g., Rom. 16:25–26; Eph. 1:9; 3:3–5; Col. 1:26–27). When the end comes, everything hidden (including the seven thunders just noted in Rev. 10:3–4) will be fulfilled. All that God predicted and prophesied to his prophets will become a reality (cf. Amos 3:7; Zech. 1:6). The plans and purposes of creation, both revealed and hidden to us in part (Deut. 29:29), will be fulfilled. God's prophecies are both a prophecy fulfilled and a mystery to be revealed. One of the purposes of the interlude is explained here. John underscores that the seventh trumpet is the end of this present evil age, and the conclusion of all things sums up divine mysteries and fulfills God's prophecies.

<span id="page-645-14"></span><span id="page-645-12"></span><span id="page-645-9"></span><span id="page-645-8"></span><span id="page-645-6"></span><span id="page-645-4"></span><span id="page-645-2"></span><span id="page-645-0"></span>10:8–10 The heavenly voice addresses John again (cf. 10:4), instructing him to take the scroll from the angel standing with one foot on the sea and one on land. When John takes the scroll, he is instructed to eat it. John's eating echoes Ezekiel, whom God commands to eat the scroll given to him (Ezek. 2:8–3:3). Similarly, Jeremiah says, "Your words were found, and I ate them, and your words became to me a joy and the delight of my heart" (Jer. 15:16). John's taking and eating the scroll signifies his prophetic ministry, and as the church proclaims John's message it shares in this prophetic ministry. Eating the scroll will make John's stomach bitter, but it will also be sweet like honey in his mouth. Again the words echo Ezekiel, who is to fill his stomach with the scroll, which was "in my mouth as sweet as honey" (Ezek. 3:3). God's Word is always a delight, always a joy (cf. Pss. 19:10; 119:103). On the other hand, eating the scroll gives John a stomachache because it is a word of judgment. Such a perspective fits with Ezekiel, for Ezekiel also prophesied judgment, and his scroll contained "words of lamentation and mourning and woe" (Ezek. 2:10). Alternatively, some think this means that John's stomach is bitter because the church will face persecution, but the word is sweet in his mouth because the church will triumph. This interpretation seems less likely, since it does not match as closely the prophecy in Ezekiel. Furthermore, the next verse indicates the message has to do with the judgment destined for those who oppose God and refuse to worship him.

<span id="page-645-15"></span><span id="page-645-7"></span><span id="page-645-5"></span><span id="page-645-3"></span><span id="page-645-1"></span>10:11 The significance of eating the scroll is now communicated to John. The verb here is actually plural, "*They* said to me" (NRSV), perhaps to represent the words of the prophets that John has ingested. The contents of the scroll, as noted above, made John's stomach ache, indicating that judgment is coming. Here the meaning of eating the scroll is explained further. Just as Ezekiel eats the scroll before he prophesies (Ezek. 2:8–3:3), so here John's eating of the scroll means he must prophecy against peoples, nations, languages, and many kings (cf. Jer. 25:30; Ezek. 25:2). "Must" indicates that John's prophetic ministry and the prophetic ministry of <span id="page-646-5"></span>the church is a divine necessity. We gain further insight into the interlude between the sixth and seventh trumpets; the seventh trumpet signals the end of the old creation, but there is more to be said in subsequent chapters about the course of history. In particular, John will pull back the curtain on the activity of Satan and the beast before the time of the end (Rev. 12:1–14:20) and on the role of Rome, the great Babylon (17:1–19:5). What John emphasizes here, then, is the judgment to be imposed on (*epi* ) nations, tongues, peoples, and kings.

#### <span id="page-646-6"></span>*Response*

The message of the seven thunders reminds us that Revelation doesn't provide a complete map of things to come. Prophecy charts are popular in evangelicalism, and many have been very specific. But while God has revealed the broad outlines of the future, many things are hidden and concealed from us. We must not go beyond what is written and make assertions about what God has not revealed to us.

<span id="page-646-2"></span><span id="page-646-0"></span>We also see in this passage that the Word of God is sweet and delightful; it tastes like honey in our mouth and fills us with joy. Even if the message is one of judgment, the Word of God has sweetness because his Word is truth. On the other hand, the Word can also cause pain and anguish when proclaiming judgment. We think of the tears of Jeremiah, who prophesied judgment against Judah and wept over what was to come (Jer. 8:21; 9:1; 13:17). Jesus also wept over the destruction of Jerusalem (Matt. 23:37–39), showing that the judgment coming upon the city caused him intense grief. So too, we should weep and groan when the message to our culture is one of judgment and destruction. We do not desire the death of those to whom we minister. We resonate with the words of the Lord in Ezekiel: "I have no pleasure in the death of anyone, declares the Lord God; so turn, and live" (Ezek. 18:32).

## <span id="page-646-4"></span><span id="page-646-1"></span>REVELATION 11:1–2

11 Then I was given a measuring rod like a staff, and I was told, "Rise and measure the temple of God and the altar and those who worship there, **2**but do not measure the court outside the temple; leave that out, for it is given over to the nations, and they will trample the holy city for forty-two months."

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-646-3"></span>The interlude continues. John continues prophesying (cf. Rev. 10:11) and is instructed to take a measuring rod and measure the temple, altar, and worshipers (11:1). As will be explained below, this symbolizes God's protection of the saints, those who belong to him. The courtyard of the temple, however, is not protected (v. 2). The nations will trample the holy city of Jerusalem for forty-two months. In other words, even though God protects his people from his wrath, they will still face persecution and trouble, which will last the entire time from the resurrection to the second coming.

#### *Section Outline*

- V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19) . . .
	- D. Interlude (10:1–11:14) . . .
		- 2. Temple Protected (11:1–2)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-647-9"></span><span id="page-647-5"></span><span id="page-647-3"></span><span id="page-647-1"></span>11:1 John is given a measuring rod and instructed to measure the temple, altar, and worshipers in the temple. The instructions are reminiscent of what we find in Ezekiel, where a man is given a measuring reed to measure the temple (Ezek. 40:3, 5, 6). Later in Revelation, the heavenly Jerusalem descending to earth is also measured (Rev. 21:15–16; cf. Zech. 2:1–2). The measuring of the temple and the city means the temple or city will be built and will prosper and will be secure from attack. Some interpreters understand John to teach here that the temple in Jerusalem will be rebuilt where the Dome of the Rock is presently, and that the altar will be rebuilt as well. It is difficult to be sure which altar John has in mind the altar of burnt offering or the altar of incense (cf. Rev. 6:9; 8:3, 5; 9:13; 14:18; 16:7)—although the altar of incense seems more likely, since it is associated with God's sanctuary. When we consider the apocalyptic genre of Revelation and the symbolism pervading the book, a literal reading is unlikely, and thus John is not thinking of the rebuilding of a literal temple or altar. Instead, all three descriptions refer to the people of God, so that the temple and the altar refer to those who worship God. Believers are called a "temple" because they are the dwelling place of God (1 Cor. 3:16; 6:19; 2 Cor. 6:16), and indeed in Revelation 21:1–22:5 (cf. also Rev. 7:15) the whole universe is portrayed as God's dwelling place. The worshipers are individuals of God's people—they are God's temple. They are also designated in terms of the altar, for their lives are devoted to and surrendered to God. To say that the temple, altar, and worshipers are measured is to say that God protects and watches over his people—they are under his care, his lordship, and his sovereign oversight.

<span id="page-647-8"></span><span id="page-647-7"></span><span id="page-647-6"></span><span id="page-647-4"></span><span id="page-647-2"></span><span id="page-647-0"></span>11:2 John is told not to measure the courtyard outside the temple (cf. Ezek. 10:5; 40:17, 19, 20, 31). The courtyard is given to the nations, i.e., unbelievers, who will trample the holy city for forty-two months. Some interpret this to say Gentiles will literally defile the courtyard outside the temple for three and a half years and will control Jerusalem during this time. Such a reading is unpersuasive and fails to see the symbolism employed here. What John teaches is that the people of God will be protected by him; they will not face his wrath (cf. Rev. 11:1). Nevertheless,

<span id="page-648-15"></span><span id="page-648-14"></span><span id="page-648-8"></span><span id="page-648-0"></span>they will not be spared persecution from unbelievers. The "holy city" refers often to Jerusalem (Neh. 11:1, 18; Isa. 48:2; 52:1; Dan. 9:24; Matt. 4:5; 27:53). John uses the term elsewhere to refer to the city to come (Rev. 21:2, 10; 22:19), and in Revelation 21:2 the city is compared to a bride, showing that the city could also be a people (cf. comments on 21:1–2). We see a similar concept in Paul, who says the Jerusalem above is the mother of believers (Gal. 4:26). So, when John speaks of the holy city's being trampled for forty-two months by Gentiles (cf. Ps. 79:1; Isa. 63:18; Dan. 8:11–14; Zech. 12:3; Luke 21:24),25 he teaches that believers who are even now members of the heavenly city (cf. Heb. 12:22) are persecuted during this time period.

<span id="page-648-10"></span><span id="page-648-7"></span><span id="page-648-5"></span><span id="page-648-2"></span><span id="page-648-1"></span>The Gentiles will trample the holy city for forty-two months. Some understand this number literally, taking it to refer to three and a half years in the tribulation period. John draws here on the seventieth week in the prophecy of Daniel (Dan. 9:24–27) and alludes perhaps to the three-and-one-half-year ministry of Elijah (Luke 4:25; James 5:17). I would suggest the seventh week in Daniel designates not a literal period of time but the final era in history, the time between Jesus' resurrection and second coming. The number seven refers symbolically to this last period of time, and such a symbolic understanding fits nicely with the book of Revelation.

<span id="page-648-9"></span><span id="page-648-6"></span><span id="page-648-4"></span>A symbolic reading also accords with the context of Daniel 9, for Daniel learns that the seventy years of exile described by Jeremiah actually refer to a much longer period of time. The meaning of Daniel 9:24–27 is intensely controversial, and space is lacking to defend what is suggested here. When Daniel says sacrifice and offering are ended for "half of the week" (Dan. 9:27), he most likely refers to the death of Jesus, which ended all sacrifices as the final and definitive sacrifice for believers (Heb. 8:1–10:18). Hence, the first half of the seventieth week ended with Jesus' death and resurrection. John picks up the reference to half a week and applies it symbolically to his readers, designating the time after Jesus' death when evil rules. Thus, half a week or forty-two months is not a literal period of time but refers to the entire period between Jesus' resurrection and his second coming. It is described as half a week in dependence on Daniel 9:27. The half-week denoted here may have begun with Jesus' death or resurrection, or, alternatively, with the destruction of the temple in AD 70, though the former is more likely. In either case, the time period symbolizes the period until Jesus comes again. John refers to this period of time in various ways. Here he speaks of forty-two months (cf. also Rev. 13:5). Elsewhere, he speaks of 1,260 days (11:3; 12:6) and of "time, and times, and half a time" (12:14), another way of speaking of three and one-half years. In every instance, the period of time is the same.

<span id="page-648-13"></span><span id="page-648-12"></span><span id="page-648-3"></span>The three and one-half years is a time when evil reigns and the people of God face opposition. We see in 11:2 that believers are trampled (persecuted) by unbelievers (cf. Isa. 63:18; Dan. 8:13) during this time period. In 12:6 we learn that the people of God are nourished and protected by God for 1,260 days, and 11:1 com-

<span id="page-648-11"></span><sup>25</sup> The references cited here refer to the judgment of the literal city of Jerusalem, but John writes symbolically and does not refer to the actual city of Jerusalem.

<span id="page-649-5"></span><span id="page-649-4"></span><span id="page-649-3"></span>municates the same notion (that believers are protected by God) when it speaks of measuring the temple. Revelation 12:14 reiterates the same message after telling the reader that the Devil is trying to destroy the woman: even though believers face persecution and death, God is watching over them. In 13:5 we are told the beast exercises authority for forty-two months and during that time makes war against the saints (13:7). The experience of believers during this present evil age is complex. On the one hand, God protects and sustains his own. On the other hand, they face persecution and death at the hands of Satan and the beast. To sum up, forty-two months, 1,260 days, and time, times, and half a time all refer to the same period of time, when Satan and his allies persecute the church, extending from Jesus' resurrection to his second coming.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-649-1"></span><span id="page-649-0"></span>These two verses summarize the glory and the agony of existence in this present evil world. On the one hand, believers are protected and guarded by God. Nothing can separate us from God's love in Jesus Christ, as Paul teaches (Rom. 8:35–39). The Good Shepherd always tends his sheep and never forsakes or leaves them (John 10:1–15). On the other hand, those who belong to Jesus Christ will experience discrimination, hatred, and even death. Life in this world is not easy but is marked by suffering, distress, and opposition, and yet God is with us, guarding, guiding, nourishing, and strengthening until the end.

### <span id="page-649-2"></span>REVELATION 11:3–14

**<sup>3</sup>** "And I will grant authority to my two witnesses, and they will prophesy for 1,260 days, clothed in sackcloth."

**<sup>4</sup>**These are the two olive trees and the two lampstands that stand before the Lord of the earth. **5**And if anyone would harm them, fire pours from their mouth and consumes their foes. If anyone would harm them, this is how he is doomed to be killed. **6**They have the power to shut the sky, that no rain may fall during the days of their prophesying, and they have power over the waters to turn them into blood and to strike the earth with every kind of plague, as often as they desire. **7**And when they have finished their testimony, the beast that rises from the bottomless pit*<sup>1</sup>* will make war on them and conquer them and kill them, **<sup>8</sup>** and their dead bodies will lie in the street of the great city that symbolically*<sup>2</sup>* is called Sodom and Egypt, where their Lord was crucified. **9**For three and a half days some from the peoples and tribes and languages and nations will gaze at their dead bodies and refuse to let them be placed in a tomb, **<sup>10</sup>** and those who dwell on the earth will rejoice over them and make merry and exchange presents, because these two prophets had been a torment to those who

dwell on the earth. **11**But after the three and a half days a breath of life from God entered them, and they stood up on their feet, and great fear fell on those who saw them. **12**Then they heard a loud voice from heaven saying to them, "Come up here!" And they went up to heaven in a cloud, and their enemies watched them. **13**And at that hour there was a great earthquake, and a tenth of the city fell. Seven thousand people were killed in the earthquake, and the rest were terrified and gave glory to the God of heaven.

**<sup>14</sup>**The second woe has passed; behold, the third woe is soon to come.

1Or *the abyss* 2Greek *spiritually*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-650-1"></span>In Revelation 11:1–2 we saw the church protected by God even when persecuted. In 11:3–14 we see what the church is doing in the period between Jesus' resurrection and return, and how the world responds. These verses are among the most difficult in Revelation, and interpreters differ regarding their meaning. In this commentary, space is lacking to delineate the various positions. I will argue that the two witnesses refer to the church, which testifies to the gospel of Jesus Christ in the period between the cross and second coming (v. 3). They are the olive trees (filled by the Spirit) and lampstands (proclaiming God's message to the world; v. 4). They proclaim God's judgment on those rejecting their message (vv. 5–6). The world is infuriated by the gospel they proclaim and puts them to death and celebrates their demise (vv. 7–10). Ultimately, however, believers in Jesus Christ will be vindicated by God (vv. 11–12), and judgment will fall on those who refuse to repent (v. 13). The second woe has concluded, and the third woe is imminent (v. 14), coming in verses 15–19.

#### <span id="page-650-9"></span><span id="page-650-6"></span><span id="page-650-5"></span><span id="page-650-3"></span>*Section Outline*

- <span id="page-650-8"></span><span id="page-650-7"></span>V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19) . . .
	- D. Interlude (10:1–11:14) . . .
		- 3. Two Witnesses Empowered, Killed, and Vindicated (11:3–14)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-650-10"></span><span id="page-650-4"></span><span id="page-650-2"></span><span id="page-650-0"></span>11:3 God has appointed two witnesses clothed in sackcloth to prophesy for 1,260 days. The identity of the two witnesses has been the subject of controversy. The activities described in the subsequent verses make us think of Moses and Elijah. Others think Enoch is one of the two in mind, and there are many other suggestions as well. But it is most probable that the two witnesses refer to the church as a whole, with the number two echoing the OT requirement for two witnesses to validate a claim (Deut. 17:6; 19:15). Several pieces of evidence support this conclusion. (1) The witnesses are persecuted by the beast (Rev. 11:7), as is the church as a whole (13:7). Daniel predicted that the people of God would be attacked by the fourth beast and its horn: "This horn made war with the saints and prevailed <span id="page-651-11"></span><span id="page-651-10"></span><span id="page-651-3"></span>over them" (Dan. 7:21). (2) The entire world sees their suffering and triumph (Rev. 11:9–13), which fits most naturally with a reference to the entire church, a worldwide entity. (3). The 1,260 days refers to the entire period between Christ's resurrection and second advent. The church witnesses to the world what God has done in Jesus Christ, declaring salvation to all who put their trust in him and judgment to those who refuse to repent and believe. The church, as the two witnesses, prophesies for 1,260 days, referring to the proclamation and declaration of God's Word. In Revelation 11:10 the two witnesses are described as "two prophets." Again, the number is symbolic, but the reference to prophecy both here and in verse 10 shows that the church has a particular responsibility to declare God's message of salvation offered in Jesus Christ, while also warning about judgment to those who refuse him. We see in the NT that the church of Jesus Christ is a prophetic community empowered by the Holy Spirit (Joel 2:28–32; Acts 2:17–21). The 1,260 days, as explained in my comment on Revelation 11:2 above, refers to the entire period between the first and second coming of Christ. The church's task as it waits for the return of the Lord is to proclaim the gospel, yet it is clothed in sackcloth while doing so. Sackcloth is worn in mourning (Gen. 37:34; 2 Sam. 3:31) or when judgment arrives (1 Kings 21:27; Neh. 9:1; Isa. 3:24). The church is clothed with sackcloth because it proclaims the need to repent, warning of the judgment to come.

<span id="page-651-8"></span><span id="page-651-7"></span><span id="page-651-6"></span><span id="page-651-4"></span><span id="page-651-0"></span>11:4 The two witnesses, i.e., the church of Jesus Christ, are also described as two olive trees and two lampstands standing before the Lord of the earth. John here picks up on Zechariah 4, where Joshua the priest and Zerubbabel the governor are described as two olive trees (Zech. 4:3, 11, 12). The parallel to Zechariah 4:14 is also evident, for Joshua and Zerubbabel are identified as the "two anointed ones who stand by the Lord of the whole earth." Zerubbabel and Joshua were king and priest, and so by speaking of the two anointed ones and the two olive trees, John refers to the church as a kingdom of priests (Rev. 1:6; 5:10; 20:6). As priests and kings they mediate God's blessing and gracious rule over the world. Kings and priests were anointed by the Spirit (Ex. 28:41; 29:7; 1 Sam. 10:1; 16:12–13), and the anointing here suggests the church, as a kingdom of priests, is anointed and empowered by the Holy Spirit. Significantly, the oil of the olives fills the lampstand so that it can yield its light (Zech. 4:11–12), suggesting the oil is the power of the Spirit enabling the two witnesses to prophesy by speaking forth the Word of the Lord (Zech. 4:6). The church is God's lampstand, shining forth to the world in both word and deed (Matt. 5:16).

<span id="page-651-9"></span><span id="page-651-5"></span><span id="page-651-2"></span><span id="page-651-1"></span>11:5 Those who desire to harm the two witnesses will themselves suffer harm. As explained above, the two witnesses symbolize believers who witness to the gospel of Jesus Christ. If people wish to injure them, fire will come from the mouth of the witnesses to consume their enemies. Certainly, this language is symbolic and apocalyptic, for it is quite unlikely that fire literally comes out of people's mouths! The fire signifies judgment pronounced on those who refuse to heed the message.

<span id="page-652-3"></span><span id="page-652-2"></span>Elijah brought fire from heaven twice to consume the enemies of the Lord (2 Kings 1:10, 12), and in Jeremiah the Lord says, "I am making my words in your mouth a fire, and this people wood, and the fire shall consume them" (Jer. 5:14). In the same way, those who reject the gospel proclaimed by the church will be killed and will face God's blazing judgment.

<span id="page-652-8"></span>11:6 John continues to use symbolic language to describe the judgment poured out on the world by the church of Jesus Christ. The church is able to "shut the sky" so that it does not rain during the time of their proclamation, and it is able to turn water into blood and call down horrendous plagues on enemies. Again, some understand this literally, but just as fire doesn't literally come out of the mouth of the church, so here too the judgments are symbolic. John picks up biblical language of judgment to depict judgment on the ungodly. Prevention of rain, of course, reminds us of Elijah, who prophesied there would be no rain except by his word (1 Kings 17:1). Turning water into blood echoes what Moses did during the exodus (Ex. 7:17–21), and Moses summoned forth many other plagues as well. These plagues and judgments anticipate the judgment to come, a judgment pronounced by the church of Jesus Christ against those who refuse to listen to its message.

<span id="page-652-14"></span><span id="page-652-13"></span><span id="page-652-12"></span><span id="page-652-11"></span><span id="page-652-10"></span><span id="page-652-9"></span><span id="page-652-7"></span><span id="page-652-6"></span><span id="page-652-5"></span><span id="page-652-4"></span><span id="page-652-1"></span><span id="page-652-0"></span>11:7 When the two witnesses—the church—have finished their testimony, the beast from the pit will wage war, conquer, and kill the witnesses. Some interpreters see here a literal martyrdom of the two witnesses. Some have, therefore, seen a reference to Enoch and Elijah, for these two men did not die during their earthly lives, and these interpreters argue that they will die in the future. But it is very unlikely that Enoch and Elijah will return to earth and live their lives again! The apocalyptic genre tilts us instead to a symbolic reading. John teaches that the church will give testimony to Jesus Christ (cf. Rev. 1:2, 9; 19:10; 20:4), but this testimony will be contested and opposed. The beast rising from the abyss will stand against the church and its testimony. This is the first mention of the beast in Revelation, and he will receive particular attention in chapters 13 and 17 (cf. comments). In John's context the beast was the Roman Empire, standing for totalitarian government opposed to God. The beast comes "from the bottomless pit" or "abyss" (cf. also Rev. 17:8). Demons come from the abyss (9:1–2), and Satan is locked in the abyss for a thousand years (20:1, 3). The beast, then, has a demonic origin (12:17–13:1). When the beast, the Roman Empire, comes on the scene, it makes war against the saints (12:17; 19:19) as it demands worship and destroys all competition. When John says the beast conquers the saints (cf. 13:7), he does not mean he overcomes them and causes apostasy (as in 2:7, 11, etc.). He means the beast takes their physical lives from them; he conquers the saints by putting them to death (cf. Dan. 7:21). But the beast does not win an ultimate victory, for in dying the saints actually triumph: they conquer by not "[loving] their lives . . . unto death" (Rev. 12:11). Once again, John is not teaching that all believers will be put to death; the church as a whole is characterized as a suffering church, a martyred church, but we should not read this as saying all believers will suffer actual martyrdom.

<span id="page-653-11"></span><span id="page-653-5"></span><span id="page-653-3"></span><span id="page-653-1"></span>11:8 If one takes the two witnesses to be two individuals, it seems that John says the two witnesses will be killed and their corpses left to lie on the streets of Jerusalem. But it is more probable that the two witnesses refer to the church as a whole, proclaiming salvation and judgment to the world. The language here is apocalyptic and symbolic instead of literal. Hence, the point isn't that the corpses of the two witnesses literally lie on the streets in Jerusalem. Instead, we see that the church of Jesus Christ is scorned, maligned, and dishonored by the world. Not to bury a corpse in the ancient world was a great indignity and shame (cf. Gen. 40:19; 1 Sam. 17:44, 46; 2 Kings 9:10; *Tob.* 2:3–8). The "great city" of the world mistreats and slays believers (cf. Jer. 22:8). John says the city that is treating believers in this way is spiritually called Sodom and Egypt, and thus is symbolic of the city of man, the world opposed to God. The reference to Sodom is not surprising, given its sordid history (cf. Genesis 18–19), and Sodom is often referenced as an example of a city that gave itself over to evil (Deut. 29:23; 32:32; Isa. 1:9–10; 3:9; Jer. 23:14; Lam. 4:6; Amos 4:11; Zeph. 2:9). On the other hand, the reference to Egypt is quite surprising since it is not a city but a country. John signals that the word "city" is not to be taken literally, but denotes the entire world in opposition to God. In other words, John refers to what Augustine called the "city of man" over against the "city of God."

<span id="page-653-8"></span><span id="page-653-7"></span><span id="page-653-6"></span><span id="page-653-2"></span><span id="page-653-0"></span>Finally, the city is identified as the place where Jesus was crucified, which was literally Jerusalem. We think of the places in the OT and NT where Jerusalem or Judah are called Sodom because of their wickedness (Isa. 1:9–10; 3:9; Jer. 23:14; Lam. 4:6; Amos 4:11; Matt. 10:15; 11:23–24; Luke 10:12; Rom. 9:29), or even are said to be worse than Sodom (Ezek. 16:46–56). John isn't indicting Jerusalem per se, nor is he thinking particularly of Rome. Instead, what happened in Jerusalem (the Lord was crucified) takes place all over the world, for the city of man rejects and despises the city of God.

<span id="page-653-12"></span>11:9 For three and a half days the peoples of the world leave the corpses on the streets and refuse to allow them to be buried. Again, the language is apocalyptic and symbolic, so that the three and a half days should not be interpreted literally. Instead, John uses the number to denote a limited period of time, showing that the defaming of the church is limited to this present evil age. The world universally dishonors the witness of the church by denying it a tomb. We see this sentiment reflected in the words of the psalmist: "They have given the bodies of your servants to the birds of the heavens for food, the flesh of your faithful to the beasts of the earth. They have poured out their blood like water all around Jerusalem, and there was no one to bury them" (Ps. 79:2–3; cf. 2 Kings 9:10; Jer. 14:16). We see here that the world scorns and mistreats the church as it witnesses to the salvation available through Jesus Christ.

<span id="page-653-13"></span><span id="page-653-10"></span><span id="page-653-9"></span><span id="page-653-4"></span>11:10 Reference to those who "dwell on the earth" is found twice in this verse and is a technical term in Revelation for unbelievers (cf. comment on Rev. 3:10). Unbelievers will be filled with joy at the killing of Christians and will celebrate with parties and gift exchanges (cf. John 16:20). They will rejoice because the "two prophets," who tormented them in their unbelief, are dead—the church in its prophetic and witness-bearing role condemned the evil engaged in by the world, and the world cannot bear to be criticized in this way.

<span id="page-654-12"></span><span id="page-654-5"></span><span id="page-654-4"></span>11:11 After the three and a half days elapse, the corpses suddenly stand on their feet when the "breath of life," i.e., "the spirit of life" ( *pneuma zōēs*), from God enters them. As a result, unbelievers are filled with fear. The three and one-half days should not be interpreted literally; they refer to what will happen at the end of history. John draws on the vision of the dry bones in Ezekiel 37, where God's breath entered the dry bones and they lived and "stood on their feet" (Ezek. 37:5, 10; cf. also 37:9, 14). Ezekiel wrote of the revivifying and reuniting of Israel and Judah, but he locates its fulfillment at the resurrection. Similarly, John describes here the resurrection of the people of God, those who have witnessed to Jesus Christ. When unbelievers see their vindication, they will be gripped with fear (cf. Ex. 15:16; Ps. 105:38), knowing judgment is at hand.

<span id="page-654-9"></span><span id="page-654-8"></span><span id="page-654-6"></span><span id="page-654-3"></span><span id="page-654-2"></span><span id="page-654-0"></span>11:12 When the witnesses come to life and stand on their feet, God summons them to heaven (cf. Rev. 4:1). They travel to heaven in a cloud, reminiscent of both Jesus' ascension to heaven (Acts 1:9; cf. 1 Thess. 4:17) and Elijah's being taken up into heaven (2 Kings 2:11). Their enemies recognize that the witnesses belong to God and have been vindicated by him. The text is not a narration of what will happen literally but is John's way of saying the church of Jesus Christ will be vindicated publicly by God himself, to the consternation of its enemies. Some think this cannot refer to the resurrection of believers, for then it would not make sense for further events to follow the resurrection. But when we remember that Revelation isn't always strictly chronological, the problem vanishes.

<span id="page-654-14"></span><span id="page-654-10"></span>11:13 The ascension of the two witnesses is accompanied by a great earthquake, in which one-tenth of the city falls and seven thousand are killed. Those who survive are filled with fear and give glory to God. Earthquakes in Revelation regularly signify the final judgment, and that is true here (cf. 6:12; 8:5; 11:19; 16:18). The figures of one-tenth and seven thousand designate judgment on the city of man and destruction of unbelievers. Are those who are spared and give glory to God believers? The reference could be to believers, but a reference to unbelievers is more likely in context. Unbelievers will glorify God at the judgment by acknowledging him to be in the right, and hence many interpreters understand the giving of glory to God to refer to judgment (cf. 1 Sam. 6:5; Isa. 42:12). In Daniel 4 we see Nebuchadnezzar giving glory to God, but he is not saved (Dan. 4:34; cf. Rev. 15:4). As noted in the comment on 11:12, sorting out chronological matters is difficult here, but it seems the judgment of unbelievers does not provoke other unbelievers to turn to God. Instead they are hardened in their unbelief. Nowhere else in Revelation do we find an end-time conversion of many unbelievers.

<span id="page-654-15"></span><span id="page-654-13"></span><span id="page-654-11"></span><span id="page-654-7"></span><span id="page-654-1"></span>11:14 The second woe and sixth trumpet were recorded in 9:13–19. The long interlude has ended and John is ready to convey the message of the third woe and seventh trumpet. The subsequent verses (11:15–19) represent the third woe and teach the final judgment of the wicked, when God's kingdom is established.

#### *Response*

The church of Jesus Christ, by the power of the Spirit, is called upon to witness to the gospel and proclaim the Word of God. It promises salvation to those who repent and believe and proclaims judgment on those who refuse to put their trust in God. At the same time, the church is a suffering church. We are not the church triumphant but the church under the shadow of the cross, despised for our message. The world rejoices when believers are put to death and scorns us as messengers. But we should take heart, for we will be vindicated, while those who fail to believe will be judged. Thus we should be encouraged to continue our faithful witness.

### <span id="page-655-1"></span>REVELATION 11:15–19

**<sup>15</sup>**Then the seventh angel blew his trumpet, and there were loud voices in heaven, saying, "The kingdom of the world has become the kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ, and he shall reign forever and ever." **16**And the twenty-four elders who sit on their thrones before God fell on their faces and worshiped God, **<sup>17</sup>** saying,

"We give thanks to you, Lord God Almighty, who is and who was, for you have taken your great power and begun to reign. **<sup>18</sup>** The nations raged, but your wrath came, and the time for the dead to be judged, and for rewarding your servants, the prophets and saints, and those who fear your name, both small and great, and for destroying the destroyers of the earth."

**<sup>19</sup>**Then God's temple in heaven was opened, and the ark of his covenant was seen within his temple. There were flashes of lightning, rumblings,*<sup>1</sup>* peals of thunder, an earthquake, and heavy hail.

<span id="page-655-2"></span>1Or *voices*, or *sounds*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-655-0"></span>With the sounding of the seventh trumpet, history comes to an end. The kingdom now belongs to the Lord and his Christ forever (Rev. 11:15). Heaven pulsates with joy as the elders fall on their faces and worship (v. 16), giving thanks because the <span id="page-656-15"></span><span id="page-656-14"></span>everlasting God has begun his reign (v. 17). The reign of the Christ means the wicked are judged and the righteous rewarded (v. 18); the judgment of the wicked explains why this is the third woe. God's temple in heaven is opened and the ark of his covenant is seen, representing full and final access to God (v. 19), but there is also a thunderous storm of judgment for those who have refused his rule.

#### <span id="page-656-16"></span>*Section Outline*

- V. The Seven Trumpets (8:6–11:19) . . .
	- E. The Seventh Trumpet: Kingdom Come! (11:15–19)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-656-12"></span><span id="page-656-11"></span><span id="page-656-4"></span><span id="page-656-3"></span><span id="page-656-1"></span>11:15 The blasting of the final trumpet also represents the third and final woe (8:13; 9:12; 11:14), signifying that the final judgment is at hand and history has reached its conclusion. It is the third and final woe for the wicked — the last judgment has arrived. Loud voices in heaven declare the time of fulfilled promises has arrived. The kingdom is now the Lord's (Obad. 21; cf. Ps. 22:29), and "the kingdom of the world" has been transferred to "the kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ," and he will reign forever (cf. Dan. 2:44; 7:14, 27; Luke 1:33). Christ already reigns at the Father's right hand (Acts 2:33, 36), but at the seventh trumpet his enemies are vanquished and are made his footstool (1 Cor. 15:24–25). We see here the recursive structure of the book of Revelation, for just as in 6:12–17 and 7:15–17, we have come to the end of history, yet John continues the narrative in subsequent chapters, circling back and looking at the same themes from a fresh perspective.

<span id="page-656-13"></span><span id="page-656-10"></span><span id="page-656-8"></span><span id="page-656-6"></span><span id="page-656-5"></span>11:16 Upon hearing that Christ has begun his reign, the twenty-four elders sitting on thrones before God are filled with joy and fall on their faces to worship God (cf. 4:4, 10; 5:8; 7:11; 19:4). The reign of Christ does not diminish God's glory but enhances it (cf. Phil. 2:9–11), for the one true God is worshiped as Christ's kingdom is realized.

<span id="page-656-17"></span><span id="page-656-9"></span><span id="page-656-7"></span><span id="page-656-2"></span><span id="page-656-0"></span>11:17 Here we see the content of the praise voiced by the twenty-four elders. They give thanks to Almighty God, the one "who is and who was," because he has taken the power he has always had and has begun his reign (cf. 19:6). Revelation regularly identifies God as "Almighty" (cf. comment on 1:8) and appeals to Exodus 3:14 (cf. comment on Rev. 1:4) in identifying God as the one "who is and who was." Here John omits the reference to God as the coming one, which we find elsewhere (1:4, 8; 4:8), for here in 11:17 his coming is no longer future. He has come! And his reign has begun. He *is* the God of the universe, he always *was* the God of the universe, and *now* he reigns forevermore (cf. Pss. 47:8; 93:1; 96:10; 97:1; 99:1). We see that the reign of Christ also means the reign of God. God and Christ are not in competition, but reign in concert. We see again the Trinitarian doctrine of coinherence; what is true of the Father as God is also true of the Son as God.

<span id="page-657-14"></span><span id="page-657-12"></span><span id="page-657-10"></span><span id="page-657-5"></span><span id="page-657-4"></span><span id="page-657-1"></span>11:18 The coming of the kingdom means accounts are settled—the wicked are punished and the righteous rewarded. The nations are enraged against God (Ps. 2:1), hating his rule and authority over them (LXX Ex. 15:14; Ps. 98:1), and as a consequence they will face his wrath on the day of judgment (cf. Rev. 6:16–17; 14:10, 19; 15:1, 7; Ps. 110:5; Jer. 30:23). The dead will be assessed and judged for their behavior (cf. Rev. 20:12). Two different assessments are made. First, God's servants are given a reward for their faith and endurance. This reward is granted to prophets, saints, and those who fear God's name. It is difficult to know how many groups are in view here, but there are probably two. Often in the OT the prophets are identified as God's servants, and thus they are probably one of the groups here (e.g., 2 Kings 9:7; 21:10; Ezra 9:11; Jer. 7:25; 25:4; Ezek. 38:17; Dan. 9:6, 10; Amos 3:7; Zech. 1:6). The saints are described as those who fear God's name, and the words "small" and "great" probably further describe the saints, who fear God's name. God is impartial and grants the same reward whether one is deemed important or unimportant in society (cf. Rom. 2:6–11; cf. also Ps. 115:13; Rev. 19:5). On the other hand, the wicked will be judged: those who destroyed the earth will themselves be destroyed (cf. Jer. 51:25; Rev. 19:2). When the kingdom comes, everything will be set right; the righteous will be vindicated and the wicked will receive what they deserve.

<span id="page-657-15"></span><span id="page-657-13"></span><span id="page-657-11"></span><span id="page-657-9"></span><span id="page-657-8"></span><span id="page-657-7"></span><span id="page-657-6"></span><span id="page-657-3"></span><span id="page-657-2"></span>11:19 When the kingdom comes, there will be full and free access to God for the saints and terrifying punishment for the wicked. God's temple is opened in heaven and the ark of the covenant is visible in the temple. There is no temple in the new creation (21:22), and thus John does not refer to a literal temple or ark. In the OT the temple was not open to all; only the high priest could enter the Most Holy Place, one day a year (cf. Lev. 16:1–34; Heb. 9:7–8). But now that the kingdom has come, God's temple (his presence) is open to all the saints. Access to God is unhindered and joyful (cf. Heb. 10:19–22). The reference to the ark of the covenant makes the same point (cf. Rev. 7:15; 15:5). Jeremiah prophesies that the ark won't be missed in the last days (Jer. 3:16), presumably because fellowship with God will surpass what Israel enjoyed during the days of the ark. In Second Temple Judaism, we find a tradition of Jeremiah hiding the ark in a cave, saying it would be revealed when God shows his mercy to Israel and the cloud of his presence returns (*2 Macc.* 2:4–8). As just noted, the ark was seen only on the Day of Atonement and only by the high priest (Lev. 16:1–34), and even then it was covered with a cloud of incense. John in Revelation, of course, isn't referring to the literal ark at all. Saying that the ark of God's covenant is seen in the temple means God's gracious presence is available to all—the warmth and radiance of his love is manifested personally to all his saints.

<span id="page-657-0"></span>On the other hand, entering into God's presence is never an informal affair, for he is infinitely holy, and thus there is a terrifying thunderstorm accompanied by great hail (cf. Rev. 4:5; 16:21; cf. also Ex. 9:24; Isa. 29:6; 66:6). Those who are wicked do not experience God's gracious presence. Instead, God rains hailstones on them as they experience the thunder and lightning of his eschatological wrath.

#### *Response*

History won't last forever; evil won't triumph. Good will triumph, and God and Christ will reign forever. They will take the reins of history into their hands and dispense justice to every person, rewarding the righteous and punishing the wicked. Things are askew now, and evil often profits the wicked. Believers are tempted to despair and discouragement, but we should be full of optimism and hope, for the triumph of evil is short-lived. The end is coming! The perfect world we long for, the world where Christ reigns, will become a reality.

### <span id="page-658-4"></span>REVELATION 12:1–6

12 And a great sign appeared in heaven: a woman clothed with the sun, with the moon under her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve stars. **<sup>2</sup>** She was pregnant and was crying out in birth pains and the agony of giving birth. **3**And another sign appeared in heaven: behold, a great red dragon, with seven heads and ten horns, and on his heads seven diadems. **4**His tail swept down a third of the stars of heaven and cast them to the earth. And the dragon stood before the woman who was about to give birth, so that when she bore her child he might devour it. **<sup>5</sup>** She gave birth to a male child, one who is to rule*<sup>1</sup>* all the nations with a rod of iron, but her child was caught up to God and to his throne, **<sup>6</sup>** and the woman fled into the wilderness, where she has a place prepared by God, in which she is to be nourished for 1,260 days.

<span id="page-658-8"></span><span id="page-658-7"></span><span id="page-658-6"></span>1Greek *shepherd*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-658-10"></span><span id="page-658-9"></span><span id="page-658-5"></span><span id="page-658-3"></span><span id="page-658-2"></span><span id="page-658-1"></span><span id="page-658-0"></span>John was told to prophesy more (Rev. 10:11), and chapters 12–14 fulfill that commission. All of history concludes with the seventh trumpet and the third woe, but John steps back so that readers can survey history from another perspective. The perspective is cosmic, encompassing the battle with the Devil (12:1–17), the emergence of the two beasts (13:1–18), and visions of heaven and earth (14:1–20). The focus in chapter 12 is on the conflict with the Devil, a conflict going back to Genesis 3. John opens up a transcendent and heavenly view for his readers. The first sign is a woman who rules the world, representing the people of God (Rev. 12:1). This woman is in agony as she is about to give birth (v. 2). But another sign appears in heaven, a red dragon who opposes the woman (v. 3). The dragon is intent upon devouring the child the woman is about to bring into the world (v. 4). The child is the one intended to rule the world as the son of David, rescued from the dragon by being exalted to God's throne (v. 5)—referring to Jesus' resurrection

<span id="page-659-11"></span>and ascension. The woman flees to the wilderness for protection and is nourished by God for 1,260 days (v. 6).

#### *Section Outline*

- VI. Signs in Heaven and on Earth (12:1–14:20)
	- A. The Woman, the Child, and the Dragon (12:1–6)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-659-8"></span>12:1 The passage has a mythological quality; this doesn't mean it is false but that it draws on mythology to make a point. Myths of gods and goddesses battling with serpents or a dragon are found in Egypt, Ugarit, Mesopotamia, the Greco-Roman world, etc. John is not reproducing these myths, but they were in the air, and John adapts what was common in the culture for his own purposes and sets it into the storyline of biblical (OT) revelation. Such an observation does not stand in opposition to the visionary nature of John's experience; the literary and the visionary come together in the book. As signs of the heavens fascinated ancient people, so a great sign appears in heaven in John's vision. The sign is a woman, beautiful and exalted, clothed with the radiance of the sun. The moon is under her feet, and on her head is a crown of twelve stars (cf. Gen. 37:9). We see in this the rule of the woman, exercising her influence in the world. The identity of this woman is contested. At first glance a reference to Mary might seem fitting, since she gives birth to Christ (Rev. 12:2, 5) and flees into the wilderness of Egypt. However, it seems better to consider this a symbolic reference to the people of God. The notion of God's people as his bride is amply attested elsewhere in Scripture (e.g., Isa. 54:5; Jer. 3:8–9; Ezekiel 16; 23; Hos. 2:16, 19–20; Rev. 19:7–9; 21:2, 9). God has made his people rulers (Rev. 1:6; 5:10; 20:6; cf. Isa. 62:3) to mediate his priestly blessing to the world.

<span id="page-659-9"></span><span id="page-659-6"></span><span id="page-659-5"></span><span id="page-659-4"></span><span id="page-659-3"></span><span id="page-659-1"></span><span id="page-659-0"></span>12:2 The woman is pregnant and suffers birth pangs. Here we have further evidence the woman is the people of God, for in the OT Israel suffers labor pains of messianic woe before salvation is accomplished (Isa. 26:17–18; 66:7–10; Mic. 4:10). Here the birth pangs bring forth a child, the son of David, the Messiah, the one who will bring in the salvation promised in the OT (Gen. 3:15; 2 Sam. 7:14; Ps. 89:26–27; Isa. 7:14; 9:6–7; Mic. 5:2–4; cf. also Luke 1:32–33; Heb. 1:5). The rule promised to Israel, the kingdom to be theirs through the covenant with Abraham and David, would be realized through a descendant of David.

<span id="page-659-13"></span><span id="page-659-12"></span><span id="page-659-10"></span><span id="page-659-7"></span><span id="page-659-2"></span>12:3 Heaven isn't free from conflict, for another sign appears in the heavens a mythological monster, a fiery red dragon with seven heads and ten horns, with seven diadems on his head. This parodies Jesus Christ, who also is portrayed in Revelation as having horns and diadems (5:6; 19:12). The seven diadems on the dragon stand for his ruling authority, and the ten horns signify his strength (cf. 13:2). In Daniel the ten horns are ten kings belonging to the fourth beast (Dan. 7:7, 24; cf. Rev. 17:12–14). The link between the numbers of the dragon and the number of human rulers suggests the dragon manifests himself in and <span id="page-660-15"></span><span id="page-660-12"></span>through human rulers and authorities. His rule is not limited to one kingdom or time period; he continues to exert influence in age after age. Here we see that the opponent of the people of God is a terrifying monster (Rev. 12:4, 7, 9, 13, 16, 17; 13:2, 4, 11; 16:13; 20:2). The image goes back to the OT, where Isaiah prophesies that Yahweh "will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent, Leviathan the twisting serpent, and he will slay the dragon that is in the sea" (Isa. 27:1; cf. Isa. 51:9; Ezek. 29:3; 32:2).

<span id="page-660-8"></span><span id="page-660-7"></span><span id="page-660-6"></span><span id="page-660-2"></span>12:4 The power and destructiveness of the dragon is evident, for with his tail he sweeps a third of the stars of heaven to the earth. This could possibly refer to angels (cf. Job 38:7), and some see here the moment in history where some of the angels followed Satan and became his angels (Matt. 25:41). In Daniel 8:10, however, the stars Antiochus IV Epiphanes throws to the ground and tramples are Israelites. This probably refers to the persecution of Israel by Antiochus; in alluding to this text, John likely makes the same point. The dragon's hostility toward the people of God leads him to oppress them. Such a reading ties the two parts of the verse together: just as the dragon persecuted the people of God, so now is he ready to pounce on the woman as she is about to give birth—the dragon seeks to devour and destroy the Christ. We see such a demonic intent, for instance, in Matthew, where Herod attempts to slay Jesus in his infancy (Matt. 2:1–18).

<span id="page-660-13"></span><span id="page-660-10"></span><span id="page-660-5"></span><span id="page-660-4"></span><span id="page-660-3"></span><span id="page-660-1"></span><span id="page-660-0"></span>12:5 The woman gives birth to a son (cf. Isa. 66:7), the son of David (2 Sam. 7:14), the one who was appointed, according to Psalm 2, to rule the nations with a rod of iron (Ps. 2:9; cf. also Rev. 2:27). Psalm 2 is a messianic psalm, in which the Davidic king is appointed as God's son (Ps. 2:6–7). The nations and the ends of the earth are his inheritance. In other words, the blessing promised to Abraham for the nations will become a reality through the Davidic king (Gen. 12:3). The dragon fiercely desired to slay this son, knowing this child spelled his demise. Remarkably, John skips Jesus' ministry and death! Instead, he moves the story to Jesus' exaltation, when he was snatched up to God and his throne. John transports us to the end of the story, showing his audience Jesus' triumph over the dragon. The audience is not in the dark about Jesus' life and ministry; they know he died, but here they are reminded that he conquered the dragon when he rose from the dead and ascended to take his seat at God's right hand.

<span id="page-660-14"></span><span id="page-660-11"></span><span id="page-660-9"></span>12:6 The woman, representing the people of God (though now in the story the focus is on the church of Jesus Christ after the birth and exaltation of the Messiah) flees to the wilderness, running from the persecution of Satan. The wilderness represents life in the present evil age. Just as God nurtured and preserved Israel during the forty years it wandered in the wilderness (cf. Hos. 2:14), so he provides for the church for 1,260 days, i.e., the time between Jesus' resurrection and return (cf. comments on Rev. 11:1–2). Even though the dragon wages war against the church and puts some believers to death, God is watching over and protecting his own from apostasy, giving them spiritual strength to endure the onslaughts of Satan.

It is easy to forget that we live in a time of war. The Devil has a passionate desire to destroy the people of God, and he especially tried to do away with Jesus the Messiah. But he did not and could not succeed, for Jesus now reigns at God's right hand. Since we serve a risen and victorious Christ, we have nothing to fear. We will be more than conquerors, despite our suffering, because of him who loves us.
