#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-687-2"></span><span id="page-687-0"></span>The judgments prepared for and threatened in chapter 15 become a reality in chapter 16. The chapter is structured by the seven bowl judgments. The angel is instructed to pour out the bowl judgments of God's wrath (v. 1). Table 9.9 best represents the judgments in chapter 16.

<span id="page-687-6"></span><span id="page-687-5"></span><span id="page-687-4"></span><span id="page-687-3"></span>

| Bowl   | Realm           | Verses | Judgment                                |
|--------|-----------------|--------|-----------------------------------------|
| Bowl 1 | Earth           | 2      | Sores on those who worship the beast    |
| Bowl 2 | Sea             | 3      | Seas turn to blood and death in the sea |
| Bowl 3 | Rivers/springs  | 4–7    | Rivers and springs turn to blood        |
| Bowl 4 | Sun             | 8–9    | People scorched                         |
| Bowl 5 | Throne of beast | 10–11  | Plunged into darkness                   |
| Bowl 6 | River Euphrates | 12–16  | Battle of Armageddon                    |
| Bowl 7 | Air             | 17–21  | Kingdom come                            |

<span id="page-687-1"></span>TABLE 9.9: The Judgments in Revelation 16

<span id="page-687-9"></span><span id="page-687-8"></span><span id="page-687-7"></span>The first four bowls strike the natural world, while the last three strike the kingdom of the beast. The bowl judgments differ from the seals and trumpets in that their destruction is universal, suggesting that the bowls are poured out at the end of history. Other interpreters, given the symbolic and apocalyptic character of the judgments, argue that the bowl judgments characterize the entire period from Christ's resurrection to the end of history. Such an interpretation is certainly possible, but the radical and comprehensive nature of the language suggests instead that John describes judgments that take place as history draws to a close.

<span id="page-688-14"></span><span id="page-688-13"></span>It is instructive to notice the comments and exhortations inserted in the bowl judgments. For instance, John inserts in the third bowl judgment the note that those judged deserve to be punished (vv. 5–7). In the fourth and fifth judgment, he remarks that people did not repent even though they saw God's judgments (vv. 9, 11). In the sixth bowl is a parenthetical exhortation for believers to stay alert and be clothed with righteousness, since Jesus is coming (v. 15).

#### <span id="page-688-16"></span><span id="page-688-15"></span>*Section Outline*

- VII. The Seven Bowls from the Sanctuary (15:1–16:21) . . .
	- B. The Seven Bowls (16:1–21)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-688-9"></span><span id="page-688-8"></span><span id="page-688-4"></span><span id="page-688-3"></span>16:1–2 A voice from the temple instructs the seven angels to pour the seven bowls containing God's judgment on the earth to complete his wrath (cf. Rev. 15:1; cf. also Jer. 10:25; Ezek. 14:19; Zeph. 3:8). In Isaiah, the Lord likewise punishes his enemies from the temple: "The sound of an uproar from the city! A sound from the temple! The sound of the Lord, rendering recompense to his enemies!" (Isa. 66:6). The first angel pours his bowl on the land, inflicting its inhabitants—i.e., those who accepted the mark of the beast and worshiped its image—with painful sores (Rev. 13:15, 16). We are reminded of the sixth plague on Egypt, in which boils broke out on the Egyptians while the Israelites were spared (Ex. 9:8–12; cf. Deut. 28:27, 35). Given the apocalyptic character of Revelation, it is unlikely John is depicting a literal outbreak of boils. Nevertheless, those who turn away from the true and living God will experience agony because they have refused the one who offers life.

<span id="page-688-10"></span><span id="page-688-7"></span><span id="page-688-5"></span><span id="page-688-2"></span><span id="page-688-1"></span>16:3 The second bowl, like the second trumpet, afflicts the sea. In the second trumpet judgment, one-third of the sea became blood and one-third of its creatures died (Rev. 8:8–9). But in the second bowl judgment, the entirety of the sea becomes like the blood of a corpse, and every single creature in the sea dies. The severity and intensity of the judgment suggest this event comes near the final judgment, when the entire world is collapsing. Everything sustaining the world begins to fall apart.

<span id="page-688-11"></span><span id="page-688-6"></span><span id="page-688-0"></span>16:4 The third bowl affects the same realm as the third trumpet. In the third trumpet, a third of the rivers and springs were embittered, leading to the death of many (8:10–11). In the third bowl judgment, all rivers and springs become blood, echoing the first plague on Egypt (Ex. 7:17–20). Once again, the severity and intensification of the judgment points to the time of the end. Water is the source of life, and thus God is eradicating in judgment what is vital for life.

<span id="page-688-12"></span>16:5 The next three verses interrupt the sequence of the bowl judgments and comment on the suitability of the judgments. The angel superintending the waters <span id="page-689-7"></span><span id="page-689-2"></span>(showing the close connection between angels and the world of nature; cf. Heb. 1:7) declares God is righteous and holy in judging the wicked. John's audience might question the severity of the judgments, but the angel assures us the recompense is fitting and right. The Lord is identified here as the one "who is and who was," paralleling 11:17, another final judgment text. In other similar texts, God is designated as the one who is, who was, and who is to come (Rev. 1:4, 8; 4:8). The omission of "who is to come" suggests the bowl judgments are part of a complex of events culminating in the final judgment. In other words, God is coming and bringing his kingdom in these very judgments.

<span id="page-689-10"></span><span id="page-689-4"></span><span id="page-689-3"></span>16:6 The rightness of God's judgments is now explained. God has turned the rivers and springs to blood because the wicked have spilled the blood of the saints and prophets (cf. 2:13; 6:9; 17:6; 18:24; 20:4). The punishment fits and accords with the crime (cf. Isa. 49:26; Rev. 11:18), and thus this is an expression, not a miscarriage, of justice. Those who have inflicted suffering on believers will themselves suffer.

<span id="page-689-11"></span><span id="page-689-9"></span><span id="page-689-6"></span><span id="page-689-1"></span>16:7 The altar now speaks (cf. 9:13), perhaps representing the voice of an angel. The altar speaks to add its witness on behalf of the saints slain under the altar (6:9), affirming that the judgments of the Lord God Almighty are true and righteous (cf. 15:3; 19:2). John is sensitive to those questioning the judgments and emphasizes that they verify God's justice. The Holy One of Israel always does what is right. Even though life often seems futile and meaningless and irrational, in the end God will make everything right.

<span id="page-689-12"></span><span id="page-689-5"></span>16:8–9 A third of the sun, moon, and stars were stricken in the fourth trumpet (8:12), but here the judgment of the fourth bowl appears to make the sun more intense, for by it people are scorched, experiencing something like a very painful sunburn. This punishment is not literal but reflects the intense punishment experienced by those who reject the Lord. Those affected are certainly unbelievers, responding with fury to the God who exercises his sovereign authority to bring these plagues upon them. They are convinced they do not deserve these punishments and thus blaspheme and revile God for punishing them, complaining the judgments are unfair and calling into question his character. John has just emphasized the justice of the punishments, and thus their response is irrational and false. God's judgments and plagues should have provoked them to repent and give glory to him, acknowledging their guilt for what they have done. Instead, they are angry at what God is doing, ironically confirming the justice of their judgment.

<span id="page-689-13"></span><span id="page-689-8"></span><span id="page-689-0"></span>16:10–11 The fifth bowl is poured on the beast's throne, his realm (cf. 13:2). His kingdom is darkened, echoing the ninth plague to strike Egypt (Ex. 10:21). The symbolic and apocalyptic language makes the exact nature of this judgment difficult to determine. We would not expect, for instance, people plunged into darkness to "[gnaw] their tongues in anguish." Whether physical, psychological, or both, this judgment clearly brings torment and anguish. It is fascinating to compare the fifth bowl and fifth trumpet, as we have done with the first four. The fifth trumpet <span id="page-690-12"></span><span id="page-690-11"></span><span id="page-690-10"></span>unleashed darkness on the earth (Rev. 9:2) and a demonic presence bringing agony to men (9:1–12). It seems the fifth bowl further intensifies the pain, suggesting John is describing events near the end of history, near the time when God will wrap everything up. The judgments of God, as both the fourth and fifth bowls reveal, are meant to be a precursor and anticipation of what is to come. They are intended to snap people out of their spiritual lethargy and turn them to God in repentance (2:21). Instead, those suffering from their pains and sores (cf. 16:2) are enraged at God, thinking that what has happened to them is completely unwarranted. As the proverb says, "When a man's folly brings his way to ruin, his heart rages against the Lord" (Prov. 19:3). Hence, they curse and blaspheme God instead of blessing him, and they do not repent of their evil deeds. The irrational response of human beings underscores the rightness of God's actions.

<span id="page-690-15"></span><span id="page-690-13"></span><span id="page-690-6"></span><span id="page-690-5"></span><span id="page-690-4"></span>16:12 The sixth bowl is poured out on the Euphrates River, drying up its waters so that kings can come from the east. Once again, an illuminating comparison can be made with the sixth trumpet (9:13–19), in which four angels bound at the Euphrates were released and an army of 200 million came forth to kill a third of mankind. In the sixth bowl's drying up (cf. Jer. 50:38; 51:36) the Euphrates to open a pathway for eastern kings (cf. Isa. 41:2, 25; 46:11), we see a kind of unholy exodus (cf. Ps. 106:9) in which evil kings are enabled to cross the river. Perhaps John was thinking of the Parthians, inveterate enemies of Rome, but the fulfillment is not limited to a specific historical moment, particularly since the Parthians did not succeed in bringing Rome down. Instead this bowl presages, in symbolic terms, the impending judgment on the wicked.

<span id="page-690-19"></span><span id="page-690-18"></span><span id="page-690-16"></span><span id="page-690-14"></span><span id="page-690-3"></span>16:13 John then sees the unholy trinity: the dragon (12:3, 9), the beast (13:1), and the second beast, who for the first time is also called the false prophet (19:20; 20:10). Something horrific and repulsive is spewed from their mouths. John repeats the word "mouth" three times, calling attention to the words of these unholy sources. Such a reading fits with the second beast's being called the false prophet, for he speaks words not from God. What comes from their mouths is as unclean and disgusting as "frogs," showing that their words defile and destroy (cf. Ex. 8:1–13). The word "unclean" also shows the demonic character of what issues from their mouths, as "unclean" spirits are demonic (Mark 1:23; 3:11; Luke 4:33; Acts 5:16).

<span id="page-690-17"></span><span id="page-690-9"></span><span id="page-690-8"></span><span id="page-690-7"></span><span id="page-690-2"></span><span id="page-690-1"></span><span id="page-690-0"></span>16:14 Now we are told explicitly that the unclean spirits are demonic, with the ability to perform signs to deceive the kings of the world (2 Thess. 2:9; 1 Tim. 4:1). We saw earlier the role of the false prophet in doing signs to deceive people (Rev. 13:13–14). Now we see a scene similar to 1 Kings 22, in which Ahab was enticed by a lying spirit to go to battle, where he met his death (1 Kings 22:20–23, 34–35). Here the rulers of the entire world gather for war on the great day of God Almighty (Rev. 17:14; 19:19), but they are deceived into assembling together for a war ( *polemos*) that will bring their own demise. The last battle is the "day of the Lord"

<span id="page-691-23"></span><span id="page-691-15"></span><span id="page-691-8"></span><span id="page-691-4"></span>that the prophets spoke of so often (e.g., Isa. 13:6, 9; Jer. 46:10; Ezek. 30:3; Joel 1:15; 2:1, 11, 31; Amos 5:18, 20; Obad. 15; Zeph. 1:7, 14; Mal. 4:5). What we read here matches what John says later, that the Devil "[deceives] the nations that are at the four corners of the earth, Gog and Magog, to gather them for battle ( *polemos*); their number is like the sand of the sea" (Rev. 20:8), although it is debated whether the battle of 16:14 is the same as that of 20:8. Clearly, those going to war are deceived, for they are about to enter into a battle with Almighty God (cf. Zech. 14:2)! It is a bit like a tiny impoverished nation going to war with the United States. Demons must be behind a battle that is fundamentally futile and ultimately insane.

<span id="page-691-16"></span><span id="page-691-13"></span><span id="page-691-12"></span><span id="page-691-10"></span><span id="page-691-9"></span>16:15 The narrative is interrupted by an exhortation from Jesus. He announces he is coming like a thief, a phrase echoing the rest of the NT (Matt. 24:42–43; cf. 1 Thess. 5:2; 2 Pet. 3:10). Just as thieves do not announce when they will strike, so the time of Jesus' return will be a surprise. Jesus then announces one of the seven blessings in the book (cf. Rev. 1:3), declaring a blessing for those who stay awake and keep their garments on. The blessing is reserved for those who stay morally alert and live righteously. These words are rooted in the Gospel tradition (cf. Matt. 24:43; Luke 12:37) and are a staple of NT exhortation (cf. 1 Thess. 5:1–11). Those who are naked (cf. Rev. 3:18; Ezek. 16:37, 39) and give themselves over to evil and idolatry will experience eschatological shame, being destined for judgment rather than salvation. Promise of coming judgment is not merely a word for unbelievers; it is an urgent reminder to the church of Jesus that they must not join forces with the wicked. If they do so, they will face the same fate.

<span id="page-691-22"></span><span id="page-691-21"></span><span id="page-691-20"></span><span id="page-691-17"></span><span id="page-691-11"></span><span id="page-691-6"></span>16:16 John resumes the thought of verse 14 after the exhortation of verse 15. The nations deceived by the dragon, beast, and false prophet assemble for a final war against the Lord's Christ. It seems this is the same battle as that of 19:11–21 (cf. esp. 19:19), where the beast, kings, and their armies gather to make war against the Lamb. From an amillennial perspective, the battle in 20:7–9 is another description of the same incident. The reference to Armageddon, meaning Mount Megiddo in Hebrew, is quite curious, for it is obvious that Megiddo is not a mountain but a plain (2 Chron. 35:22; Zech. 12:11). Anyone familiar with the land of Israel would know this, and thus John must be making a symbolic point. John provides a clue that he writes symbolically by calling a well-known plain a mountain! Many important battles took place in Megiddo in which Israel was attacked by its foes (Judg. 5:19; 2 Kings 23:29), and here we have a scene of the last battle presented in figurative terms.

<span id="page-691-18"></span><span id="page-691-14"></span><span id="page-691-5"></span><span id="page-691-3"></span><span id="page-691-2"></span><span id="page-691-1"></span>16:17 The seventh bowl, like the sixth seal (6:12–17) and seventh trumpet (11:15– 19), signifies the end of history. When the seventh angel pours his bowl into the air, a voice from the temple (cf. Isa. 66:6), God's throne, declares that everything is accomplished (cf. Rev. 21:6). The end has arrived.

<span id="page-691-24"></span><span id="page-691-19"></span><span id="page-691-7"></span><span id="page-691-0"></span>16:18 As we hear that the end has come, a massive thunderstorm breaks out (cf. Ex. 9:24). At the same time, an earthquake unparalleled in its magnitude takes place (cf. Dan. 12:1; Joel 2:2; Matt. 24:21). We have seen in Revelation that thunder, <span id="page-692-12"></span><span id="page-692-5"></span>lightning, and earthquake symbolize the arrival of the end (6:12; 8:5; 11:13, 19; 19:6). They also symbolize God's awesome holiness and the terror of entering his presence, especially for those not forgiven of their sins (cf. the thunderstorm in God's throne room; 4:5 and comment).

<span id="page-692-9"></span><span id="page-692-4"></span><span id="page-692-2"></span><span id="page-692-1"></span>16:19 The "great city" stands for the "city of man," symbolically identified as Babylon—the great enemy of the people of God (cf. Isa. 13:1–14:23; 21:9; 47:1–15; 48:20; Jer. 50:1–51:64; Dan. 4:30). The city's split into three signifies its disintegration and fragmentation; it has lost its supremacy, and the end is at hand. The plural "cities" should not be distinguished from the singular "city." John's point is that the cities of man are all Babylon; they have strayed from the ways of God. God has now remembered his promises, for the judgment of Babylon is about to commence (Rev. 14:8)—a theme to be elaborated in 17:1–19:5. God exhibits his justice by making Babylon drink the cup of his wrath (cf. 14:10; 18:6; cf. also Jer. 25:15–17), and at the same time he saves his people from the city of man that is oppressing them.

<span id="page-692-10"></span><span id="page-692-8"></span><span id="page-692-7"></span><span id="page-692-6"></span><span id="page-692-3"></span>16:20 The world as we know it vanishes, for the islands are gone and the mountains disappear. John regularly signals that the end has come by portraying displacement in the natural order. We see this clearly in a number of key texts in Revelation. For instance, in 6:14 (the sixth seal judgment), "Every mountain and island was removed from its place." When God judges on the "great white throne," "from his presence earth and heaven fled away, and no place was found for them" (Rev. 20:11). When the new creation dawns, "the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and the sea was no more" (21:1). The disintegration of the natural world means the end is at hand.

<span id="page-692-14"></span><span id="page-692-13"></span><span id="page-692-11"></span><span id="page-692-0"></span>16:21 The final judgment has already been described in terms of a thunderstorm and an earthquake, and now John adds the trope of a hailstorm, one of the plagues that devastated Egypt (Ex. 9:13–26). As usual, the language is apocalyptic; the world is imploding as hailstones of about a hundred pounds each are wreaking havoc on humanity. As strange as it might seem, even in judgment there is one more chance for mercy. But instead of repenting and turning to God, people curse and revile him in their great suffering, continuing to be convinced they do not deserve the suffering they face. Instead of acknowledging their sin, they continue to be infuriated with God, verifying again the rightness of the punishment they receive.

#### *Response*

This chapter features terrible judgments of God unleashing his wrath on the world. Contemporary readers may question if such judgments are warranted, concluding that the punishments exceed the crime and thus rejecting the God of the Bible. But John was sensitive to this objection, emphasizing the righteousness of the judgments. People are judged according to what they deserve. Indeed, when they see the judgments of God, they should be reminded of their sin and repent. Instead, the

<span id="page-693-0"></span>punished are enraged at God and curse him. Experiencing the judgments of God should soften hearts, but many become stubborn and, instead of indicting themselves, they indict God, demonstrating even more that the judgments are warranted.

### REVELATION 17:1–18

17 Then one of the seven angels who had the seven bowls came and said to me, "Come, I will show you the judgment of the great prostitute who is seated on many waters, **2**with whom the kings of the earth have committed sexual immorality, and with the wine of whose sexual immorality the dwellers on earth have become drunk." **3**And he carried me away in the Spirit into a wilderness, and I saw a woman sitting on a scarlet beast that was full of blasphemous names, and it had seven heads and ten horns. **<sup>4</sup>**The woman was arrayed in purple and scarlet, and adorned with gold and jewels and pearls, holding in her hand a golden cup full of abominations and the impurities of her sexual immorality. **5**And on her forehead was written a name of mystery: "Babylon the great, mother of prostitutes and of earth's abominations." **6**And I saw the woman, drunk with the blood of the saints, the blood of the martyrs of Jesus.*<sup>1</sup>*

When I saw her, I marveled greatly. **7**But the angel said to me, "Why do you marvel? I will tell you the mystery of the woman, and of the beast with seven heads and ten horns that carries her. **8**The beast that you saw was, and is not, and is about to rise from the bottomless pit*<sup>2</sup>* and go to destruction. And the dwellers on earth whose names have not been written in the book of life from the foundation of the world will marvel to see the beast, because it was and is not and is to come. **9**This calls for a mind with wisdom: the seven heads are seven mountains on which the woman is seated; **<sup>10</sup>** they are also seven kings, five of whom have fallen, one is, the other has not yet come, and when he does come he must remain only a little while. **11**As for the beast that was and is not, it is an eighth but it belongs to the seven, and it goes to destruction. **12**And the ten horns that you saw are ten kings who have not yet received royal power, but they are to receive authority as kings for one hour, together with the beast. **13**These are of one mind, and they hand over their power and authority to the beast. **14**They will make war on the Lamb, and the Lamb will conquer them, for he is Lord of lords and King of kings, and those with him are called and chosen and faithful."

**<sup>15</sup>**And the angel*<sup>3</sup>* said to me, "The waters that you saw, where the prostitute is seated, are peoples and multitudes and nations and languages. **16**And the ten horns that you saw, they and the beast will hate the prostitute. They will make her desolate and naked, and devour her flesh and burn her up with fire, **<sup>17</sup>** for God has put it into their hearts to carry out his purpose by being of one mind and handing over their royal power to the beast, until the words of God are fulfilled. **18**And the woman that you saw is the great city that has dominion over the kings of the earth."

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-694-4"></span><span id="page-694-3"></span><span id="page-694-0"></span>History has ended with the seventh trumpet, but John circles back and looks at history from another angle, a device that by this point is quite familiar to us as readers. In 17:1–19:10 two women are considered: the harlot Babylon and the bride of the Lamb. The former is judged and the latter blessed; the former is faithless and the latter faithful; the former is a prostitute worshiping false gods, the latter a chaste bride devoted to the Lord. John concentrates here on Babylon and the judgment coming upon that city. Chapter 17 can be divided into three subsections. First, an angel invites John to see the judgment of Babylon (vv. 1–6a). She is seated on many waters, and the kings and people of earth have come to bed with her and worshiped false gods (vv. 1–2). John is transported to the wilderness and sees a woman seated on a scarlet beast; the woman is rich and arrayed like royalty, but her riches are defiled by her abominable sins (vv. 3–4). A mystery is disclosed about the woman: she is Babylon, the mother of harlots (v. 5), and John sees her drunk with the blood of the saints (v. 6a).

<span id="page-694-11"></span><span id="page-694-10"></span><span id="page-694-9"></span><span id="page-694-8"></span><span id="page-694-7"></span><span id="page-694-6"></span><span id="page-694-5"></span><span id="page-694-2"></span>This leads to the second section of the chapter (vv. 6b–14). John is astonished at the woman, but the angel asks why he is astonished and promises to disclose the mystery of the woman and the beast carrying her (vv. 6b–7). The beast is remarkable because of his sort of resurrection, dazzling unbelievers (v. 8). John gives a hint of the location of the woman (v. 9) and provides tantalizing clues about eight kings (vv. 10–11). He also elaborates on an intriguing feature of the beast—it seems to be defunct and yet keeps returning. Ten kings unite together with the beast and yield their authority to him (vv. 12–13). They are infused with hatred for the Lamb and go to war with him, but he will conquer as the Lord of lords and King of kings (v. 14).

<span id="page-694-18"></span><span id="page-694-17"></span><span id="page-694-16"></span><span id="page-694-15"></span><span id="page-694-14"></span><span id="page-694-13"></span><span id="page-694-12"></span>In the third section the destiny of the woman is unfolded (vv. 15–18). The waters she sits on are identified as the peoples and nations and tongues of the world (v. 15). The beast and the kings allied with him will turn against the woman and consume her with fire (v. 16). In doing so, however, they are fulfilling God's will and purposes, as his words are realized as evil implodes upon itself (v. 17). Finally, John identifies Babylon as a great city, and his audience would almost certainly think of Rome (v. 18).

#### <span id="page-694-19"></span>*Section Outline*

- VIII. The Judgment of Babylon and the Wedding of the Bride (17:1–19:10)
	- A. The Harlot Babylon Destroyed (17:1–18)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-694-20"></span><span id="page-694-1"></span>17:1 History has ended with the seventh bowl, but John, as he does so often in Revelation, shakes the kaleidoscope again. Now he looks at the end of history by considering the fate of Babylon, the great harlot. One of the seven angels with the seven bowls summons John to come, and he will be shown the judgment of the great harlot sitting on many waters. Later, one of the same angels invites John to come and see "the Bride, the wife of the Lamb" (21:9). The contrast between two <span id="page-695-12"></span><span id="page-695-6"></span><span id="page-695-2"></span>women dominates the next few chapters, but the focus is on the harlot in chapters 17–18. She is called a prostitute because of her spiritual adultery and worship of false gods (cf. 19:2; cf. also Jer. 2:20; Nah. 3:4), not because of her sexual deviance, although the former clearly leads to the latter (cf. Rom. 1:18–27). The waters are identified in Revelation 17:15 as "peoples and multitudes and nations and languages." Babylon's sitting on the waters signifies her sovereignty and rule over them (cf. 18:7).

<span id="page-695-20"></span><span id="page-695-19"></span><span id="page-695-18"></span><span id="page-695-17"></span><span id="page-695-13"></span><span id="page-695-11"></span><span id="page-695-8"></span><span id="page-695-5"></span><span id="page-695-3"></span><span id="page-695-1"></span>17:2 The kings of the earth have committed sexual sin with Babylon (cf. 17:18; 18:3, 9; cf. also Isa. 23:17). Again, the language symbolically denotes spiritual adultery and unfaithfulness. And it is not as if the citizens are free of guilt (cf. Rev. 18:3; cf. also Nah. 3:4). The "dwellers on earth," a technical term in Revelation for unbelievers (cf. comment on Rev. 3:10), have happily joined the orgy. They too have loved the delicious wine of the harlot's sexual deviance (14:8)—her rejection of the one true God—and have become drunk (cf. Jer. 51:7). Hosea indicts Israel for similar sins (Hos. 4:11–12), for "whoredom, wine, and new wine, which take away the understanding. My people inquire of a piece of wood, and their walking staff gives them oracles. For a spirit of whoredom has led them astray, and they have left their God to play the whore." The language of sexual immorality, as we see also in Hosea, is not literal; John means that the city of man has loved and served other gods. In particular, they have participated in idolatry because of its economic benefits, just as Tyre profited by playing the harlot—Tyre "will prostitute herself with all the kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth" (Isa. 23:17).

<span id="page-695-14"></span><span id="page-695-7"></span><span id="page-695-0"></span>17:3 John is carried away in the Spirit to the wilderness. The reference to the Spirit means that the spirit of prophecy was upon him and he was inspired to speak the word of the Lord (cf. comment on 1:10). The parallel with 21:10 is especially significant, for there John is carried by the Spirit to see the descent of the new Jerusalem, where the new Jerusalem and the bride, the wife of the Lamb, stand in vivid contrast to the harlot Babylon. The wilderness can be a place of salvation (cf. 12:6, 14) or of judgment (1 Sam. 4:8; Isa. 21:1; Jer. 50:12; Lam. 4:19; 5:9); here it is clearly a place of judgment for Babylon. John sees a woman sitting on a scarlet beast, the beast described in chapter 13. The woman, which is clearly Rome (cf. comments on 17:5; 17:9–11; 17:18), is supported by the empire and its armies. The beast has seven heads and ten horns, demonstrating its authority and strength (cf. comment on 13:1). The beast should use its strength for humane and righteous purposes, but it resists truth and goodness, using its strength to revile and blaspheme the one true God.

<span id="page-695-16"></span><span id="page-695-15"></span><span id="page-695-10"></span><span id="page-695-9"></span><span id="page-695-4"></span>17:4 At first glance, the woman is beautiful; her clothes and jewelry are stunning (cf. 18:16; cf. also Ezek. 28:13): her clothing is purple and scarlet, and she is decked out with gold, jewels, and pearls. She holds a golden cup in her hand, but something is horribly wrong, for the cup is full of what is abominable and unclean. Her beauty has been defaced because she has given herself to evil and to false gods. She has enriched herself by giving her allegiance to others and has devoted herself to material wealth instead of the one true God. We think of what Daniel says about Antiochus IV Epiphanes: "He shall honor the god of fortresses instead of these. A god whom his fathers did not know he shall honor with gold and silver, with precious stones and costly gifts" (Dan. 11:38).

<span id="page-696-6"></span><span id="page-696-3"></span><span id="page-696-1"></span><span id="page-696-0"></span>17:5 The woman has something inscribed on her forehead, and what is written is a mystery. Typically in Scripture, a mystery is something previously hidden that is now revealed. Here the true nature and character of Rome is unveiled so that believers will not give their affection to the city of man. The woman, the city of Rome, is identified as Babylon the great (cf. Dan. 4:30), the mother of harlots and the abominations polluting the earth. John likely uses the word "mystery" because the historical Babylon that played such a central role in OT history—the head of gold in Nebuchadnezzar's vision (Dan. 2:37–38) and the lion among the kingdoms in Daniel's vision (Dan. 7:4)—pointed beyond itself to the city of man in general, to human culture and society insofar as it is opposed to and hates the living God. Historical Babylon no longer existed when John wrote, but the manifestation of evil in the city of man emerged in John's day in the city of Rome. Hence, those with eyes to see would realize that Babylon was revived in the city of Rome. And, throughout history, "Babylon" has arisen again and again. What Augustine called the "city of man" has given birth to ideologies and regimes that repudiate God.

<span id="page-696-7"></span><span id="page-696-5"></span><span id="page-696-2"></span>17:6a The evil of the woman becomes plain, for now John sees that she is actually drunk. Here we see a beautiful woman tarnished by sin and drunkenness, but she is drunk not with wine (the language is apocalyptic) but with the blood of the saints and those who witnessed to Jesus by their words and actions. The ESV uses the word "martyrs" here, which they were (cf. 2:13; 6:9–11; 16:6; 18:24; 19:2, 20:4), but the term (Gk. *martyrōn*, "witnesses"; cf. Matt. 18:16) was not yet a technical one. The saints witnessed to Jesus by their lives and paid for it with their deaths. The woman cannot tolerate anyone devoted to the Christ, and thus she drinks their blood by taking the lives of those who belong to Jesus.

<span id="page-696-9"></span><span id="page-696-8"></span><span id="page-696-4"></span>17:6b–7 The mystery of Babylon leads to the second section of the chapter (17:6b–12), in which mysteries are disclosed to John. John is shocked and probably fearful upon seeing the woman drunk with the saints' blood, and the angel asks John why he is so astonished. Clearly this is a literary device to underscore how startling and shocking it was for John to see a scheming witch instead of a beautiful woman. Furthermore, John may be full of astonishment, for so far the vision has disclosed not the judgment of the woman but her triumph. The angel informs John that there is a mystery concerning the woman, and we have already seen one facet of the mystery in verse 5. But here the mystery relates not only to the woman but also to the beast with seven heads and ten horns who carries her.

<span id="page-696-10"></span>17:8 The mystery in this case is quite puzzling and tantalizing, and interpreters continue to be vexed by what John writes. Here we come face to face with one of the most difficult texts in the entire book. John says the beast *was*, *is not now*, but *will be* raised from the abyss. It is quite puzzling how John says the beast "is not" twice in this verse, for if the beast refers to the Roman Empire—active while John wrote—how can he say it "is not"? Perhaps John thinks of a particular emperor, such as Nero, whose rule has ended, which could possibly explain what he means by saying there is no ruler presently. Some have speculated that John wrote these words in the interval between Nero (54–68 AD) and Vespasian (69–79 AD), in which Galba, Otho, and Vitellius all took power for a short time. One could say Rome lacked a ruler in this unstable period, which ended when Vitellius was defeated by Vespasian's forces and the latter began his reign (see the list of "Roman Emperors," which italicizes the three short reigns following Nero):

#### Roman Emperors

Augustus 27 BC–14 AD Tiberius 14–37 AD Caligula 37–41 Claudius 41–54 Nero 54–68 *Galba 68–69 Otho 69 Vitellius 69* Vespasian 69–79 Titus 79–81 Domitian 81–96

No solution is completely satisfactory, but I will suggest another option shortly, for it seems unlikely that we can restrict what John writes here to the one-year interval between Nero and Vespasian. It is more satisfying to say that John reflects on the empire as a whole. In other words, it will go through periods of flourishing followed by periods of decline. What John says about Rome is true also of human history generally. There are periods of history when totalitarian rule seems a thing of the past, but history keeps rolling along, and totalitarian power returns with all its ferocity and cruelty. Believers must not think that evil has been defeated permanently in the periods of relative peace.

<span id="page-697-0"></span>Those who dwell on earth (again, a technical reference to unbelievers; cf. comment on 3:10) are amazed at the beast, for it will seem as if the beast's power has ended, only for the beast to rise again, parodying Christ's resurrection. The inhabitants of the earth will give their allegiance to the beast, since it appears that he has conquered death. The inhabitants of the earth are morally responsible for their allegiance to the beast, and yet at the same time their unbelief was destined from the beginning of history. Before the world was created, their names were not inscribed in the book of life. Such a statement does not mean people are either justified or condemned before they are born, nor does it indicate our choices do not matter. It signifies, rather, that God is sovereign over all of history. He knows

<span id="page-698-1"></span>and ordains whose names will be in the book of life. Nothing takes him by surprise or deters him from accomplishing his purpose. The book of life (cf. comment on 3:5) is often mentioned in Revelation, referring to the book containing the names of those who will enter the new Jerusalem and will escape the second death and the lake of fire. Those who give themselves to the beast will most certainly be excluded from the book of life.

<span id="page-698-4"></span><span id="page-698-3"></span>17:9–11 These three verses are among the most difficult to interpret in the book, as the mystery of the woman and the beast continues to be disclosed to John. Hence, any interpretation must be adopted only tentatively. We are reminded of 13:18, where John also employs numbers and calls the readers to exercise wisdom. The seven heads of the beast are identified with the seven mountains on which the woman is seated. The seven mountains are almost certainly those on which the city of Rome was founded.

John goes on to say that the seven heads of the beast also stand for seven kings. We are then given a chronology: five of the kings have fallen and are no more. One king is now, and hence his rule continues to be exercised. Still, the rule of the present king is not the end, for another king will succeed the sixth one, though his reign will be limited. He will rule only a short time. I suggest that the short period of time designates the entire period between Jesus' first and second coming. The same term was used to designate the Devil's time on earth after being expelled from heaven by virtue of the cross of Christ (12:12). The apostle Peter also remarks that the trials and sufferings afflicting believers occur for only a short time (1 Pet. 1:6; 5:10), meaning they last until Jesus returns.

<span id="page-698-5"></span><span id="page-698-2"></span><span id="page-698-0"></span>Interpreting what John says here is quite complex, for the beast that "was" and now "is not" represents an eighth ruler. But, at the same time, he belongs to the seventh. It is puzzling for John to say the beast "is not" when the Roman Empire continued to exert its persecuting influence over believers while John was writing. And to make matters more confusing, in verse 10 he speaks of the sixth king as the one who "is." There is a sense in which the beast "is not" and a sense in which it "is." Whatever we make of the details, the end of the story is relayed to us: the beast will go to destruction and ultimately will be destroyed.

Still, we are curious: what should we make of the chronology here? Many scholars have seen Nero as the eighth, who comes from the first seven (so that John forecasts the return of Nero), and thus the reference is to Roman emperors. If we begin with Julius Caesar, the lineup would be: Julius Caesar (44 BC); Augustus (27 BC to AD 14); Tiberius (AD 14–37); Caligula (AD 37–41); Claudius (AD 41–54); and Nero (AD 54–68). The three emperors who reigned from AD 68–69 could be skipped (Galba, Otho, and Vitellius), and then the seventh would be Vepasian (AD 69–79). Against this interpretation, it is not obvious that we should skip three emperors, and Vespasian's reign does not seem to fit, for it was not short, even though John says that the reign of the seventh would be short. On the other hand, the reign of the three emperors was brief, and perhaps they could be counted as one (though

counting three emperors as one is not obvious). Others start with Augustus, but we still have the problem of how the three emperors who reigned in AD 68–69 fit into the scheme. It seems this line of interpretation explains the verses inadequately.

Perhaps it is better to think here of empires that afflicted the people of God. One possibility is that the empires are Assyria, Media, Babylon, Persia, Greece, the old Roman Empire, the new Roman Empire under Constantine, and then the rule of the Antichrist. One wonders if this scheme really works. Why is Egypt left out, and how do we choose which empires to include, for the time of their rule is not always neatly discerned? Furthermore, distinguishing between the old and new Roman Empire is artificial. On what grounds is the Roman Empire split in two? Another scheme posits Egypt, Assyria, Babylon, Medo-Persia, and Greece. Then Rome is the sixth in John's reckoning. But on this scheme, it is unclear how Rome "belongs to the seven" (Rev. 17:11), and thus the solution seems artificial. It is also difficult to grasp what John means when he says the beast (presumably Rome) was and is not, for Rome still exercised its power when John wrote, and it is unconvincing to posit (as some do) that John wrote in the interval when Galba, Otho, and Vitellius were vying for power, for we are again faced with the problem of counting the three as if they were one.

<span id="page-699-4"></span><span id="page-699-0"></span>Perhaps the best solution is to interpret what John says symbolically and generally. John reflects on the empires that have afflicted Israel throughout its history, and his point in referring to the sixth is that the end is near. This is comparable to Daniel's sketch of human history in Nebuchadnezzar's vision of the statue (Daniel 2) and Daniel's vision of the four beasts and the Son of Man (Daniel 7). Throughout history, totalitarian regimes have tilted against the people of God. And there are periods where it looks as if the power of these empires will not return, as if the beast "is not." But the beast, which refers to totalitarian power, always rises again. It may seem dead, yet the beast rises from the ashes and inflicts misery upon the saints again. This will be the pattern throughout history until the end arrives.

<span id="page-699-5"></span><span id="page-699-3"></span><span id="page-699-1"></span>17:12 The ten horns on the beast (cf. 17:3, 7) are now identified as ten kings, and these kings are probably kingly powers outside Rome's borders. But they also represent all earthly powers and governing authorities opposed to God. Such an identification fits with Daniel's vision, where the fourth beast has ten horns, representing ten kings (Dan. 7:7, 20, 24), and the fourth beast combines together the hideous and beastly character of all four beasts in Daniel 7. Horns designate strength and rule, and here they stand for political force and strength to subjugate other nations (cf. Zech. 1:18–21). These kings have not yet received their authority, but they will rule with the beast for a limited time before the end of history. The number ten should not be taken literally. It seems that John envisions a period before the end when the beast and the rulers of the world attain power before their judgment.

<span id="page-699-6"></span><span id="page-699-2"></span>17:13 The rulers of the world, predisposed to exercise their own power and infamous for their stubbornness and pride, find themselves coming together. They are harmonious in giving their power and authority to the beast. The church should not fear when nation-states conspire together against the people of God, for this is exactly what has been forecasted. Totalitarian rule is frightening and horrendous because of the toll it exacts on those under its rule, but such rule should not surprise the people of God.

<span id="page-700-10"></span><span id="page-700-9"></span><span id="page-700-6"></span>17:14 The fearsomeness of the opposition could feel overwhelming. John reminds his readers that the beast and the ten kings are implacably opposed to the Lamb. It is his authority they despise and long to remove from their lives. The rulers make war with the Lamb, manifested in the killing of the saints, for they are identified with and belong to the Lamb. Still, the final victory is sure, for the Lamb will triumph over the rulers opposing him (cf. 19:11–21). The Lamb's triumph is certain, for he is the Lord of lords and the King of kings (cf. 19:16). No power or sovereignty or majesty can compare with his. The descriptions of the Lamb here suggest his deity, for elsewhere God is identified as the Lord of lords (Deut. 10:17; Ps. 136:3; 1 Tim. 6:15) and King of kings (1 Tim. 6:15; cf. also Dan. 2:47; *3 Macc.* 5:35; *1 En.*  9:4). Here these titles are given to the Lamb. The saints must persevere, for then they will certainly triumph and conquer with the Lamb.

<span id="page-700-4"></span><span id="page-700-1"></span>John pauses to describe those who belong to the Lamb. They are those who are called, elect, and faithful. The first two descriptions emphasize the sovereign grace of God. The saints cannot take credit for belonging to the Lamb, for they have been called by God's grace. The calling here is effectual: it is a calling that inducts them into the kingdom. In the same way, the saints are elected and chosen by God, and thus are the recipients of his marvelous mercy and grace. The saints do not belong to God ultimately because of their own decision and choice but because of God's electing grace. Yet such gracious benefits do not preclude the need for a human response. Indeed, they are the basis for such a response, and hence the saints must be faithful. They are to persevere faithfully until the end to obtain the final reward.

<span id="page-700-7"></span><span id="page-700-2"></span>17:15 The third section of the chapter now commences (vv. 15–18). We were told in verse 1 that the prostitute sits on many waters (cf. Jer. 47:2), and now the angel reveals to John the meaning and significance of these waters. The waters stand for many people groups and languages. The first three terms roughly overlap, calling attention to the breadth of the harlot's rule. Her influence is massive and deleterious.

<span id="page-700-8"></span><span id="page-700-5"></span><span id="page-700-3"></span><span id="page-700-0"></span>17:16 The ten horns, which are the ten kings (v. 12) ruling alongside the beast, are filled with hatred and animus against the harlot. It seems the rulers of the empire will turn against the economic and religious center of their society. Babylon is a harlot because of her idolatrous devotion to false gods and her rapacious economic system that abuses others. The kings are animated by hatred, and thus they destroy the prostitute, who ends up desolate (cf. Ezek. 26:19) and naked (cf. Ezek. 16:39; 23:29), destroyed by fire (Rev. 18:8; cf. Lev. 21:9; Jer. 34:22). Hatred is irrational and demonic. Evil ultimately implodes upon itself; it is inherently self-destructive. The city of man will collapse under the weight of its own evil and hate.

<span id="page-701-5"></span><span id="page-701-4"></span><span id="page-701-2"></span><span id="page-701-0"></span>17:17 John provides a remarkable commentary on God's designs and purposes in the attack on, and destruction of, the great harlot, carried out by the ten kings. The desire of the ten kings and the beast to destroy the harlot is ultimately from God, and thus they are carrying out his purpose and will (cf. 10:7). The purposes of God in such events do not cancel out the authenticity of human choices and decisions, for the hatred of the ten kings and the beast for the harlot is no charade (17:16). The kings and the beasts are not puppets and marionettes whose strings God pulls. We see the same phenomenon in Isaiah, where Assyria fulfills God's will while clearly doing what it desires to do (Isa. 10:5–34). So, too, God rules over what the beast and the kings do to the harlot, yet he is not morally blameworthy or indicted for the evil the kings and beast perform. We see elsewhere that God can predestine evil events so that his purposes are fulfilled, while remaining unstained by evil. The supreme example of this is the cross of Christ: Jesus' death was predestined by God, but those who killed him were held responsible (Acts 2:23; 4:27–28). We are reminded here that God rules over history, that evil empires and kings, though culpable for the horrific evil they carry out, are never outside the hand of God. Nor should they boast as if they accomplish anything apart from his purposes.

<span id="page-701-6"></span><span id="page-701-3"></span><span id="page-701-1"></span>17:18 The identity of the woman is now disclosed, and we are told that she represents a city. The reference to the seven hills suggested Rome (v. 9), and now the reference to Rome is confirmed. Rome here represents the city of man opposed to the things of God, which John's original audience experienced firsthand. At the same time, the moniker "Babylon" suggests that what is said here transcends Rome and represents all other cultures and cities of the world opposed to the things of God.

#### *Response*

We see in this chapter a trinity of evil powers: the beast, the ten kings, and the wicked and ostentatious harlot. The evil practiced, especially by the harlot, is lurid and shocking. The blood of the saints is shed by the prostitute while she pursues a life of glamor and luxury. John reminds us, however, that evil will not triumph. Evil finally turns upon itself and implodes. The unity present at the beginning of the coalition's evil machinations dissolves at the end into mutual hatred and recrimination. The implosion of evil, however, is not merely a human reality. We live in God's world, and he steers history so that his purposes and will become a reality. Even when evil is doing its worst, God is directing the outcome without being besmirched himself by evil. Believers must never become defeatist when they see a culture descending into evil, although this does not mean we shut our eyes to the evil reigning around us. Still, we are always full of confidence and hope, for we know the end of the story. We know the final score: we win.

<span id="page-702-1"></span>18 After this I saw another angel coming down from heaven, having great authority, and the earth was made bright with his glory. **2**And he called out with a mighty voice,

- "Fallen, fallen is Babylon the great! She has become a dwelling place for demons,
- a haunt for every unclean spirit,
- a haunt for every unclean bird,
- a haunt for every unclean and detestable beast.
- **<sup>3</sup>** For all nations have drunk*<sup>1</sup>*

 the wine of the passion of her sexual immorality, and the kings of the earth have committed immorality with her, and the merchants of the earth have grown rich from the power of her luxurious living."

**<sup>4</sup>**Then I heard another voice from heaven saying,

- "Come out of her, my people, lest you take part in her sins, lest you share in her plagues;
- **<sup>5</sup>** for her sins are heaped high as heaven, and God has remembered her iniquities.
- **<sup>6</sup>** Pay her back as she herself has paid back others, and repay her double for her deeds; mix a double portion for her in the cup she mixed.
- **<sup>7</sup>** As she glorified herself and lived in luxury, so give her a like measure of torment and mourning, since in her heart she says,
	- 'I sit as a queen,
- I am no widow,
- and mourning I shall never see.'

- and she will be burned up with fire;

for mighty is the Lord God who has judged her."

1Some manuscripts *fallen by*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-702-2"></span><span id="page-702-0"></span>Chapter 17 introduced the theme of the fall of the great city, the city of man. As is typical in Revelation, John revisits, expands, and fills in the fall of the city, under the moniker "Babylon," in 18:1–19:5. Babylon refers to Rome but also stands for <span id="page-703-12"></span><span id="page-703-5"></span>the city of man in general. John picks up OT texts about Babylon and applies them to human cities in opposition to God. Indeed, the remainder of the book of Revelation could be characterized as a contrast between the city of man (Babylon) and the city of God (the new Jerusalem), a contrast between two women: the harlot Babylon and the bride of the Lamb (the church). This segment (18:1–8) consists of two voices, which are probably both angelic, declaring the judgment of Babylon. The first angel, shimmering with glory, declares the fall of Babylon (18:1–3) into desolation and demonic activity (v. 2). Babylon is judged because it has corrupted nations, kings, and merchants with its idolatry (v. 3). Another voice brings a message in verses 4–8: God's people are exhorted to leave Babylon (v. 4) since her sins are great and God is about to punish her (v. 5). Babylon will be repaid for the evil she has done (v. 6), and the glory she enjoyed will now be a cause for mourning (v. 7). Babylon will be destroyed in a day with the mighty and fearsome judgment of God (v. 8).

#### <span id="page-703-16"></span><span id="page-703-15"></span><span id="page-703-14"></span><span id="page-703-13"></span><span id="page-703-7"></span><span id="page-703-6"></span>*Section Outline*

VIII. The Judgment of Babylon and the Wedding of the Bride (17:1–19:10) . . .

B. The Declarations of Two Angels (18:1–8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-703-11"></span><span id="page-703-10"></span>18:1 Angels play a prominent role in Revelation, and the destruction of Babylon in chapter 17 is now replayed and revisited from another angle. We again see John coming to the end of history only to backtrack and fill in what has happened in more depth. It was insufficient to announce the judgment of the city in chapter 17, for John wants to explain in more detail the reasons for the judgment and the horror it engenders among unbelievers. The angel descends from heaven, showing its transcendent authority, and illumines the earth with its glory and splendor (cf. Ezek. 43:2). The beauty and power of the angel indicate it is about to introduce a matter of weighty importance.

<span id="page-703-17"></span><span id="page-703-9"></span><span id="page-703-8"></span><span id="page-703-4"></span><span id="page-703-3"></span><span id="page-703-2"></span><span id="page-703-1"></span><span id="page-703-0"></span>18:2 The angel announces with authority and majesty (cf. 7:2; 10:3; 14:7, 9, 15; 19:17) that Babylon the great has fallen. The impending fall of Babylon has been declared previously in Revelation (14:8; 16:19; 17:5), and now it is further expounded. The pronouncement of Babylon's fall echoes the words of Isaiah: "Fallen, fallen is Babylon; and all the carved images of her gods he has shattered to the ground" (Isa. 21:9). Babylon in the OT was the great enemy of the people of God. It was Babylon that sent Judah into exile in 586 BC, and Babylon is the head of gold in Nebuchadnezzar's dream (Dan. 2:32, 37–38) and the lion in Daniel's vision (Dan. 7:4, 17). The OT prophets announced God's judgment on Babylon for its evil and idolatry (e.g., Isa. 13:1–14:23; 47:1–15; Jer. 50:1–51:64). Babylon was destroyed and judged in 539 BC, but its fall became a type and pattern for kingdoms and cities opposed to God.

<span id="page-704-5"></span><span id="page-704-0"></span>Here in Revelation, Rome, as the city of man, is described as Babylon. Any city that sets itself up in opposition to God becomes Babylon, as Rome did in the ancient world. Just as ancient Babylon was judged, so too will Rome be judged. Again, John reuses the language of Scripture (cf. Isa. 13:21–22; 14:23; 34:11, 14; Jer. 50:39; 51:37). The city of man, the Babylon of the world, will become the home of demons and unclean spirits. Foul and unclean birds and animals will dwell there. Babylon was once a thriving and exciting city, but it never recovered from its destruction in 539 BC. This forecasts the final judgment, when the city of man will be desolated and destroyed forever. Rome will ultimately and finally face the same fate as Babylon.

<span id="page-704-11"></span><span id="page-704-7"></span><span id="page-704-4"></span><span id="page-704-3"></span><span id="page-704-1"></span>18:3 The fundamental reason for Babylon's judgment, and Rome's, is now relayed to John's audience. The nations of the world have drunk the wine of her immorality (cf. Jer. 25:15; 51:7). John is not talking primarily about sexual sin here, even though he uses language of sexual unfaithfulness. In the OT, Israel's defection from the Lord is described as whoredom and harlotry (cf. Jer. 3:8–9; Ezekiel 16; 23; Hos. 1:1–3:5; cf. also Isa. 23:17). So, too, the root sin of the city of man is abandoning God, pursuing other gods instead of him (cf. Rom. 1:21). The great city has influenced the nations of the world so that they have turned away from the one true God. The kings of the earth have followed the same path, and their sin is also described in terms of sexual deviance. Once again, the metaphor communicates spiritual adultery—rejection of God's lordship. The merchants of the earth are indicted for growing rich from the luxuries afforded by their alliance with Babylon. John is not saying that riches per se bring judgment, but those gained by participation in the same idolatry and evil as Babylon do indeed (cf. Ezek. 27:12, 18, 33).

<span id="page-704-12"></span><span id="page-704-10"></span><span id="page-704-9"></span><span id="page-704-8"></span><span id="page-704-6"></span><span id="page-704-2"></span>18:4 Now another voice rings out, presumably that of another angel. This voice also comes from heaven, signaling a transcendent authority. But here the message is for the people of God, those who have remained faithful to Jesus Christ. They are exhorted to come out of Babylon, to avoid participating in her sins, for those who sin like Babylon in forsaking the Lord will face the coming final judgment. In commanding God's people to flee Babylon, the angel echoes the OT: "Go out from Babylon, flee from Chaldea, declare this with a shout of joy, proclaim it, send it out to the end of the earth; say, 'The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob!'" (Isa. 48:20; cf. Jer. 50:8; 51:6, 9, 45). Israel was commanded literally to leave Babylon, to return to Judah and Jerusalem. John's readers are not commanded to leave Rome literally (cf. 2 Cor. 6:17). John means they must not participate in the idolatry of Rome; they must not give their allegiance to the emperor and forsake Jesus Christ. They must be willing to renounce the wealth and reputation of the world to follow Jesus Christ. The sins pursued by Babylon should be forsaken, for those who participate in such sins will also receive the plagues coming upon Babylon. "Plagues" refers to both the trumpet (Rev. 9:18, 20) and the bowl judgments (15:1, 6, 8; 16:9, 21), and here it designates final judgment.

<span id="page-705-9"></span><span id="page-705-2"></span><span id="page-705-0"></span>18:5 The judgments inflicted on Babylon are warranted, for her sins have reached heaven, meaning they are remarkable for their depth and breadth (cf. Gen. 18:20; Ezra 9:6; Jonah 1:2). Jeremiah said about historical Babylon, "Her judgment has reached up to heaven and has been lifted up even to the skies" (Jer. 51:9). The long stretch of no punishment made it seem as if there would be no judgment, but God never forgets iniquities, putting all things right in the end.

<span id="page-705-13"></span><span id="page-705-7"></span><span id="page-705-4"></span>18:6 God remembers Babylon's sin because he is just, and his justice is manifested in the maxim, "The punishment fits the crime." The Babylons of the world will not remain unscathed, for the evil they do will turn back on them. Often in the OT, Babylon is threatened with punishment for her misdeeds (cf. Ps. 137:8; Jer. 16:18; 50:15, 29; 51:24, 49). It is somewhat surprising, then, that the punishment is said to be double for her works—her cup of wrath is mixed to a double portion. How should we understand this? It is quite unlikely that John teaches that Babylon is punished more than she deserves. Perhaps the language is hyperbolic, expressing the thought that Babylon receives the full measure of her punishment. Or, conversely, the double punishment motif could indicate that the gravity of her sin—her sins reached up to heaven (Rev. 18:5)—warrant a greater punishment (cf. Ps. 79:12).

<span id="page-705-14"></span><span id="page-705-12"></span><span id="page-705-11"></span><span id="page-705-3"></span>18:7 The interpretation proposed for the previous verse is confirmed here, for once again John emphasizes that the punishment fits the crime. The fundamental sin of the city of man is her glorifying herself instead of giving glory to the one true God. She refuses to give thanks and praise to God and worships the creature rather than the Creator (Rom. 1:21, 25). Inasmuch as Rome has pursued luxury, to that extent will she experience torment and sorrow. Remarkably enough, the Babylons of this world are convinced they will not face punishment. Picking up the words of Isaiah 47:7–8, the harlot exalts herself as queen instead of seeing herself as a wicked and scheming prostitute (cf. Ezek. 28:2–8). She is also deluded, convinced she will never know widowhood or mourning. She thinks she has a godlike status, immune to the vicissitudes of life and the judgment of God.

<span id="page-705-15"></span><span id="page-705-10"></span><span id="page-705-8"></span><span id="page-705-6"></span><span id="page-705-5"></span><span id="page-705-1"></span>18:8 The sin pursued by the harlot will come cascading suddenly upon her, just as Isaiah predicted: "These two things shall come to you in a moment, in one day; the loss of children and widowhood" (Isa. 47:9; cf. Jer. 50:31). Again, the judgment upon the historical Babylon is appropriated typologically and applied to Rome. In a single day her confidence will vanish as plagues descend upon her. The plagues are identified as death, mourning, and famine. The prostitute, in a punishment reminiscent of the penalty for a priest's daughter who turns to prostitution ("The daughter of any priest, if she profanes herself by whoring, profanes her father; she shall be burned with fire"—Lev. 21:9), will be burned with fire (cf. Rev. 17:16). The judgment is not impersonal or simply cause and effect. God personally judges her, showing his lordship and mighty power (cf. Jer. 50:34), for no one can triumph over him. Nor can anyone give himself over to evil without facing God's wrath.

#### *Response*

<span id="page-706-1"></span>The judgment of the great harlot functions as an exhortation to the church of Jesus Christ, as seen in verse 4. We are to come out from the city of man and forsake its sins. John does not mean we are to establish a segregated society in which we have no contact with unbelievers. The point is that believers are not to throw in their lot with those who have forsaken the true and living God. Believers are to separate from the world, not by withdrawing from it but by living pure and holy lives in God's sight. We are to be in the world, as Jesus taught us, but not of it (John 17:15–16). If we belong to the Babylons of the world, we will not escape the just judgment of God.

1Or *and slaves, and human lives*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-707-10"></span><span id="page-707-7"></span><span id="page-707-6"></span><span id="page-707-5"></span><span id="page-707-4"></span><span id="page-707-3"></span>The judgment of the great harlot has been announced, and now the response to her judgment is seen in a lamentation over her fall. The lamentation is neatly split into three sections: that of kings (Rev. 18:9–10), merchants (18:11–17a), and those who work on the sea (vv. 17b–19). The kings who participated with Babylon in harlotry and enjoyed its luxury wail over its destruction and judgment (vv. 9–10). The merchants lament because "no one buys their cargo anymore" (v. 11), cargo itemized in verses 12–13. The list concludes with a shocking indictment of the merchants' evil, for they sold human beings as slaves. The delicacies and luxuries the merchants enjoyed are gone forever (v. 14). The judgment of Babylon fills the merchants with fear and grief (v. 15). Their exploitative version of the good life with its wealth and luxury has vanished in a moment (vv. 16–17a). In the same way, all those who work the sea are struck with sadness (v. 17b). The source of their wealth for so many years is gone, up in smoke (vv. 18–19). Here is further evidence that the judgment is not restricted to Rome, for just as John picks up the judgment of Babylon and applies it to Rome, so here he applies the judgment of the ancient city of Tyre to Rome. John's use of the OT suggests that every city following the path of Babylon and Tyre, every city pursuing idolatry like Rome, is part of the great city of man. For this reason he can apply the same indictment to Jerusalem, the city where Jesus was crucified (11:8).

#### <span id="page-707-11"></span><span id="page-707-9"></span><span id="page-707-8"></span><span id="page-707-0"></span>*Section Outline*

VIII. The Judgment of Babylon and the Wedding of the Bride

(17:1–19:10) . . .

C. Lamentation over Babylon's Fall (18:9–19)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-707-2"></span><span id="page-707-1"></span>18:9 The kings of the earth weep and wail when they see the judgment of Babylon, for they were, so to speak, in bed with her. They committed sexual immorality with her, but as we saw in 18:3, literal sexual sin is not in view here. Sexual immorality stands for the anti-god lifestyle of Babylon and the kings. The kings and Babylon got along swimmingly because together they tried to dethrone God; they pledged allegiance to the state and its emperor. In doing so they padded their bank accounts, got rich, and lived in luxury. But the days of luxury are over; Babylon has been thrown down. The judgment of Babylon that John describes harks back to the judgment of the great city of Tyre, which was famous for its seafaring ways, transporting wares all over the ancient world:

Then all the princes of the sea will step down from their thrones and remove their robes and strip off their embroidered garments. They will clothe themselves with trembling; they will sit on the ground and tremble every moment and be appalled at you. And they will raise a lamentation over you and say to you,

```
"How you have perished,
you who were inhabited from the seas,
O city renowned,
who was mighty on the sea;
she and her inhabitants imposed their terror
on all her inhabitants!" (Ezek. 26:16–17; cf. Jer. 50:46).
```
<span id="page-708-0"></span>The desolation of Tyre in history prefigures the upending of the city of man—the great harlot.

<span id="page-708-2"></span>18:10 Seeing the rising smoke of Babylon's judgment fills the kings with fear and foreboding. Upon seeing her torment, they do not want to get too near, sensing that the same fate awaits them. They rue and regret what has happened and cry out, "Alas," for the mighty and great city of man has been destroyed so quickly. The judgment was executed in an hour; what seemed to be invincible vanished before their very eyes.

<span id="page-708-3"></span><span id="page-708-1"></span>18:11 The merchants of the earth (cf. Ezek. 27:36) are also plunged into sorrow over the harlot's demise. Their grief, however, is self-referential, for they do not truly care about Babylon. What troubles the merchants is the loss of buyers for their wares and goods. The wicked grieve only over themselves.

<span id="page-708-4"></span>18:12–13 John specifies the goods marketed by the merchants, including gold, silver, and precious jewels and pearls. The finest and most expensive clothing was also for sale, including purple, silk, and scarlet. Various products of ivory, expensive and attractive woods, bronze, marble, and iron were also sold, as well as other delightful products such as cinnamon, spices, incense, frankincense, wine, wheat, cattle, sheep, and horses. There is nothing wrong with trade, and such products make human life more enjoyable and tolerable. John is not condemning trade and production per se. But there was something radically wrong with the trade that was practiced, for they also marketed human beings. Human beings were sold as slaves, demonstrating that profit had become a god, displacing any moral considerations.

<span id="page-709-2"></span>18:14 The pleasures the merchants delighted in, the raison d'etre of their existence, were no longer to be had. They enjoyed the exquisite beauty, fine craftsmanship, and artistry of the beautiful things they bought and sold. But this is all now a thing of the past. The day of the harlot's judgment has come, and now they can only think nostalgically about a past that will never come again.

<span id="page-709-3"></span><span id="page-709-1"></span>18:15 Like the kings (vv. 9–10), the merchants wail and weep over Babylon's downfall. They do not want to get too close, being anxious lest the judgment on Babylon come to their door as well. And yet they know Babylon's fate is inextricably tied to their own, for their wealth came from the harlot. Without her it will not be renewed.

<span id="page-709-4"></span>18:16–17a The merchants cry out in anguish as they see the judgment meted out on the city formerly decked with beauty. It was a seductive harlot, wearing stunning clothing and beautiful gold, jewels, and pearls. Yet now it has been unmasked by the judgment of God as a wicked witch, a notorious prostitute, a woman without honor. Her reign of beauty and glory has collapsed in a moment, and the true nature of the harlot has been revealed.

<span id="page-709-5"></span>18:17b–19 The lament is now voiced by sea captains, sailors, and all those who work in and profit from the maritime industry. They too rue what has happened to Babylon, and yet they stand far away so as to avoid the same fate. John again picks up the judgment of Tyre and the lament of sailors over the destruction of the city that enriched so many. A longer citation from Ezekiel's lamentation over Tyre seems fitting. Here Ezekiel records the response of those who worked the sea, upon hearing of Tyre's downfall:

<span id="page-709-0"></span> They cast dust on their heads and wallow in ashes; they make themselves bald for you and put sackcloth on their waist, and they weep over you in bitterness of soul, with bitter mourning. In their wailing they raise a lamentation for you and lament over you: "Who is like Tyre, like one destroyed in the midst of the sea? When your wares came from the seas, you satisfied many peoples; with your abundant wealth and merchandise you enriched the kings of the earth. Now you are wrecked by the seas, in the depths of the waters; your merchandise and all your crew in your midst have sunk with you." (Ezek. 27:30b–34)

John combines in his vision the judgments of Babylon and Tyre, both of which forecast the eschatological judgment of the city of man. In seeing the destruction of the harlot, the uniqueness of the city pierces the hearts of seafarers, who exclaim that no other city is comparable to the city being destroyed. Actually, there is a greater city, the new Jerusalem, coming down from heaven, but those who love Babylon fail to see that more excellent city. Those who work the sea have fallen in love with the harlot, and their lives are entwined with hers. Hence the judgment of the harlot spells the doom of their own economic enterprises, and the desolation of the harlot means their livelihood has come to an end (cf. Isa. 34:10; Ezek. 26:19).

#### <span id="page-710-0"></span>*Response*

God does not oppose prosperity and riches per se, but in a world where the rich often act unjustly and oppress and enslave others to advance themselves, many wonder if there is any justice. John proclaims there is a day coming when the glittering beauty of those who have unjustly enriched themselves will be defaced. The dazzling woman with expensive jewels and stunning clothing will be unmasked as a prostitute. Those who crawled into bed with her will face the same judgment. We will see, then, the upside-down kingdom: those who belong to the Lord will be exalted, while those who rejected him will be humiliated. The reversal will happen quickly and will shock and astonish those who have given their allegiance to the city of man. They will be filled with grief as they see everything they have given their lives to slipping away. John's message for his churches and for us is not to be lured and enticed by the harlot. Her charms and beauty and riches beckon us, but her joys are short-lived, and her time of judgment is coming.

### <span id="page-710-1"></span>REVELATION 18:20–19:5

#### **<sup>20</sup>** "Rejoice over her, O heaven, and you saints and apostles and prophets,

for God has given judgment for you against her!"

**<sup>21</sup>**Then a mighty angel took up a stone like a great millstone and threw it into the sea, saying,

"So will Babylon the great city be thrown down with violence, and will be found no more;

**<sup>22</sup>** and the sound of harpists and musicians, of flute players and trumpeters, will be heard in you no more,

and a craftsman of any craft

will be found in you no more,

 and the sound of the mill will be heard in you no more,

**<sup>23</sup>** and the light of a lamp will shine in you no more, and the voice of bridegroom and bride will be heard in you no more,

 for your merchants were the great ones of the earth, and all nations were deceived by your sorcery.

**<sup>24</sup>** And in her was found the blood of prophets and of saints, and of all who have been slain on earth."

19 After this I heard what seemed to be the loud voice of a great multitude in heaven, crying out,

"Hallelujah! Salvation and glory and power belong to our God, **<sup>2</sup>** for his judgments are true and just; for he has judged the great prostitute who corrupted the earth with her immorality, and has avenged on her the blood of his servants."

**<sup>3</sup>**Once more they cried out,

"Hallelujah! The smoke from her goes up forever and ever."

**<sup>4</sup>**And the twenty-four elders and the four living creatures fell down and worshiped God who was seated on the throne, saying, "Amen. Hallelujah!" **<sup>5</sup>**And from the throne came a voice saying,

"Praise our God, all you his servants, you who fear him, small and great."

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-711-5"></span><span id="page-711-4"></span><span id="page-711-3"></span><span id="page-711-2"></span><span id="page-711-1"></span><span id="page-711-0"></span>The world laments and grieves over Babylon's demise, but heaven, saints, and apostles rejoice. Words of joy and praise help us structure and delimit the text. First, heaven, saints, apostles, and prophets rejoice over Babylon's judgment (Rev. 18:20). The world will not go on as it has for centuries: no more concerts, no more craftsmen, no more production of food, no more weddings, no more selling (18:21–23). The judgment descends on account of the merchants' sorcery and the harlot's shedding of the blood of God's people (18:23–24). Second, a loud "Hallelujah" resounds, for God's salvation and power have appeared, and he has judged the one who has corrupted the earth and killed the saints (19:1–2). Third, two more "Hallelujahs" are uttered and God is worshiped when saints and angels see the smoke of Babylon rising forever (19:3–4). Fourth, a voice from God's throne summons God's servants to praise him (19:5).

#### *Section Outline*

- VIII. The Judgment of Babylon and the Wedding of the Bride
	- (17:1–19:10) . . .
	- D. Rejoicing over Babylon's Fall (18:20–19:5)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-712-9"></span>18:20 The contrast between people of the world and saints could not be more dramatic. The former wail and weep and grieve over the desolation of Babylon, but the latter rejoice. The call to rejoice begins in heaven, and the saints, apostles, and (presumably OT) prophets are summoned to rejoice as well, for God has judged Babylon. John picks up and applies the words of Jeremiah: "The heavens and the earth, and all that is in them, shall sing for joy over Babylon, for the destroyers shall come against them out of the north, declares the Lord" (Jer. 51:48; cf. Deut. 32:43). Believers are to pray and long for the salvation of all people as long as life lasts, but they also pray for God's kingdom to come and his will to be done (Matt. 6:10). When God judges the wicked, believers rejoice because they see God's justice vindicated.

<span id="page-712-10"></span><span id="page-712-8"></span><span id="page-712-0"></span>18:21 The judgment of Babylon is now depicted in apocalyptic terms, as if a mighty angel threw a millstone into the sea. Again the words of Jeremiah about Babylon are applied in John's account of his vision: "When you finish reading this book, tie a stone to it and cast it into the midst of the Euphrates, and say, 'Thus shall Babylon sink, to rise no more, because of the disaster that I am bringing upon her, and they shall become exhausted'" (Jer. 51:63–64). Rome, likewise, will be drowned in the sea, so to speak, never to resurface (cf. Ezek. 26:12).

<span id="page-712-11"></span><span id="page-712-7"></span><span id="page-712-6"></span><span id="page-712-4"></span><span id="page-712-3"></span><span id="page-712-1"></span>18:22–23 The ordinary actions of human society have come to an end (cf. Jer. 7:34; 16:9; 25:10; 33:11). In a bustling city, music is played in all kinds of venues, but now the harp, flute, and trumpet have grown quiet (cf. Isa. 24:8; Ezek. 26:13). Craftsmen improve the quality of life with their inventiveness, creativity, and skill, but when disaster strikes their work comes to an end. So too, the mill ceases production. The lights that kept the city stirring and bustling at night have been extinguished. Indeed, all joy has vanished, for the pristine joy of bride and bridegroom is no more. The day of judgment has come, for although the merchants of Rome were renowned, they deluded the nations with their sorcery. At its heart the city was anti-god, having rejected his authority to turn instead to false gods (cf. Isa. 47:9; Nah. 3:4).

<span id="page-712-12"></span><span id="page-712-5"></span><span id="page-712-2"></span>18:24 The judgment of murderous Babylon is warranted, for she put to death both saints and prophets (6:10; 16:6; 17:6; 19:2; cf. Jer. 51:49). Her opposition to the people of God reflects her rejection of God's rule, manifested in putting to death those opposing the great harlot. The rest of the slain in this verse may refer to the death of other people, even unbelievers. Babylon could abide no one, believer or unbeliever, who stood in her path or resisted her ways. She insisted on totalitarian devotion and worship and was enraged to the point of shedding the blood of those refusing to participate in her idolatries.
