<span id="page-713-6"></span>19:1 The judgment of the great Babylon, the mother of harlots, is done. John hears the voice of a great multitude in heaven crying out "Hallelujah!" and ascribing salvation, glory, and power to God. Why does John refer to salvation, when the judgment of the harlot is the theme? Probably because the people of God have been saved from the evil witch, the monster who tormented them relentlessly. God has shown himself glorious and powerful by delivering his people and judging their great enemy.

<span id="page-713-7"></span><span id="page-713-3"></span>19:2 Is the "Hallelujah!" of verse 1 warranted? Should God be praised for judging Babylon? Is such praise actually a distorted and twisted response to God's judgments? Verse 2 answers this question by giving us a reason "for" (*hoti* ) the harlot's condemnation. John informs us that God's judgments are "true and just." The judgment is not arbitrary or unfair (cf. 15:3; 16:7). Quite the contrary: God's judgment of Babylon accords with justice and is the right thing to do. In other words, God's justice would be called into question if he did *not* judge Babylon. The saints rejoice because they see that God has put everything right. The regime of the great harlot has been destroyed forever, and the world can enjoy the peace and harmony God intended for it from the outset. The judgment of the harlot is fitting because of her harmful impact on the earth. She corrupted it with her immorality. Again, the focus is not on sexual sin, though it is likely included. Sexual immorality here, as we have seen so often in Revelation, signifies the idolatry of Babylon and her refusal to worship the one true God. Babylon's passion is to see all people everywhere worship the beast. The judgment is warranted also because of the martyrdom of God's servants. God has "avenged" their blood (cf. Deut. 32:43; 2 Kings 9:7). "Avenged" does not signify a crazed and unrestrained vengeance. Instead it signifies the just punishment deserved by those who have murdered the people of God.

<span id="page-713-8"></span><span id="page-713-0"></span>19:3 The contrast between the response of the world and the saints continues, for again believers voice a loud "Hallelujah." Their praise comes as they see the smoke of Babylon rising forever. They are full of praise when they see the justice and rightness of God's judgment of their great enemy. The judgment is permanent and irreversible, for the smoke of Babylon ascends forever (cf. Isa. 34:10; Rev. 14:11; 18:9, 18). Babylon will never rise again; her reign is over!

<span id="page-713-9"></span><span id="page-713-5"></span><span id="page-713-2"></span><span id="page-713-1"></span>19:4 The worship is not limited to human beings. The angelic beings, both the twenty-four elders and the four living creatures that have played such a prominent role in Revelation, reprise their role described in chapters 4–5. They bow in worship to the God seated on the throne, to the sovereign God who exercises his rule and justice in condemning and judging the harlot for her evil. They do not shrink back from God for his judgment but give him praise. They affirm what he has done by exclaiming "Amen" and delight in it by crying, "Hallelujah."

<span id="page-713-10"></span><span id="page-713-4"></span>19:5 A voice comes from the throne, a phenomenon we see on two other occasions in Revelation (16:17; 21:3). Once again there is a call to praise God, presumably again for his saving intervention. In judging Babylon, God also saves his people and delivers them from his enemies. Such a motif is regularly present in the OT. When God routs <span id="page-714-0"></span>his enemies, be they Egypt, Assyria, or Babylon, he also saves his people. Thus all of God's servants, those who fear and honor him, whether insignificant or influential in the world's eyes, are summoned to praise God (cf. Pss. 22:23; 113:1; 134:1; 135:1).

#### *Response*

The loud hallelujahs and praise from the people of God when Babylon is judged may seem strange and even anti-Christian. How should we apply this as Christians today? First, the praise comes after the judgment, not before. Why does this matter? Because as long as unbelievers are alive, we are to long and pray for their salvation. But on the last day, after history has concluded, we will see that the judgment of God is right and true and just. None of us will question whether those who are in hell should be there, for then we will see the perfect rightness and goodness of God's judgment. Second, we should underscore that God's judgment is just and righteous. The punishment of Babylon is akin to the destruction of the Nazis under Hitler. When an evil empire that has spread terror and torment is destroyed, people rejoice. Third, the judgment of the wicked means the deliverance of the righteous. Saints praise God at the destruction of Babylon because her demise means relief and freedom for the saints.

## <span id="page-714-1"></span>REVELATION 19:6–10

**<sup>6</sup>**Then I heard what seemed to be the voice of a great multitude, like the roar of many waters and like the sound of mighty peals of thunder, crying out,

"Hallelujah! For the Lord our God the Almighty reigns.

- **<sup>7</sup>** Let us rejoice and exult and give him the glory, for the marriage of the Lamb has come,
- and his Bride has made herself ready; **<sup>8</sup>** it was granted her to clothe herself
- with fine linen, bright and pure"—

for the fine linen is the righteous deeds of the saints.

**<sup>9</sup>**And the angel said*<sup>1</sup>* to me, "Write this: Blessed are those who are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb." And he said to me, "These are the true words of God." **10**Then I fell down at his feet to worship him, but he said to me, "You must not do that! I am a fellow servant with you and your brothers who hold to the testimony of Jesus. Worship God." For the testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-715-10"></span><span id="page-715-8"></span>This passage presents a contrast of two women and two cities: the harlot—Babylon—and the bride of the Lamb—the new Jerusalem. The saints are full of praise for the judgment of the harlot, and in these verses they praise God's reign and the marriage of the Lamb. In verse 6 the multitude with a mighty roar cries out, "Hallelujah," because God has begun to reign. In verse 7 the commencement of God's rule is seen from another perspective. There is a call to rejoice and glorify God because the marriage of the Lamb is at hand and the bride is ready for the wedding. The bride's readiness means she wears proper clothing: beautiful linen that is pure, representing the righteous deeds of the saints (v. 8). Then John steps back to pronounce a blessing on those who are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb (v. 9). The wonder and glory of the marriage and feast propel John to worship at the feet of the angel who disclosed such things to him (v. 10). But John is forbidden to worship the angel and must worship only God, for the angel is not a divine being but a fellow servant. The text ends with a puzzling and provocative saying about the testimony of Jesus being the spirit of prophecy. Perhaps John means that the essence of prophecy centers on the testimony about and given by Jesus Christ.

#### <span id="page-715-12"></span><span id="page-715-11"></span>*Section Outline*

- VIII. The Judgment of Babylon and the Wedding of the Bride
	- (17:1–19:10) . . .
	- E. Rejoicing over the Marriage of the Lamb (19:6–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-715-6"></span><span id="page-715-0"></span>19:6 On the one hand there is a call to joy and praise because of the judgment of Babylon. But there is also thunderous praise because the kingdom has come—God has begun to reign (cf. 1 Chron. 16:31; Pss. 93:1; 97:1; 99:1; 118:24; Zech. 14:9; Rev. 11:15, 17). The reign of God cannot, of course, be separated from the judgment of Babylon. The sound—like a multitude, the roar of a waterfall, and peals of thunder—demonstrates we have arrived at the climax of history (cf. Dan. 10:6; Rev. 1:15; 14:2). The awesome joy is comparable to the roar of the crowd in a stadium today.

<span id="page-715-9"></span><span id="page-715-7"></span><span id="page-715-5"></span><span id="page-715-4"></span><span id="page-715-3"></span><span id="page-715-2"></span><span id="page-715-1"></span>19:7 Believers are told to rejoice and exult and glorify God because the wedding of the Lamb is at hand (cf. Isa. 61:10). One of the remarkable features of this section is the irrepressible gladness bursting through the text. It is hard to imagine anything more joyful than a wedding, and this is the wedding of all weddings. Indeed, all other marriages are modeled after Christ's relationship with the church (Eph. 5:22–33, esp. v. 32). We have been prepared for this, for Yahweh's relationship to Israel is also explained in terms of bride and groom (e.g., Isa. 49:18; 50:1; 54:5; 62:4–5; Jer. 2:2, 32; 3:20; Ezekiel 16; Hos. 1:1–3:5). The wedding of the Lamb represents the consummation of God's purpose in history, signifying his desire to be in relationship with human beings. The bride must be ready to marry the Lamb, as is further explained in the next verse.

<span id="page-716-10"></span><span id="page-716-9"></span><span id="page-716-4"></span><span id="page-716-3"></span><span id="page-716-1"></span><span id="page-716-0"></span>19:8 The bride is prepared for her wedding to the Lamb, wearing the proper clothing (cf. Isa. 61:10). Her adornment consists of "fine linen, bright and pure." In Ezekiel we read of the Lord caring for Jerusalem and adorning her with linen and silk (Ezek. 16:10, 13), but the context there demonstrates that she was an unworthy wife. Another anticipation of the wedding scene in Revelation is the marriage of the Davidic king to a foreign bride in Psalm 45, in which the bride approaches the king in beautiful robes (Ps. 45:13–14). Two things are said about the bride's adornment here in Revelation 19. First, the fine linen is given to her by God. The goodness of the bride is a gift of God, not a result of the inherent virtue or wealth of the bride. Second, the adornment of the bride stands for the goodness actualized in her life. The fine linen of the bride in Revelation, John explains, represents the "righteous deeds of the saints." Here the bride's apparel stands in contrast to the fine linen of Babylon (18:16), which signified Babylon's luxury and debauchery. The bride is ready because she has lived a holy life, has done what is pleasing to God, has not followed the pathway carved out by Babylon. Still, the righteous deeds of the bride are the result of God's work in her life.

<span id="page-716-8"></span><span id="page-716-7"></span><span id="page-716-6"></span>19:9 One of the seven blessings is now written down for posterity (cf. comment on 1:3) so that it will not be forgotten. Those who are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb are blessed by God (cf. Luke 14:15). No feast compares to this feast, and the joy at this supper is incomparable to any joy on earth. We see anticipation of this feast in the messianic feast promised in Isaiah, which also includes the hope of the resurrection:

 On this mountain the Lord of hosts will make for all peoples a feast of rich food, a feast of well-aged wine, of rich food full of marrow, of aged wine well refined. And he will swallow up on this mountain the covering that is cast over all peoples, the veil that is spread over all nations. He will swallow up death forever; and the Lord God will wipe away tears from all faces. (Isa. 25:6–8; cf. also Matt. 8:11–12; Mark 14:25; Luke 13:28–29)

<span id="page-716-14"></span><span id="page-716-13"></span><span id="page-716-5"></span><span id="page-716-2"></span>The angel also affirms that his words are the true words of God (cf. Rev. 21:5; 22:6). The promises are so great and stunning and so different from life on earth, with its sorrows and sufferings, that we need to be assured they are true; they will become a reality.

<span id="page-716-15"></span><span id="page-716-12"></span><span id="page-716-11"></span>19:10 The words and appearance of the "angel" (cf. v. 9) are striking, and John responds by falling on his face in worship before the angel (cf. 22:8). But the angel rebuffs John, saying that he is merely a fellow servant of John and of those who subscribe to the testimony of Jesus. The angel commands John to worship God alone. The starkness and brevity of the command to "Worship God" reminds us of the God-centered vision of the book of Revelation. God is the center and circumference of John's visions, but the next words demonstrate that the centrality of God also includes the preeminence of Jesus. The command to worship God does not exclude the worship of Jesus, as the entire book teaches repeatedly. Hence, we have the fascinating words that follow, stating that "the testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy." The saying is tantalizingly ambiguous and has provoked a number of different interpretations. John probably means that Spirit-inspired prophecy focuses on the testimony given by and about Jesus Christ. Christians are to worship God and be God-centered, but prophecy also points us to the centrality of Jesus and his majesty and greatness.

#### *Response*

The coming joy, promised in both the Lamb's marriage to the bride and his marriage supper, is more than we can digest. Our passions and desires for God are weak, and John wants us to imagine the future when our delight in God is maximized. Every joy on this earth, every wedding and every feast, points us to the most sublime wedding, the most exquisite feast. We are to prepare ourselves by following Jesus so we can enjoy this coming wedding feast. Then our hearts will sing as they never have before, and we will laugh and rejoice as never before. It will be a laughter and joy unstained by any sin or sorrow or worry. Death will be a distant memory, and we will rejoice forever.

### <span id="page-717-0"></span>REVELATION 19:11–21

**11**Then I saw heaven opened, and behold, a white horse! The one sitting on it is called Faithful and True, and in righteousness he judges and makes war. **12**His eyes are like a flame of fire, and on his head are many diadems, and he has a name written that no one knows but himself. **13**He is clothed in a robe dipped in*<sup>1</sup>* blood, and the name by which he is called is The Word of God. **14**And the armies of heaven, arrayed in fine linen, white and pure, were following him on white horses. **15**From his mouth comes a sharp sword with which to strike down the nations, and he will rule*<sup>2</sup>* them with a rod of iron. He will tread the winepress of the fury of the wrath of God the Almighty. **16**On his robe and on his thigh he has a name written, King of kings and Lord of lords.

**<sup>17</sup>**Then I saw an angel standing in the sun, and with a loud voice he called to all the birds that fly directly overhead, "Come, gather for the great supper of God, **<sup>18</sup>** to eat the flesh of kings, the flesh of captains, the flesh of mighty men, the flesh of horses and their riders, and the flesh of all men, both free and slave,*<sup>3</sup>* both small and great." **19**And I saw the beast and the kings of the earth with their armies gathered to make war against him who was sitting on the horse and against his army. **20**And the beast was captured, and with it the false prophet who in its presence*<sup>4</sup>* had done

the signs by which he deceived those who had received the mark of the beast and those who worshiped its image. These two were thrown alive into the lake of fire that burns with sulfur. **21**And the rest were slain by the sword that came from the mouth of him who was sitting on the horse, and all the birds were gorged with their flesh.

1Some manuscripts *sprinkled with* 2Greek *shepherd* 3For the contextual rendering of the Greek word *doulos*, see ESV Preface 4Or *on its behalf*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-718-5"></span><span id="page-718-4"></span><span id="page-718-3"></span>The judgment of Babylon and the marriage supper of the Lamb are the end of history. John cycles back, shakes the kaleidoscope, and gives us another picture of the end. Postmillennialists see the spread of the gospel throughout history in this text, but the imagery used here and the parallels with other texts referring to the end (Rev. 16:14, 16; 17:14) indicate this is a dramatic picture of the second coming of Jesus Christ. Heaven opens, and Jesus is seated on a white horse—the one who is faithful and true is coming to wage the final battle (19:11). His eyes see all, nothing is hidden from him, and the diadems on his head signify his sovereign rule (v. 12). No one knows his name, meaning no one rules or controls him. His robe is dipped in blood, signifying he is coming for judgment, and he is called the Word of God, for he is God's message to humanity (v. 13). As Jesus comes, the armies of heaven follow him, clothed in white garments and riding on white horses (v. 14). Jesus is coming in judgment, for he has a sword to pierce his adversaries and will rule them with an iron rod and tread them in the winepress of God's wrath (v. 15). On his robe and thigh are inscribed "King of kings and Lord of lords" (v. 16). No opponent can conquer him.

<span id="page-718-12"></span><span id="page-718-11"></span><span id="page-718-10"></span><span id="page-718-9"></span><span id="page-718-8"></span><span id="page-718-7"></span><span id="page-718-6"></span>An angel appears and invites birds to a great sacrifice of human flesh (vv. 17– 18). The kings of the earth and the beast array themselves against Jesus, seated on the white horse, and his army (v. 19). The battle, however, is anticlimactic: Jesus seizes the beast and false prophet and throws them into the lake of fire (v. 20)! The remainder of their army is killed with the sword of his mouth, and the birds gorge themselves on their flesh (v. 21).

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-718-13"></span>IX. The Triumph of God in Christ (19:11–20:15)
	- A. Defeat of the Beast, the False Prophet, and Their Adherents (19:11–21)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-718-2"></span><span id="page-718-1"></span><span id="page-718-0"></span>19:11 The end has arrived with the judgment of Babylon and the marriage of the Lamb, but John recapitulates and gives us another picture of the final judgment. Heaven opens to signal a revelation from God (cf. Ezek. 1:1; Acts 10:11; Rev. 4:1). John sees a white horse (cf. Rev. 6:2), and the one sitting upon it, Jesus Christ, is identified as the one who is faithful and true (cf. 1:5; 3:7). The white horse points <span id="page-719-5"></span><span id="page-719-4"></span>to Jesus' rule and majesty as a great warrior. He is faithful to God and his promises, and believers can count on him to vindicate them and vindicate the truth. Jesus is coming on his horse for war. Many wars are unjust: a ruler rampages and ravages for selfish gain. But Jesus judges and makes war righteously (cf. Pss. 9:8; 96:13; 98:9), fulfilling the vision of the Messiah in Psalm 72 and Isaiah 11 (Ps. 72:2; Isa. 11:4). Righteous judgment includes both punishment and salvation; Jesus judges and wages war for righteous and good purposes, so that evil is removed from the earth and the shalom promised for creation is established.

<span id="page-719-13"></span><span id="page-719-12"></span><span id="page-719-8"></span><span id="page-719-7"></span><span id="page-719-6"></span>19:12 How do we know Jesus judges and wages war righteously? Because his eyes are like a flame of fire (cf. 1:14; 2:18)—he sees beneath the surface, and hence his judgment is not superficial or mistaken. As Isaiah 11:3 says about the branch from David, "He shall not judge by what his eyes see, or decide disputes by what his ears hear." His judgment accords with the truth, with the way things really are. He is also able to judge and triumph because of his kingly rule and strength; the "many diadems" on his head signify sovereign rule and authority. He not only sees what is right; he has the strength to enforce the right as sovereign ruler. The rider on the white horse is sovereign, for the name inscribed on him is known only by himself (cf. Prov. 30:4). In the ancient world, to know another person's name was to exercise control over that person. Thus, the one who wrestled with Jacob did not disclose his name to Jacob (Gen. 32:29). Similarly, the angel of the Lord did not tell Samson's parents his name, saying only that it was wonderful (Judg. 13:18). No one is able to control or manipulate the one on the white horse. Yet it is no contradiction that Jesus is also identified as having the names "King of kings and Lord of lords" (Rev. 19:16) and "The Word of God" (v. 13), for there is a sense in which we know Jesus and a sense in which he is hidden from us. He is both immanent and transcendent, near to us and hidden from us. We truly know God through Jesus Christ, but we do not know him exhaustively or fully.

<span id="page-719-15"></span><span id="page-719-14"></span><span id="page-719-11"></span><span id="page-719-10"></span><span id="page-719-9"></span><span id="page-719-3"></span><span id="page-719-2"></span><span id="page-719-1"></span><span id="page-719-0"></span>19:13 The robe dipped in blood might suggest to some the atoning blood of Christ, but the context here is the second coming of Christ to judge the wicked. This fits with the OT background of Yahweh's garments spattered with blood in the judgment of Edom: "Why is your apparel red, and your garments like his who treads in the winepress? 'I have trodden the winepress alone, and from the peoples no one was with me; I trod them in my anger and trampled them in my wrath; their lifeblood spattered on my garments, and stained all my apparel'" (Isa. 63:2–3). The day is characterized as the "day of vengeance" for Edom but the "year of redemption" for Israel (Isa. 63:4). Edom in the OT often stands for all the kingdoms of the world (cf. Isaiah 34), and John's appropriation of that theme is quite fitting. The judgment of the wicked, which stains Christ's garment with blood, constitutes vengeance for the wicked, but at the same time signals redemption and deliverance for the people of God. Jesus is coming as the divine warrior to destroy his enemies and deliver his people (cf. Exodus 15; Deuteronomy 33; Judges 5; Habakkuk 3).

<span id="page-720-9"></span><span id="page-720-2"></span>Jesus is also called "The Word of God," which echoes John 1:1 while adding the words "of God." God's word is effective and powerful, unleashing his judgment upon the world (cf. *Wisd. Sol.* 18:15–16). We read in Psalm 33:6, "By the word of the Lord the heavens were made." Isaiah says that God's word does not "return to me empty, but it shall accomplish that which I purpose, and shall succeed in the thing for which I sent it" (Isa. 55:11). Jesus himself is God's word, God's message, to the world, expressing his message of both judgment and salvation.

<span id="page-720-13"></span><span id="page-720-11"></span><span id="page-720-6"></span><span id="page-720-3"></span>19:14 The rider of the white horse is not alone but is accompanied by the armies of heaven wearing beautiful linen, white and pure, signifying righteousness and holiness (cf. 3:4; 7:9; 19:8). The army could consist of believers (17:14) or angels (Ps. 68:17; Dan. 7:10; Zech. 14:5; Matt. 16:27; Mark 8:38; Luke 9:26); perhaps both are included. They also ride white horses, designating goodness and purity. Although the picture of the battle here need not be literal, the point is clear: the forces of good are arrayed against the forces of evil.

<span id="page-720-14"></span><span id="page-720-10"></span><span id="page-720-5"></span><span id="page-720-4"></span>19:15 The three descriptions found in this verse provide further evidence that Jesus is coming for judgment. First, from his mouth comes a sharp sword to strike the nations. The sharp sword stands for the word issuing from his mouth, showing the inherent power and effectiveness of Jesus' words (cf. 1:16; 2:12). Isaiah 11:4 speaks similarly of the branch of David (cf. also Isa. 49:2): "He shall strike the earth with the rod of his mouth, and with the breath of his lips he shall kill the wicked." We read in 2 Thessalonians 2:8 that Jesus will slay the man of lawlessness "with the breath of his mouth." Second, Jesus rules over the nations with an iron rod (cf. Rev. 2:27; 12:5). Such rule fulfills the prophecy of Psalm 2, where God promises that the anointed Son of David, installed as king, will break his opponents with a rod of iron (Ps. 2:9; cf. *Psalms of Solomon* 17:23–24). Third, Jesus treads the winepress of God's wrath (cf. Rev. 14:20). Again, the image is rooted in the OT, where God treads out the winepress in his wrath (cf. Isa. 63:2–3; Lam. 1:15; Joel 3:13). All three images indicate the last judgment is at hand.

<span id="page-720-15"></span><span id="page-720-12"></span><span id="page-720-7"></span><span id="page-720-1"></span><span id="page-720-0"></span>19:16 The one who judges has a name inscribed on his robe and thigh: "King of kings and Lord of lords" (cf. comment on 17:14). Jesus has the authority and power to judge because he is the sovereign Lord over every other king and ruler. No one can ultimately frustrate his will or purposes. Those who oppose him will experience his wrath.

<span id="page-720-16"></span><span id="page-720-8"></span>19:17 John then sees an angel standing in the sun, sheathed with its glory and standing over the earth. In a loud voice the angel summons birds to gather for a great supper prepared for them by God. The vision draws on the judgment of Gog and Magog in Ezekiel 38–39, in which birds are invited to gather for a sacrificial feast and eat the flesh and drink the blood of Israel's enemies:

Speak to the birds of every sort and to all beasts of the field: "Assemble and come, gather from all around to the sacrificial feast that I am preparing

for you, a great sacrificial feast on the mountains of Israel, and you shall eat flesh and drink blood. You shall eat the flesh of the mighty, and drink the blood of the princes of the earth—of rams, of lambs, and of he-goats, of bulls, all of them fat beasts of Bashan. And you shall eat fat till you are filled, and drink blood till you are drunk, at the sacrificial feast that I am preparing for you." (Ezek. 39:17–19; cf. also Ezek. 39:4; Isa. 34:6; Jer. 46:10)

<span id="page-721-15"></span><span id="page-721-2"></span>In Ezekiel the judgment is visited upon the enemies of Israel as the last judgment in history, paralleled closely by the angel's summons here in Revelation 19.

<span id="page-721-16"></span><span id="page-721-9"></span><span id="page-721-4"></span><span id="page-721-3"></span>19:18 As we see in Ezekiel 39, the birds are invited to gorge themselves on the flesh of human beings and horses (Ezek. 39:18, 20): kings, captains, mighty men, horses and their riders, and the remainder of mankind (cf. Rev. 6:15). The picture of human flesh being consumed by birds is a grisly way of depicting the destruction of those who reject Jesus Christ. In the ancient world, to remain unburied was a great dishonor, and such is the fate of those who reject Jesus Christ.

<span id="page-721-17"></span><span id="page-721-14"></span><span id="page-721-5"></span>19:19 John looks in his vision and sees the enemies of Christ gathered to wage war against him. The beast, the kings aligned with him (cf. Rev. 17:12–14), and their armies are poised to fight the one riding on the white horse and his armies. Such a battle fulfills the words of Zechariah 14:2, "I will gather all the nations against Jerusalem to battle." The rage against the Lord and his Christ spoken of in Psalm 2:2 comes to a climax here, and the last battle ( *polemos*) noted in Revelation 16:14 is about to occur. What animates the beast and his kings is a hatred of the Christ.

<span id="page-721-18"></span><span id="page-721-13"></span><span id="page-721-8"></span><span id="page-721-1"></span><span id="page-721-0"></span>19:20 The armies are facing one another and poised to fight, but the battle turns out to be ridiculously easy. Jesus seizes the beast and false prophet and casts them alive (cf. Num. 16:33) into the lake of fire and sulfur (cf. Dan. 7:11). As 2 Thessalonians 2:8 says, the Lord "will kill [the man of lawlessness] with the breath of his mouth and bring [him] to nothing by the appearance of his coming." The power and the glory of the beast and the false prophet, though they seem remarkable, are no match for Jesus Christ.

<span id="page-721-12"></span><span id="page-721-10"></span>The false prophet (cf. Rev. 16:13; 20:10) is the same figure as the second beast in 13:11–18, but the designation "false prophet" emphasizes his deluding power via signs and wonders and errant prophecies. In fact, John pauses here to note his signs and how they deceived those who received the mark of the beast and worshiped his image (cf. 13:13–15). This suggests that those led astray *desired* to be misled.

<span id="page-721-20"></span><span id="page-721-19"></span><span id="page-721-11"></span><span id="page-721-7"></span><span id="page-721-6"></span>John encourages his audience to persevere to the end by portraying the final fate of the beast and the false prophet. The lake of fire is mentioned for the first time here, and it reappears several times in the concluding chapters (20:10, 14, 15) as a place of torment identified as the second death. The image of fire for final punishment is used elsewhere in the NT as well (Matt. 5:22; 13:40; 18:8–9; 25:41; Mark 9:43, 48; Heb. 10:27; Jude 7). Those who die the second death will never come to life, and thus all those who side with the beast and false prophet will regret forever that they were co-opted by them.

<span id="page-722-4"></span><span id="page-722-3"></span><span id="page-722-2"></span><span id="page-722-0"></span>19:21 If the beast and false prophet are so easily disposed of, the rest of the armies are no problem. They are killed by the sword coming out of the mouth of the majestic warrior, Jesus, who sits on his white horse. In other words, his word is powerful and effective enough to wipe out his enemies (cf. 1:16; 2:12, 16; 19:5; cf. also Isa. 11:4; 49:2). It leaves carnage on the battlefield, and birds satisfy themselves with the flesh of those who are judged (cf. comment on Rev. 19:17 and Jer. 7:33; 16:4; 19:7; 34:20). The picture of the last judgment is apocalyptic; it is not a transcript of how the final judgment will play out. Nor is it necessary to think that birds will literally feast on human flesh. The language is a vivid way of speaking of the final judgment and eternal destruction of those opposing Jesus Christ.

#### <span id="page-722-1"></span>*Response*

Sometimes it seems as if evil will triumph forever, but such an impression does not accord with reality. Jesus is coming again, and the rulers and people opposed to him will be destroyed. Evil is no illusion, but goodness is always stronger and has an enduring permanence that evil cannot match. God has allowed evil to do its worst for many millennia, but he will not tolerate it forever. When Jesus returns, we will see the last battle. But the battle is remarkably easy, for Jesus simply speaks the word and his enemies are routed and thrown into the lake of fire. We all want to be on the side of the victors. If we belong to Jesus, we are assured of ultimate victory.

### <span id="page-722-5"></span>REVELATION 20:1–6

20 Then I saw an angel coming down from heaven, holding in his hand the key to the bottomless pit*<sup>1</sup>* and a great chain. **2**And he seized the dragon, that ancient serpent, who is the devil and Satan, and bound him for a thousand years, **<sup>3</sup>** and threw him into the pit, and shut it and sealed it over him, so that he might not deceive the nations any longer, until the thousand years were ended. After that he must be released for a little while.

**<sup>4</sup>**Then I saw thrones, and seated on them were those to whom the authority to judge was committed. Also I saw the souls of those who had been beheaded for the testimony of Jesus and for the word of God, and those who had not worshiped the beast or its image and had not received its mark on their foreheads or their hands. They came to life and reigned with Christ for a thousand years. **5**The rest of the dead did not come to life until the thousand years were ended. This is the first resurrection.

**<sup>6</sup>**Blessed and holy is the one who shares in the first resurrection! Over such the second death has no power, but they will be priests of God and of Christ, and they will reign with him for a thousand years.

1Greek *the abyss*; also verse 3

#### *Section Overview*

Here we have the famous millennial text, certainly the most debated text in the book of Revelation.28 There are very good arguments for both the premillennial and the amillennial views. Both views will be explained, although a slight preference will be given to the amillennial view.

<span id="page-723-4"></span><span id="page-723-3"></span><span id="page-723-2"></span>The text begins with an angel descending from heaven with a key to the abyss and a chain in his hand (Rev. 20:1). He seizes Satan and binds him in the pit for a thousand years (v. 2). The pit is closed and locked so that Satan cannot deceive the nations, but near the end of the thousand years he is released for a short time (v. 3). John then sees people seated on thrones (v. 4a). Those on the thrones have authority to judge. John tells us that those on the thrones are martyrs: all who refused to worship the beast come to life and reign with Christ for a thousand years (v. 4b) and participate in the first resurrection (v. 5b), while the rest of the dead do not come to life until the thousand years are over (v. 5a). A blessing is pronounced over those who enjoy the first resurrection, for the second death has no authority over them; they will be priests of God and Christ and will reign with Christ for one thousand years (v. 6).

<span id="page-723-7"></span><span id="page-723-6"></span><span id="page-723-5"></span>This text is the most controversial in the book of Revelation, and interpreters debate the credibility of various millennial views. A brief sketch of the positions advocated should prove helpful. Postmillennialists maintain Christ will return *after*  a long period of blessing on earth, hence the prefix *post*, meaning "after": Christ will come after the millennium. After the millennial reign, the new heaven and earth will arrive. The one thousand years are not literal but signify a long period of time in which the world is transformed by the gospel. Some postmillennialists believe the thousand years begin at an undefined time in history—some point after the resurrection of Jesus. Other postmillennialists believe the thousand years began at the resurrection. The timing of the millennium is not vital for the postmillennial position.

Amillennialism literally means "no millennium," but such a label is not the best descriptor of the position. *Realized* millennialism is better. The thousand years in this view stand for a long period of time and do not designate a literal thousandyear reign. Amillennialists argue that the millennium began with the resurrection of Jesus and will last until the second coming. During this time, deceased believers reign spiritually with Christ in heaven in the intermediate state, awaiting their physical resurrection and the renewal of all things, and Satan is bound in the sense of being bound at the cross while the gospel goes out to the nations (Matt. 12:29).

<span id="page-723-1"></span><span id="page-723-0"></span><sup>28</sup> For texts that function as parallels in some respects, cf. Isaiah 24:21–22; *1 Enoch* 10:4–6, 11–13.

<span id="page-724-2"></span>Other amillennialists think the saints' coming to life refers to regeneration (Eph. 2:6; Col. 3:1) instead of reigning in heaven, and thus there is some diversity within amillennialism concerning what it means to come to life and reign with Christ.

Premillennialists say Christ will literally return to earth *before* the millennium (hence the prefix *pre*) and will reign one thousand years on earth before bringing an end to everything at the end of the millennium. Most premillennialists believe the thousand years designate a literal period of time, but such a view is not necessary for the position, for one could believe in a literal reign of Christ on earth for a long period of time other than exactly one thousand years and still be premillennial. Premillennialists are divided into historic and dispensational premillennialists. Some are called historic premillennialists because they identify themselves with premillennial church fathers, including Papias, Justin Martyr, and Irenaeus. Dispensational premillennialists, who first appeared in the nineteenth century, are distinguished from historic premillennialists by arguing for a secret rapture seven years before Jesus returns to inaugurate the millennium.29 Dispensational premillennialists emphasize the fulfillment of promises to the Jewish people during the millennium.

<span id="page-724-8"></span><span id="page-724-5"></span><span id="page-724-4"></span>I suggest here that the best options are the historic premillennial and amillennial views. The dispensational premillennial view rests on the notion of a rapture seven years before Jesus returns, which is quite unlikely, although space is lacking here to demonstrate why. Suffice it to say that 1 Thessalonians 4:16 does not describe a secret rapture. In addition, in 2 Thessalonians 1–2 the punishment of the wicked, deliverance of the righteous, and gathering of the saints occur at the same time. Furthermore, the notion of promises specially fulfilled for the Jews in the millennium is not even mentioned by John in Revelation 20, nor is this idea found in the rest of the NT. Dispensationalists read their interpretations of OT prophecies into Revelation 20, but their interpretation is flawed, for the NT maintains that Jews and Gentiles are equally members of the people of God (e.g., Eph. 2:11–3:13). The notion of Jews having a special place in the millennium contradicts the NT witness that all believers are children of Abraham (cf. Rom. 4:9–17; Gal. 3:6–9).

<span id="page-724-7"></span><span id="page-724-3"></span><span id="page-724-1"></span><span id="page-724-0"></span>The postmillennial view also fails to convince for a number of reasons, although the notion of a world gradually transformed by the gospel is one all Christians wish were true. But Scripture clearly indicates that evil will intensify before the end (cf. Matt. 24:9–31; 1 Tim. 4:1–3; 2 Tim. 3:1–5). In addition, postmillennialists argue Revelation 19:11–21 refers not to the second coming but to the routing of God's enemies, leading to a long period of peace and prosperity on earth. But in the commentary above I argue that the text refers almost certainly to the second coming. Hence, below, I will focus on the historic premillennial and amillennial readings of the passage. I include both views equally since it is difficult to decipher which view is correct, and readers should appreciate this difficulty.

<span id="page-724-6"></span><sup>29</sup> By this view, the seven years between the rapture and the millennium would be the time of "tribulation," but cf. comment on 7:13–14.

<span id="page-725-3"></span>Still, for the following reasons I tentatively opt for the amillennial view, although I have changed my mind more than once and feel uncertainty as I write. First, nowhere else in Scripture is a thousand-year millennium clearly taught, and a new doctrine should not be founded on an intensely controversial text, especially from an apocalyptic book full of symbolism. Second, we have seen that Revelation is recursive and recapitulatory, coming to the end and then telling the same story again from a fresh perspective. John might be doing the same thing in Revelation 20, telling the story of Revelation 19:11–21 from another perspective. Third, many of the texts allegedly speaking of the millennium in the OT (e.g., Isaiah 60 and Ezekiel 40–48) are not alluded to in Revelation 20. What is even more striking is that these same chapters are copiously alluded to in Revelation 21:1–22:5. In other words, the so-called millennial texts are fulfilled in the new creation! This suggests the promises of a renewed world and new temple in the OT are fulfilled in the new creation, not in a millennium. Some want to say the fulfillment is in both the millennium and the new creation, but it is hard to see how the new temple prophesied in Ezekiel 40–48 is fulfilled in any way in the millennium.

<span id="page-725-5"></span><span id="page-725-2"></span><span id="page-725-1"></span><span id="page-725-0"></span>Fourth, the early church fathers were divided on the millennium. Sometimes it is claimed the earliest fathers were premillennial, but Charles Hill has demonstrated the matter was disputed, and many were amillennialists.30 Hence, we cannot appeal to the early church to find a consensus on the matter. Fifth, the historic premillennial view has difficulty explaining the unglorified people in the millennium, for when Jesus returns at the end of chapter 19, he destroys all his enemies. It is straining to say that some were left on earth who survived Jesus' return. The NT clearly teaches Jesus' return is the day of reward and judgment for all (Matt. 25:31–46). Sixth, in Scripture the final resurrection, final judgment, victory over death, arrival of the new creation, and second coming of Christ are part of a total package. There is no indication in any other text that these great events are separated. Finally, we will see below that the premillennial reading of Revelation 20 has some very good arguments, but the amillennial reading has remarkable strengths too. And since the latter fits best with the rest of the scriptural witness, it should be favored. Unfortunately, clarity will be lacking on this issue until Jesus returns. Fortunately, the central truth is that Jesus is indeed returning!

#### *Section Outline*

- IX. The Triumph of God in Christ (19:11–20:15) . . .
	- B. Reigning with Jesus for a Thousand Years (20:1–6)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-725-4"></span>20:1–2 A new section begins with "Then I saw" (*kai eidon*), a very common phrase in Revelation, occurring thirty-two times. Premillennialists maintain the phrase

<sup>30</sup> Charles E. Hill, *Regnum Caelorum: Patterns of Millennial Thought in Early Christianity,* 2nd ed. (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 2001).

<span id="page-726-15"></span>has chronological significance, but amillennialists say this is not necessarily the case. Given the diversity of usage of the phrase, it is difficult to argue that it clearly points to a new section chronologically. It is quite possible that 20:1–10 describes from another angle the events recorded in 19:11–21, as we have often seen Revelation recapitulate the time of the end.

<span id="page-726-14"></span><span id="page-726-13"></span>One significant problem with the premillennial view is that Jesus had destroyed all unbelievers at the end of chapter 19; thus it is difficult to understand how anyone could enter the millennium with an unglorified body. Why would Satan need to be bound if the armies opposing God were destroyed at the second coming? Historic premillennialists argue the armies in chapter 19 do not represent all people—some were not destroyed at the second coming and thus enter the millennium. However, nowhere else is there any indication that some human beings are not judged at the second coming. Perhaps there is ammunition for the premillennial view in Zechariah 14; there the Lord judges and slays those opposed to him (Zech. 14:12), but some remain who refuse to worship the Lord, and because of their recalcitrance the Lord withholds rain (vv. 17–19).

<span id="page-726-9"></span><span id="page-726-6"></span><span id="page-726-5"></span><span id="page-726-4"></span><span id="page-726-3"></span><span id="page-726-2"></span>Angels descending from heaven are a common feature in Revelation, and here an angel holds in his hand the key to the abyss and a great chain (cf. Rev. 9:1, 11; 11:7; 17:8; cf. also Luke 8:31; Rom. 10:7). The angel seizes the dragon, the great monster opposing the people of God, and binds him in the pit for a thousand years. We see an interesting parallel text in Isaiah 24:21–22: "On that day the Lord will punish the host of heaven, in heaven, and the kings of the earth, on the earth. They will be gathered together as prisoners in a pit; they will be shut up in a prison, and after many days they will be punished." The dragon is described further (cf. also Rev. 12:9) as the ancient serpent who deceived Eve (Gen. 3:1, 2, 4, 13, 14; cf. Ps. 91:13; Isa. 27:1; 2 Cor. 11:3) and as the Devil (the slanderer of God's people) and Satan (the adversary of God's people).

<span id="page-726-16"></span><span id="page-726-12"></span><span id="page-726-11"></span><span id="page-726-10"></span><span id="page-726-8"></span><span id="page-726-7"></span><span id="page-726-1"></span><span id="page-726-0"></span>20:3 The angel throws Satan into the pit and locks him in. Thus Satan is unable to deceive the nations for one thousand years. Near the end of the thousand years, Satan is released for a short time to wreak havoc. Premillennialists say the events in verses 2–3 occur when Christ returns to earth, arguing that Satan cannot be locked up before Jesus returns, for he is alive and well during the present evil age, standing behind the beast and false prophet, deceiving (13:14) and inciting the people of the world to persecute Christians (13:1–18). Satan is called the "ruler of this world" (John 12:31), and elsewhere John writes, "The whole world lies in the power of the evil one" (1 John 5:19). It is difficult to see how, according to premillennialists, these statements can be true if Satan is confined to the abyss. In Revelation 12 Satan is cast from heaven to earth, and the point there, though certainly symbolic, is that Satan has no ground to accuse believers before God since the death of Christ has removed their guilt. It seems here, however, that John goes a step further, the symbolism indicating Satan is absolutely restricted from acting on the earth.

Amillennialists suggest the locking away in a pit is symbolic and does not mean Satan is absent from earth. The text says he can no longer deceive the nations. Some interpret this to mean that Satan, during the present evil age, is unable to deceive the nations into gathering at Armageddon. According to this reading, the text does not say Satan does not deceive anyone; the point is that the nations are not deceived to the extent that they wage final war against God's people. Another way of interpreting this from the amillennial perspective is that the deception relates to the spread of the gospel. With the coming of Christ, the gospel now goes to the ends of the earth. In the OT salvation was confined to Israel, and the nations of the world were deceived. Now the gospel is believed in all nations, and thus Satan no longer deceives the nations as he did in the OT era. Unbelievers are still deceived by Satan, but the deception over all nations that characterized the OT period is now lifted, so that some believe from every tribe, tongue, people, and nation. Satan was bound at the cross (Matt. 12:29; cf. John 12:31; Col. 2:15; Rev. 12:9), say amillennialists, prevented from gathering and uniting all nations to oppose the Christ and his people until the time of the end.

<span id="page-727-8"></span><span id="page-727-5"></span><span id="page-727-4"></span><span id="page-727-3"></span><span id="page-727-2"></span><span id="page-727-1"></span>20:4 John's vision shifts to human beings. He sees thrones, and those who sit on them are given the responsibility of judging. He also sees martyrs, those beheaded because of the "testimony of Jesus" and the "word of God." The testimony of Jesus has played a significant role in the book (cf. comment on 1:2; cf. also comments on 1:9; 12:17; 19:10), as has the word of God (cf. 1:2, 9; 6:9). Rule is given to those who suffered for Jesus' sake, who gave their lives because of the word of the gospel (cf. Dan. 7:22; Matt. 19:28; Luke 22:30; 1 Cor. 6:2; Rev. 3:21). As in 6:9, John sees their "souls," introduced with the word *kai*, which may have the sense of equivalent ("even") or of additional ("also"; ESV); in either case John likely refers to all believers. In a sense, the entire church is viewed as a martyr church, as those who have given their lives for Jesus Christ. In this particular verse, those who have been given "the authority to judge" have faithfully refused to compromise with the beast. They did not worship the beast or its image, or receive the mark on their hand or forehead. John has earlier made it very plain that those who worship the beast or its image or receive the mark will suffer torment forever (Rev. 14:9–11). On the other hand, the saints triumph over the beast and its image (15:2). Judgment and reward belong to faithful believers, to those who give their lives to Jesus and overcome until the end. In other words, eternal rewards are granted to all true believers. The reward specified here is that they "came to life and reigned with Christ for a thousand years."

<span id="page-727-9"></span><span id="page-727-7"></span><span id="page-727-6"></span><span id="page-727-0"></span>Premillennialists understand this passage to refer to the physical resurrection. Those who were martyred are vindicated by God and come to life again. The verb *zaō* can refer to the resurrection of Christ (2:8; cf. also Ezek. 37:10; Rom. 14:9), and it is argued that the same is true here, especially when correlated with the first resurrection of Revelation 20:5. Scholars holding this view point out that this is the only verse referring to the resurrection of believers in the book, and that seeing this as a

reference to the resurrection shows the victory of the saints more fittingly than the amillennial reading, which sees the saints reigning in heaven during this present evil age. Furthermore, the notion of *souls* coming to life supports the notion that souls are raised to a life new and better than mere existence in the intermediate state.

<span id="page-728-5"></span><span id="page-728-4"></span>Amillennialists find the reference to "souls" here to be signifying that the souls come to life during this present evil age (cf. Rev. 6:9–11). In other words, coming to life here refers not to physical resurrection but to life in the intermediate state. The souls of believers reign with Christ in heaven now—the word "thrones" elsewhere in Revelation refers to heaven, and thus it does not fit for it to refer here to the reign of saints on earth. We see in Revelation 14:13 that death is blessed for believers as they are given the crown of life for persevering until the end (2:11). Other amillennialists understand the coming to life here to be conversion—those who are converted are now raised with Christ (Eph. 2:6; Col. 3:1).

<span id="page-728-6"></span><span id="page-728-3"></span><span id="page-728-1"></span>20:5 The rest of the dead do not come to life until the thousand years have ended. If only martyrs come to life in 20:4, the remainder of the dead includes all unbelievers and all other believers. If 20:4 refers to all believers, the rest of the dead refers only to unbelievers. It is much more likely, as argued above, that the latter view is correct, as the entire church is viewed as a martyr church (without requiring the idea that all are literally put to death). John pauses and remarks, "This is the first resurrection," clearly referring to the coming to life of the martyrs and saints described in verse 4.

Premillennialists understand the first resurrection to refer to physical resurrection. Unbelievers are raised from the dead after the thousand-year reign of Christ, but this is distinguished from the first resurrection, which refers to the physical resurrection of the martyrs and believers mentioned in verse 4. One of the strongest arguments for the premillennial view appears here; the noun "resurrection" (*anastasis*) invariably refers to physical resurrection in Jewish thought. Indeed, there is no clear example of it not referring to physical resurrection. Also, the sequence here presents a good argument for premillennialism, for the rest who come to life a thousand years later do not experience a different *kind* of resurrection. Almost all agree that the rest experience a *physical* resurrection, but if that is the case, the first resurrection is likely physical as well. We have not two different *kinds* of resurrection here but *two stages* in which the dead are raised physically. One objection to the premillennial view is that John 5:28–29 presents the resurrection of those who are good and evil as occurring at the same time. Premillennialists respond that the book of Revelation clarifies that there is an interval, and it is not necessary for every statement about the resurrection to also mention an interval between the two resurrections.

<span id="page-728-2"></span><span id="page-728-0"></span>Amillennialists argue, on the other hand, that the first resurrection is a spiritual resurrection. Even if the term "resurrection" (*anastasis*) refers to physical resurrection elsewhere, we should not be surprised by a symbolic meaning in apocalyptic literature; there are texts speaking of a spiritual resurrection conceptually (Eph. 2:6; Col. 3:1) elsewhere as well. The first resurrection means life in the intermediate state (or, alternatively, conversion), while the second refers to physical resurrection. Similarly, the first death is physical death, while the second death is final judgment. This is an intriguing suggestion, though it should be noted that John never specifically refers to a "first death" or a "second resurrection" (see table 9.10).

<span id="page-729-0"></span>TABLE 9.10: Amillennialist View of First Resurrection and Second Death in Revelation

| First resurrection: spiritual/intermediate state | First death:* physical  |
|--------------------------------------------------|-------------------------|
| Second resurrection:* physical                   | Second death: spiritual |

*\*Not specifically named in Revelation*

<span id="page-729-5"></span>I noted above that premillennialists argue that the relationship between the two resurrections indicates they are of the same nature, i.e., they are both physical. But if the schema advanced here is correct, the two resurrections are *not* of the same nature. The premillennial reading is certainly possible, and may very well be right, but it is also possible that the first resurrection anticipates and looks forward to the second resurrection, so that the first is spiritual and the second physical. The words "first" ( *prōtos*) and "new" (*kainos*) should be distinguished, according to amillennialists. "New" refers to the coming new creation. "A new heaven and a new earth" are coming (Rev. 21:1)—a "new Jerusalem" (21:2)—and God will make "all things new" (21:5). The new heaven and earth are contrasted with the "first heaven and the first earth" (21:1). "First" refers to life in this present age, for the "former [i.e., first] things" ( *prōta*) have passed away (21:4). If we follow this pattern, the *first* resurrection is the preconsummated resurrection, the spiritual resurrection occurring in this age, and the *second* resurrection is the physical resurrection—the final resurrection to be enjoyed by all believers in the age to come. Similarly, the first death is physical death, which all experience, in contrast with the "second [*deuteros*] death" that the wicked will suffer forever (2:11; 20:6, 14; 21:8). According to this reading, what is "first" refers to this present world, while what is "second" or "new" refers to the coming new world.

<span id="page-729-6"></span><span id="page-729-4"></span><span id="page-729-3"></span><span id="page-729-1"></span>20:6 One of the seven blessings of the book (cf. comment on 1:3) is now pronounced over those who enjoy the first resurrection. The first resurrection is so wonderful because the second death has no power over those who experience it (cf. 2:11; 20:14; 21:8). In other words, those who experience the first resurrection will avoid the lake of fire. Instead, participants in the first resurrection will be priests of both God and Christ. We see here that God and Christ share the same stature, that Jesus is fully God; it is inconceivable, e.g., that the author would say they are priests of God and of angels. The picture of believers as priests mediating God's blessing has been present since the outset of the book (cf. 1:6 and 5:10)—believers are priestkings, like Adam in the garden, and will reign with Christ one thousand years.

<span id="page-729-2"></span>Premillennialists understand this rule to refer to a thousand-year (or very long) reign on earth after Christ's return—if the resurrection here denotes the physical resurrection promised to believers. Amillennialists take it to refer to the rule of deceased saints in heaven between the first and second coming, if the first resurrection refers to life given in the intermediate state—a spiritual, not physical, resurrection. Other amillennialists see a reference to regeneration, the new life believers enjoy as born-again Christians.

#### *Response*

Christians have disagreed over the details of this passage for nearly two thousand years. But one thing is clear: the persecution, the execution, the death of believers is not the final reality. Those on the "wrong" side of history will live again; they will be shown to be in the right after all. They may die once, but not twice. They will reign as priest-kings; they will fulfill the original mandate given to Adam. Satan's power is limited and circumscribed by God, while God's plan for his own will be realized, and hence we can be full of hope for the future.

### <span id="page-730-1"></span>REVELATION 20:7–10

**<sup>7</sup>**And when the thousand years are ended, Satan will be released from his prison **<sup>8</sup>** and will come out to deceive the nations that are at the four corners of the earth, Gog and Magog, to gather them for battle; their number is like the sand of the sea. **9**And they marched up over the broad plain of the earth and surrounded the camp of the saints and the beloved city, but fire came down from heaven*<sup>1</sup>* and consumed them, **<sup>10</sup>** and the devil who had deceived them was thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur where the beast and the false prophet were, and they will be tormented day and night forever and ever.

1Some manuscripts *from God, out of heaven*, or *out of heaven from God*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-730-0"></span>At the end of the thousand years, Satan is released for a short time to deceive the nations of the four corners of earth. John picks up the language of "Gog and Magog" from Ezekiel 38–39. The nations of the world gather with incalculable numbers for the last battle as the anti-god forces march against the saints and surround the city of God. The battle is short-lived, for fire comes down from heaven and consumes them. The Devil is cast into the lake of fire, along with the beast and false prophet, and suffers torment there forever.

#### *Section Outline*

- IX. The Triumph of God in Christ (19:11–20:15) . . .
	- C. The Last Battle (20:7–10)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-731-13"></span><span id="page-731-2"></span>20:7–8 At the end of the thousand-year period, Satan is released from his prison to deceive the nations at the four corners of the world. In Ezekiel 38–39 the nations attacking Israel are called Gog and Magog; here the terms designate all the kingdoms of the world bent on attacking the people of God. Such an attack is due to Satan's deception, for fighting against the people of God is futile. John echoes Ezekiel, who says that in the last days Gog and others will move against Israel like storm clouds, while the people of God will be secure and unconcerned (Ezek. 38:8–9, 11–12, 16; 39:2). According to John, these mysterious nations represent the anti-god forces conspiring against the people of God (cf. 1 Sam. 13:5). Satan gathers the nations, countless as the sand on the seashore, for the final battle against God's people.

<span id="page-731-12"></span><span id="page-731-4"></span><span id="page-731-3"></span><span id="page-731-0"></span>Premillennialists understand these verses to refer to a final battle near the end of Christ's millennial reign on earth. The people of God have become accustomed to peace and hence are surprised by the sudden surge of force against them (Ezek. 38:8–11). Premillennialists typically argue that the evil breaking forth demonstrates the iniquity of the human heart, for even after a paradisiacal reign of nearly a thousand years, unbelievers still turn toward evil. Amillennialists maintain that this battle is another picture of the battle ( *polemos*) described in 19:11–21 (cf. esp. Rev. 19:19; cf. also 16:14 and Zech. 14:2), in which the wicked turn against believers before Jesus returns. John regularly returns to the final battle and describes it from different angles. Evil will increase dramatically near the end of history before the end arrives. Amillennialists and premillennialists agree that evil will rear its ugly head at the end of history before the new creation dawns.

<span id="page-731-14"></span><span id="page-731-10"></span><span id="page-731-9"></span><span id="page-731-7"></span><span id="page-731-6"></span><span id="page-731-1"></span>20:9 The plot against the saints spreads and widens (cf. Hab. 1:6) as the nations surround the camp of the saints and their beloved city to destroy the people of God. This city is not Jerusalem but the people of God as a whole (cf. Gal. 4:26; Heb. 12:22–23). As God's enemies are poised to attack, fire descends from heaven, from God himself, annihilating them (cf. 2 Kings 1:10, 12). John again draws on Ezekiel, where the nations conspire to attack Israel but instead provoke God's wrath and judgment (Ezek. 38:18–19) of fire and hail (Ezek. 38:22; 39:6). Once again premillennialists see this as taking place near the end of Christ's thousand-year reign on earth, and amillennialists as taking place near the end of history, shortly before the second coming.

<span id="page-731-15"></span><span id="page-731-11"></span><span id="page-731-8"></span><span id="page-731-5"></span>20:10 The unholy trinity (cf. 16:13) are together forever, but not in a place they would desire. The Devil, who incited the last battle and deceived the peoples of the world to participate in the battle against God and the Lamb, is cast into the lake of fire, along with the beast and the false prophet. They will be tormented there forever (cf. 14:9–11; Matt. 25:46). Premillennialists assign the punishment of the Devil to a period one thousand years after the beast and the false prophet were thrown into the lake of fire. Amillennialists contend that John pictures the final judgment from another angle, and hence the judgment of the Devil, beast, and false prophet took place at the same time. Part of the debate centers on the English verb "were," which suggests the beast and false prophet were already in the lake of fire before the Devil arrived. Premillennialists thus argue that the Devil is cast into the lake of fire *after* the beast and false prophet. Amillennialists, on the other hand, point out there is no such Greek verb in the text. English translators have supplied the word "were," but the verb "are" can just as easily be supplied; hence the verse is unclear about the timing of the Devil's incarceration. John is not giving us a chronology but simply telling us that the Devil, beast, and false prophet are in the same place.

#### *Response*

The insanity of evil stands out here—it cannot truly triumph over good, and thus Satan's attempts to persuade humans to rebel against God are an exercise in futility. Yes, he brings many down with him, but at the end of the day he will be routed. We are reminded that all sin is ultimately a kind of insanity; it never makes sense. It brings no satisfaction or joy and never succeeds ultimately. Those who trust in the Lord and persevere in faith will have the greatest joys.

### <span id="page-732-0"></span>REVELATION 20:11–15

**<sup>11</sup>**Then I saw a great white throne and him who was seated on it. From his presence earth and sky fled away, and no place was found for them. **<sup>12</sup>**And I saw the dead, great and small, standing before the throne, and books were opened. Then another book was opened, which is the book of life. And the dead were judged by what was written in the books, according to what they had done. **13**And the sea gave up the dead who were in it, Death and Hades gave up the dead who were in them, and they were judged, each one of them, according to what they had done. **14**Then Death and Hades were thrown into the lake of fire. This is the second death, the lake of fire. **15**And if anyone's name was not found written in the book of life, he was thrown into the lake of fire.

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-732-4"></span><span id="page-732-3"></span><span id="page-732-2"></span><span id="page-732-1"></span>The punishment of the beast, false prophet, and Devil brings us to the last judgment, the great white throne, where God sits to assess human beings (Rev. 20:11a). The universe as we know it has come to an end, as witnessed by the earth and sky's fleeing away (v. 11b). All the dead, all human beings, stand before God, and he opens the books, including the book of life (v. 12a). Everyone is assessed according to whether his name is inscribed in that book (v. 12b). The sea, Death, <span id="page-733-13"></span><span id="page-733-12"></span>and Hades give up their dead (v. 13). Nothing can finally stand against the Lord, so Death and Hades are also thrown into the lake of fire, identified as the second death (v. 14). Anyone whose name is not written in the book of life is also thrown into the lake of fire (v. 15).

#### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-733-14"></span>IX. The Triumph of God in Christ (19:11–20:15) . . .
	- D. The Last Judgment (20:11–15)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-733-10"></span><span id="page-733-8"></span><span id="page-733-4"></span><span id="page-733-3"></span>20:11 God's throne, representing his authority and rule, plays a major role in Revelation—the word "throne" refers to God's rule more than thirty times in the book. In particular, in chapter 4 it signifies the sovereignty and rule of God as the creator of all. All creation bows in worship before the one exalted in his majesty. The prophecy of Daniel 2:35 is becoming a reality, for the stone representing the kingdom of God is now a great mountain filling the earth, and the anti-god kingdoms no longer reign. The great white throne signifies God's place of judgment (cf. Dan. 7:9). Heaven and earth flee from God's presence, and no place is found for them. It is evident from this expression that the end of history has arrived; their fleeing means the world as we know it is no more. We see similar expressions elsewhere in Revelation (cf. also Ps. 114:3, 7). For instance, in Revelation 6:14 the sky vanishes like a scroll being rolled up, and every mountain and island disappears. Likewise, in 16:20 every island flees and the mountains vanish (cf. also 2 Pet. 3:7, 10). When the new heaven and earth arrive, the first earth passes away, along with the sea (Rev. 21:1). Thus John speaks here of the passing away of the old creation.

<span id="page-733-15"></span><span id="page-733-11"></span><span id="page-733-9"></span><span id="page-733-7"></span><span id="page-733-6"></span><span id="page-733-2"></span><span id="page-733-1"></span><span id="page-733-0"></span>20:12 All the dead, whether powerful or poor, stand before God's throne to be assessed by him. Books are opened, including the book of life (cf. comment on Rev. 3:5; cf. also Isa. 4:3), meaning that the time of judgment is at hand (Dan. 7:10; cf. Rev. 11:18). The dead are judged by what is written in the book, i.e., according to their works. Scripture repeatedly says that judgment will be according to works (Ps. 62:12; Prov. 24:12; Jer. 17:10; 32:19; Matt. 16:27; Rom. 2:6; 14:12; Rev. 2:23; 22:12). Judgment according to works is not merely an OT theme but is also prominent in the NT. Those who are in the book of life have performed works warranting inclusion, while those who are punished are those who have pursued and practiced evil. Such works are not the basis for being found in the book of life but constitute the necessary evidence of belonging to God. As Daniel teaches, those written in the book will be delivered on the last day, raised to everlasting life, but those who have done evil will know "shame and everlasting contempt" (Dan. 12:1–2).

<span id="page-733-5"></span>20:13 None of the powers of the world, those that terrify human beings, can withstand the voice of God or his power. The sea, Death, and Hades yield their dead (cf. *1 En.* 51:1). The sea here is not a neutral entity but represents chaos and destruction, which explains its absence in the new creation (Rev. 21:1). John reiterates that <span id="page-734-0"></span>the dead are judged according to their works (cf. Ps. 28:4; John 5:28–29; cf. also *Sir.* 16:12). God's judgment is impartial and fair, not arbitrary or spiteful. It accords with what is right and true; no one will question its veracity.

<span id="page-734-12"></span><span id="page-734-11"></span><span id="page-734-8"></span>20:14 There is no doubt that the end of history has arrived as Death and Hades are cast into the lake of fire. Death is the last enemy (1 Cor. 15:26), and Hades represents the realm of death and final punishment. Everything opposing God is confined to the lake of fire (cf. Rev. 19:20; 20:10, 14), defined as the second death. Death is absent from the new creation, along with the pain and sorrow it brings (cf. 21:4). The promise of Isaiah 25:8 has now become a reality: "He will swallow up death forever." The first death is separation from God, sealed by physical death (cf. Rom. 5:12; 6:23). But the second death is eternal separation from God, as his enemies are cast into a place of torment forever and ever (Rev. 14:9–11).

<span id="page-734-14"></span><span id="page-734-10"></span><span id="page-734-6"></span><span id="page-734-4"></span><span id="page-734-3"></span><span id="page-734-1"></span>20:15 If one's name is not inscribed in the book of life, he is cast into the lake of fire. Matthew describes the place of punishment as a "fiery furnace," a place of "weeping and gnashing of teeth" (Matt. 13:42, 50). Matthew also tells us the "eternal fire" is "prepared for the devil and his angels" (Matt. 25:41). The punishment here is not temporary; John has made it very clear that the wicked suffer torment forever; they will never enjoy rest (Rev. 14:9–11). Again, Matthew confirms this reading, for the righteous will enjoy "eternal life" while the wicked will suffer "eternal punishment" (Matt. 25:46). The parallel in Matthew shows that the punishment is permanent, just as the life enjoyed by the righteous lasts forever: those whose works testify that they truly belong to God will be vindicated at the great white throne; their names will be in the book of life.

#### <span id="page-734-5"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-734-16"></span><span id="page-734-15"></span><span id="page-734-13"></span><span id="page-734-9"></span><span id="page-734-7"></span><span id="page-734-2"></span>Final judgment is according to works, as this text clearly teaches. Such a teaching seems strange to some believers, who even wonder if it contradicts the gospel of grace—that we are justified by faith alone. But, as we saw in Revelation 20:12 above (cf. also 1 Cor. 6:9–11; Gal. 5:24; 6:8; James 2:14–26; 2 Pet. 1:5–11; 1 John 2:3–6; 3:4–10), the notion of good works as necessary for final reward is a pervasive theme in the NT. Those who practice evil and give themselves to it will not enjoy eternal life but will find themselves in the lake of fire. What John teaches here does not contradict justification by faith alone, for John is not teaching that good works earn or merit eternal life, nor is he claiming them as the basis for final reward—the gift of life is free (cf. Rev. 21:6; 22:17). True faith expresses itself in a changed life—though not a perfect life, to be sure—revealing the transformation taking place by God's grace. Those who live in the same way they did before conversion reveal that they never truly belonged to God (cf. Matt. 7:23; 1 John 2:19).

Also he said, "Write this down, for these words are trustworthy and true." **6**And he said to me, "It is done! I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end. To the thirsty I will give from the spring of the water of life without payment. **7**The one who conquers will have this heritage, and I will be his God and he will be my son. **8**But as for the cowardly, the faithless, the detestable, as for murderers, the sexually immoral, sorcerers, idolaters, and all liars, their portion will be in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death."
