#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-735-6"></span><span id="page-735-3"></span><span id="page-735-1"></span><span id="page-735-0"></span>The book takes a major turn in chapter 21, for now the new creation—the new heaven and earth—has arrived. The new creation is announced in verses 1–5, and those who enjoy the new creation and those who are excluded from it are described in verses 6–8. In 21:9–22:5 the new creation is described in visionary and apocalyptic language, expanding upon the announcement here in 21:1–5. The previous passage (20:11–15) serves as the bridge to the new creation, as those thrown into the lake of fire are excluded from the new creation, whereas those in the book of life (20:15) are included. Verse 1 of chapter 21 continues John's vision, and he sees a new heaven and a new earth; the old heaven and earth are no more. The new creation is also described as the new Jerusalem (v. 2), representing heaven coming to earth. The new Jerusalem is further described as a bride dressed for her husband. Is the new creation a people or a place? It is both—people and place, community and new creation, bride and domicile. A loud voice from God's throne declares that God's covenant with his people has been fulfilled (v. 3). God will dwell with his people and be God to them, and they will be his people. All the wretched realities of the old creation have passed away: mourning, death, and pain <span id="page-736-17"></span><span id="page-736-16"></span><span id="page-736-15"></span>(v. 4). The first things are over; the last things have arrived in their fullness. God, seated on his throne, declares he is making all things new (v. 5), and these words are affirmed as true and trustworthy. The text transitions to those who will enjoy the new creation. God announces that all has been fulfilled (v. 6). His purposes have been realized from beginning to end, for he is the Alpha and the Omega. All who are thirsty will drink freely of the water of life. The one who conquers will be an heir, and God will be his father (v. 7). By contrast, those who give themselves over to evil will experience the second death, the lake of fire (v. 8).

#### <span id="page-736-19"></span><span id="page-736-18"></span>*Section Outline*

X. The New Heavens and New Earth (21:1–22:5) A. All Things New (21:1–8)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-736-13"></span><span id="page-736-10"></span><span id="page-736-9"></span><span id="page-736-5"></span><span id="page-736-4"></span>21:1 The new creation promised in the OT (cf. 2 Pet. 3:13) has finally become a reality. Isaiah promises the new creation in two texts: "I create new heavens and a new earth, and the former things shall not be remembered or come into mind" (Isa. 65:17); and, "As the new heavens and the new earth that I make shall remain before me, says the Lord, so shall your offspring and your name remain" (Isa. 66:22). When John speaks of a new heaven and new earth, he does not mean the old creation is annihilated. The parallel 2 Peter 3:7, 10–13 passage should be interpreted to mean the old creation is purified and renewed; the old creation is not blotted out of existence. The new creation, then, is a renewal and transformation of the old. The first heaven and earth pass away in the sense of being transformed and cleansed of all evil (cf. comment on Rev. 20:11). When John says the sea is no more, he does not mean there are no bodies of water in the new creation. The sea in Hebrew thought stood for chaos and evil, the source of hideous monsters (cf. Dan. 7:3; Isa. 27:1; 51:9–10; Rev. 11:7; 13:1). For instance, the flood—i.e., the sea—destroyed all life on the land in the days of Noah (cf. Pss. 42:7; 69:1; Jonah 2:3). That the sea is no more means nothing destructive and deforming will be in the new creation (cf. Job 38:8; Ps. 74:13).

<span id="page-736-14"></span><span id="page-736-12"></span><span id="page-736-11"></span><span id="page-736-8"></span><span id="page-736-7"></span><span id="page-736-6"></span><span id="page-736-3"></span><span id="page-736-2"></span><span id="page-736-1"></span><span id="page-736-0"></span>21:2 The new creation that dawns is a city, a holy city of no unrighteousness or evil, consecrated and dedicated to God (cf. Isa. 52:1; Rev. 11:2). It stands in stark contrast to Babylon, a detestable prostitute. The city of God is identified as the new Jerusalem. It is not the earthly Jerusalem but a transcendent one, coming down from heaven, from God. The earthly Jerusalem pointed forward to a heavenly Jerusalem far surpassing the one located in Israel. Other NT writers refer to Jerusalem in a similar way. Paul speaks of the "Jerusalem above," calling it "our mother" (Gal. 4:26), and Hebrews refers to a heavenly Jerusalem (Heb. 12:22; cf. comment on Rev. 3:12). A new and heavenly Jerusalem is anticipated in the OT and in Second Temple literature of the day (cf. Heb. 11:10, 13–16). This language is apocalyptic, and we should not see it as a literal description of the coming new

The city is also described as a beautiful bride adorned for her husband. Isaiah anticipates what John writes here about Jerusalem:

You shall no more be termed Forsaken, and your land shall no more be termed Desolate, but you shall be called My Delight Is in Her, and your land Married; for the Lord delights in you, and your land shall be married. For as a young man marries a young woman, so shall your sons marry you, and as the bridegroom rejoices over the bride, so shall your God rejoice over you. (Isa. 62:4–5)

<span id="page-737-7"></span>The question arises as to whether the new creation, the new Jerusalem, is a place or a people. Both options are possible, but perhaps the best answer is that it is both. The new creation is like a city, with all the beauty and excitement sparked by a bustling metropolis. At the same time, the new creation also means the formation of a people, described as a radiant and perfect bride (cf. Rev. 19:7; Isa. 61:10; Eph. 5:26–27). The coming new world includes both a people and a place.

<span id="page-737-19"></span><span id="page-737-17"></span><span id="page-737-15"></span><span id="page-737-13"></span><span id="page-737-12"></span><span id="page-737-11"></span><span id="page-737-9"></span><span id="page-737-6"></span><span id="page-737-4"></span><span id="page-737-3"></span><span id="page-737-2"></span>21:3 A loud voice is heard from the throne, declaring that God's dwelling, his tabernacle (*skēnē*), is with human beings (cf. 7:15). God will dwell (*skēnōsei* ), i.e., "tabernacle," with his people forever. In the OT, the Lord specially dwelt in the tabernacle (cf. Exodus 25–31, 35–40; Lev. 26:11–12; Zech. 2:10–11) and the temple (1 Kings 6:1–38; 8:12–13; Psalm 84), but the tabernacle and temple pointed to something greater (cf. 1 Kings 8:27). Jesus himself is the new temple (John 1:14; 2:19–22), and the Spirit indwells the church of Jesus Christ (1 Cor. 3:16; 2 Cor. 6:16). Now, in the new creation, he dwells in the new Jerusalem, and the whole world, the entire universe, is his temple. As we shall see shortly, both God and the Lamb will be the new temple (Rev. 21:22). The covenant formula of the OT is now realized fully (cf. Gen. 17:8; Ex. 29:45, 46; Lev. 26:44, 45; 2 Sam. 7:24; Jer. 31:1, 33; 32:38; Ezek. 11:20; 37:23, 27), for the redeemed will be God's "peoples" (*laoi*; cf. ESV mg.) and God will be their God. The plural "peoples" is significant, denoting the diversity of the people of God. The fulfillment of God's promises is not limited to Israel but includes all peoples, just as he said to Abraham (Gen. 12:3; 18:18). The greatest blessing of the new creation is the presence of God with his people. What makes the new creation so thrilling is fellowship with the living God: Father, Son, and Spirit.

<span id="page-737-18"></span><span id="page-737-16"></span><span id="page-737-14"></span><span id="page-737-10"></span><span id="page-737-8"></span><span id="page-737-5"></span><span id="page-737-1"></span><span id="page-737-0"></span>21:4 The sorrow and sin of the old creation do not continue in the new creation (a theme anticipated already in the book; cf. 7:17, e.g.); all the troubles and pain that bedevil human beings are absent in the new Jerusalem (cf. Isa. 43:19). Every tear will be removed; there will be no occasions for mourning, crying, or pain. Death is dethroned and defeated as the last enemy (cf. 1 Cor. 15:26). Since death is part of the former things thrown into the lake of fire (Rev. 20:14), the story of the new creation is one of life and fruitfulness and a deep and lasting joy transcending

<span id="page-738-0"></span>and surpassing any joy we have tasted in this world. We cannot improve on the way Isaiah describes future joy: "Everlasting joy shall be upon their heads; they shall obtain gladness and joy, and sorrow and sighing shall flee away" (Isa. 35:10; cf. 51:11; 65:19).

<span id="page-738-15"></span><span id="page-738-14"></span><span id="page-738-11"></span><span id="page-738-3"></span><span id="page-738-1"></span>21:5 The old things have passed away, and the one who sits on the throne (cf. 4:2, 9; 5:1; 20:11), who rules and reigns over history and has appointed its end, declares he is making everything new (cf. Isa. 43:19; 2 Cor. 5:17). We could call this a performative statement, for the words of God are effective. What he *declares* to be new *becomes* new, just as the words of a minister declaring a couple husband and wife effect a new reality. It is particularly important that those who belong to God believe the words spoken here. If they doubt that a new world is coming, they will be prone to side with the old world, with the harlot and the beast and the false prophet and the Devil. But if they trust the words contained here, they will sacrifice everything to be part of the coming new world. It is important that the words be written so that they are not forgotten but are preserved for future generations. What is written is true and reliable, as is the case with every word of God (cf. Rev. 22:6).

<span id="page-738-18"></span><span id="page-738-16"></span><span id="page-738-13"></span><span id="page-738-9"></span>21:6 God declares to John that all is accomplished; history has come to an end (cf. 10:6; 11:17). Everything God has purposed has been realized, and the new creation has dawned. God's purposes are realized because he is the sovereign God, the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end (cf. 1:8; 22:13). He has always ruled and reigned as the God of the universe; things were never spinning out of his control. He declares from the very beginning what the end will be, and his purposes and plans are never frustrated (Isa. 46:9–11).

<span id="page-738-6"></span><span id="page-738-4"></span><span id="page-738-2"></span>The joys of knowing God and having him dwell in one's midst belong to those who are thirsty (Isa. 49:10), who long to be satisfied with God and are tired of relying on themselves and their good works (cf. Isa. 55:1; Zech. 14:8; John 4:10; 7:37; Rev. 7:16–17; 22:1, 17). God freely quenches the spiritual thirst and longing of human beings; the water of life is a gift that comes with the asking. People do not have to work or show they are worthy of it. All they need to do is to desire it.

<span id="page-738-17"></span><span id="page-738-12"></span><span id="page-738-10"></span><span id="page-738-8"></span><span id="page-738-7"></span><span id="page-738-5"></span>21:7 Those who thirst, those who receive the free gift, also conquer and overcome. The necessity of conquering is a major theme in Revelation (cf. comment on 2:7). Eternal life is free, but those who receive it freely also conquer. The gift received empowers those who drink freely to overcome the beast, the harlot, and everything opposed to God. Hence they will "have this heritage [*klēronomēsei* ]," probably a reference to inheriting the blessings of the new creation in verses 1–6. In the NT, the verb *klēronomeō* is typically used with reference to eschatological blessing: inheriting the earth (Matt. 5:5), eternal life (Luke 10:25; 18:18), the kingdom (1 Cor. 6:9, 10; Gal. 5:21), the imperishable body (1 Cor. 15:50), salvation (Heb. 1:14), and blessing (1 Pet. 3:9). Here John speaks generally of eschatological blessing. What is clear is that there is no life in the age to come, no enjoyment of the new creation, unless one overcomes. The next line establishes this. Those who overcome <span id="page-739-5"></span><span id="page-739-2"></span><span id="page-739-0"></span>have God as their father, and they will be his sons. The text is especially close to 2 Samuel 7:14, where David's heir is called a son of God. Israel was also God's son (cf. Ex. 4:22; Isa. 43:6; Jer. 31:9; Hos. 1:10; 11:1), and now those who belong to Jesus Christ are sons of God (cf. Rom. 8:14, 15; 2 Cor. 6:18; Gal. 3:26; 4:6). The covenant relationship God promised to Israel now belongs to all those who are members of the people of God.

<span id="page-739-11"></span><span id="page-739-10"></span><span id="page-739-9"></span><span id="page-739-8"></span><span id="page-739-4"></span>21:8 Those who conquer will inherit the new creation as God's sons and daughters. On the other hand, those who fail to conquer and instead give themselves over to evil will be in the lake burning with fire and sulfur (19:20; 20:10, 14, 15)—they will experience the second death (cf. 2:11; 20:6, 14). The first death is the initial separation from God experienced by all those born into the world as sons and daughters of Adam (Rom. 5:12–19; cf. Rom. 6:23). The second death, however, is eternal separation from God, and there is no redemption or salvation for those who experience the second death; they will be tormented forever (Rev. 14:9–11). Unbelievers are excluded from the city for cowardice and unbelief. Cowardice expresses itself in conforming to and following the beast instead of risking one's life for allegiance to Jesus. Unbelief or unfaithfulness means trusting in one's own resources instead of staking one's life on God. Murder and sexual immorality also separate one from God. It is not as if these sins automatically exclude anyone; the point is that one is excluded by engaging in such sins instead of repenting and turning from them (cf. 1 Cor. 6:9–10; Gal. 5:19–21; Eph. 5:5; 1 Tim. 1:9; Rev. 22:15). Sorcery or magic is regularly condemned (Ex. 7:11, 22; 8:18; Isa. 47:9, 12; Gal. 5:20; Rev. 18:23; cf. *Wisd. Sol.* 12:4; 18:13) as a way of trying to manipulate circumstances to bring about one's desired ends instead of trusting in God. Idolatry, like sorcery, represents rejection of God's lordship (cf. Rom. 1:21–25). Liars do not trust God's providence in their lives and thus distort the truth to accomplish their own desires and schemes.

#### <span id="page-739-7"></span><span id="page-739-6"></span><span id="page-739-3"></span><span id="page-739-1"></span>*Response*

Sometimes we wonder if trust in Christ and faithfulness to God is worth it. John reminds us that the new creation is truly coming. No more melanoma, no more multiple sclerosis, no more murder, no more indescribable loneliness accompanied by weeping, no more pain of having one's head sawed off by the enemies of God. And the greatest joy, the greatest reward, is the presence of God himself. The universe will be his temple; he will dwell in the entire cosmos. We will enjoy the glory of his presence in a way that is undiminished and far surpasses what we enjoy now. All that is tawdry and defiled and unclean will pass away, and we will dwell in the new Jerusalem forever.

### <span id="page-740-0"></span>REVELATION 21:9–22:5

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-741-6"></span><span id="page-741-5"></span><span id="page-741-4"></span><span id="page-741-2"></span>John steps back to describe the new Jerusalem in symbolic language that fits the apocalyptic nature of the passage. The angel says he will show John the bride of the Lamb (Rev. 21:9), but, as in 21:1–2, we are surprised because John is shown the holy city of Jerusalem coming down from God (21:10). The glory of the city is described (21:11), including its wall and gates (21:12–14). The city includes the people of God from both the OT and the NT. The measurements of the city are given in verses 16–17—it is a perfect cube, like the Most Holy Place in the temple (21:16), and the wall measures 144 cubits (21:17). The materials of the wall and the city are explained (21:18–21): the wall is made of jasper and the city of gold (21:18), and beautiful stones are laid as its foundation (21:19–20). The twelve gates of the city are a single pearl, and the streets are gold (21:21).

<span id="page-741-14"></span><span id="page-741-13"></span><span id="page-741-12"></span><span id="page-741-11"></span><span id="page-741-10"></span><span id="page-741-9"></span><span id="page-741-8"></span><span id="page-741-7"></span>In verses 22–25 surprising characteristics of the city are set forth. There is no temple, for God and the Lamb are the temple (21:22). Nor is there need for sun or moon, since God and the Lamb illumine the city (21:23). The nations will walk in the light of the city, and its gates will never be shut, for night will never fall (21:24–25). The city will be full of the glory of the nations, and nothing defiled or evil will be in the city, for it is reserved for those whose names are written in the book of life (21:26–27).

<span id="page-741-20"></span><span id="page-741-19"></span><span id="page-741-18"></span><span id="page-741-17"></span><span id="page-741-16"></span><span id="page-741-15"></span>As we come to chapter 22, John continues to describe the city. The river of life flows in the city from God's throne and from the Lamb (22:1), and the tree of life grants healing to the nations (22:2). Nothing cursed will be in the city, for God's throne and the Lamb will be there, and his people will worship him (22:3). We will see God's face—the greatest joy of all (22:4)—and night will never descend again, for the Lord will be our light, and the saints will reign forever (22:5).

#### <span id="page-741-22"></span><span id="page-741-21"></span>*Section Outline*

- X. The New Heavens and New Earth (21:1–22:5) . . .
	- B. The Bride and the Holy City (21:9–22:5)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-741-3"></span><span id="page-741-1"></span><span id="page-741-0"></span>21:9 One of the angels holding the seven bowls (cf. 15:1–16:21) approaches John and speaks to him. This time he shows John a beautiful and entrancing vision, summoning him to see the bride, the wife of the Lamb. Earlier John had referred to the bride and the marriage supper of the Lamb (19:7–8) and compared the new Jerusalem to a bride dressed for her husband (21:2). He now sees the church as a bride of unrivaled beauty.

<span id="page-742-11"></span><span id="page-742-8"></span><span id="page-742-3"></span><span id="page-742-2"></span>21:10 John is carried away in the Spirit of prophecy (cf. comment on 1:10) to a great and high mountain, just as Ezekiel was brought to a mountain to see the building of a city-temple: "In visions of God he brought me to the land of Israel, and set me down on a very high mountain, on which was a structure like a city to the south" (Ezek. 40:2). God often discloses himself to his servants, from Sinai onward, on a mountain. We see the fulfillment of Ezekiel's vision here in Revelation, as the whole world is God's temple. There is no literal temple, but the temple (the universe where God dwells) is portrayed as a city. Hence, it is clear that a proper interpretation of Ezekiel 40–48 does not foresee the building of a literal temple. Ezekiel's vision of the temple is highly symbolic, pointing to God's presence among his people. Just as the Spirit inspired Ezekiel to see the glory of God in the temple (Ezek. 43:5), so too the Spirit lifts John up to see God's glory in the new temple. The fulfillment of Ezekiel's prophecy is the new creation, the new world, where God's glory dwells in his temple (the entire universe). Here John sees the holy city, Jerusalem (cf. *Tob.* 13:9), coming down from heaven. The transcendent and heavenly character of the city is emphasized, as John adds that it is from God.

<span id="page-742-10"></span><span id="page-742-9"></span><span id="page-742-5"></span>As in Revelation 21:2, the new Jerusalem is linked with the people of God; once again the city designates both a people and a place. Everything said about Jerusalem and Zion in the OT (cf. comments on 3:12; 21:2) is fulfilled in the heavenly Jerusalem, the city where God dwells. This city stands in contrast to Babylon, the harlot city, which John was earlier carried away in the Spirit to see. In contrast, Jerusalem is clean and holy and stunningly beautiful—not a prostitute but a faithful and chaste bride.

<span id="page-742-12"></span><span id="page-742-1"></span>21:11 The beauty of the heavenly Jerusalem is breathtaking; it shimmers with the glory of God (Isa. 58:8; 60:1–2, 19; Ezek. 43:2–5; Rev. 21:23; 22:5). Its radiance and loveliness are comparable to jewels of exquisite color and brightness. The city is like a rare piece of jasper and shines as clear as crystal.

<span id="page-742-13"></span><span id="page-742-7"></span><span id="page-742-4"></span>21:12–13 John continues to describe the city, telling us it has a massive, high wall and twelve gates. In the ancient world, a wall protected a city from enemies, so this high wall symbolizes the city's safety from all enemies (cf. Ezek. 40:5). The wall also has twelve gates: three each on the east, north, south, and west (cf. Luke 13:29). At the gates are twelve angels, again suggesting the city is protected from anything that would destroy it. On the gates are inscribed the names of the twelve tribes of Israel. The number twelve is almost certainly symbolic, signifying that the OT people of God are in the city. The promise that Israel would be restored has been fulfilled in the people of God, the church of Jesus Christ. We think also of Exodus 28:21 and 39:14, where the twelve tribes of Israel are represented by twelve stones in the high priest's ephod, again suggesting protection for the people of God.

<span id="page-742-14"></span><span id="page-742-6"></span><span id="page-742-0"></span>21:14 John's attention returns to the city wall; it has twelve foundations, inscribed with the names of the twelve apostles of the Lamb. Jesus chose twelve apostles for his ministry (Matt. 10:2–4; Mark 3:14–19; Luke 6:13–16), the number twelve sig<span id="page-743-2"></span>nifying the apostles as the nucleus of the new people of God, the new Israel. Paul says something quite similar, calling the apostles and NT prophets the foundation of God's new temple (Eph. 2:20), the cornerstone of the church of Jesus Christ. John is likewise teaching that the one people of God is grounded on the apostolic testimony. There are not two peoples of God (Israel and the church) but one people, now that the new covenant is realized in its fullness. As the OT points forward to, anticipates, and is fulfilled in the NT, the people of God are centered on the revelation of Jesus Christ mediated through apostolic testimony (cf. 1 John 1:1–4).

<span id="page-743-7"></span><span id="page-743-5"></span><span id="page-743-4"></span><span id="page-743-3"></span>21:15–16 The one speaking with John, presumably the angel of Revelation 21:9, had a golden measuring rod in his hand to measure the city and its gates and walls. Measuring the city signifies that it is protected and safe (cf. 11:1). The city is built foursquare, having the same length and width. When measured, the city is 12,000 stadia, which some versions translate into modern measurements; the NRSV, e.g., reads "fifteen hundred miles." Departing from the 12,000 stadia in the translation is a mistake, however, obscuring the symbolism of the number twelve multiplied by one thousand; the size of the city dwarfs any conceivable city and is far larger than the country of Israel. In other words, John is not saying the city is literally fifteen hundred miles, a ridiculously large size.31 Instead, he is communicating that the city is a perfect place to reside. This symbolic nature is evident from the next phrase, for the city is a perfect cube—its length, width, and height are equal (cf. Ezek. 45:2). This evokes the Most Holy Place in the temple, which was also a perfect cube: "twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and twenty cubits high" (1 Kings 6:20). This indicates not that the city is literally fifteen hundred miles, but that it is like a massive Most Holy Place. The city is where God dwells! The entire universe is like the Most Holy Place of the temple.

<span id="page-743-8"></span><span id="page-743-6"></span><span id="page-743-1"></span><span id="page-743-0"></span>21:17 The wall of the city, noted in verses 12–14, is featured again and measured. It is difficult to know if the height or the width of the wall is in view, though it is probably the former. The measurement is clearly symbolic, for the wall is 144 cubits, or twelve times twelve. The symbolism is even clearer from the next statement, for John says the 144 cubits is a human measurement, but also the measurement of the angel. Referring to the measurement of angels is very strange. John does not expect readers to say, "Of course, that makes sense. It is the measurement angels use." Instead, by appealing to the measurement employed by angels, he is signaling to the readers that this is symbolism—none of us knows angelic measurements! The great height or thickness of the wall symbolizes absolute safety and security; no one can breach or get over the top of this wall. The city is a walled city (like most cities in the ancient world) and is therefore impregnable.

<span id="page-743-9"></span>21:18 The wall is built of jasper, and the city is pure gold and like clear glass. Why is this important? Clear glass was very unusual in the ancient world, since the technology to make it was rare. Most glass was opaque and therefore difficult to see

<sup>31</sup> It is not clear if the figure refers to the length or to the perimeter of the city. Either way, the city is massive.

through. Both the wall and the city, then, are indescribably beautiful. Those who dwell in the city will be ennobled by its superb artistry and eye-catching splendor. The city reflects the glory and beauty of God himself.

<span id="page-744-10"></span><span id="page-744-9"></span><span id="page-744-8"></span>21:19–21 The wall of the city, as we have already seen, has twelve foundations and twelve gates (vv. 12–14), and the number twelve, as we have repeatedly seen in Revelation, is symbolic. Verses 19–20 describe the foundations, and verse 21 the gates. The foundations of the city consist of twelve different kinds of beautiful jewels. We should probably not read significance into each jewel specifically—they simply drive home the beauty of the city and echo Isaiah's description of future Jerusalem: "I will set your stones in antimony, and lay your foundations with sapphires. I will make your pinnacles of agate, your gates of carbuncles, and all your wall of precious stones" (Isa. 54:11–12). The jewels also remind us of the twelve stones on the high priest's breastplate symbolizing the tribes of Israel, whom the high priest represents before the Lord (Ex. 28:17–20; cf. Ezek. 28:13). Each gate of the city is made of a single pearl, and the streets are of gold comparable to transparent glass. These symbols communicate the perfection of the new creation, the glory of God in it, and the purity of his people.

<span id="page-744-11"></span><span id="page-744-6"></span><span id="page-744-3"></span><span id="page-744-0"></span>21:22 John relays some surprising features of the new creation. It is quite striking that he sees no temple in the city. Instead, the temple is Almighty God and the Lamb. In the portrayal of the new creation in 7:15, John had said that believers "serve [God] day and night in his temple." We have no contradiction here—the whole new creation is God's temple, in which his people serve Almighty God and the Lamb as they abide together. This also speaks to the Lamb's equivalence with God, showing him to be fully God, sharing his very nature.

<span id="page-744-14"></span><span id="page-744-12"></span><span id="page-744-7"></span><span id="page-744-2"></span>21:23 In the new creation there is no need for illumination by sun or moon (cf. Isa. 24:23; *2 Esd.* 7:39, 42), for the light will stream from the glory of God (cf. 21:11; 22:5), and the lamp for the world will be the Lamb. This statement perhaps refers not to physical illumination but to the true enlightenment flowing from God and the Lamb, fulfilling the words of Isaiah: "The sun shall be no more your light by day, nor for brightness shall the moon give you light; but the Lord will be your everlasting light, and your God will be your glory. Your sun shall no more go down, nor your moon withdraw itself; for the Lord will be your everlasting light, and your days of mourning shall be ended" (Isa. 60:19–20). It is striking that John calls upon a text typically understood by many to refer to the millennium and applies it to the new heaven and new earth, suggesting the language of the OT prophets is fulfilled fundamentally in the new creation in a way that is not necessarily "literal"—he is not necessarily saying there will be no celestial lights in the new earth.

<span id="page-744-13"></span><span id="page-744-5"></span><span id="page-744-4"></span><span id="page-744-1"></span>21:24 John again appropriates Isaiah 60, seeing its fulfillment in the new creation. The nations will walk by the glory and light streaming from the Lord and the Lamb (cf. Isa. 60:3). Everyone in the heavenly city will be illumined and strengthened by the Lord. As Psalm 36:9 says, "In your light do we see light." Life can be lived only in <span id="page-745-10"></span><span id="page-745-9"></span><span id="page-745-2"></span><span id="page-745-1"></span><span id="page-745-0"></span>the light of the Lord, for he is our "light" and "salvation" (Ps. 27:1). In John's Gospel, we read that in Jesus "was life, and the life was the light of men" (John 1:4), for he is the "light of the world" (John 8:12). The kings of the nations will also bring their glory into the city (cf. Ps. 72:10). As Isaiah 60:5 says, "The wealth of the nations shall come to [Jerusalem]" (cf. Ps. 68:29), while Isaiah 60:11 declares, "People [will] bring to you the wealth of the nations." It seems John is saying that every good and beautiful thing from the old creation will be in the new creation. Nothing of beauty will be lost. Instead, it will be present in a perfected and incorruptible way.

<span id="page-745-12"></span><span id="page-745-11"></span><span id="page-745-6"></span>21:25 We have seen earlier that the wall of the new Jerusalem is impregnable, unbreachable (21:12, 17). Now we are told the gates of the wall are always open, another fulfillment of Isaiah 60: "Your gates shall be open continually; day and night they shall not be shut" (Isa. 60:11). The apocalyptic and symbolic character of Revelation is clearly evident, for there is no use having a high and thick wall if the gates are open all the time! Believers in the heavenly city are so safe that the gates of the city are never shut. There are no enemies on the outside, for they are confined to the lake of fire. The gates are not open to welcome those from hell, as some argue—we find no suggestion in the book that some in the lake of fire migrate to the heavenly city.

<span id="page-745-8"></span>John also addresses the dangers associated with darkness and night, for at night enemies creep near and attack without being observed. But there is no need to fear, for night never comes (cf. Rev. 22:5). John draws on Zechariah 14:7, which records what will happen on the day of the Lord: "There shall be a unique day, which is known to the Lord, neither day nor night, but at evening time there shall be light." John is not speaking literally about whether there is darkness in the new creation (cf. Rev. 22:5); darkness stands for evil. Thus evil is completely absent in the new creation; there is nothing that can remove the peace and security and goodness of what is to come, for the glory of God and the lamp of the Lamb provide unending light to the city.

<span id="page-745-13"></span>21:26 John reverts to the message of verse 24, saying that the glory and honor of the nations will be brought into the new Jerusalem. No one should fear that anything good or delightful will be lacking. Indeed, it will be present to an even greater degree. Again, we should not read this to say that good things are continually brought into the city, nor that those who are evil can change their status and eventually enter the city.

<span id="page-745-15"></span><span id="page-745-14"></span><span id="page-745-7"></span><span id="page-745-5"></span><span id="page-745-4"></span><span id="page-745-3"></span>21:27 Everything good, and nothing defiled or anyone who does what is detestable or false, will be in the city (cf. 22:15). There are many OT prophecies that nothing unclean will be present when God brings his kingdom. Isaiah 35 looks forward to return from exile and the coming of the kingdom, declaring that the unclean will not be on the highway to Zion (Isa. 35:8). No one uncircumcised or unclean will enter the city of God (Isa. 52:1). Joel also promises that, in the day of the Lord, Jerusalem will be holy, and strangers will not enter (Joel 3:17; cf. Ezek. 44:9).

<span id="page-746-10"></span><span id="page-746-4"></span>Zechariah envisions a day when "Every pot in Jerusalem and Judah shall be holy" (Zech. 14:21). Only those inscribed in the Lamb's book of life will be in the city (cf. Rev. 17:8; 20:12, 15; 22:19; cf. Isa. 4:3); they will enter the gates of the city because they have washed their robes in the blood of the Lamb (Rev. 7:14; 22:14).

<span id="page-746-15"></span><span id="page-746-13"></span><span id="page-746-11"></span><span id="page-746-6"></span><span id="page-746-3"></span><span id="page-746-2"></span><span id="page-746-0"></span>22:1–2 Both Zechariah (14:8) and Ezekiel (47:1) prophesy that in the last days a river will flow from Jerusalem and the temple. The image of the river is used to describe replenishment and refreshment for God's people. As Psalm 46:4 says, "There is a river whose streams make glad the city of God, the holy habitation of the Most High." We see the ultimate fulfillment of these prophecies in Revelation. This is no ordinary river—it has the "water of life" (cf. John 4:10; 7:37). It is as clean and bright as crystal, unsullied by pollutants; it flows from God's throne and the Lamb and runs down "the middle of the great street of the city," showing that life comes from God and the Lamb. John seems to say that one or more trees of life stand on each side of the river, harking back to Genesis (Gen. 2:9; 3:17, 22, 24; cf. Rev. 2:7; 22:14, 19; cf. comment on Rev. 2:7). The tree yields twelve kinds of fruit, and its leaves are "for the healing of the nations," echoing Ezekiel 47:12: "On the banks, on both sides of the river, there will grow all kinds of trees for food. Their leaves will not wither, nor their fruit fail, but they will bear fresh fruit every month, because the water for them flows from the sanctuary. Their fruit will be for food, and their leaves for healing" (cf. *2 Esd.* 7:123). This allusion to Ezekiel is especially significant because it comes from a chapter describing the new temple. We see again that the temple prophecy in Ezekiel refers to the new heavens and earth—where there is no literal temple! In the new creation is full and constant replenishment—a river to refresh and enliven, and a tree of life that never grows old or rotten, whose leaves reinvigorate the people of God.

<span id="page-746-16"></span><span id="page-746-12"></span><span id="page-746-9"></span><span id="page-746-7"></span><span id="page-746-5"></span><span id="page-746-1"></span>22:3 After Adam and Eve sinned, the ground was cursed and they were expelled from the garden and banned from the tree of life (Gen. 3:17, 22–24). We saw in the previous verse that the tree of life is given to the saints, and now John affirms that there is nothing cursed in the heavenly city, for all its members have been redeemed by the blood of the Lamb (Rev. 1:5; 7:14). The freedom from curse accords with Zechariah's vision of Jerusalem: "There shall never again be a decree of utter destruction. Jerusalem shall dwell in security" (Zech. 14:11). Remarkably, God's throne is shared by the Lamb (cf. Jer. 3:17)—he shares God's identity. Their throne is in the new city, and thus God reigns in the new Jerusalem, the heavenly city, forever and ever. This fits with the end of Ezekiel's vision of the temple in Jerusalem, which says the name of the city shall forever be, "The Lord Is There" (Ezek. 48:35). The presence of God is what sets the city apart (Rev. 7:15; 21:3, 23). When the saints see God as he is, they will worship him as Lord (cf. 7:15; 19:5); they will bow before their king and glorify him with gladness and inexpressible joy.

<span id="page-746-17"></span><span id="page-746-14"></span><span id="page-746-8"></span>22:4 What makes the new creation new is the presence of God, and his servants will enjoy the greatest blessing imaginable: "They will see his face." This is commonly <span id="page-747-8"></span><span id="page-747-6"></span><span id="page-747-2"></span><span id="page-747-0"></span>called the "beatific vision." It is impossible to describe what this will be like, since none of us has yet experienced it. As Psalm 17:15 says, "I shall behold your face in righteousness; when I awake, I shall be satisfied with your likeness." The greatest agony in life is to be separated from God (Ps. 42:3), but those who are "pure in heart . . . shall see God" (Matt. 5:8; cf. 1 Cor. 13:12; 1 John 3:2). God's name will be imprinted on the forehead of those who are his (cf. Rev. 3:12; 7:3; 14:1), just as the mark of the beast is on the forehead and hands of those who give themselves to evil (13:17; 14:9, 11; 16:2; 19:20; 20:4). John is not thinking literally, as if there were an actual mark on the forehead of God's servants. The point is that God's servants are identifiably his; they are God's and will enjoy him forever.

<span id="page-747-10"></span><span id="page-747-9"></span><span id="page-747-3"></span>22:5 John circles back to the theme of light, since there will be no night in the city (cf. 21:25; Isa. 60:19)—there will be no smidgen of evil in any corner. There is no need for lamp or sun, for the Lord God will be the light for his people (cf. Rev. 21:23). And God's people will fulfill what was intended in the beginning; they will reign forever, fulfilling the mandate originally given to Adam (cf. also Dan. 7:18, 27; Luke 22:30; 1 Cor. 6:2; 2 Tim. 2:12). They will be kings and priests over the new creation (Rev. 1:6; 5:10; cf. 20:4; Rom. 5:17).

#### <span id="page-747-7"></span><span id="page-747-5"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-747-11"></span><span id="page-747-4"></span><span id="page-747-1"></span>The coming new world transcends our understanding and experience; John tries to describe the indescribable. The most important feature of the new world is not what we will do but whom we will see. The greatest joy in the new creation will be fellowship with God and the Lamb. John does not concentrate on our seeing and enjoying one another (though doubtless that will happen); he fixes our attention on the beauty of the city, and the city is lovely because the Lord is there (Ezek. 48:35). If our hearts do not thrill at the prospect of seeing God and the Lamb, we need to know God better, follow him more nearly, and love him more dearly. The psalmist knew the emptiness and ache and loneliness of the human heart that can be filled only with God (cf. Psalms 42–43; 62–63; 84). He is our true satisfaction and joy.

<span id="page-748-1"></span>**<sup>6</sup>**And he said to me, "These words are trustworthy and true. And the Lord, the God of the spirits of the prophets, has sent his angel to show his servants what must soon take place."

**<sup>7</sup>** "And behold, I am coming soon. Blessed is the one who keeps the words of the prophecy of this book."

**<sup>8</sup>** I, John, am the one who heard and saw these things. And when I heard and saw them, I fell down to worship at the feet of the angel who showed them to me, **9**but he said to me, "You must not do that! I am a fellow servant with you and your brothers the prophets, and with those who keep the words of this book. Worship God."

**<sup>10</sup>**And he said to me, "Do not seal up the words of the prophecy of this book, for the time is near. **11**Let the evildoer still do evil, and the filthy still be filthy, and the righteous still do right, and the holy still be holy."

**<sup>12</sup>** "Behold, I am coming soon, bringing my recompense with me, to repay each one for what he has done. **<sup>13</sup>** I am the Alpha and the Omega, the first and the last, the beginning and the end."

**<sup>14</sup>**Blessed are those who wash their robes,*<sup>1</sup>* so that they may have the right to the tree of life and that they may enter the city by the gates. **15**Outside are the dogs and sorcerers and the sexually immoral and murderers and idolaters, and everyone who loves and practices falsehood.

**<sup>16</sup>** "I, Jesus, have sent my angel to testify to you about these things for the churches. I am the root and the descendant of David, the bright morning star."

**<sup>17</sup>**The Spirit and the Bride say, "Come." And let the one who hears say, "Come." And let the one who is thirsty come; let the one who desires take the water of life without price.

**<sup>18</sup>** I warn everyone who hears the words of the prophecy of this book: if anyone adds to them, God will add to him the plagues described in this book, **<sup>19</sup>** and if anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God will take away his share in the tree of life and in the holy city, which are described in this book.

1Some manuscripts *do his commandments* 2Some manuscripts *all the saints*

#### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-748-0"></span>The book of Revelation began with a prologue (1:1–8) and ends with an epilogue. Many of the themes introduced in the prologue are repeated in the epilogue. This section does not seem tightly organized, but in it John makes a number of <span id="page-749-12"></span><span id="page-749-11"></span><span id="page-749-10"></span><span id="page-749-9"></span><span id="page-749-8"></span><span id="page-749-7"></span>observations highlighting what has been featured in the book and bringing it to conclusion. The reliability of the angel's revelation to John is emphasized, along with the nearness of fulfillment (22:6–7; cf. 1:1, 3). A blessing is pronounced on those who keep the prophecy (22:7; cf. 1:3). John is moved to worship the angel who revealed these matters to him but is instructed to worship God only (22:8–9). The prophecy should not be sealed, since the fulfillment is soon (v. 10), and those who practice evil and good will be assessed shortly (v. 11). The nearness of Jesus' coming is emphasized again, whereupon he will repay each according to works (v. 12). Jesus declares his rule over the beginning and end of history (v. 13). A blessing is pronounced on those who have washed their garments and have access to the tree of life and the city (v. 14), whereas those who practice evil are excluded (v. 15). Jesus sends his angel to bear witness to these matters to the churches, and he identifies himself as David's heir and the morning star (v. 16). All who read and hear these words are invited to come and drink freely of the water of life (v. 17). Those who add to or subtract from the words of the prophecy will not enter the holy city or eat from the tree of lie (vv. 18–19). Jesus declares again that he is coming soon, and John prays that he will indeed come (v. 20). The book concludes with a grace benediction (v. 21).

#### <span id="page-749-18"></span><span id="page-749-17"></span><span id="page-749-16"></span><span id="page-749-15"></span><span id="page-749-14"></span><span id="page-749-13"></span>*Section Outline*

XI. Epilogue (22:6–21)

#### *Comment*

<span id="page-749-6"></span><span id="page-749-4"></span><span id="page-749-1"></span><span id="page-749-0"></span>22:6 As the book of Revelation comes to an end, the angel looks back at what John has revealed and written for the churches and declares it is trustworthy and true (cf. 21:5 and 19:9). These are the very words of God for the churches, and they must be heard, believed, and obeyed. We know they are true, for the same Lord who rules over the spirits of the prophets (cf. Num. 27:16; 1 Cor. 14:32), the God who inspired them to speak and write their words (e.g., Dan. 2:28–29, 45), has now sent his angel to show his servants what will soon come to pass. We recall the first verse of the book, also communicated to John by an angel, which announced God's revelation about and from Jesus Christ to his servants, to show them what would happen soon.

<span id="page-749-5"></span><span id="page-749-3"></span><span id="page-749-2"></span>22:7 The speaker in verse 6 may be Jesus, though it could also be an angel (cf. 22:1). The speaker in 22:7, however, is clearly Jesus, for he says he is coming soon. The nearness of Jesus' coming and the fulfillment of what has been spoken and written pervade the book (cf. 1:1, 3; 2:16; 3:11; 22:6, 12, 20). How we should understand "soon" is discussed more fully in the comment on 1:1, but the passing of two thousand years does not mean John and/or Jesus was mistaken. The nearness of Jesus' coming is a relative term, for as Peter says, "with the Lord one day is as a thousand years" (2 Pet. 3:8). Every generation must be prepared for the Lord to return.

<span id="page-750-6"></span>A blessing is then pronounced on those who keep the words of the prophecy contained in the book of Revelation.32 Again we have a striking parallel with the beginning of the book: "Blessed is the one who reads aloud the words of this prophecy, and blessed are those who hear, and who keep what is written in it, for the time is near" (Rev. 1:3). The flow of thought in 22:7 is clear. Since Jesus is coming soon, those who keep the words of the prophecy will be blessed—they will gain an eternal reward. Nothing in life is more important than receiving such a reward. Merely hearing the prophecies does not suffice; one must observe and keep what is prophesied.

<span id="page-750-13"></span><span id="page-750-9"></span><span id="page-750-8"></span>22:8–9 John attests that he is the one who has heard and seen the visions (1:1, 4, 9). After hearing and seeing such remarkable things, he is overcome and bows to worship the angel who disclosed such things to him. The angel, however, rebukes him; he is a fellow servant along with John and the prophets and all who keep the instructions recorded in this book. He commands John to worship only God. Angels are glorious, and this is the second time John is commanded not to worship an angel (19:10; cf. Acts 10:25–26). The worship of Jesus as the Lamb stands out all the more starkly when we read these words, because believers and angels worship him throughout the book. Such worship is never criticized but always commended, for Jesus is truly God.

<span id="page-750-16"></span><span id="page-750-14"></span><span id="page-750-4"></span><span id="page-750-1"></span>22:10 Since the time is near, it is imperative for John not to seal up or hide the words of the prophecy recorded in the book. We are reminded again that the book of Revelation is not merely apocalyptic but is also prophetic (cf. 1:3; 22:7, 18–19). Daniel was told to seal up his prophecy for the end of time (Dan. 12:4; cf. *1 En.* 82:1), but John must not seal up what he has written, for the end is at hand (cf. comment on Rev. 10:4).

<span id="page-750-15"></span><span id="page-750-11"></span><span id="page-750-10"></span>22:11 The words of this verse are certainly among the most unexpected in the book, for here the unrighteous and the "filthy" are told to continue in their unrighteousness and filthiness, while the righteous and holy are to continue to be righteous and holy. Certainly this does not mean people should not repent of evil, for John clearly thinks people should do so (9:20–21; 16:9, 11). The shock of the statement is meant to prompt repentance, as in Amos's command to "Come to Bethel, and transgress" (Amos 4:4). Furthermore, those who are evil are invited to come and drink freely of the water of life (Rev. 21:6; 22:17).

<span id="page-750-12"></span><span id="page-750-5"></span><span id="page-750-3"></span><span id="page-750-2"></span><span id="page-750-0"></span>The command of verse 11 is not some fatalistic word, as if the evil *should* in fact pursue their wicked ways. Daniel 12:10 helps us understand what John means, which is not surprising, for John alluded to Daniel 12 in the previous verse. In referring to the time of the end Daniel 12:10 says, "Many shall purify themselves and make themselves white and be refined, but the wicked shall act wickedly. And none of the wicked shall understand, but those who are wise shall understand." Here we have a clue as to John's intention. The point is that Daniel's prophecy is

<span id="page-750-7"></span><sup>32</sup> For the importance of blessings in Revelation, cf. comment on 1:3.

<span id="page-751-5"></span><span id="page-751-2"></span>being fulfilled; many of the wicked will never understand but will continue in their wickedness (cf. Isa. 6:9–10). Their incomprehension seems baffling to the righteous; it can even sow doubts in the hearts of the saints as to whether *they* are right in following the Lord. The problem, though, is not with any lack of clarity of truth but with wicked hearts. As Ezekiel 3:27 says, "He who will hear, let him hear; and he who will refuse to hear, let him refuse, for they are a rebellious house." The parallel to Revelation is again striking, and Ezekiel clarifies that the wicked do not comprehend the truth because of their rebellion. The righteous should understand, then, that the evil have no desire to be cleansed of their filth or to depart from their unrighteousness. Hence the godly should not be deterred by the recalcitrance of the wicked but should continue to pursue righteousness and holiness. Paul expresses the same thought when he writes, "Evil people and impostors will go on from bad to worse, deceiving and being deceived" (2 Tim. 3:13). The righteous should heed the mandate of Isaiah 56:1: "Keep justice, and do righteousness, for soon my salvation will come, and my righteousness be revealed."

<span id="page-751-8"></span><span id="page-751-6"></span>22:12 The importance of our actions in this life is again underscored and sharpened, for the end is near. The "I" who declares he is coming soon is almost certainly Jesus. The nearness of Jesus' coming is emphasized a number of times in the book (cf. 1:1, 3; 3:11; 22:7, 20). Christians of every generation have rightly believed that Jesus might come during their lifetime, and hence the prophecy functions as promise and warning. The announcement provokes believers to be prepared for Christ's return. When he returns, he will reward or repay all in accordance with what they have done. This theme was already emphasized in 20:12–13 (cf. 2:23), and, as we saw there, it accords with many biblical texts (e.g., Pss. 28:4; 62:12; Prov. 24:12; Isa. 40:10; 62:11; Matt. 16:27; Rom. 2:6; etc.). John heralds the freeness of the water of life (Rev. 21:6; 22:17) while insisting that those who drink from it must live in a way that pleases God.

<span id="page-751-13"></span><span id="page-751-12"></span><span id="page-751-11"></span><span id="page-751-10"></span><span id="page-751-9"></span><span id="page-751-7"></span><span id="page-751-4"></span><span id="page-751-3"></span><span id="page-751-1"></span><span id="page-751-0"></span>22:13 Jesus, who is still presumably the speaker (cf. v. 12), now declares that he is the "Alpha and the Omega, the first and the last, the beginning and the end." Elsewhere *God* is the Alpha and the Omega (1:8; 21:6), but here Jesus is declared as such. Isaiah especially proclaims that God is the first and the last, that Yahweh is the true God, the only God (Isa. 41:4; 44:6–8; 48:12), who gives his glory to no other (Isa. 48:11). Yet Jesus is also identified as the first and the last (Rev. 1:17; 2:8), the beginning and the end (cf. Isa. 46:10). Clearly he has the same stature as God himself. Interestingly, this verse is nestled between two verses promising a future reward for believers. What is the logical relationship between these statements? Jesus is declaring that he has the stature and the power to reward and punish. The promise of a reward is not an idle promise, for the one who rules over all of history from beginning to end makes the promise. He will most certainly make good on his word.

<span id="page-751-14"></span>22:14 The last of the seven blessings is enunciated here (cf. comment on 1:3). Those who wash their robes, who are clean from evil, have the right to eat from <span id="page-752-10"></span><span id="page-752-5"></span><span id="page-752-1"></span><span id="page-752-0"></span>the tree of life and enter the gates of the city (Ps. 118:19–20). The tree of life and entering the city are two different images for the life of the age to come. The tree of life was withheld from Adam and Eve because of their sin (Gen. 2:9; 3:17, 22, 24), but now it is given to those who enjoy life in the garden to come, the paradise of God (Rev. 2:7). Garden images are juxtaposed with the bustling life of the city, which seems strange to us, but both pictures communicate the wonder of new life in store for those who have clean robes. The robes of believers are clean because they have washed them in the Lamb's blood (7:14). No one is able to remove his defilement by his own efforts. At the same time, clean robes stand for those who, having once been cleansed by the Lamb, have walked in white and have conquered (3:4–5). Those who are truly clean must live lives of virtue.

<span id="page-752-17"></span><span id="page-752-16"></span><span id="page-752-15"></span><span id="page-752-14"></span><span id="page-752-12"></span><span id="page-752-8"></span><span id="page-752-7"></span><span id="page-752-4"></span><span id="page-752-3"></span><span id="page-752-2"></span>22:15 Not everyone eats of the tree of life, for some are outside the city. We have seen this pattern before in Revelation. Some drink from the water of life and become heirs (21:6–7), while others pursue evil and are punished in the lake of fire (21:8). John gives us a sample of those who are outside the city. He mentions dogs first, unclean animals (cf. Ex. 22:31; Isa. 66:3) who went about in packs to ravage and scavenge (1 Kings 14:11; 16:4; 21:19; Ps. 59:6, 14; Prov. 26:11). By NT times, "dogs" was used to designate Gentiles (Matt. 7:6; 15:26, 27; Mark 7:27, 28; cf. Phil. 3:2), those outside the people of God. The appellation "dogs," therefore, refers to those who have unwashed robes (Rev. 22:14), who are unclean in God's sight. John also mentions sorcerers (cf. comment on 21:8), who try to manipulate circumstances with magic instead of trusting God, and the sexually immoral and murderers, who violate God's commands (Ex. 20:13–14). Those who give themselves to sexual sin do not entrust their bodies to God but seek out pleasure in accord with their own desires. Those who murder deface another person made in God's image and take justice into their own hands. Idolaters are also excluded, for they certainly cannot inhabit a city characterized by the presence of a God they despise and refuse to serve. Lastly, those who love and practice lying are outside the city. This may be an indictment of those who claim to be Christians but deny their profession by their lives. The expression strikes even to the desires of the heart; indeed, the practice of lying has its roots in loving what is not true, and those who love and practice falsehood cannot be in the heavenly city. The city is a place where the clarity of truth shines and no lie is tolerated. The truth centers on God and the Lamb, and those who love lying hate both.

<span id="page-752-18"></span><span id="page-752-13"></span><span id="page-752-11"></span><span id="page-752-9"></span><span id="page-752-6"></span>22:16 As the book rushes to a close, the importance of what is written is stressed. Jesus himself addresses the audience, underscoring that he sent an angel (cf. 1:1, 4) to testify about these matters to the churches. These are urgent words of the risen Christ for all the churches. What is emphasized is the message of the Messiah: he is the root and heir of David (cf. Isa. 11:1, 10; 53:2). Jesus' messianic stature is quite important to John, playing a major role in the decisive chapter on Christ's redemptive work (Revelation 5; cf. esp. 5:5). Jesus is also the bright morning star (cf. 2:28), an allusion to Numbers 24:17, which prophesies, "A star shall come out of Jacob, and a scepter shall rise out of Israel." This scepter and star will pulverize God's enemies, a major theme of Revelation. The destruction of God's enemies also means vindication for his people. It is difficult to know what the morning star refers to here. Perhaps it means Jesus reigns even now, even though his reign is not consummated. The star has risen, but we have not yet seen it shine in all its brightness.

<span id="page-753-7"></span>22:17 The key word of the verse is "come." It is difficult to know if the audience is invited to come to Jesus for salvation or if Jesus is invited to come again. Certainty is impossible. Many interpreters claim the first two invitations are addressed to Jesus and the third to believers. This is possible, but I lean toward all three being addressed to humans. It is a bit jarring if the subject of the coming shifts from Christ to human beings. The Holy Spirit, through the words of the book of Revelation and the bride of Christ (his church), invites people to come to Jesus to satisfy the thirst of their souls. In addition, those who hear the words of Revelation invite others to come. The urgency of the invitation is communicated by its threefold repetition. John pleads with his audience to come to Jesus before it is too late. Who is invited to come? Those who are thirsty, who long to be filled, who feel their need for Jesus (cf. 21:6). As Isaiah 55:1 says, "Come, everyone who thirsts, come to the waters." Isaiah goes on to say they can buy and eat "without money and without price" (Isa. 55:1). So too here, the one who desires to come can "take the water of life without price." To respond to the call to come is to give one's life to Jesus, to crown him as one's Lord. To those who do so, life is offered freely and openly. Nothing hinders anyone but his own desires, and he who comes will find his deepest longings satisfied, the thirst and ache in his heart filled by Jesus.

<span id="page-753-8"></span><span id="page-753-6"></span><span id="page-753-4"></span><span id="page-753-3"></span><span id="page-753-1"></span><span id="page-753-0"></span>22:18 As the book concludes, Jesus sternly warns against adding to or subtracting from what is written in the book of Revelation. Those who hear the prophetic words must not add to them. We see Revelation again described as prophecy (cf. 1:3; 10:11; 19:10; 22:6, 7, 9, 10), and it must not be tampered with. Adding to the book changes the content of the prophecy and alters its message. To do so is to distort the word of God. As Deuteronomy 4:2 says, "You shall not add to the word that I command you," and Deuteronomy 12:32 adds, "Everything that I command you, you shall be careful to do. You shall not add to it or take from it." How serious is it to add to the words of the prophecy in Revelation? It is of eternal significance, for on those who do so God will set the plagues described in this book (cf. 9:18, 20; 11:6; 15:1, 6, 8; 16:9, 21; 18:4, 8; 21:9; cf. Deut. 29:19). Clearly this is no trivial matter, for those who transgress will suffer eternal punishment.

<span id="page-753-9"></span><span id="page-753-5"></span><span id="page-753-2"></span>22:19 To add to the prophetic words recorded in this book is not the only potential danger; there is also the danger of subtracting, of removing the words deposited and thus eliminating crucial elements of the message. Certain texts and themes may be cut away because they are distasteful or unattractive to readers. Still, readers have no right to alter the words of God, and those who subtract from the message <span id="page-754-3"></span><span id="page-754-2"></span>will be removed from the tree of life and the holy city (cf. comment on 2:7; cf. 3:12; 21:2, 10, 14, 15, 16, 18, 19, 21, 22, 23; 22:2, 14). The admonition does not relate to textual criticism or legitimate questions of the wording of the biblical text. Nor does it prohibit exposition of Scripture, unfolding its meaning for readers and hearers. By extension, what is said here rightly applies to all of Scripture. Those who deliberately add to or subtract from God's Word so as to distort its message are threatened with eternal punishment.

<span id="page-754-4"></span><span id="page-754-1"></span>22:20 The last words of Jesus in the book are recorded here. He is identified as the one who has witnessed to and verified the message communicated in the book. Jesus reminds his hearers of the eschatological urgency of the times. He affirms he is coming soon—the end is near. The message at the beginning of the book is reaffirmed at the end (cf. comments on 1:1; 1:3). History is short, and Jesus is at the door. John now speaks, affirming with his own voice ("Amen") the near coming of Jesus and adding his own prayer, the prayer of every true believer: "Come, Lord Jesus." If this is not the cry of our own hearts, we have not truly understood this book or the message of the NT.

<span id="page-754-5"></span><span id="page-754-0"></span>22:21 The book of Revelation and the NT appropriately end with a grace wish. More specifically, grace from the Lord Jesus; it is not an abstract power or entity but flows from a person. Grace benedictions are pervasive in the NT books (e.g., Rom. 16:20; 1 Cor. 16:23; 2 Cor. 13:14; Gal. 6:18; Eph. 6:24; Heb. 13:25), and it is fitting that the NT itself ends with a word of grace.

#### *Response*

We sometimes feel as if life as we know it will last forever, but we are reminded of the truth when we visit the emergency room or attend the funeral of a loved one or close friend. We are reminded by John in these last verses that the end is at hand—Jesus is coming soon. Our final destiny awaits us, whether the lake of fire or the tree of life, the second death or the heavenly city. As long as life lasts, we are invited to come, to drink freely from the water of life. All of us are thirsty; all of us are weak and empty and deficient. Jesus invites us to come to him, to humble ourselves and drink to our everlasting satisfaction. Come, Lord Jesus!
